column2: TOKYO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Twelve Japanese demonstrated today outside the United States Embassy as funeral services were conducted for a fisherman regarded by his countrymen as the hydrogen bomb's first victim.
Two more steamship operators, the Cunard Steam-Ship Company and the Home Lines, last week scheduled liners for long Mediterranean cruises next year.
The tragic plight of refugees and the responsibility of the United Nations for the solution of their problems will be a subject of debate in the ninth session of the U. N. General Assembly.

THERE is always a right place for flowering shrubs. They can be selected to provide spring-to-fall bloom in the garden, plus branches for indoor forcing and arrangements. They give foliage effects in summer and autumn, and some feature colorful berries and bright bark in the winter.

A plan for an office building about fifty stories high in place of the present Grand Central Terminal Building, has been studied by the board of directors of the New York Central Railroad, it was announced yesterday.
Averell Harriman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, pledged yesterday that his supporters would extend civil rights to end discrimination in housing and employment.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 25 -- Penn State, sharp defensively and with a tornado-like attack led by Don Bailey, quarterback, and Lenny Moore, halfback, subdued highly favored Illinois and its sputtering runners to score a 14-to-12 triumph today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- The Giants, engaging in their next-to-last game before plunging into the world series, got a good workout for next week's classic as Curt Simmons, the Phillies' brilliant southpaw, carried them through eleven innings tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- There is evidence in official records that many members of Congress are campaigning for re-election with claims of having introduced legislation that they knew did not have a real chance of even initial consideration.

LEWIS MUMFORD makes his plea for sanity in our culture and civilization in a frankly alarmist mood. He notes some obviously decadent elements in our culture and dwells upon the familiar perils of atomic war in the future of our civilization.

The Soviet chess players, winners of the Hamilton-Russell trophy for the second time, completed their schedule by defeating the Netherlands, 3 1/2 -- 1/2, in the eleventh and final round yesterday, according to a report from Amsterdam.

SUBURBANITES will find a new kind of suit this fall -- one that has been designed with the home-owner in mind. It is the suburban suit -- a relaxed, informal suit for week-end and general at- home wear.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- West Bromwich Albion advanced to the top of the English League soccer standing today with a 6-4 victory over Leicester City.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Army's favored football squad was beaten by South Carolina, 34 -- 20, today as the teams opened their campaigns before 12,000 at Michie Stadium. The Gamecocks outclassed the cadets with a second-half display of precision ground maneuvers.

CHINHAE, Korea, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The United States Air Force is running a prison camp school to teach United States pilots how to resist Communist "brainwashing" techniques if they ever are captured by the Reds, it was disclosed today.

THIS is a book as recondite as it is small. It is all about time and the end of it; all about eternity, and its relation to the end of time. Eternity is conceived of as something following and completing time and the relationship between them such that we cannot think of our place in time and of our use of it, apart from the end of time, which is eternity.

MEN'S clothing, more orderly and responsible than ever before, calls for more important looking shirts -- which usually means a French-cuffed shirt. French cuffs require cuff links and, as every man knows, links dress up shirts.

ATLANTA, Sept. 25 -- Home buying and contracts for new residential and heavy engineering projects continue to be a major factor of business strength in the Southeast. Contract awards in the region for residential buildings reached an estimated $81,000,000 in August, 35 per cent above the level of the corresponding month last year.

SEATTLE, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The English Electric Export and Trading Company of London filed a formal protest today with the Seattle Board of Public Works over the second rejection of bids on a 100,000 kilovolt power generator.
DENVER, Sept. 25 -- President Eisenhower named George C. McConnaughey of Columbus, Ohio, as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission today.
The New York Veterans Administration Hospital, built at a cost of $26,500,000, will be dedicated today at a ceremony in front of the institution at First Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

FRANCES KEENE, who reviewed Arie van der Lugt's novel "The Crazy Doctor" (which I translated), makes some gratuitous remarks about modern Dutch literature which I would like to challenge. She finds that the most recent book of any significance translated from the Dutch was Couperus' "Book of the Small Souls," back in 1932.

SINCE the American Hotel Credit Corporation was established a year ago by the American Hotel Association, the subsidiary corporation has issued more than 41,000 universal-type credit cards good at any hotel that is a member of the association.

During this past week Indonesia's Prime Minister has been visiting in India. His principal purpose has been to lay the foundation for a conference of Indian and African states in Jakarta some time next year. Some of that foundation, however, if one is to judge by the Premier's remarks to a cheering Indian Parliament, is to be opposition to the Southeast Asian defense treaty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Marty Furgol shot into a two-stroke lead at the three-quarter mark of the $40,000 "world series of golf" today with a third straight subpar round that gave him a 54-hole total of 204 -- nine under par.
AURORA, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- The appointment of James E. Nagle as director of development at Wells College was announced this week by Dr. Louis J. Long, president of Wells.

FROM the viewpoint of newspaper reporters, city editors fall into two categories. A city editor is a blithering incompetent, than whom the commenting reporter could do much better. Or he's a baroque genius, whose talents for divining news and coordinating its coverage remain a matter of perpetual awe even to the men immediately under him.
The fifteenth annual celebration of National Newspaper Week will begin Friday with a ceremony in honor of John Peter Zenger in the rotunda of Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Syracuse University's ground-gaining football squad bounced back from a barren first half tonight to triumph over Villanova, 28 -- 6.

It is easy to understand the impulses that led the Senate majority leadership to postpone consideration of the Watkins committee report on Senator McCarthy until after Election Day. It is also easy to understand why the minority leadership, which couldn't do anything about the matter, anyhow, tacitly acquiesced in the decision announced by Senator Knowland.

EVER since the Round Table was first mentioned in 1155 by the Anglo-Norman chronicler Wace, or perhaps since Nennius in 796 referred to Arthur as a "Christian warrior leading the Kings of Britain against the Saxon Kings of Kent," the story of the doughty monarch who wielded Excalibur has been public domain.

FROM Buenos Aires comes word that plans are maturing for a 1958 series for the centenary of the first postal paper associated with Argentina. The 1858-60 group was issued for use in Corrientes by Juan Gregorio Pujol (1817-1861), then Governor, and the 1958 stamps will carry his portrait. It was not until 1862 that Argentina as a republic released its first issue after Corrientes joined other provinces in the River de la Plata region.
AMARILLO, Tex., Sept. 25 -- Texas Republicans are "ready to lay back our ears, get in the fight and win some Congressional seats."
TOKYO, Sept. 10 -- A new suitor has appeared in the wooing of Japan by the Communist Asian states -- this one North Korea.

HAWTHORNE, N. J., Sept. 25 -- While hundreds of friends and well-wishers looked on. Clarence (Red) Mosley, one of the Korean war's five quadruple-amputee veterans, today married Miss Ruth Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Shaw of 233 Paxton Street, Paterson.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- The American Federation of Labor, in a major policy shift, called on the United States today to stop lavishing economic and military handouts on other nations.

The vivid shirts above highlight a changing pattern in men's wear. Only a few years ago men who wore pink shirts to the office received slightly jaundiced looks from confirmed white shirt wearers. Today the pink shirt is a commonplace; so are the soft blues, yellows and greens.

What one considers to be the "most perfect line of poetry" in the English language depends largely, of course, upon how much and whose poetry one has read or -- in, unfortunately, rather rare instances these days -- is reading.

Demand for ferroalloys has been livelier in the last two weeks than any other time in more than a year -- welcome news for steelmakers keeping an anxious watch for any signal that a real upturn in the steel business is on the way.

THE fall courses at the Photography Department of the Evening Division, New York City Community College of Applied Arts and Sciences, started last week at 300 Pearl Street, Brooklyn, with an expanded curriculum and a certificate program.

THE first morning after father brought the new cow pony home Billy woke with a feeling that something either wonderful or pretty terrible had happened. Chica was a shock at first, with her bony legs, flappy ears and disapproving eye, but she was a pleasure to ride.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The United States made public today notes between it and the Soviet Union on President Eisenhower's proposal for a pooling of atomic energy resources.

FORCED bulbs provide colorful and often fragrant flowers for the indoor window garden at a time when other house plants may have few blossoms. This is especially true during winter and early spring when the short days with meager sunshine are not conducive to flower production.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 25 -- The tri-state area of Tennessee, Mississippi and Arkansas was stirred this week by heated public controversy resulting from conflicts between private and public power interests.

In selecting candidates and adopting platforms during the past week, the DemocraticLiberal coalition and the Republican party in New York have presented a marked contrast in the relative importance they assign to national and state issues in this year's election.
Heavy supplies of potatoes and lower prices are in prospect the rest of the year. However, for the first six months of 1955, the outlook is for light stocks and higher prices.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP)--The 4-year-old son of a prominent Springfield business man and a baby sitter were murdered tonight in the child's home while the infant's parents were away.

I HAVE just read your Sunday article in which you appear to give unqualified praise and endorsement to film groups especially Cinema 16. As a for more member of this organization I feel that I must raise a voice of protest to this endorsement.
As Jews over the world prepared to usher in Rosh-ha-Shanah, which marks the Jewish New Year of 5715, messages from religious and secular organizations called for a rededication to spiritual values.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 25 -- A Federal grand jury has rejected as "irresponsible" allegations of fraud in the 1952 New Mexico general election in which Dennis Chavez, Demo crat, was re-elected to the Senate over Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 25 (UP) -- Quarterback Bill Bonney intercepted a pass in his end zone in the final minute today to give Virginia a 27-to-21 opening-day victory over Lehigh.

The Riverdale Children's Association will be the beneficiary of the Oct. 27 performance of "All Summer Long." Robert Anderson's play, featuring John Kerr, Ed Begley and June Walker, opened on Thursday at the Coronet.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 -- The campaign for a "right-to-work" law being waged in Missouri "is clearly opposed to Catholic principles concerning the rights of labor and management," it was declared this week by The St. Louis Register, official Roman Catholic newspaper of the Archdiocese of St. Louis.

TO explore, to interpret, to define the struggles of youth's raw, aching emotions has proved a pitfall for more than one writer. But Mary Stolz, who has written several novels about adolescents for adolescents, understands her young people thoroughly, and in this portrait of 17-year-old Harry Lynch has written a first-rate novel.

MATTHEW ARNOLD'S well-known phrase describing Shelley as "a beautiful and ineffectual angel, beating in the void his luminous wings in vain," was only slightly improved upon by Thomas De Quincey when he wrote that Shelley was an "angel touched by lunacy."

Norway's idle tanker tonnage has increased from 50,000 in January to more than 200,000, or 6 per cent of the nation's oil-carrying fleet, according to a report by L. Usterud-Svendsen, president of the Norwegian Shipowners Association, that was made available here last week.

WHAT," asked a royal Prince who was the guest of honor at a London dinner-party in the eighties of the last century, "does an artist make in a year?" "Possibly, sir, 35,000," answered Sir John Millais to whom the question had been addressed.
Only one who has proved himself so true a friend of India as Chester Bowles could write such a much-needed article
NEWARK, Sept. 25 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican Candidate for the Senate, today struck back at Republicans opposed to him.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 25 -- The South is taking its first steps in public school integration cautiously, slowly and with probably fewer "incidents" than most educators had been led to expect. This is the pattern evident from a survey of the seventeen segregation-practicing states and the District of Columbia.

BEETHOVEN: Violin Sonatas in C minor, Op. 30, No. 2, and G, Op. 30, No. 3; Jean Fournier and Ginette Doyen (Westminster). Musical, steady performances, but Fournier's bow arm is not a tower of strength, nor is his tone always pleasant.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The United States has made it clear that revision of existing American defense arrangements on the Continent will have to be considered should the European nations fumble or delay unduly in their efforts to ally an armed Germany with the West.

IN "Black Power," Richard Wright, the American Negro author of "Native Son" and "The Outsider," reports on a recent visit to the Gold Coast. The Gold Coast has just become the first self-governing territory in British West Africa and now stands on the threshold of independence and dominion status.
HONG KONG, Sept. 25 -- The chief political commissar of Communist China's armed forces declared today these forces would intensify their training in amphibious operations to "liberate" formosa.

From the day when the first atomic bomb was exploded in New Mexico the United States realized the heavy social responsibility that it had incurred. Singly and with the United Nations it framed plan after plan for the orderly utilization of atomic energy under international control.

BECAUSE Ruskin was a social prophet and because the family fortune came from the sherry business, a wag once said that what began in vino ended in veritas. Like much of what we hear about Victorian England, this was a pleasant half-truth.
RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Five thousand children took-part in a fishing contest here today as part of central Jersey's fourth annual Kids Day.

The Dec. 14 performance of Noel Coward's comedy "Quadrille," at the Coronet Theatre starring Alfred Lunt, Lynn Fontanne, Edna Best and Brian Aherne, has been taken over for the benefit of the Berkshire Industrial Farm.
The role of a prosecutor is "largely a disappointing and discouraging endeavor," in the opinion of Miles F. McDonald, former District Attorney of Kings County.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- The intra-party Republican dispute over the candidacy of Clifford P. Case, an avowed liberal, for United States Senator from New Jersey erupted into open warfare this week. And the rebellious group finally revealed clearly its identity and objectives.
THE odd jacket isn't what it used to be. Gone is the horse blanket look, with its bold stripes and hair-raising plaids. Today's country clothes are calm and collected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Britain made it clear today that she was looking for deeds rather than promises by the United States before making any major move toward freedom in the exchange of world currencies.

Lenore Leiser, 18 - year - old Mount St. Vincent College freshman, representing the Equitable Life Assurance Society, captured the 880-yard feature race yesterday in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union women's relay carnival at Randalls Island.

A bullish summary of business so far this month and cautious optimism on the near future featured the September report of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. It was released yesterday by the group's business survey committee.

Orchids are the flowers with that extra special something which fascinates gardeners everywhere. Whether the blossoms be the big showy cattleyas, the tiny vandas, the dovelike phalaenopsis or the colorful cymbidiums -- all have admirers.

IN her latest book Joan Henry has exchanged minds with Mary Hilton, an Englishwoman with only a fortnight of life left before she is brought to the gibbet for murder -- murder done in jealousy over a man. The exchange is most extraordinary.

DELIGHTFUL in late winter is the flowering of the "little bulbs" which need only the slightest encouragement of pale sunlight to burst into refreshing bloom. Such a delight is my own small bulb garden, an east-facing strip of rich soil (originally an old fence row) edging a bit of woodland near house windows from which the exquisite detail of the small flowers may be seen and enjoyed.

THE Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences is celebrating its 131st year as a center of culture and informal education, "the oldest organization of its kind in America." In the total of some 350 events scheduled for the coming season, the dance does not fare too badly.
The rearmament of Germany, military keystone of United States plans for the defense of Western Europe, will once again be in debate at the nine-power conference in London, which starts Tuesday.
GRETNA GREEN, Scotland, Sept. 24 -- The marriage business is still going strong here -- but it is not what it was 100 years ago.

Bicarb's nose was the one that hit the teletimer's electric-eye beams at all the clocking points in the $29,450 New York Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. He led from shortly after the start and he opened up in the stretch to win with five lengths to spare.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- Results in today's British soccer and rugby games:

Dr. Harris Peck's excellent article "Are Parents the Delinquents?" (Sept. 12) does a public service in calling attention to the magnitude of the problems of prevention and in disposing of the easy alibi: "It's all the parent's fault."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 25 -- Ralph Guglielmi scored two touchdowns and passed to a third as Notre Dame's Fighting Irish gave Terry Brennan a 21-0 victory over the stubborn Texas Longhorns in his coaching debut today. It was the first Texas shut-out since 1946.

I was very pleased to read your article on the growing popularity of film societies. I have watched with great interest the growth of film clubs in New York. So it was with some surprize that I failed to see mentioned some of the less known but certainly no less deserving film groups. I speak of three in particular:
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 25 -- Alaska's 1954 political campaign is under way and the Democrats, bolstered by a clearcut victory in the primaries, seem to be taking the offensive.

WHERE Henry Huggins is, there is Ribsy, complicating life as only a loyal, bumbling, well-intentioned mutt can. In this third volume of escapades Henry faces one of the stiffest challenges of his life keeping Ribsy out of trouble for a month.

Observers smiled when officials of the Association of American Railroads cried "wolf" last January regarding the carriers' business prospects for 1954. Now it's late September, and there are no more skeptics. The wolf arrived right on schedule, twice as big and fierce as foreseen.
Pessimists who predicted that the Cross County Center in Westchester would be a "firecracker that would never explode" are being proved wrong.

THIS little Austrian town is famous for its music festival, and the visitor who arrives during the season will find the signs of it on every hand. If he stays long enough, however, he may discover other things less publicized, but well worth knowing.
SEATTLE, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Lou Baldacci drove over the goal line twice today to lead the Michigan Wolverines to a 14-0 victory over a surprisingly stubborn Washington football team.

Teamster and trucking officials agreed yesterday that some progress had been made in their efforts to negotiate a new contract, but they acknowledged that they had a long pull ahead in this week's bargaining talks.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 25 -- Bill Beagle, the Dartmouth quarterback and the Ivy League's top-ranking passer last year, lofted a touchdown aerial on the game's final play today and Leo McKenna kicked the extra point that beat Holy Cross, 27 -- 26, before 9,000 fans at Memorial Field.
An addition that doubles the amount of selling space of the White Plains branch of Macy's New York will begin operations tomorrow.

IT is a dated notion that dinner jackets aren't comfortable. They now have the natural, easy lines of business suits. Tropical worsteds, man-made fibers blended with wool, and winter-weight silks have pushed heavier fabrics out of the evening picture. Black is the big color news.

THE new low-cut shoes -- a step forward in making men lighter on their feet -- are actually an inch lower and weigh a pound less than the regular shoes in the same size. They have two to four eyelets as compared with ten to twelve. Yet they wear as well as the heavier shoes.

" WHEN Paris sneezes, Europe catches cold." So it was said a century ago. A generation later, every word uttered by Bismarck was pondered all over the world, and only the very young can forget the days when the outbursts of the Fuehrer sent shudders down the backs of all citizens of the world who treasured peace and freedom.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 25 -- The premiers of India and Indonesia concluded their talks today and issued a joint statement expressing the desirability of convoking a conference of Asian and African nations at an early date.
DETROIT, Sept. 25 (AP) -- New-car inventories continue to decline and used-car stocks are less of a problem than they were a few months ago.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Al Lary, a rookie pitcher, and Jim Davis combined to stop Cincinnati today, the Chicago Cubs winning, 4 -- 2, before a Ladies' Day crowd of 7,385.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Tony De Marco of Boston vaulted into contention for the welterweight title by stopping Chris Christensen of Denmark at 2:10 of the sixth round of a scheduled ten-rounder tonight at the Arena. De Marco weighed 145 pounds, Christensen 146.

THIS discerning and candid book by William E. Hocking, a Harvard Professor of Philosophy emeritus and former lecturer in Bavaria under the American Military Government, deals with "the world's first scientifically directed surgical operation on a body politic, our Nazi-ectomy."

Although I have during the past quarter of a century heard most of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's programs either from a seat at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoons or in my living room by radio, I rather hesitate to cite one or two works given at these concerts as towering above the others.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Lew Burdette fashioned a four-hitter today to give the Milwaukee Braves a 3-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals before 34,445 fans.
The marine section of the National Safety Council will meet in Chicago Oct. 19-21 as part of the forty-second national Annual Safety Congress and Exposition.

FREDERICK KNOTT, creator of "Dial M for Murder," is back at playwriting. Mr. Knott who, since his arival here from England, has taken himself a wife and settled down on these shores -- and, as a true member of the writing fraternity, has seized upon the required adjustments as excuses to remain away from his typewriter -- is engaged on a new mystery play.

BATON ROUGE, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Alabama took the wraps off Bart Starr, quarterback, and sent its speedy halfback, Cecil Ingram, galloping to smother Louisiana State University, 12 to 0, before 40,000 fans tonight.

WHAT is considered the foremost philatelic event in the history of American Catholicism -- a six-week exhibition of stamps having vignettes associated with religion, held at the National Philatelic Museum in Philadelphia -- was dedicated by Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York and Archbishop John F. O'Hara of Philadelphia at a testimonial dinner in the Cardinal's honor at the Hotel Bellevue-Stratford in Philadelphia last Wednesday night.

FALL brings crisp, clear, bug-free days -- the perfect picnic weather. This is the season when the gardener can collect extra dividends on his summer labors. No tiring drives through traffic jams to crowded parks for him.

A REMARKABLE lot of encouragement for gentlemen of so-called middle years who may be waxing slightly wistful about the possible fading of their charms is assured by two bright pictures which opened here last week.

American teachers who wish to work in educationally neglected parts of the world will be able to get special training for that service this fall at New York University's School of Education. A new two-course program, "Teaching at Home and Abroad in Fundamental Education," is to be presented by the school during the fall and spring terms.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's motto is "Ars Gratia Arts," which my limited knowledge of Latin would translate into "Art for Art's Sake," or something to that effect. In "Brigadoon" I believe M-G-M makes every attempt to follow their motto.

I HAVE read with interes Paul J. C. Friedlander's objective criticism "Delays a the Dock" in The New York Times. I found it to be informative and refreshing, although I question the value of denying the assertion that European ports handle passengers better than does New York.

WHAT are the most perfect lines in poetry? This challenge, posed in a letter to the London Sunday Times, inevitably provoked a rich response from Britain's inveterate letters-to-the-editor writers. When the correspondence was closed the other day, the paper reported that 126 poets were represented, of whom 12 per cent were modern. Shakespeare's score was double that of both Keats and Tennyson, who tied for second place. Milton, Wordsworth, Shelley.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- The captured Nazi submarine U-505 was dedicated today as a memorial to 55,000 Americans who lost their lives at sea in two world wars.

Roosevelt University in Chicago has announced a new program to train college-educated housewives for elementary school teaching. Aimed at easing Chicago's critical shortage of elementary teachers, the accelerated program will train selected students for certification after one academic year's work plus a summer session.

Leon H. Keyserling, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Adivsers under President Harry S. Truman, said yesterday that "the penny-squeezing and stupid economic policies" of the Republican Administration had plunged the nation's annual output $30,000,000,000 under the full-economy level.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Nearly 1,300 prisoners of the Bridewell, Chicago's city prison, rioted for more than three hours late today, smashing windows, starting a fire, and causing damage estimated at thousands of dollars.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 25 -- A one-room schoolhouse here will soon become a museum. The Paramus Historical and Preservation Society is preparing to move its vast collection of records, costumes, farm implements and other memorabilia of early rural life in this area into the building.

National Governments and voluntary groups throughout the world are showing increasing concern for the welfare of their disabled. They are calling more and more on the United Nations and its specialized agencies for aid in establishing rehabilitation services.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles declared tonight that the United States could find safety neither in isolation nor in "arrangements and programs that have no reasonable prospect of providing genuine security."

DESPITE its subtitle, this book is not really about birds. It isn't essentially a travel book, either, though it is built around a journey to the llanos of Venezuela -- the great drainage basin of the Orinoco River -- in search of the nesting grounds of the ibis. Paul A. Zahl, author of "Flamingo Hunt," eventually found the elusive ibis and he gives a vivid description of its home life.

NIGHT wear used to be the big yawn -- it all looked alike -- you bought it to sleep in, and it was gone with the dawn. Now to fit in with our "late late" night life, centered around radio and TV screens, makers are putting out some real teasers, that lead a double life.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24 -- Yugoslavia is experiencing a severe period of economic difficulties. Prices are rising generally, wheat shortages have affected the quality of bread, and there are fuel and electric power shortages.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The search for a way to link Western Germany to the defense of the free world has brought the Brussels Pact organization back from almost four years of obscurity to the front of the international stage.

ADMIRERS of Margaret Irwin's brightly tapestried historical novels will find happy recognition in the eleven stories here collected. For this English-bred, Oxford-educated author handles the language as stylishly as anybody writing today.

PRACTICALLY every category in which Bach composed is represented in releases that have been issued in the last few months. Most of the recordings are of good quality, but they have to face the sort of handicap that is becoming the common lot of most new recordings -- namely, stiff competition from versions that have preceded them.

CLEVELAND, Sept 25 -- With no orders for new freighters on their books and fewer vessels scheduled to undergo repairs, Great Lakes shipyards are negotiating for Government contracts in an effort to avoid layoffs during the winter months.

THE other day we read that Samuel Goldwyn had established an annual $1,000 award for the best creative writing to come out of U. C. L. A. The chancellor stated that he knew of no one in the industry, either here or abroad, that has contributed more to the stature of the writer in making films than Mr. Goldwyn -an understandable statement since Mr. Goldwyn was standing right alongside of him.
Unloosing a bombardment of long distance blows, the Dodgers yesterday clinched second place in the National League by beating the Pirates, 10 -- 5, at Ebbets Field.

TODAY marks the closing of the New York City Ballet's summer-fall season at the City Center. With two new ballets by George Balanchine, both produced without proper setting and costuming, and a general reshuffling of ballerinas, it has been, significantly enough, a prosperous season at the box office, which indicates a solid support from the general public for the company itself and its general policy.

EGYPT, which has been hit by several Hollywood invasions in the recent past, is about to face a most formidable force commanded by Cecil B. De Mille and including a large detachment of technicians, two stars and thousands of extras who will campaign nine weeks in the land of the pharoahs for "The Ten Commandments."
MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 26 -- The Soviet Union held out hope today that resumed negotiations on President Eisenhower's atomic pool proposals might lead to some agreement.

THERE'S a feeling among some men that the casual, open-throat sport shirt has gone far enough. These are the men who are backing a new entry in the sport-shirt field: the button-down shirt in sports fabrics -- India madras, blends, knits and lightweight wools.

St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases will be aided by a fashion show and card party on Tuesday afternoon at the Pierre. The Women's Auxiliary Board and Hospital Unit Associates are sponsoring the party, proceeds of which will be used for the maintenance of a free bed at the hospital for one year and for expansion of the hospital's rehabilitation department.

When Lester Pearson, Canadian External Affairs Minister, arrived in London this week-end for the Nine-Power conference that opens on Tuesday, he said: "I doubt if there has been a more important meeting in recent years.

Victor Konow, defeated candidate for the Democratic nomination for the State Senate in the Ninth District, Queens, said yesterday he had obtained a court order requiring the Board of Elections to show cause why it should not order a recount or new election.

Commissioner of Correction Anna M. Kross expressed belief yesterday that inmates of the Women's House of Detention would be moved soon to buildings on North Brother Island. She said she would see Mayor Wagner tomorrow and would "move heaven and earth to expedite the transfer."

Legal expenditures incurred in connection with perfecting title to patents, or defending the validity of patents, are generally capital expenses, not deductible for income tax purposes. But where it can be shown that no question of title is involved, the expenses may be deductible in spite of the fact that the litigation giving rise to the expenditures was initiated as an infringement suit.

IN an industry built on superlatives it may seem almost slighting to say that the J Arthur Rank Organization, whose annual report and accounts lately have been the most important film topic here, has had a good year. But the whole tone is of quiet confidence and modest satisfaction.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- Radical Deputies introduced two resolutions in Congress last night, one asking the Peron Administration to explain why it prohibited the entry into Argentina of the Mexican publisher, Miguel Lanz Duret, president of the Inter-American Press Association.

THE voice of authority in men's clothing is not that of a famous designer here or abroad. The man who has the say is the fellow who lays the money on the line. He expresses his own taste and preferences, but trends and developments in men's clothing influence him.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Corny Shields with his International, Aileen, and Gerald Abels' Atlantic, Crossrip, were winners in the first of the post-season regattas at Larchmont Yacht Club today.

As was to be expected, cancer of the lung received considerable attention at last week's meeting in Washington, D. C., of the American Roentgen Ray Society. Most optimistic of the specialists who discussed the subject was Dr. Leo G. Rigler of Minneapolis.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- The long note delivered to the Soviet Union today was the second one in which the United States requested the Moscow Government to submit an aircraft dispute to the International Court.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Sept. 25 (AP) -- The State Board of the Professional and Business Women's Clubs today criticized the Democratic and Republican parties for failing to nominate any woman to run for state office.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 25 -- Ngo Dinh Diem, Premier of South Vietnam, charged today that Vietminh authorities were obstructing the departure of 200,000 Vietnamese from North Vietnam to the south.

IN the religious field, biographies continue to be numerous, popular and worthwhile. A new and impressive project in this category is Sheed Ward's The Makers of Christendom series, a collection of Christian biographical and autobiographical documents published under the general editorship of Christopher Dawson.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox clinched at least a tie for the American League's fourth place and a share of the world series money today by storming from behind for a 7-6 victory over the Washington Senators.
The Hebrew Language and Culture Association of America announced yesterday that it had adopted an annual budget of $500,000 to finance a Hebrew educational and cultural program in the United States.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Eldean Matheson, a junior halfback who carried the ball only four times a year ago for forty-two yards, raced fifty-two today to rally Iowa to a spectacular 14-10 victory over Michigan State's Rose Bowl football champions.

The first grant ($10,000) for studies in this country of mothers and newborn children at high altitudes has been made by Playtex Park Research Institute of Dover, Del. The study will be carried out at St. Vincent's Hospital, Leadville, Colo.

With three minutes remaining, Normie Kaufman plunged over from the 7-yard line to give Midwood the first opening-game victory, a 7-0 triumph over Erasmus High, at Brooklyn College Field yesterday.
NEWARK, Sept. 25--The older folks took over the Tommy Dominic Benefit Fund Committee this week but 12-year-old Anthony Brito, who organized it, remained its most zealous worker.

THE city of Charlotte lies in America's Bible Belt, the stronghold of native Protestantism, and it has claimed a larger churchgoing population than any other city in the United States. It is the largest community in North Carolina -- where one citizen in four is a Negro -- and it is an important distribution and financial center.

THE art of antiquity, an ever-recurring theme in Western civilization, has always captured the imagination of creative people. Shown on this page are contemporary household objects inspired by four great cultures -- Greece, Rome, Egypt and Israel. Some are replicas of museum pieces, others only suggested by the past.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A new Federal debt policy was urged today by the Committee for Economic Development, a national nonprofit research group of business men and educators.
A year ago, on Sept. 3, 1953, this correspondent was permitted by the Soviet censorship to report the death of one of the most famous Russian revolutionary figures, Michael Borodin.
Directors of the Penn Fruit Company have approved a plan to split the common stock two for one, subject to approval of a stockholders' meeting Oct. 15.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 25 -- Toledo's economy, hard hit by cutbacks in the automotive industry, got a $2,000,000 shot in the arm this week.

VIENNA. Sept. 25 -- Leon Hendler, commercial attache of the Polish political mission in Austria, disappeared from Vienna last Thursday when he was reported to have been arrested by the Soviet police and sent by plane to Warsaw.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Rain makes lawns grow. After mowing, rake up clippings, which are extra long and probably damp, and add to the compost pile. If the lawn has a somewhat yellow tinge, this will disappear after a little sun. New or old lawns need cutting until early November at a height of two inches. AND IF THERE IS TIME: Stake perennial asters and chrysanthemums . . . .
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 25 (UP) -- Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert today gained the final in the Pacific Coast tennis championship but Seixas came within a breath of defeat before he beat Whitney Reed.

ATLANTA, Sept. 25 (AP) -- At least six states prepared today to ask the Supreme Court for gradual mixing of white and Negro children in classrooms.

Removal of a gauze dressing from a healing wound or sore can be an agonizing process. The bandage or dressing often sticks to the healing tissue, and its removal starts bleeding. Now comes the Chicago firm of Bauer Black with a surgical wound-dressing that can be peeled off like the skin of a banana.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The pro-McCarthy forces say they are pleased and the anti-McCarthy forces claim to be disappointed by the decision to postpone the Senate's vote of censure on Senator McCarthy until after the election. On any realistic appraisal of the facts it should be the other way around.

HONG KONG, Sept. 25 -- The Nationalists' blockade of the southeast China coast is facilitated by their control of a number of islands off the mainland. These offshore islands, shown above, help the Nationalists control entry into Communist ports like Amoy, which is covered by Quemoy, and Foochow, which is covered by Matsu and Paichuan.

IF a young man should ask what were the prerequisites for the career of naturalist, an elderly adviser might find it difficult to give a useful answer. There are as many varieties of naturalist as there are varieties of nature.

But no one, I venture to say, has ever told it with the warmth, the simplicity, the terrifying personal urgency, that mark this quiet, matter - of - fact account

THE World Series games, between the Cleveland Indians and the New York Giants, scheduled to start on Wednesday, will receive the most extensive television and radio coverage ever accorded the baseball classic.
Recent spectacular developments in the New York banking field lend special importance to the quarterly condition statements to be issued next week.

THE next time you see a grizzly bear at the zoo, imagine it reared on its hind legs and savagely angry. Then imagine yourself hugging that vast frame with all your strength while trying to cut to its heart with a knife, your sole weapon. Think you'd win ?

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Sept. 25 -- Brig. Gen. Lester J. Maitland of Lansing, Director of Michigan Civil Defense and of its Department of Aeronautics, intends at 55 years of age to become an Episcopal minister.

PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Following a four-year study of this city's traffic problms, Paterson's Planning Board has submitted to Mayor Lester F. Titus a report calling for major changes and extensive improvements, including a highway loop around the central business district.

GARDENERS with short memories are less likely to be successful than those who have learned to turn one year's experience to the next year's advantage. The beneficent rains of recent weeks (hurricane Carol excepted) will not erase from a wise gardener's mind the memory of the seemingly endless periods of drought that have blighted the last two summers.

The Dec. 6 performance of Noel Coward's "Quadrille," starring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne; Brian Aherne and Edna Best, at the Coronet Theatre, has been taken over as a benefit for the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, Inc.
At least one Indian has returned to Manhattan Isle -- if not to claim an additional $24, at least to obtain an education.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Boston College rolled up a two-touchdown lead in the first half tonight but was forced to stave off a desperate University of Detroit rally in the closing minutes of the game to gain a 12-to-7 victory.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- The business pace picked up slightly in the Midwest during August, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago report on bank debits indicated. The August total topped the year-ago month for the first monthly increase since March with a 2 per cent gain.

HONG KONG, Sept. 25 -- The question of a United Nations seat for Communist China appears to have been formally shelved for another year by the General Assembly's decision not to consider this matter at its current session. Nevertheless the pressures for a showdown on the "China problem" are almost sure to continue.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Princeton's Tigers, opening their eighty-sixth year of football, stopped Rutgers three times at the goal line today and beat the Scarlet, 10 to 8.
ALL too often we hear the heated statements that children today "can't read" or "can't spell" or "can't handle numbers" and that, what's more, "the school does absolutely nothing about it."

HELENA, Mont., Sept. 24 -- With a nominee emphasizing membership on the "Eisenhower team" Montana Republicans have set as their goal this fall the banishment from the Senate of this state's "Mr. Democrat."

THE opening weeks of the local art season have introduced more than a dozen new, hopeful and ambitious galleries, the work shown being for the most part by newcomers, many of them young. Museums and the long established show places have not as yet begun their serious programs.

The parent education program of the Child Study Association of America, Inc., will be furthered by the Oct. 5 performance of the Old Vic's production of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream." DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- Michigan is in the usual situation at the moment of having both major parties running scared.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- An impressive collection of the free world's financial leaders is here this week-end for the annual joint meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Included on the roster are George M. Humphrey, United States Secretary of the Treasury; R. A. Butler, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, and a score of finance ministers of Europe, Asia and Latin America.

British ship operators are still being plagued by the twin evils of rising operating expenses and uncertain replacement costs for new tonnage, Sir Ernest H. Murrant, chairman of Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., said last week.

LONDONDERRY, Vt. -- Few people take so positive a pride in their state as the Vermonters, and there is no time they like their state better than in the fall. Anyone who has been there in summer remembers the native's urging: Come back in September or October and see the best of it.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Sept. 25 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, tonight renewed his use of the Dixon-Yates power contract as a weapon for attacking the Administration.

THERE are not many trustworthy first-hand accounts of life in Red China. Access to the truth is diminishing instead of increasing as time goes on. On page 11 of this newspaper's Magazine today there is printed one of the few photographs of a Soviet slave-labor camp ever to reach the West. It is a photograph taken by our correspondent Harrison E. Salisbury on his trip to East Siberia earlier this year.

INDUSTRIAL activity has faltered slightly this month, giving rise to the belief that full recovery from the business recession may be farther away than was predicted earlier in the year. According to The New York Times Index of Business Activity, the average rate of production for the first three weeks in September, based on carloadings, electric power, steel, paperboard and lumber, was slightly lower than it was in August.

ALL of us agree mechanically that the audience is the theatre's most crucial factor. The thought is hardly valuable if we view the audience as an inert mass. We must regard the audience not as a buyer but as a collaborator. And just as we yearn for good plays, should we not also seek good audiences?

Practical help on how to build a better community will be given this fall in the new Study Center in Community Participation which has been set up at the New School for Social Research. The center will be directed by Dr. Max Wolff, community consultant. The project opens Oct. 2.
Two city colleges have begun a new course of treatment aimed at alleviating the shortage of nurses.
Amid a more or less familiar setting but with an entirely different cast, baseball moves in this week with its fifty-first world series.

LONDON. N0 matter what happens to Sandy Wilson's "The Boy Friend" when it opens this week at the Royale, its place in English theatre history will remain impregnable. For this young British composer has abolished an ancient prejudice and worked a preposterous miracle.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 -- Early Wynn missed a no-hitter in the ninth but the Cleveland Indians set an American League record of 111 victories in a single season by defeating the Detroit Tigers 11 to 1, today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 25 -Republican party delegates here unanimously nominated today Howard T Hogan of Farmingdale and Assemblyman Samuel Rabin of Queens as candidates for the Supreme Court in the Tenth Judicial District, consisting of Nassau, Suffolk and Queens Counties.
The issue of Germany, key battlefield of the cold war, is at fever heat now as the Western allies prepare for this week's nine-power conference in London.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Soviet diplomacy and Communist intrigue had a hand in Chinese affairs as long ago as 1937, diplomatic correspondence kept secret since then showed today.

CAPE HATTERAS, N. C. -- America's only national seashore park is nearing the final stages of development along this barren North Carolina coastline. Only recently bids were received for a toll highway from Virginia Beach to Nags Head which will give excellent access to it.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- The United States will ask the United Nations to assign high priority to debate on President Eisenhower's proposals for sharing the peaceful uses of atomic energy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- McCarthyism may now be a profound moral issue, as many people believe, but the events of this week again proved that politics is one of its inescapable ingredients.

MILTON BERLE, the grand-daddy of all television comedians, began his seventh season last week with a disappointing show that lacked wit and style. In the absence of fresh material the show offered tired old puns and a coarze "book" that was more disposed toward having the actors, rather than the audience, swing from the rafters.

Activity in New York's billion dollar garment market rose to fever pitch along Seventh Avenue last week with the influx of thousands of out-of-town buyers. Production and shipments held to peak levels as producers sought to get into the hands of the nation's retailers the great quantities of women's coats, suits, dresses and sportswear that will be needed to meet consumer requirements for autumn and early winter.

NEVER before have so many adults been concerned with finding the right book for the right child. And never before have there been so many to choose from (approximately 1,200 new titles were published in 1953) or so many distractions from reading.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 25--Averell Harriman opened his campaign for the governorship here tonight by accusing the Republican national and state administrations of "callous indifference" to the problem of unemployment.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 (AP) -- At least seven persons perished today in the mid-air collision of two airplanes over the Patapsco River entrance to Baltimore Harbor.

Little Effie, a pint-sized steamer that has created nearly as much stir along the Hudson as the Claremont did in her day, is back on short-haul service. She is again in Long Island Sound after an epochal voyage upstate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Army-Navy-Air Force Journal said today that, contrary to expectations, American youths "are not rushing" to apply for appointment to the new Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs, Colo.
ROME, Sept. 25 -- The Senate today voted its confidence in Premier Mario Scelba and his Government.
ROME, Sept. 25 -- By the end of 1954 Italy may have ceased to receive United States Government aid, economic or military.
An agreement for a new contract between an armored car drivers' union and four major operating companies was reached here yesterday.

Standard time replaced daylight saving here today at 2 A. M. However, most New Yorkers set their clocks and watches back one hour before going to bed, so as to regain without interruption the hour of sleep lost April 24 when summer time began.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 25 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren, who wrote the Supreme Court decision outlawing segregation in public schools, said at an old southern university today that this country's "passion for justice" had often required that it "wipe some things from the slate and start again."
TOKYO, Sept. 25 -- Japan signed a reparations agreement with Burma today.

Another plant using the Bartrev continuous press to make a continuous board from lumber waste is under construction at Avvezano, in southern Italy. This was announced here last week by Dr. Robert S. THE editor of Ebony magazine, Era Bell Thompson set out for Africa in the spring of last year "looking for blood ties between the American Negro and his African cousin. I had wanted to know what it would be like to come 'home.'"

The appointment of a committee of twenty-one leading business men to assist him in matters of policy was announced yesterday by Commissioner Richard C. Patterson Jr. of the city's Department of Commerce and Public Events.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- An Army of twenty - three combat divisions, three more than the United States had during the Korean War, is expected to emerge from the quick reshuffling of men and units now under way.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- The "cold war," now seven, years old, has emerged as the dominant issue at the current session of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The United States formally demanded today that the Soviet Union pay $1,620,295.01 damages for shooting down an Air Force B-29 plane off Hokkaido, Japan, on Oct. 7, 1952, or agree to submit the dispute over the incident to the International Court of Justice.

OPERA, both on the stage and in concert form, has been assuming more and more importance in recent years. The oncoming music season will see no decrease in number and novelty of performances. From the American Opera Society comes news that the organization will present two series, one at Town Hall on four Tuesday evenings and one at the Brooklyn Academy on four Saturday evenings.

GOOD wine needs no bush, the old English proverb warns, but the mysteries of wine-making, and even the etiquette of wine-sampling, need elucidation. This has been most gracefully provided by the English novelist J. M. Scott, author of the exciting sea story. "Heather Mary."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 25 -- Navy scored two touchdowns in the first half, then added two more in the last period as it rolled to a 27-0 triumph over William and Mary today in the season's opener for both schools.
DALLAS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Dallas Club of the Texas League today signed a working agreement with the New York Giants.
ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 25 (UP) -- Jimmy Harper's versatile play carried Georgia to a 14-to-7 victory over Clemson before 28,000 fans today.

HEAT-AND-EAT foods -- usually associated with the can-opener cuisine -- have that good home-cooked flavor if made ahead and kept on hand in the freezer. A recent booklet by the United States Department of Agriculture, "Freezing Combination Main Dishes," brings out certain points to observe in this new way of laying up for future meals.

Sales continued active in the city's department stores, spurred partly by continuing promotional pressure and the kind of weather that makes the customer think about fall clothing. Merchants estimated that their business for the past week would be about 5 per cent ahead of the like week a year ago.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The dismissal of Chief Police Inspector Jean Dides and the official inquiry into security leaks from the Committee of National Defense came up today in a meeting of the French Cabinet.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Jaclyn Stable's Closed Door, winner of the Salvator Mile at Monmouth Park earlier this year, sped to a photo-finish victory over Mrs. J. R. H. Thouron's Royal Vale today in the $67,500 United Nations Handicap.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Billy Pierce hurled a five-hitter as the Chicago White Sox routed the Baltimore Orioles, 11 -- 0, today in the final game of the season for both clubs.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- The Giants, newly crowned champions of the National League, added one more notable achievement to their season's accomplishments on this, the final day of the 1954 campaign. Their Willie Mays made off with the league's batting championship after a stirring three-cornered battle with his team-mate, Don Mueller, and the Dodgers' Duke Snider.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Schools must give greater attention to the special educational and emotional needs of adolescent and teen-age youngsters, Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Education Commissioner, declared here today.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Ted Williams, Boston Red Sox slugger, said farewell to baseball today.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, will meet privately tomorrow with Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier and Foreign Minister, in an effort to improve United States-French relations.
ROME, Sept. 26 -- The Pope had sufficiently regained his strength today to resume speaking to pilgrims in the courtyard of his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo.

While the Lord does not condemn persons who perform necessary tasks on Sunday, Christians should look upon the first day of the week as a time when "we abstain from unnecessary servile work in order to devote our thoughts to the love and worship of God," the Rev. Once more Courtney Burr, John Byram and Gloria Axelrod are planning to put on a play. Depending on how quickly the script is polished, look for the presentation to come here before Christmas.
A 21-year-old man was injured fatally yesterday and five other persons were hurt when the car they were riding in smashed into a pole in Mariners Harbor, S. I. All the passengers were from Newark.

A slump in British sterling last week dropped it to $2.79 3/8, lowest since October, 1952. It was a continuation of an easier tendency begun in the last week of August. The week's highest was $2.80 1/8 (Monday) and the close on Friday, $2.79 3/8, a loss of 11/16 cent from the preceding week. Business was in good volume, although not nearly as heavy as the size of the decline might indicate.

Oscar Pearson's retirement from active teaching at Phillips Exeter Academy after forty-four years of service is really official. The popular coach of hundreds of Exeter athletes was not to be found last week as the Bid Red's athletic program began rolling.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, of Washington Heights and Washington, started his campaign for State Attorney General yesterday on the Coney Island boardwalk.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Sagging prices were the rule in grain futures trading last week. Free long liquidation occurred in wheat as holders became discouraged over the market ineffectiveness of the bullish crop developments in western Canada.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 -- A political truce of uncertain duration is expected by well-informed observers here to result from Premier Yoshida's departure on his bitterly controversial visit to Canada, the United States and Western Europe.

Although American manufacturers have made a large percentage of the cigarette machinery used here, they have missed the boat on producing an attachment for putting filters in cigarettes and are only now entering the race.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 26 -- No critical disagreements between the Vietminh and the French in the execution of the armistice in Vietnam have occurred so far, it was indicated here today.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 26 -- Federal troops were held ready in barracks today to break a spreading transport strike that has paralyzed three cities. They are Tampico and Madero, on the Gulf of Mexico, and Victoria, about 200 miles south of Brownsville, Tex.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Senate Select Committee that investigated the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy makes public its report tomorrow at 9 A. M.

There have been some hopeful developments these past few days in the Soviet-American stalemate over atomic negotiations. With Soviet approval, the United Nations General Assembly has agreed to consider the United States proposals for international cooperation regarding peaceful use of atomic energy.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The stock markets have had another unsettled week as a result of some further clearing-up of weak speculative positions arising out of the recent run of activity in industrial shares.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 (UP) -- A tattered band of Greek hostages, seized by the Communists during the civil war in Greece, was en route home by train today after years of forced labor and concentration camps in Czechoslovakia.

Averell Harriman, Democratic and Liberal nominee for Governor, told an Interfaith Day gathering in Central Park yesterday that man's right to work and think and worship in dignity had been challenged as never before by "godless Communist imperialism."

Seabrook Farms, one of the pioneers in growing and quick-freezing vegetables and other foods, has completed reorganization of its official structure and, through N. W. Ayer Son Inc., has begun an intensive advertising campaign.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday that it would begin a campaign next month for $16,950,000 for its 116 member hospitals and social service institutions.

GENEVA, Sept. 26 -- While many of the economic problems that Western Europe has become accustomed to living with since World War II are moving off-stage, some new and unexpected ones are presenting themselves.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- France must rebuild her economy without more foreign aid, Premier Pierre Mendes-France said today. In a speech at the town hall in Annecy, he said that outside help henceforth must come only in the form of military aid.

The agreement just reached between Japan and Burma on the question of reparations is less important for the terms and the quantity of the indemnification than for its other implications. Recently General Gruenther made the statement that "the first targets in a future war would be enemy forces and not population centers."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Czechoslovakia, last Communist member of the International Monetary Fund, will be expelled from the organization at the end of this year unless she supplies information about her foreign trade and internal economy, authoritative sources said tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Quarterbacks Bobby Thomason and Adrian Burk each pitched a pair of touchdown passes today as the Philadelphia Eagles routed the Cleveland Browns in a National Football League game with a superiority not indicated by the 28-10 score.
Shipowner resistance to low-rate charter offers in the last few months has resulted in a steady, even, if slow, upward trend in rates, both in the dry-cargo and tanker fields.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Wally Moon wound up his first year of major league baseball today with a two-run homer into the center-field bullpen in the eleventh inning to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 2-0 victory over the Milwaukee Braves before 39,485 fans at County Stadium.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 26 -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns warned today that Israel's ban on the free movement of United Nations observers might lead the outside world to conclude that Israel had something to conceal.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Why Daddy, a dun gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Merkel of Brookville, L. I., won the open jumper championship in the Sands Point horse show at Manorhaven Beach Park today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- French officials are expected to tell the United States at a conference at the State Department during the coming week what forces France intends to maintain in South Vietnam in the next two years.
A couple of years ago Alec Guinness, as the hero of a hilarious British movie called "The Man in the White Suit," invented a remarkable fabric that never got dirty and never wore out.

Seven new films, including an import from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

LONDON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- British authorities said today an army private had escaped from the Tower of London. But the man's moment of glory was brief. A London policeman seized him less than two hours after his escape and less than a mile from the Tower.

The Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net income of $7,051,729, after providing $6,125,000 for taxes, in the fiscal year ended on June 30. Charles Allen Jr., board chairman, reported the earnings in the annual statement issued for release today.
A thirty-nine-year career with the United States Lines will end Friday for Van Courtlandt Short, who will retire as general purchasing agent.
Four New York physicians and surgeons will begin a drive today to help increase the Negro students qualified for admission to the medical schools of the country.

The piece appearing in this space a week ago was titled "On Budgets and Bulldozers," and it dealt with the first official revision of the Administration's budget figures for fiscal 1955. More specifically, it dealt with the treatment of the story by one particular correspondent.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market became firmer last week with indications of a tightening supply. On the New York Cotton Exchange active future contracts closed 40 cents to $2.40 a bale higher. Deliveries for the current season all scored life-of-contract highs.

Mark Stevens will play the role of Steve Wilson, managing editor of "The Illustrated Press," on the new series of "Big Town," a dramatic program based on the operations of a metropolitan newspaper. The show will start over N. B. C. television on Wednesday, Oct. 6, at 10:30 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Marty Furgol stood off a spirited challenge by Bo Wininger today to win the $40,000 "world series of golf" by a single stroke.
Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, served notice yesterday that he was not toning down his liberal views to suit conservative elements in the Republican party.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- Warner Brothers has purchased screen rights to "Rebel Without a Cause" as the basis for a film drama about modern youth problems.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 26 -- John V. Riffe, executive vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, testified today that the Moral Re-Armament movement had changed his life.

MANILA, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Carrier-based jet fighters of the United States Seventh Fleet are not likely to intercept Chinese Communist bombers carrying out "strictly nuisance" raids on Formosa, Rear Admiral S. C. Ring said today.

For the Yankees the 1954 season ended yesterday at the Stadium as it started last April at Washington -- with a defeat. An 8-6 victory by the tail-end Philadelphia Athletics over Casey Stengel's "power" line-up brought down the curtain and wrote finis to what many rated as one of the most amazing acts in baseball history.
Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said yesterday the Federal Government was concerned over the disparity in economic standards between wage-earners in different parts of the country.

DENVER, Sept. 26 -- President Eisenhower tonight sent "warm greetings" to Americans of Jewish faith on the eve of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, which begins at sunset tomorrow.

Better shopping weather and an extra shopping day, helped department stores last month to exceed sales of August, 1953, by 6 per cent, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

How eighteen operators got windfalls totaling more than $14,000,000 from forty-four housing developments will be put into the record of the Senate Banking Committee, beginning today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- The new no-raiding pact between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations is heading for its first major test this week.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A home run into the right field stands by Fred Hatfield broke up a 13-inning season finale today as Detroit toppled the pennant-winning Cleveland Indians, 8 -- 7.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- Stirred by disclosures of union welfare rackets, the American Federation of Labor prepared today to pledge its aid in Government moves to root out abuses in administration of the funds.

MILFORD, Del., Sept. 28 -- Foes of racial integration in the schools today urged parents to "beat" Federal and state laws by keeping their children home when schools opened here tomorrow.

Commercial banks, savings banks, savings and loan associations, Federal Reserve and Federal Home Loan banks will now be able to convert their blanket bond coverage to a "discovery" basis with no increase in rate, it was announced yesterday by the Surety Association of America.

VALLEYFIELD, Que., Sept. 26 -- Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec made his reply today to the charge of Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada that the Provincial Government was impeding Federal unity and progress.

But a Justice must by his very title represent the basic ideal of a free government, and this Chief Justice Warren did.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The acquisition of Savage Shoes, Ltd., of Canada by the International Shoe Company of St. Louis was announced today by the presidents of the two concerns. The terms were not disclosed.

Americans for Democratic Action yesterday endorsed Averell Harriman, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, but voted to remain neutral in the contest between Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and Jacob K. Javits for Attorney General.

Last June we were greatly heartened by your editorial urging the Administration to "get together with management and labor" in the woolen and worsted industry "to seek answers to their basic problems" ("Two Sick Industries," June 7). This was exactly what we had proposed, and we felt sure the support of The New York Times would make the proposal more palatable to the powers that be in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that world bread-grain production this year would be about 8,390,000,000 bushels, slightly below last year's record harvest but more than enough to meet expected demand.

ARLES, France, Sept. 8 -- American tourists, who came down the Rhone Valley into Provence by thousands last summer, divided themselves into two categories somewhere between Lyon and Avignon: those who liked olive oil and those who avoided Provencale dishes.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur is the subject of two biographies that will be published almost a month apart. On Wednesday, McGraw-Hill will issue "MacArthur, 1941-1951," by Maj. Gen. Charles A. Willoughby and John Chamberlain.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The appointment of a committee to make a two-year study of the needs and problems of secondary education in the United States was announced here today by A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- The Illinois Central Railroad reported today that its net income for the first eight months of 1954 totaled $10,844,115 or $3.58 a common share, after preferred dividends. This compared with $17,236,667, or $5.93 a common share, in the corresponding 1953 period.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 26 -- H. Irving Pratt's 52-foot yawl, Merry Maiden, was the over-all victor today as the seventh annual Philip J. Roosevelt Trophy event for cruising yachts was completed on Long Island Sound. Merry Maiden, third today in a twelve-mile test, finished with a total of 6 points.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept 26 -- Isolation of a potent growth-promoting agent in highly purified form was announced here today by the University of California.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Two private, nonprofit organizations today announced the launching of a two-year study of the peacetime uses of atomic energy, with major emphasis on the economic problems raised.

Major league baseball attendance rose 10.8 per cent over 1953 this year with the American League showing a 13.8 increase and the National League a 7.1 per cent rise, the United Press reported yesterday.

A little news item from Buenos Aires in The Times of Saturday deserves special attention. The city was warned yesterday that it must continue to face rising welfare costs because of a steady increase in the public assistance roster, coupled with the existence of "an army of about 200,000 unemployed persons."

Harry Horwitz, operator who recently bought the blockfront of 205 feet on the west side of Greenwich Street from West Eleventh to Bank Streets, has resold it to clients of Heller Grossman, attorneys, for improvement with apartments. Louis P. Sill, vice president of Herbert Charles Co., was the broker. E. Louis Gothelf was the attorney for Mr. Horwitz.
BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Rear Admiral Donald B. MacMillan returned today from his thirtieth Arctic expedition. He reported that an Eskimo pilot had nearly sunk his ship.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Syrian voters have chosen two Communist deputies, the first elected in the nation's history in parliamentary elections, it was announced today. One of the Communists elected was Khalid Bakdash, leader of the Syrian party.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs missed an opportunity to tie Philadelphia for fourth place today in the final National League standings when they dropped a 5-2 decision to the Chicago Cubs.

The 1954 world series rivals certainly are most evenly matched. BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams went 80 yards to score on the first play of the new National Football League season with an old-fashioned sleeper trick today and then proceeded to crush the Baltimore Colts, 48 -- 0.
OCEAN CITY, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Sixty ministers of the New Jersey Conference of the Methodist Church were assigned today to new posts for the coming year by Bishop Fred Pierce Corson of Philadelphia.

The Central Bank of Bolivia announced over the week-end that it had informed Bolivian importers and merchants that sight drafts on foreign merchandise must be paid for within thirty days of maturity. Otherwise the bank will assume responsibility for payment and the merchandise will be placed at the disposition of the Ministry of Economy for public sale.

Harness racing will return to Yonkers Raceway tonight for a seven-week stand. The feature event on the eight-race opening night card is a $4,000 Class AA pace of one mile. The first race is scheduled to go off at 8:40.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 26 -- A direct appeal for defense work was made to Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, by Louis J. Horvath, president of Studebaker Local 5, United Auto Workers, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that a concentration of defense contracts in General Motors Corporation by Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson had "greatly contributed to 'monopolistic' conditions in the auto industry and to the plight of the independent producers."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Foreign governments outside the Soviet bloc are spending millions of dollars a year in the United States in a concentrated effort to gain more American friends and dollars.
American distributors of Japanese sewing machines are objecting to a proposal of the Japanese Government that they say would sharply restrict the handling of exports.
DENVER, Sept. 26 -- Reaction to President Eisenhower's Western political tour was described today as the "best to any political speeches he has made since he took office."

Formation of a subcommittee on consumer interests was announced yesterday by Nathan Straus, chairman of the Mayor's Advisory Council. The council, a volunteer group, was created by Mayor Wagner in February as an unofficial agency to be consulted on matters of major city policy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Sparked by Joe Perry who scored two touchdowns, the San Francisco Forty Niners rolled to a 41-7 victory over the Washington Redskins today in the National Football League opener for both teams.

GOSHEN, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The ninth annual show of the Northwestern Connecticut Dog Club drew a quality entry today. Among the final six that appeared before him, Col. Edward McQuown of Dayton, Ohio, selected as best the smooth dachshund, Ch Reinwald of Edlidge.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- Radcliffe College officials announced yesterday that the college would drop the honor system both during exams and in the college library.
