DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Rookie Bill Bowman, 210 pounds of fullback fury, combined with the versatile Doak Walker today to lead the Detroit Lions to a 42-23 victory over the Chicago Bears before 52,343 in Briggs Stadium.

Karl Spooner, the Dodgers' 23-year-old rookie southpaw pitcher, proved yesterday at Ebbets Field that he is no flash in the pan by setting a National League strikeout record for two consecutive games.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Ted Williams smashed his twenty-ninth home run today and Sammy White hit two homers as the Boston Red Sox clinched fourth place in the American League with an 11-2 victory over the Washington Senators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, charged today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon had told an "outright lie about the number of Communists removed from Government jobs by the Eisenhower Administration.

Reports by officers of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society at the society's recent annual meeting brought the disturbing news that the Philharmonic in its 1953-54 season of concerts had incurred a deficit of $124,205. An operating deficit of $251,914 was partly offset by other income, but even this other income was $1,000 less than in 1952-53.

Adjourned eleventh - round matches in the finals for the Hamilton-Russell chess trophy were completed yesterday, giving Yugoslavia the runner-up position to Russia, according to a report from Amsterdam.

The Air Force has awarded to the Curtiss-Wright Corporation a contract to build the country's first turboprop flight simulator. The electronic trainer will reproduce the cockpit of an Air Force transport with combination turbine and propeller power plants.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 -- The slow but steady improvement in steel demand continued last week. There is evidence that the betterment is coming later than had been supposed and there is a probability that a good-sized spurt may not come before mid-October.

The men's clothing industry operated at 70 per cent of capacity in the first eight months of this year, compared with 82 per cent in the 1953 period, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 27 -- A train ferry capsized last night, drowning almost 1,000 persons, including more than fifty Americans -- troops and Army dependents and other civilians.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Sam Barton took the second race of the International Class post-season series for the de Coppet and Haebler Trophies at the Larchmont Yacht Club today by outsailing eighteen rivals with Aries.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- Tens of thousands of sight-seers have already visited the United States' "The Atom" display in the George C. Marshall House at the annual German Industrial Exhibition in Berlin. The display opened Friday night.
Mrs. Bernice P. Rogers, deputy Commissioner of Housing, has begun a new phase in the city's offensive against one-room family occupancy and overcrowding.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Austria made a new appeal to the United Nations today for approval of her seven-year-old application for membership. Austria has been blocked twice by Soviet vetoes.

The Federal Communications Commission has approved a request made by the National Broadcasting Company to change the call letters of its company- owned stations in New York, Los Angeles and Washington, N. B. C. reported yesterday.

Before leaving for the London conference on Western defense Premier Mendes-France emphasized again that the primary aim of his program is the economic reconstruction of France. He has made clear his belief that before France can play her proper role in world affairs, or tie up with an economically powerful partner like Germany, France must become strong economically.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A Polish athlete who fled to the West said today he had been forced by Russian trainers to compete in the European track and field championships in spite of an injured foot.
The Silver Cross Day Nursery will be the beneficiary of the Halloween Ball to be held on Oct. 29 at the Plaza. Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, wife of the Mayor, is honorary chairman of the ball.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, today blamed lack of knowledge and misunderstanding of the facts for criticism of the Defense Department's procurement policies.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The American League will get an official report on the status of its Philadelphia franchise tomorrow when Roy Mack, executive vice president of the Athletics, appears before his fellow club owners in New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Three groups of Missouri Pacific Railroad stockholders and two directors of the railroad have raised objections to the plan of reorganization for that railroad approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission in July.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 -- Quemoy and the other Nationalist-held islands that are threatened with Communist assault from the Chinese mainland are "very important" to the defense of Formosa, the chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff said today.
The Outdoor Cleanliness Association has scheduled its annual entertainment, the White Winged Ball, for the night of Oct. 22 in the new Ambassador Ballroom of the Ambassador.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has bought 11,000 acres of undeveloped jungle in Brazil as a site for its first new rubber plantation in nearly twenty years.

SENNE, Germany, Sept. 27 -- "Battle Royal," the North Atlantic alliance's largest military maneuver, came to an end today with both sides simulating atomic bomb attacks on each other's main supply areas.

Record sales and earnings were attained by the Hooker Electrochemical Company and its subsidiaries in the nine months ended Aug. 31, with increases of 17 and 19 per cent, respectively, over the prior year's period.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Following is a summary of the charges filed against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, his defense against the charges and the recommendations made today by the Senate Censure Committee:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Louis Weinstock, New York Communist, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on two counts charging false statements before the Subversive Activities Control Board.

A study of the accident figures on New York City's one-way north-south avenues reveals that results are not wholly favorable, but that any firm generalizations must await a broader foundation of fact. Joseph C. Ingraham, reporter for The Times who specializes on traffic problems, points out that "any accident study here is basically unsound because the available data are meager, vague, inconsistent and misleading."
DENVER, Sept. 27 -- Neil McElroy, president of Procter Gamble Company of Cincinnati, was asked by President Eisenhower today to assume the chairmanship of the White House conference on education.

James J. P. McShane, honor veteran of the Police Department, was reinstated yesterday as a second-grade detective. Mr. McShane had been demoted because he was photographed holding an umbrella over his friend Rocky, Marciano, the heavyweight champion.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Ruth Neptunia Wasmund was presented today with a lifetime pass, good aboard any ship of the Greek Line, but she slept unconcernedly through the ceremony.

MADRID, Sept. 27 -- Scores of non-Spanish Jews were unable to attend any New Year's service here today because the Spanish police had barred a meeting of leaders of the Madrid Jewish community in a private hall of a hotel.
The price fetched by a "seat" on the New York Stock Exchange dropped yesterday for the first time since last May.

OTTAWA, Sept. 27 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan held informal talks with heads of the Canadian Government today. The talks are understood to have ranged over a variety of subjects of interest to both countries.
The Communist party was evicted yesterday from its New York County headquarters, at 73 West Ninety-ninth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A $2,100,000 anti-trust suit will be filed against the National Football League and nine of its clubs in Federal District Court here tomorrow, Bert Bell, N. F. L. commissioner, disclosed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- A general wage increase of 5 cents an hour was granted today by Swift Co., largest of the meat packers, to more than 30,000 workers in forty-nine plants throughout the country in new agreements reached with three unions.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 27 -- After spirited debate, delegates to the Labor party's annual conference here rejected today two motions condemning the Southeast Asia defense treaty. Both were opposed by leaders of the party.

Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday the election of George M. Parker as president of the Esso Export Corporation, its international sales affiliate. He succeeds William J. Haley, who is retiring Oct. 1.

Carmelo Costa, Brooklyn featherweight, extended his unbeaten skein to twenty-six by gaining a split decision over Gene Smith of Washington, in a thrilling ten-round bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

Democratic leaders expressed high confidence yesterday that they could now win the Congressional seat held by Representative Jacob K. Javits. Mr. Javits officially withdrew yesterday as a candidate for re-election on the Republican and Liberal tickets so he could run for Attorney General on the state Republican ticket.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture denied today that it made secret deals with "favored grain exporters" to sell Government-owned flaxseed at low prices.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Australia, the Netherlands and the Philippines endorsed today the United States proposal to create a new international agency to develop the peaceful uses of atomic energy.
A robbery suspect was shot down by the police yesterday afternoon during a pistol battle in West Harlem's St. Nicholas Park. The exchange of thirty-one shots sent strollers scurrying for safety.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A special Senate committee unanimously recommended today that the Senate censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 27 -- If President Will Harridge of the American League is suddenly deluged with telegrams from people he never heard of before, it won't be an accident.
In a world-wide observance that began at sunset yesterday, millions of Jews ushered in Rosh ha-Shanah, the year 5175 on the Jewish calendar and the first of Judaism's annual high holidays.

A large-scale advertising campaign to promote dining out is being scheduled by P. Ballantine Sons, Newark brewery, in support of National Restaurant Month, a promotion planned for October by the National Restaurant Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 27 -- "Tender is the Night," the late F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel published in 1934, may finally reach the screen under the sponsorship of Columbia Pictures as a result of discussions between David O. Selznick, who controls the property, and Jerry Wald, the studio's executive producer.

The 113th season of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra will open at Carnegie Hall Thursday evening, Oct. 7, with Dimitri Mitropoulos, musical director, leading the orchestra in Weber's Overture to "Der Freischuetz." The major part of the opening concert will be devoted to Act I of Wagner's "Die Walkuere," with Astrid Varnay, Ramon Vinay and Luben Vichey as soloists.

PARIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France has declared he will resign if the French Parliament rejects whatever proposals he makes to it as a result of the nine-power London conference on arming West Germany.

George P. McKinney, a 27-year-old automobile salesman, pleaded guilty yesterday to taking part in the robbery of $190,319 from a Floral Park, L. I., bank on Aug. 18, 1953. None of the money has been recovered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Samuel C. Waugh, Assistant Secretary of state for Economic Affairs, denied allegations today that there was a new trend in the United States toward high tariff protectionism.
How many millions of "spetsi" there are in the Soviet Union no one except the M. V. D. can estimate and even the M. V. D. probably hasn't a precise figure.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 27 -- Israel will release to the Arab refugees all funds they have on deposit in the banks of this country. The total mounts to $8,500,000.
Henry W. Grunewald, the Washington "mystery man," failed to appear yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court, where he was to face an indictment charging him with perjury before a grand jury in 1952.

Ronald Loesch, the 16-year-old boy who was freed of a first-degree murder charge in the "stomp" slaying of a Brooklyn man, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate term up to three years as a probation violator.

GROUP exhibitions of work by artists associated with various galleries continue to dominate the art displays of the early season. The most widely known names represented thus far are in the opening show at Paul Rosenberg's entitled "Twentieth Century French Paintings" which with the exception of two early paintings by Vuillard and a late flower piece by Braque were all done in the period between the two wars.
NEWARK, Sept. 27 -- Former Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. declined here tonight to stand as a write-in candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- An open and perhaps permanent breach between Turkey and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development was averted late today as Ankara ended a boycott of the annual meeting under way here.
TORONTO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A. R. Mosher, president of the Canadian Congress of Labor, warned workers today against making pay demands that employers cannot afford.

MANDAN, N. D., Sept. 27 -- Dedication of the first complete refinery to be built by Standard Oil Company (Indiana) in nearly fifty years will be held one and a half miles north of here Saturday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Bert Bell, commissioner of the National Football League, today labeled "unsportsmanlike" an 80-yard sleeper pass play that started the 48-0 victory scored by the Los Angeles Rams over the Baltimore Colts yesterday.

I read with interest the recent comments in The New York Times about the difficulties encountered by travelers disembarking in New York from ships from foreign countries. Unfortunately, people trying to meet the travelers in New York encounter difficulties as serious if not more serious than those of the travelers themselves.

BUFFALO, Sept. 27 -- United States District Court Judge John Knight today set Nov. 22 for the trial of six officers and nine corporations of the Schine theatrical organization on criminal and civil contempt charges.

IN Venezuela, some 200 miles south of Caracas and the Caribbean Sea, the Apure River flows eastward toward its confluence with the Orinoco. There in the llanos state of Apure lies San Fernando de Apure, a city of 13,000 persons. During "the hot and fluvial winter" the temperature never drops below 80 degrees and never rises above 85.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Thousands of workers have fled to West Germany since late August to escape increasingly dangerous work in the Soviet-operated uranium mines of East Germany, the State Department reported today.
ROME, Sept. 27 -- A small but definite beginning has been made toward bringing the Italian wage earner into modern industrial society.

The new Idria Mining and Chemical Company, the nation's largest producer of mercury, has formed a division to offer experienced mine management and operation services to individuals and companies in the uranium and manganese mining industries.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 -- The transport strike against Government-ordered increases in gasoline prices spread to the important sugar-producing area of El Mante today. Meanwhile, a standstill had been reached in the negotiations between the Government and representatives of the strikers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- One of the principal claims asserted by this Administration to a vote of confidence, to be registered by the election of a Republican Congress in November, is that it has "restored the integrity and dignity of the Government."
Windsor Locks, Conn., sold $1,547,000 of school bonds due from 1955 to 1974 to Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and associates at a bid of 100.089 for 1.90s.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- A State Education Department recommendation that school systems make greater use of Regents examinations has touched off a controversy among some officials at the annual meeting here of the State Council of City and Village School Superintendents.

It is almost five years since the civil war ended in Greece. To put the case in another way, it is almost five years since international communism gave up its attempt to conquer Greece by sending men and munitions over the frontiers. Part of the inhuman communist strategy of the war years was to kidnap Greek civilians, including women and children.
The completion of eleven tankers and one cargo ship, totaling 171,424 tons, was the highlight of global ship construction activity under the supervision of the American Bureau of Shipping in August.
Striking embalmers voted last night to return to work without a contract after rejecting the latest employer proposal for a reduction in hours, a union spokesman said.

The Italian Government of Premier Scelba has weathered a dangerous storm in gratifying fashion. The Senate has given the Government a 114-to-97 vote of confidence on the Montesi scandal. There will be more storms, but the four-party coalition of Christian Democrats, Liberals, Right-Wing Socialists and Republicans is showing a cohesion and discipline that has rarely been evidenced in Italy.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 27 -- An Anglican prelate said here today that the Moral Re-Armament movement had brought "new life" into his personal faith.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A majority of Senators publicly maintained a judicial attitude today on their reaction to the proposed censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Canada and the United States took a long stride today toward a comprehensive early warning radar barrier across the top of the continent.

The New York Stock Exchange ended an inconclusive session yesterday with a gain in the industrial average offset by a slump in rails. More issues were down than up. Rails were generally lower. Even among the industrials only oils, motors, aircrafts and a few specialties displayed strength.

An estimated 10,000 persons visited two armories here yesterday for the golden anniversary of the National Business Show, in which the $2.5 billion-a-year office equipment industry exhibited its latest ideas in business equipment.

Representatives of the trucking industry and of twelve locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., resumed negotiations yesterday in a race to beat a Thursday midnight strike deadline.

Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Roxy, the attraction is "Woman's World," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic comedy with Clifton Webb, June Allyson, Van Heflin, Lauren Bacail, Fred MacMurray, Arlene Dahl, Cornel Wilde and Elliott Reid.

On the strength of a stinging left jab, Danny Joe Perez, 139 1/2 pounds, of Manhattan's West Side scored a unanimous decision over Bobby Bickle, 138, Topeka, Kan., in the ten-round main event at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The United States and France reached a "broad area of agreement" today in negotiations on the future of United States aid to Indochina.

Sol Gelb, special counsel to the State Insurance Department in its investigation of labor union welfare funds, was chosen yesterday as the Republican candidate for General Sessions judge. He will run for the seat vacated by former Judge Saul S. Streit, now a candidate for Supreme Court justice.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 28 -- Japanese and United States authorities counted today a grim death toll of more than 1,000 men, women and children drowned Sunday night when the train ferry Toya Maru turned over and sank off Hakodate on Japan's northermost island of Hokkaido.
New trouble from inmates in the Women's House of Detention added fresh fuel yesterday to the controversy over the city administration's plan for obtaining more prison space.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 27 (UP) Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, United States Eighth Army commander, arrived here today from Korea for what he said was a "long overdue" inspection of Formosa's defenses against possible Communist invasion.

The volume of cauliflower shipments from Long Island has increased sufficiently to make that vegetable an attractive selection at produce stands. A serving averages 5 cents in cost. For this aristocratic member of the cabbage clan, the following simple preparation method is suggested:
Personnel work is "the internal sales branch" of a company, the American Management Association's personnel conference was told yesterday.

A loan by a builder in 1952 to Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. of $3,000, no part of which has been repaid, was disclosed yesterday. The story was brought out at a public hearing of the Senate Banking Committee, investigating Federal Housing Administration scandals.

Although the survival of fifty persons aboard a plane that crashed in England recently was attributed to rearward-facing seats, most of the safety experts in this country are not convinced that the reversed seating arrangement necessarily saves lives.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, asserted yesterday that the record of Governor Dewey's twelve years at Albany "is a necessary and important part of the people's consideration of the Republican ticket headed by Senator [Irving M.] Ives."
Events today: New York Festival Band Concert, Battery Park, 12 noon; Cantata Singers, pre- season sing, 122 East Eighty- third Street, 7:45 P. M.: Howard Shaw, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30.
Communist China's first Constitution, adopted last week, provides for a political and economic system similar to that of the Soviet Union in many respects, but also differing sharply in some ways.
High Gun easily beat older horses yesterday. The achievement was hardly a surprise to the 21,429 fans on hand, for they made the 3-year-old son of Heliopolis the favorite, although by a small margin.

The Legal Aid Society moved its Harlem office yesterday to 290 Lenox Avenue, at 125th Street, from 1400 Fifth Avenue. An increased need for the society's service in Harlem necessitated the move to larger quarters.
Election of William H. Lang as a director of General Mills, Inc., was announced yesterday by Harry A. Bullis, chairman.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 27 -- The C. I. O.'s fight against Communism was praised here today by the Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell, at the opening session of the convention of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers C. I. O.

The independent United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America union charged yesterday that the Republican party was attempting to conceal an anti-labor bias by keeping Senator Joseph R. McCarthy from active participation in the 1954 political campaign.
HONG KONG, Sept. 27 -- Mao Tse-tung was re-elected chairman of the Chinese People's Republic today. Gen. Chu Teh was named deputy chairman and placed in a position to succeed Mr. Mao.
Modern homemakers have shown increasing interest in furniture styles and objets d'art dating from the French and English periods of 1795 to 1820.

ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 27 -- Steve Sorota, the former Fordham star who has rolled up an impressive record during his nineteen years as head football coach at Phillips Academy, Andover, seemed surprisingly chipper this afternoon as he discussed his team's prospects.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Representative Patrick J. Hillings, Representative of California, said today that Guatemalan Communists had hidden away "enough weapons to equip two full divisions" when the Red-infiltrated Government was toppled from power.

The New York Knickerbockers will open their National Basketball Association campaign Saturday night, Oct. 30, when they meet the Minneapolis Lakers, defending league champions, at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Committee for a National Trade Policy said today it was more determined than ever to work for a freer flow of world trade because "Russia is endeavoring to trade us out of our free world friends."

The rejection of the E. D. C. by the French National Assembly was followed by a wave of anti-French feeling in this country. Some of the friends of France tried to offset it by arguments which tend to lead to a wave of anti-German feeling. The final consequence, if this trend is not checked, will be the development of anti-European sentiment, and a strengthening of isolationism.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 -- The American Federation of Labor condemned Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, today as "unworthy of the American tradition."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations accused President Eisenhower today of a "lack either of political realism or of a genuine desire for change" in unemployment compensation payments.
The most priceless intangible asset of a university is freedom, Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor of New York University, said yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Dean Acheson says any law curbing the President in foreign policy matters would endanger national security.

The unanimous recommendation of censure against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy by a respected, conservative and bipartisan committee of his colleagues is by all odds the heaviest blow that Wisconsin's junior Senator and the nation's senior demagogue has suffered in his entire political career.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Following is the text of the report of the Senate Select Committee to Study Censure Charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 27 -- Brown paid rather dearly for its victory over Columbia, the start of a season of high promise for Alva Kelley's Bruins. For the game coming up with Yale in the bowl at New Haven Saturday, two of the best backs have been lost.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- John W. Powell, former American editor of The China Monthly Review, today heard himself denounced as a "murderer" deserving punitive action for publishing a magazine distributed as Communist propaganda to prisoners of war in Red Korea.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange experienced one of its widest price swings in months yesterday. Prices closed barely steady, 18 to 26 points net lower than on last Friday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 -- Convention delegates representing 10,200,000 members of the American Federation of Labor unanimously pledged today their "strong and whole-hearted support" to Government curbs on welfare fund abuses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A Government witness who admitted he once was sentenced for second-degree murder testified today at a Federal Communications Commission hearing that once in 1938 and again in 1940 he saw Edward Lamb make contributions to a Communist. He said the contributions totaled $7.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The British Government has launched a nation-wide drive to recruit civilian defense volunteers. Gen. Sir Sidney Kirkman, former Quartermaster General of the British Army, has been named Director General of Civil Defense.
President Eisenhower did his part yesterday in bringing public attention to beef stew. He prepared it for some eighty-five luncheon guests at the summer White House in Denver.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 27 -- A stern and somewhat authoritarian program was outlined today as the policy of the reorganized Ngo Dinh Diem Cabinet by the new Information Minister, Phan Xuan Thai.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Watkins committee's report recommending censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy became a scarce commodity soon after it was made public today.

Outwitting the tides and winds of the East River, a small fleet of tugboats floated into position yesterday the 420-foot center span of the new vertical lift bridge linking Welfare Island with Long Island City, Queens. The structure is scheduled for completion by April 1, weather permitting.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Prospects for conquest of the problem of West German armament and sovereignty improved today. A principal factor in the better outlook was a successful consultation between John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Pierre Mendes-France, Premier and Foreign Minister of France.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 27 -- Brazil will never be able to get its petroleum above ground by its own resources, it was declared today in a resolution of the ninth round table of the Confederation of Commercial Associations. The organization represents business associations throughout Brazil.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy will begin a "vigorous and lengthy fight" against censure when the Senate convenes on Nov. 8.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- The Special Senate censure committee today recommended certain changes in the rules of committee procedure to eliminate much of the criticism of investigative groups.

Regular line insurance companies write disability insurance for as little as 55 to 75 cents per hundred dollars paid out in wages. Under this coverage workers receive as much as twenty-six weeks of disability pay up to $30 weekly. A maximum of $780 can be collected by workers covered by this insurance.

Comparing the Giants and Indians on the offense, the world series expert again cracks into some knotty problems. Much of this stems from the fact that neither club generates all of its power from a set line-up of regulars.

Collaboration between a group of artists and an expert craftswoman has produced a collection of fourteen unusual accent rugs that went on view yesterday at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Fordham University, offices and library, in 61 Duane St; Murray Slocum, exports-imports, in 370 Lexington Ave; Gramercy Stationery Co, store in 488 Madison Ave -- Cross Brown Co, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Today's report by a special Senate committee that investigated censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, is the second in a month to be received by the Senate on the conduct of its most controversial member.
The State Industrial Commissioner charged the Democratic candidate for Governor yesterday with using employment statistics misleadingly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A vote censuring Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for contempt of the Senate would be entirely different from filing contempt charges against a person who refused to answer questions of a Congressional committee.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Cornell University announced today that Prof. Chandler Morse of its Economics Department had been named director of its Social Science Research Center. He succeeds Robin M. Williams Jr., Professor of Sociology, who will spend the next academic year at the University of Oslo on a Fulbright grant.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 27 -- Yachtsmen of the United States and Norway as represented by International Class members of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club and the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club divided two races today at the beginning of an annual series for the Skoal Trophy.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Herbert E. Hotu, secretary and controller of The Sharon (Pa.) Herald, was elected president of the Institute of Newspaper Controllers and Finance Officers at the group's seventh annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Military morale -- a human equation composed of many unknowns -- is certain to be affected by today's report on the activities of Senator Joseph McCarthy. But how and when was the big question.

Farewell, old car, good-by. In another hour or so that man from the dealer's will arrive in a shiny new machine, will leave it and will take you away in partial exchange. After the superior manner of his kind he will be disdainful, ashamed of your shabby looks, and he will drive back roads to the garage and not down the superhighway.

After a long and bitter struggle in his Parliament, Japanese Premier Yoshida is now out of Japan, in this hemisphere, and embarked on his goodwill trip, that will bring him later to the United States. The obstruction to this trip was much more petty political than the moralizing facade that was given to it.
The search by the Playwrights Company for a director to take charge of "The Bad Seed," Maxwell Anderson's melodrama derived from William March's book, is rapidly drawing to an end.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 21 -- A serious problem, bearing on the thirteen-year-old relationship between United States armed forces personnel and the population, has been created here by the steadily increasing use of motorized bicycles.

ACCORDING to late reports the striped bass run has started, at least in the Cape Cod-Rhode Island area, for several nice fish were taken over the week-end, including a number that scaled more than forty pounds.

PERHAPS this is merely a hunch which was discarded by Leo Durocher, even though it's to be doubted that the Dandy Little Manager of the Giants ever left a hunch unused. It runs contrary to logic, statistics and the betting odds. It defies reason. But it's there nonetheless and it's inescapable. The hunch is this: The Giants will beat the Indians in the world series that starts tomorrow.
Charles (Chuck) Dressen, who is reputed to have more bounce than any other man in baseball, bounced back into the major leagues yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Ideal weather throughout the principal grain areas accentuated bearish local sentiment in corn and soybeans and prices for these products declined sharply, soybeans being especially heavy. Wheat and oats were affected by the declines in the other pits, buyers being far from aggressive.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Great concern was expressed in Government circles today lest the diplomacy of Premier Pierre Mendes-France should be damaged by charges that his Minister of the Interior had moved against a system of police surveillance of the Communist party.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Prices finished irregular but a shade higher than Friday in most sections of the stock market here today.

LEROY, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- The sale of the Champion Container Corporation to the Krafco Container Corporation of Dallas, Tex., was announced here today. The Leroy plant, established twenty years ago, employs fifty workers.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Mario Laureti, Vernon Hills aide, and Len Byan of Briar Hall carded 32, 33 -- 65, seven under par, in best-ball play at Wykagyl today. This gave them a one-shot victory in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament.

Czechoslovakia, Washington dispatches report, is about to be expelled from the International Monetary Fund for failing to provide basic economic information required by that organization's rules. The Prague excuse has apparently been that "national security" prohibited release of data regarding foreign trade and the internal economy of the country.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 -- The Studebaker-Packard Corporation will begin operation on Friday with an extra $70,000,000 in working capital. Terms of a negotiated loan for this amount were announced today by Harold S. Vance, president of the Studebaker Corporation,

William W. Wallace, general manager of the international division of Servel, Inc., manufacturer of refrigerators and air conditioners, has been named assistant vice president as well, Mr. Wallace has been associated with the company since 1935.
Jewelry carved with cupids, lace - lined umbrellas, ostrich - plumed collars and full-blown roses everywhere gave a Victorian flavor to yesterday's showing of boutique items by Saks Fifth Avenue.

Although trading in most commodities on the New York exchanges was dull yesterday, potato futures registered the most active trading in the history of the market and hides had the heaviest volume since trading reopened in March, 1952.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The California Horse Racing Board today sharply criticized Andrew J. Crevolin for loose talk about horse racing and kept his suspension in effect until Oct. 30.
PRESQUE ISLE, Me., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Ted Williams, who decided he had "had enough" of baseball, began a five-day vacation devoted to fishing and bird hunting in northern and eastern Maine today.

The memoirs of John Leighton Stuart, former Ambassador to China, will be published Oct. 15 by Random House. It will be entitled "Fifty Years in China." The author was born in Hang-chow, China, of missionary parents. Educated in the United States, he returned to China in 1904 as a missionary.
The capricious and destructive Hurricane Carol, which tore into New England without adequate warning on the morning of Aug. 31, still remains a lady of mystery.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Iraq launched a blistering word attack against Israel today in the opening debate in the United Nations General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) Charles V. Bush, a slim 14-year-old Negro boy with an easy grin, went to work today as a Supreme Court page boy.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, personally intervened today in the dispute between Italy and Yugoslavia over Trieste and prospects brightened for a settlement within a matter of days.
LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Sterling continued to lose ground in terms of the United States dollar on the London foreign exchange market today, dipping to its lowest level for some years.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- The integrity of the Federal Housing Administration, whose reputation "has been injured by our exposure of the past misdoings of a few faithless men," has been restored, President Eisenhower today told William A. Clarke, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
Operating revenues of the American Gas and Electric Company showed modest gains for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, but earnings were down slightly, the utility system reported yesterday.
DENVER, Sept. 27 -- President Eisenhower, whose culinary artistry has won wide acclaim, let the American housewife in today on "practically the same" recipe he uses for his old-fashioned beef stew.
Tensions found here between Negroes and Puerto Ricans barely exist in Puerto Rico, Edward S. Lewis, executive director of the Urban League of Greater New York, said yesterday.

RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Proposed new township names of Edison and Nixon for this community will go on the ballot here Nov. 2, it was decided today after Superior Court Judge Ralph J. Smalley refused to interpret the state law governing name changes.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 -- The American Federation of Labor called on its 113 affiliated unions today to press for "substantial" wage gains, despite a convention report of a general business slump.

An offering of 82,000 shares of $2.375 cumulative preferred stock of the General Telephone Company of Illinois at $49.50 a share will be made today by an underwriting group headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis; Stone Webster Securities Corporation and Mitchum, Tully Co.
Generoso Pope Jr., until a week ago publisher of the weekly New York Enquirer, resigned yesterday as a member of the Board of Higher Education because of the "pressure of business interests."
YONKERS, Sept. 27 -- Rilma's Widower, the favorite, won the Miss Yonkers $4,000 pace by a length from Adam Frisco in 2:06 as Yonkers Raceway opened a forty-three-night fall meeting tonight.
Driving through the streets of Dublin recently, this writer was struck by the character of the Georgian houses that surround the verdant parks scattered throughout the city.
Gordon Dean, forme chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said yesterday that the atomic research center at Los Alamos, N. M., had been libeled in the new book "The Hydrogen Bomb."

Donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Friday totaled 608 pints of blood. Included were 159 pints given at the New York City Housing Department, 346 Broadway; 121 donated by Army and Coast Guard personnel at 89 Lafayette Street, and 108 at the Home Insurance Company, 59 Maiden Lane, bringing the total for a three-day collection at Home Insurance to 279.
A gradual improvement in steel order volume was reflected in an increase of 2.3 percentage points last week in the industry's operating rate. A further rise is expected this week.

One million cheering New Yorkers turned out in brilliant sunshine yesterday for a civic welcome for the New York Giants, winners of the National League pennant and the team that will oppose the Cleveland Indians in the world series.
Mayor Wagner went on a tour of five new public schools yesterday morning to see how New York's "school construction dollar" was being spent.
MILFORD, Del., Sept. 27 -- The Milford public schools, closed for a week because of threats over integration, reopened today with Negro pupils in attendance at a previously all-white school.

WHEN the noon whistle blows on Friday the impatient wildfowlers will have an excuse to exercise their shotguns, for the season on scoters (also known as coots and skunkheads), eider ducks, and old-squaws will get under way at that time, provided the hunting is done "outside the outer harbor lines."

America's future depends upon the continuing faith of those who invest in it, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared yesterday. Thus, he told the thirty-seventh annual convention of the National Association of Securities Administrators, the investment business had a patriotic duty to keep that faith intact.

Those four-color two-page spreads don't just happen. To make a copper-bottom sauce pan glow cherry red in an advertisement for Revere Copper and Brass Inc, its manufacturer, a photographer heated it with two blow torches, one inside and the other out, for some time before he took a picture.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Sept. 28 -- Mrs. Caryl Sayre of the Creek Club shot 40, 38 -- 78 to win the low gross prize by one stroke in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament at Wheatley Hills today.

CAIRO, Sept. 28 -- Egypt charged today that an Israeli merchant ship had fired upon and wounded inhabitants of the Red Sea coast of Egypt south of Suez early today. The vessel has been taken into custody by Egyptian authorities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Wallace Moir, president of the Wallace Moir Company of Beverly Hills, Calif., was elected president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America today at the annual convention. He succeeds William A Clarke of Philadelphia.

HONG KONG, Sept. 28 -- Communist China's first National People's Congress adjourned today after having endorsed a new Government Cabinet and Defense Council. Premier Chou En-lai retained the Foreign Ministry portfolio and appointed Gen. Peng Teh-huai to fill the new post of Defense Minister.
Ohio sold $30,000,00 0of major-thoroughfare bonds in the public market yesterday at a net cost of 1.3811 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Columbia Pictures has bought the screen rights to "My Dear Children." The Catherine Turney-Jerry Horwin play served in 1940 to bring John Barrymore back to Broadway for his last stage, appearance after an absence of seventeen years.
New York City's 5 per cent tax on theatre admissions was upheld as valid and constitutional yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Percy D. Stoddart in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Republican leaders expect an official announcement soon raising and revising the total number of "security risks" separated from the Federal Government payroll since the Eisenhower Administration took office.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon predicted today that the special Senate committee report recommending censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy "will have great weight with the Senate."

Favored by mild, pleasant weather, a dozen ardent baseball fans set up overnight housekeeping outside the Polo Grounds to make sure they would be among the first bleacher customers for today's opening game of the world series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A high official of the Polish secret police who had defected made an appearance here today and threw off some of the mystery of Noel, Herta and Hermann Field, United States citizens who disappeared behind the Iron Curtain five years ago.

Television viewers from coast to coast who were tuned in last night to the National Broadcasting Company's "Truth or Consequences" quiz show suddenly found themselves looking at "Life With Father," a Columbia Broadcasting System program.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- In the absence of Premier Pierre Mendes-France, the French Cabinet today approved price-fixing measures affecting sugar, milk and alcohols as part of the Government's economic program.
The doughnut has its day in October, when the industry begins its annual sales promotion keyed to the theme of National Donut (doughnut) Month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Louisiana officals agreed today to cancel the State's plan to lease submerged oil and gas lands on which the Federal Government also has a claim.

Police Commissioner Adams has made amends by admitting he was wrong in demoting an honored officer, James J. P. McShane, for being photographed off duty holding an umbrella over his friend Rocky Marciano, the heavyweight boxing champion. Mr. McShane goes back to rank of second-grade detective and the Commissioner, a bit quick on the trigger, gets a lesson in the force of public opinion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Government of South Vietnam informed the United States today that it had decided to ask the French expeditionary corps to withdraw by March, 1956.
Reflecting increased sales, net income of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company and its subsidiary rose in the twelve months ended Aug. 31, the company announced yesterday.

The apartment building accommodating seventeen families at 9-11 Broad Street in Newark, N. J., has been sold by Edward W. and Jane Malley to the 9-11 Broad Company, represented by George J. Lasky, attorney. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker and Edward P. Becker was attorney for the sellers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A Congressional inquiry heard today that the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and a group of New York banks had agreed to put up 95 per cent of the $107,000,000 required to carry out the controversial Dixon - Yates power contract with the Atomic Energy Commission.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Mansfield Tire and Rubber Company announced today the completion of negotiations for establishing a $3,000,000 tire and tube manufacturing plant in Alexandria, Egypt.
The Weatherman is tired of being the butt of a parade of stale jokes.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, yesterday told the freshman class of Columbia College that free institutions held the key to intellectual freedom.

Although operating revenues of the Southern Railway Company dropped to $20,974,190 last month from $22,240,145 in 1953, the road reported yesterday net income of $2,011,975, or approximately the same as the $2,020,322 earned in August, 1953.

Justice Michael F. Walsh of Brooklyn plans to retire from the Supreme Court bench in the Second Judicial District because of ill health. He has applied to the Appellate Division for a disability pension, which would provide him with $20,000 of his $30,000-a-year salary until his term expires Dec. 31, 1956.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today it would give most subscribers to last week's issue of 1 5/8 per cent Treasury notes half of what they offered to buy.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 28 -- James E. Carey, president, and Al Hartnett, secretary-treasurer, of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C. I. O., were re-elected unanimously today for their third two-year terms.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 28 -- The striking transport workers in Tampico agreed today to send a delegation to Mexico City for negotiations with the Government to end the tie-ups in a dozen or more cities in northeast Mexico.

DETROIT, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Fred Hutchinson, who lifted the lowly Tigers to within one game of finishing in the American League's first division this year, indicated today he might quit as Detroit manager unless he could get a two-year contract.
The eviction last Monday of the Communist party from its New York County headquarters at 73 West Ninety-ninth Street was attributed yesterday to the nonpayment of rent for two months.
Notre Dame was chosen the No. 1 college football team yesterday in the weekly Associated Press poll.

On the day of the world series Brooklyn Dodger fans are undergoing an agonizing reappraisal all their own. Should they root for their traditional enemies, the Giants, who pushed them into second place, or should they think internationally beyond the borders of the home town and cross their fingers for Cleveland?

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Prince Wan Waithayakon, Foreign Minister of Thailand, told the United Nations General Assembly today his Government was gravely concerned over the situation in Southeast Asia despite the Indochina armistice.

Warner-Hudnut, Inc., plans to offer to holders of its 6 per cent $100 par preferred stock the right to exchange their shares for subordinated 5 per cent debentures, due on Dec. 1, 1974. The basis for the exchange would be $105 of debentures for each share of preferred.
Five new security issues totaling $49,500,000 will be offered to investors today. Three public utilities and two industrial organizations are represented.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Following are the texts of notes sent by the United States today to Hungary and Poland requesting the release of three United States citizens, Hermann, Noel and Herta Field.

The Polo Grounds is easily accessible from all parts of the city by subway and bus and from the suburbs by automobile. Here are the preferred means of reaching the site of today's world series opener:

Leo Durocher, on the verge of directing a team in a world series for the third time in his managerial career, seemed unusually quiet when he arrived at the Polo Grounds shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 28 -- The Most Rev. and Right Hon. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, said today that the dropping of the atom bomb on Hiroshima was leading to a reconciliation between religion and science.

TRENTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner reported today that New Jersey had a surplus of $33,000,000 at the end of the 1953-54 fiscal year. He said "there is hope" there would be no new taxes next year.

About 38,000 square feet of office space has been leased by the Cerro de Pasco Corporation, miners of metals, in the twenty-five-story building being built by Uris Brothers at 300 Park Avenue, on the west blockfront between East Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Italy and Yugoslavia have accepted a compromise territorial settlement of their nine-year-old dispute over Trieste.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- A better demand developed for both wheat and corn after these grains had been depressed substantially in the early trade here today. Early wheat losses were recovered as a result of short covering following commission absorption, but prices receded from the tops.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, said today that the American people "are sick and tired" of the McCarthy issue and that it would have no effect on the Congressional election.

PARIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A former Red-hunting police inspector, suspended during the current Government search for leaks of French defense secrets, said today that the name of France's counter - intelligence chief appeared on a party index of Communist sympathizers.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 28 -- In keeping with the truce terms the Vietminh military forces are pulling out of Vietnam south of the Seventeenth Parallel. Politically, however, the Vietminh is working hard in the South to consolidate its influence.

The weather affects everyone, all the time, and on its accurate forecasting -- especially in times of threatened storms -- the safety of both life and property depends. Yet both meteorology and the art of weather prediction have been the stepchildren of modern science.
MONTREAL, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Members of the Montreal Stock Exchange and the Canadian Stock Exchange have been cautioned against dealings with nonmember promoters of highly speculative stocks.
AN unusual art form, newly christened a "galaxy," designed and painted by the architect, painter and sculptor Frederick Kiesler, swings into New York's ken at the Sidney Janis Gallery.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A government scientist said today research with new nuclear aids showed that 98 per cent of the basic material in the human body was replaced yearly.
The real estate trust has put over some pretty frightful things on us poor defenseless New Yorkers, but this latest wild scheme of William Zeckendorff is the most outrageous.

TO the best of my knowledge and belief no living writer has written as many fine historical novels as Margaret Irwin. If she has never achieved a major masterpiece comparable to Hope Muntz' "The Golden Warrior," neither has she ever produced a tired and clumsy cloak-and-sword romance of the sensational variety so distressingly popular today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- A report on United Nations efforts to assist the settlement of thousands of European refugees received a top place today on the agenda of the Social Committee of the General Assembly.

COLLINGSWOOD, N. J., Sept. 28 -- The Democratic and Republican candidates for United States Senator from New Jersey engaged tonight in a debate that centered around the premise that all President Eisenhower needed right now was a Democratic -- or Republican -- Congress.
FAIRMONT, W. Va., Sept. 28 -- Judge J. Harper Meredith granted today an injunction in Circuit Court restraining fifty-three defendants from interfering with the operation of the Annabelle School.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- The State School Building Commission took New York City to task today, asserting it had failed to prepare a sound plan for enlarging and modernizing its educational plant.

OTTAWA, Sept. 28 -- The Canadian Tariff Board began hearings today to decide whether to raise the tariff on imported woolen cloth so as to protect the Canadian woolen cloth industry from British competition.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Because of Britain's improved dollar situation United States film companies will repatriate more of their earnings in this country during the next twelve months. They will be able to take out $19,250,000, compared with $17,000,000 remitted during the past year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- The General Services Administration will lease an aluminum forging plant at Erie, Pa., to the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation in mid-1956 if the Justice Department approves, a spokesman said today.

New York business and professional men have been befriending boys in trouble under the Big Brother plan for fifty years. The experiences of the half century have demonstrated how much can be done to prevent the loss of boys to a career of crime, Joseph H. McCoy, executive director of the movement, declared yesterday.
ROME, Sept. 28 -- Three days after having won a vote of confidence in the Senate the Government found itself face to face with the Chamber of Deputies today.
Motors, chemicals and rubbers charged ahead in yesterday's stock market and carried The New York Times' industrial and combined averages to new highs for the year and for the upward movement.

It will be Sal Maglie against Bob Lemon, both right-handers, at the Polo Grounds today as the Giants and Indians square off in the first game of the 1954 world series before an estimated crowd of 54,000.

PELHAM, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- The British Consul General in New York or another high civil servant of Her Majesty's Government win appear at Pelham's 300th anniversary pageant the night of Oct. 15 to collect twenty shillings.

The New York Singing Teachers Association presented last night at Town Hall the winner of its first Recital Award, the baritone Howard Shaw. A native of Ohio, Mr. Shaw was graduated from Wooster College, and in the lobby last evening was a large "Welcome Howard" sign inviting all Woosterians to visit backstage after the recital.
HAWTHORNE, Nev., Sept. 28 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, collapsed and died tonight while addressing a Democratic rally. He was 78 years old.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Domestic politics are playing a larger part in the nine-power conference here than they have in any other international meeting since World War II.

The disappearance in Eastern Europe of Noel Haviland Field and other members of his family whose whereabouts were suggested yesterday by a Polish defector, was one of the sensations of "cold-war" intrigue and of Soviet satellite politics.

Members of the women's committee of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center have taken over a block of seats at the premiere showing of the motion picture "A Star Is Born" on the night of Oct. 11 at the Victoria Theatre to raise funds for the organization.

Edwin Holton's Trisong won the Step Lightly Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, under a good ride by George Glassner. The daughter of Spy Song defeated T. F. White's Weesie by a neck in the six-furlong test for fillies and mares. Third, more than two lengths back of Miss Weesie, was Elmendorf's Banta.
The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, independent union, indicated yesterday that it would press for the thirty-hour week in future contract negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today designated 52-year-old Scovel Richardson, first Negro member of the Federal Board of Parole, as board chairman for the coming year.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 28 -- The Chilean Government has declared a state of emergency in the northern Province of Atacama to prevent a threatened strike in the Potrerillos mines of the Andes Copper Mining Company, subsidiary of Anaconda Copper.
Officials of the Board of Elections, busy yesterday with preparations for the opening of registration tomorrow, took time out to explain why some citizens will be unable to vote this fall.
American industry was chided by a high official of the Atomic Energy Commission yesterday for failing to venture into the field of atomic power with its traditional boldness.

Since recent moderation of the United States embargo on exports to Iron Curtain countries, expectations of increased peaceful trade with the Communists have continued more theoretical than real, a Department of Commerce official told exporters yesterday.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Sept. 28 -- Big Mike Holovak is a friendly, cheerful person and it's not like him to be downcast, but he was today. He was trying to figure how to prepare his Boston College football team for Saturday's game with Temple without a quarterback.
DENVER, Sept. 28 -- President Eisenhower sharply denied today that the Administration was opposed to rural electrification programs and that drastic cutbacks were planned for next year.

GUATEMALA, Sept. 29 (UP) -- President Carlos Castillo Armas disclosed today, three months after his successful anti-Communist revolution, that 2,000 persons remained in Guatemala jails on charges of Communist activity.

Miss Caroline Schade, last member of an old German-American family, left her residuary estate of $150,000 to eight religious, charitable or educational institutions, papers in the Surrogate's Court show. She lived at 524 West 182d Street and died on July 22, when 89 years old.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- The nation's top civil defense authority said today that seventy prime target cities must prepare plans now on how to evacuate 70,000,000 persons if enemy planes headed their way with hydrogen or atomic bombs.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Two Army psychiatrists today testified Cpl. Claude Batchelor "knew right from wrong" while a prisoner of war in Korea.
An Indonesian official who broke with his Government on the ground that it is Communist-dominated, has been arrested here for deportation. He is being held at Ellis Island.

CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 28 -- Leonard (Bunny) Barker, athletic director at St. Paul's School, who was busy last week issuing equipment and uniforms to more than 300 football players, was back at his regular job today of watching the school's traditional club system in operation.

We were told in print the other day that the Staats-Zeitung, last active relic of the days when Park Row opposite City Hall was the center of New York's working press, had left to the mercies of the wreckers clearing the way for Brooklyn Bridge's up-to-date traffic the building in North William Street, home since 1920 of the German language newspaper which had its beginnings in General Jackson's time.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Governors of the International Monetary Fund voted today to expel Communist Czechoslovakia, the lone member from behind the Iron Curtain.

The Tri-Continental Corporation, closed-end investment company, is offering to exchange two shares of a new $2.70 preferred stock of $50 par for each share of its outstanding no par $6 preferred stock.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Federal aid to states for conferences on education, from $5,000 to $61,426 in New York State, was made available today to the several Governors.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- As a preliminary to the Women's United States Senior Golf Association championship, 104 players took part in a Pinehurst-style scotch foursome tournament at the Westchester Country Club today.

SENNELAGER, Germany, Sept. 28 -- Atomic missiles will be a major weapon of the armies of the future, but will not supersede them, the commander-in-chief of the North Atlantic Alliance maneuver Battle Royal said today on conclusion of exercise.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board estimated today that the airlines would be paid $139,219,000 for carrying mail this fiscal year, and $141,193,000 in the year beginning next July 1.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Fairly large receipts helped depress hog prices today, butchers selling steady to as much as 40 cents down. Sows generally held steady.

Under a new agreement of city and state housing authorities, rents of more desirable apartments in new state-aided housing can be raised from the present $9 rate to $12.50 a room, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- British archaeologists are resigned to the probability that the site of the Roman temple of Mithras recently unearthed in the City of London will soon become the foundation of a new seven-story office building.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Sixteen nations signed today an international convention providing minimum standards for the treatment of stateless persons. It will become operative ninety days after receipt of the sixth instrument of ratification.

After conferring for seven hours behind closed doors yesterday on what to do about the moribund Philadelphia Athletics, the American League clubowners left the matter up in the air. Unable to reach an immediate decision, they adjourned until "after Oct. 12."
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Vonnie Colby of Hollywood, Fla., won medalist honors today in the women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament with a 77, one over women's par.

The Louisville Orchestra, conducted by Robert Whitney, will begin a thirteen-week concert series over the C. B. S. radio network on Saturday, Oct. 9, from 10:30 to 11 P. M. The series will feature the radio premieres of the works of twenty-four contemporary composers.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Disruption of all ship repairs in the Port of London was threatened here today when port workers belonging to the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions voted almost unanimously for strike action against the Ship Repairers' Association.

The promotional groups which are subjecting the population to one of the most high-pressure promotions ever conceived have taken great pains to inform the managerial group -- namely, water works superintendents -- that they are not competent to evaluate the merits of fluoridation or even rationalize on the subject.

While the new Soviet Government has launched a rather low tension campaign against the Russian Orthodox Church, it seems to have set its face firmly against the recurrent anti-Semitic policies of the Stalin regime.

An anecdotal profile of the several William Simpsons, who for five generations maintained "the oldest, best-known and most respected" pawnshop in the United States, will be published Oct. 18 by Random House. Called "Hockshop," it is written by William R. Simpson. Florence K. Simpson and Charles Samuels. Mr. Simpson is the great grandson of the William Simpson who began the family business in 1822 on New York's Chatham Street.
Trucking employers offered their 30,000 organized workers a 10-cent hourly wage-welfare package yesterday, but the union rejected it after two hours of deliberation.

There should be a general sigh of relief throughout the democratic West now that the resolution to support German rearmament has squeaked through the annual conference of the British Labor party at Scarborough. It was a close call, as it figured to be one way or another, but in a democracy like Britain the verdict of a majority, however slim, is accepted.
To be qualified to vote in New York a person must be:

SID CAESAR and Imogene Coca, who as a team once upon a time virtually monopolized Saturday night television, are going their separate ways this season. Mr. Caesar was first under the wire on Monday night and Miss Coca has her turn on Saturday evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- A bipartisan committee of Representatives was formed here today to spearhead a campaign for Federal funds to deepen the Delaware River channel from Trenton, N. J., to the sea.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A House subcommittee majority reported its opposition today to any Federal aid to the fine arts.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 28 -- Some well-informed European diplomats are speculating that the Soviet Government may offer to settle the German question if the London conference produces agreement in principle to arm the West Germans.

DENVER, Sept. 28 -- President Eisenhower was briefed today on plans for increasing Army strength to twenty-three combat divisions. Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens flew from Washington and was joined here by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 28 -- The sailors of the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club gained on every leg in a smart westerly breeze today, to become 1-up over their opponents of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club in the team racing for the Skoal Trophy.
A 23-year-old Staten Island bank teller, his wife and their three small children disappeared yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday. The close was 1 point off to 9 points up, with the far months showing the most strength.

Sausage meat, which costs several pennies less a pound than sausage links, may be combined with vegetables in a time-saving, meal-in-one-dish casserole. As an accompaniment to this savory dish a salad that includes fresh apple slices is particularly appropriate.
The Federal Maritime Board has given permission to the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company to transfer four ten-year-old tankers to Panamanian registry.
In 1626 the Indians sold Manhattan Island for the equivalent of $24. Yesterday the Indians reclaimed a small part of it, taking over the Polo Grounds for a two-hour pre-world series workout.

When the Cort Theatre was reserved recently for the incoming play, "The Rainmaker," due Oct. 28, it was expected that "The Fifth Season," current occupant of the Broadway playhouse, would move elsewhere. Plans for such a transfer, however, have been discarded in favor of a road tour.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The stock markets were quieter here today, the settling day for the last bookkeeping account and the Jewish New Year holiday. But the tone remained firm, and prices, where altered were generally improved.

THE diamond on which the Giants and the Indians will open the world series today is the remnant of a farm granted by the British Crown in the closing years of the seventeenth century to the Gardiners of Gardiners Island, a Captain Kidd treasure site.
Stanley L. Haines has been named director of industrial engineering of the American Locomotive Company, Schenectady.

J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, emphasizes in a magazine article the danger to civil liberties and national security inherent in the unauthorized use of confidential F. B. I. files.
William White expects soon to be back operating railway service out of the Grand Central Terminal -- this time as president of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad Corporation.
A top executive of a major oil company said yesterday that state control of gasoline station sites on toll highways is costing motorists considerable money.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- The Israeli delegation is drafting a protest to the United Nations Security Council in which it will demand that Egypt release the Bat Galim and her cargo and permit the ship to continue her voyage to Haifa.
CAIRO, Sept. 27 -- France and her Premier, Pierre Mendes-France, have replaced Britain and Sir Winston Churchill as the primary targets of the anti-imperialist campaign in Egypt's nationalist press.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, released a letter today from high Government housing officials saying that builders who had made "windfall" profits on Government-insured mortgages might be eligible for new loan insurance under certain circumstances.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- Governor Dewey named five New York City residents today to interim appointments on the bench. All are Republican candidates for the same judicial posts in this fall's election.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 -- Los Angels' first new legitimate theatre in nearly a generation opened last night in Hollywood.

LEO DUROCHER, who certainly must be used to it by now, laid himself open for the second guess by electing to start Sal Maglie in today's world series game. This isn't necessarily the wrong selection, mind you. It may even be the most penetrating and adroit maneuver of all. But the experts were arguing fiercely over the nomination of the Barber into the small hours of this morning.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The censure recommendation played second fiddle in European papers today to the nine-power conference on Germany. It received its biggest displays in Britain, Denmark and Holland. Elsewhere, papers either printed the story on back pages or ignored it altogether.

Frederick Wallach's suggestion in your issue of Sept. 18 that the United States make Western Germany a commonwealth offspring of this country, so that we may enlist German nationals in the United States Army, is novel, and startling in its implications. Dr. Wallach appears to hope that in this way we might hope to contain and control a revived German General Staff.

It is time that American business "stood up to be counted" in support of medical education, leading American business men declared yesterday in an observance of the incorporation of the National Fund for Medical Education.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Governor Dewey, held certain to stump the state for the Republican ticket this fall, will visit the Ithaca and Binghamton areas Oct. 6 in a tour of state construction projects.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today the failure of an equalizer caused the derailment of the Chicago-to-Los Angeles Santa Fe Chief at Lomax, Ill., on Aug. 22.
The Atlantic Coast wage scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association met here yesterday but disclosed no details about its new contract demands.
The Jews of New York yesterday began the year 5715 in the history of their religion with a renewal of the traditional covenants of peace with themselves, their neighbors and God.
MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- There is at least one place in the world, here on Red Square, where the dress designers obviously have not heard of Christian Dior and the flattened line.

Today's new film is "The Barefoot Contessa," co-starring Humphrey Bogart and Ava Gardner and written and directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz for Figaro Productions and United Artists release, at the Capitol Theatre. The technicolor drama was filmed in Italy, with a supporting cast headed by Edmond O'Brien, Marius Goring, Valentina Cortesa and Rossano Brazzi.

In his 1948 book Mr. Bean estimated that the Presidential vote that year would be "well above 55 million," and he wrote that "this and other indications could be taken as pointing to victory for the Democratic candidate in 1948, with a popular vote of 54 to 55 per cent -- in a two-party contest."

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 28 -- The Democrats are preparing to put the Eisenhower Administration's power "partnership" program under fire in this state as the Congressional election campaign, involving seven House seats, begins to roll. Neither unemployment nor the Benson farm program is the big issue it once had promised to be.

In his 1948 book Mr. Bean estimated that the Presidential vote that year would be "well above 55 million," and he wrote that "this and other indications could be taken as pointing to victory for the Democratic candidate in 1948, with a popular vote of 54 to 55 per cent -- in a two-party contest."

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 28 -- The Democrats are preparing to put the Eisenhower Administration's power "partnership" program under fire in this state as the Congressional election campaign, involving seven House seats, begins to roll. Neither unemployment nor the Benson farm program is the big issue it once had promised to be.

Cocoa prices fell the cent-a-pound limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The decrease reflected trade hedge selling and liquidation with little buying by manufacturers. Trading was light, with 107 lots changing hands. The spot prices fell 1 cent a pound, with Accras at 52.45 cents and Bahias at 46.2 cents.
The Armour Research Foundation of the Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, announced plans yesterday for what it said would be the first nuclear reactor for industrial research.

The world series may be watched by donors to the New York regional Red Cross blood program at the Brooklyn Chapter House, 57 Willoughby Street. Two television receiving sets have been installed there -- one in the room where the blood is taken and the other in the canteen room -- for the Giants-Indians baseball games by courtesy of Dave Adelman, appliance dealer.
YONKERS, Sept. 28 (AP) -- George Phalen posted a double at Yonkers Raceway tonight -- the $152.50 daily double.
TORONTO, Sept. 28 (Canadian Press) -- The United Automobile Workers of America (C. I. O. C. C. L.) today set a strike deadline of Sunday for Ford of Canada's Windsor plant.

An Institute for Veterinary Research that will investigate diseases of pets ranging from the dermatological to the psychological has been announced by the Speyer Hospital for Animals. The University of Pennsylvania is an affiliate of the research unit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A Government witness who said he had once been an undercover Communist for a Toledo, Ohio, detective agency disclaimed any knowledge today that his employer had then been running "a notorious strike-breaking agency."

Arthur Krock's column of Sept. 21 on "the confusing effects" of "the harmless pastime" of interpreting the Maine election results contains a paragraph that needs straightening out in the interest of correct reporting.
Senator Irving M. Ives indicated strongly yesterday that he would refrain from comment prior to the election on the report recommending censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country on the Watkins Committee report recommending Senate censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, as gathered by The New York Times:
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The nine-power conference opened today with progress toward arming West Germany within the Atlantic community and toward that country's sovereignty.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The number of new polio cases outside New York City this year rose to 747 last week -- a drop of 666 from a year ago, the State Health Department said today.

As the representatives of nine nations were preparing for their meeting in London to discuss the future of a good part of the Western World throngs of Londoners were walking past the ruins of a Roman temple recently uncovered in the heart of their city.
The sale of $25,000,000 of new 3 1/2 per cent mortgage bonds to a group of institutional investors was announced yesterday by the Puget Sound Power and Light Company.

MILFORD, Del., Sept. 28 -- The revolt against racial integration in this school district spread today to the village of Lincoln, four miles south of here, while attendance at the previously all-white Milford School rose slightly.

Former Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, who in 1952 introduced a resolution calling for Senator McCarthy's expulsion from the Senate, declared last night the Senate should censure him and force him to answer questions about his finances.

On the theory that Democratic-Liberal chances of winning depend primarily on the size of the New York City vote, Averell Harriman and his running mates will start today an intensive get-out-the-vote drive.

It certainly seems a great pity that there is a reactionary element in the Republican party attempting (not infrequently successfully) to dominate party policy and procedure -- to party shame and defeat.

A new building at 34-21 Fifty-sixth Street in Woodside, Queens, containing 6,800 square feet of space, has been leased by the American Bosch Corporation from the Lonard Corporation. The lessee will use the building for distribution purposes in Queens County.
Leaders in the mutual savings bank field renewed their demands yesterday to expand the system.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 28 -- Two of Indonesia's principal Opposition leaders have warned that Indonesia will play directly into Communist hands if she enters into a nonaggression pact with Red China. These standpoints were taken following reports that Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo, now in Rangoon after a flying visit to New Delhi, is trying to induce Premier Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Premier U Nu of Burma into a nonaggression treaty with Peiping.

I was intrigued by the suggestion of Charles B. Collins that, in the matter of military aircraft, territorial waters should be extended to 100 miles offshore. One sentence in his letter reads, "All nations would find this a convenient rule."

SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 28 -- By the slender margin of 248,000 votes out of more than 6,000,000, the Labor party reaffirmed today its support of the policy of arming West Germany within the Western European defense system.

I notice in The Times of Sept. 24 another of the frequent articles your newspaper has carried on the subject of auto safety. This time it reports that T. W. Ryan of the State Division of Safety lays the blame for rising highway accidents at the door of the drivers who profess to be the best citizens.
