Despite the "new look" put on the horrors of Soviet existence by the Malenkov regime, as recounted by Harrison E. Salisbury, there is growing evidence both of continued opposition among the masses and of spreading revolt among members of the state apparatus charged with imposing the terror by which that apparatus rules.

Yesterday it was California's turn to take the center of the fashion stage in New York. A show of designs by Irene was presented at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the aegis of Gunther Jaeckel where the entire collection is available.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 28 -- Some indication was given here today as to where and how the Moral Re-Armament Movement obtained financial backing to conduct its international campaign for a new and better world.
Veal shoulder, one of the most attractive offerings at meat counters now, makes a delicious roast when it is boned, well seasoned with herbs and spices, rolled, tied and cooked in a slow oven.

AFTER thirty years the Cherry Lane Theatre is housing "The Way of The World" again. That is a good idea. For the Congreve comedy is much revered in school and college, though it seldom reaches the professional stage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 22:
MILFORD, Del., Sept. 29 -Segregationists stepped up their protest activities today as the revolt against racial integration in the local high school spread to other communities in Sussex County.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Eight historic houses in this part of northern Westchester will be opened to visitors on Saturday during the third annual open house of the county Historical Society.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 29 -- Political leaders were awaiting a ruling today on procedure to be followed in choosing a successor to Democratic Senator Pat McCarran, who died unexpectedly last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Army awarded today to the Chrysler Corporation a $160,601,200 contract for Patton M-48 medium tanks, now built solely by the General Motors Corporation.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Chinese Nationalist Government reported forty Communist craft, sighted today east of a small island in the Nationalist-held Matsu group [1 on map] off Fukien Province, had fled after coastal guns opened fire.
There will be a "command performance" in Bay Ridge Magistrate's Court on Oct. 8 for 11,500 defendants who have violated the Multiple Dwelling Law.

An ill wind, the Indians said, blew them out of the ball game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The same left-to-right air current that prevented Jim Hegan's long drive to left from going into the stands in the eighth inning pushed Dusty Rhodes' game-winning homer into the stands in the tenth, they insisted.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Hogs fell to a new low since February, 1953, as 50 to 75 cents was cut off values of butchers today. Sows mainly lost 25 cents.

ESSEX FELLS N. J., Sept. 29 -- Clifford P. Case declared here today that the election of President Eisenhower in 1952 ended twenty years of demagogic government that had left the United States in "poor shape" and its people "insecure."
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) --Al Andrews landed a hard right at the outset of the third round to Knock out Gil Turner in an upset at the Chicago Stadium tonight.
SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 29 -- Aneurin Bevan called tonight for a change in the leadership of the Labor party.
Events tonight: "La Cenerentola," City Center, 8:15 o'clock; Stephan Kovacs, pianist-composer, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
Sales of Gimbels Brothers, Inc., for the six months ended on July 31 declined 4.7 per cent from those of a year before and earnings fell 54.1 per cent.
A new communications system that permits the motorman of a moving subway train to talk to his dispatcher's office will be put in use experimentally tomorrow on the Flushing line of the I. R. T.

About half of the 400,000 square feet of office space in the twenty-seven-story building to be built at 20 Broad Street, adjoining the New York Stock Exchange, has been rented since plans for the structure were announced nearly three months ago, according to Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent.
William A. Lyon, state Superintendent of Banks, predicted last night that the savings banks in this state would achieve their aim of broader branch powers.
The Hercules Powder Company announced yesterday the election to its board of L. W. Babcock, director of personnel; John E. Goodman, treasurer, and Ernest S. Wilson, director of engineering.
Macon County, Ill., sold $7,030,000 of Decatur School District 61 bonds in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 1.941 per cent. The bonds mature from 1955 to 1973.

The opening of this fall's season of the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., at the City Center marks the rounding out of a full decade of activity by this organization. For ten years the company has pioneered in operatic repertory, first under the direction of Laszlo Halasz and now under Dr. Joseph Rosenstock.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 10 points yesterday.

BANDAR PAHLEVI, Iran, Sept. 19 -- The Iranian National Fisheries Company, which annually earns in caviar alone more than half the $2,500,000 value of its properties, has embarked on a coordinated expansion program. The program includes:
TRENTON, Sept. 29 -- A candidate for office in Mercer County running under the designation of the Communist party lost a place on the election ballot in court today.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 29 -Off to its most encouraging start in recent years with its victory over Holy Cross, the Dartmouth football team is preparing for the arrival of a strong Navy eleven Saturday.
Parents should be able to make gifts of common stocks to their children without going through legal labyrinths, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The United States agreed today to consider financial support of the French Expeditionary Corps in Indochina during its gradual withdrawal and replacement by native armies.

HAVANA, Sept. 29 -- Cuban baseball fans watched the opening game of the world series today in the first direct television broadcast from the United States to Cuba. The program was arranged by CMQ-TV, Cuba's largest radio and television system.

The chairman of the Republican National Committee echoed a bit of wishful thinking indulged in by many political professionals when he said that the American public was "sick and tired" of the McCarthy issue and that it would have not "one iota of effect on the election."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -Underdeveloped nations told the World Bank today that their need for investment to promote economic growth was one the free world could ignore "only at risk of its own survival."

Strong and continuing national advertising was urged yesterday by Mortimer Berkowitz, treasurer of Brief Publishing, Inc., to put baked products back in the running against the competition of low-calorie foods and drinks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered hearings today that might result in trimming millions of dollars from the transatlantic mail subsidies paid two major airlines.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -Floyd Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, left here today for the United States after conferring with President Juan D. Peron on four investment projects which have been under negotiation since last July.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -Gen. James A. Van Fleet told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that the Korean war was "the right war" to win against the Communsits, that it could have been won and that it could be won even today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner said today that he has asked the Justime Department "to press a treason charge" against John W. Powell, former editor of a magazine in Red China and now a lecturer and free-lance writer in this country.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The stock market here was quieter and less firm today. British Government securities tended to improve in late dealings but industrials closed irregularly. Dullness among industrials was relieved by only a few individual rises but falls were small.
Belgium is in effect betting $200,000,000 that there will be no major international disturbance before 1958. She is asking other nations, including Russia and her satellites, to bet also.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration announced today a reduction in the interest rate on business disaster loans from 5 to 3 per cent. The rate to companies damaged by fire, storm, hurricane or other disasters is now the same as that for homeowners.

The second day of the celebration by Jews of the opening of their New Year 5715 was marked yesterday by the services of Rosh ha-Shanah that were attended by members of Conservative and Orthodox congregations.

TIME'S mellowing process is evident in the work of Mervin Jules, whose recent paintings at the ACA Gallery make up his first one-man show in several years. The somewhat brash expressionism and overcharged emotional reactions of his earlier work have given way to more considered organization, subtler color and greater clarity of expression as well as greater diversity of theme.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The United States and Britain pledged full military support for a united Europe today. Thus they broke the back of French resistance to the restoration of West Germany's military and political independence.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 29 -- A Federal District Judge here said today that he would withhold his decision in a public school segregation case until two weeks after the Federal Supreme Court had decided on the manner in which its decision outlawing public school segregation could be put into effect.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 29 -Gabriel Alarcon, millionaire theatre owner, surrendered to judicial authorities today in connection with the murder last month of Alfonso Mascarua, a leader of the motion picture industry workers union.

A biographical assessment of John Stuart Mill by Michael St. John Packe will be published Oct. 26 by Macmillan. Mr. Packe, who is History Scholar of Magdalene College, Cambridge, has had access to source material heretofore unavailable, including 180 unpublished manuscripts and letters.

A group of five Latin-American insurance companies have set up a trust fund here that is designed to insure payment in dollars of premiums and claims on them by their American and Canadian policyholders of fire and allied line insurance.

The New York City Opera Company, one of the City Center's main enterprises, is playing it safe this fall for the good reason that it cannot afford to do otherwise. Nothing follows more naturally than that it should turn to "Aida" for its opening night.

The Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company sold $10,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds due 1984 to Lee Higginson Corporation and associates yesterday. The award was made on a bid of 102.22 for a 3 1/4 per cent coupon.
The city moved yesterday to smash a baggage racket at the piers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--Senator William E. Jenner today invited Senator Arthur V. Watkins, chairman of the committee that recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, to testify on his proposals for Senate rules changes.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 29 -Jawaharlal Nehru, the Indian Prime Minister, said today that apprehension was caused by the presence of large Chinese populations and by the nature of Communist parties.
The skipper told me to "grab a bat" in the tenth inning, but I gues I reached out and grabbed the brass ring instead.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Sept. 29 -- The first of nine segments of the 240-ton shield of the Lincoln Tunnel's third tube was lowered into place late today at the bottom of the tube's ventilating shaft fifty-five feet below the foot of King's Bluff.
DENVER, Sept. 29 -- President Eisenhower declared today that "no institution is more necessary to our way of life than a free press."

A decline last week of 642,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 151,145,000 barrels, compared with 151,787,000 a week earlier and 140,298,000 a year before.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Sept. 29 -- Hilda Lusberg, 7 - year - old Uniondale girl whose life has hung on a thread since she was burned last Feb. 8, was reported today to be in an extremely critical condition at Meadowbrook Hospital.

Rivalry between waterfront unions in the Port of New York became more complicated yesterday as two leading American Federation of Labor pier leaders reversed themselves and promised a continuing fight against the old International Longshoremen's Association.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schols, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

DENVER, Sept. 29 -- There probably will be no announcement on a revised list of "security risks" separated from their Federal jobs until the next meeting of the National Security Council, it was said today at President Eisenhower's headquarters.
General trucking companies in the New York-New Jersey area offered yesterday to submit their dispute with eleven teamster locals to binding arbitration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The soft coal industry is being pinched by nonstrike economic pressure, it hasn't experienced in a quarter century.

GUATEMALA, Sept. 29 -- The Presidents of Guatemala and El Salvador reaffirmed the friendship of the two Governments at a border meeting yesterday, President Carlos Castillo Armas told a press conference today.

CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 29 -New Hampshire Republicans launched the 1954 campaign today with a warning from Vice President Richard M. Nixon that their state was a target for left-wing groups "sniping" particularly at Senator Styles Bridges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission today authorized two independent natural gas producers to sell gas to interstate pipeline companies -- the first formal authorizations to independent producers since the commission assumed jurisdiction over them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -Following is the text of the communique, made available at the State Department tonight, on the talks here this week between Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Acting Secretary of State; Guy La Chambre, French Minister of State for Relations with the three Associated States, and Edgar Faure, Finance Minister of France:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- National political leaders inclined to the belief tonight that the Republicans would not pick up a seat in the battle for Senate control as a result of the death of Senator McCarran.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The Israeli delegation to the United Nations sent a letter to the Security Council today protesting Egypt's seizure of the freighter Bat Galim. The letter did not ask for a meeting on the matter but indicated that Israel would do so if the ship was not freed and permitted to go through the Suez Canal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Members of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America were told today that shopping centers are not going to displace trade areas of our big cities or the main streets of smaller communities. Instead, they will merely take the pressure off the downtown centers by providing outlying areas with convenient buying facilities.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 29 (AP) -A new warrant charging John David Provoo, former Army staff sergeant with treason while a prisoner of the Japanese during World War II, was issued here late today.
Freedom of information must be protected against demagogues, Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, former president of the General Assembly of the United Nations, said last night.
NEWMARKET, Eng., Sept. 29 (UP) -- Britain's "Wonder Boy" jockey, 18-year-old Lester Piggott, staged a successful comeback to racing today after his suspension from the turf of 102 days.

Oliver Wendell Holmes found an inspirational message of great power in a certain species of South Pacific mollusk and proceeded to write a poem that has since become familiar to generations of American school children.

The Canadian National Railways System has a tight rein on operating expenses but management of the road said again yesterday that it expected 1954 results to be written in red ink. A month ago the company declared it would have an "over-all deficit for the year."

FAIRMONT, W. Va., Sept. 29 -- Under the protection of a court injunction the Annabelle Grade School in near-by Four States reopened without incident this morning with 95 per cent of its 171 pupils present.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Doris Day plans to star next year in "Nothing But a Woman," a musical with a Western back-ground, to be produced by Arwin Productions, Inc. The independent company is owned by the star and her husband, Martin Melcher, and they anticipate making a production-distribution arrangement with Warner Brothers. The latter company has Miss Day under contract.
William White, who was president of the New York Central Railroad System at $120,000 a year until June 14, when Robert R. Young won control of the road, went back to work yesterday.

WELLSBURG, W. Va., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Six Follansbee Steel Corporation shareholders took preliminary steps to day to halt sale of the concern to New York interests, headed by Frederick W. Richmond, for a reported $9,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The ninth annual meeting of the governors of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank ended today without moving any closer toward convertibility of currencies.
Many persons prominent in society are working toward the success of the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue on Oct. 14 in the St. Regis Roof.

Today is the first of six days, nonconsecutive because of the week-end and religious holidays, in which eligible residents of New York City and Westchester County can and must register if they are to vote on Nov. 2. The hours of registration, today and tomorrow, are 3:30 P. M. to 10:30 P. M.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The Woodland Farm's Blue Sparkler, with Glen Lasswell up, sped to her third straight triumph today when she defeated eight other 2-year-olds in the $11,450 Home Bred Stakes.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 29 -- The threat of a strike against the General Electric Company was contained in a resolution adopted here today by delegates to the sixth annual convention of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O.
DENVER, Sept. 29 -- President Eisenhower, who will be 64 years old on Oct. 14, appears to be "maintaining an excellent state of health."

VIENNA, Sept. 29 -- Bruno Folta, former announcer for Radio Free Europe, said today in Bratislava that he had voluntarily returned to Czechoslovakia to "make good his past offenses" against his country.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate, presented his Government's $10,400,000 check today to the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The United Nations heard a warning today from one of its perennial targets -- the Union of South Africa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A Senate subcommittee investigating the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract renewed today an earlier request to the Atomic Energy Commission to delay final action on the contract until the subcommittee's inquiry was finished.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 29 (UP) -A Detroit friend of Pfc. G. David Schine paid a $224 storage charge on a car he had loaned Private Schine after the automobile was attached by Sheriff's deputies here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A statement by a State Department spokesman and views expressed by diplomatic officials here today appeared to confirm a Washington dispatch in The New York Times of today that Italy and Yugoslavia had reached a settlement of their dispute over Trieste.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The State Department announced today it had engaged the American National Theatre and Academy to encourage and facilitate foreign tours by American entertainers and cultural groups in the musical, theatrical and other fields.

AS United States representative in the Economic and Social Council, this is to correct the record which I am sure was unwittingly presented incorrectly in the letter of Jonathan Bingham to you published Sept. 23.

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The texts of statements by Secretary of State Dulles and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and of a communique of the nine-power conference on West Germany's armament and Western defense:
LONDON, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- A battle of the giants is shaping up here between Britain's biggest automobile maker and subsidiaries of the Ford Motor Company and General Motors Corporation.

"The Boy Friend," a British musical dealing with the "Roaring Twenties" and complete with cloche hats, knee-length skirts, the recently restored boyish chestline and the Charleston, will open at the Royale Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.

In spite of raised eyebrows at Police Headquarters when the plan was first proposed, some sixty-four women and four men wearing police caps, white belts and yellow arm bands are now protecting children in the Bronx from traffic as they cross the streets to school -- and more will be recruited.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics announced today they had signed nine players for assignment to their minor league farm clubs.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- An estimated 2,000,000 American baseball fans in Europe, deprived of the chance to see the 1954 world series on television, did the next best thing tonight and crowded around their radios to hear special broadcasts of the opening game.
TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 29 -There is a saying here that about every twenty years Kansas has a drought and elects a Democrat to a state-wide office.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 29 (AP) -Harlow H. Curtice said today General Motors would introduce "the hottest car in the world in the lower price class" in 1955. The new car would be shown for the first time about Nov. 1.
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. campaigned with the aid of a Dixieland jazz band last night in Harlem to stimulate the registration of voters.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Army made it official today that, despite a manpower cut of 231,000, the number of its combat divisions would be increased from nineteen to twenty-four.
A pension plan is assured for a union of deck officers who man ships on all three coasts of the United States, with only a $25 gap between employer and union proposals, it was learned yesterday.
Senator Irving M. Ives, the Republican candidate for Governor, will concentrate his bid for upstate support in two tours, the first to start next Monday and continue though Thursday.

OTTAWA, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Led by shipments of wheat and other grains, Canada's exports to all countries dropped 5.8 per cent in August compared with a year earlier. Prices were down 3.4 per cent. The Bureau of Statistics reported today that August exports dropped to $322,700,000 from $342,600,000 in August, 1953, despite increased shipments of wood products, wood pulp, newsprint, aluminum, copper and nickel.

The gain in textile sales that began in August has gained sufficient momentum to continue through the balance of the year and well into 1955, according to J. Spencer Love, chairman of the board of Burlington Mills Corporation.

Government and business can best contribute to stability and growth by trying to avoid or minimize booms instead of endeavoring to perpetuate them, according to the Guaranty Survey, monthly publication of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Films of nine football games to be played by Notre Dame, currently ranked as the number one team in the nation, will be televised over Channel 9 beginning Sunday from 9 to 10 P. M. The series leads off with the Fighting Irish-Purdue encounter scheduled for Saturday.

The stock market eased yesterday in moderately active dealings. Almost all major divisions were mixed or lower, with the railroad section the softest. Some key issues, such as General Motors and du Pont, were in rather heavy supply.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Senator Frank Carlson denied tonight that the Eisenhower Administration tax revision law was "a tax reform for the chief benefit of big business and wealthy individuals."
By common consent, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy appears to have been discarded as a possible campaign issue in New York by both major candidates for Governor.

NEWARK, Sept. 29 -- An automobile plummeted into a thirtyfoot cut of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad this morning, delaying thousands of east-bound commuters on twentyfive trains from eleven to fortyfour minutes.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 -- A two-hour "cooling-off" recess was called today to halt a verbal clash between two members of a House subcommittee investigating labor racketeering.

Brazil's Consul General in New York, Hugo Gouthier, proposed yesterday that this country's Congress enact flexible legislation to allow special income tax treatment for Americans who invest in economic developments in Brazil and other Latin American countries.
Fog halted all flights last night at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. Fourteen flights were canceled, thirty-seven diverted and six more were delayed until this morning.
The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn is going into the orchid business, more or less, and is scheduling advertising in all the major metropolitan newspapers and on several radio programs to say so.

Debutantes from New York and other cities, as well as many young women from European and South American countries, will be presented formally to society at the first International Debutante Ball to be held on Nov. 23 in the ballroom of the Plaza.

At precisely 4:12 o'clock by the huge clock atop the center-field clubhouse at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, Leo Durocher peered intently at his hand and decided it was time to play his trump card.
One man was injured slightly yesterday morning in a scuffle involving members of rival electrical workers' unions at the New Yorker Hotel. The police were called to restore order.

The comparison of today's travel wardrobes with those of fifty years ago was the novel theme of a fashion show yesterday at Best Co. Presented in collaboration with Pan American Airlines, it marked the fiftieth anniversary of the David Crystal sportswear concern.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France appears to have obtained from Britain today a commitment similar to that the French tried in vain to get at the Bermuda conference last December.

The State Department yesterday expressed cautious hope over the possibilities for a solution of the Trieste dispute. When it comes to Trieste there is good reason for caution until an agreement is signed and sealed. There have been so many disappointments in the past year that the proper attitude for the moment had better be to keep one's fingers crossed.
Your readers may be interested in the American Civil Liberties Union's view of the report of the Senate Select Committee on the censure charges against Senator McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -John Roosevelt, youngest son of the former Democratic President, was named today as vice chairman of the National Citizens for Eisenhower drive to elect a Republican Congress.
Revenues and net income of the Philadelphia Electric Company and subsidiaries increased for the twelve months ended on July 31, the company reported yesterday.

Last fall, C. Mahlon Kline's Kaster endeared himself to a few of Belmont Park's customers by scoring at 30 to 1 in the Highweight Handicap. Yesterday, in a $15,000-added grass course handicap, Kaster had thousands of the 21,399 onlookers rooting for him.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Buying demand for wheat was slow today, and there was less mill interest than yesterday. Offerings increased on the hard spots, with free selling of the July late in the session.

Four United States Representatives who were instrumental in obtaining legislation that placed the United States Marine Academy at Kings Point, N. Y., on even terms with the three other Federal academies, are to be honored at a dinner of the New York chapter of the marine academy's alumni association.

Communist China's parliament, the National People's Congress, closed its first session on Tuesday after transacting such business as the adoption of a Constitution and the election of the first nominally constitutional Government of Communist China. So far as can be judged from the available evidence, matters went smoothly and with as little dissent or real parliamentary activity as one observes in a meeting of Russia's Supreme Soviet.

HONGKONG, Sept. 29 -- According to a delayed dispatch from Peiping, China's worst floods of the past century inundated 41,665 square miles of land this year. The report was carried today by the Hsinhua (New China) news agency.

In a dispatch from Washington printed in The New York Times of Sept. 27 your correspondent states that "the State Department is searching hard for a replacement for George V. Allen in the highly important and demanding post of Ambassador to India."

Coffee and cocoa prices fell yesterday in active trading on the New York exchanges. Coffee was off the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit in all positions except September, 1955, and cocoa tumbled the 1-cent limit in the nearby December option.

Many parties will be given at the Fiesta Dinner Dance for the benefit of the Anglo-American Hospital in Madrid to be held tonight at the formal opening for this season of the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Angier Biddle Duke heads the committee for the event and among her aides is Mrs. Jay Rutherfurd.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The playback today of a tape recording showed The Associated Press misquoted Vice President Richard M. Nixon in a speech at Huron, S. D., Sept. 18.

The United Nations is now formally called upon to deal with a particularly sinister stratagem which has become a weapon of Communist imperialism and expansion. This stratagem, which won its most spectacular triumph in Czechoslovakia but threatens many other nations as well, is Communist subversion designed to undermine and overthrow the Governments and social orders of other countries as a step toward their conquest and incorporation into the Communist bloc.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The Most Rev. Dr. Cyril Garbett, Archbishop of York, decried today a campaign of "hate" against Britain that has been launched by Greek advocates of uniting the island of Cyprus with Greece.
The city asked the Supreme Court yesterday to declare unconstitutional the state law that recently gave the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road back to the Pennsylvania Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Secretary of Labor, William P. Mitchell, announced today "a department-wide program for the improvement of the status of women workers."

Registration in New York City and Westchester for this year's state election starts today and will continue, with two breaks, until a week from Saturday. In all, the registry books will be open for six days.
In an impish mood, the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Dr. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, teased ship news reporters yesterday who saw him off for England aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The United States wants the proposed new agency for developing peaceful uses of atomic energy to be on a basis corresponding to that of a specialized agency of the United Nations.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Stenographer, a 3-year-old trotting filly from Camp Hill, Pa., scored another victory today as the ten-day Grand Circuit meeting opened here.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- A vast increase in productivity in West Europe's industry, agriculture and commerce was presented today as the next important task of the organization for European Economic Cooperation.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 29 -Indiana's progress in dealing with the increasingly serious problem of mental illness was praised today by the American Psychiatric Association, which has a reputation for being hard to please.
HALIFAX, N. S., Sept. 29 -Canada's four Atlantic provinces took steps yesterday to improve their economy and the lot of their people.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 29 -- The Russians and Swedes are now committed to mutual aid in all rescue operations in the Baltic Sea. A treaty signed in Moscow today provides for continuous liaison between the maritime rescue services of both countries with a view to safeguarding human lives. The pact also covers aircraft.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey said today the Eisenhower Administration was trying to achieve "the highest possible level" of world trade that is "consistent with our national security and interest."

There were 52,751 paying spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday for the opening contest of the 1954 world series and, barring proof to the contrary, 52,750 saw Dusty Rhodes break up the ball game with his tenth-inning pinch homer.

Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, predicted last night that West German armament and the tactical use of the atomic bomb could produce in three or four years a reasonably good chance of preventing the Soviet Union from overruning Europe.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The Executive Committee of the French Socialist party took strong disciplinary action today against fiftythree of the party's Deputies who voted against the European Defense Community Aug. 30 in the National Assembly.

Underwriting of an offering of 910,883 additional shares of common stock to the New England Electric System's stockholders will be made by an investment banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers and Bear, Stearns Co., it was announced yesterday.

In an effort to accommodate thousands of potential kindergarten children who have been crowded out of their home district schools, Board of Education officials advised principals yesterday to eliminate district lines.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon predicted today that the Republicans would pick up Senate seats in Illinois and Ohio at the November election, but "have an uphill fight" to retain control of the House of Representatives.
Parents who try to smoothe all the bumps from their youngsters' paths and strive to keep childhood a rosy dream actually hinder their children's growing-up, Dr. Norman J. Levy declared last night.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Gene Martin, an 18-year-old rider from St. Louis, scored four consecutive victories at Suffolk Downs today -- culminating his streak with a triumph aboard Dave Borenstein's Kay Russell in the Arlington Purse.

OREGON CITY, Ore., Sept. 29 -- Here in green valleys below snop-capped Mount Hood, a filbert crop of close to bumper proportions will be harvested beginning next month. Of the nation's entire production of this nut, grown only in Oregon and Washington, 85 per cent comes from orchards within a fifty-mile radius of Portland.
Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan, en route to Europe, made a single public appearance here yesterday to tell off Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Roger Wybot, head of a French security service, today filed a suit for damages against Jean Dides, police inspector, who had charged M. Wybot with having been a Communist. This was the latest development in the controversy that has gathered round the investigation of a series of leaks of French defense secrets.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Swollen by torrential rains, flooding rivers rampaged through the towns and banana plantations of Northwest Honduras today. The United States Embassy sent a message for United States help in coping with the threat of "national disaster."

TOMORROW should serve as the deadline for those who are planning to hunt at distant camps during the season. The week-end should provide a final opportunity for checking near-by covers, for October will find upland game, waterfowl and even big-game seasons opening in many areas from Maine to New Jersey.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 29 -- Hard, wet sailing on Long Island Sound brought an end to the Skoal Trophy series today, with the helmsmen of the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club in possession of the prize and those of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club absorbing both a sound thumping and the misfortune of a dismasted boat.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- Senator William F. Knowland accused Clement Attlee, former British Prime Minister, today of putting "his moral stamp of approval upon a future aggression which the Communist leaders of China have announced they will make."

A new organization representing 240,000 American engineers and scientists has been set up to study nuclear engineering problems concerned with producing usable electricity at economical rates from atomic energy.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury and admirer of the Soviet Union, testified today at the United States Embassy that he was not and had not been a member of the Communist party. He declared that he did not regard himself as part of the world Communist movement.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Sept. 29 (UP) -- Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., and Mary Lena Faulk of the host club paced the favorites through the first round of the twenty-fourth women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today.

THE Merriwell boys are still in business. In another of their frantic and fictional finishes, the Giants wrenched the opening game of the world series from the Indians at the Polo Grounds yesterday. They did it in the same implausible fashion they had used for winning the big ones all year long -- with a pinch-hit home run.
YONKERS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The favored True Dale, a 5-year-old horse, was driven to victory by Tommy Winn in the featured Fordham Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, says the United States must expect the Soviet Union to reach "the atomic absolute" of power in 1956, with enough hydrogen weapons and bomber planes to destroy major United States cities and industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Entangled in this year's campaign for the control of the Eighty-fourth Congress and certain state governments are the political fortunes of many men and women, but five are outstanding. Some general and some particular decisions of the voters of Nov. 2 will determine the degree of their political influence hereafter, especially in the national conventions and Presidential campaign of 1956.

In its reply to my Sept. 13 letter to The Times the Indonesian Embassy has twisted and turned in a vain effort to deny that the present Sastroamidjojo regime is leading Indonesia toward communism. The embassy has also attempted to discredit the Islamic Republic of Indonesia with the charge of terrorism.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Sept. 29 -- On what one of the members of the faculty called "the nicest afternoon of the whole summer," the Choate School's football squad went through an intensive workout today. It was a session designed to brush up on the weak spots uncovered in the Blue and Gold's practice scrimmage against Hamden High's varsity yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29 -- The 145-year-old Harvard Divinity School opened today what the university president, Dr. Natham M. Pusey, termed "a further new and inspiring chapter" in its history.
ROME, Sept. 29 -- Italy is making no significant progress in overcoming her greatest economic and social problem -- unemployment.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of the 870 applicants for admission to the bar who passed the examination given last June 29 and 30. The examination was taken by 1,844 persons.

QUAKERTOWN, N. J., Sept. 29 -- Representative Charles R. Howell charged here tonight that the Eisenhower Administration had lost and failed to regain the initiative in world affairs and was unable to restore prosperity on the home front.

A syndicate organized by Irving Enkells, real estate operator, has purchased the four apartment houses at 161 to 167 East Ninetyfifth Street, near Lexington Avenue. The property, assessed at $190,000, comprises fifty-nine suites in units of two to four rooms.

It was difficult to find the No. 1 hero in the Giants' clubhouse yesterday. Of course, Dusty Rhodes, who popped Bob Lemon's first pitch into the right field stands to win the ball game, was a big man.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Robert F. Beard of Gladwyne, Pa., assumed the lead in the Women's United States Senior Golf Association championship today.
A plan for integration of the Police Academy and the Bernard M. Baruch School of Business Administration at City College was sent yesterday by Mayor Wagner to the Board of Higher Education.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 29 -President Syngman Rhee said tonight the front lines were collapsing as a result of the sudden United Nations troop withdrawal. No plan has been prepared by United Nations military leaders to fill the gaps left by the departing divisions, he said, and South Korean troops are being abandoned, thereby inviting a new Red offensive.

The New York Public Library will go on winter schedule tomorrow. Seven of the divisions in the Fifth Avenue, building at Fortysecond Street will be open until 10 P. M. on Monday and Thursday nights and from 1 to 6 P. M. Sundays.
ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Governor Dewey will make two trips within a few weeks to participate in ceremonies at four state construction projects.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -Jozef Swiatlo, former Polish secret police official, said today he believed Noel Field and his wife Herta, United States citizens seized by Hungary five years ago, were dead.

Electric power production in the week ended on last Saturday declined to 9,072,000,000 kilowatt -hours from 9,074,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended on Sept. 26, 1953, was 8,354,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Admiral Robert Bostwick Carney -the Chief of Naval Operations to official Washington but "Mick" Carney to the Navy -- and some 2,600 other graduates of the nation's School of the Sea thronged the streets of Annapolis last week-end for the annual alumni "homecoming."

KENT, Conn., Sept. 30 -- The Kent School football team has an experienced line, but the backfield is somewhat of a question mark. That's how Chester H. Brown, head coach, described his Blue and Gray eleven today.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Naked Alibi," a Universal-International drama with Sterling Hayden and Gloria Grahame, is at the Paramount. Ross Hunter produced and Jerry Hopper directed, from a screen play by Lawrence Roman and an original story by J. Robert Bren and Gladys Atwater.

The honorary chairmanship of the 1954-55 national campaign of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation has been accepted by Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower. The drive will begin on Nov. 15. Its goal is $5,000,000.

Irwin D. Davidson, a Special Sessions Justice, was chosen last night to replace Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as the Democratic candidate for Congress in the Twentieth District. Mr. Roosevelt had withdrawn as a candidate after his nomination for Attorney General on the Democratic and Liberal tickets.

Arthur Levitt, the new candidate for State Controller on the Democratic-Liberal ticket headed by Averell Harriman, proposed last night that the state vastly increase its activities in the field of education.

TRENTON, Sept. 30 -- State Treasurer Archibald S. Alexander issued a report here today charging two former state officials with having deprived New Jersey of $600,000 to nearly $1,000,000 in interest on its funds over a five-year period.

George P. McKinney, a 27year-old automobile salesman, told Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers and a jury of six men and six women yesterday how he and two confederates planned the successful robbery of $190,319 from a Long Island bank on Aug. 18, 1953.

PARIS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A Venezuelan mission, headed by Col. Luis Felipe Llovera Paez, will leave for New York Saturday to receive proposals from American groups on the building of a steel industry in the South American country.

The proposed amendment to the New York City Building Law to send alleged building violations directly to the Magistrates' courts, without giving home owners the opportunity of adequate administrative discussion or removal of violation, will make potential criminals out of more than 500,000 property owners of this city and will improperly transfer administrative functions to judges who are not equipped to handle them.
The statements by Aaron L. Jacoby and his running mates follow:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy filed today a "bill of exceptions" to the censure proposal lodged against him on Monday. He asked his colleagues not to prejudge him before the Senate begins debating the issue on Nov. 8.

The continuing importance of handcrafted objects, which supply a touch of individuality in today's rooms, where much of the furniture is made by machine, is pointed up in a collection of ceramics and glassware now on view at Bonniers.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Lord Beaverbrook announced tonight the Canadian charitable uses that would benefit from the gift of all his ordinary shares in The Daily Express, The Sunday Express and The Evening Standard.

Aneurin Bevan, Sir Winston Churchill once remarked, is "the ambitious demagogue who called one-half of his fellow-countrymen [the Tories] 'vermin'." On Wednesday he did not call Clement Attlee and Herbert Morrison names, but he did step to the microphone on the stage of the Labor party's annual conference at Scarborough and demand a change in the Socialist party leadership.

Ancestor, part of a triple entry saddled by George Bostwick, won the $11,625 Rouge Dragon hurdle handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Closest to the winner was Hyvania, also part of the entry, who was two and a half lengths out of first place and a length ahead of Khumbaba of the Winding Way Farm.
Brooklyn bus riders will have a chance on Nov. 15 to present their views on Transit Authority proposals to reduce service.
TEANECK, N.J., Sept. 30 -- A Republican Congress can carry forward an Eisenhower program that will insure "still lower taxes for all," Vice President Richard M. Nixon said here tonight.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 30 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer arranged today for the Bundestag (lower house of the Federal Parliament) to met in a special sitting Tuesday to hear his report on the London conference.
During a paternal moment in the spring the head of the house was prevailed upon to rent his home for the summer months. It was a very paternal moment, and in addition they came at him from all sides.

Coffee prices continued to drop yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The declines were 105 to 190 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 103,500 bags. Heavy liquidation and hedge selling were induced by rumors that the Brazilian cruzeiro might be devaluated and reports that the next crop may be larger than earlier estimates.

Aaron Jacoby withdrew as the Democratic-Liberal candidate for State Controller early yesterday. He explained that he wanted to prevent Republicans from using an old and "disproved" charge against himself to divert attention from the real issues of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner said today there was no constitutional provision or Federal law that prohibited "reasonable segregation" of white and Negro passengers traveling in interstate commerce.
A potentially paralyzing truck strike in the New York-New Jersey area was averted yesterday for at least fifteen days.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 447 pints of blood on Wednesday, of which 191 were collected at Stewart Air Force Base, Newburgh, N. Y., and 164 at a community donation at the West Brighton Armory on Staten Island.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 30 -- Dr. Eddie Anderson has been coaching football teams long enough to be prepared for any eventuality. So it was that he could smile in a philosophical mood today in discussing the game Holy Cross lost to Dartmouth by the extra point kicked after time had run out on the Green's touchdown pass.

Christmas gifts to officials of the Federal Housing Administration was among thirteen witnesses who told yesterday of gathering $10,393,171 windfall profits through F.H.A. guarantees of excessive mortgages.
DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Fred Hutchinson resigned today as manager of the Detroit Tigers amid rumors he next would be seen in the uniform of he Baltimore Orioles.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Nearly 3,000,000 alien residents, including 6,752 United States citizens, were faced today with the alternative of accepting automatic Argentine nationality after five years' residence or publicly declining it.
ROME, Sept. 30 -- The Chamber of Deputies confirmed its confidence in Premier Mario Scelba and his Government today by 294 votes to 264. The Senate did so last Saturday by 114 votes to 97.

Will you please tell your millions of readers from me, and millions like me, that we have not forgotten that we owe our lives and liberty -- and, sad to say, our false air of prosperity -- to the aid of you Americans, given freely and unstintingly both during and after the war.
The Board of Higher Education early today dismissed three Hunter College associate professors who were members of the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The Government's crop insurance corporation may lose $7,000,000 this year because of drought, disease and other farm disasters.

WEST FORTY-NINTH STREET was part Of the real West yesterday. Cowpokes and cowgirls were on the pavement in front of Madison Square Garden throwing leather over their mounts. They lifted horses' hoofs to make sure nail studs projected far enough to grip wet street surfaces in the rodeo parade from City Hall.

A blueprint for a new European defense structure, designed to assure a German contribution and to heal some of the wounds to Western unity caused by the French defeat of the European Defense Community, began to emerge yesterday when the London conference of nine nations agreed "in principle" on a program providing for the following:

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- The Paris press assumed today that the problem of Western defense was now solved, since Britain had offered conditionally to leave her troops on the Continent for the duration of the revised Brussels Treaty or so long as the Continent wanted them there.
DENVER, Sept. 30 -- A new Administration investigation program designed to detect and prevent misconduct among Federal workers was announced tonight by the White House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Aviation in the United States officially switched over at midnight from the statute mile to the nautical mile and the knot. Tomorrow sees the start of the new system of logging distances and speed.
An old and forgotten municipal law dealing with public porters will be applied next Tuesday, when the Queen Mary docks at West Fiftieth Street.
John Nuveen Co. and associates are offering $4,300,000 of electric revenue bonds of Denton, Tex., at yields of 1 to 3 per cent.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 30 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today India was the fourth power in the world, after the United States, the Soviet Union and Communist China.
An interested spectator at yesterday's fashion showing, in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel, was Ben Reig.
"La Cenerentola" was staged by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center last evening, with Rosemary Kuhlmann, a last-minute replacement for Frances Bible, singing the title role.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -A Federal Trade Commission hearing examiner has approved an order by which nearly 200 paint and wallpaper dealers in the New York City area have agreed to settle a case accusing them of restraint of trade.

The former legislative director of the Communist party was seized yesterday on a Manhattan street corner by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who said he had been working in the Communist "underground."

ROME, Sept. 30 -- Atomic, bacteriological and chemical weapons may be legitimately used only in self-defense, Pope Pius XII said today. In no case may such weapons be used if their use results in the annihilation of all human life within their radius of action, he added.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Hogs today made a slight recovery after yesterday's bad price spill. Butchers sold steady to 25 cents higher than Wednesday's average, while sows were taken mainly at steady prices. Salable receipts at 7,000 head fell 1,500 under the advance estimate. Department of Agriculture reports trading today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, declared today that one of the companies, participating in the proposed Dixon-Yates atomic power contract might have been guilty of "direct violation" of the Holding Company Act.

An increase of $5,925,605,000 in total resources during the year ended June 30, 1954, brought the assets of state supervised banks to $110,361,169,000, it was announced yesterday by L.K. Elmore, bank commissioner of Connecticut and president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

Sales of textiles by the recently formed Amerotron Corporation will probably be factored through Amwool Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of American Woolen Company, according to Royal Little, chairman of the board of Textron Incorporated.
DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP)-- The Right Rev. Archie Henry Crowley was consecrated Suffragan (assistant) Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Michigan today.
DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Eleven men and seven women were indicted today by a Federal Grand Jury investigating home improvement loans of the Federal Housing Administration.

The total of bonds called for redemption before maturity declined to $118,787,000 in September from $193,221,000 in August. It was the smallest amount in four months, but it enormously exceeded the $17,966,000 redeemed a year ago, and was the largest for any September since 1950.
Plans of the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation to sell $17,000,000 of new securities to a number of institutional investors were announced yesterday by Ernest R. Acker, president.
The distinguishing feature of James Lamar (Dusty) Rhodes, the batting hero of yesterday's world series game, as he was of Wednesday's opener, is his confidence.

It took a while for their judgment to be upheld, but the major league scouts who haunted the doorsteps of 18-year-old Johnny Antonelli's Rochester (N.Y.) home in 1948 evidently accurately appraised the talents of yesterday's world series pitching hero.

Leroy Gore, publisher of The Sauk Prairie (Wis.) Star, a "lifelong Republican" and a supporter of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, turned against the junior Senator from Wisconsin and spearheaded a recall campaign. The story of the "Joe Must Go" campaign is told by Mr. Gore in a book that Messner will publish Oct. 18.
The International Press Institute finds that censorship and other restrictions often delay and distort the news from the Middle East.

A plot of about 13,500 square feet at Tenth Street and Van Alst Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Dubied Machinery Company for an expansion of its business. James P. Guinane was the seller and the C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker in the transaction.
The DU Mont television network has started a "re-evaluation" of its program schedule and will drop several sustaining shows, including "Author Meets the Critics," within the next few weeks.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Directors of the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company voted unanimously today for partial liquidation of the company through distribution of the company's stock investments to shareholders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Three days and some hours after the release to the public of the Watkins committee report much evidence has accumulated that Senate action will be based on its central finding. This was that Joseph R. McCarthy in several ways has done violence to "the dignity, honor, authority and powers of the Senate" in which he serves as the junior member from Wisconsin.

Queens Felony Court in Ridgewood turned down yesterday a suggestion by twenty car laundries that windowshields scrubbed on Sundays made for cleaner and safer cities and should, therefore, exempt car washers from the law banning unnecessary labor on the Sabbath.

ASBESTOS, Que., Sept. 30 -- The world's largest mill to extract asbestos fiber from ore the Indians once called "the rock with hair on it" was formally opened here today. Upon completion, scheduled for early 1956, this new mill of the Johns-Manville Corporation will have an annual capacity of 625,000 tons of asbestos fiber -- some sixty carloads a day.
ALBANY, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Industrial Government Party has nominated a slate of candidates for state office to be put on the ballot for election day, Nov. 2.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The United States will start sending military equipment to Pakistan under a new mutual defense agreement within the next thirty days, informed sources said today.
HONG KONG, Sept. 30 -- A triumphant keynote was sounded tonight by Communist Premier Chou En-lai as Red China prepared to celebrate the Peiping Government's fifth anniversary.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped 1 to 10 points yesterday.

OUT of some cliches from the foolish Twenties, Sandy Wilson has written a delightful burlesque, "The Boy Friend," which opened at the Royale last evening. He wrote it originally for British audiences who have been enjoying it ever since.

Today begins National Newspaper Week. As President Eisenhower said in a statement issued from Denver, "the nation joins the editors, publishers and reporters of this country in observance" of this occasion. Editors, publishers and reporters are naturally interested in seeing newspapers prosper.

The crew of the Coast Guard icebreaker Westwind was happier than most sailors back home from a long voyage when their ship tied up shortly before noon yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn. They had finished a 121-day, 12,000-mile Arctic supply mission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -Mrs. Robert Wallach, Noel Field's adopted daughter, is in a Soviet prison camp in Siberia.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Federal Housing Administration insurance of a home loan doesn't relieve the lender's obligation to see that the loan is properly applied, Albert M. Cole, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, said today.

Two down meant way down. A feeling of gloom yesterday spread through the Cleveland Indians dressing room, brought sharp and sarcastic answers to questions and left the impression that a lot of usually affable fellows suddenly had turned sour.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Mike Turnesa, professional, and Fred McKenna, of the Knollwood Country Club combined for a best-ball score of 32, 34 -- 66 today to win the annual Westchester P.G.A. pro-president tournament at Winged Foot.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Sept. 30 (UP) -- Vonnie Colby of Hollywood, Fla., the medalist, today defeated the defending champion, Mrs. Edean Anderson Ihlanfeldt of Seattle, Wash., 6 and 5, in the second round of the twenty-fourth women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, sometimes taunted by union leaders who say another cabinet member calls the tune on labor policy, suggested today that his critics look at the results.
SHELBYVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30 -- At 76 years of age, Alben W. Barkley still is a political slugger.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The Army announced today plans to weed out older active duty Reserve officers and make careers more attractive to younger Reservists.
YONKERS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Shamrock Bobby, a 9-to-1 shot, won the feature at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Driven by Joe Hylan, the Royal Napoleon gelding paced the mile and a sixteenth in 2:11 2/5.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (AP) -Happy and smiling, the New York Giants stepped off their chartered airliner tonight in their first invasion of Cleveland Indians' territory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent above sales in the same period of 1953, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the Board's weekly report on sales by districts follow, in terms of percentage changes from like periods of last year:
The text of the address of Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General of the United States, as delivered before the New York chapter of the Public Relations Society of America here yesterday, follows:

GROTON, Conn., Sept. 30 -- The sleek-hulled Navy submarine Nautilus, the first machine that will carry man on an atom-powered journey, joined the Atlantic fleet in a "routine" commissioning ceremony here today.
Operating revenues and net income of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiaries rose in both the quarter and the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, the company reported yesterday.

The Oct. 7 performance of the Old Vic's production of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" has been taken over for the benefit of the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement. The show opened Sept. 21 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

An underwriting syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. and Salomon Bros. Hutzler yesterday put up for sale $30,350,000 of 3 3/8 per cent first and refunding, Series I, bonds of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Members of "Operation Lady" were briefed by the Foreign Operations Administration today on work-a-day conditions in France and Italy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -Former President Hoover today named Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker and three others as members of a special Hoover Commission task force that will study the super-secret Central Intelligence Agency.

THE week-end fishing prospects are better than fair, with the bluefish still present in many areas, stripers in good numbers and the bottom fishing excellent out of most of the New Jersey and Long Island ports.

The F.L. Jacobs Company, manufacturer of auto parts, is negotiating for a property outside the automotive field, Frank Howard, chairman, disclosed at a special meeting of stockholders yesterday in Detroit.

The most important thing to have come out of the series of conferences in Washington on our aid to France and Vietnam is not the size of the French expeditionary force that will be retained there or the size of the American aid budget. The important thing is the agreement.
Dusty Rhodes was the fabulous man in the Giants' clubhouse yesterday after the third of his heroic exploits in the second game of the world series.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday for the quarter ended Aug. 31 net profit of $5,328,000, compared with $3,458,000 in the similar three months last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Representative A. L. Miller, Republican of Nebraska, charged today that "the hard core" of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association "seems to be made up of a small group of Socialists."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Consumer installment credit rose $64,000,000 in August to a total of $21,310,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

DENVER, Sept. 30 -- United States planes, helicopters and ships with life rafts, medical and other supplies have been sent to northwestern Honduras where torrential rains have caused rivers to rampage. This aid has been directed from the Panama Canal zone.
Registration started here yesterday smoothly and slowly.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The European defense conference here is developing into a nine-power exercise in regaining friends and influencing statesmen.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The United States expressed concern today over the "high" administrative costs incurred in the operation of the United Nations children's fund.

THE sure-fire magic act that Leo the Magnificent performs with such hoopla and elan has lost none of its crowd-pleasing appeal. The Dandy Little Manager executed it at the Polo Grounds yesterday as he again had Dusty Rhodes materialize. Once more it stole the show.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Solid progress was made today at the nine-power conference on the arming of West Germany. The positive results of the day's session, which brought the end of the conference in sight, were these:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Federal Trade Commission today dismissed a complaint charging Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., of Boston and New York with discriminatory pricing in the sale of radio tubes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 --The Soviet Union proposed today that the world make a new attempt to agree on the prohibition of atomic and hydrogen bombs and on "a substantial reduction of armaments."

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Signs of growing labor unrest, coupled with yesterday's fall on Wall Street, made for a cautious approach by investors on the stock exchange here today. Consequently prices fell in nearly all markets.

Before Dusty Rhodes yesterday added an Occidental homer to his Oriental blow of Wednesday, he was proudly displaying a telegram he had received from the opportunistic proprietor of a local Chinese restaurant.

Six hundred employes of the American Safety Razor Corporation at 315 Jay Street in Brooklyn sat down on their jobs all day yesterday over a dispute involving the company's decision to move the Brooklyn plant to Staunton, Va.

TOKYO, Sept. 30 -- A legislative investigating committee today called the Government Railway Administration and the captain of the train ferry "partly" responsible in the drowning Sunday of more than 1,000 passengers.
The Guild of Catholic Lawyers of New York has named George A. Timone chairman of a committee to study juvenile crime here. Mr. Timone is vice president of the guild and of the Board of Education.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30 -- The first Baltimore picketing against desegregation broke out today at an elementary school with twelve Negro children among almost 600 pupils. About 500 pupils stayed away or left the school. The pickets said they planned to demonstrate tomorrow at more schools.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Inez de Koning admits that she doesn't exactly like living alone, but the 12-year-old Dutch girl says she manages to keep occupied enough to prevent boredom.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended last Saturday totaled 710,215 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N Y., Sept. 30 -- Indonesia urged the United Nations today to consider relaxing the embargo against the shipment of strategic material to Communist China.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Two explosions in quick succession blew up two small buildings and damaged a third at the E. I. du Pont de ATemours Company, Inc., blasting materials plant here tonight. No one was injured.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $48,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 30 -- The chief topic of conversation today among delegates to the Labor party's annual conference was a speech that Aneurin Bevan made at a rally here last night and his chances of winning power in the party.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- The revelation of a new conspiracy of "hooded men" to wreck democracy in France may be made by the Government next month, according to the weekly paper Express. The paper supports Premier Pierre Mendes-France.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The Soviet Union called on the United Nations today to look into "piratical attacks" by Nationalist China against ships trading with the Communist Chinese mainland.
DENVER, Sept. 30 -- White House spellers were rueful today over the "roux" in President Eisenhower's beef stew.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- A late buying flurry in soybean futures, with shorts reported covering extensively, helped vitalize the grain futures here today. There was a burst of activity in all pits in the last half hour, following a sluggish trade up to that point.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 28 -West German authorities have begun to take cognizance of an attempt to resurrect the Nazi organization. The resurgence is being promoted by mutual benefit societies whose announced aim is the recovery of property confiscated by denazification courts.

Cabbage, one of the season's best vegetable buys, may be used as a basic ingredient in many pickle relishes. Cabbage combined now with other fall vegetables -- green and red peppers, onions, cucumbers, beets, green tomatoes -- and cooked in a spicy vinegar solution will produce a great variety of condiments to add zest to winter meals.
New York bank loans to business maintained their downtrend during the week ended on Wednesday, declining $13,000,000 to a total of $7,270,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- R. A. Butler, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, proposed today that the United States triple its rate of capital investment abroad as one contribution to freer world trade and currencies.
The State Housing Commissioner accused the city Administration yesterday of abandoning the block-by-block inspection system for housing law violations without giving it a real trial.
Once again the stock market had a light-volume day in which most morning gains failed to survive a wave of afternoon selling. Steels and rails were especially soft.

Young women headed by Mrs. Alfred M. Ehrenclou, and including Mrs. Maxwell E. Cox, will assist in receiving at the reception and tea to be held on Monday at the headquarters of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East Seventieth Street.

In your editorial of Sept. 24 discussing the problem of electing the state Attorney General a companion suggestion is made to take the office of New York State Controller off the general election ballot. It is stated that the example of the Controller General of the United States might be studied as a profitable parallel to having the state Controller elected by the Legislature.
New York waterfront employers and the longshoremen who work for them begin today their second year without a contract.
A Netherlands Government official revealed yesterday that American investors had started three-fourths of all the subsidiaries of foreign concerns that have been set up in Holland since World War II.

EATONTOWN, N. J., Sept. 30 --The Army formally dedicated here today a new Signal Corps Engineering Laboratory--a series of buildings that will soon constitute the largest scientific and research center in the United States.
Make safety education and practice in the home a cooperative undertaking and a subject for discussion by the family council, parents are urged in a recent safety publication.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -The Government announced today that gamma globulin, one of the anti-polio weapons, would go on sale to the public for the first time tomorrow.

National Airlines, Inc., has elected to its board of directors Daniel R. Topping and Edwin C. McDonald, it was announced in Miami yesterday by G.T. Baker, president and board chairman. Mr. Topping, co-owner and executive head of the New York Yankees, and Mr. McDonald, vice president of group insurance activities for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, succeed Joseph A. Thomas and Salim L. Lewis.

Homemakers are being urged by meat and vegetable interests -- and Government figures all the way up to President Eisenhower himself -- to use abundant beef and vegetables in beef stew. As an appetizing variant to this thrifty dish, home cooks might well consider pork.

Princeton's head coach, Charley Caldwell, told a press luncheon at Columbia's John Jay Hall yesterday the players he probably would start against the Lions tomorrow. Lou Little, without trying to be circumspect, said he wouldn't decide on the starters until he saw what the weather was like.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 30 -- Nevada apparently will have two Republican Senators in Washington, instead of its present one, at least until next Jan. 1.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- A British inquiry board today called on the Malaya rubber industry to meet the competition of American and German synthetic rubber with a massive replanting program.

FOR twelve years now Wright Morris has been writing his peculiar books, and his reputation among certain literary intellectuals has mounted with each one of them. Several consisted of photographs taken by Mr. Morris accompanied by fragments of lyrical prose. Others were novels about supposedly ordinary people so weighed down with satire, cryptic symbolism and cosmic significance that they thoroughly intimidated some of their readers.

Belgium, a country long noted for its sound economy and free enterprise, is now offering exceptional inducements for new American industrial investment, members of the Belgian Chamber of Commerce in the United States were told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -United States diplomatic authorities here expressed qualified optimism today toward an agreement in London on West German armament. These informants based their caution mainly on these considerations:

L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, declared yesterday that he was "fed up" with Democratic insinuations that the split period for registration of voters was part of a Republican plot to keep the vote down.
Eight unidentified youths beat a 72-year-old widower with sticks and baseball bats in a Brooklyn park last night inflicting injuries that included paralysis of one leg.
TORONTO, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press) -- A nonaggression agreement between Canada's two largest union groups became assured today when it was approved by the Canadian Congress of Labor.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Cpl. Claude Batchelor tonight was convicted of collaborating with the enemy and informing on fellow prisoners of war in Korea. He was sentenced to life in prison.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30 (UP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, today accused former President Truman, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Adlai E. Stevenson and Elmer Davis, radio commentator, of being "leaders in the fight against Congressional exposure of Communism."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept 30 -- Five non-salaried trustees of the Davella Mills Foundation have found that giving away an $11,000,000 fortune to worthy causes and persons can become as difficult as earning it.

In an article printed in The New York Times on Sept. 18 your correspondent, stressing my remarks made in connection with a discussion of the Russian language courses at the United States Military Academy and concerning the origins of the Russian language, included several statements which, unless clarified, may appear misleading.
Ever since Stalin died Moscow and some other big Russian cities have been plagued by crime and drunkenness.

NEWARK, Sept. 30 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority today opened its campaign against fog by installing two of the first four experimental fog-dispelling devices near the Newark-Elizabeth city line. The dispellers are ten-foot, two-blade propellers rigged atop thirty-foot aluminum posts.
MILFORD, Del., Sept. 30 -- In the face of an organized revolt, Delaware late today abandoned its first attempt at racial integration in the public schools of Sussex County.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston said here tonight that Vice President Nixon was being used by the Republican party to lead a Fascist-type attack on the Democrats, employing the technique of "the big lie."
DENVER, Sept. 30 -- Negotiations for the sale abroad of $384,1000,000 worth of Government-owned surplus farm products will be completed in a few days, President Eisenhower heard today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices declined 2 per cent between mid-August and mid-September. They had increased a similar amount a month earlier.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -Following is the text of a letter and statement sent to the Watkins Censure Committee today by the attorney for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that planting allotments for 1955 crop peanuts would be held to the minimum permitted by law -- 1,610,000 acres. The same acreage was allotted for this year's crop.

Book lovers who went to the New York Public Library's main building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street in the drizzle yesterday morning learned that the library had gone in for "rain insurance" in the form of paper shopping bags to keep its borrowed books dry.
With a "Yippee" and a flourish of his creamy Stetson, America's great folk hero, the cowboy, rode into Madison Square Garden last night.

A plot 95 by 100 feet at 137-141 East Fifty-fifth Street has been sold by Frederick Brown to Joseph Sager Sons who plan to improve it with a twelve-story apartment house. The Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation was the broker and the attorneys were Joseph Sohm for the buyers and Joshua Bernstein for the seller.

What does the youth of today see on all sides? The tax collector collects taxes for himself, the Big Shots rob the country of millions, then comes a blown-up investigation for the pay-per-day benefit of the investigators, good money is thrown after lost, millions are never paid back; it pays to go to jail for one or two millions.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. J. Walker Hoopes of Wilmington, Del., captured the Women's Unit-States Senior Golf Association championship today.

Alexander Smith, Inc., floor coverings manufacturer which recently transferred its operations from Yonkers to its southern plants, is making plans for a newspaper advertising test described as new for the industry. It is modeled after campaigns in the automobile and other industries.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 (UP) -Members of the United Electrical Workers, an independent union, today overwhelmingly approved a new contract ending the 108-day-old strike against the Square D Electrical Company.
Shooting for four straight, Leo Durocher's Giants yesterday made it two in a row as they defeated Al Lopez' Indians from Cleveland, 3 to 1, in the second game of the world series at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Marion B. Folsom, Under Secretary of the Treasury said today further tax cuts were "badly needed" but could not be undertaken until the Administration made deeper cuts in Federal spending.

The plan for relieving overcrowding in New York's jails by converting Riverside Hospital on North Brother Island into a prison was scuttled yesterday by Dr. Basil C. McLean, Commissioner of Hospitals.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30 -- The blockade of Tampico was lifted today. Its ending brought a collapse of the transport strike that had spread from Tampico through northeast Mexico.
The Justice Department's anti-trust prosecutors turned thumbs down yesterday on the proposed merger of the Bethlehem Steel and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Corporations.
