UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Following are excerpts from an official translation of a statement today by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, to the General Assembly, and the text of a statement by Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative, on a disarmament proposal made by Mr. Vishinsky:

The existence of an employer offer of a $100 monthly pension for deck officers was denied yesterday by Walter E. Maloney, chairman of the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, which negotiates with the Masters, Mates and Pilots, A.F.L., for approximately forty steamship lines.

Six scientists and an armed forces laboratory were cited yesterday for distinguished work in medical research and public health by the American Public Health Association. They will receive the annual Albert Lasker Awards to be presented at the association's annual meeting in Buffalo on Oct. 14.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 30 -- Finance Minister Jung Jae Lee announced today that unless United Nations forces repaid all Korean currency advances tomorrow at the official exchange rate of 180 whan to $1, the command's credit would be cut off immediately by the South Korean Government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has purchased the screen rights to one of the four historical romantic stories written by Lesley Blanch and published in book form as "The Wilder Shores of Love."

FRANKLIN, N.J., Sept. 30 -The closing tomorrow of the New Jersey Zinc Company's mine and mill will leave this Sussex County community of 4,000 persons without a major industry for the first time in 106 years.
ROME, Sept. 30 -- Italy is the only West European country whose East-West trade is controlled by Communists at both ends.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Administration officials have begun drafting a bill to provide for the renewal of the Defense Production Act for two years beyond June 30.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- A British helicopter flew an iron lung today to an American boy stricken with poliomyelitis aboard an eastbound United States troop transport.

Quickly accepting the State Department's bid to facilitate foreign tours by American entertainers, the American National Theatre and Academy, which operates under a Congressional charter, sprang into action yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Prospects for a new attendance record may be hindered tomorrow by cloudy weather when the Cleveland Indians and New York Giants continue the world, series here.

"SATINS AND SPURS," which laid the first color egg of the season on N.B.C. television, has company this morning; it is "Shower of Stars," seen last night over C.B.S. television. From the looks of things color may be the death of television yet.
Dr. Virginia C. Gildersleeve, dean emeritus of Barnard College, yesterday presented the first copy of her autobiography, "Many a Good Crusade," to Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The 1,800-year-old Roman temple of the god Mithras, recently unearthed in the City of London, is to be dug up and "rebuilt" to make room for a new block of office buildings.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- A sharp Latin-American protest against the United Nations handling of the Guatemalan case was heard today by the General Assembly.
More than 125,000 persons visited the Golden Jubilee National Business Show, which last night ended a five-day run in the Sixty-ninth and Seventy-first Regiment Armories.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 1 -Five thousand textile employes in ninety dyeing, printing and finishing plants in this city and one in Rutherford went on strike today. It was the industry's first major work stoppage in this area in twenty years.
ROCKFORD, Ill., Oct. 1 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared tonight "a majority of the American people" are going to reject in November a philosophy that he said calls stagnation "stability."

Resistance to the Communist regime in Poland has resulted in overflowing prisons, factory strikes and the withholding of government levies by farmers, a former Polish secret police official reported here yesterday.
DENVER, Oct. 1 -- President Eisenhower is following closely developments in the Soviet Union's new proposals to outlaw hydrogen and atomic bombs and reduce world armaments.

Favored by good shopping weather, New York City's department stores last month substantially exceeded their sales of September, 1953, according to a survey by The New York Times. The strong performance was consistent with the pattern of sales in the city since the post-Easter period.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, 30-year-old United States tennis champion from Philadelphia, and Gustavo Palafox, Mexico's top player, will meet tomorrow in the first match of the final round of the North American zone Davis Cup competition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A move to get funds for a full-scale inquiry into alleged monopolistic operations by power companies will be made next month by the anti-monopoly subcommittee of the Senate's Judiciary Committee.
The Liberal party gave its endorsement yesterday to Arthur Levitt, who became the Democratic candidate for State Controller after Aaron Jacoby declined.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Union and Yugoslavia formally resumed trade relations today. These were broken off in 1948 at the time of the break in their political relations.
The proposal for a bridge over the Narrows, between Brooklyn and Staten Island, appeared yesterday to have taken a step closer to reality.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Federal Reserve Board today opened the way for additional sources of five-to-ten-year credits for exporters.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- The Rev. Dr. Hewlett Johnson, left-wing "Red Dean" of Canterbury, today paid his second visit this week to the United States Embassy here to sign a court deposition for a subversion hearing in the United States.
The Motor Wheel Corporation has bought, for an undisclosed amount of cash, the physical assets of the Reo lawn mower division of Reo Motors, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- The Cleveland Police Department was criticized by the head of a Congressional subcommittee investigating labor racketeering today. Chairman George Bender, Republican of Ohio, pledged continuation of the investigation of bombing, extortion and conversion of funds.

The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company has signed an agreement with the Atomic Energy Commission giving it authority to study at its own expense the use of atomic power in generating electricity, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles E. Oakes, president of the utility.

The Times of Sept. 15 carried a letter from a reader urging immediate action by the United Nations in the matter of Formosa and the Chinese situation generally. Similar expressions of opinion are noted from other residents of the New York area, and many public pronouncements -- editorials, sermons and the like -- appear to say about the same thing.

DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Ford Motor Company reported today its factories built 156,276 cars and trucks in September to bring the year's nine-month total to 1,570,096. In the comparable nine-month period last year 1,381,879 cars and trucks were produced.

In addition to having been elected President of the United States, Herbert Hoover, Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower have something else in common: each was a newsboy at some point in his career.

If the weather is good during the next few working days, it is expected that the $250,000 job of repaying part of the West Side Elevated Highway and rebuilding its drainage system will be completed in another week.

Those companies that have the right style, color and merchandising plans for spring will reap the major share of the $6 billion men's apparel business next year, according to James B. Lee, president of the Frank H. Lee Company, maker of Lee and Disney hats.
Following is the text of last night's television address by Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for Governor:

Now that the members of the task force that will conduct the study have been appointed, the Hoover commission's projected inquiry into "major intelligence activities of the Government" should soon be fully under way.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of help to the homemaker:

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- Ruben Gomez, the slender Puerto Rican right-hander who put the crusher on the Cleveland Indians in the third game of the world series today, is a Johnny-come-lately to the Giants. This was only his second season with the club.

The little city of Milford, Del. (pop. 1950, 5,179), will probably not incur legal penalties because, under pressure of "public opinion," it has given up its attempt to adjust its school system to the anti-segregation decision handed down by the Supreme Court on May 17.
OTTAWA, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press) -- United States restrictions against imports of Canadian oats have ended, but officials here believe new ones may be imposed shortly.

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., Oct. 1 -- If the weather continues to plague potato growers in Maine, consumers in New York may feel the effects. The spuds would be scarce next winter when New Yorkers depend on Maine for the major portion of their potatoes.
SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 1 -- The British Labor party's annual conference ended today in an atmosphere of good-fellowship that contrasted sharply with the tension and bitterness of the opening.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 30 -- Chile, Ecuador and Peru are preparing a legal battle to defend their fishing and whaling rights against the "piracy" of foreigners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission has ruled a 1,289 mile Louisiana-to-Michigan natural gas pipeline may be built if producers who have contracted to supply the line submit to Federal regulation of their rates.

Stanislav Mikolajzcyk, president of the International Peasant Union and former Polish Premier, called the Soviet "new look" in agrarian policy yesterday an admission of the failure of previous collectivization programs.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 1 -The political crisis in South Vietnam took a more serious turn today.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 1 -A call for state cooperation in a four-point Federal program to halt the "national scandal" of highway traffic deaths was made here today by Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby.

The plant of Manning, Maxwell Moore, Inc., at 446-452 Communipaw Avenue in Jersey City, N.J., has been purchased for investment by H. Yablick in a transaction negotiated by J.I. Kislak, Inc., as broker. Littlefield, Miller Cleaves of New York were attorneys for the seller and Isidore Hornstein of Jersey City acted for the buyer.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Prince Victor won the $3,400 Phellis Challenge Cup trot in straight heats on the Grand Circuit card today to lift his stock for next week's $70,000 Kentucky Futurity.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it had approved the transfer of the 7,636-gross-ton Seatrain New Orleans from American to Liberian registry.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Cpl. Claude Batchelor returned to confinement at Fort Sam Houston today to await review of a life sentence imposed last night by a general court-martial.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 -- An angry crowd of 800 white adults and students attacked four Negro pupils in front of a south Baltimore high school this afternoon as violence flared in protest against desegregation ordered by the local school board.

GROTON, Conn., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The gaiety that attended yesterday's commissioning here of the Nautilus, the world's first atomic submarine, was succeeded today by labor dissatisfaction. A union leader said workers were unhappy over the discharge of a man blamed for a recent explosion aboard the craft.
To the lie detector and word association tests, there now has been added the heartbeat test as a method of crime detection.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Cornell University needs a "rock-bottom $500,000 to $1,000,000 more income a year" to keep going forward, its president, Deane W. Malott, declared today.

THE next two weeks will enable the "long distance" sportsmen to get salmon fishing as well as hunting in some sections of New Brunswick, where the hunting opened yesterday. The salmon fishing will continue on a few rivers until Oct. 15.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 1 -- A wild upswing in the price of gold here has aroused the concern of Indonesian authorities. Within the last fortnight the gold price has soared from 41 rupiahs to 50 rupiahs a gram (1/31.1035 ounce).
The last dispatch this correspondent filed before leaving Moscow was killed in entirety by the censorship. So was the next to the last.

A site of about 100,000 square feet fronting on Schenck and Hill Park Avenues and Middle Neck Road in Great Neck, L.I., has been purchased for improvement with an apartment house in a transaction negotiated by J. Edward Breuer as broker.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- The Public Service Commission denied today the New York Telephone Company's petition for a rehearing on its request for a $69,000,000 annual increase in rates.

The nineteenth annual convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union, independent, ended yesterday after delegates had voted to work to abolish Congressional committees that have been investigating Communists.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -- The Under Secretary of State, Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, appealed today to the American people to support President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in their foreign policy efforts.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 1 -- The national open champion, the Meadow Brook -- C.C.C. team led by Pete Bostwick, gained a 5-4 victory over Westbury in a semi-final match of the Monty Waterbury handicap polo tournament on Hitchcock Field at the Meadow Brook Club today. The winners will play Brandywine for the title on Sunday.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A system of uniform traffic tickets described as "fix-proof" went into effect over most of the state today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- United States diplomatic officials remained guardedly hopeful tonight for "agreement in principle" on West German armament despite the last-minute hurdle erected by Pierre Mendes France, the French Premier.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. of the Sixteenth (New York) Congressional District called yesterday for the removal of an Interstate Commerce Comission examiner for his ruling on segregation in buses.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 9,165 pints of blood in September, its administrator, Dr. William M. Markel, announced yesterday.
Columbia will play host to Princeton at Baker Field today in the opener of the New York college football campaign. The kick-off is at 2 P.M.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 1 -Effort of British industry to break through into the lucrative business of supplying electrical equipment for the Columbia River hydroelectric development at the Dalles failed when bids were opened here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The State Department announced today that Communist Czechoslovakia had agreed to release two United States Army men seized Sept. 17 at the German-Czech border.
YONKERS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Philip Scott, the 13-20 choice ,won the $6,000 Port Chester free-for-all pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight and defeated five top side-wheelers in 2:01 4/5.

A three-story classroom and office building at Washington Square North and University Place for occupancy by New York University was among plans filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The building will be at 2 Washington Square North, 2-4 University Place and 15-16 Washington Mews. It is estimated to cost $68,000.

Mrs. Bernice P. Rogers, Deputy City Housing and Building Commissioner, challenged yesterday a statement on Thursday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, that the city's block-by-block inspections for housing violations had been abandoned. No part of the program has been abandoned, Mrs. Rogers! declared.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad plans to retire another $15,000,000 of its 4 per cent collateral trust bonds due in 1965, Howard E. Simpson, president, disclosed yesterday.
Deep under the East River a loudspeaker in a moving subway train boomed: "This is Times Square, calling Train 799. Over."

The building containing eighty-three apartments and four stores at 3235 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been sold by Lenlad Realty to Citra Realty through Wishnow Horowitz, brokers. The property is assessed at $425,000 and was for cash above mortgages totaling $450,000, the brokers reported.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Members of the United Nations were called on today to give $12,000,000 to find permanent homes and a decent livelihood for thousands of destitute European refugees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 109.7 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices of farm products and foods were partly offset by a fractional increase in average prices of industrial materials.

BOGOTA, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Anthony Pepe, president of the Bank of Bogota, said today "it is incredible to believe that the State Treasurer, regardless of his political affiliations, should question the legality or propriety of my asking that the Bank of Bogota be used as a depository for state funds."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Florida asked the Supreme Court today to permit a gradual and discretionary adjustment of its school system to conform to the decision outlawing segregation.

The recent Democratic State convention, which I attended, has brought home the fact that reform in our state Election Law is long overdue. New York is one of the three or four remaining states which do not have machinery for state-wide primary for the Gubernatorial and other state offices.
MANILA, Oct. 1 -- A land reform intended to change the almost feudal relationship between the Philippine landowner and the peasant was set in motion today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (UP) -- Walter Bryant Pierce, 55 years old, shot himself to death today, four days before he was scheduled to go on trial in Newark, N.J., on charges of transporting $87,000 in stolen securities.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- France put a hitch today in the conference for European unity. She rejected a plan for control of West German arms that she apparently accepted yesterday. The plan was acceptable to the eight other nations at the conference.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 1 -- Gov. Charles H. Russell today appointed Ernest S. Brown, a Reno lawyer and a Republican, to replace Senator Pat McCarran, Nevada Democrat, who died Tuesday.
Two witnesses agreed yesterday at a public hearing that education of future parents was the best single way to reduce juvenile delinquency.

Robert Lee Doughton, who died yesterday at his home in Laurel Springs, N.C., in his ninetieth year, was the son of a captain in General Lee's army. After a hard beginning in Reconstruction days he won an early success as farmer, stock raiser, merchant and banker.

A contrast between the handling of slum-clearance projects by two sets of private developers was drawn yesterday at a public hearing of the Senate Banking Committee into Federal Housing Administration scandals.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1 -- Harvard enjoyed its happiest football season in some years last fall. Those who feared lest the Crimson abandon intercollegiate competition with the steady decline of its prestige rejoiced in the turn in its fortunes.

The National Broadcasting Company, in cooperation with New York University, will present a new weekly radio discussion series concerned with major news developments under the title, "Headlines In Perspective," for the first time tomorrow evening on WNBC from 11:30 until midnight.
The fifteenth annual celebration of National Newspaper Week began yesterday, stressing the role of the press in preserving freedom of the press as a guarantee of the freedom of the American people.

Clifford D. Oberkirch, the head bookkeeper of a Long Island bank when it was robbed of $190,319, pleaded guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to an indictment charging him with sharing in the loot.
A group of waste paper collector and deliverers of garment boxes, paper and twine went on strike yesterday for higher pay.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Bob Baker, a Pittsburgh heavyweight, dropped Coley Wallace for a count of 9 in the fourth round and battered his New York opponent in the final stages tonight to win a unanimous upset decision in ten rounds at the Cleveland Armory.

Major offerings of new securities next week will exceed $180,000,000, with the bulk of the sales scheduled for Tuesday. There will be eight principal corporate issues and three tax-exempt bond issues sold in the public market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today it will support grower prices of 1954-crop corn at an average of $1.62 a bushel in an officially designated commercial corn-producing area and at $1.22 outside that area.
An apathetic citizenry continued yesterday to shun the city's 4,195 polling plices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -Leonard W. Hall, Republican national chairman, said today Democratic chairman Stephen A. Mitchell should apologize to Vice President Richard M. Nixon "for calling him a liar, or remove his signature from the 'fair play' statement he signed last Sept. 14."

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., owners and operators of merchant ships, served notice yesterday on the Maritime Administrator and the Federal Maritime Board of its intention to file for an operating differential subsidy for its 'round-the-world service.

The New York Shipbuilding Corporation has acquired all the outstanding convertible preferred stock of the Highway Trailer Company of Edgerton, Wis., it was announced yesterday by Harry W. Pierce, president of the shipbuilding concern.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- The grain futures market had a strong tone today, with commission absorption taking care of profit-taking sales that caused slight recessions in the morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the Communists in this country were peddling a new party line based on pretended cooperation with American ideals.

New securities offered publicly here in September increased sharply over the preceding month and a year ago. Bond flotations were the largest for any month in the twenty-eight years since The New York Times began compiling such figures; stock offerings were the largest for a September since 1945.

SALONIKA, Greece, Sept. 27 -- Three hundred seventy-one hostages, ranging from infants to men and women bent with age, arrived here tonight from Czechoslovakia for repatriation under the auspices of the International Red Cross.

It is unfortunate that political charges have begun to center about the issue of arms production. The news that the Chrysler Corporation has been awarded a contract to produce the M-48 medium tank, thus replacing General Motors as supplier, has been interpreted in some quarters as a concession to Senator Jackson's complaint regarding the supposed lion's share of arms contracts going to General Motors.

The twenty-sixth annual edition of the Motion Picture and Television Almanac, offering thumb-indexed reference material in the two fields, was brought out this week by the Quigley Publishing Company. The publication provides up-to-date listings of all theatre circuits in the United States and Canada and of all the drive-in theatres in both countries.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- Unlike what happened in the first two contests at the Polo Grounds, the Indians never were in today's ball game at Municipal Stadium. The Giants moved into the driver's seat at the outset, took immediate charge and rolled comfortably to their third straight victory in the world series.

In a recent television broadcast Admiral Lewis Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, repeated his assertion made at the Founders' Day dinner of the National Association of Science Writers that some day when atomic power was a commercial reality it would not pay to read electric meters.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Dusty Rhodes wows them on the road, too.

HORTON, Kan., Sept. 30 -- Two northeastern Kansas farmers were engaged this week in a rousing fight for the First Congressional District seat while national and state leaders of both major parties anxiously looked on.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Government used its taxing powers today to attract more defense industries to labor surplus areas in the country.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The University of California at Los Angeles came from behind in the final quarter to defeat mighty Maryland, 12 -- 7, tonight and put a severe dent in the reputation of the nation's 1953 champion college football team.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- The state completed today a right-of-way purchase reported to be the largest in its history.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Oct. 1 (UP) -- The co-favorites, Mary Lena Faulk and Polly Riley, scored victories today to move into the semi-finals of the Trans-Mississippi women's amateur golf tournament. They will meet tomorrow.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Nineteen American business men arrived here today to explore the possibilities of increasing trade between the United States and Europe.

The Penn Fruit Company, Inc., operator of supermarkets in Philadelphia and its suburbs, announced yesterday the calling of a special meeting of stockholders for Oct. 15 to approve a two-for-one split in the common shares. Stockholders at that meeting also will be asked to increase authorized common shares from 850,000 to 2,000,000 and to create 100,000 shares of a new class of $50 par value preferred stock.

A pair of intersectional games, a contest with an inter-league flavor and a test in which a coach and his one-time protege will match wits add interest to the local scholastic football schedule today.

It is indeed heartening, at this low point in our relations with Latin America, to learn from a Sept. 20 dispatch in The Times that our Assistant Secretary of State for Latin American Affairs, Henry F. Holland, is on an extended tour of our southern neighbors.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 1 (UP) -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said today that while he and James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, might not see eye to eye on certain matters, "differences of opinion make for progress."

Hasan Mohammed Tiro, a former Indonesian Government official here, was given until Nov. 1 yesterday to leave the United States voluntarily or face deportation proceedings. Since Aug. 15, when he broke with his Government, his Indonesian credentials have been invalidated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A Government witness insisted under cross-examination today that he could recall two visits to the Toledo (Ohio) law office of Edward Lamb in 1938-1940 to request donations but said he could not remember the names of any other persons he solicited in the same period.

Dr. V. Jerauld McGill, one of three suspended Hunter College faculty members who were dismissed as the result of the Board of Higher Education's investigation of Communist influence in the municipal colleges, said yesterday that he would appeal his discharge to the State Education Commissioner.

The refinement of rattan, a trend noticeable in furniture of that material introduced in the last two years, is carried to new lengths in a group designed by Tommi Parzinger and introduced here by Willow Reed, 1 Park Avenue, where the pieces are available through decorators.

Under the impact of widespread international approval of President Eisenhower effort to create an atomic pool for peaceful purposes -- without the aid of recalcitrant Russia, if necessary -- Mr. Vishinsky has now submitted to the United Nations a new disarmament proposal to redeem the untenable Soviet position.

Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" returned to the City Center last night. An experienced cast handled the opera. Only one newcomer was heard in a major role; that was Marguerite Willauer, who made her debut with the New York City Opera Company as the Countess.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 1 -- Developments at the nine-power conference in London on the question of West German rearmament are being received here with apathy.

Paul Litchfield, chairman of the board of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, has written his life story. Doubleday will publish it Thursday under the title "Industrial Voyage." For fifty years with the company, Mr. Litchfield was a pioneer in mass production and mass marketing, in labor relations and Government relations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -- A Senate subcommittee that has been investigating "crime" programs on television reported today its four members were "adamantly" agreed on one point "they are strongly opposed to censorship."

The Clinton Trust Company reported as of Sept. 30, 1954, total deposits of $31,765,610 and total assets of $34,233,093, compared, respectively, with $30,739,570 and $33,172,414 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $9,049,345 against $9,319,903; holdings of United States Government securities to $13,714,401 against $12,195,763; and loans and discounts to $8,928,253 against $9,220,946. Surplus and undivided profits totaled $1,157,542 against $1,138,746 at the end of June.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Fordham opens its 1954 football campaign here tomorrow against once-beaten Rutgers. The game will start at 2 P.M. in the Rutgers Stadium.

The substitution of Arthur Levitt of Brooklyn for Aaron Jacoby of Brooklyn as the Democratic nominee for State Controller adds strength to the ticket headed by Averell Harriman. Mr. Jacoby's qualifications -- except extraneous, irrelevant ones -- did not seem impressive for the office in the first place.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 1 -- Michael Ryan, the champion of the host Southward Ho Country Club, carded a 69 today to win the medal in the fourth annual Havemeyer invitation golf tournament.

The Sparks-Withington Company, manufacturer of radios, television receivers and automotive products, suffered a net loss of $304,975 in the fiscal year ended June 30, despite a substantial increase in sales.
BELGRADE, Sept. 30 -- Yugoslavia's "normalization" of relations with the Soviet Union has reached a stage where even "political" consultations should be possible, a high Yugoslav official said today.
Brokers, and the investors for whom they act, may be losing their love for baseball.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Israel took to the State Department today her protest against Egypt's seizure of a Israeli ship in the Suez Canal.
MILFORD, Del., Oct. 1 -- Public education in Sussex County virtually was back to normal today, but the racial prejudices responsible for two weeks of strife over school integration lingered on.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Central American diplomats expressed the hope today that an expanding program of mutual economic cooperation would lead to the political unification of Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador.

The Brown Corporation has agreed to sell its Quebec woodlands and pulp mill to the Canadian International Paper Company and its hydroelectric power interests to the Shawinigan Water and Power Company for more than $40,000,000, it was announced last night.
Four men broke into the Manufacturers Trust Company on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street yesterday, and the police watched millions being carried out.

New York's first major football attraction of the 1954 campaign will present Columbia against Princeton at Baker Field today at 2 P.M. This contest is one of many good Eastern matches on a day when there is no game that monopolizes national attention.
Elihu Root Jr. severed his connection with the filth of Root, Ballantine, Bushby Palmer yesterday to become counsel with Grenville Clark to the firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Friendly Ball.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the first nine months this year exceeded that for the entire year in 1953 and 1952 and was the largest for such a three-quarter period since 1933.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 1 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, said today that with wisdom, patience and perseverance the Allies could prevent World War III and win the "cold war."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- They brought the 1954 world series to the shores of Lake Erie today. But so far as the majority in a gathering of 71,555 in Cleveland's vast Municipal Stadium was concerned, they could have left it in New York.

The basic materials of home building, a completed three-bedroom house and two others under construction, fourteen model rooms and twenty-four table settings feature the Exposition of Modern Living. The exposition opens at 2 P.M. today at the Kingsbridge Armory, 29 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges were irregular yesterday in generally dull trading. Activity was confined mostly to evening holdings for the week-end. Coffee, zinc, copper and lead rose; cocoa, soybean oil, cottonseed oil and rubber declined, and sugar, potatoes, wool, burlap and hides closed mixed.

TABIGHA, Israel, Sept. 6 -- Out of this site of the miracle of the loaves and fish is to come the feeding of the multitudes of modern Israel. Here a ranch to train "cowboys" is being developed with the aim of large-scale production of beef and lamb, scarcest items of the nation's diet.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Two units of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the Transport Workers Union and the United Railroad Workers, completed their amalgamation today.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The stock markets were a little brighter today. Selling of industrial shares was lighter and prices steadier. British Government funds remained firm.

A bargaining session between the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association has been scheduled for 11 A.M. Monday at the offices of the shipping group, 80 Broad Street.

The rails, neglected and soft for several weeks, made their best gains since June in yesterday's stock market. Moreover, they managed to offset a loss for the industrials, enabling a lackadaisical session to close with a small plus sign.
The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, the "moving man" of the armed forces and the largest shipping agency in the world, quietly observed its fifth anniversary yesterday.
CHARLEROI, Belgium, Oct. 1 -- The first internationally subsidized housing project was started yesterday in a stone-laying ceremony at Leernes, near Charleroi.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Dr. Peter Schlumbohm, who invents things in a penthouse at 2 Fifth Avenue, New York, was awarded his seventy-ninth American patent this week. It is for a mirror to be attached to a dashboard cigarette lighter.

FOUR of the current one-man exhibitions of painting are about as different from each other as can be imagined though all four artists are realists, content with the face of nature and sometimes striving to get behind it.
SWINDON, England, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Britain announced today invention of a contraption that takes 99 per cent of the noise out of a jet engine undergoing tests at full power on the ground.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 1 -- The Secretary of the Treasury, George M. Humphrey, said here today that taxes must be kept "relatively high" as long as "so much of our income" had to go into defense spending.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Oct. 1 -The Community Synagogue here has asked the State Supreme Court to upset a village ordinance that in effect prohibits a religious group from purchasing property it plans to use as a place of worship.

ELIZABETH, La., Oct. 1 (UP) -- A two-year-old paper mill strike that erupted in more than 179 acts of violence ended today. American Federation of Labor officials admitted defeat and advised members of two local unions to hunt other jobs.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Borg-Warner Corporation, Chicago, today called a special stockholders meeting for Dec. 10 to vote on a proposed three-for-one stock split.

Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer received a vote of confidence yesterday from Federal, financial, business and scientific leaders who are trustees of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. The vote was said to have been unanimous.

Senator Irving M. Ives, making his first television appearance of the state campaign, promised last night that he and his running mates on the Republican ticket would "talk sense and stick to the truth."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has instructed the Federal National Mortgage Association to establish a $10,000,000 revolving fund to help hurricane victims replace their lost homes.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A member of Gov. John S. Fine's cabinet and one of Governor Fine's former administrative assistants were indicted today along with thirteen others on charges of forcing state employes to contribute to a Republican campaign fund.

Plans have been made to accommodate 3,000 delegates at the annual Methodist family life conference next Friday through Sunday, Oct. 10, in Cleveland, Ohio. Members of study groups in more than eighty annual Methodist Conferences have worked for a year to provide data in advance for the participants.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 24 -- The Guild of Danish Cabinetmakers is celebrating its twenty-fifth year with a furniture exhibition in The Forum, the biggest exhibition hall of Copenhagen.

Lack of building and repair work has forced Brooklyn shipyards to reduce personnel drastically and threatens the existence of some of the facilities, a House merchant marine subcommittee was told yesterday.
DETROIT, Oct. 1 (UP) -- Stanley (Bucky) Harris became the first manager in history to be hired by Detroit a second time today when he accepted an offer to direct the Tigers next season.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France suspended the Secretary of the National Defense Committee, Jean Mons, tonight after two of his assistants had been charged with responsibility for the disclosure of reports on the committee's secret meetings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1 -- Burt Lancaster, a member in good standing of the Screen Actors Guild, has been put on probation by the Screen Directors Guild because he allegedly had expressed opinions about directors regarded as uncomplimentary by the organization.

The comment after the Anticipation purse at Belmont Park yesterday had the following general tone: "It looks as if Fitz is going to win his first Futurity this year." There were few in the crowd of 16,237 willing to take a stand to the contrary in view of what had just eventuated.
Detectives have been assigned to guard Louis E. Wolfson, 42-year-old financier and industrialist, who recently started a campaign to acquire control of Montgomery Ward Co.
The cotton futures market moved 6 points lower to 1 point higher yesterday. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was light.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 4.5 per cent above that of the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 5.1 per cent and orders 3.1 per cent.

HONG KONG, Oct. 1 -- Gen. Peng Teh-huai, Defense Minister, declared today that Communist China would "never stop" until it had liberated Formosa. He issued an order of the day calling on the armed forces to be "constantly prepared for combat," as the Peiping Government celebrated its fifth anniversary.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -The Public Health Service reported today that there were 35,592 cases of polio over the country in 1953.

The ninth annual joint meeting of the Governors of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank has just come to its conclusion in Washington. These twin institutions were brought into being during World War II, and they have had to function most of the time to date under world economic conditions that were completely alien to their purpose.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) -- A Jefferson County grand jury that investigated alleged communistic activities in Louisville indicted six persons tonight on charges of advocating sedition.

What is described as the first United States professional performance of "The Clandestine Marriage," a comedy by David Garrick, an eighteenth century actor-playwright, will be given at the Provincetown Playhouse tonight at 8:45.

Your editorial of Sept. 17 "Another Probe" is so misleading in its report of the work of the Subcommittee on Education of the House of Representatives Committee on Education and Labor, and is so void of the truth about the constitutional functions of this Congressional committee, that I ask courtesy of your columns to make corrections.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 1 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali told the nation tonight that "in the United States of America we have an ally who on several occasions has given proof of genuine friendship."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- This is rather an extraordinary team of Giants. The fact that they had just won their third straight world series game from the Indians and, on today's performance, looked like a team that would win just as easily tomorrow, seemed to have no visible effect on them.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 1 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that Democratic statements indicated "unfortunately, to me, that the issue of how to handle Communists in Government will be an issue in this campaign."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- A United Nations committee began today a study of responsibilities that the organization would undertake under the United States program for peaceful uses of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -The Federal Housing Administration put into effect today rules designed to protect the agency's billion-dollar-a-year 'home improvement program and safeguard home owners from "exploitation by unscrupulous salesmen or dealers."

Having followed with the greatest of interest the reports by Harrison Salisbury on his travels through Russia, I have experienced keen disappointment with the first of his current articles published in your edition of this date.

FALL clean-up in my garden is a flexible affair to be accomplished when time permits. It may be done little by little, beginning early in the season; that is the best way. But circumstances or the weather may interfere and cause delays.

OTTAWA, Oct. 2 -- From one end of Canada to the other this week there was speculation on the outcome of a battle between two political titans. They are Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent, leader of the Liberal party that governs Canada, and Maurice Duplessis, leader of Quebec's Union Nationale, the strongest political machine in any of the country's ten provinces.
HOUSTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Dicky Moegle included a 78-yard scamper among four touchdown runs tonight while leading Rice Institute's Owls to a 41-20 football victory over Cornell University.

AFTER a routine prelude to the season, it is a joy to see a production with dramatic quality. In Robert Anderson's "All Summer Long," the originality of the material and the fineness of the stage work go a long way toward compensating for the elephantine obtuseness of the Old Vic's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and the dullness of "Home Is the Hero."

BONN, Germany, Oct. 2 -- Turkish Premier Adnan Menderes and his Foreign Minister, Fuad Koprulu, arrived today in West Germany on one week's official visit. While they are here, an attempt will be made to establish intimate political and economic relations between Turkey and the West German Federal Republic.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 2 -- The Israeli-Egyptian Mixed Armistice Commission noted today, "with extremely great concern, the deterioration during the last month of the already serious situation prevailing along the demarcation line as a result of repeated aggressive acts by Egypt against Israel."
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 2 -- A new $1,000,000 research center to study the causes of mental illness is to be constructed here soon, it was announced this week by Gov. George N. Craig of Indiana.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 2 -- Bids will be opened Oct. 8 for the water-crossing phase of the projected Hampton Roads tunnel-trestle project.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 2 (UP) -- Stanford's Indians struck for two touchdowns in the second period today, then bottled up J.C. Caroline and Company to defeat Illinois, 12 -- 2, and hand the Illini their second straight upset loss of the season.

AN exhibition of photographs by the four prize winners in the last Village Art Center Open Photography Show will go on display tomorrow at the Center, 42-44 West Eleventh Street, where it will hang until Oct. 27.

ALTON BLACKINGTON is a dedicated man. For going on thirty-five years, with notebook and ears both open, he's roamed New England, a "hard land but rich in lore," in search of colorful Yankee yarns and legends.
MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Oct. 2 -- Centuries of tradition in the dress of Roman Catholic nuns had been put aside by a new Pennsylvania order that will wear stylish modern garb.

Deputy Chief Inspector Louis Goldberg, demoted to captain after a series of bingo raids in Brooklyn, will retire Oct. 9 on an annual pension of $4,800, Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday.
Stuyvesant High rolled to 19-0 victory over Taft's football team at Randalls Island yesterday. Aram Hagoplan, an end, set up the first touchdown when he blocked a Taft punt in the openings period.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Boston College's Eagles wore down Temple with two second-half scores today to ruin the Owls' 1954 opener, 12 -- 9, before 5,000 fans at Temple Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- At noon Monday page boys will part red velvet curtains that are forty-five feet long and black-robed Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, will step forth. After him will come the eight Associate Justices.

THERE are two kinds of cookbooks, those one takes into the kitchen and those one takes to bed for mouth-watering reading. "Tante Marie's French Pastry," though as practical as a kitchen match, has also the lip-smacking quality of the culinary spellbinders.

I read the Moscow dispatches of Harrison Salisbury with understanding, feeling that the naivete of some of his stories was due to Soviet censorship. Knowing well the conditions in Soviet Russia, where I spent two years in forced labor camps and a half-year in freedom observing Soviet life without the limitations the Soviet Government imposes on foreign correspondents, I could detect the tendentious in Mr. Salisbury's picture of Soviet Russia.

Mrs. Calista Woolley Bryson celebrated yesterday her 100th birthday in her home at 45 South Elliot Place, Brooklyn. She received 125 birthday cards from former pupils she taught in Sunday school in Iowa fifty years ago.

There were two $61,000 horse races at hot, sticky Belmont Park yesterday. The winners were Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Pet Bully, a $9.80-for-$2 second choice, and the Wheatley Stable's High Voltage, a $6.20 favorite.

THE cod may lack the elegance of the turbot and the fine flavor of the Dover sole. But it has a versatility that neither of these can boast, for it is sold fresh, frozen, salted and smoked. In pounds caught annually it is among the most important food fish of the world.

ROME, Oct. 2 -- The exodus of Italians to Trieste has begun from Lazzaretto, Crevatini and two or three other small places in Zone A of Free Territory that are to be surrendered to Yugoslavia under the terms of the Italo-Yugoslav agreement on Trieste.

MOODY cynics, to be found especially among those who write it, have a melancholy definition for light verse. It is those few lines, they say, with which an editor fills the bottom of a column near the back of the book.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2. -- (UP) Gustavo Palafox scored one of the biggest upsets of the 1954 Davis Cup competition today when he whipped the United States champion, Vic Seixas, but Tony Trabert gave the United States a split in the first day's play against Mexico by trimming Mario Llamas, the Mexican champion.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- In a game in which power plays determined the outcome, Penn State turned in a 13-to-0 triumph over Syracuse today. It was a contest devoid of thrills as the Nittany Lions played it according to the book in posting their second straight triumph.

AS one of numerous followers of the former N.B.C. Symphony, I enjoyed particularly your article, "They Will Not Quit." Certainly this magnificent group can and should be kept intact. Except for your article, I marvel at the fact that no person or group carrying weight has come forward to take the necessary steps to accomplish this.

THE bid by Charles Skouras, president of National Theatres, for Department of Justice approval of a plan that would permit the big theatre chain to enter into the production of movies is fraught with ramifications of major importance to the film industry.

Holiday Concerts for Young People, the first in a series of events planned for the benefit of the St. Luke's Hospital Building Fund, will take place on Dec. 28 and March 29 during the Christmas and Easter holidays.
Two changes in the rules for the coveted Pulitzer prizes in journalism has been announced by the advisory board on the awards.
ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Texas A. and M., an undermanned team, abandoned its running game in the pinch today and turned to passing to upset Georgia, 6 -- 0.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (AP) -Fred Haney, manager of the National League's last-place Pittsburgh Pirates for the last two years, signed a one-year contract today to pilot the club next season.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 2 -- The question of reunifying Germany is showing signs of becoming a chronic ailment for Europe.

Midterm election campaigns are deceptive. Scanned from a national eminence, there seems to be no war going on, or only a desultory one. But in the states and Congressional districts, there are sharp battles; and wherever the fight is in doubt, there the big guns, which in Presidential years are trained on one another at continental distance, will be found supporting local candidates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Congress gave the Justice Department some shiny new weapons to use in its fight against communism and subversion, and the department intends to use them. But no wild shooting is to be expected, because the department intends to proceed with caution.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 2 -One of the nation's more conservative legislators, United States Senator Wallace F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, is taking a long, lingering look at the scene hereabout -- studying color schemes rather than the political picture.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Fordham overcame the Rutgers football team today by just about the margin that was generally expected. The Rams, making their season debut, set down the local eleven by a score of 13 to 7 before a sweltering crowd of 9,500.

THE first Monday in October begins the 164th term in the history of the Supreme Court of the United States -- and the second year in the judicial history of Earl Warren, its fourteenth Chief Justice. One year ago, Warren was too new on the bench to participate in the first orders of the court.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 2 -Chile's major industrial strike was resolved today when the Braden Copper Company and labor leaders signed a new wage agreement calling for a 26 per cent increase for the miners and other workers.

LOOKING back, at the age of 50, on twenty-five years in the vast Australian outback, Charles Toppingham -- Old Top he was now to the denizens of the Northwest Territory -- let the memories of those years flood past his eyes.

IF it is true that the correct statement of a problem goes a long way toward suggesting the solution, this volume, the tenth in a series of studies under the auspices of the Bureau for Intercultural Education, has unusual value.

THE installation along highways of directional signs showing the cardinal points of the compass is being urged by the New York State Automobile Association to guide motorists who may have lost their bearings temporarily.
MISS FLORA McFLIMSEY, leaving the security of the doll house for a woodland visit, finds some small lost creatures -- a rabbit, a bird and, frightening to Miss Flora, a baby bear bigger than she is.

ALMOST no recent historian has claimed the large general audience that George Bancroft or James Ford Rhodes attracted in an earlier generation. Partly this is because the national diffusion of literacy has been accompanied by a contagious innocence of learning.

EVEN in this city of calculated risk, the office of the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company is an imposing structure. Its first floor executive rooms also are awesome, with rugs, glass-topped desks and a silence suitable for those who deal with the subtleties of insurance.
Stores are doing fine, generally, but here and there a smudge of discontent mars an otherwise smooth surface.
LONDON, Oct. 2 (Reuters) -Results in today's British soccer and rugby matches:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, demanded today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon identify the Communists he said were being "kicked out" of Government or repudiate his statement and apologize to the public.

I THINK it was John Kieran who said, "Whenever a new book comes out, I reread an old one" -- a process that would seem at once impossible and sterile. But a few out-of-print novels do so imperatively demand rereading that their republication is more welcome than any new appearances; and such are the three novels by Josephine Tey now collected, with an infectious introduction by James Sandoe, as THREE BY TEY (Macmillan, $3.95).
Drs. R.J. Kutsky and Morgan Harris of the University of California have discovered a potent growth-promoting agent which promises to heal wounds more rapidly than ever.

Zinc is an essential component of an enzyme needed in digestion, Dr. Bert L. Vallee of the Biophysics Research Laboratory, Harvard Medical School and Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, Boston, and Dr. Hans Neurath, professor and head of the department of biochemistry at the University of Washington in Seattle, report in the current issue of the Journal of the American Chemical Society.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 -- The steady rise in claims for unemployment, which extended over seven weeks, was checked temporarily when claims dipped from 23,870 to 22,669. This compares with a high of 24,200 last spring and an intervening low of 20,600 last May.

DALLAS, Oct. 2 -- Unseasonably hot and dry weather slowed department store sales in August and September. August sales were marked by greater use of credit. Installment and regular charge account sales were 11 per cent and 1 per cent respectively above a year ago.

Mr. Penner's letter in the September 26th New York Times describes Cinema 16's programs as "esoteric nonsense." This is a horrid and ludicrous indictment of the body of work of the international documentary, art and avant-garde film movement over the past 20 years, which has been the content of the Cinema 16 programs.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 2 (AP) -Alfred Carlton Gilbert, toy manufacturer whose great-great-great-great-great-great-great-grandmother was hanged as a Connecticut witch, is himself a vanishing type of American.

NO opera season at the Metropolitan is complete without a success story, and this year's concerns the soprano Shakeh Vartenissian. Armenian by birth, Miss Vartenissian was living in Lebanon when she was advised to come to the United States for vocal study.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Japan has a good chance of balancing her exports and imports at approximately $2,100,000,000 each within a five-year span, according to statistics being assembled here.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2 -- There is too much "scapegoating" on the subject of juvenile delinquency and not enough careful search for the real causes, an authority on adolescent psychology said today.
Fundamentally, the proceeds of sale of a corporation's own stock should constitute capital and should not be subject to the income tax.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Frank Nardulli, Colgate halfback, scored two touchdowns -one on a 39-yard run and the other on a 15-yard pass from the quarterback, Dick Lalla -- as the Red Raiders whipped Holy Cross, 18 -- 0 today for their second successive football victory.

YOUR unqualified enthusiasm for "Sabrina" is, in my opinion, a view that would be hard to defend. Is it not puzzling that so knowing an artisan as Billy Wilder, whose deft and skillful way with a comedy first came to my notice with "The Major and the Minor" more than a decade ago, should have injected so grim a note into Samuel Taylor's light-hearted play?

MOST if not all of the myths that Americans hold about the Arctic are the result of misconceptions based on unfamiliarity. To them the word conjures up visions of inaccessible stretches of snow and ice where mere survival is well-nigh impossible.
DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 2 (UP) -Duke turned Tennessee's flank for one touchdown run and then held on today to beat the Volunteers, 7 to 6, before 30,000 fans.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- While the British gave what they call a lead to Europe this week in agreeing to leave their troops on the Continent at the pleasure of Continental nations, Pierre Mends-France, the French Premier, appeared to have changed from an opponent to an advocate of supranational powers.

EVER since Stanislavski told the story of the actress who had her hands tied behind her back by the director until her need to make a gesture became so urgent she burst her bonds, there has grown in our players a fear of their hands and a reluctance to use them lest they be accused of "cheap theatricals."
October, supposed to initiate a season of crisp, clear and invigorating weather, instead has arrived hot, humid and strongly smacking of the midsummer dog days.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 2 -Len Dawson cut down the nation's No. 1 football team, Notre Dame, today with four touchdown passes good for a total of 156 yards to sharpshoot Purdue to a stunning 27 -- 14 upset triumph.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 2 -- A blue belton English setter from the kennel of E. Keene Annis of Ashland, Mass., became best in show today in the sixteenth event of the Suffolk County Kennel Club. He was a 3-year-old, Ch. Silvermine Jackpot, put up to the top award by James Wright, a vice president of the club, just before night closed in on the West Hills Riding Club grounds.
Members of the benefit committee of the Children's Village, a rehabilitation school for boys at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., have chosen two shows for its annual autumn theatre parties.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2 (AP) -- The University of Massachusetts, which couldn't score a touchdown in Harvard Stadium in three previous meetings, tallied a pair today to upset the Crimson, 13 -- 7.
GUATEMALA, Sept. 25 -Further proof that clandestine organizations are working underground against the Government is furnished by the current surreptitious circulation of a subversive manifesto.

IN "The Foster Brothers" Mr. Frankland makes a valiant attempt to break free of the standard historical novel mold, to re-create England in Viking times as it really was. His is a concept of novel-writing that is very different from the easier, more popular one that has latterly produced its hundreds of colorful costume romances.

WAIDHAUS, Germany, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Two United States soldiers, with Czech-style military haircuts as souvenirs of two weeks' imprisonment in Communist Czechoslovakia as spy suspects, were set free at this West German border point today.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 2 (UP) -Duke Washington, fullback for Washington State, made a sparkling debut today as the first Negro to play in the University of Texas' Memorial Stadium, but Texas power proved too much and the Longhorns rolled to a 40-14 victory before 27,000.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 2 (UP) -- Allie Reynolds of the New York Yankees, highest paid pitcher in the team's history, at a reported $41,500, said today he may not play next year.
Princeton leveled Columbia's defenses with a series of long-range strikes yesterday to register an impressive 54-20 victory in New York's first major football attraction of the 1954 campaign.

A SPECIAL supplement of The Times Literary Supplement has just come to hand, and it is our pleasure to report it is a prodigious job, both in bulk and dedication. Numbered from i to c (100 to us), the page i screamer reads "American Writing Today: Its Independence and Vigour."

THIS is the ninth book by Wright Morris, probably the most original young novelist writing in the United States. With each book, the chorus of critical praise has swelled, and spread out across the country is a thin band of Morris addicts who share in a kind of fraternal enthusiasm.

Arthur Daley in "Players + Spirit + Leadership" (Sept. 5), an explanation of pennant winning baseball, makes this statement: "There are some who will shrivel in the heat of a pennant race and others who will come from the fire as hard as tempered steel.

THE westward movement in television is gathering momentum. If the pace keeps up without slackening for another year, Hollywood won't be just the movie capital of the world but the television center as well.
A limited number of the best seats has been taken for the Oct. 19 performance of the musical comedy "The Boy Friend" by the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy.

TRENTON, Oct. 2 -- Although all of New Jersey's fourteen House seats are at stake this year, political observers are watching only six of the contests. The Republicans are virtually assured of victory in three other contests and the Democrats in five.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 2 -Eleven million Brazilians will vote tomorrow for members of the Chamber of Deputies, Senators, Governors and Aldermen.

BOSTON, Oct. 2 -- The business situation in New England indicates no important trend. Unemployment, which showed a large increase over last year, dropped moderately in August, but by less than seasonal proportions.

The Great War With the Indians has ended. The tomohawks, the arrows and the scalping knives lie broken and scattered in the dust. The war cries and tribal dances which stamped the determined chant of "Beat the Giants" into the earth have ceased. From the poles of the Indians' tepees there hangs no scalps or trophies.
A nation-wide safety campaign starts today with the opening of Fire Prevention Week, which has been set aside by President Eisenhower for special observance.

An original and colorful decor and an elaborate program of entertainment are being planned for the Belmont Futurity Ball to be held Thursday night in the redecorated ballroom of the Ambassador under the auspices of Belmont Park.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 -- A breathless hush fell over the sprawling expanse of the Municipal Stadium in the ninth inning today. It was so quiet that you almost could hear a heart break. The Cleveland Indians, proud champions of the American League with a record victory total of 111 games, were down to their last three outs.
The New York Giants won the 1954 world series yesterday when they defeated the Cleveland Indians 7 to 4, for the fourth straight game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- In the wake of the censure recommendation against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy this week, many political observers here feel that the Eisenhower Administration has succeeded in isolating the Senator from the issue that gained him prominence.

A 4-year-old Michigan girl who has never walked because of a disease but who plays cheerfully with her walking doll has been selected as the national poster child in the Fire Fighters' March for Muscular Dystrophy.

ON Wednesday and Thursday a two-day tour has been planned to absorb much of the historic heritage and culture centered in the Hudson River Valley. This tour is called "Country Days" and is sponsored jointly by the New York Botanical Garden, the Clermont Recreational and Educational Committee and the Red Hook Students Aid Association, Inc.
A new method of coopering, or sealing, railroad freight cars that each year transport 7,500,000 carloads of grain and grain products has been perfected by A.J. Gerrard Co., Melrose Park, Ill.

Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, former president of the United Nations General Assembly, said last night that her native India "will have betrayed" the late Mohandas K. Gandhi unless it could recapture his "courage and faith."

DURING World War II teams of Allied soldiers in Southeast Asia infiltrated behind enemy lines to spread propaganda and sabotage strategic objectives. In "The Bridge Over the River Kwai" Pierre Boulle attempts to tell alternately the story of one such British team of "Force 316" and that of British soldiers in a Japanese jungle prison camp who are forced to build a link in a crucial supply line.
HARTFORD, Oct. 2 -- Connecticut's gentlemanly election campaign continued on its leisurely pace this week, with the three candidates for Governor hardly taking notice of one another.

SUMMER-FLOWERING bulbs have done their stint in my New Jersey garden for this season, and the time has come to dig them up and store them for the winter. On this care depends their potential well-being for another performance in the flower border next season.

REDUCED rates in Italy will enable the tourist who elects to visit the country during the off-season period to avail himself of the Italian Tourist Economy Plan. This plan, recently announced as effective between Nov. 1, 1954, and March 15, 1955, entitles foreign visitors to a 25 per cent reduction on railroads, cableways, buslines and coastwise and lake shipping in Italy.

An examiner of the Federal Maritime Board has recommended disapproval of a petition by the Trans-Pacific Freight Conference of Japan for Federal Maritime Board approval of the use of a contract-non-contract rate system.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2 -Yale and Brown put on a football scoring jamboree in midsummer heat of 88 degrees today and the decision went to the Elis, 26 -- 24, on their ability to kick extra points after touchdown.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 2 (AP) -- A disputed touchdown by Alan (The Horse) Ameche -- made when Michigan State had only ten men on the field -- gave Wisconsin a 6-0 victory in a wild and weird Big Ten football game watched by 51,195 today.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 -- Maybe taking four straight World Series games from the Indians was too easy for the Giants. Maybe the league champions were confident they could do it from the start. But certainly the players failed to stage any uproarious demonstration today as they returned to their dressing room after the clincher.
A strike and a lockout in 460 commercial printing and lithographing plants in the New York metropolitan area are scheduled for tomorrow morning.

RICHMOND, Oct. 2 -- Business news in the Fifth Reserve District this week was highlighted by the announcement that a $24,000,000 steam electric generating plant will be built in North Carolina. Upon completion it will be the largest single plant of its kind in the Southeast.

Harrison E. Salisbury, in his article "Russia's Art Reflects Trends in Russia" (Sept. 12), states that "the most important requirement of present-day Soviet painting is, undoubtedly, that it should tell a story, preferably a story with a certain moral value."
The Citizens Union yesterday questioned the desirability of reported Park Department plans to build six boys' club type of recreational centers to fight juvenile delinquency.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The future of Aneurin Bevan, leader of the Labor party's left wing, was the principal subject of discussion among delegates to the party's annual conference at Scarsborough as they packed and left for home on Friday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Youngsters now can start delving into the intricacies of science and technology and have a good time doing it.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 2 -- Army's black knights, uncoiling a frightening ground game, extended one of football's most baffling jinxes today by upsetting Michigan, 26 to 7, before 69,783 fans. The Cadets, rated 13 points below Michigan, scored three times in the first half on end thrusts by Mike Zeigler, Pat Uebel and Tommy Bell.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (Reuters) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda criticized today the London nine-power conference on German rearmament and at the same time extolled the latest Soviet disarmament plan.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 2 -- The complex problem of how to bring about varying measures of racial integration in the public school systems of more than one-third of the country has produced a checkerboard pattern of reaction.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- Another step forward in the state's pioneer cancer research program will marked on Oct. 14 when Governor Dewey dedicates a new wing of the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo.
Baseball was merely a passing interest yesterday in Brooklyn, where 5,000 persons turned out to see an orchid display in the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, Fulton Street and DeKalb Avenue.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 -- Little Don Liddle, the southpaw who drew his first world series start today and emerged the winning pitcher, was very happy but a little annoyed with himself because of his error in the three-run Cleveland fifth inning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- In labor history the period running roughly from 1946 to 1956 may come to be known as the welfare fund era.

ALTHOUGH it may sound somewhat incongruous, now is the time for summer-long vacationers to think of their garden. For careful fall planning and planting will give the away-from-home gardener a chance to see some bloom before he leaves for the summer's respite and to find some blossoms coming into being upon his return.

DENVER, Oct. 2 -- The United States must improve its techniques of influencing world opinion to preserve the unity of the free nations, the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe asserted today. If it fails to do so, it runs the risk of having the Soviet Union "pick us off one by one," said Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther.
WASHINGTON, with Congress gone, is like a summer resort when the season has ended. Its two greatest political hostelries, the Capitol and the White House, are left to the caretakers and the cleaners.

IT is usually the hunter with a "sense of direction," who fails to return to camp by dark. He is the type who "doesn't need a compass," but he forces the rest of the party to spend half the night burning up ammunition and building fires in order to guide him home.
WHITE LAKE, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- The International Fur and Leather Workers Union, independent, announced today the resignation of Ben Gold as its president.

THE first exhibition of the season to bring together work by many well-known modern artists has opened at the galleries of Paul Rosenberg. It is retrospective in character as so many of this season's events seem to be.

Paced by Earl Bloom, who scored 17 points, Worcester Tech's football team crushed Brooklyn College, 61 -- 0, yesterday on the loser's gridiron. The game opened the season for both teams and extended to twenty-one the number of successive contests the Kingsmen have played without winning.

L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, declared yesterday that it was becoming clear the Democratic candidates for state office proposed to "carry on the high-tax tradition of the Democratic party."

IMMORTALITY, Mary Watkins Cushing notes in the foreword to her intimate and enthralling account of the life and times of the great diva Olive Fremstad (1870-1951) is not for the interpretive performer.

An intensive talent search, designed to recruit for the teaching profession young men and women of highest intellect, character and personality, has begun at Princeton University. The search is sponsored by the National Woodrow Wilson Fellowship Program.
SEATTLE, Oct. 2 -- Another national emergency would find America weak in trained personnel for shipyards, a subcommittee of the House Merchant Marine Committee was told this week.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 2 -(UP) -- Southern California, sparked by a 68-yard first-period gallop by towering Ed Fouch, took advantage of ten fumbles by Northwestern University today and gained a 12-7 victory over the Evanston Big Ten entry for its third consecutive triumph of the year.
BERLIN, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Russians began erecting a new tank memorial just outside Berlin today to replace the battered one in the United States sector -- a sore spot to them in recent years.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 2 -- Nebraska voters have a chance to overhaul the property tax system and bring a couple of other things up to date through eight constitutional amendments on the election ballot Nov. 2.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Freddie Wilcox, a sophomore quarterback, led Tulane to a 7-7 tie with favored North Carolina today.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 (UP) -- The National Hockey League All-Stars spotted the Detroit Red Wings two goals in the first period tonight, but fought back to gain a 2-2 tie in the eighth annual All-Star game before 11,188 fans at Olympia. The Stars scored twice in the second period.
QUEBEC, Sept. 25 -- Thanks to "fish sticks" and Government aid, a revolution is taking place in the fishing industry of the Gaspe peninsula.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 2 -- Nevada Republican leaders are planning a new legal move to keep the state's second Republican Senator in office through 1956.

ELIZABETH CITY, N. C., Oct. 2 -- A world speed-boat record for a competitive five-mile course was broken twice by the same pilot today on the Pasquotank River in the first half of a two-day international cup regatta.

WHEN Ginette Neveu died in a plane crash in 1949 the musical world experienced a shock paralleled only by the death, in similar circumstances, of William Kapell last year. The young French violinist was on the threshold of greatness.
I read your report on conductors' choices with interest. I was struck by certain divergences.

The number of school-age youngsters in classroom groups studying early American history has jumped 14 per cent over last year, reports Colonial Williamsburg (Va.), the nonprofit educational organization restoring eighteenth-century Williamsburg. The total has jumped 150 per cent since the program of integrated study tours started eight years ago.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 2 -Middlebury College announced tonight a gift of $116,500 to its $3,000,000 development fund from Edwin S.S. Sunderland of New York. Mr. Sunderland, a lawyer, is chairman of the development program and a Middlebury trustee.

The Jewish Holidays last week meant that many garment manufacturing plants were closed and this kept retail buyers home. But the mails were being delivered and they brought resident buying offices an increasing number of requests for merchandise.

NOTING that are "people are prone to criticize their legislators, but too seldom give them honor for the good they do," the National Parks Association is presenting an award for distinguished service to Representative John P. Saylor (Republican) of Pennsylvania, one of the most effective supporters in Congress of the conservation of or country's resources.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 2 -Indonesian authorities arrested four more Dutch nationals yesterday, bringing the total number of Netherlanders detained here this week to ten. An undisclosed number of other persons, believed to include Chinese, have also been arrested.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 3 -- All outstanding differences on the arming of West Germany and on the Federal Republic's sovereignty were resolved early this morning when the nine-power conference completed its deliberations.

ONE conspicuous feature of twentieth-century art has been its drastic separation into exclusive compartments. The painter has produced his canvases without a thought to their proper setting; the architect has built as if masonry by itself were sufficiently eye-catching; and the sculptor has been relegated to the garden.

AFTER all the righteous indignation that was shouted some nine months ago over a simple suggestion by Samuel Goldwyn that the screen's Production Code should be "revised," it is interesting -and slightly ironic -- that announcement should have been made the other day to the effect that certain simple revisions in the Code had, indeed, been approved.

The Guggenheim Medal; an aviation award, will be presented to Clarence Decatur Howe, Canada's Minister of Trade and Commerce and Minister of Defense Production, Friday in Los Angeles. This was announced yesterday by J. Carlton Ward Jr., chairman of the Daniel Guggenheim Board of Award.

THE Broadway theatregoing pace for October, following its seasonal bent, will be almost double that of last month, when five new stage attractions were unwrapped for the followers of the drama. As of the moment, three musicals and five straight plays are scheduled to be displayed.
One major retailer here is quietly getting tough about discount competition.

LIKE his Turkish counterpart Nasr-ed-Din Hodja, the Persian folk-hero Nasr-ed-Din Mullah is a priest who also acts as teacher and judge. It is easy to see from these stories which Mrs. Kelsey heard in Iran that he is loved there for a remarkable combination of simplicity, wit and wisdom.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Sixteen world series records were broken and fifteen tied in the New York Giants' four-game sweep of the Cleveland Indians.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The extraordinary furor over "The Hydrogen Bomb," a new book by James Shepley and Clam Blair Jr., has ripped open again the ugly scars left by the Oppenheimer case.

NEW HARTFORD, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Senator Irving M. Ives hammered New York State democrats on four counts today he carried his Republican campaign for Governor into the heart of the state's dairy country.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP) -Mississippi's Rebels routed Villanova, 52 -- 0, tonight with a powerful passing attack before 95,607 spectators at Municipal Stadium.
