PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (UP) -Dick and Bob McNamara, brothers from Hastings, Minn., and a Minnesota pass offense carried the Golden Gophers to a 46-7 victory over Pittsburgh today before a crowd of 33,369.

DE FALLA: Ritual Fire Dance; PONCE: Estrellita; GADE: Jalousie; CHABRIER: Espana; LECUONA: Malaguena; Andalucia; PADILIA: El Relicario; GRANADOS: Intermezzo From Goyescas; Hollywood Bowl Symphony Orchestra, Carmen Dragon, conductor (Capitol).

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- At 12:13 P. M., on Oct. 11 the ninth annual Pennsylvania Week is scheduled to be launched with the aid of a ray of sunshine and the firing of a Noonday Gun at Philadelphia's Franklin Institute.

SARANAC LAKE -- A week from tomorrow, Oct. 11, is Canada's Thanksgiving Day, a day for which the Adirondack Mountain resort people also are grateful. Preparations are under way in hotels, motels and in shops and tourist centers for the throngs of Canadian holidayers expected to cross the border to enjoy the foreign flavor of a three-day week-end in the States, a chance to do some shopping, and a look at the autumn foliage.

ENGLISH history is here treated with the respectful familiarity befitting the book's title. Helen Ashton has chosen the back-stairs' approach to a view of England's royal family under the reign of George III and IV.
The first major oil refinery in North Dakota was dedicated officially yesterday.

VERY English in detail, very knowledgeable in horsemanship, Kathleen Herald's books have a rather special audience, but they are marked by an intensity of feeling, spiked by a wry, dry humor which appeals to those girls who want something more than the average, hackneyed horse story.

Throughout the country considerable attention is being paid to the financial structure of public school systems. Local communities are calling upon the state governments for greater support. As operating expenses rise, the pressures put upon the states increase.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 2 -Projects involving some 4,000,000 kilowatts of hydroelectric capacity -- equivalent to two Grand Coulee dams -- are scheduled for completion in the Pacific Northwest in the next eight years.

APPRECIATION of life is not easy. One says he must earn a living -- but why? Why live? It seems as though a great many who do earn the living or have it given them do not get much out of it. A sort of aimless racing up and down in automobiles, an aimless satisfaction in amassing money, an aimless pursuit of "pleasure," nothing personal, all external.

THE Italians, who planted their flag on the summit of K-2 (Mount Godwin Austen) on July 31, had the foresight to tote color cameras on this exhausting Himalayan climb and, as a result, a feature film record of their conquest of the world's second highest peak is being made ready for release next month.

KURT WEILL'S Threepenny Opera, in an English adaptation by Marc Blitzstein, opened a successful run on March 10 of this year at the Theatre de Lys on Christopher Street. The work has now Been recorded for M-G-M by the Theatre de Lys cast, with Lotte Lenya, widow of the composer, in the role of Jenny, which she created at the Berlin premiere.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France began tonight his explanation to the French people of the agreement on West German armament he has apparently reached in London with representatives of eight other allied nations.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor announced yesterday that it planned drastic action immediately to stop "gangster-directed discrimination" in hiring longshoremen and to prevent a return to the illegal shape-up system of hiring.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Armour Research Foundation of the Illinois Institute of Technology is planning construction of a 50,000 watt nuclear reactor that it hopes to have in operation within a year, Dr. Haldon A. Leedy, director, has announced.

A FEW weeks ago this reviewer was flying over Central Africa in a large airliner when one of the motors failed. For two and one-half interminable hours the passengers sweated it out until the safe landing at Kano -- an interesting, though hardly agreeable, experience.

That Sir Winston Churchill, who celebrates his eightieth birthday in November, continues to stand conspicuous as Great Britain's leading citizen should not be surprising. There have been many elder statesmen; in fact, it might be argued that practicing statecraft is an aid to longevity.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 2 -- Frank Wengrzyn's tackle of George Iartlett in the end zone for a safety proved the difference today as Carnegie Tech edged Lafayette, 23--21.

FOR the third time Mr. Price has used an effective formula for serving up a satisfying package of suspense and derring-do. Again we find those two energetic young adventurers, Hal and Roger Hunt, embarking on a South Seas scientific expedition, sponsored this time by the Oceanographic Institute.

SOMETHING akin to "normalcy" prevails in the business world. A good definition of business "normalcy" is difficult to find. but for most concerns it is a happy medium between the high and low extremes of volume.
United States foreign trade, especially in nonmilitary exports, has been presenting a much brighter picture in recent months than had been expected earlier this year.
New schools and playgrounds are necessary here if the problem of juvenile delinquency is to be solved, Rabbi Samuel M. Segal declared yesterday at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

FOR the first time in its history, the International Contemporary Music Festival at Venice this year chose only English-language works to represent its operatic contribution. First came Benjamin Britten's Biennale-commissioned chamber-opera, "The Turn of the Screw"; and, as the grand finale, the first Italian performance of "Porgy and Bess" which, judging from the interest of the critics, will be as successful here as elsewhere.
In regard to the letter in your section on Sept. 12 about the disrespect shown to patrons at the box office I would like to state my experience with theatre box-office men.
Thank you for George F. Kennan's fine article "For the Defense of Europe" (Sept. 12).

MUSK oxen, named for their smell, have just come to reside in a square-mile farm in Vermont, having been captured on the snowy tundra of Arctic northwest Canada. They were introduced to establish a new kind of wool industry in the Granite State.
The passing of Harry Conway (Bud) Fisher, the creator of "Mutt and Jeff," should not be forgotten without paying proper homage to Mr. Fisher's contribution to the animated cartoon.
LONDON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Moscow-bound Arsenal wiped out a two-goal deficit and forced a thrilling 3-3 draw at Leicester today before a crowd of 42,486 -- a Leicester record.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 2 (AP) -Washington lost all its quaterbacks but still managed to make its Coast Conference debut successful tonight, defeating Oregon State in a bitter battle, 17 -- 7.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Evenings soon may hold a hint of frost. Bushel and peach baskets, burlap and newspapers kept in a handy place for covering may save tender plants so that they continue to bloom in ensuing mild weather. Marigolds, zinnias, cosmos, dahlias and tomatoes are among the plants harmed by early frost and worth protecting.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 2 -In Iowa, one of the critical states in the struggle for control of the next Congress, the issue has become simple:

The American Association of Social Workers has announced the appointment of Miss Margaret E. Adams as assistant executive secretary for chapter services. The association is the largest professional membership association in the social work field, with 13,500 members in 131 chapters.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2 (AP) -- William G. Helis Jr.'s Helioscope established a track mark in winning the $28,625 Olympic Handicap today before 19,407 patrons.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 2 -Harry Powell stepped out front on the first leg and was never headed as he won the International class race with Three Belles during the third post Y.R.A. regatta for the deCoppet and Haebler trophies off Larchmont Yacht Club today.
TRENTON, Oct. 2 -- Twenty girls clad in night clothes broke out of a home for juvenile delinquents here tonight, but seventeen were caught within two hours.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 2 -Navy's football team paid its first call in history to this New Hampshire town today. And though the reception accorded by the Dartmouth Indians was none too cordial for three periods, the midshipmen scored thirty-five points in the last period to win, 42 -- 7.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 2 -- King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia today postponed his scheduled arrival in Bangkok tomorrow on a state visit.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- The building pace in the Chicago area picked up in August, compared with July, and topped year-ago figures. The improvement was more pronounced in comparing the record with July, when a pick-up was noted over June, but totals for the month, were under a year ago.

DURING the last year the level of stock prices on the New York Exchange has risen about 30 per cent. On Sept. 16, almost a year after the start of the boom, the Standard and Poor index of fifty industrial stock prices made an all-time high -- 27 per cent higher than in 1929.

THE statement may be premature, but writers of Westerns seem to be inclining toward the historical -- if not precisely historical novels, at least novels with historical backgrounds. An outstanding fault marks many of them -- the writers attempt to make history and historical characters subordinate to the plot.
TOKYO, Sept. 24 -- Japan is seeking means to present her quarrel with South Korea over Take Island to an international body for adjudication.
C. Waller Barrett, who has spent thirty-four years working hard to meet tight steamship schedules, was two years ahead of himself last Thursday.

TO have geraniums gaily blooming in the house all through the winter is the goal of many a gardener. This, of course, is a definite possibility if one point is kept in mind. Geraniums that have flowered outdoors all summer will seldom perform again in winter.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 2 -Jack Lyons of the Garden City Golf Club will face Eddie Neu of Rockville and Tony Cisco of St. George's will meet George Hayden of Huntington Crescent in the semi-finals tomorrow morning of the fourth annual Havemeyer invitation golf tournament at the Southward Ho Country Club.

THE scientific and political odyssey of the H-bomb is the main theme of this book by two Washington correspondents of Time and Life. The story is also the triumph of Edward Teller, the scientist the authors regard as most responsible for the success of the American H-bomb.
A novelty soap factory started in Vienna more than a century ago has received a big infusion of American merchandising, promotion and advertising methods.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Oct. 2 -- Haverford College capitalized on two Wagner miscues in the first five minutes to capture its opening football game, 14 to 6, at Walton Field today. The setback was Wagner's second in as many starts.
While in the Soviet Union Mr. Salbury's reports on Russia were factual and calm, he now seems to have suffered a sea-change which cannot be excused by lack of restrictions.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 2 -- Stores in the Tenth Federal Reserve District are poised to push ahead of their 1953 sales total now that the results for the first nine months are shown to be on a par with last year. Since volume was tapering off in the fourth quarter of 1953 the comparisons will not be so difficult.
The first Shot in what is likely to become the branch banking battle at the next legislative session in Albany was fired last week.
MONTREAL, Sept. 29 -- Montreal's Mayor, Camillien Houde, will retire soon from his hectic political career.

TWO of the United Nations' specialized agencies not hitherto postally honored by the world organization will be the themes of four of the eight commemorative stamps being planned for release during 1955. DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- One of the most important factors in the world situation today is that "while the American economy has been shrinking, the Soviet economy has been growing fast," Adlai E. Stevenson said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -Albert M. Cole, Housing Administrator, today set up standards that cities must meet to qualify for Federal aid in slum clearance and "urban renewal" projects.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 -- Hot and cold, one club steaming, the other freezing. That was the story of the 1954 world series.
Mayor Wagner deferred yesterday for sixty days from last Friday the deadline by which city departments would be required to set up joint labor relations committees.

An unusual loan exhibition of paintings, known a "Young Collectors," will be held next month in the Guest House of Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d at 242 East Fifty-second Street for the benefit of the work of the Junior Council of the Museum of Modern Art.
GEORGE BEYNON celebrated his ninetieth birthday last month, or rather the bridge players of New York City celebrated it for him. They did it in the most appropriate way, with a duplicate bridge game.
DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- Two of the world's oldest automobile companies became the Studebaker-Packard Corporation yesterday -- and speculation about further mergers started up again.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Field reports of the trend of the November election reflect a high prevalence of belief by observers for the national party managements and the press that the Democrats will carry Congress. So high at the moment is this prevalence in private calculation that it brings to mind the identical condition in 1948 when the bulk of the forecasts went wrong.

KHARKOV, U.S.S.R., Oct. 1 -- The trip by automobile from Moscow to Kharkov is a journey through two eras of Russian history.

Hours before he was scheduled to go on the air, Jackie Gleason, the television comedian, threatened to cancel last night's production of "The Jackie Gleason Show" after a dispute with members of the production crew.

A study of plans to deal with the Supreme Court decision on segregation in the schools, made by this newspaper and published today, suggests that some difficult problems still lie ahead, especially in the Deep South. In Alabama, in Florida, in Georgia, in South Carolina, in Texas, in Louisiana and in Mississippi, there is either a tendency to work for more time or to evade the Court's decision in one way or another.

I read with great interest and encouragement Greg MacGregor's "Most Studious Army" (Sept. 19) -- which told how the Eighth Army in Korea had licked its illiteracy problem. I am happy to be able to add another facet to the story, which perhaps might be headed "Most Generous Army."
From Harvard comes the news that Prof. R.B. Woodward and some colleagues in the department of chemistry have succeeded in totally synthesizing strychnine, well known as a powerful poison.

National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week will be marked by the Federation of the Handicapped, Inc., today through Saturday. Milton Cohen, executive director of the federation, invited employers and the general public yesterday to visit and see how physically handicapped persons are preparing for jobs at the federation, 211 West Fourteenth Street.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Jean Mons, Permanent Secretary of the French National Defense Committee, which coordinates defense, was arrested today on a charge of negligence in allowing "leaks" about the committee's meetings.

MORE than thirty hours of broadcast time will be devoted by WNYC to its fifth annual American Art Festival which starts today and will run through Saturday. In addition to the many special programs concerned with the problems of the artist, the collector and the layman and the activities of museums, art galleries, educational institutions and art groups, most regularly scheduled programs will give time to interviews, discussions and music on an art theme.

New York City retailers faced the problem last week of matching last year's sales despite two days of religious holidays and the beginning of the World Series. In the final analysis though, neither of these events affected business as much as the weather.

ONCE again the doctors have been gathering gravely round the bedside of the novel. Everybody knows that the old harridan, after a lusty life, has been suffering from recurrent megrims, but according to the latest bulletins, this time she's a goner.

The second annual Versailles Ball will be held on Oct. 28 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Arranged under the auspices of the American Friends of Versailles, the fete serves to raise funds for the restoration of the Royal Chateau at Versailles, France.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 2 -- The passing of Gary Kerkorian, and the running of Buddy Young were the chief weapons as the Baltimore Colts notched their first National Football League victory in two starts tonight by halting the New York Giants, 20 to 14, before 27,088 fans in Memorial Stadium.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2 -A Harvard College program for meeting the special needs of outstanding students in the country's secondary schools was announced this week by Dean McGeorge Bundy of the college.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1 -- Yugoslavia would like to join the Council Of Europe, but a majority of that body apparently does not want her, a high Government official declared today.

COURAGE and family love help make happiness out of hardship in this tale of postwar Italy. Aldo, shivering in his family's puddle-filled basement, dreams of sunshine and warmth and sets forth adventuring.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The prospects for international control of atomic energy, which had become the most hopeless of the United Nations' lost causes, have suddenly revived as a result of the surprise new Soviet proposals. If they mean what they seem to mean, there is now a real possibility that a way can be found to banish the specter of destruction by atomic or hydrogen bombs.
TRENTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner has written Secretary for Air Harold E. Talbott that his Administration is opposed to operation of jet fighter planes at Newark Airport.

ANYA SETON, like her father Ernest Thompson Seton, is a skilled yarn spinner. In her new novel she has an interesting yarn to spin: a love story that changed the course of history. Katherine de Roet was Chaucer's sister-in-law and the wife of a Saxon knight when John of Gaunt (Edward III's fourth son) began the pursuit of her, which ended in Katherine's becoming his mistress.

THE 1954 convention of the Photographic Society of America, to be held Wednesday through Saturday at the Drake Hotel in Chicago, offers a rounded program of talks, demonstrations, picture exhibits and special events in the fields of still, movies, stereo and specialized photography.

WHEN Libby Holman returns to Broadway tomorrow night she will be offering a program of songs for which she has not yet been able to find a satisfactory description. On the marquee of the Bijou Theatre, they are calling the presentation, "Blues, Ballads and Sin-Songs" and Miss Holman thinks that will have to do.

COMFORTABLE assurance in our external relations has left us, probably not to return for incalculable years, if ever. Keeping track of the delicately interactive factors of capability and intentions in relationships between ourselves and the world beyond is exacting business of highest subtlety -- an exercise not in statics of algebra but in dynamics of a vital sort of calculus.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 2 -- Malayan Communist insurgents are said to realize now that their armed struggle has failed and they are reported to have switched over to the Chinese Communist party's policy of infiltration and penetration.

DENVER, Oct. 2 -- The temporary White House announced today that the United States would send a small expedition aboard an icebreaker to the Antarctic "in line with continuing United States interest in the region."
CARLSBAD, N. M., Oct. 2 -The United States potash industry, which is centered in five mines near here, is looking for new customers.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 2 -- A solution of the political deadlock in Vietnam seemed today to depend greatly on French and United States action.

The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that Mrs. Herbert Witherspoon, director of the Metropolitan Opera, Guild, resigned last week. She will enter music, theatre and lecture management in Denver.

In recognition of his sixteen years of service, B.A. Tompkins, president of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., was the recipient of a testimonial dinner last Wednesday at the River Club, 447 East Fifty-second Street.

DENVER, Oct. 2 -- President Eisenhower will give Friday night what is described as a hitting inspirational talk" at a public appearance in Denver's City Auditorium. Vice President Richard M. Nixon will appear with him.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- A semi-automatic transmission for passenger cars operated by electromagnetic control is among the newest developments offered as automotive equipment in France. The extra cost when installed is about 22,000 francs or $63 in American currency.

WU, a small boy of the ancient Miao people who still live in southwest China, sets his heart on buying his mother a bracelet so that everyone will know she is the most beautiful mother in the world. He pins his hopes on two watermelon seeds -- rarities in that region -- and secretly tends his plants on a hidden terrace through drought and storm.

FRANKFURT. TUCKED away in one of twenty-five display buildings at the International Fair which opened in Frankfurt last month was an exhibit of a new kind. It was composed of household articles being introduced to buyers for the first time. The items had been selected for their beauty and functionalism by a committee of architects, designers and craftsmen.

An unidentified middle-aged woman was stabbed fatally by a 20-year-old youth on an I.R.T. subway train at 1 o'clock this morning. After the attack the youth was captured by a patrolman as he attempted to flee.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 -- The overwhelming vote Thursday for the city tax on individual and business earnings created a stable financial base for a long-deferred program of public improvements. It also freed the city administration of the fear of periodic financial crisis.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Oct. 2 (UP) -- Polly Riley of Ft. Worth, Tex., eliminated erratic-shooting Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, 6 and 5, today to move into the final round of the twenty-fourth Trans-Mississippi women's amateur golf tournament.

Native Dancer, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's great race horse, made a final appearance under silks at Belmont Park yesterday. Between the fifth and sixth races he walked to the head of the stretch, and then jogged back past the stands, to the accompaniment of applause from many of the 33,600 fans.

A backward look at September's stock market produces a somewhat confusing picture. From a price standpoint it was a good month -- the best in fifteen years. Share prices as measured by The New York Times composite average of fifty representative issues rose 14.52 points, lifting that index 52.63 points for the year.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 3 (AP) -- George Blanda had a hand and foot in all his team's scoring today, flipping a touchdown pass and kicking a field goal and extra point as the Chicago Bears defeated the Green Bay Packers, 10 -- 3, in a National Football League game at rain-drenched City Stadium.

Liquidation of the October contract and hedge selling put pressure on domestic cotton prices last week, according to the weekly report of the New York Cotton Exchange. By the close of trading Friday active futures contracts were down 19 to 48 points from the end of the preceding week, with December losing most and distant March least.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A House committee reported today that the Defense Department had abolished 17,500 unnecessary jobs in the last nine months, and cut an estimated $95,000,000 a year from its payrolls.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Export-Import bank of Washington today is a firmly established institution with the blessing of the Republican Administration. Congress recently expanded its lending power to $5,500,000,000, and President Eisenhower last week began making appointments to an expanded directorship.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- The world's greatest manufacturing industry is heading into the 1955-model automobile year with several critical questions up for answer. The last twelve months have been a period of test; the next twelve should be one of decision.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., Sept. 30 -- It was pouring rain today in the Ukraine, bringing autumn relief to this major grain-growing region of the Soviet Union after a hot, dry summer.

Edward R. Murrow, radio and television reporter and commentator, last night received the annual Freedom House award and a plaque inscribed: "Free men were heartened by his courage in exposing those who would divide us by exploiting our fears."

Senator Ives, promptly and properly, has declined to take a stand in advance on the issues presented by the Watkins committee. "For me as a member of the Senate, which must act in a quasi-judicial capacity in passing upon the charges against Senator McCarthy, to prejudge the case would be most inappropriate."

The financial plight of many of the nation's private colleges and universities was discussed again at a meeting of the National Fund for Medical Education. The eighty-four business and medical leaders in attendance were told that medical schools alone would require $10,000,000 annually in contributions just to cover their operating deficits, to say nothing of financing new construction and modernization of existing facilities.

Jude Smith tallied two touchdowns, passed for another and figured in the scoring of the other two as St. John's Prep downed All Hallows, 31 -- 7, in a Catholic High School Football League contest at Tilden Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Bobby Walston caught three touchdown passes and kicked five points after touchdown for 23 points today as the Philadelphia Eagles overcame a 16-point Chicago Cardinal lead for a 35-to-16 victory before 17,084 fans in Comiskey Park.
The contemporary world needs a "sensible religion," the Rev. Dr. Stanley Rawson, minister of the Messiah-All Souls Universalist Church of Portland, Me., said yesterday.
Two French leaders will fly here from Paris next month to attend a dinner commemorating the 150th anniversary of the first award of the Legion of Honor by the French Government.
The lumber industry faces rough weather in the next two decades, according to an exhaustive study recently made by the Stanford Research Institute.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Science Service) -- The rare trumpeter swan now boasts a census of 642 in the United States, it was announced today by Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Administration sources pictured the success of the nine-power conference in London as a vindication of Secretary of State Dulles' foreign policy.

Gerald Moore, most widely known of contemporary English accompanists, gave a recital entitled "The Accompanist Speaks" yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Although deeply serious in his approach, Mr. Moore infused his talk with such a rich fund of humor, and had so much to say that was illuminating, that he had his large audience with him at every moment.
AVON, Conn., Oct. 3 -- A new field trial champion, Hardthill's Scotch Mist, was crowned today. The dog took a tightly contested open all-age stake for English springer spaniels.

TREBINJE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3 -- President Tito turned his attention today to the Middle and Far East. He offered to help out in the Israeli-Arab dispute and he praised the foreign policy of India under the leadership of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

TWO of the six carp bought for the pool in front of the Japanese House in the Museum of Modern Art's back yard have died. For a while the museum people were a little worried about it. The fish were contributed by a Wall Street broker on the museum board because the Japanese think carp bring good luck to a dwelling.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Democrats are believed to hold the edge, as of the moment, in twenty-five of the thirty-eight Senatorial elections to be held on Nov. 2.

The first of a series of theatre benefits for the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will be held tomorrow night at a preview performance of the musical "On Your Toes" at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. The show opens next Monday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Leo Sjogren, a 40-year-old tool and dye maker representing the Finnish-American A.C. of New York, today won the national championship 30-kilometer walk. His winning time for the 18 3/4-miles was 2:58:02.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Federal Government has put "for sale" signs on an atomic power laboratory, some old lighthouses, an acre of land reachable only by helicopter or parachute, six acres completely under water, a weather bureau and two islands in Lower New York Bay just off Staten Island.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The defense of the West has been set upon a "secure, constructive path," Secretary of State Dulles said tonight.
PARIS, Oct. 3 -- Premier Mendes-France tonight summoned a special session of the National Assembly for Thursday to hear his report on the European defense agreements adopted in London today.

Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, R.A. Butler, who is also the United Kingdom's representative on the board of governors of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, did not attend the seventh and eighth annual joint meetings of the Bretton Woods institutions in 1952 and 1953.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 3 -- When darkness rolled over the autumn-tinted five hills that circle the Danbury State Fair tonight, 40,000 men, women and children had streamed through the gates. The assemblage, on this first Sunday and second day of the 85-year-old exposition, was a near record.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 3 -- Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak returned tonight with qualified praise of the London agreement on European defense.
British sterling moved erratically last week. Under the weight of dollar purchases in London, the pound sold down to $2.79 1/32, on Monday and Tuesday. This was the lowest since October, 1952.

SHIRAZ, Iran, Oct. 3 -- The Paramount Khans of the powerful Ghashghai tribes and recently reinforced troops of the central Government are bracing for a showdown here. The issue is an ultimatum from Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi ordering Khosrow Khan, youngest and fiercest of four brother chieftains, to leave Iran for good.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 3 -- The North Vietnamese metropolis of Hanoi is going through the last stages of a transfer of control from French-Vietnamese to Vietminh hands.

The New York Civil Service Reform Association will begin today a campaign to acquaint public employes with laws that forbid them to give to or solicit for political funds. Hundreds of posters on the subject are being distributed to city, county and state offices.

The Husky Oil Company of Cody, Wyo., achieved a new record in sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended on June 30. This was disclosed in the annual report of Glenn E. Nielson, president, issued for publication today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 3 (AP) -- An Army officer popped half-way out of an airliner's emergency hatch 13,000 feet above Indiana yesterday and said today that he thought for a moment, "This is it."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today listed six Republican Senators and 104 Representatives -- including one Democrat up for re-election this fall -- whose votes on a half-dozen "key" issues this year were termed "wrong."

The airline pilots of the United States have slipped into the habit of using a new set of terms of speed and distance, as recently required of them, as easily and quickly as the public makes the transition from daylight saving to standard time.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 3 -- A 2-year-old Irish setter whose sire had been best in show at the event a year ago kept the title in the family today at the large Westbury Kennel Association competition at Phipps Field.
The appointment of Dr. Price A. Kirkpatrick, a psychiatrist, as director of the Domestic Relations Court's Bureau of Mental Health Services was announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The San Francisco Forty-niners and the Los Angeles Rams fought to a 24-24 tie before a crowd of 93,553 in a National Football League game today.

GRINNELL, Iowa, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Joseph N. Welch, the Boston attorney who came to national prominence during the Army- McCarthy hearings last spring, told a Grinnell College convocation today that "the truth about me is that I am not actually real."

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller declared here in a sermon yesterday that while life was a struggle against adversity, struggle and competition should not be guide-posts for man in his relationships with others.
The Rev. Francis X. Duffy urged Roman Catholics yesterday to pray the rosary daily during October.

Any pianist giving a recital yesterday had a handicap. The exceptionally soggy weather did not do the strings of the piano any good; and it may be that Howard Wells, who made his debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, had atmospheric conditions to blame for the lack of brightness to his tone.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 3 -- A. Donald Beveridge's forehand shot forty-six seconds into the second overtime period enabled the Meadow Brook-Triple C poloists to nip Brandywine, 9 -- 8, today for the Monty Waterbury Trophy and the national handicap championship.

DENVER, Oct. 3 -- No statement was issued today by President Eisenhower on the results of the nine-power conference in London on the rearming of West Germany and the defense of Western Europe. Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican of Indiana, said: "The President feels like I do -- it is a great triumph. He is very happy at the turn of events."

Hoping to dispel the apathy evident in the first two days of registration, Democratic leaders summoned key party workers to a conference last night to chart an all-out drive in the four remaining days.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister for External Affairs and the Canadian delegate at the nine-power conference, said tonight:

Mayor Wagner has proclaimed this week as Fire Prevention Week. When Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. took office as Fire Commissioner earlier in the year he hastened to say that henceforth fire prevention would be an all-year affair, not restricted to one week.
The merchandising support given by daily newspapers to their advertisers exceeds that possible for any other medium, the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association declares.
An ardent endorser of the feminine look and the natural figure is Sophie Gimbel, reigning spirit in the Salon Moderne of Saks Fifth Avenue, of which her husband, Adam Gimbel, is president.
HONOLULU, Oct. 31 -- Frank Francis Fasi, 34-year-old former Marine officer from Hartford, Conn., upset Mayor John Henry Wilson, 82, in Saturday's Democratic Mayoralty primary.

The present pattern of increasing state aid to local school districts may lead to complete state control over the schools, the Tax Foundation, a private nonprofit research organization, warned yesterday.
Senator Irving M. Ives, the Republican candidate for Governor, urged yesterday that problems concerning schools and state aid to localities for education be kept out of campaign discussions.

New York Harbor made a good showing last year in maintaining its position as the nation's leading port. The myriad craft populating the major roadsteads and byways of the harbor, ranging from squat freighters to lowly sand scows, carried 139,395,118 short tons of cargo.
NEWARK, Oct. 3 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican nominee for Senator, declared today that he was the candidate "because of my record for which I have been criticized."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A special Subcommittee on Indian Affairs of the House of Representatives has recommended that all major functions of the Bureau of Indian Affairs be discontinued or transferred to other agencies of the Federal Government or to the states.

A laboratory building for the research facilities of Jewish Memorial Hospital at Broadway and 196th Street was dedicated yesterday. The red brick structure and its equipment, which will be used in medical application of atomic knowledge, is said to have cost $650,000.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Bishop Bernard J. Sheil, an outspoken critic of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, launched his "personal fight" against communism today at a "Freedom Festival."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy declared tonight he would not provide any accounting of his use of funds given him to fight communism.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 3 -- Increasing pressure from West German labor for a bigger share in the national prosperity is expected to make itself felt this week when the national Trade Union Federation holds its biennial congress at Frankfurt.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- After reaching a new peak early last week and surmounting, with apparent ease, a formidable and in some respects difficult settlement, stock markets have in the last few days lost some of their speculative sparkle and become relatively quiet.

Distinguished readings of fine music, old and new, were offered by Fritz Rikko and the Collegium Musicum at Carl Fischer Hall yesterday afternoon. The concert, which opened the group's fourth season, was the first of four events they will present during 1954-55.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- With striking London dockworkers planning to extend their walkout tomorrow, Manchester longshoremen voted today for a one-day stoppage then.
Averell Harriman and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. toured some of the city's lower income districts yesterday in a bid for the workingman's vote.

In The Times of Sept. 27. I learned with great interest that only 25 million dollars was allotted to the United States Weather Bureau for this year. I read further and found that the number of weather stations has declined from 443 to 321 in the period of 1947 to 1954, and that, for lack of a sum as low as $10,000, the bureau could not put into use 100 secondhand radar sets.

"Die Fledermaus," an unpretentious but engaging work, can almost always be counted on to make an impression of sorts, and if given half a chance is a very pleasant evening in the theatre. Last night, as presented by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center, it had the benefit of a good cast, competent staging and the serviceable English translation of Ruth and Thomas P. Martin.

THREE weeks ago today one of the finest historical novels of modern times was published. "The Long Ships," by Franz Bengtsson, is a masterly tale of heroic adventure in the Viking Age. Now, by one of those coincidences so frequent in the book-publishing business, another superior historical novel about the same subject is on display in the bookshops.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A reliable baseball source today said the winning New York Giants would each receive the record sum of $10,810 on the basis of 34 1/2 shares in the world series players' pool, and each Cleveland Indian would get $6,457 on the basis of 38 1/2 shares.

An article in The Times of Sept. 28 reports a controversy among educators in New York State which has been going on for many years and which should be resolved once for all. This has to do with Regents examinations.
The Women's City Club of New York yesterday urged the establishment of a Youth Center to rehabilitate delinquents awaiting trial.

I wonder how many people noticed an almost parenthetical remark by General de Castries, defender of Dienbienphu, in an interview published in The New York Times a few days ago. General de Castries said that in the final decisive phase of the siege of Dienbienphu four Vietminh divisions attacked, equipped with United States 105 mm. guns given them by the Chinese Communists after they were taken from the Chinese Nationalists.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 -- Steel activity last week ran ahead of forecasts, as a result of a steady increase in the volume of new business. The faster tempo of orders was attributed in turn to low inventories.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Exports of American farm crops fell 20 per cent from June to July but overseas shipments in July were still 8 per cent above those of a year earlier, it was reported today.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 3 -- The Netherlands Bank announced last week that residents would be allowed to buy and sell locally held American securities on the exchange here for guilders. Until now dollar securities owned by Dutch residents could be sold only if the buyer had an arbitrage license allowing him to buy these securities for guilders and sell them for dollars.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, today renewed his attack on this country's military purchasing policies.

Sudden rain at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon failed to quench the enthusiasm of 135,000 marchers who turned out to set a record for the annual Pulaski Day parade on Fifth Avenue. The marchers exceeded by 10,000 the number who took part last year.
TELEVISION'S week-end was rather unusual: There were more premieres than crises.
Manhattan's poorest and most miserable dwelling block, 101st Street between First and Second Avenues, may eventually be torn down for new housing as a result of studies now quietly under way.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- The wheat market lagged in volume last week. But late week price changes indicated that recent overbuying has been corrected to a great extent. There was accumulation on the setbacks and fair recoveries from the low spots.

The Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor paid tribute last night to the International Peasant Union for its struggle to free 100,000,000 Eastern and Central Europeans from Communist tyranny.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Swedish trotters won three of the five races in competition with thirteen standard-bred horses from Russia before 30,000 spectators, at the Solvalla trotting park today.

AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 2 -- Indian pudding, boiled lobster and steamed clams were some of the fine regional specialties that thirty-eight food editors from the East and Midwest savored during the last three days as they toured the State of Maine.

The American Academy in Rome is offering fellowships for mature students and artists capable of doing independent work in architecture, landscape architecture; musical composition, painting, sculpture, history of art and classical studies.
The agreement signed in London yesterday promised the end of military occupation of Germany by the Western Allies, which has lasted more than nine years.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Nine powers signed an agreement today to integrate West Germany politically and militarily in Western Europe.

"NOW I know what's holding back my ball club," said Fred Haney mischievously. "It's a matter of geography. We're in the wrong league. Except for the fact that we occasionally have some real lousy days, I'd almost believe that we could beat the Indians, too." Mr. Haney is the manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, the last-place team in the National League.

Negotiations to merge the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., and the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute into a national textile trade group have failed to produce an agreement, it was made known over the week-end.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Chancellor of the Exechequer R.A. Butler said today on his return from the United States that he could not make any promises at this time about lifting financial restrictions in Britain. But he added that the outlook was hopeful because the British economy was buoyant and sterling was strong.

Traffic on Canal Street between Broadway and Lafayette Street was detoured last night when 3,000 members of Local 831, Uniformed Sanitation Association, of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., assembled at 277 Canal Street to hear a report by John J De Lury, local president.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The 164th term of the Supreme Court began today with brief opening ceremonies.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- Nevada Republicans, who are trying to avert a November election contest for the unexpired term of the late Senator Pat McCarran, are confronted by a formidable body of contrary precedent.
The first contingent of the 523 Maasdam passengers who returned here Sunday afternoon after a collision at sea will leave for Europe by air today, the Holland-America Line announced yesterday.

Averell Harriman last night accused his Republican adversary for Governor, Senator Irving M. Ives, of being the champion of private power interests. He also charged Governor Dewey with attempting to rig the election.

The historic Act of London, which blueprints the foundations of a new Europe, is rightly being hailed as a triumph of Western diplomacy. To a large extent this act wipes out the debacle of the European Defense Community and gives new strength and vitality to the whole Atlantic community.

The city's 400 commercial binderies were shut last night by a combination strike and lockout of their 3,000 unionized employes. It was the first time in forty-two years that a labor dispute had halted the industry.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Parents who feel personal "guilt" because a child has long-lasting illness should be reassured that their feelings are groundless, a Syracuse pediatrician said today.

Mrs. Henry Ittleson gave a cocktail party yesterday afternoon in her home at the Hampshire House for a group of women serving with her in furthering arrangements for the dinner to be given on Nov. 8 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The strike of London dock workers, which has tied up more than half of the ships in port, spread today as 3,000 members of the Transport and General Workers Union defied their leaders and voted to join the walkout.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Francis P. Carr resigned today as executive staff director of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee, effective Oct. 31. On Nov. 1 he will take a position with Associated Transport, Inc., a trucking concern in New York City.

Johnny Saxton, now in training for a title match with Kid Gavilan, welterweight champion, has something more on his mind than the fight. It is a fifteen-day workhouse term he received, yesterday as a traffic scofflaw.

David J. Wilson, a Utah attorney with more than thirty years of trial experience, was inducted yesterday as a Judge of the United States Customs Court in a ceremony in the courtroom at 201 Varick Street. Judge Wilson, who was appointed to his $15,000-a-year lifetime post by President Eisenhower, succeeded Judge William P. Cole Jr., who was appointed to the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals in Washington.

Howell E. Jackson's Ballerina took the first running of the Maskette Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. With Stanley Small guiding her in the $26,200 mile race, the 4-year-old daughter of Rosemont scored by three-quarters of a length.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Officials of the Wilkes-Barre Publishing Company and the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., announced today that a tentative agreement ending a six-month strike of 119 union employes of this city's two daily newspapers had been reached.

Young women, including Miss Catherine M. Hannon and Miss Denise Lawson-Johnston, are aiding Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark in the plans for the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the New York Chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- When the Army needs some information, or runs out of something to do, it makes a staff study.
The police shut down a bingo game at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Jackson Heights, Queens, at 10:30 last night, sending 300 disappointed housewives home at an unusually early hour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- George C. McConnaughey was sworn in as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission today and he said he was "pretty much on record as believing in as few controls of business as possible."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- A total of 23,857 prisoners of World War II are known to be still held in Communist areas, according to data filed with the United Nations by West Germany, Italy and Japan and released today.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Armament contracts totaling $612,050,000 were awarded in Europe by the United States in the fiscal year ended June 30. The United States European Command announced the total today.

Months ago there appeared in the pages of The Times a heart-warming article about a successful physician who had gotten his start from a scholarship and was now himself creating a scholarship fund. Since then I have felt impelled to write about the need for scholarships to be awarded to a much-neglected group of students, those in evening schools.
An extremely gifted Italian violinist named Renato Bonacini made his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening.

A four-month campaign of winter baseball awaits Willie Mays, the center-field sensation of the world champion Giants. Willie, it was learned yesterday, has received permission from the Giants to play with the Santurce club in the Puerto Rican League, which swings into action next month.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- For nearly a year United States, British, French, Italian and Yugoslav diplomats have been negotiating a Trieste agreement, which will take the form of an international understanding rather than a treaty.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Oct. 3 -- Leaders of both major political parties Were marshaling their strength in Missouri this week in an effort to change the line-up in the House of Representatives. It now stands at seven Democrats and four Republicans.

The frontiers have been vanishing rapidly in recent years. Men have now climbed the highest mountain on earth and descended for miles into the sea. The North Pole, the goal for which brave men toiled long and sometimes died, is now little more than a geographic marker for the innumerable military, and even commercial, planes which today fly the Arctic regions.

Total resources of The National City Bank of New York on Sept. 30 amounted to $6,016,340,492, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition, issued for publication today. The total compares with $5,966,644,957 at the end of the previous quarter, and $5,897,819,619 a year ago.

WESTVILLE, N. J., Oct. 4 -The mother of two brothers who have renounced the United States to seek asylum with the Reds in East Berlin today said she and her family were "terribly shocked" at the news.
IT was unreliably reported that a number of week-end anglers were able to forego boats for the fog was said to be so heavy at some resort fishing spots that it was merely necessary to walk out on it.
ROME, Oct. 4 -- The Trieste question, which for the last nine years has embittered relations between Italy and Yugoslavia, will be settled tomorrow by an agreement to be signed in London.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 4 -- A slight trend toward the left was indicated today as the first fragmentary returns began coming in from yesterday's Congressional and gubernatorial elections in Brazil.
Organized stock exchanges are becoming increasingly concerned over the fever of speculation in worthless stocks and the toad- stool growth of the fly-by-night "investment" houses that sell them.

When the indices of economic activity in the United States turned downward it was the signal for demands in certain quarters that the Government step into the breach with a vast program of deficiteering, tax reduction and public works expenditures.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra has canceled all rehearsals as a result of failure to negotiate a new labor contract with Local 77, American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L.
The first patient was admitted yesterday to the new $26,500,000 Veterans Administration Hospital at First Avenue and Twenty-third Street as it began a partial operation of its facilities.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 3 -- The award of a Roman Catholic Church decoration to a Mexican woman has touched off the frankest public debate over church-and-state relations since Mexico's bitterly anti-clerical period immediately after the 1917 revolution.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Dr. Goodwin Watson, Professor of Education at Columbia University and a part-time research consultant for the Guidance Center of New Rochelle, was "acquitted" today by the Larchmont Community Chest of charges of pro-Communist affiliations.
A new cellulose yarn with unusual wearing and washing qualities has been placed in commercial production by the Celanese Corporation of America.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Herbert Hoover Jr. took the oath of office today as Under Secretary of State.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 4 -- The Government issued today a White Paper on the dispute with India over ownership of the state of Jammu and Kashmir. It declared that direct negotiations with India for settlement of the issue "have been tried and failed."

TRENTON, Oct. 4 -- The state of New Jersey is withdrawing $23,000,000 of the $26,000,000 it has on deposit in time accounts with 200 financial institutions. The money will be reinvested in Government securities.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., was accused yesterday by two Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions of engaging in contract bargaining practices "apt to tear apart the entire structure of wages and welfare benefits of all American maritime workers."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Atomic science may have proved what little Johnny has suspected all along -- spinach is questionable stuff at best.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Trustees of Williams College have agreed to permit the use of the Adams Memorial Theatre on the campus for a summer playhouse if the Williamstown Theatre Committee, appointed by the Board of Trade, meets certain stipulations.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York held deposits of $2,613,811,701 on Sept. 30, the bank's quarterly condition statement shows. Issued for publication today, the statement listed total resources at $3,071,966,441.

A slate of 146 candidates has been nominated for election to seventy-three offices in the newly formed Writers Guild of America, embracing the Screen Writers Guild, Radio Writers Guild and the Television Writers Group. The first general election among West Coast writers will be held Nov. 17.
Events today: Herbert Burtis, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, noon; William Doppmann, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; David Abel, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 36 points down yesterday. The near months showed the most weakness.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 4 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, predicted victory here today for himself and the entire Democratic ticket in Union County.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of the statement by Mr. Dulles today:
Projected into the center of the football stage with its defeat of Notre Dame, Purdue finds itself matched with Duke Saturday in one of the spotlight games of the week.

Ten thousand students and faculty members from eleven Roman Catholic colleges in the metropolitan area attended a special Marian Year mass yesterday on the Bronx campus of Fordham University. Cardinal Spellman presided at the solemn high mass, which was held on the terrace of Keating Hall.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (UP) -- General Manager Hank Greenberg and Manager Al Lopez held a world series post mortem today and although details were not forthcoming they agreed on one thing about the 1955 Cleveland Indians: There'll be some changes made.
James L. Dixon, a 53-year-old educator, took over the leadership of the Queens County Democratic Committee last night from James A. Roe.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Israel asked today that the United Nations Security Council take up her complaint charging Egyptian interference with Israel-bound ships in the Suez Canal.
A reversal in the downtrend of prices of black-and-white TV sets is under way.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The satisfactory conclusion of the nine-power conference here encouraged a slightly better tone on the stock market today, but price movements remained irregular.

YONKERS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Titanic, a 6-year-old son of Titan Hanover owned by Mr. slid Mrs. Stanley Dancer and driven by William Myer, won the $4,000 Bedford Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight in 2:03. He beat the Harris Stable's David Candle by a length and returned $6.80 for $2.00.

Governor Dewey took part yesterday in ceremonies dedicating the new $4,000,000 building of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. He said the federation's work was the "finest example of human sympathy and care by neighbor to neighbor."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A national farm leader declared tonight that Americans do their nation and the world a "grave disservice" when they claim that United States tariffs are a major barrier to expansion of world trade.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Four of the seventy-four competing teams tied for best-bali honors with 5-under-par 66's in today's Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament at Woodway.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, still not in top form, scrambled to a four-set victory over Mario Llamas of Mexico today and clinched the American zone Davis Cup tennis title for the United States.

The Navy confirmed in Washington yesterday that the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N. J., had voluntarily ended negotiations on a contract for the construction of four destroyer-escorts at a cost of about $28,000,000.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 (UP) -- Marilyn Monroe said today she would sue Joe DiMaggio for divorce tomorrow.

Cases involving mail fraud and armed robbery of the United States mails will be depicted in a new television series, "The Mail Story," which makes its debut over the A. B. C. Network on Thursday from 8 to 8:30 P. M.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 5 -- Tass, official Soviet news agency, declared early today that the London agreement on West German armament constituted "the strongest threat to the security and independence of the European countries."

No previous period in history has had the opportunities and facilities for communication which are available today. One secondary effect of this wealth of machinery for the exchange of news, information and general intelligence is a growing tendency to give public recognition on specially designated days or weeks to all sorts of causes, occasions and purposes -historical, patriotic, charitable, commercial, educational, conservative, progressive, or merely antiquarian.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 -- Jose Ferrer is being sought to star in "The Cockleshell Heroes," a story about the exploits of the Royal Marines in World War II.

Ed Danowski, Fordham football coach, took the opportunity yesterday to halt "two rumors." First, he explained at the weekly Football Writers luncheon at Toots Shor's restaurant, that the Rams had emerged in good physical shape from their victory over Rutgers on Saturday.

Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, chairman of volunteers of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, appealed yesterday for hundreds of daytime volunteers needed to carry on the winter work of the chapter. She asked that women living in Manhattan and the Bronx enroll in the humanitarian services of the organization and directed a plea especially to former volunteers to resume their services.

The twelve-story commercial building at 104-110 Greene Street and 123-127 Mercer Street has been purchased by Maurice L. Relkin, Alexander Rapaport Associates from Boris Feinberg and others. Robert Joseph Co. were the brokers and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
The July-in-October weather that has plagued the New York area should take its unlamented departure today, the Weather Bureau said yesterday.

OGDEN, Utah, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, today indicated he did not think the new farm law would cost the Republicans votes because, he said, "I don't believe that the farm vote * * * is for sale to the highest bidder."

Dentists and other medical men do not have the right to decline Federal support of medical services, either direct or indirect, as long as untreated disease victims are suffering, it was suggested here last night.

The New York Couture Designers fashion show presented yesterday by Bonwit Teller provided a comprehensive collection of fall fashions that were received enthusiastically because they were not only fashionable but pretty and feminine.

IN recognition of the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in America, the American Jewish Tercentenary organization will open a contemporary art exhibition, with a preview for tercentenary leaders this evening at the Riverside Museum.'
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 4 -- The long-standing friction between the Malan Government and Johannesburg, biggest city in Africa south of the Sahara, was brought to an issue today. The Government announced the formation of a rival local authority to shift 58,000 Negroes from western Johannesburg to a location farther out of the city.

Sickness took a happy, short recess yesterday in the courtyard of Bellevue Hospital, where galloping horses, snaking lariats and cowboy jinks of the Twenty-ninth Annual World's Championship Rodeo brought flushed cheeks back to bedroom captives.

One custom smelter increased the price of lead by one-quarter cent a pound yesterday to 15 cents -- the highest quotation in almost two years. At least one major domestic producer of lead failed to match the new price immediately, but trade authorities predicted that 15 cents would be quoted generally by late today.
For the woman who wants a new look plus elegance in her furs, Gunther Jaeckel's has the answer.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Two United States soldiers held by Czechoslovakia for sixteen days said today they had been subjected to heavy psychological pressure by Red guards seeking atomic weapons secrets.
The little Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie Railroad, better known as the "Soo Line," has done better earningswise in the first eight months this year than in all of 1953.
YONKERS, Oct. 4. (AP) -- A 49-year-old silver cup won by the great pacer Dan Patch will be put back into circulation, Yonkers Raceway announced today.
European imports ranging from delicately embroidered christening dresses to sturdy leather trousers were presented yesterday at Gimbels showing of boutique items for children.
The text of the television address by Averell Harriman last night follows:

Good news keeps coming out of London. Today, at long last, an agreement is being signed in London between Italy and Yugoslavia, settling the Trieste dispute. This has been one of the most vexing and dangerous conflicts in Europe, and now we can say good-by to it for a long time to come.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Secretary of State Dulles returned from London in a jovial mood this morning. He said that the nine-power agreement on a substitute for the European Defense Community "will be very much in our national interests."

Fifteen thousand persons came to gawk yesterday at Fifth Avenue's shiniest new adornment -- the glass-walled branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company. Some veteran bankers snorted at the "newfangled architecture" and appointments, but visitors were almost unanimous in admiration.

Hydrogen particles have been fired from the massive cyclotron of the University of California deep into the brain of a patient with advanced cancer in a last desperate effort to preserve life. This was disclosed here last night by Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Like his father, Herbert Clark Hoover Jr. has been around the world quite a lot. Like his father, he studied mining engineering at Stanford University. Like his father, he gave up a successful private career to work for the United States Government. A year ago he became a special adviser to Secretary of State Dulles on international petroleum problems.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 4 -- French-German negotiations on the Saar territory are to be reopened shortly.
PORT ARTHUR Ont., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Lorne (Gump) Worsley has beaten Johnny Bower for the goaltender's job on the New York Rangers, reversing their positions of a year ago.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 4 -- The Committee for a Stronger New Jersey Republican Party announced today that it had appealed to the Republican high command to throw "its weight and approval" behind the write-in Senatorial candidacy of former Representative Fred A. Hartley.
Oklahoma took over the No, 1 place in the United Press college football rating yesterday by a narrow margin over U. C. L. A.
ROME, Oct. 4 -- Cardinal Borgongini Duca was made a Prince of the Church in 1953 by Pope Pius XII.

OTTAWA, Oct. 4 -- Canadian authorities were told today of the recommendation by United States Great Lakes shipping interests for a change in the dimensions of the St. Lawrence Seaway locks. But there the matter rested.
Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, spelled out in a television address here last night a personal declaration of independence from pressure groups.

Coffee prices jumped the 2-cent-a-pound limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was influenced by reports that Brazil would maintain its minimum price and might support the market.
DENVER, Oct. 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today limited imports of oats to 40,000,000 bushels during the period Oct. 1, 1954, to Sept. 30, 1955.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Grain and soybean futures showed a strong undertone today, with an initial upturn of as much as 5 cents in soybeans stimulating purchases of grain futures. Wheat prices were not much changed at the opening, but commission absorption dried up offerings in the pit and later short covering was instrumental in advancing prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department today alloted $49,500,000 to the forty-eight states and the District of Columbia to help increase the consumption of milk under the Government - sponsored school lunch program
Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, gave an offhand remark about baseball an edge of international sarcasm as he was officially welcomed to New York yesterday.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 4 -- William Crowley and Walter Scheiber, Great River, shot 32, 29 -- 61, nine strokes under par, to take the first prize in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association amateur-pro tournament at the Huntington Crescent Club today.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 416 pints of blood on Friday. Included were 106 pints given at the United Whelan Drug Company, Thirty-ninth Street and First Avenue, Brooklyn.
In an appeal last night to independent voters, Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for Governor, taxed his Democratic opponents with "double-talk" and "pompous nonsense."

KIEV, U. S. S. R., Oct. 1 -- Private trading in agricultural products is being strongly encouraged by the Soviet Government in the interest of raising the cash income of farmers and increasing the food supply of the urban population.
With sales up 13 per cent, the Shamrock Oil and Gas Corporation realized an increased net profit of $5,473,219 in the nine months ended Aug. 31, the company reported yesterday.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared yesterday that since his term of office began "politics have been kept out of the department."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The London Agreement was primarily a Western European defense compact attained by Western Europeans. But, according to persons closely involved in the proceedings, and reports from foreign offices to their embassies in Washington, two indispensable parts were played most skillfully by Secretary of State Dulles.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Ed Furgol, Marty Furgol, Dutch Harrison and Tommy Bolt were named today as United States team members for a month long series of golf matches in Australia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it would support grower prices of 1954-crop burley tobacco at an average of 46.4 cents a pound, compared with last year's 46.6 cents.

Decorative fashions continue to enhance the bed and bath, judging from the ten new room settings that opened on McCutcheon's fifth floor yesterday. Arranged by Mary L. Brandt, the vignettes show bedroom accessories coordinated with those for the bathroom.

Directors of the new Studebaker-Packered Corporation at their organizational meeting yesterday formally elected James J. Nance president and Paul G. Hoffman chairman of that $250,000,000 concern. Harold S. Vance was elected chairman of the executive committee of the board.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Two brothers from Westville, N. J., who had dropped out of sight mysteriously, turned up at a Communist news conference today and announced they had asked for political asylum in the Soviet zone.
The Turkish Ministry of Education, the University of Ankara, and New York University have established a $1,500,000 cooperative program designed to extend higher education facilities in Turkey.

Lulu Perez, fifth-ranking featherweight contender from Brooklyn, gained the unanimous decision over Bobby Woods of Spokane, Wash., in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway arena, Brooklyn, last night.
The Curtis Publishing Company is fashioning a giant magazine-selling organization.

The imaginative flights of which Italian designers are capable are vividly demonstrated in a new collection of furniture imported from Italy and available through decorators from Altamira, a new showroom at 18 East Fiftieth Street.

The fabulous "Abie's Irish Rose" is returning to Broadway for the third time. Originally produced in 1922, Anne Nichols' comedy became one of the world's wonders by achieving a New York run of 2,327 performances, in spite of critical brickbats.

Dr. Norman Salit, president of the Synagogue Council of America, proposed yesterday that "free peoples" everywhere join the Jews of the world in fasting on Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement. The holy day of prayer and fast begins at sundown tomorrow.
Investment banking syndicates are planning to place on the market today new issues of public utility and industrial securities valued at more than $3,000,000. The offerings are as follows:

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Senator Irving M. Ives charged tonight that the Democratic party lacked the "know-how" to continue the "unprecedented prosperity" that he said had been brought about under twelve years of Republican rule at Albany.
A record program of construction of public improvements for 1955 calling for a capital outlay of $814,587,730 was recommended yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

Business and agriculture should be left "free and untrammeled" to achieve their highest potential, Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for Governor, told the National Association of Mutual Insurance Companies yesterday.

Six days were set aside by law to register for the Nov. 2 election, and half of that period has now been used up. Early registration was disappointingly small, especially in New York City, accounted for in part at least by preoccupation with the world series and the hot, muggy weather.
BUFFALO, Oct. 4 -- Erie County Democrats tonight elected Peter J. Crotty chairman of the county committee to succeed William B. Mahoney.
Superscope, the wide-screen projection process developed by Joseph and Irving Tushinsky, has been made compatible with CinemaScope projection equipment, it was announced yesterday by R. K. O.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The long-established White House reception for the armed services has been merged with the reception for other Federal departments in the official social program for the coming season, the White House announced today. It will be held Dec. 2.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 4 -- About 2,000 white students took part in running demonstrations here today against desegregation of the public schools.

Now that a more cheerful atmosphere prevails in the councils of Europe and that the problem of German sovereignty and of Germany's rearmament seems near a solution, one may be permitted to express some regret at the harsh and often peevish tone assumed by several American newspapers in their recent comments on France.

OTTAWA, Oct. 4 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent warned today that unless Asia, with the help of the West, could win its struggle against crippling materialistic handicaps the world might be faced with a hydrogen bomb war.

The officers of the Parents'-Teachers' Association of Public School 49, Middle Village, Queens, resigned last night at a meeting at the school auditorium, 79-15 Penelope Avenue, Middle Village, in a surprise move, following ratification by ballot of their election last May.

The offer of Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation to stockholders of the Marion Power Shovel Company will be effective for twenty days, beginning tomorrow and ending Oct. 26, Louis E. Wolfson, president and chairman of Merritt-Chapman Scott, announced yesterday.

Stable retail food prices for the coming year were predicted yesterday by Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc. He spoke at the opening of the eleventh annual Newspaper Food Editors Conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

DENVER, Oct. 4 -- President Eisenhower hailed today the nine-power accord signed yesterday in London as possibly "one of the greatest diplomatic achievements of our time." The conference decided to arm West Germany and give it sovereignty.

The American Safety Razor Corporation obtained a court order yesterday in an attempt to evict eighty sit-down strikers from its plant at 315 Jay Street, Brooklyn. The strikers are protesting a company plan to move its operations to Staunton, Va., next May 27.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Following are excerpts from a statement by Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State, and from the translation of a statement by Guerin de Beaumont, French Minister of Justice, made today before the United Nations General Assembly:
VIENNA, Oct. 4 -- Though fundamentals must not be changed, the Roman Catholic Church will welcome the incorporation of modern musical tendencies and techniques in church music.
A crippling new pier strike hit the Port of New York at midnight last night.

For sixty-one years the Visiting Nursing Service of New York, founded by the late Lillian D. Wald, has been looking after an increasing number of sick persons in their homes in this city. It now operates in Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx. Last year it made 330,647 nursing visits to 40,663 people.

At a special meeting of Thompson Products, Inc. in Cleveland yesterday, stockholders approved an increase in the authorized common stock to 5,000,000 from the present 2,500,000 shares, paving the way for a two-for-one stock split.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- The United States Government announced today that it would ask Congress to contribute to a proposed $12,000,000 fund to seek to solve the problem of 350,000 European refugees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Louis F. Budenz, former Communist editor, today identified a March 8, 1936, issue of The Sunday Worker, a Communist newspaper, as containing an article by the publisher - broadcaster, Edward Lamb.

After fighting the two most terrible wars in history in order to disarm Germany is it anything else but absurd to move heaven and earth to re-arm her, while the same men are high in her councils who brought these disasters upon us? The same plan would also be logical for Japan, the ex-enemy whom we actually did help to a non-military status with the approval of the Japanese themselves.

Japan must be given greater opportunity to expand her trade with the rest of the world through removal of restrictions now seriously hampering her exports, Japanese Finance Minister Sankuro Ogasawara declared yesterday.

The police sought Navy help yesterday in confirming their tentative identification of a woman, who plunged to her death from a seventh floor ledge of the Hotel Taft, as the widow of Comdr. Eugene Frieh, a Navy hero.

It figured; a look at the program in advance told you so. Istvan Nadas had to be either an exceptional pianist or a man suffering from delusions of grandeur. No one else would take on so formidable program at a New York debut.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 4 -- Delaware will file a complaint tomorrow to "revoke and forfeit" the charter of the National Association for the Advancement of White People, the state's Attorney General, H. Albert Young, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Government spending for scientific research and development reached a peak after the Korean fighting, but has leveled off now at about $2,000,000,000 a year. This is twenty times the rate of such spending before the war.
In the Sept. 27 issue of your paper I. Q. Miller suggests that the retirement age and Social Security pension should be lowered to 60 years. He also states that most oldsters die before 65.
Ever since the announcement of Dior's flat-bosomed H-line collection persons in all stations of life have been perturbed by it.

NEW DELHI, India, Tuesday, Oct. 5 (UP) -- United States military aid to Pakistan increases the necessity for "sufficient" Indian forces to protect Kashmir against possible invasion, the Government said today.
PINEVILLE, Ky., Oct. 4 -- Having a strongly Republican district in Kentucky can be -- and is -- a problem for the Republicans.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 4 -- First stringers on The Hill School's football squad enjoyed a day of camparative rest this afternoon. Coach Frank Bissell spoke to them briefly, sent them through a short signal drill and then ordered them to the showers.

Although it lost a bit of its drive in the afternoon, the stock market made a strong advance yesterday on an expanding volume of dealings. Most industrial groups rose, and du Pont, Goodyear and Northern Pacific registered notable gains.

A G.I. party with a different twist was held last night at the Cathedral Canteen conducted by the National Catholic Community Service at 641 Lexington Avenue. There were juke-box music, hot-dogs, sandwiches, soft drinks and also plenty of hard work for the 200 service men and hostesses.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The mountainous Palmer Peninsula of Antarctica is to be mapped and investigated by eight scientists and surveyors who left Southampton today aboard the royal research ship John Biscoe. The expedition will last two years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The smooth course of this city's integration of whites and Negroes in the public schools was broken today by demonstrations of white students at two high schools.
Registration spurted slightly yesterday, the third day of enrollment, but the pace still was 20 per cent below 1950, the last comparable year, when a state election took place.

Lorenz Haderspeck, 52-year-old Yugoslav immigrant, remained aboard the North German Lloyd liner Gripsholm yesterday after his third Atlantic crossing. He was refused permission to land here, and it appears he may become a man without a country unless he is permitted to debark when the vessel reaches Germany on Oct. 16.
