WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class I railroads during August at $64,000,000, compared with a net of $81,000,000 in the same month last year.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 4 -- The Israeli Government indicated tonight it had tried a policy of non-retaliation for Arab attacks for a month and found it did not work.
Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday that a working agreement had been signed by the New York and Maryland state commissions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the net working capital of corporations in the United States was at a record high at the end of last June.

An account of the 1952 Italian National Underwater Expedition to the Red Sea will be published by Rinehart on Oct. 25 Under the title "The Blue Continent." The author is Folco Quilici, who headed the photographic unit of the group.

THERE were any number of Giant heroes in the world series but the fellow whose name was on everyone's lips was Willie Mays. He's an exciting ballplayer even when he does nothing -- which is rare. But when he makes a catch such as he did on Vic Wertz in the opening game, he also sold a bill of goods to millions of television viewers.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The police raided the offices of the unofficial Communist newspaper Liberation today in a search for evidence that the French Communist party had received secret information on the nation's defenses.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State, gave a cautious welcome today to the Soviet Union's new proposals on atomic control and disarmament.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4 -- Maj. Jaime Rosenberg, former chief of the Guatemalan secret police, has been arrested here. He is charged by the Guatemalan Government with the murder of hundreds of anti-Communists.
Chicago announced plans yesterday for the sale of $12,500,000 of school bonds on Oct. 27. The city obligations are to be dated Nov. 1, 1954, and will come due annually on Nov. 1 from 1957 to 1974.

Monetary policy appears slated for even larger roles as an instrument to foster balanced economic expansion, according to the latest monthly Review of Credit and Business Conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

SIXTEEN years having gone into the trashbasket, Libby Holman is appearing on Broadway again. Not amid the rough-and-tumble of a Broadway show, however. "Blues, Ballads and Sin-Songs," which opened for one week at the Bijou last evening, is more concert than theatre, and she is the sole performer.
Mrs. Jacqueline Taranger, 51 years old, was found dead about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the bathroom of her penthouse apartment at 81 Irving Place, the police reported.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Mrs. E. Brewster Prindle of Wee Burn today captured the Harriet Bassler Memorial Trophy by posting low net of 86 -- 17 -- 69 in the final one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association season.
Oklahoma, idle over the weekend, recaptured first place yesterday in the Associated Press college football poll. Beaten Notre Dame tumbled from first to eighth.
TOKYO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The United States Army added today the names of twenty more American military personnel to the list of known dead in the capsizing of the ferry Toya Maru at Hakodate Sept. 26.

A drive to support free nursing service in 1955 was opened yesterday by the Visiting Nurse Service of New York with a reception at its headquarters, 107 East Seventieth Street. The first campaign gift, $35,000, was presented by Thomas P. Jerman, general chairman, to Miss Marian G. Randall, executive director.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had dropped slightly.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The most important development of the nine-power conference that ended yesterday may be that it was dominated by an Englishman and a Frenchman.

The money market turned easier yesterday while banks made payments on the new Treasury issues. The payments will raise the banks' reserve requirements some $500,000,000 to $600,000,000 today, but indications are that the banks can meet the situation satisfactorily.

DETROIT, Oct. 4 -- A week ago today the Lutz Bakery Company of 201 Sylvania Avenue, Toledo, Ohio, a 33-year-old family enterprise employing about fifty persons, announced that it was ceasing operations at the end of the week.
DENVER, Oct. 4 -- "Considering the magnitude of the Defense Department, the number of security risks already removed or on the docket is happily quite small," Secretary Charles E. Wilson said today.
The Department of Health assured the City Council yesterday that a city's right to fluoridate its water supply had been upheld in every court test, right up to the United States Supreme Court.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati led a procession of United States players through the first round of the Pan-American tennis tournament today.
A group headed by Elmer L. Ward, former president of the Goodall-Sanford Company, will acquire the Palm Beach Company from the Burlington Mills Corporation, it was announced yesterday.
I wish to express my profound dismay at the news that our Department of State will discontinue publication of its German-language daily newspaper in Vienna, the Wiener Kurier.

Intelligence agents in Malaya report the capture of fresh instructions to the Communist terrorists there that may indicate a significant change in tactics. As these documents are interpreted they would call for a halt to violent means and a substitution of subversion and infiltration.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 5 (UP) -- District Judge A.J. Maestretti issued a temporary restraining order today preventing the names candidates seeking the late Senator Pat McCarran's Senate seat from being listed on Nevada's Nov. 2 election ballot.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Scott Frost today became the first 2-year-old of either harness-racing gait to race a mile in 2 minutes when he trotted the second heat of the $9,605 Cimarron Ranch Trot in 2 minutes flat on the Grand Circuit card.
Two recent Soviet moves to demonstrate friendship for Finland have aroused wide discussion in diplomatic circles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Americans for Democratic Action joined Mr. Mitchell in criticizing Mr. Nixon's campaign tactics. It said he was conducting a "campaign of vilification and misrepresentation" against the organization.
Price cuts of $37 to $287 on most cars in the 1955 Studebaker line were announced yesterday by the Studebaker-Packard Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Construction trouble in the atomic submarine Nautilus, which came to light when a steam pipe burst Sept. 18, will delay trials of the submersible at least three months, the Navy said today.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein obtained an injunction yesterday permanently putting out of business a dealer in municipal, state and Federal bonds whom he charged with swindling customers of nearly $250,000.
The luxury liners Independence and Queen Mary discharged 1,790 passengers and 8,000 pieces of luggage yesterday despite the longshoremen's strike.

MASON CITY, Iowa, Oct. 5 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that the Eisenhower Administration "in the very near future" would announce new figures on security risk dismissals from Federal employment.
Following is the text of a telegram sent yesterday to Mr. Mitchell by Whitelaw Reid, editor of The Herald Tribune:

Two ways to use color in the home were presented here yesterday. One set of schemes, relying on a subtle, dull palette, is demonstrated in seven model rooms at Bloomingdale's. A second and different set of schemes could be derived from the brilliant collection of fabrics designed by Alexander Girard and introduced by Herman Miller, 1 Park Avenue, where they are available through decorators.

David Abel, 18-year-old violinist from San Francisco, made his debut in recital at Town Hall last evening. A native of the state of Washington, Mr. Abel for the last seven years has lived in the California city. His teacher is Naoum Blinder, concertmaster of the San Francisco Symphony.

MASON CITY, Iowa, Oct. 5 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today told Iowa voters that since they had voted overwhelmingly for President Eisenhower two years ago, they were entitled to two Senators who would uphold the President's program.

The resignation of Eldon Claggett Upton Jr. as a member of the Federal Maritime Board, effective Oct. 29, was accepted yesterday by President Eisenhower. Mr. Upton, a New Orleans insurance man, has served on the board for the last fifteen months.

"The Literary Situation," a study by Malcolm Cowley, is scheduled for Oct. 25 publication by Viking Press. It is a book of literary observation and deals with the practical, "factual aspects" of writing and winters in America today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A Washington architect testified today that Clyde L. Powell had demanded and was paid $10,000 in cash to approve a $709,000 increase in a Federal loan commitment on an apartment project here.

OTTAWA, Oct. 5 -- Japan and Thailand were admitted to membership in the Colombo plan today. The action was taken by unanimous decision of the fourteen other member nations attending the annual meeting of the plan's consultative committee here.

THE Bronx has had its own Johnny Appleseed for fifty-four years. He has planted fig trees, peach trees, finochio, hot peppers, sweet peppers, miniature tomatoes, eggplant, beets, corn, lettuce, long squash, round squash, garlic (much garlic), onions, string beans, carrots, basil, Swiss chard.
Carmine G. DeSapio essayed the role of political lecturer at New York University last night and accused Republicans of maligning Tammany to divert attention from their own shortcomings.

The Army announced yesterday it had awarded a $164,850,000 contract to the Western Electric Company for production of Nike. This new anti-aircraft weapon is the first guided missile system to defend American cities against atomic attack from the air.
The People's Chorus of New York will hold auditions on Monday and Friday evenings, beginning this week, in Studio 501, Steinway Hall, from 5:30 to 7 o'clock.

Neji, under the excellent pacing of Frank (Dooley) Adams, won the $17,700 Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Overtaking the heavily burdened King Commander just after the final jump, the 4-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. Ogden Phipps scored by more than a length in the test of about two and a half miles.

Great Hebrew literary treasures, some dating to the tenth century will be on display today at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The commemorate the American Jewish Tercentenary.
Aided by good weather, Second District department stores were able to make promotions pay off in August, sales figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 5 -- Proponents of segregation in the public schools were set back strongly on several fronts here today.
Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India, former president of the United Nations General Assembly, declared last night that Asians could not be frightened by American talk about the hydrogen bomb.

Kamal el-Malakh, the young Egyptian discoverer of the famed funerary solar ship of the Pharaoh Cheops at Giza, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Queen Mary. The 34-year-old savant, who, through a combination of good fortune and acumen, unlocked a secret that had remained buried and undisturbed through 4,700 years, shared honors on his arrival with another noted Egyptologist, Dr. Zakaria Ghoneim.
Averell Harriman accused the Republican party yesterday of trying to create "a spirit of hatred" between upstate and New York City voters.
Heavy gains dotted the New York Stock Exchange list yesterday but few of them were for the standard issues that are used in compiling market averages. The latter made only moderate advances.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Personal income in August, running at an annual rate of $285,500,000,000, was unchanged from July and about the same as in the first eight months of 1954 and 1953, the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce reported today.

ART exhibition openings are coming thick and fast this week, and today is marked by two openings of especial distinction. The Guggenheim Museum is presenting a group of modern European and American paintings and sculpture, entitled "Selection IV," from the museum's collections, and the Wildenstein Galleries are showing a collection of Dutch and Flemish water-colors, outstanding examples from the De Grez collection, now the property of the Royal Museum in Brussels.

The spot October cotton contract opened 26 points up yesterday, and other months 9 points higher to 1 point off. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange continued steady all day and prices at the finish were 8 to 25 points higher than on Monday.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The seventh annual conference of the Inter-American Commerce and Production Council opened today with representatives from the twenty-one American republics.
The fate of the 380,000 inhabitants of Trieste has been the subject of intensive diplomatic maneuvering ever since World War II, and is likely to become again a subject of United Nations debate.
VIENNA, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Austria reacted unfavorably today to the Trieste settlement and officially expressed, hope that Italy would not neglect Trieste's harbor.

May we bring to the attention of your readers the very unhappy plight of the more than 1,000 friendless patients at Rockland State Hospital. By friendless we mean just that -- they receive no visits, no letters, no packages.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Almost twenty-four hours of continuous negotiation ended today when the United Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union and the American Brass Company agreed to a contract ending a seven-week strike.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A minimum target of $1,000,000,000 a year for foreign investment in Latin America was recommended today in a report presented by the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A record output of 41,166,600,000 kilowatt-hours of electric energy was produced by the nation's electric utilities during August, a 2.7 per cent increase over the previous record of 40,077,004,000 k.w.h. in July.

A House merchant marine subcommittee, which has been inspecting New York shipbuilding and repair yards with a view to determining their war potential and present needs, toured ten facilities in Brooklyn yesterday.
A false statement that a man is the brother of a notorious Communist is not by itself grounds for damages for libel, and the victim must show special damages suffered, a court here ruled yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 5 -- The deadlock over the currency exchange rate seemed no closer to being broken here tonight as officials of both the United States Army and South Korea stood firm in their demands.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- It will be "homecoming" day tomorrow at the Commerce Department for Herbert Hoover, who gave up his job there in 1928 to become President of the United States.
BOONTON, N.J., Oct. 5 -- It will take a play-off among three teams on Oct. 30 to decide the New Jersey Golf Association's amateur best-ball championship.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 5 -- A Marine combat veteran is challenging a retired stockbroker for the House seat in the sprawling Third District this year. The campaign is being watched with special interest by leaders of both major parties.
The pier strike was settled last night with the same dramatic suddenness as it began.

The election of Percy J. Ebbott, president of the Chase National Bank, as chairman of the clearing house committee of the New York Clearing House Association took place yesterday at the 101st annual meeting of the association. Mr. Ebbott succeeds J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Chanel remains true to herself in a small autumn collection that she preferred to present now when her Parisian clientele is back in town rather than during the summer couturier showings.

The startlingly large capital budget for calendar year 1955 proposed by the City Planning Commission should set at rest any complaints that the city lacks borrowing power. Total allocations of $814,587,730 make this a record budget; they compare with $531,209,579 at a similar stage of the budget-making process last year.

Public utility and railroad enterprises raised $36,520,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of bonds, preferred stock and equipment trust certificates at competitive bidding. The new issues of securities have been priced for reoffering by banking syndicates as follows:
DETROIT, Oct. 5 -- There was a comedy skit on the vaudeville circuit several years ago by a team called "The Two Black Crows."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- James N. Juliana is reported to be Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's choice to succeed Francis P. Carr as staff director for the Senate Investigations subcommittee.
Governor Dewey yesterday denounced as a "dirty fraud" the charge by Averell Harriman that Republicans attempted to "rig" this year's election by splitting up the registration period.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 5 -- An erroneous impression was received by some readers from a story in The New York Times last Friday that the Davella Mills Foundation has a considerable fund left for distribution for charitable, religious, educational and scientific purposes.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Insurance companies in the United States should not make payments to beneficiaries behind the Iron Curtain, Daniel J. Reidy of New York, general counsel for the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, said today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5 -- Three changes probably will be made in the Yale line-up for the football game with Columbia at Baker Field in New York Saturday.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France and his Minister of Interior, Francois Mitterand, are expected to make statements to the National Assembly this week on the leakage of defense secrets in France.
The Mississippi River Bridge Authority of Louisiana financed yesterday the construction of a bridge connecting New Orleans with Algiers, La.
There certainly was no lack of excitement in Bergdorf Goodman's showing of furs yesterday.
Three professors at Hunter College have been suspended without pay for membership in the Communist party as far back as five or, in two cases even thirteen, years ago.
Many dinner parties will be given at the Fancy Free Ball, which will be held tonight in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Ballet Theatre.

Joe Black, the rookie of the year in 1952 and the disappointment of the year in 1953, has "worked his way back to Brooklyn" and will get another chance to reclaim his old bullpen job with the Dodgers in 1955.

The sporadic student "strikes" against the end of school segregation are reprehensible, but they should not be allowed to distort the entire picture. With a few notable and well-publicized exceptions, the program of integrated education has been going ahead smoothly since the opening of the academic year in most of the border areas where division of races had heretofore been enforced in the school.
LORAIN, Ohio, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. George M. Humphrey, wife of the Secretary of the Treasury, broke a bottle of champagne today, christening the biggest vessel ever built on the Great Lakes.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 5. -- The deadlock between political factions here remained unresolved today after a meeting between the Premier and Opposition leaders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, predicted today the Senate would vote overwhelmingly to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as recommended by the Watkins committee.
How to attain "new levels of prosperity" was charted yesterday by Arno H. Johnson, vice president and director of research of J. Walter Thompson Company.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The stock markets improved today, favorable company dividend statements helping industrial shares to make many small gains.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 5 -- United States truck and bus manufacturers will be completely frozen out of the Chilean market for the next five years if current plans of the Government are realized, automotive importers declared today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Local selling pressure in all Board of Trade pits today caused recessions in coarse grain prices. Rye sold off sharply following a big decline at Winnipeg, as a result of the reported postponement of German buying.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Fred E. Wright of Leewood, the Westchester husband-and-wife champions, scored 41, 35 -- 76 in alternate-stroke play at Quaker Ridge today for a one-shot victory in Metropolitan Golf Association mixed scotch foursome competition.

The London conference, which in less than six days created a new framework for European unity and security, could of necessity work only in broad outlines and principles, and many things necessary to make this framework a habitable structure had to be left to the experts or to separate negotiations.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 5 -- In a sharply worded resolution calling for intensified political action on the part of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the Republican party was characterized today as a "conglomeration of splinter groups, each trying to rule not only the party but the nation."
BONN, Germany, Oct. 5 -- Germany's top labor leader hinted today that the Soviet Union might be buying into the coal and steel industries of the Ruhr.

The strike of the International Longshoremen's Association is now over except for the formality of union ratification this morning. Called without warning or explanation in the middle of Monday night, it again tied up the Port of New York -- for the second time in six months.

Steel companies in August shipped 4,681,242 tons of finished products, an increase of 191,000 net tons over July. Of the twenty industrial classifications, thirteen took more steel in August than in the previous month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The psychology of human adjustment will be the subject matter for a new series of educational programs, which will have its premiere over WPIX on Monday, Oct. 18, from 9:30 to 10 P.M.
RYE, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Dr. Thomas J. Conte of Winged Foot won the New York State senior golf title today with a thirty-six hole aggregate of 147.
An expanded program of high school athletics, backed by an annual subsidy of $300,000, was recommended yesterday by a special committee appointed by the Board of Education.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The steering committee of the United Nations General Assembly agreed today to recommend including on the agenda the Soviet proposals on disarmament and international atomic-energy control.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (Reuters) -- One thousand more dock workers joined a two-day strike in the port of London tonight in defiance of union orders, swelling the total to 11,000.

The new S. Klein policy of raising the level of its styles while keeping its prices low was evident in the extensive collection of coats shown to the fashion press yesterday morning at this store on Union Square.

Throughout New York State most of the judges are elective. Upstate the election of a county judge or a Supreme Court justice is an infrequent local event, commanding attention from press and public; the elective system works up there not too badly.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A third indictment involving a Federal Housing Administration loan was returned today as a result of hearings conducted here last month by the Senate Banking Committee.

Monday's donations to the New York Regional Red Cross blood program totaled 307 pints of blood. Included were 161 given under the auspices of the Tri-Community Council of Laurelton, Springfield Gardens and Rosedale, Queens, at Public School 156.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Joseph E. Cole, president of National Key Co., said today he headed a group seeking to buy the Cleveland Indians, but declared "any talk about the sale of the club right now is premature."
ROME, Oct. 5 -- It seemed to be with satisfaction and relief rather than with wild exultation that the Italian public learned today that the Trieste question had been settled.

DENVER, Oct. 5 -- President Eisenhower looked upon settlement of what he described as "the delicate Trieste question" today as opening the way for greater security against Communist aggression in Southeast Europe.

NEWARK, Oct. 5 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey, made a plea yesterday for a middle-of-the-road Republican party that would support the program of President Eisenhower.
SPRINGFIELD, Vt., Oct. 5 -- Vermont Democrats, pointing out that "it happened in Maine," are determined this year to prove that campaigns in the state no longer end with the September primary.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 6 -- Two United States Congressmen traveling simply as tourists arrived in Moscow early today for a two-week visit.
CAIRO, Oct. 5 -- Egyptian security forces have seized members of an alleged spy network said to be under Israeli direction.
William H. Kehoe has been named trade sales manager of the Atlantic branch of the National Lead Company.

The 500-bed Nathan B. Van Etten Hospital, first unit of the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, was opened officially yesterday on a sixty-three-acre grassy hill crest between Pelham Parkway and Eastchester and Morris Park Avenues.

It's time for a change. Not necessarily in politics. In menus, Cross off the salads, the aspics, the cold meats; naturally, no insult to these fine summer foods is intended, although for this year their usefulness has seen better days.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, forecast today a lag of two years before a West German army could join Western defense foroes.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- A newcomer to the Soviet Union, having made a journey from Moscow to Kiev and back is impressed most of all by the immensity of the country and its population and the agricultural potential of the Russian black earth belt.
The business of converting the home of Andrew Carnegie's daughter to a school for the very young has been occupying the staff of the New York School for Nursery Years during the last few weeks.

If your favorite football player appears to be shooting off sparks from the vicinity of his chin, it's because the sunlight of October's sometimes "bright blue weather" is reflected from his plastic bar mask.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct, 5 -- The Opening of the Philadelphia Orchestra's fifty-fifth season, scheduled for Friday afternoon, will have to be postponed unless an agreement can be reached with the musician's union by tomorrow night.

A kibitzer remarked recently to Alfred de Liagre Jr. that Jed Harris had relinquished "The Green Lamp." Whereupon Mr. de Liagre got busy and is ready to tie up Theodore St. John's drama for a local opening around Christmas. The action of the one set, twelve-character play takes place in Connecticut against a Civil War background, with the underground movement accelerating the plot development.

IN February of 1949 Harper's Magazine published an article of light-hearted social analysis that seemed to many readers not only highly entertaining but extremely perceptive. It was '"Highbrow, Lowbrow, Middlebrow," by Russell Lynes, one of the editors of the magazine. Mr. Lynes argued that class distinctions based upon wealth, social prominence and occu pation were being replaced by a new stratification itemized in his title.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Oct. 5 (UP) -- Willie Shoemaker became the first jockey in history to ride 300 winners in four seasons when he booted home First Down in the fifth race at Tanroran today.

DENVER, Oct. 5 -- President Eisenhower today invited his top Congressional leaders to meet with him on Friday for a major political strategy session. It may determine the President's future role in the election fight for control of Congress.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 5 -- Representative Charles R. Howell accused the Eisenhower Administration here today of by-passing the United Nations. He said that decisions were made at the Pentagon and the White House and that the Administration then tried to "force them down the throats of our allies."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- An investment group has been formed to provide capital to develop commercial peacetime uses of atomic energy.

The dock strike influenced trading yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Dealers feared that roasters and other users did not have enough coffee and sugar to tide them over a prolonged strike. On the other hand, the inability to export potatoes flooded the domestic market and weakened prices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- School officials and the police of this city put in another tense day today dealing with "strikes" by white students at schools recently desegregated.

If it isn't one thing it is another in this exciting world of ours. Having, for the time being, settled the knotty problems of German rearmament and Trieste, we have been reminded that there are a few other Gordian knots to be untied or cut. Kashmir has hit the front pages again.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The Soviet bloc lashed out today at the United Nations refugee aid program.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5 -- Yugoslavia accepted the Trieste agreement "with satisfaction but without enthusiasm," the semi-official news agency Yugo-press said today. This echoed a the mood of self-sacrifice adopted by the Government.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 5 (AP) -- James (Dusty) Rhodes, a dangerous man with a baseball bat, arrived tonight en route to Rock Hill, S.C., and a rousing welcome home celebration tomorrow.

EARLY reports on the northern waterfowl openings give little indication of what may be expected in this area when the season starts, for with the exception of teal most of the shooting has been provided by "native" black ducks and mallards.
Ninety-five years ago this week -- the precise date and location have been obscured -- a small store opened in Vesey Street under the impressive name, The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.
PARIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Machinery was set up today to hasten the admission of West Germany into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Louis F. Budenz testified today that Edward O. Lamb of Toledo, Ohio, once served on national committees of two organizations controlled by the Communist party.

Arguments in favor of the $200,000,000 state bond issue for low-rent public housing, to be voted on this fall as Proposition No. 2, were advanced yesterday at a meeting called by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today he did not think President Eisenhower's participating in the political campaign would make much difference in the outcome.
My attention has been directed to several letters published in your paper from individuals opposed to the fluoridation of public water supplies.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 5 -- A listless Bundestag listened today to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's report on the nine-power London agreements. These will arm West Germany and grant it sovereignty and membership in a Western alliance through the instrumentality of an enlarged Brussels pact and North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver charged today that one of the power companies in the Dixon-Yates group has been "milking and bleeding" operating subsidiaries in just the way that led to passage of the Holding Company Act.

DOVER, Del., Oct. 5 -- A petition was filed in the court of chancery for Kent County here late today directing that a subpoena be issued against the National Association for the Advancement of White Persons to show cause why a preliminary injunction should not be issued halting further activities by the organization.
Johnny Antonelli of the Giants and Mike Garcia, Cleveland's husky right-hander, continued a trend by winning the major league earned-run titles in 1954, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
Rosette Pennington's fall and winter collection, shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, offered a diversified selection of silhouettes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Essential conditions for setting up the much-debated United Nations Special Fund for Economic Development "do not at present exist," according to a world-wide survey submitted today.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 5 (UP) -- George Mikan became vice president and general manager of the world professional basketball champion Minneapolis Lakers today.

"FATHER KNOWS BEST," one of the more durable of radio properties, came to television on film on Sunday night (10 P.M. over C.B.S.) and from all present indications should turn out to be a warm and engaging hit.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 5 -- Steve Kuk head football coach at Blair Academy, is handling his squad gingerly this season. Although well fortified With first-string material, Colgate's former star quarterback is aware that the team lacks depth.

VIENNA, Oct. 5 -- Chancellor Julius Raab, head of the People's party, tonight denied, and Socialist Vice Chancellor Adolf Schaerf sharply condemned, suggestions made from Rightist quarters here that Austria might accept a state treaty that would leave the Russians in possession of military bases.

IN the ghostly half-light of yesterday's dawn, Native Dancer was trundled into a van at Belmont Park and headed toward retirement at Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Sagamore Farm in Maryland. The Gray Ghost was leaving a race track for the last time.
YONKERS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Hugh Bell, 52-year-old Marion, Ohio, reinsman, drove three winners at Yonkers Raceway tonight, including Date Knight at 11 to 1 in the featured $3,500 Briarcliff Pace.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations ordered a broad investigation of union welfare funds today in an effort to weed out racketeering.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Marilyn Monroe sued Joe DiMaggio for divorce today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Stockholders of Midland Utilities Company, a part of the late Samuel Insull's utility empire, voted today to dissolve the company. Twelve men and seven women of the 8,500 stockholders were present for the proceedings.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston gave Prime Minister Churchill today a silver and ebony cigar box as a mark of its respect and admiration.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Senator Irving M. Ives made a stinging attack on Tammany Hall tonight after he had been the target of tomatoes while addressing a street rally here. The tomatoes missed the Republican candidate for Governor, but one of them spattered Mrs. Ives, who was sitting next to him.

A city administration bill was introduced into the City Council yesterday to set up formally the Department of Commerce and Public Events. The bill took 1,200 words to empower the department to spread New York's fame and greet visiting notables.

From the busy test kitchens of the Lever Brothers Company have come two new suggestions for easy-to-bake desserts. The innovations, small pastry shells that may be prepared in half an hour and a cake that may be baked in pans of varying sizes and shapes, were shown yesterday at the eleventh annual Newspaper Food Editors Conference being held here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A showdown report on whether the Salk vaccine is effective in preventing or mitigating polio will not be ready until around April 1, the director of a country-wide appraisal survey said today.

Herbert Morrison, former British Laborite Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Secretary, declared yesterday that there was "a very real chance for the return of the Labor party after the next parliamentary elections."

William Doppmann, the pianist who made his debut at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, last season distinguished himself by winning both the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award and the Michaels Memorial Award. Since both these awards are sought by the very finest of the nation's young musicians, Mr. Doppmann's first appearance promised to be something out of the ordinary.

A housewife who has two small sons was accused yesterday of permitting bookmakers to use the telephone in her one-family home at 118-15 205th Street, St. Albans, Queens. She was quoted as saying that she needed extra money and had been paid $40 a month for this service by a man she knew only as "Jack."

From the busy test kitchens of the Lever Brothers Company have come two new suggestions for easy-to-bake desserts. The innovations, small pastry shells that may be prepared in half an hour and a cake that may be baked in pans of varying sizes and shapes, were shown yesterday at the eleventh annual Newspaper Food Editors Conference being held here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A showdown report on whether the Salk vaccine is effective in preventing or mitigating polio will not be ready until around April 1, the director of a country-wide appraisal survey said today.
Registration soared again yesterday, the fourth day, to qualify for the election on Nov. 2, when 379,584 men and women signed the registry books.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- A Conservative newspaper publisher and a member of the Labor Party Executive criticized today the new European defense agreement.

The most generous food relief program in the history of American churches is being activated by the Church World Service. The relief agency is a branch of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America.
Seventeen hundred applications were made yesterday for jobs as city policemen, with 200 job-seekers standing on line at the filing office at 96 Duane Street when it opened at 9 A.M.

Plans for a new $7,700,000 Fashion Institute of Technology were moved forward yesterday by the City Planning Commission when it approved $625,000 in capital funds for the municipality's share of a site and plan.
The York Corporation announced yesterday that it had made a substantial realignment of its organization which should result in an increase in its sales volume.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Native Dancer came home today to Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Sagamore Farm in suburban Baltimore after winning 21 of 22 races.

The Chase National Bank had total resources of $5,573,758,743 on Sept. 30, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition issued for publication today. The total compares with $5,678,726,511 on June 30 and $5,553,147,256 on Sept. 30, 1953.

OTTAWA, Oct. 5 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Composers, Authors and Publishers Association of Canada could continue to charge privately owned radio stations 1 3/4 per cent of their gross revenues as a royalty on recorded music.
Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan suggested yesterday that a friendly power act as a mediator to try to establish a basis for direct Arab-Israeli peace talks.

TRIESTE, Oct. 5 -- An enormous Italian flag, sixty-five by thirty feet, was hoisted shortly after noon today to the top of a high pole in Piazza dell'Unita. It symbolized the reunion of the port and city of Trieste with Italy, which the majority of Triestenes long have regarded as their mother country.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 5 (UP) -- Frederick C. Mayer, venerable organist and choir leader at the United States Military Academy who was saved from enforced retirement two years ago by President Truman, was ordered retired today in an Executive Order signed by President Eisenhower.

BIG SPRING, Tex., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The chairman of the Big Spring draft board resigned today in protest against the life sentence given to Cpl. Claude Batchelor for collaborating with the Communists in Korea.

Col. Ben C. Limb, Korean Permanent Observer at the United Nations, was host yesterday at a luncheon honoring the motion picture industry on the eve of a nation-wide movie theatre campaign to raise funds for the American-Korean Foundation.

United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., manufacturer and distributor of textiles, commercial factor and operator of the Robert Hall Clothes, Inc., chain, improved its sales in the fiscal year ended June 30. Earnings, however, were slightly lower than in the preceding fiscal year.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Henry J. Kaiser signed a contract early today to manufacture cars, trucks and jeeps in Argentina in partnership with the Argentine Government and Argentine private investors.

BIG SPRING, Tex., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The chairman of the Big Spring draft board resigned today in protest against the life sentence given to Cpl. Claude Batchelor for collaborating with the Communists in Korea.
TRENTON, Oct. 5 -- In a sense, the race in New Jersey's Fourth Congressional District is a re-run of the 1952 Presidential contest. And the Democrats think they will win this time.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- John van Druten's "Bell, Book and Candle," which opened here tonight at the Phoenix Theatre, was received mildly by the newspaper reviewers. Their consensus was that the acting of the leading players, Lilli Palmer and Rex Harrison, deserved more credit than the play.

TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Al Lopez, manager of the Cleveland Indians, returned home today, thinking more about the 1955 New York Yankees than losing the world series to the New York Giants in four straight games.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Following is the text of the memorandum of understanding between the Governments of Italy, the United Kingdom, the United States and Yugoslavia regarding the Free Territory of Trieste:
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The dispute between Italy and Yugoslavia over Trieste ended today with the initialing of a memorandum of understanding by the two countries.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Hogs slumped to a new low for the year in a very slow market today. Butchers dropped 25 to 50 cents while sows were unevenly steady to 25 cents lower. Salable receipts at 12,000 head were 1,000 more than expected.

The Institute Of World Affairs, founded thirty years ago to help selected college students "become leaders in their own countries," will benefit from a performance on Oct. 28 of "Fragile Fox" at the Belasco Theatre.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The stock market displayed buoyancy again today, helped by yesterday's firmness in Wall Street. Among the industrials, demand was selective, but good gains were recorded in the store, motor and electrical groups.

Election of Broderick Haskell and J.L. Atwood as directors of the Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc., was announced yesterday. The organization is supported by industrial companies, educational institutions and labor groups interested in the development of atomic energy for peaceful purposes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the Trieste settlement "opens the way" to a new economic and military relationship between the United States and Yugoslavia.
Herbert Stanley Morrison, who was British Foreign Secretary under Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee, told Mayor Wagner yesterday that "New York is probably the noisiest city in the world."

Judge Samuel S. Liebowitz said yesterday that the state's Republican Administration appeared to be "more interested in building roads for farmers upstate than in providing adequate psychiatric treatment" for law offenders "who don't bring votes."

MONTREAL, Oct. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian Industries, Ltd., today reported what appeared to be a decrease in net profits for the first six months of 1954, prior to the division of its assets and operations between Canadian Industries (1954), Ltd., and du Pont of Canada Securities, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A Navy investigation is under way to fix responsibility for a mixup that resulted in putting the wrong kind of steam piping into the atomic submarine Nautilus.
Averell Harriman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, will carry his campaign upstate for the second time today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 6 -- The Interior Minister said today Thailand would evacuate about 40,000 Vietnamese refugees to free Vietnam only, although the overwhelming majority wish to go to the Communist-controlled north.

The agreement to end the New York dock strike had the effect of weakening commodity future markets here yesterday. Coffee fell the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit in all months and cocoa dropped as much as the 1-cent limit.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Representative Charles R. Howell charged here tonight that the Eisenhower Administration had violated the spirit, if not the letter, of the Employment Act of 1946. This law, he said, permits the Federal Government to maintain full employment in an expanding economy.

When the American League meets next Tuesday in Chicago to determine whether the Philadelphia Athletics must be sold by the Mack family, the New York Yankees are expected to join the Washington Senators and Detroit Tigers in opposing a shift of the Athletics to Kansas City.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 6 -- Dr. Leander A. Newman of Port Washington, L.I., 68-year-old general practitioner whose professional life dates back to the horse-and-buggy days, was selected today by the Nassau County Medical Society as the county's Doctor of the Year.
The sacrifice fly generally increased 1954 major league batting averages 2.4 points, with seven players indebted to baseball's revived regulation for their marks of .300 or better.
James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, said yesterday he hoped to stage both heavyweight and middle- weight championship fights in Miami this winter.

Mrs. Vincent G. Hart will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 960 Fifth Avenue for Lady Valerie Goulding of Dublin and her mother Lady Walter Monckton. During the afternoon plans will be discussed for the preview of the exhibition of paintings by Gretta Bowen, Irish artist, on Oct. 18 at the Karnig Gallery, 19 1/2 East Sixty-second Street, for the benefit of the Central Remedial Clinic in Dublin.
ROME, Oct. 6 -- Opposition speakers denounced the Trieste settlement as a "sellout" in a stormy Senate debate tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A Federal grand jury that has been considering perjury charges against Owen Lattimore for three weeks is expected to report tomorrow.

The world of painting, with its collection of experts, art dealers and forgers comes in for some spoofing in "Reclining Figure," the comedy by Harry Kurnitz, opening tonight at 8 o'clock at the Lyceum Theatre.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows;
President Eisenhower is reportedly being urged by anxious politicians in his own party to "talk more," schedule more appearances in key states where there are close races shaping up.
Geometric trends in lighting fixtures were demonstrated in the work of two young designers this week. The circle interests Jason Harvey; Leslie Larson is similarly fascinated by the triangle.

A liquor union official, who is facing possible contempt charges for hindering a grand Jury investigation of union activities, has been suspended from his union post. He is Sol Cilento, secretary-treasurer of the International Distillery, Rectifying and Wine Workers Union of America, A.F.L.

AMERICAN LEAGUE fans undoubtedly would prefer that the topic be placed on the forbidden list and never be mentioned again. But a fellow that has just been saturated with the world series finds all sorts of odds and ends tucked away in pockets or crannies of the mind. Here are some samples.
With only two days left to register for the election on Nov. 2, enrollment in the city still is lagging behind 1950, the last comparable year when a state election took place.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- India reacted to the decision of the United States Supreme Court on the issue of school segregation with a wave of emotion that swept the country, Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Glenn Ford will be starred as a school teacher who grapples with the problems of juvenile delinquency in "The Blackboard Jungle." The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer feature is being adapted from the Evans Hunter novel by Richard Brooks, who also will direct.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Pro. Government candidates led followers of the late President Getulio Vargas today in the third day of vote counting in Sunday's national elections.
CAIRO, Oct. 6 -- An official spokesman of the Egyptian Government charged today that recent Israeli gestures toward peace with the Arab states were "designed to gain a cheap propaganda victory."

Marlon Brando, who led striking longshoremen back to work in a triumphant revolt against their union bosses in the movie, "On the Waterfront," decided yesterday not to try to play the some role in real life.
The Chicago Symphony Orchestra will resume its series of weekly concerts over the Du Mont television network next Wednesday from 9 to 10 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Joseph E. Davies, ambassador to Russia from 1936 to 1938, testified today that he was in no way associated with official acts of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The president of Ford Motors Company of Canada, Ltd., urged the United States today to adopt a policy of progressive reduction of its tariffs "and other trade barriers." The executive, Rhys M. Sale, addressed the annual meeting of the American Life Convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Clyde L. Powell, former Assistant Federal Housing Commissioner, testified today before a Federal grand jury especially impaneled to investigate alleged scandals in the housing program. He appeared briefly and is scheduled to return Monday.
A major consumer marketing research service -- with 1,600 permanently employed field interviewers, largest, such enterprise in the country -- was created yesterday.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were somewhat irregular yesterday, closing 5 points higher to 4 points lower than on Wednesday.

The Maritime Administration's $11,000,000 Liberty ship conversion and engine improvement program will embrace some propulsion innovations that are considered extreme, even among American shipbuilders with experimental inclinations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The State Department was awaiting tonighta note from the Soviet Union that would signal Moscow's diplomatic offensive against the London agreement on West German armament.

Espionage is the subject of two books scheduled for publication soon. On Monday, Messner will issue "The Eddie Chapman Story," by Frank Owen, an account of the London safecracker who worked for Hitler and British Intelligence at the same time.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 6 -- The Soviet Union proposed tonight an immediate four-power conference to reunify, neutralize and evacuate Germany.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 6 -- If Italians could be taught to drink milk habitually and to use steel frames in buildings the rapidly growing economy of northern Italy could expand even faster than it has done.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Under Secretary of Agriculture True D. Morse said today the Government would not hesitate to reduce sugar quotas in an effort to improve prices if such action was warranted.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The Port of London was threatened with complete paralysis as the strike of dock workers spread again today.
HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, Oct. 6 -- For the fourth year in a row a team representing the Women's New Jersey Golf Association won the Mrs. J.J. Thompson Cup over the St. Andrews course today.
YONKERS, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Bobby King, a 6-year-old gelding driven by Del McTavish, won the featured Nutmeg mile pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight in 2:06 3/5.

The friskiest run at Belmont Park yesterday was made by the Bohemia Stable's Kope's Baby in the $6,000 purse that was seventh on the program. The colt's clocking was only a fifth of a second away from the track record for a mile and a sixteenth.

Kamal el-Malakh, Egyptian discoverer of the solar boat of the Pharoah Cheops, predicted last night that "other discoveries will be taking your front pages next year; the Cheops vessel will have become history, like the Sphinx."

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 6 -- Utah's Gov. J. Bracken Lee, having first refused to proclaim Oct. 24 as United Nations Day, issued a proclamation today calling for a statewide observance of United States Day on Oct. 23.

Critics of the Administration's economic policies have been talking a great deal recently about what they refer to as the necessity of maintaining the rate of national economic growth. While most economists agree on this general principle, few would accept, if indeed they recognized, the caricatured version of it that has intruded itself into the midterm national election campaign.

Efforts of the McLean Trucking Company of Winston-Salem, N.C., to obtain control of established coastwise steamship facilities apparently have failed. The McLean concern is one of several transportation companies about to embark in the coastwise transportation of loaded truck trailers aboard newly constructed trailer-ships.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Juan Lechin, powerful Bolivian Left-Wing leader, has resigned as Minister of Mines, an authoritative source said today.

Though Americans spent $1,627,000,000 for candy products last year, per capita consumption fell off 45 cents. Failure of candy to maintain its position in the general expansion of consumption was laid yesterday at the door of the candy makers themselves by the National Association of Tobacco Distributors.
Silver medals were presented yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. to 340 public and parochial school pupils for essays on fire prevention.

The proposals by the special committee of the Board of Education calling for direct financial aid to high school sports deserve favorable consideration by the Board of Estimate. Here is one area where a relatively modest expenditure -- $300,000 is the estimate -- can be applied with assurance of far greater returns.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Senate investigators suggested today that Ian Woodner, Washington and New York builder, charged to the cost of his housing projects funds paid to detectives he hired to fight his wife's divorce suit.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Don Holleder's return has set in motion a series of changes in Army's line-up for Saturday's contest with Dartmouth at Michie Stadium.
The directors of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., moved yesterday for the second time since 1951 to increase the bank's capital through the declaration of a stock dividend.
BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- An Atomic Energy Commission spokesman today promised American industry powerful new radioactive materials which may be important in sterilizing products.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 6 (AP) -- A comparative newcomer to harness horse racing tries tomorrow to capture the rich Kentucky Futurity for the second straight year.

The thing that makes autumn so bitter sweet is its silence. The bird bath in the garden stays filled to the brim for days; no saucy catbirds; no ruffled robins splash in it now, sending shining droplets of water in every direction.
A supergovernment to provide transit, water and certain other services to 550 communities in the metropolitan area was proposed yesterday by City Administrator Luther Gulick.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Weakness in soybeans and rye put a damper on grain buying this morning, but there was a strong tone in the major grains reflecting strength in the cash markets.

Today's new film is "Suddenly!'' a melodrama starring Frank Sinatra and Sterling Hayden at the Mayfair. James Gleason, Nancy Gates and Kim Charney head the supporting cast of the United Artists release.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Following are excerpts from statements by Ambassador Abba Eban, Israeli delegate, and Mahmoud Azmi, Egyptian delegate, to the United Nations General Assembly today:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- India called today for direct unification talks between leaders of East and West Germany.
TORONTO, Oct. 6 -- The Rev. Dr. Franklin Clark Fry of New York was elected here today to his sixth consecutive two-year term as president of the United Lutheran Church in America.

Robbins Mills, Inc., linked with Textron, Inc., and the American Woolen Company in merger talks, suffered a net loss of $5,960,000 in the nine months ended on Aug. 28. This is in contrast with the $704,000 loss sustained in the corresponding period last year.
The International Longshoremen's Association kept the port tied up for a second day yesterday, despite a unanimous vote by union delegates to end the costly strike of 25,000 dock workers.
Five new Dodgers were added to the Brooklyn club roster yesterday from its two Triple A farm clubs, Montreal and St. Paul, and all will report for spring training at Vero Beach, Fla.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- President Will Harridge today called a meeting of American League club owners here next Tuesday to discuss the future of the Philadelphia Athletics. At a similar session in New York on Sept. 28 Roy Mack, one of the Athletics' owners, received fourteen days to false $750,000 to buy control.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 6 -- Republicans of Nevada won an important victory late today when District Judge A.J. Maestretti permanently enjoined the Washoe County Clerk from placing the names of candidates for United States Senator on the general election ballot Nov. 2.

Department stores in the Second District couldn't maintain in September the hot pace of August but still managed to beat September, 1953, according to preliminary data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BETH SHEARIM, Israel, Sept. 30 -- The facade of a tomb with magnificent architectural adornment is being uncovered here. Archaeologists believe it is the family crypt of Judah the Prince, the rabbi who compiled the basic code of Jewish oral law known as the Mishnah.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Oct. 7 -- Lieut. Col. Herbert A. Peters, 37, a pilot of the First Marine Air Wing, who was returned by the Communists yesterday after eight months imprisonment, said today his captors had mistaken him for a defecting Allied flier when he was first captured.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Senator Irving M. Ives accused his Democratic opposition of trying to tag him as anti-Semitic and called for an end of "hate" in the current political campaign.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France hopes to get the National Assembly's endorsement of his West German armament policy by Friday night and its ratification of the requisite treaties by the end of November.
The Southern Pacific Company borrowed $8,505,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance the purchase of eight Diesel locomotives and other equipment.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Israel invited the Arab states today to join her in non-aggression pacts as a first new move toward bringing peace to the Middle East.
Two Europeans who were frustrated in their attempts to gain a foothold in America sailed for Germany yesterday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Gripsholm.

THE verses for today are from "Light Armour,''* a book of industriously irresponsible poetry by Richard Armour, who, as someone once said in another connection, views all pointing with pride with alarm:

BEATRICE, Neb., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Delegates to the thirteenth Biennial Convention of the American Lutheran Church voted unanimously today in favor of a proposed merger plan to bring together four Lutheran churches.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 6 -- A break was expected before the weekend in Miami's motel rate war, which moved into its third day today.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The economic expansion that began in Britain in 1953 has continued this year, the Treasury said today.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Bordentown Military Institute's football squad meets Peddie for the twenty-second time since 1888 on Saturday and Bob Hoehn, the cadets' head coach, is leaving nothing undone to gain a victory.

Premier Mendes-France has plunged immediately into battle to win parliamentary approval of the London agreements. In a Cabinet session, presided over by President Coty, he has obtained not only the solid support of his multiparty Government for the agreements themselves but also authority to stake the Government's life on the issue and, if necessary, to demand a vote of confidence, the refusal of which could lead to new national elections.

MIAMI, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Northwest storm warnings were posted tonight over the Netherlands Antilles and the coastal islands off Venezuela as hurricane Hazel, a small but violent tropical storm, neared that region.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State, Inc., said today it had received the assurances of the two major party candidates for Governor that they would not discriminate against women in political appointments.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- The opening Friday afternoon and Saturday evening concerts of the Philadelphia Orchestra's 1954-55 season were canceled today because of a contract dispute with the musicians union.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 6 -- Marshal Tito, Yugoslav President, said today the Trieste agreement was unsatisfactory but was the best Yugoslavia could achieve under the circumstances. Speaking at a Communist League meeting in Sarajevo he asked members of the organization to explain this to the people.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 6 -- Attendance in this city's 170 public schools was back to 95 per cent of normal today, the Office of the superintendent of schools reported.

The two new luxury liners that the Moore-McCormack Lines plans to build for the South American trade will be fitted with outboard wing-type stabilizers to control rolling if the equipment can be installed at reasonable cost, Robert C. Lee, vice president of the board of the company, said yesterday.

The cornerstone of the New York Coliseum, a $35,000,000 structure at Columbus Circle that it is hoped will establish New York in the forefront of convention cities, will go into place in two weeks. Mayor Wagner will be the principal speaker at noon ceremonies sponsored by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.

An increase last week of 973,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. On last Friday total supplies were 152,118,000 barrels, compared with 151,145,000 a week earlier and 140,829,000 a year ago.

Many important changes in Federal legislation are required in "the interests of common justice to the customers of electric power companies," Harold Quinton, newly elected president of the Edison Electric Institute, declared yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 6 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon swung today from farm to industrial territory pocked with unemployment. Mr. Nixon, campaigning for Republican candidates nationally as well as locally, declared:

Irving Maidman, real estate investor, has contracted to purchase the five-story store and apartment building at 308 West Forty-second Street from Eugene C. Ludin. The property, assessed at $102,000, occupies a lot 25 by 100 feet on the south side of the street near Eighth Avenue.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The United Nations General Assembly rejected tonight a demand by the Soviet Union for immediate consideration of its complaint that Nationalist China was guilty of "piratical" actions.

Much has been written, and justly so, on the constant vigilance and care required to guard against accidents on the highways. Industry long has recognized the loss each year of man-days of work caused by accidents to employes in factories, shops, stores and offices.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Informed observers here speculated tonight on the possibility that the speech of the Soviet Foreign Minister in East Berlin presaged a Soviet reply to the Western Allies' note of Sept. 10.
WILLOWS, Calif., Oct. 6 (AP) -- An Air Force B-50 weather reconnaissance plane crashed and burned southeast of here tonight and the Sheriff's office indicated at least eleven men aboard were killed.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Kansas City means business in its bid for a major league baseball franchise, and ticket orders poured in today to prove it. One of the first orders was a $2,500 pledge.
The experts on the rearing of children seem to have reached a point of unanimity on basic theories and one of sympathy with parents, according to Mrs. Sidonie Matsner Gruenberg.
DENVER, Oct. 6 -- The Administration's role as a world peacemaker appeared today to be shaping up as the central point in President Eisenhower's speech to the nation Friday ...
FORT BRAGG, N.C., Oct. 6 (AP) -- An Air Force C-119 transport plane, its left engine spouting flames, crashed into a barracks construction project here today and killed the pilot and co-pilot.

The problems of Federal Government service will be discussed by the sixth American Assembly, which begins today a four-day session at Arden House, the Harriman Campus of Columbia University, Harriman, N.Y.

Sales and profits of American business in the fourth quarter of this year should improve over the levels of a year ago, Roy A. Foulke, vice president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., said yesterday. "Any such improvement," he added, "will continue into 1955."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Individual savings were maintained at a high rate through the second quarter of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 6 -- The United States today Urged leaders of the Asian members of the Colombo Plan Consultative Committee to make greater use of the Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act for the disposal of surplus food commodities.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 6 (UP) -- The President of the Inter-American Press Association proposed today the adoption of a code of newspaper ethics to strengthen freedom of expression.
ROCK HILL, S.C., Oct. 6 -- This textile center of 26,000 persons set a national record for enthusiasm today when it turned out to honor James (Dusty) Rhodes, hitting hero of the 1954 world series.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator, accused New Jersey Democratic leaders today of attempting to divert the campaign from national to state issues.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert, stars of the United States' Davis Cup team, slipped through their second round matches with ease today in the nineteenth Pan-American tennis tournament. They won in straight sets, as did all the seeded players in the men's singles.
An 11-year-old boy survived a nine-story drop yesterday as he leaped from a window after being spanked by his mother.

The pier strike, called without warning in the middle of one night, and called off the next day with no more notice -- both acts taken without the slightest effort to explain them to the public -- shows a degree of irresponsibility, coupled with vast power, almost beyond belief.

OTTAWA, Oct. 6 -- Political observers here believe that a conference of the political leaders of all ten Canadian provinces will be the sequel to the meeting yesterday of Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent and Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec.
Attractive fashions shown yesterday by Jay Thorpe at the Plaza Hotel proved that with proper draping, well-scaled details, and appropriate fabrics, there are no fitting problems for the mature woman.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 6 -- The three-sided contest in New Jersey's Sixth Congressional District -- which may serve as a political barometer in this midterm election -- is overlaid with complexities.

I would like to add my voice, both as a citizen of New York and as a candidate for its highest legislative body, to those of the many responsible civic leaders who have urged all qualified persons, regardless of party affiliation, to register for the November

The wail of the ambulance siren may be heard here for the last time on Halloween, Oct. 31. Starting the next day sirens will be banned for the more than 100 ambulances from municipal and voluntary hospitals that belong to the emergency ambulance service.

The Brazilian Finance Minister, Dr. Eugenio Gudin, announced yesterday that a one-year $160,000,000 loan had been granted to his country by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Dr. Gudin, who had just completed negotiations on the loan, outlined its purposes at a news conference in the Ambassador Hotel.

The fifth annual Fan Ball for the benefit of the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund, Inc., will be held on the night of Nov. 12 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Herbert T. Mundin, president of the beneficiary, again is serving as executive chairman of the ball, and Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower again is honorary chairman.

An 85-year-old heel-and-toe walker, probably the world's oldest active competing athlete, blew into town yesterday for his first visit. During the day he bicycled from midtown to the financial district and back again.
Representative Jacob K. Javits accused Averell Harriman and Democratic leaders yesterday of attempting to incite religious bigotry in New York City for political purposes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Former President Hoover came back to the Department off Commerce, which he headed twenty-six years ago, to get a flag.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A comprehensive port improvement program for Mexico, affecting seventy ports on the nation's 10,000-mile littoral, is well under way after a year of the six-year project, Gen. Rodolfo Sanchez Taboada, Mexican Minister of Marine, said here today.

THE New York Historical Society, Central Park West between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets, was organized in 1804 and is thus celebrating its 150th anniversary this year. As a commemoration of this event, a special exhibition of its treasures opened yesterday, featuring historical material pertaining to the United States and to New York in particular.

Directors of the Griesedieck Western Brewery Company who had recommended that its assets be sold to the Carling Brewing Company, Inc., now are considering converting the company into an investment trust, rather than liquidating.

The Dr. Pepper Company, soft drink manufacturer, and Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., have decided to end their client-agency relationship and the account has gone to Grant Advertising, Inc., of Chicago, which is setting to work on plans for the year ahead.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The superintendent of schools late today directed all students absent in protest against desegregation to return to classes by Friday or forfeit all school honors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A demand for immediate information on whether a contract for power with the Dixon-Yates power interests already had been approved was made to the Atomic Energy Commission today by a Senate subcommittee.
PRESQUE ISLE, Me., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Men of the United States Air Force traveled along rows of potatoes instead of the skyways today, helping to harvest the Maine crop.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Governor Dewey charged today that Averell Harriman was attempting to inject racial and religious prejudice into the state campaign.

Carried astray on their annual southern migration by a wild northwest wind, 123 birds and four bats crashed into the Empire State Building in the early hours of yesterday morning. Porters found them on the five set-backs of the structure from the eighty-sixth (observatory) floor down to the sixth.
CLERMONT, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- One hundred eighty guests from 1954 tonight attended the gala wedding reception of Katrena Ten Broeck and Peter Van Hous, who were married at The Bouwerie here in 1762.

The five-story apartment house at 656 East 176th Street has been sold by a client of Sidney Holtzman to the Roen Woodycrest Corporation for cash above mortgages of $24,000, Langsam Schiffman and Leonard Goldkopf were the brokers.

DES MOINES, Oct. 6 -- The Congressional election is still a month away, but so far, the Republicans seem to have failed in their two major objectives: to capitalize in the Korean armistice and to transfer President Eisenhower's popularity to the G.O.P. candidates for Congress.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Helicopter service from central London to the London Airport at Hounslow will be established in April with eight regular round trips a day, British European Airways announced today.

The announced Trieste agreement between Rome and Belgrade is a typical example of a "final" settlement based on not only a temporary but also a very questionable expediency. Because the Governments of Italy and Yugoslavia, the two imperialistic contenders for Trieste, were opposed to the latter's legal status as an independent free territory the Western diplomats decided and pressed for a partition of the Trieste territory between Belgrade and Rome.

License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey announced yesterday that he would hold a closed hearing tomorrow on complaints made to his office about advertising displays by motion picture theaters on West Forty-second Street.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will begin today the first series of free public lectures in its Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, one of the major undertakings in the museum's three-year reconstruction and rehabilitation program.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The United States hopes to open the way to international agreement on freedom of the seas by having the General Assembly consider problems of fishing rights.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 29:

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Jacques Duclos, secretary general of the French communist party, denied today having received defense secrets. He protested that the Government investigation of defense leaks had been "side-tracked" toward the Communists through the influence of "French McCarthyism."

Duncan Hines, writer on American restaurants, yesterday remarked to the 139 newspaper food editors attending their eleventh annual conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that "eating is more fun than anything else in the world."

MANY of those planning to participate in the special antlerless deer season in the "isolated" portions of the Adirondack Forest are apparently beginning to suffer from that familiar ailment known as "cold feet," for the wilderness expedition promises to have more problems than had been anticipated.

The annual devotions of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, started at sundown yesterday. Services were held in synagogues and temples and attended by thousands of devout Jews. The traditional Kol Nidre chant, a prayer for absolution, was recited as a prelude.

A vacant plot of 80,000 square feet at Seaview Avenue and Rockaway Parkway, adjoining the Bay View Houses of the New York City Housing Authority, in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn was sold at auction yesterday for $155,000. The high bidder was Lee Harris Co. of 116-55 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens, representing a builder who will improve the site with a retail shopping center.

Kansas City, Mo., borrowed $12,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of water revenue bonds maturing serially from 1961 to 1984. The issue was sold at competitive bidding to a banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., Drexel Co., Glore, Forgan Co. and Braun, Bosworth Co.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- The United Electrical Workers Union filed today a court challenge to the new Communist Control Law.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 6 -- The shipbuilding industry is going to be "recessioned to death," Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today at the seventeenth national convention of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O.

James R. Shepley and Clay Blair Jr., authors of a new book, "The Hydrogen Bomb," challenged yesterday a statement by Dr. Henry DeWolf Smyth, former member of the Atomic Energy Commission. Dr. Smyth said last Sunday that the authors "seem to have talked at length with a few people who knew parts of the story."

HAZELTON, B.C., Oct. 6 (Canadian Press) -- A world-record thirty-six-pound steelhead trout was caught today in the rocky little Kispiox River near this northern British Columbia town. It was the third record steelhead pulled from the stream this season.
Louis E. Wolfson, industrialist and financier, asserted yesterday that he and his associates own "substantially more" than 250,000 shares of the stock of Montgomery Ward Co.
High fashion was brought within easy reach of short women yesterday at the Pierre Hotel when Bloomingdale's presented a collection of Varden Petite originals.

Sale of nationally branded frozen foods are booming here, like all other branded products, and a foreign market is opening for them. These statements and predictions were heard yesterday at a luncheon in the Belmont Plaza Hotel by members of the Eastern Frozen Foods Association.
Buford Long, offensive right halfback of the Giants, gave Jim Lee Howell a slight scare yesterday when he appeared for practice at Fordham Field with an infection in his right foot.

The three-story building at 134 Metropolitan Avenue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn has been leased by H. Landau and will be used for the processing and shipping of feathers and down. The property, containing 6,000 square feet of space, is owned by Anthony Siano and was leased through the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.
WELLSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Follansbee Steel Corporation today asked the Brooke County Court to dismiss a petition for an injunction to halt sale of its assets to New York interests.

The one-story taxpayer building at 120-39 Eighty-third Avenue, corner of Grenfell Street, in Kew Gardens, Queens, has been resold by Lawrence M. Lyons, real estate operator, to the Lefferts Holding Corporation. The property fronts 127 feet on Eighty-third Avenue and eighty-seven feet on Grenfell Street. It was sold for cash above mortgages of $79,880.
Members of the Fashion Group previewed yesterday fabrics that will be fashionable in the spring and fall of 1955.
HIGHLAND PARK, N.J., Oct. 6 -- One of the quieter political contests this year is being waged in New Jersey's Fifth Congressional District.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 6 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations labeled President Eisenhower's economic program "a complete fizzle" today and said the business outlook "is actually cause for serious concern and alarm."
The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago thinks housewives can look forward to bargains at their favorite meat counters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -"National Precinct Day," Friday, during which the President and Vice President will speak, also will feature nationwide "dawn to dusk" recruiting for party workers, local rallies, caucuses and clambakes.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 6 (UP) -- If the Cleveland Indians are sold, it appeared today that $4,000,000 would be needed to turn the trick.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Harry (Cookie) Lavagetto signed a two-year contract as first-base coach of the Washington Senators today.

PENN YAN, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Participants at the third annual Family Life Conference at Keuka College today agreed that women could combine marriage, career and citizenship successfully. Sponsored by the Hattie M. Strong Memorial Foundation of Citizenship, the conference topic was "Harmonizing the Many Roles of Modern Women."
