LANGLEY AIR FORCE BASE, Va., Oct. 6 (AP) -- A new twin-jet bomber with the agility of a fighter plane and the ability to attack enemy targets at low level in darkness performed publicly for the first time today. It is the B-57-B, latest model of the Martin Canberra.
Within two years, if the Board of Estimate approves, subway passengers traveling between Times Square and Grand Central stations will make their journey by conveyor instead of shuttle trains.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Charley Norkus, Port Washington, L.I., heavyweight, halted the fistic climb of Charley Powell of San Diego when he scored a seventh round technical knockout in their scheduled ten-rounder tonight.

Vice President Nixon appears to have selected a theme for his Congressional campaigning which is contrary to the facts as well as a slander upon a nonpartisan political group. In The Times of Oct. 2 the Administration's keynoter charges that "the Americans for Democratic Action wing of the Democratic party [is] presently running the Democratic National Committee."

BOSTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Gene Conley today spurned a "ridiculously low" baseball salary offered by the Milwaukee Braves and turned to basketball for the income he needs to support his "wife and two kids."
Some long gains were made in yesterday's stock market, but the averages changed little.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- An official of the National Education Association said today some public school classes were being conducted in converted coal bins, garages, church basements and commercial stores.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission was urged today to reverse the action of one of its examiners in dismissing a complaint against Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, N.Y., that its fair trade practices violated the law.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Cup Man from the Rokeby Stable won the Absecon Island Handicap, the closing day feature of the 1954 Atlantic City thoroughbred racing meeting, today. A crowd of 11,940 attended the program.
The Columbia University football squad went through a long scrimmage at Baker Field yesterday in preparation for the game against Yale at Baker Field.
TRIESTE, Oct. 6 -- Trieste, effervescent over its imminent return to Italy, welcomed today the first Italian officer in full uniform and on an official mission to come here in the last eleven years.

The Regional Plan Association celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday by providing a forum for stimulating discussion of the New York metropolitan area's future in the quarter century ahead. Chancellor Heald of New York University set a keynote for this meeting in a sense when he expressed confidence in "man's ability to control his environment."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Mr. Hoover, said he had spent "eight years of the happiest period of my life" in the Commerce Department.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Sweden proposed today that the cost of future United Nations efforts on behalf of 350,000 European refugees should be appropriated by the sixty-member General Assembly.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Following are excerpts from a statement today by V.K. Krishna Menon, Indian delegate, to the United Nations General Assembly:
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The worker who gets his boss to provide group annuities, pensions and other benefits is getting nothing for nothing, an insurance executive asserted today.

La Salle College of Philadelphia, National Collegiate Athletic Association champion last season, yesterday was seeded No. 1 for the 1954 Holiday Festival basketball tournament in Madison Square Garden, Dec. 27, 29 and 31.
DETROIT, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Metro Prystai and Marcel Pronovost rapped in goals tonight that carried the Detroit Red Wings to a 2-to-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs before 10,205 fans at Olympia.

Three men attempted a $100,000 hold-up of a Queens bank yesterday with the same Willie Sutton technique that netted $97,500 in a Mount Vernon bank robbery on Sept. 23, but they failed to follow the script.

Rear Admiral Paulus P. Powell, retired, has given up his post as president of Town Hall by mutual agreement with its trustees. This was announced yesterday by the trustees and confirmed by the admiral.
Three new productions will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera during the coming season, the company announced yesterday.
LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 7 -- Hotchkiss School's football players may not be big but they certainly are enthusiastic.

Every so often, usually after the test explosion of an atomic bomb, heads are wagged dolefully and people wonder aloud if the world would not be better off if scientists had never unlocked the secrets of the universe.
Two awards will be made at the annual dinner meeting of the Hundred Year Association of New York, to be held on Nov. 9 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- An experimental "all-transistor'' calculator, which may surpass conventional electronic "robot-brained" machines, was exhibited today at a press preview of the new International Business Machines research laboratory.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Harlan, an easy-going colt that had chased the leaders all season, found his stride in the grand finale of the Grand Circuit today and scored a straight-heat victory in the $64,410 Kentucky Futurity.

I am shocked by the continuing charges of the Democratic candidates for state office that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and the Republican-controlled State Legislature deliberately caused the splitting of registration dates as an alleged method of holding down registration in the city of New York in order for the Republicans to "gain" numerical voting advantages upstate.

The third and last segment of registration will start today with the final opportunity to qualify for the election on Nov. 2 taking place tomorrow. Polling places in this city and Westchester will be open today from 3:30 to 10:30 P.M. and tomorrow from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M.

Your editorial of Oct. 2 "Milford Takes Its Stand" clearly states some aspects of the pattern of tragedy, irony and injustice which now brands this area of Delaware. In order to evaluate the significance of the Milford tragedy and determine its effect upon other communities, a number of other facts must be clearly presented to the public.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 7 -- Senator Irving M. Ives pledged his best efforts today to wipe out unemployment in the state and declared it would be achieved without "leaf-raking or a W.P.A."

Libby Holman has decided to extend her engagement at the Bijou Theatre through the evening of Oct. 16. The throaty blues singer opened her one-woman show, "Blues, Ballads and Sin-Songs," last Monday. She had planned to limit her local stay to six nights, closing after tonight's performance.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Muhammad Zafrulla Khan, the Foreign Minister of Pakistan since that nation was created in 1947, was elected to the Internation Court of Justice by the United Nations today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Navy's football squad flew to California today and Coach Eddie Erdelatz also plans to have the team in the air against Stanford Saturday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The commissioner, Bert Bell, today sent a directive to referees and coaches in the National Football League "re-emphasizing" the rules governing rough play.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 7 -- The Federal Executive Council formally approved today the memorandum of understanding on Trieste.

CAIRO, Sept. 7 -- Pursuing a purge of dissident or unreliable elements, Egypt's military regime has dismissed 109 high-ranking police officers, including thirty-one brigadiers and generals, in the last ten days.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 7 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, rejected today the latest Soviet offer on German's reunification. He felt that this proposal, like its predecessors, sought the subversion of a united Germany by the Communist minority.
Ten persons -- a fireman, a young woman and eight children -- were rescued yesterday as heat and smoke from a one-alarm fire roared up through a five-story tenement house at 3 West 117th Street.
From the abundance spilling out of fields and orchards in the autumn harvest come some strange fruits.

DENVER, Oct. 7 -- Mid-way on his third speechmaking tour of the election campaign, Vice President Richard M. Nixon scheduled a fourth trip today. It will take him from coast to coast and give him a total of thirty-one states visited.

PORT WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Mrs. J. B. Balding, Creek, carded a 41, 39 -- 80 to win low gross by four strokes in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at North Hempstead today.

With a gain of $2.38 a share, the average price of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month broke through all month-end high marks since May of 1946. The average price on Sept. 30 was $48.71, against $46.33 on Aug. 31, 1954, and $50.44 on May 31, 1946.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France said today that the campaign against his Government over the leakage of defense secrets had nearly prevented the London accords on West Germany's armament.

Cleveland borrowed $11,000,000 in the public market yesterday for the improvement of the city's water and electric system. The money was raised through the sale of $6,000,000 of water revenue bonds due from 1959 to 1983 and $5,000,000 of electric revenue bonds due from 1959 to 1978.

The University of Kentucky Press has announced the establishment of a $5,000 fellowship for the writer who displays the most insight and scholarship in projecting a book-length manuscript analyzing a significant aspect of the culture of Kentucky, or its region.
More than half of the 800 children for whom the city provides schooling at home because Of severe orthopedic handicaps may be able to go back to school after all.

The transparently synthetic efforts to invent or discover a basis for charging religious bias that have dominated the headlines of the New York political campaign in the last few days are tediously ridiculous. There is nothing in the record of Irving Ives, on the Republican side, or of Averell Harriman, on the Democratic side, to justify in the slightest such an approach.
In their first rise in three weeks, business loans of New York banks gained $72,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Archaeologists have dug up what appear to be the remains of a second or third century pantheon among the ruins of the Roman temple of Mithras in the City of London.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Gov. Rober B. Meyner declared here tonight that the Republican party in New Jersey, "disgruntled, demoralized and defeated," was now following a course of "self-destruction." He further accused former Representative Clifford P. Case, its candidate for United States Senator, of being a "quitter."
Eleven Brooklyn youths between 16 and 18 years old were held yesterday in $5,000 bail each in Brooklyn Adolescent Court after Williamsburg police averted a threatened gang fight.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 7 -- Zainul Arifin, Second Deputy Vice Premier, told local Chinese leaders today he would investigate the order for the deportation to Communist China of Tjiong Hoen-nji. Mr. Tjiong is regarded by the Chinese community here as its No. 1 anti-Communist Chinese leader.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, commander of the First Army at Governors Island, New York, will retire on Nov. 30 after thirty-eight years as an officer. He will be succeeded by Maj. Gen. Thomas W. Herren, the Army announced today.
Governor Dewey has renewed his war on gangster elements in the old international Longshoremen's Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Department store sales last week were 2 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The United States has been sounding out other delegations on the idea of giving a voice, without a vote, in the United Nations General Assembly to some of the countries kept out by the Soviet veto.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 -- Legislation under which at least 20 per cent of all Government shipbuilding would be allocated to the Pacific Coast will be introduced in Congress, members of the House Merchant Marine Committee said today.

Witty Brothers' new store at 724 Fifth Avenue, its fifth in the city, will open on Monday. Completely air conditioned, the men's clothing store has 12,500 square feet divided into a main floor, a mezzanine floor and a basement workshop.

Spokesmen for 30,000 unionized truck drivers in the metropolitan area notified Federal, state and city mediators yesterday that an "impasse" had been reached in wage talks with the general trucking industry.

HEAVENS to Betsy but the college football situation is an untidy mess. It's almost like a young housewife who leaves the children playing primly in the living room while she goes to answer the telephone. Upon her return she discovers to her horror that the little monsters have sawed a leg off the piano, scribbled crayon drawings on the walls, pulled the stuffings out of the cushions and burned a hole in the Oriental rug.

Copper nails of unusual shape have been found in the cedar planks of the top deck of the funerary ship of Pharaoh Cheops, who ruled Egypt more than 4,700 years ago. The presence of the hook-like nails in the vessel appears to be the first known instance of the use of copper or other metal rivets in the history of naval construction.
The Giants' players struck a bigger bonanza than had been anticipated by winning the richest world series and the vanquished Indians fared mighty well financially, too.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The first regional organization for nuclear research in the world will convene tomorrow in Geneva. At its head will be Prof. Felix Bloch, a Nobel Prize winning physicist from Stamford University.

Racing colors of the ten leading stables of the country and jockey statuettes provided a colorful decor for the Belmont Futurity Ball held last night at the formal opening of the redecorated ballroom of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club.

Directors of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company voted yesterday to create a new issue of $1.20 cumulative preferred stock, $25 par, to be offered in an optional exchange for common stock on a share-for-share basis.
Domestic shipments of slab zinc last month were the largest since June, and smelter stocks of unsold metal dropped to a ten-month low.

Ten years ago this morning the news of Wendell Willkie's death occupied the same front pages that carried word of a United States First Army victory in Germany. He died on the eve of a Presidential campaign in which, if fate had played its hand differently, he would have been a candidate.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A United States District Court jury awarded the Electric Theatre here more than $2,400,000 damages against six movie companies in an anti-trust law suit today.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., had a consolidated net income of $15,595,243 in the twelve months ended Aug. 31, it was reported yesterday by E.H. Dixon, president. This was equal to $2.19 a share on the outstanding common, and compares with a net of $13,876,357, or $1.95 a share, in the year to Aug. 31, 1953.

ROSWELL, N.M., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Four were drowned, three were presumed dead and seven persons were missing tonight in flash floods that battered an eighty-mile stretch of the rich irrigated Pecos Valley in southern New Mexico. Damage was expected to run into millions.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Except for a wingback, Bob Russell, Princeton will have every member of the regular line-up ready for Pennsylvania in the football game here Saturday in Palmer Stadium.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Jim (Bear) Owens pitched a two-hitter tonight as the Syracuse Chiefs of the International League gained a 1-0 victory over the Louisville Colonels of the American Association to square the little world series at two victories apiece in the four-out-of-seven set.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Bermuda swept the best-of-seven series for International One Design yachts from Norway today by winning its fourth straight race, 32 1/4 points to 28, despite the bad weather conditions the Norwegians had hoped for.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 7 -- Their yacht sinking beneath them from a hole in her side, two men and two women donned life jackets, lashed themselves together and plunged into the Atlantic about thirty miles southeast of Cape Henry today.

C.V. Whitney's Fisherman impressed a crowd of 25,084 with his class in winning the $27,950 Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday. The son of Phalanx was the favorite in the mile and five-eighths fixture, and he performed brilliantly to score in the sixty-second running of the test for 3-year olds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that his sixty-member committee studying the anti-trust laws was "very qualified to go into all phases of the anti-trust laws."

MIXING a few ideas with a lot of professional cynicism, Harry Kurnitz has written a funny comedy entitled "Reclining Figure," which opened at the Lyceum last evening. It tells the story of an eccentric collector of paintings who buys a forgery with considerable gusto and pride.

Many a housewife is alone in the house during her working hours. Unlike workers in business and industry, the home manager seldom has immediate asistance from others when she has an accident, because there is no one around.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 7 -- A youthful-looking Democratic lawyer has been pitted against a veteran Republican legislator for a seat in the House of Representatives from the Eighth New Jersey District, and impartial political observers are reluctant to predict the outcome.

THREE months ago four teen-age school boys kicked to death a man they did not know. Newspaper readers across the nation stared at the headlines with incredulous horror. What kind of inhuman monsters could the young killers be? But in certain schools in New York City, says Evan Hunter in his first novel, "The Blackboard Jungle,"* boys only a little less vicious are gathered in large numbers.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 -- The City Fire Commission today deferred for another week steps to end racial segregation in the Fire Department.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Averell Harriman declared today that the Eisenhower Administration had undertaken a "giveaway" program of the nation's natural resources that should belong to the people.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Stock prices rose again today, influenced by a strong demand for high-class industrial equities.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 7 -- An ancient town that was a center of activity at various periods from the time of the first Temple and the Jewish Monarchy to the early Arab era (about the eighth century, A.D.) has been unearthed between Bethlehem and Jerusalem by the Israeli Department of Antiquity.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- "Belly-sleeping" in bed, or squatting Indian-style in front of a TV set for hours on end might help exaggerate and prolong a recently recognized form of "bow legs" possible in some children.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped to a new low for the year today as butchers lost 25 to 40 cents and sows 25 to 50 cents in moderately active trading. Salable receipts were in line with expectations at 9,000 head.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 -- Public school attendance here was described as "practically normal" today by Dr. John H. Fischer, Superintendent of Public Instruction. No incidents involving parents who opposed desegregation were reported.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Mr. Harriman said here today that 100,000 new jobs a year were needed in New York. He said Republicans failed to understand this.
Empire State bankers are recruiting as large an audience as possible to see a forthcoming television show that will depict their profession sympathetically.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A pioneer in one of the newest forms of transportation -- the movement by water of loaded highway truck trailers -- reported today that he was now operating profitably after two and a half years of nearly disastrous problems, disappointments, "trials and tribulations."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- The Army announced today it had developed a new hospital railroad car with adjustable wheels so it could operate on any broad gauge track in the world.

"CLIMAX," which made its debut at 8:30 o'clock last night on the C.B.S. television network, can go right to the head of the class. For many different reasons it was not only fine entertainment but also a welcome turn of events for TV as a whole.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The Czech-born orchestra conductor Rafael Kubelik has been appointed musical director of the Covent Garden Opera Company, it was announced here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The student "strike" against public school desegregation appeared over today.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 -- A jurisdictional tussle has developed within the Mexican Government over the fate of Maj. Jaime Rosenberg, former chief of the Guatemalan secret police.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Nationalist China has stopped bombing attacks on the Chinese Communist mainland at the suggestion of the United States, diplomatic authorities reported today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The Broadway success "The Fourposter," planned as the season-opener for the Canadian Repertory Theatre group here Oct. 15, has come under the ban of a church censor because of its "risque" approach.

Fifteen high school graduates yesterday received $200 each in junior scholarships, awarded because they had earned some of the money for their education, made good grades and written essays on American free enterprise.

ON Wednesday, Oct. 11, in 1854, a gentleman from The New-York Times journeyed by stage from Park Row to the new Marble Collegiate Church in Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street to hear the Rev. Thomas De Witt eloquently utter the church dedication sermon.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer won an easy victory in the Bundestag today for the London agreements to arm West Germany.

COGAR, Okla., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Battling a thick morning fog with one engine dead, a California pilot crash-landed his twin-engine plane in a cotton field near here today. He and two passengers perished in the flaming wreckage.

Members of Fordham's famous Seven Blocks of Granite of 1936 and winners of Madow Trophies will be honored during the half-time ceremonies of the Boston College-Fordham game at the Polo Grounds a week from tonight.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, Dimitri Mitropoulos conductor, opened its 113th season last night in Carnegie Hall, with a program, curiously compounded, and presented with a curious variety of interpretive effects within the frame of brilliant virtuoso performances.
The following recipe utilizes an unusual vegetable currently in the city market stalls.
MILAN, Italy, Oct. 7 -- One of Italy's industrial white elephants is showing surprising signs of life.
CAIRO, Friday, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -- Hassan Hodeiby, supreme aide of the fanatic and ultra-nationalist Moslem Brotherhood, has been arrested, the police announced early today.

The Nevada State Supreme Court has under advisement today a case of some interest to those who believe, let the chips fall where they may, in representative government. This case arises out of the death of Senator Pat McCarran, a Democrat.

Economic policies of the Eisenhower Administration and the steady moves of foreign currencies toward full convertibility were linked yesterday as indicating a trend toward less government control of individual lives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The executive director of the National Parking Association today accused Robert Moses, New York City Construction Coordinator, of fostering "a slick socialistic scheme to fool the public."

Dr. Eugenio Gudin, Finance Minister of Brazil, has just announced here the completion of arrangements for a one-year line of credit of $160 millions with the New York Federal Reserve Bank. Half the proceeds will be used to repay a temporary loan of the same type in anticipation of its maturity, the rest will provide the Brazilian Government with needed additional dollars.
HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 7 -- In an atmosphere of resignation and imperturbability, authority is shifting rapidly in this ancient city from French to Vietminh hands.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Nevada's Supreme Court today took under consideration whether an election should be held next month to fill the two-year unexpired term of the late Democratic Senator Pat McCarran.
BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for Senator from New Jersey, charged today that the State's Democratic administration was trying to do "a hatchet job" on him.

What might be called a "delicious detergent," which is still in the research stage, was reported yesterday by Dr Henry B. Hass, president of the Sugar Research Foundation, Inc., an industry-sponsored group.

NORTH REDINGTON BEACH, Fla., Oct. 7 -- Roy E. Larsen, president of Time, Inc., said today that the circulation of Sports Illustrated, new weekly magazine, was 500,000 and had justified "a year of hard work planning America's first all-sports weekly."
Marian Anderson has been signed for the coming season at the Metropolitan Opera House. She will be the first Negro to sing with the company since the theatre was opened in 1883.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- A Vassar College senior was injured fatally at 4 P.M. today, in a head-on collision between two automobiles on the Taconic State Parkway near here. A man riding in the other car also suffered fatal injuries, and nine other persons were hurt.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 7 -- Republicans are grim and Democrats are pinching themselves in amazement in Oregon today.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The National Assembly listened without much emotion apparent as Premier Pierre Mendes-France addressed it today in defense of the accords reached in London to arm West Germany within the North Atlantic Treaty and an enlarged Brussels treaty.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 7 -- Radioactive albumin was tested here today as a tracer to help doctors learn more about blood circulation in cases requiring surgery or special drug treatment.
Another strand in the golden thread of New York tradition was severed yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 points off to 4 points up yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- The executive committee of the Philadelphia Orchestra Association accepted late today an offer by the American Federation of Musicians, A.F.L., to resume contract negotiations. The breakdown of talks had led to cancellation of the opening two concerts of the 1954-55 season.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 7 -- Turkey convicted 131 men and women today on charges of organizing an underground Communist party to try to overthrow the Government.

Time is running out for qualifying yourself to vote in the election Nov. 2. If you are at all interested in choosing the men who will govern your State of New York, who will make your laws in Albany, who will sit for you in the House of Representatives in Washington, who will sit in judgment in your courts, then you will want to register today or tomorrow.

The increase in the references to pacifists and pacifism, especially in dispatches about political developments in Western Europe, is noteworthy. It is, however, evident that the terms are employed to designate a considerable variety of viewpoints and programs.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Astrid Varnay. Ramort Vinay and Luben Vichey soloists, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; "Faust," City Center, 8:15; "Lucia di Lammermoor," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Beverly Baker Fleitz of Belmont Shores, Calif., gained the fourth round of the Pan-American tennis tournament today by defeating Mrs. Barbara Scofield Davidson of Milwaukee, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

Trapped on the top floor of a Harlem tenement after he had wounded a policeman, a 47-year-old ex-convict engaged scores of policemen yesterday in a ninety-minute pistol battle before he was killed in a concentrated burst of shots.
PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The forty-first International Automobile Show opened here today in an atmosphere relatively novel for French manufacturers: the element of competition.

Republic Aviation Corporation announced yesterday that it would begin rehiring many of the 7,000 employes it had laid off in the last six weeks. About 1,000 are expected to be back on the job by Nov. 30 as the company resumes full production schedules.
A general committee has been formed to further plans for the fifth annual Fall Frolic dinner dance for the benefit of the Hemophilia Foundation, Inc.

TRIESTE, Oct. 7 -- The evacuation of Trieste by Allied forces began shortly after dawn today with the departure of twelve United States Army trucks for Leghorn. They carried only thirty men, taking instead the large quantities of supplies needed to expand the facilities in Leghorn to accommodate most of the United States troops from Trieste.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Representative Prince H. Preston Jr., Democrat of Georgia, was described to Senate investigators today as a hidden stockholder in a company that had netted $143,000 on an initial investment of $7,000 in a Government-insured housing project.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and its subsidiaries achieved the second highest sales in its ninety-six-year history with a total of $340,316,153 for the fiscal year ended July 31. Earnings were $102,464 less than the year before.
A spiritual basis for secular life was urged in Yom Kippur sermons here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Grain futures again displayed an undercurrent of strength today with the feed cereals especially strong at times.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 7 (UP) -- A former Marine whose life story was told to a nation-wide television audience last night said today he had unknowingly refused an after-program telephone call from President Eisenhower.
WESTBURY, L.I. Oct. 7 -- The Mineola Fair and Industrial Exposition, featuring exhibits ranging from goats to jet aircraft, will open at Roosevelt Raceway here Saturday for nine days.

Rums of Puerto Rico, an agency of the Puerto Rican Government, is planning to spend $300,000 between now and Christmas, which is the peak of the year for sales of rum, to promote the product as an all-around drink.
George Gainford, manager of Ray (Sugar) Robinson, said yesterday the former world welterweight and middleweight champion was considering a return to the ring.
"Falstaff" at the City Center last evening turned out to be one of the best productions yet seen in the New York City Opera Company's fall season.
WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 7 -- Adlai E. Stevenson tonight urged the voters of Kansas to emulate Maine and loosen the grip of Republican control of the state in the November elections.
Topcoat weather hit the city in earnest yesterday. The temperature dropped to 38.4 degrees at 6:30 A.M., setting a new record for the date. The previous low was 38.6 set in 1935.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 7 -- Ground was broken here today by the Army Engineers, and officials of the city and Shelby County for a new marine cargo terminal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Except for a few hours of excitement the usual national conventions of the major political parties in this country are given over to long and boring periods, the product of loose and archaic rules. And when these gatherings furnish a daily measure of drama it is in consequence of a party conflict which often inflicts lasting wounds and weakens the convention ticket on Election Day.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, said today the battle for control of Congress Nov. 2 was "nip and tuck" with most of the major blows yet to be struck.

She went away, and the date happened to coincide with the time the bills were so long overdue they could be ignored no longer. Her desk was piled high with them, and some were peremptory in tone. Before she left she had set up a prohibition against touching anything upon the desk, in particular the bills.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 602 pints of blood Wednesday. Included were 167 pints taken at Fort Monmouth, N.J., on the final day of a three-day, 437-pint collection; 135 pints given at Mitchel Air Force Base, Garden City, L.I., and 119 taken at the Woodbourne (N.Y.) Correction Institution.

The H.K. Porter Company, Inc., yesterday took control of the Laclede Christy Company without a proxy fight. Laclede Christy makes refractory products and Porter, in addition to producing a wide line of industrial rubber goods, also makes fire brick.

As was to be expected, the Soviets have launched an immediate diplomatic and propaganda campaign against the London agreements. The opening shot was fired by no less a Soviet spokesman than Foreign Minister Molotov, who hurried to East Berlin and from the appropriate stage of its Opera House delivered an oration, with threats and promises mingled, in which he called on the West to abandon the Act of London.
DENVER, Oct. 7 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower chalked up two firsts today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon Johnson, Democrat of Texas, told oil and gas operators here that Congressional action would be needed to solve problems raised by the Supreme Court decision in the Phillips Petroleum case.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Muhammad Zafrulla Khan is usually a quiet man. After being elected a justice to the International Court of Justice today he was ebullient.

An American Federation of Labor union was found guilty of "raiding" yesterday in the first arbitration case to arise out of the new peace pact between the Federation and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

LIKE the moor hen and the passenger pigeon, the National Sportsmen's Show has passed into limbo. Most hunters and fishermen who have been show visitors in recent years will breathe an irreverent "Amen" upon hearing this news.

MONTREAL, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard, the greatest goal scorer in the history of the National Hockey League, figured in four tallies tonight as the Montreal Canadiens downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -2, before 14,548 fans in the season's opening game at the Forum.

E. Victor Seixas of Philadelphia, beaten in both his singles matches in the Davis Cup challenge round at Melbourne last December when the Americans lost to the Australians, 3 -- 2, again was selected yesterday to represent the United States in its quest for the world's most coveted tennis trophy.

ALBANY, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A total of 3,385 physically and mentally handicapped persons in the state were rehabilitated for suitable employment in the year to June 30, the Department of Education reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- The Army plans to double milk rations at many of its posts in an effort to ease the Government's surplus butter problem, Department of Agriculture officials reported today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 7 -- The election, of Mohammed Zafrulla Khan to the International Court of Justice was the climax to seven years of attacks upon him as a member of a minority Moslem sect by a group of religious extremists.
DENVER, Oct. 7 -- President Eisenhower is playing "a correct role" in the Congressional election campaign by refusing to barnstorm the country, Vice President Richard M. Nixon asserted today.
THE twenty-ninth annual exhibition of work by artists associated with the gallery has opened at the Downtown.
Averell Harriman and the other candidates on the Democratic-Liberal state ticket were endorsed unanimously yesterday by the Political Nonpartisan Committee of the State Federation of Labor.
Future prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Cocoa, coffee, wool, copper, hides and lead declined, while potatoes, rubber and zinc moved into higher territory.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Arnold Johnson of Chicago said today he would pay the New York Yankees a "reasonable amount" for their Kansas City territory if he is able to buy the Philadelphia Athletics and shift the club to the Midwestern city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 721,883 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,668 cars, or 1.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 90,651 cars, or 11.2 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 130,037 cars, or 15.3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

MIAMI, Oct. 7 (UP) -- A hurricane in the southern Caribbean churned toward the northwest tonight, aiming 115-mile-an-hour wind at the Yucatan "slot" on a course that might hit the Texas-Louisiana coast. The Yucatan channel is between Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula and Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee said today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon had voted in ten cases against positions later taken by President Eisenhower in the 1952 campaign.

Stocks ran into heavy going in yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Although the steels and some of the aircrafts continued to push ahead and the rails broke a little better than even, more issues fell than rose and The New York Times combined average fell almost a point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today that it had formally approved but had not signed a contract by which the Dixon-Yates power groups would supply energy to the Tennessee Valley Authority.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The mystery of the missing paragraph put United States-Yugoslav relations through a jittery hour this morning.

May I express through your columns the hope that the Board of Estimate will give attention to the suggestion of the Citizens Union concerning plans of the Park Department to build recreational centers to combat delinquency.

YONKERS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Billy Haughton drove home two horses at Yonkers Raceway tonight to equal the national record of 129 harness racing winners for one year. He scored with Quick Chief and Bluett Hanover.

In reply to a protest by the head of the American Veterans of World War II against the "desecration" of Veterans Day, Nov. 11, by a political demonstration in support of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Rabbi Benjamin Schultz said yesterday that the rally would be nonpolitical.

The need for counseling young women to plan and prepare for long-term earning is stressed in a recently published study made by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 -- "The dragon of fear has been slain" and the motion-picture business is moving forward again with renewed "self-confidence," Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $544,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The significance of Wendell L. Willkie's one-world concept has been emphasized by the decade since his death, Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Freedom House and the Willkie Memorial Building, said yesterday. His statement marked the tenth anniversary of the death of the 1940 Republican Presidential nominee,
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that it has not been asked to buy any surplus butter under a farm price support program since Sept. 17.

HARTFORD, Oct. 7 -- Connecticut is attacking the problem of mental illness by emphasizing a Program of prevention and rehabilitation, Gov. John Lodge told the Northeast Conference of State MentalHealthAuthorities today.
By the calendar, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be 70 years old next Monday. But by any other reckoning, her pace would be that of living at seventy miles an hour and up.

The administrative offices of the National Council of the Boy Scouts of America will be moved today from 2 Park Avenue to the organization's new two-story building in North Brunswick Township, N.J. The site is about two miles southeast of New Brunswick.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 7 -- The Democrats of the Seventh Congressional District say they are determined to give the Republicans "the surprise of their political lives" next month. The Democrats predict they will elect a Representative in what is normally a banner Republican area.

Lou Little, whose Columbia football team has lost its first two games, sat quietly at a luncheon table in the school's John Jay Hall yesterday, listening to an amplified telephone talk from New Haven by Jordan Olivar, coach of a twice victorious Yale eleven.

A block of 130,410 shares of capital stock of Southern New England Telephone Company was placed on the market yesterda by Blyth Co., Inc., at $38 a share, in connection with a subscription rights transaction related to the telephone company's current offering of 488,888 new shares of stock to company stockholders.
MADRID, Oct. 7 (Reuters) -- More than 200 Jews of many nationalities gathered today in Madrid's tiny basement synagogue to take part in Yom Kippur (Day of Atonement) ceremonies.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Four Watertown High School students emerged today as the nonpolitical culprits in the tomato attack on Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for Governor, at a rally here Tuesday night.

Norman Spears, football prognosticator, will be featured in a weekly film series to be presented over Channel 4 beginning tomorrow from 1:30 to 1:45 P.M. Each Saturday he will evaluate college players and teams and predict the outcome of games to be played that afternoon.
J. Raymond McGovern, Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, assailed Averell Harriman yesterday as "the high tax candidate through whom Tammany wants to get the key to the state treasury."
Another traffic bottleneck on the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive will end today when the Ninety-sixth Street overpass goes into service.

Directors of the National State Bank of Newark, N.J., recommended to stockholders yesterday that the authorized stock be increased to 125,000 shares from 20,000 and the par value be reduced to $25 from $100. W. Paul Stillman, president, said a special meeting of stockholders had been called for Oct. 19, to act on the propbsal.

The first trans-Atlantic yacht race since 1935 became definite yesterday at a meeting of the New York Yacht Club. The New York club agreed to act as co-sponsor with the Royal Swedish Yacht Club and the Royal Yacht Club of Gothenburg for a thrash to Sweden next summer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Employment remained stable in September for the third successive month, the Government announced today.

A set of nine English tapestries, woven from designs by the great Renaissance painter Raphael, were dedicated yesterday at the New York Cathedral (St. John The Divine). The tapestries, which depict the "Acts of the Apostles," were a recent gift of Mrs. Louis S. Bruguiere of Washington and Newport, R.I.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- British Railways, operator of the nationalized railroad system, placed an embargo today on shipment of goods to the port of London as the dockworkers' strike widened still further.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids of banking houses yesterday for the purchase of issues of the Authority's temporary loan notes totaling $23,828,000 dated Nov. 1, 1954, and maturing on May 2, 1955.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Congress, which in recent years has voted down several bills to increase its own pay lest it bring down the wrath of the voters back home, received a friendly nudge today from an unexpected quarter -- the United States Civil Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Owen Lattimore was reindicted by a Federal grand jury today on two counts charging perjury.

VIENNA, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Bakir Farchudinov of Russia equaled the world record by hoisting a total of 315 kilograms (693 pounds) tonight to win the bantamweight title as the 1954 world weightlifting championships got under way.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 7 -- The battle for real freedom of the press in the Americas is still far from won, according to reports presented at the tenth annual meeting of the Inter American Press Association here.

TORONTO, Oct. 7 -- Religious life in the United States stands on the threshold of a "new Reformation," Dr. Elton True-blood, chief of the Religious Information Service of the United States Information Agency, said here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (AP) -Boardwalk Billy Smith, 173 1/2 pounds, scored a major upset tonight by knocking out Harold Johnson, 174, Philadelphia, No. 1 light heavyweight title contender, in 1:22 of the second round of a scheduled ten-round bout at the Arena.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The stock markets here were less cheerful though still firm today. A little selling, caused by the London dock strike, was well absorbed and rises outnumbered falls.

BINGHAMTON, Oct. 8 -- The neighborly practice of offering lifts to persons waiting for buses at street corners was frowned upon officially today by the Binghamton Center Labor Union of the American Federation of Labor, which asked its 10,000 members to stop it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Persons who work at the Federal Communications Commission are under notice not to commit such "ill-considered acts" as getting drunk in public or attending "loud or disorderly parties."
DENVER, Oct. 8--President Eisenhower called upon American voters of all political faiths tonight to give him a Republican Congress to prevent "a cold war of partisan politics" in Washington.
Passers-by who might have assumed that the United States Rubber Building at 1230 Avenue of the Americas was being demolished from the bottom up learned yesterday that this was not the case.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
A tiny airplane that flew the Atlantic to Europe nearly two months ago without official sanction landed in New York yesterday with its wings clipped.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- United States policy in the Far East still is to try to prevent a new war there, Administration authorities said today.

Yale will be strengthened by three shifts when it faces the Columbia eleven at Baker Field today. The Lions, who lack depth this season, will count on the same group that has lost to Princeton and Brown.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Mrs. James Dorment of Montclair and Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won low gross honors by a stroke in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association scotch foursome tournament at Essex County today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 8 -The difficulties affecting Federal low-rent housing projects in this city, as the result of which more than 20 per cent of the apartments already are or soon will be empty, can be cured within a matter of months, the Bridgeport Housing Authority was informed tonight.

Trading was dull and featureless in most of the New York commodity futures markets yesterday. Dealers evened holdings for the week-end. Prices drifted irregularly, with rubber, burlap, wool, copper, cottonseed oil and soybean oil mixed; potatoes, sugar, hides and zinc lower, and cocoa, coffee and lead higher.
CLINTON, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Pointers took four of six places in the open derby and puppy stakes that opened the three-day fall program of the North Jersey Field Trial Club today.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge of Georgia declared here today that the Supreme Court overstepped its constitutional bounds in ruling against public school segregation. He added that it had set itself up "as a glorified board of education."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A public investigation of the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract with the Atomic Energy Commission was put off today until after the November elections.
OTTAWA, Oct. 8 -- The United States informed members of the Colombo plan today that it would increase its economic aid to Asia to try to save it from communism.
Perhaps a resident of a neighboring state may express opinions concerning the coming elections in New Jersey and New York.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Holders of thirty-one tickets reaped a harvest of $1,393.80 for each $2 on the daily double at Suffolk Downs today after Our Town won the opening race for a $202.80 mutuel and Djuna accounted for a $24.20 pay-off in the second event.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- After negotiations lasting ten months, the British Transport Commission reached agreement today with three unions granting wage increases to approximately 400,000 employes of nationalized railroads.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The index of average primary market prices declined 0.1 to 109.6 (1947-49=100) over the week ended Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. A decline in average prices of farm products and foods was partly offset by a fractional increase in average prices of industrial materials.

A surge of buying by insurance companies and pension funds yesterday broke up the congestion of inventories of new high grade public utility and railroad bonds that has been piling up on the hands of underwriting syndicates over the last fortnight.

HARTFORD, Oct. 8 -- Action on a resolution urging increased state appropriations for the early treatment of mental illness and research into its causes was deferred today at a meeting of mental health officials from ten Northeastern states.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Oct. 8 -- Officials here commented bitterly today on reports the United State's had suggested that Nationalist China cease attacks on the mainland.
Each year I hopefully believe some smart politician will drop appeals for the "farmer" vote, the "labor" vote, the "private and public power" groups, etc., in favor of the tremendous consumer group.

I read with interest the recent article about the rise in one-way traffic accidents by Joseph C. Ingraham. I do not believe the anomaly puzzling Traffic Commissioner Wiley and his experts is puzzling to many motorists driving on these avenues.

TRIESTE, Oct. 8 -- Triestines finally have got around to examining closely the accord under which the administration of their territory is formally turned over to Italy and Yugoslavia. On the whole they find it good, or at least as good as could be expected under the circumstances.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short term borrowing costs are showing signs of stability.

The appointment of George C. Wildermuth as chairman of the $50,000 drive for the Naval Branch Young Men's Christian Association was announced yesterday. Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey has been named honorary chairman.

I have just returned from another trip to Europe. I happened to be in Germany when the French Assembly rejected E.D.C. Although the effects seem to have been overcome with the signing of the Nine-Power London pact, that in itself is merely a "diplomatic achievement," as the President has exclaimed.
MONTREAL, Oct. 8 -- Montreal's police chief was discharged and fined today following a vice investigation. In addition, heavy fines were levied against seventeen policemen.
New York gave a party last night for delegates attending the 1954 session of the United Nations General Assembly.
The Bay Ridge Magistrate's Court was the scene of legal procedure of gargantuan proportions yesterday. It was also the scene of considerable bedlam.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 8 (UP) -- More than a million orders for home games of a major league baseball team that does not yet exist have poured in here and thousands more were arriving today.

Generalizations about national traits are so often tinged with personal bias that people grow wary of them. But generalizations based on scrupulous research are another matter; they are always illuminating, always welcome. In 100 pages of closely printed type The Literary Supplement of The Times of London has courageously undertaken to define the national essence of our literature.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Penn will try to untangle its new multiple offense tomorrow when the Quakers invade Palmer Stadium to meet Princeton in the forty-sixth renewal of their rivalry.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Dallas defeated Meadow Brook, 10 -- 9, and Old Westbury topped Westbury, 5 -- 4, in the semi-final matches of the sixteen-goal Autumn Plate polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -The chances of direct Government action to strengthen producer prices of eggs and poultry appeared slim tonight after an industry advisory committee recommended against it.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (UP) -- The hope of Roy Mack to keep the Athletics in Philadelphia was dealt a jolt tonight when John McShain said he was not interested in buying into the club.

"Faust" returned to the City Center last night. It was a refurbished, well-scrubbed "Faust," restaged by Vladimir Rosing (who was responsible for the original New York City Opera production). Since the City Center has been Faustless for two years, and since a new Mephistopheles graced the revival, more than a normal amount of interest attached itself to the occasion.

TRIESTE, Oct. 8 -- The Boundary Commission to draw the new frontier between the two zones met today at Albaro Vescova, one of the largest villages in the area to be handed over to Yugoslav control. The commission consists of British, United States and Yugoslav officers. Yesterday's slight setback -- when the Yugoslavs objected to the presence of Italian officials on the commission -- has been resolved by appointing two Italians as observers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Saturday, Oct. 9 (AP) -- United Nations employes, including 1,556 Americans, were told today to put loyalty to the United Nations above loyalty to their own countries. They were warned at the same time to steer clear of revolutionary activity aimed at the forcible overthrow of any government -- and even of "active criticism of a government."
Retailers plan to go to the Federal Trade Commission to find out whether selective enforcement of fair trade prices is an unfair trade practice.
The cotton futures market moved 8 points higher to 13 points lower yesterday, with a moderate volume of business.

A new ciborium will be used at 10 A.M. tomorrow at a pontifical mass of thanksgiving at St. Patrick's Cathedral in celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of its dedication. A ciborium is used to hold consecrated eucharistic wafers distributed to Roman Catholics receiving holy communion.
There's a 71-year-old Staten Islander, a retired staff sergeant, who for forty-nine years was nagged by a small gap in his memory.

Fordham Prep's football team registered its second triumph in two starts yesterday by turning back James Monroe High, 25 to 6, at Fordham Field, the Bronx. It was Monroe's first setback in two games, the other contest ending in a tie.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Oct. 8 -- The Republican party in Florida's west coast tourist area, which narrowly missed victory in two Congressional races in 1952, is making a vigorous campaign to "close the gap" on Nov. 2.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 8 -- The United Nations Command "postponed" today further payment to Korean employes of United States forces on the peninsula as a result of the South Korean Government's refusal to advance won, the nation's currency.

The Governor-General of Canada, the Rt. Hon. Vincent Massey, has asked the makers of House of Lords cigars to stop using the advertising phrase "by appointment to His Excellency the governor-general."
The Armstrong Cork Company, a major producer of hard-surface floor coverings, is going into the rug business.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration today ordered airlines that fly certain DC-6 airplanes to make a special check of emergency exit hinges.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Grandslam home runs by Norm Zauchin and Pete Daley paced the Louisville Colonels of the American Association to a 14-9 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs of the International League tonight and a lead of three games to two in the four-out-of-seven little world series.
A $15,000,000 financing program has been undertaken by the Argus Corporation, Ltd., Canada, to retire $5,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent notes due in 1957, and for investments and other purposes.

Despite concentrated get-out- the-vote drives, registration in this city slumped again yesterday, the fifth day. Only 400,873 men and women qualified for the election on Nov. 2, and with only today left to enroll, the pace this year was 8 per cent below that of 1950, the last comparable year when a state election took place.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The American Geographical Society paid tribute today to the conquerors of Mount Everest with the presentation at the United States Embassy here of the Cullum Geographical Medal for the team that climbed the Himalayan peak in 1953.

That the pier strike was unnecessary has now been made clearly evident from its settlement terms. The employers granted the 8 cents an hour increase for the past year which the union had demanded -- but they had said all along they were ready to pay it so as to equalize wages between New York and the other ports.
United States Government observers are studying the comprehensive picture of Communist China's economic situation given by Premier Chou En-lai recently.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, appointed James N. Juliana acting staff director of his Senate Investigations Subcommittee today after the subcommittee's three Democrats had declined at this time to approve Mr. Juliana for the post.

Events today: "Cenerentola" at 2:30 P.M. and "Tosca" at 8:15, New York City Opera Company, City Center; Young People's Concert, Philharmonic-Symphony, Town Hall, 3; Bessie Mayle, soprano, Town Hall, 5:30; Stan Kenton and his orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 and midnight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Week-end profit taking by longs in various grains and soybeans caused some easiness in the market early today. But the selling was well taken and prices rallied in all pits. Some of the early sellers turned buyers when the markets began to show firmness.
Two men, one armed, held up an employe of the American Direct Mail Company, Inc., at 421 Hudson Street yesterday and escaped with a $6,600 payroll, the police reported.
The postman will ring earlier at homes in three midtown Manhattan areas beginning Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A move by a House of Representatives subcommittee to draft a bill providing Federal aid to school construction was opposed by an Administration leader today. A similar Senate bill in the Eighty-third Congress met the same lack of support.

The Brittany Corporation, a Knott Hotel subsidiary, has sold the Brittany Hotel at 55 East Tenth Street and 787-789 Broadway to Herbert R. Weissberg, hotel operator and investor. The sale was made through L.V. Hoffman Co. as brokers. Irwin Berliner of Olvany, Eisner Donnelly was attorney for the seller and Harold S. Budner of Budner Budner acted for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Officials of the State Department and Foreign Operations Administration professed bewilderment today at a proposal in Ottawa by Mr. Stassen to help finance the Colombo plan out of "savings" resulting from the ending of the Indochinese war.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Representative Charles R. Howell declared here tonight that the Eisenhower Administration had suffered serious foreign policy reverses during the last year because of its "failure to combine patience with common sense."

The Indiana Toll Road Commission announced yesterday plans to market $178,000,000 of Indiana Turnpike revenue bonds under the management of the investment banking house of Lehman Brothers A.J. Wedeking, executive director of the Commission, said the projected borrowing had been reduced from $225,000,000 because of a decision to reduce the length of the road by about twenty miles at the Indianapolis end.

Directors of Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad yesterday authorized officers, in cooperation with the chairmen of the preferred and common stockholder committees, to formulate a definitive plan for recapitalizing the company. Officers were also directed to submit the completed plan at its next meeting on Nov. 4.

Some years have passed since New York City gave the delegates of the United Nations a party. One such occasion had an unharmonious note in it when the Russian delegation took umbrage at something that was said and walked out. Last night's party was planned with the thought of happier auspices.
ROME, Oct. 8 -- The Senate approved tonight the Italian-Yugoslav understanding on Trieste, confirming its confidence in Premier Mario Scelba's Government. The vote was 129 to 89.
Canned baked beans may well come to the aid of the harried home cook for Saturday night supper.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 8--India and Ceylon began talks today to try to evolve a formula governing the treatment of persons of Indian origin in Ceylon.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's campaign address at Denver, Colo., last night as recorded by The New York Times.
Of the ranking college football teams, Oklahoma, Purdue, Duke, Wisconsin and Ohio State are looking for the stiffest fights today.
A warning that diminishing water supplies pose a serious threat to the United States was given last night by Fairfield Osborn, president of the Conservation Foundation.

MIAMI, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Miami's Hurricanes, snapping to life in the nick of time, sped 66 yards to a last-period touchdown tonight to rack up a hard-earned 26-20 victory over a pass-crazy Holy Cross football team.

Selva Sons, Inc., have leased about 20,000 square feet of space in the building at 195 Front Street in Brooklyn from the Drispin Realty Company. The lease was negotiated through the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.
Warmer autumn weather is due in New York today after the dip of the last few days. The forecaster predicts some cloudiness with afternoon mercury readings in the sixties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- John E. Peurifoy, former United States Ambassador to Guatemala, reported today that Kremlin-controlled Communists still posed "a very real menace" to Latin America despite their loss of Guatemala.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 8 -- West German experts are considering the feasibility of seeking foreign workers to replace the 500,000 men to be called for military service.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 8 (UP) -- N. Araujo Jorge, prosecuting attorney, filed indictments today against Benjamin Vargas, younger brother of the late President Getulio Vargas, and seven others accused of complicity in the killing of an Air Force major during an attempt to assassinate an anti-government newspaper editor.

The twelfth annual open-air religious service under the auspices of the Union of the Holy Name Society in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is scheduled for 3 P.M. tomorrow at the Polo Grounds.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- United States aviation has been flying according to the nautical mile for one week now, without difficulty.

Lafayette High, which has not lost a football game in twenty-five starts during the past three seasons, begins the defense of its mythical Public Schools Athletic League crown today against New Utrecht.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The Government acknowledged tonight that it had seriously underestimated the number of civil serants who required screening for security purposes.

It was Mexico's turn this week to invade the fashion world of New York. Henri de Chatillon, well-known designer in Mexico City, Paris and New York, brought a collection of his custom-made designs to the Gotham Hotel, where he is stopping.
TORONTO, Oct. 8 -- The Toronto metropolitan area of 1,200,000 persons will get its first natural gas about Nov. 1 by way of a 100-mile pipeline from the Niagara frontier.

"New York is probably the noisiest city in the world." That statement was just made by a distinguished visitor to our shores, Herbert Morrison, currently deputy leader of the British Labor party in Parliament and formerly British Foreign Secretary in the Clement Attlee Government.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 8--Britain has explained to the United States "in words of one syllable" that there will be no further lowering of British trade barriers until American trade practices toward the United Kingdom improve, Chancellor of the Exchequer R.A. Butler declared today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart said today that "pressure" had been put on him not to investigate $60,000 in fees he said had been paid to two Washington men for help in getting Government-insured loans on housing projects.
The Zim-Israel America Line will begin its new service to New York next September with the liner Theodor Herzl, which was launched recently in Germany.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Oct. 8 (UP) -- A leader of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference warned today that South American and African farmers might "go Communist" unless they got the right help and leadership.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 8 -- Finance Minister Fritz Schaeffer told the Central Council of Jews in Germany today that the Government was ready for a speedy and satisfactory settlement of claims under last year's restitution act.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democratic candidate for State Attorney General, went barnstorming in the Bronx last night, urging residents to register for the elections and to elect his party's ticket.
DENVER, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower decided today to make another pre-election speech, the second added to his campaign program in two days. The dates and places are still to be announced.

TORONTO, Oct. 8 -- The nineteenth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America conferred sweeping new powers today on its president. But it turned down efforts to strengthen its fifteen-member executive board.

All of us will wish to join in congratulation to the Metropolitan Opera upon its having placed under contract one of the greatest singers of our generation, Marian Anderson. That she has fulfilled a lifelong ambition is not nearly so important as the fact that we will have an opportunity to hear her in still another medium.
Robert Fryer, Lawrence Carr and Harry Rigby have banded together to produce "Stars in a Person's Backyard," a first play by Jay Presson, Texas novelist.

REOPENING for the new season in more spacious quarters, at 29 East sixty-fifth Street, the Edwin Hewitt Gallery presents a group show of paintings whose clear color and narrative emphasis proclaim their allegiance to Magic Realism.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Ronnie Clinkscale, running 60 and 58 yards the first two times he carried the ball, led Texas Christian University to a 20-7 upset victory over Southern California tonight.
That familiar work-saving principle of use and discard, which has made the paper towel a success, has been unexpectedly applied to electric ranges.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8 -- Integrated classes of white and Negro pupils began in the public schools here a month ago yesterday. And the elementary school with by far the highest percentage of Negro children has not had a single one of the disturbances that have affected only twenty-five of the city's 170 public schools since a week ago yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- In conversation with foreign correspondents, Andrei A. Gromyko re-emphasized last night that the Soviet Union no longer was insisting that an undertaking not to use atomic weapons should be the first step in international disarmament.
Averell Harriman called yesterday for a huge protest vote against the "callous indifference" for the Dewey Administration to the needs and problems of New York City residents.
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin and two generals testified in private today in the inquiry into the leakage of French defense secrets.

This morning, in New York, it is already Saturday night in Vietnam, largest state in Indochina. And tonight, in Indochina, Hanoi, another great traditional Asian city, has gone behind the Iron-Bamboo Curtain. The last representative of the free Vietnamese and the last official of the French who have spilled their blood for that freedom will have been withdrawn to a still smaller perimeter.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The United Packinghouse Workers, C.I.O., today announced the signing of a new contract giving wage increases and other benefits to some 10,000 workers in eight Wilson Co. meat packing plants.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 8 -Some of the preferences enjoyed by war veterans have become a "stumbling block" to efficient Federal Civil Service, participants in the sixth American Assembly agreed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (AP) -Terry Moore is on his way out as manager of the Philadelphia Phillies and Frank (Lefty) O'Doul, former National League batting champion and a Pacific Coast League manager, may succeed him, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Malcolm MacDonald, British Commissioner General for Southeast Asia, declared today that the West could defeat communism there only by responding to the Asians' demand for national liberty and economic progress.

Total paint sales during the first seven months of this year dropped 4 per cent compared with the corresponding period of last year, according to the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, Washington, D.C.
PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The recent opening of Universite, specialty shop for de luxe ready-to-wear, has put Jacques Fath chic within the means of many Parisian women who up to now could only dream of it.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The insurance industry was urged today to prepare to finance the building of industrial plants making use of atomic power. The urging came from Charles M. White of Cleveland, president of Republic Steel Corporation, in an address before the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Life Convention.
Five Manhattan properties have been sold for the estates of Marx and Moses Ottinger through Walter Samuels as agents.

Three New Yorkers shared the benefits of this year's Marian Anderson Scholarship Fund competitions, it was announced yesterday. Miriam Burton, soprano, who is understudy for Mae Barnes in "By the Beautiful Sea," won the first prize of $1,000. Reri Grist, soprano, and Lee Cass, baritone, in a tie for second prize, received $500 each.

Joseph Ritter, 22 years old, of 1396 Remsen Avenue, Brooklyn, was arraigned in Queens Felony Court, Ridgewood, yesterday on a robbery charge in the attempted hold-up of a Laurelton bank. He was held in $50,000 bail.

NEWARK, Oct. 8 -- Clifford P. Case asserted today that the Eisenhower Administration, with the support of a Republican Congress, could meet the challenge of communism at home and abroad better than the Democratic party.
Four awards from three organizations and a university went to Mayor Wagner yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- In a tradition-upsetting decree the Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that, as of Jan. 1, it would provide no more annual or trip passes for officials and employes of other railroads traveling on business.
WASHINGTON, Oct 8 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today estimated this year's Government-restricted cotton crop at 12,511,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight.

PARIS, Saturday, Oct. 9 -- Facing strong opposition to the unconditional endorsement of his policy on West German armament that he sought, Premier Mendes-France has made the issue one of confidence in his Government.

A House Maritime subcommittee, headed by Representative John H. Ray, Republican of Staten Island, completed its investigation of conditions in New York shipyards yesterday after taking testimony from spokesmen for small facilities in Brooklyn.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Debate on Western and Soviet plans for disarmament and the control of atomic energy will start Monday morning in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

The Storer Broadcasting Company will purchase for $330,000 all of the capital stock of WJW, Inc., an ABC 5,000-watt outlet in Cleveland, according to a joint announcement yesterday by William O'Neil, president of WJW, Inc., and George B. Storer, president of Storer Broadcasting.

The Isbrandtsen Company and the Department of Justice won a delay yesterday on a decision by a Federal Maritime Board examiner in behalf of the rate system under which shippers exclusively using conference lines pay less than other shippers.

Motion picture theatre owners on Forty-second Street agreed yesterday to consider adopting rules for self-guidance on lobby and marquee advertising displays. Acting on com plaints from clergymen and civic leaders, representatives of fourteen theatres conferred for two hours with their critics and License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey in his office at 137 Centre Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -Powerful backing developed today for a move to set up a special Federal agency to finance a $100,000,000,000 highway improvement program over the next ten years.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 483 pints of blood on Thursday. Included were 143 pints taken at the Railway Express Agency, 218 East Forty-fourth Street, and 111 pints at Mitchel Air Force Base, Garden City, L.I., on the third day of a three-day collection totaling 361 pints.
The Waterfront Commission acknowledged yesterday that it had not succeeded in establishing a pressure-free employment system in the Port of New York.

The Storer Broadcasting Company will purchase for $330,000 all of the capital stock of WJW, Inc., an ABC 5,000-watt outlet in Cleveland, according to a joint announcement yesterday by William O'Neil, president of WJW, Inc., and George B. Storer, president of Storer Broadcasting.

Acting on com plaints from clergymen and civic leaders, representatives of fourteen theatres conferred for two hours with their critics and License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey in his office at 137 Centre Street.

The Ninety-sixth Street overpass of the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive was officially opened to traffic at 10:22 A. M. yesterday. The opening of the roadway eliminated Tunnel Authority, and William J. Tracy and George V. McLaughlin, vice chairmen of the Authority, cut a ribbon to open the six-lane steel viaduct to traffic.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 -- A retired mail carrier and his wife, parents of ten, all college graduates, were hailed here tonight as the "Methodist Family of the Year" was announced.
TOKYO, Oct. 8 -- Japan is to embark next year on her first naval construction program since the end of the Pacific war.

A pair of rich races, the Futurity and the Manhattan Handicap, will be presented at Belmont Park today. The Futurity, one of the nation's most famous tests for 2-year-olds, will be worth $114,715 if its nine listed starters perform, while the Manhattan will carry a gross purse of $35,300, with ten competitors.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- The Consolidated Edison Company of New York will build a multimillion-dollar electric generating plant, with provision for possible conversion to the use of atomic power, on the banks of the Hudson River near Peekskill.
Senator Irving M. Ives called last night for an end to the use of hate and bigotry as an issue in the campaign for the Governorship.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -Powerful backing developed today for a move to set up a special Federal agency to finance a $100,000,000,000 highway improvement program over the next ten years.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 483 pints of blood on Thursday. Included were 143 pints taken at the Railway Express Agency, 218 East Forty-fourth Street, and 111 pints at Mitchel Air Force Base, Garden City, L.I., on the third day of a three-day collection totaling 361 pints.
