As a visitor to the United States from Edinburgh I have been privileged since my arrival six weeks ago to view many of the facets of the American scene at various angles. Many of the conclusions I have arrived at are necessarily of a tentative character, but there is one aspect which I have no reason to think will be influenced by any circumstances that may arise before the termination of my visit.

The Brooklyn Dodgers traded Ray Moore of their St. Paul American Association farm club to the Baltimore Orioles yesterday. In return, they received Vinicio Garcia, an undisclosed amount of cash and another player to be transferred by Dec. 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- The underdeveloped countries were invited today to harvest the benefits of a new United States law that would help them keep their peoples fed while they concentrated on industrializing their economies.
"Tunisia Today: Crisis in North Africa," by Leon Laitman, will be published Oct. 25 by Citadel Press. It is a study of social, economic and political conditions in Tunisia.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has reported to Senate investigators that it found bookkeeping methods and financial operations of the Mississippi Power and Light Company in conformance with Federal regulations.

KYOTO, Japan, Saturday, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Institute of Pacific Relations closed its two-week meeting yesterday with general agreement that Communist China should be admitted to the United Nations as a means of easing cold war tension in Asia.

HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 8 (AP) -- The football team of Huntsville High School is flying to Alaska for a game Oct. 22 but it won't be all play -- it's taking along three teachers to keep the players up with their classwork.

Cortland Equipment Lessors, Inc., a subsidiary of Safeway Stores, Inc., has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a new issue of $75,000,000 of debentures. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will head the underwriting. Cortland, which owns equipment used in Safeway food stores, will use proceeds to pay off debts to banks and to Safeway, and for working capital.

The seven New York metropolitan daily newspapers enlarged their gains in advertising linage in September. For the year through August, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures, they were ahead of last year by 0.18 per cent. For the nine months through September, yesterday's study discloses, the advance was 0.26 per cent.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 8 (AP) -- From picking cotton at 50 cents a hundred pounds to an $11,147.90 bonus for four days' work in the 1954 world series is the story of Jim (Dusty) Rhodes, an adopted favorite son of Montgomery.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 -- Hecht-Lancaster Productions is negotiating for three more television plays written by Paddy Chayefsky, author of the TV play "Marty," which the producing company is filming.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- America's "coddled youth huddling over television" was compared unfavorably with Russia's "amazing athletes" by Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Games Committee, who recently visited Russia.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 8 -- The Nevada Supreme Court ruled this morning that Gov. Charles H. Russell could not appoint a successor to the late Senator Pat McCarran for his entire unexpired term. It decreed that the voters in the Nov. 2 general election must choose a successor for the two-year period beginning Jan. 3.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 8--There were twenty-four entries for the start tonight of the New Rochelle Yacht Club's annual Stratford Shoal race, the last overnight event of the Long Island Sound season.
Federal legislation is being prepared that would prohibit "shows" of hynotism by entertainers or magicians, it was reported yesterday at the first meeting of the Academy of Psychosomatic Medicine.
TORONTO, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Connie Smythe announced his immediate retirement as general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs today.
Sales of Langendorf United Bakeries, Inc., in the fiscal year ended June 26 reached a new high, but earnings declined from the previous year.

The debate in the French National Assembly on the London accords is fateful. It has been a curious and exasperating feature of this whole great effort to reach a solution of European defense and integration that many of the French politicians do not seem to have grasped the consequences of failure.
Ronald E. Martin denied in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday that he was implicated in the $190,319 robbery of a Long Island bank on Aug. 18, 1953.

YONKERS, Oct. 8 (AP) -Prospectus, a 7-1 shot, owned by K.F. Lunman of Adams, N.Y., and driven by Stanley Dancer, won the $5,000 Junior free-for-all trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight when Betty Astra was disqualified after finishing first.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins today grabbed one of the Philadelphia Eagles' star defensive backs for the $100 waiver price because the Eagles overlooked a National Football League rule.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- The Army football team will meet Dartmouth at Michie Stadium tomorrow before a crowd expected to reach 25,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A oneman tank, about the size of a sports car, was patented this week by George L. Turner for the Clark Equipment Company, Buchanan, Mich.

CAIRO, Oct. 8 -- A senior Egyptian security official categorically denied tonight that the Government had taken any police action against the leader of the Moslem Brotherhood, a bitter critic of the ruling military junta.
HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Nine suspended policemen, seven of whom still face court trial, were cleared today of departmental charges related to gambling and prostitution and restored to duty.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Oct. 8 -- Adlai E. Stevenson today breezed through Oklahoma City. He left in his wake a crowd of smiling, cheering Democrats who appeared ready to order tickets for a Democratic inauguration ball in 1957.

The recent missions to the Soviet Union and Communist China by Clement R. Attlee, former Prime Minister, and other British Labor party leaders drew a sharp attack last night from George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor.

An innovation in football halftime entertainment will be presented tomorrow afternoon by the Du Mont television network. Between halves of the Giants-Redskins professional game, the National Symphony Orchestra will give a concert in Griffitth Stadium in Washington.

After five sessions the American Assembly, which meets at Arden House at Harriman, N.Y., has become a respected institution in the nation's political life. It has fulfilled the hopes of General Eisenhower, who organized it shortly before he left Columbia University to become commander of SHAPE, as a meeting place for representatives of a cross-section of American opinion where the tasks and problems confronting the nation could be discussed and clarified.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8 -- Yugoslav sources looked hopefully today toward wider commercial relations with Italy, particularly the establishment of improved communications.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 (AP) -Local 29 of the General Teamsters Union, A.F.L., key union in a forty-five-week-old strike against five department stores, today agreed to submit a proposed settlement, still to be worked out, to its members next week.

The Public Service Commission is expected to announce today approval of plans to relocate the main-line tracks of the New York Central Railroad at Batavia, N.Y., as part of the state's grade-crossing elimination program.

NOTHING like the peace and quiet of the countryside to bring out the muse for playwright Joseph Kramm. The winner of the Pulitzer Prize in 1952 for "The Shrike," Mr. Kramm has been toiling at his rural retreat outside of Middletown, N.Y., these recent weeks and, says a late bulletin, he may have two scripts ready for perusal by year's end.

THE gradual revelation of the stored richness of modern art at the Guggenheim Museum has now reached a stage entitled "Selection IV." Here are sixty-eight paintings and four pieces of sculpture by the chief instigators of the revolution in twentieth century art, the highly gifted anarchs who destroyed the prestige of academic art in a series of stunning blows.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 9 (UP) -- West Virginia, shaking off a bad case of jitters, sent its junior halfback, Bob Moss, over from the 7-yard line with the winning touchdown in the final period today to defeat George Washington, 13 -- 7, and open defense of its Southern Conference crown.

Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for the sixteenth annual White Elephant party for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association. The fete, a buffet dinner dance, will be held on the night bf Jan. 14 in the ballroom of the Ambassador.
DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Skip Thompson scored 27 points on four touchdowns and three extra points today to lead National Agricultural College to a 34-0 football victory over Brooklyn College.

SUSSEX, N.J. -- Sussex County is near enough to New York City for an easy day's outing, but it is a richly rural area with much scenic interest. More specifically, its dairy farms offer an excellent opportunity for city people, and particularly city children, to find out where the morning milk really comes from.
Sticky weather and the Jewish holidays were the factors that have most affected the ready-to-wear markets recently, according to resident buying offices.

THE free-standing fireplace set in the center of a room has a startlingly contemporary look. Yet the central hearth is one of the oldest traditions in home design. In the tents and tepees of ancient time, in the huts of the Middle Ages, in the castles of the pre-Gothic period, the fireplace -- rightfully important -- was placed in the middle of the main room.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared tonight that the real issue in the current election was whether Congress should be given "the proved leadership of the Democratic party" or should continue under "a divided, quarrelsome, squabbling Republican regime."

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 9 -- Duke's alert defenders ran Len Dawson, Purdue's sophomore passing sensation, out of the airlanes today, but Purdue struck back in a second half rally with the crunching runs of 204-pound Bill Murakowski to score twice and gain a 13-13 tie.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25 -- The United States is winding up a $17,000,000 claims settlement program involving Yugoslavia's repayment for seized and nationalized property of United States citizens.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9 -- A magazine distributor who handles three of every four publications reaching newsstands in central Ohio will spearhead a campaign against proposed legislation banning horror comic books when the matter comes before the City Council Monday.

THAT the United States began as a republic but has become a democracy is the favorite thesis of a certain minority group. This little treatise by a former president of Rochester University is perhaps the ablest attempt yet made to give the thesis a definite content, to explain precisely what it means, and to defend it in rational terms.

HENNIE STACPOLE is 43, and she is still entrancing in body as well as mind. She has an essentially contented nature, two nice children, beautiful clothes, a lot of Lowestoft, and a husband who is not only affectionate but almost incredibly well heeled.

HARTFORD, Oct. 9 -- Connecticut Democrats, who hold only one of six seats from this state in the United States House of Representatives, are hoping to pick up two or three more in the election on Nov. 2.
AMARILLO, Tex., Oct. 9 -- Here in Amarillo is a tax supported public school that this week observed its third anniversary of the elimination of racial segregation.

CALHOUN, Tenn., Oct. 9 -- The Bowaters Southern Paper Corporation dedicated its $60,000,000 newsprint mill here today in ceremonies attended by more than 450 newspaper publishers, paper industry representatives, state officials and other persons.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 9 (UP) -- Led by a tackle who popped into enemy backs before they could get started, Wake Forest battled heavily favored Maryland to a 13-to-13 tie today before 10,000 fans.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 9 (AP) -- James (Dusty) Rhodes, the New York Giants' outfielder whose slugging helped beat Cleveland in the 1954 world series was "king for a day" in his adopted home town today.

CARDENAS, Cuba -- The City of Key West, a trim, white converted L.S.M. (landing ship medium) last week inaugurated a daytime car-ferry service between Key West; Fla., and this port city 100 miles east of Havana on the north coast of Cuba.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 9 -- This week's Trieste settlement has again proved the merit of patient diplomatic negotiations as opposed to some of the swashbuckling polemics and troop movements of the past. It has also raised questions affecting the future of the whole Mediterranean area.

NOT very long ago Frank Leahy sadly remarked that football had become so complicated that only a vigorous young coach could, withstand the game's ever-increasing pressures and intricacies. So Leahy, a doddering old man of 45, yielded his coaching portfolio at Notre Dame to the sprightly infant protege, Terry Brennan, age 26.
RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Oct. 9 -- The town that Thomas Edison made famous is now trying to change its name in honor of "the Wizard of Menlo Park."

WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Tommy Egan and Bill McKenna -- Brandeis University's ace passing combination -- led the Judges to an easy 20-0 victory over Bates today before 3,000 fans at Gordon Field.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- Deputy Premier V.M. Molotov's restatement of Soviet policy in Europe set the tone of newspaper comment here this week on the decisions of the nine-power conference and the French Assembly's debate on the London plan for rearming West Germany.

Nance confronts the huge task he has taken on in attempting to restore the business fortunes of those proud names -- Studebaker and Packard -- with a confidence that seems to argue that he isn't impressed with its magnitude. WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The independent voter is cock of the walk out around the hustings today, just as he has been in many elections past. And on how he makes up his mind between now and Election Day -- if, in fact, he has not already made it up -- rests the question of which party will control one or both houses of Congress for the next two years.

FOR a number of years Mrs. Roosevelt has answered the questions of readers, first for The Ladies' Home Journal and now for McCall's. DALLAS, Oct. 9 -- Although drought and declining prices have cut into farm-ranch income in Texas so far this year, industrial activity has been brisk enough to offset the loss, the University of Texas Bureau of Business Research has reported.

On Oct. 10, 1911, Dr. Sun Yat-sen set in motion the Chinese democratic revolution that changed the face of Asia. OF all the catastrophes common to childhood, a lost pet is one of the most grievous. Around this situation, all too common, James Tippett has written an easy story for beginning readers. ON Tuesday, London's Festival Ballet is scheduled to give its first performance on this side of the Atlantic, in Quebec, as the beginning of a tour of fifty-eight cities in Canada and the United States. CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 9 (UP) -- Mrs. Frank Dougherty's Turf Sun, 14 to 1 in the wagering, sped through the stretch today to score a one-and-a-half-length triumph in the $30,150 Jersey Belle Stakes, the opening-day feature at Garden State Park.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson said today the Eisenhower Administration had saved the American taxpayers more than $2,000,000,000 annually through "more effective" use of manpower within the Defense Department.

PARIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France predicted today that the National Assembly would put its final approval within sixty days on the London decisions to arm West Germany, but only after "a hard fight."

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Henry Hopkinson, Minister of State for the Colonies, said today that the situation in British Guiana had improved, but was still "potentially dangerous." He made the statement on his return from a tour of British Guiana and the West Indies and a week's visit to the United Nations in New York.

THE major event in the art world this week, and certainly one of the major events of the whole season, takes place at the Philadelphia Museum. After a preview reception Friday evening the museum will open to the public on Saturday twenty-two newly constructed galleries which house the most important part of the truly fabulous Arensberg Collection.
Drawings from the Museum of Besancon, France, will be exhibited in the Knoedler Galleries from Oct. 27 through Nov. 13 for the benefit of the museum.

SCHOOL days are open for flower arrangers this week at the County Center, White Plains, N.Y. For the Ninth District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., announces its Course V for flower show exhibitors and judges.

Nearly 4,500 representatives of the $14,000,000,000 gas industry are scheduled to convene at Atlantic City this week for their thirty-sixth annual convention, which opens tomorrow and continues through Wednesday.

IN spite of the fanciful title, this handsome volume meets the challenge of the subtitle in a fashion which commands ungrudging admiration. The father and son whose life work is represented in the photographic record have been ably seconded by the men who made the selections from an attic full of negatives running through all the stages of the photographic process from the daguerreotype on.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A swashbuckling Minnesota eleven split Northwestern wide open on the swift strikes of Bob McNamara and John Baumgartner today to herald its return as a Big Ten force with a 26-7 victory.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct, 9 (AP) -- Butch Hanover won the $10,795 Lexington Trot for 2-year-olds and Convair took the $10,625 Tennessee Pace for 2-year-olds as the ten-day Grand Circuit meeting ended today.

AN interview with Celeste Holm is like sitting onstage during a gay theatre performance. The tall, blonde-haired actress and singer, who begins her first regular television series ("Honestly, Celeste!") tonight from 9:30 to 10 over Channel 2, radiates warmth and friendliness.

ACCORDING to your reviewer Reinhold Niebuhr, Lewis Mumford in his book "In the Name of Sanity" suggests, among others, three ways for establishing such sanity among nations: a world armistice limited to one year; a conference in which nations would reveal the lethal weapons at their disposal and a suggestion that the United States and Soviet Russia take the initiative in transforming the United Nations into "a complete system of world government."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 9 -- A congressional Deputy has been arrested for hiding a Communist agitator from the police. The Chilean authorities today seized the agitator and shipped him to a distant providence under the current state of seige.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 9 -- An unusual and, at this point, unpredictable Senatorial contest has stirred revolt among South Carolina Democrats for the third time in six years.

Years ago, his father had gone to Guatemala in search of gold and had never returned to Tenoch's Indian mother. For clanging a stone off the Viceroy's helmet, Tenoch is imprisoned and then made to serve as cabin boy on Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo's expedition to map the California coast.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 9 -- October is harvest time at the Santa Barbara Botanic Garden which sprawls over several hundred acres of foothills back of this city.
PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The population of France, including foreigners, was put today at 43,041,000, the highest in the country's history.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 9 -- The vagaries of the weather influenced retail distribution in the Kansas City area last week. Rain in many parts of the district dampened the movement of seasonal merchandise and a cool snap sparked a buying rush for coats and heavier wearing apparel.

Individual groups and issues, rather than the action of the entire list, spotlighted movements in the stock market last week. Evidence of this is that while The New York Times' composite price index showed a net gain of 1.61 points, twenty-three of the fifty issues used in computing the average declined during the week, three were unchanged and only twenty-four advanced.

DEVON, Pa., Oct. 9 -- A 3-year-old red Pekingese, in this country about a year, became best in show today in the 745-dog event of the Devon Dog Show Association. He was Ch. Kai Lung of Orchard Hill, owned by Mrs. Richard S. Quigley of Lockhaven, Pa.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- An alert Notre Dame team, aided by two touchdown passes fired by a reserve quarterback, Tom Carey, swamped Pittsburgh, 33 -- 0, today to climb back into the national football spotlight.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Bob Jones of Atlanta returned to the Winged Foot Golf Club today to view a partial re-enactment of a scene in the United States 1929 open championship, which he won here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 9 -- The Inter-American Press Association announced tonight the award of five Mergenthaler prizes for meritorious achievement in Latin-American press activities, four to individuals and the fifth to a newspaper.
BRISTOL, R.I., Oct. 9 -- Boat building will be resumed at the Herreshoff Boat Yard in Bristol this month by a man who learned his trade there at the age of 17.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 9 -- Who will represent Nebraska in the Senate when the time comes to vote on the Watkins Committee report on the proposed censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy?
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 -- Television receivers so thin they can be hung on walls like pictures will be possible through electronic advances now nearing the production stage.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 9 (UP) -- Southern Methodist completed twelve of eighteen passes today and scored in every period to gain its sixth consecutive football triumph over Missouri, 25 -- 6.

NOW that the hotelkeepers and restaurateurs of Paris are vacationing on the profits they made from the summer's vacationing Americans, and the Americans themselves, home again, are discovering that their golf and garden-club friends are really pretty inadequate listeners, let us pause to take stock of the Tourist Problem.

Daniel J. Quinn has been elected vice president of sales of the plumbing and radiator heating division of American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation. He succeeds D.D. Couch, who has been named vice president of marketing and commercial development.

STABILITY is the new economic watchword. The recession has been checked but business activity still falls far short of the high point attained in 1953. White it reflects a lack of fluctuation on the productivity and consumption charts, stability is no substitute for growth.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Prof. Robert Mosse of the University of Grenoble, in an article published in the October number of the financial magazine Banque, concludes that the dollar gap in Europe has become a problem of fugitive capital from Europe.

EAST VIEW, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- An emergency appeal for more nurses to care for an unusually heavy number of polio cases in Westchester County was issued tonight by Dr. Edwin L. Harmon, director of the county's Grasslands Hospital here.
MONTREAL, Oct. 9 -- A second wave of European migration is beginning to fall upon Canada, bringing with it a new shipping boom.

Marty Williams of Morris, Ed McAllister of Grover Cleveland and Phil Petrie of Music and Art turned in the individual victories yesterday in the second of a series of cross-country group runs sponsored by the Public Schools Athletic League at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. All of the races were conducted over the two-and-one-quarter-mile course.

LONDON -- The two main themes of the Ninth General Assembly of the International Union of Travel Organizations which met in London recently were (1) the importance of tourism as a source of foreign exchange and a factor in the international balance of payments, and (2) the gradual elimination of such barriers to travel as visas, passports, restrictive currency arrangements and frontier formalities.

IF science fiction has any formula whatsoever, it goes something like this: First, the writer asks his audience, "What if?" Then he explores the results of this question. Occasionally, the "what if" is simply absurd; more often, its consequences are treated carelessly, with scant attention to detail or logic.

NORFOLK, Va., Sunday, Oct. 10 -- Eleven survivors from the crew of forty-eight of the American freighter Mormackite reached this naval base early today, three days after their ship capsized and sank in a gale off Virginia.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology is undergoing a renaissance of imaginative teaching, its president said today.

ONE of the most timeworn adages of jazz is that a musician plays his best before an enthusiastic audience, that the coldness of a recording studio inhibits his performance. This appears to be due for revision.

TULIP bulbs planted in October or November will bring a rainbow of color into the garden next spring. From the early Kaufmannianas in April to the late May-flowering Darwins come two months of radiant color.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP) -- The New York State Conservation Council today urged a thirteen-day deer season for western and southern New York next year instead of the customary six-day season.
Putting on ice skates merely to stand around was frowned on at the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink, which reopened yesterday for the winter season in Central Park.

Among the many art exhibitions this week is one opening on Friday at the National Academy of Design to commemorate the Bicentennial of Columbia University. Entitled "Memorabilia 1800-1900," it will include paintings, sculpture, drawings, photographs, medals and other material from the academy, various museums and private collections.
THE N.B.C. Television Opera Theatre this year will be offered on Sunday afternoons from 3 to 4:30 P.M. Last season the operas were presented on Saturdays. All will be sung in English.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP) -- The University of Massachusetts scored its third straight victory and first of the year in the Yankee Conference today by upsetting the University of Connecticut eleven, 20 -- 13.

DAFFODILS are one of the most truly satisfying of all garden plants and among the first that should be stressed for new home owners. My garden in West Virginia would seem bleak indeed without the cheerful yellow and white flowers of varying sizes that come along year after year from March until the end of April.
MIAMI, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Hurricane Hazel, roughest tropical storm of the season, roared westward in the Caribbean Sea toward Jamaica today with 125-mile-an-hour winds.

A SELECTION of fifty pictures from "The Face of New York," a forthcoming book by Andreas Feininger, in which he participates both as photographer and as editor of the work of others, is displayed in an exhibition which opened last week at the Museum of the City of New York, where it will hang to Nov. 28.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Post Office Department, operationally speaking, is being broken up into fifteen geographic regions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, assured the dairy industry today that his department was "on the right road" leading to fulfillment of the Government's program aimed at turning the industry's "handicaps into opportunities, and (its) problems into success."

ANEW Shostakovich symphony is always news, and the furore attending the American premiere of the Tenth symphony has spread to the record companies. Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony are scheduled to perform the Tenth in Carnegie Hall on Oct. 14.

NOW is the time to plant the many varieties of small bulbs that add to the glory of spring in the rock garden. Fortunately each year a few more of the different species are added to the plant catalogues, for these small bulbs do more to prolong the flowering season both in spring and fall than any other plants.

WILLIAM HOLDEN, 1953 Academy Award winner for "Stalag 17" and newly appointed member of the Los Angeles Park Commission, is a Hollywood anomaly. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- James J. Wadsworth will speak for the United States during the United Nations' atomic control and disarmament debate starting next week.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 9 -- Israel formally announced tonight her agreement to the appointment of Lieut. Col. Charles F. Brewster of the United States Army as chairman of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission. This means that Israel will end her seven-month boycott of the commission when Colonel Brewster assumes his post Oct. 15.

Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, 80-year-old dean of the horse-trainers, attained a long-sought success at Belmont Park yesterday when the Belair Stud's Nashua, in a tremendously exciting race, won the sixty-fifth Futurity.

Dartmouth ran off with the individual, victory but Yale captured team honors yesterday in a triangular cross-country meet over the five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park. Columbia was the other Ivy League participant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The private dispute that has been going on among Republican leaders over the degree of campaign activity the President should assume became open this week when Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Speaker Joseph Martin Jr. gave opposing views to the public. And this development lent support to two speculations which have been gaining credence in political circles.

The United States delegation to the United Nations is making a sound and practical approach to the complex problem of freedom of the seas and the definition of territorial waters. It expects to come into this question at this session of the Assembly through the discussion of fisheries and fishing rights.

A large variety of attractions will be offered to the auction-buying public this week as the season steps up its pace. At two galleries, the offerings are considerable. Collections of books, Oriental art, and eighteenth century French furniture and decorations will be found at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, and a collection of American, English and French antiques at the Plaza Art Galleries.
A new labor pact covering 23,000 nonsupervisory employes of the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been signed, it was announced here last night.

The need for professional social workers and psychiatrists in courts to cope with the problems of juvenile delinquency was stressed yesterday by Irving Ben Cooper, Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions of New York City.

The United States has more butter than it can use at home or ship abroad. In fact, warehouses are glutted with the commodity and several times this year there have been predictions that exhaustion of space for butter storage was imminent.

LIVE OAK, Fla., Oct. 9 (UP) -- A drawling country judge jailed a nationally known author tonight on a charge the writer had held the court up to contempt while collecting information on a lurid murder case.

New Utrecht's football team scored a 23-13 upset victory over Lafayette at Lincoln Field yesterday, snapping the Frenchies' unbeaten string of twenty-five games. Lafayette had won twenty-four and tied one over a four-year span.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct 9 (UP) -- Bishop Loughlin High School of Brooklyn won the sixteenth annual Grout Memorial cross-country run today.

THE Egyptian State Tourist Office at 630 Fifth Avenue, the first foreign tourist bureau established by Egypt anywhere in the world, was opened formally last week. Here for the ceremonies were the director general of the Egyptian State Tourist Administration in Cairo, Mohyeddine el-Shazli, and the discoverer of the solar boat at Cheops Pyramid, Kamal el-Malakh.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 9 (UP) -- Georgia abandoned its passing game when it failed to click and used two power runners, Bob (Foots) Clemens and Charlie Madison, to grind out a 21-to-7 victory over favored North Carolina today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Leonard W. Hall, the Republican National Chairman, said today that President Eisenhower had given a vote-getting "shot in the arm" to the campaign for election of a G.O.P. Congress.
Domestic steel production amounted to 6,771,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last month -- the largest output since June, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ATLANTA, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Billy Teas scampered 77 yards to unlimber Georgia Tech's ground and air arsenal today and the Atlanta Engineers went on to outscore Louisiana State, 30 to 20, before 28,000 fans.

The immediate reopening of Townsend Harris High School, the three-year school for bright students that was closed in 1942, was urged yesterday by the Citizens Committee for the Restoration of Townsend Harris High School.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 9 -- On a quiet street of small new homes five miles outside this city, an explosion on June 27 shattered the wall of a house belonging to Andrew E. Wade 4th. His was the only Negro family in the block.

Hamilton College handed Wagner its third straight loss yesterday, defeating the Seahawks, 25 -- 6, at the Grymes Hill Field in Staten Island.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 9 -- Republicans and Democrats agree generally that the most important single question of the 1954 campaign, as it has developed thus far, is how the voters will react to President Eisenhower's appeal for a Republican Congress to help him complete his program in the next two years.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 9 (UP) -- The University of Oregon spotted California two touchdowns in the first quarter on fumbles, then came back to triumph, 32 -- 27, today in one of the wildest football games ever seen in Memorial Stadium.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Leaves are starting to fall from dogwoods and oaks as well as maples and elms. Rake up, especially where new lawns have been planted. Any healthy leaves go on a compost pile; oak leaves may be placed under acid-loving azaleas as a mulch. Burn only diseased leaves. AND IF THERE IS TIME: Spray roses and shrubs with nicotine sulfate to control aphids.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sunday, Oct. 10 -- Nationalist President Chiang Kai-shek predicted today a Communist attempt to invade Formosa, but said that any large-scale invasion would bring destruction and final collapse to the Communist regime on the Chinese mainland.

AS most of her readers know, Ann Nolan Clark, has spent much of her life working with the Indian children of Intermountain School in Utah. This new story is set in that region and concerns an Indian boy and his young mare. The mare deserts him to run with the wild horses in the mountains until her colt is born.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- The architects of the United Nations, optimists that they were, built the General Assembly Hall big enough to take care of about ninety delegations, instead of the sixty that already belong to the club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Defense Department has started a broad new survey of its whole guided-missile program, on which $1,200,000,000 will have been spent for purchases by next June 30.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 9 -- Honduras has developed a case of jitters as she faces tomorrow's national elections, the country's first contested balloting in twenty-two years.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 9 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon appealed to New Mexico voters today to stand fast with President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The Arab League has decided on a "new approach" to getting its viewpoints across to the American people, its secretary general, Abdel Khalik Hassouna, said tonight.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 9 -- Bucknell defeated Lehigh in a free-scoring football game today, 48 to 46, before 5,500 spectators. The ninety-four points scored is believed a new record for Memorial Stadium.

WASHINGTON. After forty-four years of service to his country, Maj. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith quietly resigned last week as Under Secretary of State. A spare, gaunt, tired and slightly snappy 59-year-old soldier -- he was 59 last Tuesday -- General Smith went out as he came in -- talking straight and making sense.

Following is a summary of the registration in New York City for 1954. Because new district lines are being used, no accurate comparisons by Assembly Districts can be made with other years. The recapitulation shows the comparison, by boroughs, with 1953, a Mayoral year; 1952, a Presidential year, and 1950, the last state election year:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 -- John Farwell Moors, Boston investment banker, has, through gifts in his lifetime and from his estate, become the largest single donor in the history of Radcliffe College. The college has received close to $2,000,000 from Mr. Moors.

THE story of a young girl's adjustment to her environment, to current history and to sex is usually told patronizingly if not nauseatingly. To handle it as the serious experience it is requires a really civilized writer, and in "To Wake in the Morning" Hilda Sidney Krech has proved that she is indeed genuinely civilized. She writes well too.

DR. SAYRE was an obstetrician on the aging Dr. Kildare side, leading a quiet, un-Hollywoodian life and practice. His social life was spent principally with his friends Pete and Marcy Devery, and occasionally a girl in New York, Jocelyn Randolph, who was in love with him and whom he intended one day to marry.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Michigan State scored its first Big Ten victory of the year today, defeating Indiana, 21 -- 14, with Johnny Matsock turning the tide for the Spartans on a 74yard touchdown punt return.

Mr. and Mrs. David Coleman of 55 Central Park West have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Anita Joan Coleman, to Warren David Manshel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benno Manshel of New York. The ceremony was performed on Sept. 22 in Anacapri, Italy, by the Mayor.

DALLAS, Oct. 9 -- Oklahoma's powerful Sooners fumbled and rumbled against their traditional rival, Texas, today, but the nation's No. 1 team whipped up a blend of passes and ground power to gain a 14-to-7 victory before 76,204 fans.

TOKYO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Little Heinz Futterer of Germany came within one-tenth second of the world record for the 100-meter dash today running 10.3 seconds on a soggy clay track in a meet against Japan Futterer equaled his best previous time also.

Thank you for the article "To Bigotry, No Sanction" (Sept. 12). Dr. David de Sola Pool writes, in his account of the new immigrants of September, 1654, that they arrived on the frigate St. Charles. May I draw your attention to the fact that it was not the frigate St. Charles but a tiny bark named St. Catarina on which they arrived.
BARTOK: Song, Op. 16; Hungarian Folk Songs; Magda Laszlo, soprano; Franz Holetschek, piano (Westminster). The difficult and vocally demanding Bartok songs get a capable performance.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Arthur Davis, a fleet 183-pound halfback, set up two Mississippi State touchdowns today to lead his team to a 14-0 Southwestern Conference victory over Tulane.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 -- Plans for the construction of a $3,000,00 atomic laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology were announced this week.

Charles H. Fecke, veteran passenger representative of the Cunard Line, has just celebrated his eightieth birthday on a most annoying note. He shot a disappointing 105 in golf at the Hudson River Country Club, a good ten strokes above his usual eighteen-hole score.

AN American of German origin, Hans Rosenhaupt served as an interrogator in United States Army Intelligence. His central character in his novel, of course, is a young man who came to America from Germany and is now interrogating German prisoners of war.
HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 9 -- Thirty thousand Vietminh soldiers, including many who had fought at Dienbienphu, marched into Hanoi today amid the cheers of a flag-waving populace.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- More than half of the paintings in the city-owned Wilstach Collection along with other art objects will be auctioned by the Philadelphia Museum of Art at Memorial Hall from Oct. 25 to Oct. 30.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Vic Romagna's Lord Jim, a forty-two-foot yawl out of Manhasset Bay, was a 39-second winner of the New Rochelle Yacht Club's annual Stratford Shoal overnight race which had its finish inside Huntington Bay today.

WHEN the United Nations celebrates U.N. Day on Sunday, Oct. 24, one of the features of the afternoon may be a concert by the former N.B.C. Symphony. And, by a neat touch of irony, if the concert does go through, it will be broadcast and telecast by the N.B.C. network.

Your editorial of Oct. 3 on "Segregation -- What Next?" -- was a sane and welcome contribution to this topic. It seems to me that you might have touched on two other points which are somewhat hopeful. One is that all the major denominations -- including those with a large white membership -- have gone on record at conventions in the right way on this issue.
REIMS, France, Oct. 2 -- The champagne industry, including its United States distributors, has donated a six-panel window to the Cathedral of Reims.

AMARILLO, Tex., Oct 9 -- The High Plains farmers of the Lone Star State are gradually whipping the old bugaboo of the prairies -- drought -- by boring irrigation wells. All across the Northern tier of the Texas Panhandle counties that abut the elongated Oklahoma Panhandle irrigation wells are being sunk.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Army buried Dartmouth under an avalanche of touchdowns today in an exhibition of offensive prowess that dazzled 23,250 spectators at Michie Stadium.
Averell Harriman repudiated yesterday a plank in the Liberal party platform that called for higher taxes.

To commemorate the tenth anniversary of the Battle for Leyte Gulf, the personnel of the Kitkun Bay (CVE-71), an escort carrier, will hold a reunion at the Military-Naval Club, 4 West Forty-third Street, the night of Oct. 25.

Pat Malone, New York actor, hopes that the 100th anniversary of the charge of the Light Brigade, on Oct. 25, will find him in possession of the Victoria Cross that his grandfather won for an act of bravery that day in 1854.

IF you have ever wondered what the real stories are behind the headlines and sensational crimes that are a staple commodity of the metropolitan tabloid press, "The Violators" will answer your wonder. Israel Beckhardt has, for the past nineteen years, been a pre-sentence investigator for the Bronx County Court and he gives us twenty-seven case histories drawn from his file of 3,000 cases on which he has worked.
MADRID, Oct. 6 -- A proposal to use United States economic aid to reduce Spain's high illiteracy rate has been submitted to the Cortes (Parliament).

DETROIT, Oct. 9 -- Goalie Terry Sawchuk of the Detroit Red Wings turned in his first shutout of the National Hockey League season tonight as he blanked the Rangers in the New Yorkers' opener, 4 -- 0, before 10,127 fans at Olympia.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 9 (UP) -- Unbeaten Penn State added to its stature as the top-ranking team in the East today by overwhelming previously undefeated Virginia, 34 -- 7, for its easiest victory this season.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 9 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas announced today that extradition proceedings had been started against sixteen Guatemalan exiles in five countries, including former President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, deposed Leftist leader.

SUSAN B. ANTHONY would have a good time if she were living now. The picture drawn of her by Katharine Anthony (no relation) makes it clear that the Quaker sufragist was a century ahead of her time in her absorption in committees, conferences, conventions, propaganda, travel, fund-raising, campaigning, lecturing -- all the things her spiritual successors accept as modern demands on modern women.

OF the many kinds of small spring-flowering bulbs to be planted in gardens this fall, none is more appealing to Northern gardeners than the tiny snowdrop. Preceding the calendar arrival of spring by a month or more, the frosty, white bells come into bloom even before the robins return and the swamp maples redden.
Frank L. Cooper has been named treasurer of the Crucible Steel Company of America, Pittsburgh, succeeding James F. Prince, who has retired.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Oct. 9 -- Capt. Patrick J. McMahon, 42-year-old skipper of the Mormackite, is a native of Ireland who came to the United States as a child. His family settled in New Jersey, where he attended the public schools. A career employe with the Moore-McCormack Lines, he started work as a youth. During the war he served as a lieutenant in the United States Navy.

VIENNA, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Pete George of Akron, Ohio, won the middleweight title in the world weight lifting championships today but Russia maintained a comfortable 15-point margin over the United States in the team standings.
TOKYO, Sept. 25 -- The Communist party has launched a drive to infiltrate the new Japanese Army.

EVERY city undertaking to sponsor a music and theatre festival has to put up with many adversities, but few have had to contend with tribulations of such magnitude as the Danube floods which inundated the ancient, gemuetlich Bavarian city of Passau in the middle of July, just two months before the opening ceremonies of this year's European Festival Weeks there.

With the cooperation of the Coast Guard and its Auxiliary, U.S. Power Squadrons, American Red Cross, Boy Scouts of America, and many state conservation departments and waterways eommissions, the Outboard Boating Club of America has put together a "Recommended Uniform Boat Regulation Act."
HURTADO DE CORDOBA and his Spanish Ballet open this evening at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, where they are scheduled to remain for four weeks before setting out on a cross-country tour.

HANOI, Oct. 8 -- Southern Vietnam, the truncated half nation left under the control of the anti-Communist Saigon Government by the Indochina peace settlement, is in the throes of a particularly serious political crisis.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 9 -- Guatemalians will go to the polls tomorrow for the first time since the overthrow of Jacobo Arbenz Guzman's regime in June. They will elect sixty-six Deputies for the Constituent Assembly which will write a new constitution to substitute the one approved in 1945 and revoked in July.

For two years the International Longshoremen's Association has been fighting the most powerful opposition any union ever has had to buck. The limitless resources of the Federal and state Governments have been dedicated to its destruction since the State Crime Commission exposed the organization as a hatching ground for extortion, exploitation, bribery, murder and theft.

OUR American poet, historian, minnesinger and goat-breeder, Carl Sandburg, has taken the time to cut his six volumes on Lincoln, "The Prairie Years" and "The War Years," down to one volume, which contains much, but obviously not all of the grandeur of the originals.

IN this sequel to "The Ark" Margot Benary-Isbert continues the post-war experiences of a displaced Pomeranian family who found haven in West Germany. The year is 1948 and the Lechows are reunited, living snugly if frugally in an old railroad car at Rowan Farm.
HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Oct. 8 -- As French forces progressively withdrew, Vietminh troops took over the suburbs of Hanoi today.

AT the first fall meeting of the Wings Club in New York the principal speaker criticized the commercial airlines because of the amount of information they do not pass on to their passengers, J. Carlton Ward Jr., board chairman of the Flight Safety Foundation, noted that airline captains "clam up" just at the time that their customers would like to be informed about the progress of their trips.

Even with the abnormal period of post-war reconstruction ended, the agencies set up in recent years for the promotion of international finance on an adequate and sound basis are being found wanting and supplementary ones are being proposed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Democratic party's two top leaders in Congress struck back tonight at President Eisenhower and what they called his "new position of rigid, unswerving partisanship."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 -- After a week of diminishing disorders on the issue of mixed classes in the public schools, this city presents a case history in desegregation that might prove of value to other communities.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9 -- The Supreme Court has rejected Jacques Mornard's appeal against his conviction for the murder of Leon Trotsky fourteen years ago.

MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- More than one-fourth of the people in the Soviet Union are engaged in studies, and nearly a billion books and pamphlets were published last year. The lecture organization of the Ministry of Culture alone organized 3,600,000 lectures.
TRENTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Civil Defense Director Leonard Dreyfuss urged New Jerseyans this week to improve their knowledge of civil defense to avoid confusion in the event of enemy air attacks.

NEWARK, Del., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Quarterback Don Miller scored one touchdown and passed for two more today as a fired-up Delaware University team routed Temple 51 -- 13 for its third straight victory in unbeaten season.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 9 -- The 4,000 Conservatives gathering at this seaside resort this week for the party's seventy-fourth annual conference could not suppress an inner queasiness like that of a landlubber as his ship leaves the harbor and enters the open sea.
A new provision in the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 (Section 1361) permits certain proprietorships and partnerships to elect to be taxed as corporations.
DENVER, Oct. 9 -- Midterm apathy among voters appeared to Republican party political strategists today as the main obstacle to the G.O.P.'s keeping control of congress.

Since the turn of the century there has been a progressive increase in the number of mentally defective children and a progressive decline of intelligence in the population as a whole. This is not an opinion or a guess but a conclusion that a well-known pediatrician, Dr. I. Newton Kugelmass of New York City, draws in his new book, "Management of Mental Deficiency in Children" (Grune Stratton).

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 9 -- Princeton alertness in exploiting Pennsylvania's mistakes brought the Tiger football team out on top by 13 -- 7 today in Palmer Stadium. The victory was Princeton's third straight.

The scholarship funds of the Rudolf Steiner School here and the High Mowing School in Wilton, N.H., will be augmented by the proceeds from the pre-opening performance of "Quadrille" on the night of Nov. 1 at the Coronet Theatre.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 9 -- Michigan handed two gift touchdowns to Iowa in the opening minutes today, but roared back under the direction of Jim Maddock, a sophomore quarterback, to upset the previously unbeaten Hawkeyes, 14 -- 13, before 69,607 fans at Michigan Stadium.

AT the dockside they seem confused, tired and strangely quiet. They pour down the gangplank with their old ones and their children, wearing the traditional cai non (coolie caps) and carrying their worldly belongings in bulging sacks.
Emotional disturbances may play an important part in the loss of vision, the first annual meeting of the Academy of Psychosomatic Medicine was told yesterday.

MAYBE you haven't noticed -- as you very well might not, because this sort of thing has been most noticeable in the area of the lower-grade films -- but there has been a heavy efflorescence lately of pictures about crooked cops.

GENEVA, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- The Organization for European Nuclear Research today ended a three-day meeting after approving definite plans for the world's first international, non-secret, atomic research plant at Meyrin, on the French-Swiss frontier near Geneva

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The United States demanded today that the Soviet Union pay $2,785,492,94 for the destruction of a B-50 bomber shot down July 29, 1953, by Soviet jet fighter planes over the Sea of Japan.

IT has been more than fifty years since I have seen a print of the great flood at Johnstown that accompanied the review of "Man Against Nature" (edited by Charles L. Neider). I well recall a large-size reproduction of some 30 x 40 inches which my mother occasionally permitted me to unroll on the living-room floor.
ALLENDALE, N. J., Oct. 9 -- Strideaway, 7-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Chales McGovern of Greenwich, Conn., was the top winner as the fifth annual two-day Allendale horse show began today.
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Powerful Trinity chalked up its third straight football victory by overwhelming previously unbeaten Tufts, 27 -- 6, today before 5,000 fans at Tufts Oval.
President Eisenhower will come to New York Oct. 20 to help celebrate the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in the United States.

Labor and civic groups paid tribute yesterday to the Rev. Jerome A. Drolet, pastor of St. Charles Roman Catholic Church in Thibodaux, La., for "his distinguished service to labor's rights" during the last twenty years.

THE rather amusing uproar over Mario Lanza's "appearance" on "Showers of Stars" -- the gentleman only mouthed the words of his songs while some old recordings were fed into the sound channel -- may serve as a useful purpose in the long run.

AS managing editor of Harper's Magazine Russell Lynes has been an apt disciple of his late chief, Frederick Lewis Allen, and of the latter's wife, Agnes Rogers. The same backward look off the left shoulder at contemporary America in the eyes of our parents and grandparents has resulted in a mature and thoughtful book; almost, but happily for the reader not quite, an encyclopedia of the development of American taste.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 9 -- The new mayor of this city, Harry T. Clew, is a reporter, and thereby hangs a story.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 9 -- Sir Winston Churchill warned France today against seeking further major concessions on West German armament lest this disrupt cooperation between Europe and the United States in the defense of the West.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 9 -- Justice Minister Djody Gondokusumo said today that Tjong Hoen-nji, the Chinese community's anti-Comunist leader, was facing expulsion from Indonesia because his political activities were "endangering the safety of the state."
Another move was made yestearday by The Jockey Club's special committee, which last month made public its proposals for the rehabilitation of the New York race tracks.

NOISE is one of the most troublesome by-products of our modern age. In particular, noise resulting from motor vehicle traffic, horns, brakes and the pounding of cars, trucks and busses on pavements assails the human ear nearly twenty-four hours a day.

PERHAPS only President Eisenhower and former Secretary of State George C. Marshall have matched the range and duration of General Smith's career in the past four astonishing decades, and in some ways his experience has been even wider than theirs.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Oct. 9 (UP) -- Mackie Prickett, whose family breeds race horses, proved a capable jockey today in his first quarterback start and led South Carolina to a 27-7 victory over Furman before 9,000 fans.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Adrian Burk, benched in the first half for inept passing, returned in the final three minutes of the game to direct an 81-yard touchdown drive that gave the Philadelphia Eagles a 24-22 National Football League victory over the surprisingly rugged Pittsburgh Steelers tonight before a sellout crowd of 37,322 at Connie Mack Stadium.

Londoners are greatly interested in the ruins of the Mithraeum recently discovered in their city, but the cult of Mithras meant little to the Britons of the second and third centuries A.D. Mithraism was the religion of the Roman legions, who spread it rapidly through the whole of the Western Empire.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- Fordham's eleven staggered through a harrowing first quarter tonight and was unable to recover, as it absorbed a 55-to-20 defeat from Boston University before 18,000 persons at University Field. It was one of the worst showings by a Ram squad in recent years.
HOUSTON, Oct. 9 -- The lines have been drawn here for what may be one of the hottest political races in the city's history. Three candidates have filed for Mayor and all of them have strong backing.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Mario Verga, 44-year-old Italian motor boat champion, was killed today on the calm waters of Lake Iseo when his speedboat sank while he was trying to beat the United States-held world record.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 9 -- The Ninth Wisconsin Congressional District, which elected a Democratic member of Congress for the first time in its history in a special election a year ago, is expected to send Representative Lester Johnson back to Washington for a full term.
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Oct. 9 (UP) -- Arkansas defeated Baylor, 21 to 20, today on a fourth-period field goal by Preston Carpenter.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 9 -- Alan (the Horse) Ameche ripped through a tiring Rice line that had thrown back two previous fourth-quarter drives for the winning touchdown in the last 50 seconds today as Wisconsin triumphed over the Southwest Conference Owls, 13 -- 7.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Off-street parking in the downtown district was augmented yesterday with the formal opening of the city's new twelve-story garage at 120 North La Salle Street.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 9 (UP) -- Oscar L. Chapman, former Secretary of the Interior said tonight that Eisenhower Administration policies had been a "betrayal of the West."
LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Tottenham Hotspur, lackluster London outfit with a puny record, knocked West Bromwich Albion out of first place in English soccer today with a 3 -- 1 victory.

TORONTO, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Caprain Ted Kennedy, lured out of retiremeni{ "for jus one more season," scored twice with less than two minutes remaining tolnight ito salvage a 3-3 deadlock for the Toronto Naple Leafs in their National Hockey League home opener against the Chicago Black Hawks.

LINDEN, N.J., Oct. 9 -- Patrolman Herman Stoeffler was held for the grand jury today on a charge of selling a .45 caliber automatic pistol to a 19-year-old youth who, the police said, lacked a permit to buy it.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- United Nations employes were advised today that they had better quit if they found it difficult to place allegiance to the world organization above that of their own countries.

For the second successive week warm weather and a Jewish Holiday cut into department store sales in New York. As a result merchants estimated that sales during the week would be about 10 per cent below the like week a year ago.

NO demands upon the novelist are so imperative as those made by the succinct short story: they show up, as nothing else will, his strength or weakness. The ten short stories in this volume demonstrate Wilson Tucker's mastery of characterization, suspense and above all, mood.

THE announcement by the Film Council of America of plans for the second annual American Film Assembly heralds a repeat performance of a highly significant, large-scale 16mm. motion-picture undertaking. Scheduled for next April 4-9, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the Assembly again will feature the Golden Reel Film Festival, the only such open competition for creators in the field.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 9 -- The Santa Barbara Parent-Teachers Association and the Public Library have moved to meet juvenile reading needs by establishing lending libraries in the city's grammar schools. They acted after sixty horror comics had been dropped by a regional distributor.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 9 -- Erection of six 200-foot steel towers on Moore Mesa near Suburban Goleta has been explained by members of North American Weather Consultants whose offices are at the Santa Barbara Municipal Airport.

Nine large industries have joined Lafayette College in sponsoring the Lafayette Evening College for their employes. The industries provide tuition scholarships so their employes may prepare to assume greater responsibilities.

BILLINGS, Mont., Oct. 9 -- "Opposition to any effort to legalize any form of gambling in Montana, such as that proposed" by the Montana Economic Improvement Association was expressed in a resolution adopted by the Montana Council of Churches at the end of its annual state convention here Wednesday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Harvard pulled a close one out against Cornell today. The Crimson eleven from Cambridge subdued the Big Red outfit by a 13-to-12 count before a Cornell Homecoming Day Crowd of 19,000. The game was a thriller with Harvard's ability to advance on the ground enabling it to spring a mild upset.

MOTOR travel this country will reach a total of at least 500,000,000,000 miles this year, which equals 1,978,522 trips from New York to the moon with almost one-half mile to spare. This comparison is based upon scientific space measurements indicating that the farthest the moon ever gets from the earth in following a somewhat erratic orbit is 252,710 miles.
CHICAGO -- Two honorary fellowships and an honorary membership led the list of awards at the annual Photographic Society of America honors awards banquet held here last night at the Drake Hotel.

Trieste, a natural harbor at the head of the Adriatic, has been an international bone of contention since the break-up of the Roman Empire. Italians from Dante to Mussolini have called it "ours." The Hapsburgs built it into a "port of empire" with the aid of local Slavic labor.

VIENNA, Oct. 9 -- The Hungarian Government, which recently denied that there was any real unemployment in Hungary, has been forced to announce emergency measures to deal with what apparently is an alarming situation.

HILLSBORO, Ind., Oct. 9 -- The main road eastward across southern Indiana (Route 136) runs through pleasant rolling country between the Wabash and the Ohio, and suddenly comes upon this lonely village on the brow of a hill.

EVEN though the minimum footage for a New York patrolman was reduced recently from 5'8" to 5'7 1/2". (to get more men into uniform), that's still an inch taller than the average American male, according to Selective Service figures. It is also an inch taller than a fireman has to be and 7 1/2" taller than the barefoot minimum for soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines.

EDUARD VAN BEINUM is the principal conductor of the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra, which starts its first American tour this week. He will share the podium during this visit with Rafael Kubelik, and United States audiences will get a chance to become acquainted in the flesh not only with a famous European ensemble but with a conductor whose reputation in Europe is high.

SUPPOSE we put aside for the time being the question raised here last Sunday, as to whether the novel is dead or dying, or merely taking a siesta, and examine a little more closely Sir Harold Nicolson's belief that it is a literary form which can flourish only in a time of tranquillity.

IN "Man and Beast" there is a change of mood and pace for the author of "Private Worlds" and "The Mortal Storm." This provocative collection of short stories about wild and domestic animals explores the psychological, borderland where man and animal meet.

The winter series of weekly recorded concerts of the New York Public Library will have its first program on Wednesday. This popular response to audience requests, begun in 1948, runs from noon to 2 P. M. every Wednesday in Room 213.

Ten years ago today, a 37-year-old man, severely crippled by arthritis, hobbled with the aid of two canes to board a bus to church. Unemployed for five years because of his disability, his weekly visit to church was about the only time he left his home.

GWEN JEFFREY had everything a girl could want: she enjoyed living in New York and working in an architect's office, and the man she loved, Phil Webb, had asked her to marry him. But that old devil, jealousy, just wouldn't leave her alone.

A bandit who would accept only $5 bills and quarters held up two employes in a dry cleaning shop at 1453 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday and escaped with $31.50. He spurned at least $20 in other bills.

The more I think about it, the juster appears this paradoxical seeming conclusion of this second and final volume of Koestler's autobiography, covering the years from 1931 to the present.

GLEN BURNIE, Md., Oct. 9 -- Gov. J. Caleb Boggs of Delaware ordered today the arrest of Bryant W. Bowles, segregationist leader in the school bias troubles of Milford, Del., if Mr. Bowles stepped back into Delaware.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- A fairer deal for Federal employes under the loyalty-security program was sought today by the Sixth American Assembly.
MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (UP) -- It is night in Moscow.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Unbeaten Ohio State, riding on the fleet heels of Bobby Watkins, routed Illinois, 40 -- 7, today to become a Big Ten football title contender.

Your Oct. 3 editorial on reform in the Far East, stressing land reform, touches on the real reason for our failure in China. The hunger for land and the oppression of landlords was and is the chief source of Communist influence and strength in Asia.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Clarence Decatur Howe, Canada's Minister of Trade and Commerce, last night became the first Canadian to win aviation's Guggenheim Medal.

ACHERISHED tenet of the American credo is that state government, as the keystone of the Republic, represents some kind of quintessential perfection. Any reporter who has covered state politics knows this is bunk -- that state governments are not sterile monoliths, but squirming imbroglios of human beings who in their conjunction magnify such human frailties as stupidity, hypocrisy and dishonesty.

New York will welcome today the hundred musicians of one of Europe's most distinguished orchestras. This is the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra, almost a hundred years old, and usually regarded as having no superior in its record of achievement.
Any build-up of peaceful trade between the United States and the Soviet bloc -- a recurrent rosy mirage for some American exporters -- will have to start from levels that recently reached new lows.

WHEN Ernest Gann is at the top of his game, as he was last year in "The High and the Mighty," he is very, very good indeed. When he is in something less than top form, as in this new adventure story, the seams in his cleverly stitched plots begin to show.

THE development of an incisive chemotherapy based on the natural combativeness of certain soil-dwelling microorganisms is without much doubt one of the major medical achievements of our time. As a means of alleviating human misery, it ranks with the introduction of anesthesia in surgery.

Mexican merchant marine officials were "impressed" yesterday, on a tour of New York Harbor aboard the Coast Guard cutter Mahoning. Gen. Rodolfo Sanchez Taboada, Mexican Minister of the Navy, led the visiting delegation, which also included Admiral Mario Rodriguez Malpica.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- "Natives" of this city of more than 500,000 residents must come to understand mountaineers' ways, and the 25,000 to 50,000 mountaineers now living here must learn to adapt themselves if these newcomers are to be integrated in a friendly manner.
TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 9 -- A program of "clinical interneship" for theological students was approved here this afternoon by the nineteenth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church of America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Norman Armour, new United States Ambassador to Guatemala, was revealed this week as having issued a warning against Bolshevik plans for world-wide Communist domination long before the threat was commonly recognized in this country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Conjecture continued here today on possible successors to the Supreme Court seat of Justice Robert H. Jackson, who died yesterday after a heart attack.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks reported today that his department had approved $7,108,000 worth of applications for exports to European Communist countries in the first half of 1954, compared with $484,000 a year earlier.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 -- The volume of incoming steel business for the past two weeks has been greater than was expected by practically all steelmakers. There is little doubt that a definite and strong upturn in steel activity has set in and will continue through the balance of this year.
Club owners yesterday agreed to keep the Class A Eastern Baseball League in operation next season with the possibility of a franchise shift in the eight-team circuit.

LEFTY JAMES, the Cornell coach, now has a clear understanding of how Al Lopez felt during the World series. According to the experts the Cleveland Indians were supposed to bowl over the Giants and Cornell was supposed to bowl over all Ivy League rivals, thus becoming one of the top-ranking teams in the East.

Even if Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, who reaches a youthful 70 years today, had not been the wife of a President she would be outstanding among the women of her generation. She has been teacher, social worker, lecturer and (in her work with the United Nations) a public servant.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Howard Fast, novelist, objected in a letter to The Sunday Observer today to a characterization of him by one of its book reviewers as a Communist. He said that "to put it very mildly" this designation was unfortunate.
Twenty-two Cub Scouts of Pack 505 from Manhattan's West Seventies, trailed by sixteen fathers bearing the extra jackets, cameras and toys, followed a soldier across Governors Island yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Lard future prices on the Board of Trade fluctuated nervously in a narrow range last week, and neither the bulls nor the bears had much advantage at the end of the week. Closing prices were 17 cents up to 2 1/2 cents lower.

On the basis of returns for July and August, the 1954-55 revenue from the city's 5 per cent amusement tax on motion picture admissions alone will approximate the $5,500,000 a year estimated in June by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
Small taxicabs are cutting more and more sharply into the ranks of the city's 11,812 licensed hacks, once the exclusive domain of jumbo-sized cabs.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 10 -Although the results of Brazil's elections are far from complete after a week of counting, it appears that backers of the late President Getulio Vargas are losing ground with the electorate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -Assistant Secretary of Commerce James C. Worthy said today the nation had enjoyed unparalleled prosperity under the Eisenhower Administration and must keep "responsible leadership in government" to keep free enterprise flourishing.

Dr. Ralph J. Burche has been elected to the Board of Trustees of the New York house of the International House Association. Dr. Bunche has had a distinguished career in international affairs, and he and International House go well together. For thirty years the New York house has been offering the foreign student a respite from what must appear to him at times as the total wilderness of a metropolitan civilization.

Coincidentally with the successful conclusion of the London conference a group of 169 prominent citizens from eight of the NATO countries has urged extension along political, economic and cultural lines of the present ties binding the members of the Atlantic community together in military alliance.
Averell Harriman charged last night that a Republican policy of "helping the few and not the many" was threatening the country with economic stagnation.

Progress is being made in the merger negotiations of the American Woolen Company, Textron Incorporated, and Robbins Mills, Inc., according to Robert Huffines, president of Textron and the newly formed Amerotron, Inc., selling, purchasing and management company for the three textile manufacturers.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 10 -- There were several scattered incidents of violence in the Honduran national elections today, but widespread fears that the voting would touch off a civil war proved groundless.
Registration for this year's election fell behind the totals for the last such poll in 1950, both here and in upstate cities where personal registration is required.
TORONTO, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A 542-mile superhighway without a traffic light or a left turn is taking shape across southern Ontario. It will run from Windsor to the Quebec border.

DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 10 -Mrs. Marion McDermott's Ch. Brando von Aichtal, a 7-year-old black and cream dog imported from Germany three years ago, became best of breed tonight in the 160-dog specialty of the German Shepherd Dog Club of America.
Grants totaling $427,325, mostly to foster a better understanding of life in the United States, were announced yesterday by Charles Dollard, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York.

The most extensive tour the New York City Opera has undertaken will open in Worcester Mass., on Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday. Twentynine performances in ten cities of the East and Midwest are scheduled.
President Eisenhower praised the courage and independence of Christopher Columbus yesterday in a message to the committee arranging the annual Columbus Day Parade here tomorrow.
PARIS, Oct. 10 -- It was generally agreed tonight that the French National Assembly would approve the London accord for West German armament when it votes Tuesday.

British sterling made slow but steady progress upward last week from the irregularity which had previously depressed it to the lowest in the last two years. Dealers attributed the rally to a natural rebound and the dissipation of earlier pressures.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 10 -- New Jersey's Ninth Congressional District is a Republican bastion undergoing one of the most formidable Democratic sieges in its history while not quite sure of its defending troops.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 -- A donation of $100,000 to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will be made by the Association of Motion Picture Producers to help the Academy meet operating expenses for the year, it was announced yesterday.

Next July 24 Ernest Bloch will be 75 years old. At that time there doubtless will be observances, musical and otherwise, of the gallant composer's birthday. Last night, at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Women's Hebrew Association, a group of musicians presented a pre-birthday program of Mr. Bloch's music that covered nearly all periods of his career.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 10 (AP) -- David Livingston of Lake Village, Ark., became a triple titleholder in the world outboard championships here today by defending one title and winning a new one.
DENVER, Oct. 10 -- President Eisenhower began today the final week of his eight-week work and play vacation.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The Duke of Kent, a first cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, spent thirty minutes of his nineteenth birthday yesterday in a punishment drill at the Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst.

Puccini's "Tosca" received its first presentation of the season by the New York City Opera Company Saturday night at the City Center. The title role was allotted to Wilma Spence, who returned to the troupe after an absence of four years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- "Public Power," the magazine of the American Public Power Association, charged today that the Dixon-Yates contract would provide a pattern for the "ultimate destruction" of the Tennessee Valley Authority's power program.

In your column of Oct. 4 a reader criticizes Regents examinations and, by implication, the current effort of the Board of Regents and the State Education Department to have these tests used more widely. Your correspondent-says:

The Soviet Union appears to be rolling up a record deficit in its trade with the free world this year. If the trend for the first half of 1954 continues, the Russians may spend almost $250,000,000 more in the non-Communist nations this year than the value of the goods they sell them.

DETROIT, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Detroit's defensive-minded Lions bottled up Los Angeles' attack and defeated the Rams, 21 -- 3, in a key National Football League game today before 56,523 fans in Briggs Stadium.

HANOI, Oct. 9 -- In taking over Hanoi from French troops today Vietminh forces made contact with big city life for the first time since late 1946. For nearly eight years troops of the Communist-dominated Democratic Republic of Vietnam have lived and fought in the jungles, mountains and rice field villages of Tonkin, while the French have held the cities and towns.

Hurtado de Cordoba and his Spanish Ballet opened last night at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre what is scheduled to be a four-week engagement, after what the program notes report as sensational successes in Europe and Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has denied time and again that he is shrinking the broad production base constructed at great cost and effort during the Korean War by his predecessors, General of the Army George C. Marshall and Robert A. Lovett.

The appointment of Nathaniel L. Goldstein, New York State Attorney General, as chairman of the Board of Overseers of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, now under construction in the Bronx as part of a new $100,000,000 Medical Center, was announced yesterday by Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of Yeshiva University.

NEWARK, Oct. 10 -- A young middle-of-the-road Eisenhower Republican is seeking to recapture the Tenth Congressional District in New Jersey. The district, once a Republican stronghold, went shakily for a Democratic Representative in 1948 and has gone solidly so since.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A Senate report said today that ten years of Communist terrorism had failed to stamp out the burning desire of millions of Poles for independence.
The trends in fashion fabrics are reflected in new yarns from some of the major yarn companies. Some new products already are in knitting shops and department stores; others will be shortly.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 2 -- The Government has lowered two kinds of special duties on imports, imposed by the previous regime, and stands to lose little less than $2,000,000 a year in revenues.
The ship charter market last week leveled off a bit in its steady climb of recent weeks. However, certain rate improvements encouraged onlookers to forecast continued smooth sailing.

LEWISTON, Idaho, Oct. 9 -- A dusty automobile draws up to a curb in an Idaho farming community and recorded band music pours from loudspeakers. When a group of listeners has assembled, the chauffeur, a businesslike man of 50, graying at the temples, climbs a ladder to a platform on the car roof.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- What is probably Chicago's heaviest rain on record drove thousands from their homes today, forced the Chicago River to overflow and pour into downtown skyscrapers and caused at least $10,000,000 damage.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 10 -- Public schools of New Bedford and Fairhaven must be kept open tomorrow, despite votes of the respective school committees to close them. Court injunctions to that effect were served on the individual committee members last night.
Four new films, including an import from England, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
