ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- The opening of a new link in the Buffalo-New York City Thruway on Oct. 26 will give the state the longest operating toll highway in the country.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 10 (UP) -Norman Brinker of Roswell, N.M., fiance of the tennis star Maureen Connolly, suffered a broken collarbone in the horse riding division of the world pentathlon championship today, but remounted and made three more jumps to finish eighteenth.
Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market drifted lower last week, chiefly as a result of crop reports that indicated a larger harvest than had been expected.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The New York Rangers defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game tonight as the Black Hawks opened their home season before 5,032 fans. The victory was the first of the season for the Rangers, who lost their opener to the Red Wings last night.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 10 -- The Stock average on Friday reached the year's high here at 206.54, as against 201.09 a week ago and this year's low of 169.20.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 -- Delegates to the Methodist National Conference on Family Life recommended today that the Methodist Church cooperate with other religious denominations in a campaign to elevate television and radio programs.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 10 -Following is the text of the summary prepared by the America Assembly of findings at its four-day session on the Federal Government service:
Deputy Chief Inspector Louis Goldberg is expected to tell today "the real story" of his demotion to captain and retirement from the Police Department following an anti-bingo drive.
Civilization can scarcely stand the strain put upon it without spiritual help, the Rev. Dr. Hermann N. Morse said yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 10 -- Painstaking police work resulted in the arrest last night of a suspect in a hit-and-run accident in which Cpl. Luis A. Aflleje, 23 year old, of the Suffolk Air Force Base, was killed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, is scouring the country for a man who will give a "fresh approach" to hiring and dismissing at the Treasury.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 (UP) -Top-seeded Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert, defending champion, led the way today into the quarter-finals of the men's singles as the Pan-American tennis play resumed after a two-day delay forced by rain.

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 10 -Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator, asserted here today that President Eisenhower had "made more solid gains in the area of foreign policy in his first twenty months in office than the Democrats had in twenty years."

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 10 (UP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt always has preferred giving parties to attending them but she indulgently obliged her children tonight by letting them give her a seventieth birthday party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -The Air Force is expected to start work soon on a $30,000,000 laboratory at East Hartford, Conn., to help in developing an atomic airplane engine.

The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said that "to htry to break down barriers of misunderstanding and hostility by offering friendship is the Christian way to make peace."
The shirtwaist dress, once thought of as a strictly casual style, now appears in countless interpretations.

At 8 o'clock this evening when the curtain rises at "On Your Toes," the younger generation will observe at the Forty-sixth Street what delighted their elders eighteen years ago. In its first revival here since then, the show has music by Richard Rodgers, lyrics by Lorenz Hart and a plot from Messrs.
"La Traviata," with Laurel Hurley singing Violetta for the first time with the company, was yesterday afternoon's bill.

KITCHENER, Ont., Oct. 10 -- A thousand Lutherans from the United States went to church here this morning and later shared a Canadian Thanksgiving Day dinner as house guests of their fellow churchmen in this strongly Lutheran community.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 10 (AP) -Early returns in Guatemala's oral plebiscite gave President Carlos Castillo Armas an overwhelming vote of approval today. The voters had to step up and utter a loud "aye" or "nay."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Democratic candidates are reported leading, as of now, in nineteen of the thirty-three campaigns for Governor being waged across the nation.

Eighty-eight college football teams, headed by little Peru (Neb.) State and the University of Oklahoma, came through the week-end with undefeated-untied records, a United Press survey showed yesterday.
HARRINGTON, Del., Oct. 10 -- Bryant W. Bowles, founder of the National Association for the Advancement of White People, was arrested here today.

When the governors of the two Bretton Woods Institutions -- the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development -hold their week-long joint annual meeting each fall, almost invariably the doings of the fund capture most of the headlines.

MARTINSVILLE, Va., Oct. 10 -- The Virginia convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People adjourned this evening on a note of "uncompromising insistence" on the constitutional rights of Negroes.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 10 -The Dallas (Texas) polo team defeated Old Westbury, 6 -- 4, in the final round of the sixteen-goal Autumn Plates tournament on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

ROEBLING, N.J., Oct. 10 -Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, asked today why President Eisenhower and Senator Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois had not come to New Jersey to speak in behalf of the candidate's Republican opponent, Clifford P. Case.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10 -- Unlike most of New York, London or Paris, Moscow does not shut up shop on Sunday. On the contrary, all the stores open for the convenience of the working people and today they were doing a roaring business.

For several years past you have been kind enough to print my letter asking for volunteer workers at the Welfare Island Dispensary, located at 535 East Eightieth Street. The need is more urgent than ever, since our attendance has increased from 1,000 to 1,400 patients daily.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Jim Lee Howell's New York football Giants put the emphasis on attack today and romped to a 51-21 victory over the Washington Redskins at Griffith Stadium.
Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of Columbia University's Faculty of Medicine, terms the family physician the "keystone" to adequate health services.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly, today called Liberal party endorsement of Democratic state candidates "political chicanery and political fakery."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Senator Homer Capehart, Republican of Indiana, today demanded a thorough housecleaning of the Federal Housing Administration and said he had written President Eisenhower offering to introduce legislation making it legally possible.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- A number of suggestions for improving the Federal Government service was offered today by the Sixth American Assembly.

One hundred years ago this day one of Fifth Avenue's great churches was dedicated. The Marble Collegiate Church, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, built of Hastings marble chipped out by hand, is noteworthy for various features of architecture and construction, without steel, but even more for its vigorous ministry whose influence has been felt far beyond the borders of city and state.

INWOOD, L.I., Oct. 10 -- The Garden City Country Club No. 1 team of Don Cherry, Frank Strafaci, Harry Opsahl and John Dobbs, took the Long Island Golf Association team title with 306 at the Inwood Country Club today.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 -- Two of the Guatemalans whose extradition from Mexico has been sought by the Guatemalan Government asked President Carlos Castillo Armas today for visas to return voluntarily "to defend our good name."
The program Marjorie Hamill put together for her Town Hall debut recital yesterday in the late afternoon was indicative of musical taste and enterprise.

DEDICATED to the presentation of serious drama as a form of worship, the Broadway Chapel Players, appearing in the Broadway Tabernacle Church (Congregational), at Fifty-sixth Street, have demonstrated for the second time that their work is fully a admirable as their intentions.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 10 -- Dr. Hossein Fatemi, once one of the most powerful men in Iran as former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's Foreign Minister, was condemned to death today for rebellion against the monarchy.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Oct. 10 (UP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said today that Chinese Nationalist preparations for a counter-attack against the Communist-held mainland were almost complete and the battle of liberation should begin in the foreseeable future.

Trailing, 14 -- 0, as the final quarter began, St. John's Prep scored three quick touchdowns to defeat Cardinal Hayes, 18 -- 14, in Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. The victory was St. John's Prep's second in three Catholic League starts.

I am indeed saddened by the glee with which so many Americans welcome the fact that Germany is about to be rearmed. This is not a mere matter of arming a nation to help us guard against Russian aggression. The fact that we possess atomic and hydrogen type bombs is enough to deter any thinking people from any actions which would precipitate a war.

The special subcommittee of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, headed by Representative John H. Ray, Staten Island Republican, announced here yesterday that it would keep its records open for two weeks more.

Perhaps the most important thing about the just-concluded meeting of the Colombo Plan nations in Ottawa was the enlargement of the group. Japan, Thailand and the Philippines were formally admitted as member states in this organization, whose primary purpose is to foster development in areas of need, particularly in the Far East.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Last week it was remarked that although the stock market boom was growing old and its demise had been prophesied in some quarters, it was by no means dead yet and still was capable of a vigorous existence.

Regardless of whether the Democrats or the Republicans win control of New York State next month, one result of the election is clearly predictable. Bingo, which poured thousands and thousands of dollars into the treasuries of churches and other organizations while the police looked the other way, will be brought into the open and voted upon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Activity on the Board of Trade increased in wheat, oats and rye last week, while purchases of corn and soybeans fell off rather sharply. The soybean trade was still the most active, being nearly double the volume of wheat, but purchases of soybeans were about 27,000,000 bushels less than the previous week.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Y.A. Tittle, his broken left hand encased in a special cast, went into the game in the fourth period today and led the San Francisco Forty-niners in a two-touchdown rally that beat the Green Bay Packers, 23 -- 17.
With its victory over Texas, Oklahoma is sitting on top of the college football world. Bud Wilkinson has excellent prospects now of bringing the Sooners through their schedule without a setback.

DETROIT, Oct. 10 -- Record or near-record voter registrations in Detroit and other Michigan industrial centers were interpreted last week as enhancing Democratic chances in the Nov. 2 elections. Registration ended Monday.
VIENNA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Russia successfully defended its team title in the world weightlifting championships today, topping the runner-up United States by six points.

PARIS, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The General Motors Corporation announced today a European expansion program amounting to more than $182,000,000. And Harlow H. Curtice, president, here on a 2,500-mile inspection trip, said additional projects were under consideration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today that he would vote to dismiss censure charges against Senator McCarthy. He estimated that the Senate would spend "thirty days" on the censure debate.
The nation's Founding Fathers probably were the greatest group of intellectual giants since those of ancient Greece, Herman Wouk, author of "The Caine Mutiny," said yesterday.

HONG KONG, Oct. 10 (AP) -Ceylon's Minister of Commerce, Trade and Fisheries, G.C.S. Corea, said here today that Communist China was offering 27 pence (about 32 cents) a pound for Ceylon's rubber. That price is 7 pence (about 8 cents) higher than the world market price.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 -- Veteran Republicans are counting Vice President Richard M. Nixon their most effective campaigner, text to the President himself.
Trial of the $11,000,000 suit of Arnold Bernstein against the Holland-America Line resumes this morning in Federal Court after a vacation recess of five weeks.
PARIS, Oct. 10 -- The National Assembly's vote Tuesday for the London accord on arming West Germany will be taken with some misgivings and not much enthusiasm.

Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson, who died in Washington on Saturday at the age of 62, will be remembered for the vigor, the incisiveness and the clarity of his thinking as a judge; for the passionate earnestness of his prosecution of the Nazi leaders at the Nuremberg trials; and to a lesser extent as a usually successful defender of New Deal legislation before the Supreme Court when he was Solicitor General under President Roosevelt.
ABOARD U.S.S. CORAL SEA, Off Valencia, Spain, Oct. 10 -- The United States Sixth Fleet put on an eight-hour performance for Generalissimo Francisco Franco today.
The six-story loft building at 100-102 Worth Street has figured in a quick resale.
In "Videotown," people are going back to the movies, Cunningham Walsh, Inc., has discovered.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 10 (UP) -The vice president of Lamb Industries, Inc., has claimed victory in the company's fight for control of the majority stock in the Air-Way Electric Appliance Corporation.
SANTA FE, N.M., Oct. 10 -- The three cultures of ancient New Mexico -- "Anglo," Spanish-American and tribal Indian -- seem not very stirred as this state's Senatorial campaign enters the final phase.

The gypsum industry has achieved a healthy post-war growth in spite of a passive attitude toward fundamental product research, according to what is described as the first management audit ever made of an entire industry.

PAUL HORGAN, who comes from Buffalo, N.Y., lost his heart to the Southwest in 1920 when he enrolled as a student in the New Mexico Military Institute. In the thirty-four years since then Mr. Horgan has written many books about the Southwest, both novels and history. His most ambitious is "Great River: The Rio Grande in North American History,"* which is published today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Except for rye, the general tone was strong on the Board of Trade last week. Wheat showed modest gains, while there were more impressive gains in corn and oats. The reaction in rye was substantial. Soybean futures moved up after early declines.
A massive and colorful religious service -- one of the largest in the city's history -- was held yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds.

Camara Laye, a 26-year-old native of French Guinea, was reared among the Malinke, one of the few secret ritual societies remaining in central Africa. He was chosen by the French Government for advanced technical training in Paris.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- More than 10,000,000 readers throughout Britain will go without newspapers today, and no evening national papers -- The Star, The Evening Standard and The Evening News are main ones -- will be published this afternoon.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 10 (UP) -- Thirty-two major league baseball players have signed to tour the country as members of "Jimmy Foxx's Baseball Stars on Parade" in an effort to combat juvenile delinquency by "preaching the gospel of baseball."

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Aneurin Bevan, left-wing Laborite, assailed Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden tonight for having committed four British Army divisions to the defense of Continental Europe and for having moved to arm West Germany.

VIENNA, Oct. 10 -- Vasile Luca, former Deputy Premier of Rumania, has been condemned to death for economic sabotage, but his sentence has been reduced to life imprisonment, according to an announcement tonight by the Bucharest radio.
The Rev. Dr. Frederick Myers Morris became yesterday the tenth rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church. He was the first to be instituted there in twenty-eight years.
LES BOULES, Que., Oct. 10 -The world's largest submarine power cable system was officially opened here today by Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec.
A "new look" has been given the official position of Federal postal authorities on strike-bound mail in New York Harbor.
A congregation of 2,150 persons yesterday filled Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, to celebrate its 100th anniversary.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A rich new supply of strategic sulphur will soon be developed in Venezuela by the United States-owned Venezuelan Sulphur Corporation, it was announced here yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- A slight increase in lower level wages and a decrease in the cost of power (coal, electricity and fuel oil) are to be decided by the Government before the end of the month, according to an announcement by the Ministry of Finances.

TOKYO, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Heinrich Will led Germany's track team to a smashing victory over Japan today with a javelin throw of 253 feet, one of the best marks in the world this year. The world record of 263 feet 10 inches, is held by Bud Held of the United States.

Ceremonies at the beginning of the twenty-fifth anniversary year of New York's Museum of Modern Art will be carried from 10:30 to 11 P.M., on Tuesday, Oct. 19, over WCBS and the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network.
The man who boasts he can turn out a steak better than anyone else he knows can show off his talent in an attractive setting at the new Charcoal Room, 848 Second Avenue.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- The Herreshoff S. Class fleet of Long Island Sound today regained the Tiffany Trophy with a 91 1/2-74 1/4 victory over Narragansett Bay skippers in their annual three-race team series off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 10 (UP) -- J.R. Wiggins, managing editor of The Washington Post and Times Herald, said today, that there was a growing tendency to keep facts from the American people that was threatening this nation's form of Government and way of life.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The United States Supreme Court will meet tomorrow to eulogize Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson, who died here yesterday of a heart attack.
WINDSOR, Ont., Oct. 10 (AP) -Fifty-seven hundred workers struck at the Ford Motor Company plant here tonight to back up demands for a new contract. They went out at 10 P.M.

Richard S. Childs, vice chairman of the Citizens Union, in his letter published Oct. 6 very accurately described the manner and method of choosing judges in Greater New York. He pointed out that judges are not actually elected by the voters, but by political party leaders, who do not pick them because of their learning.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The Chicago Bears, scoring twice on passes, once on an intercepted pass and again on a blocked punt, overpowered the Baltimore Colts today, 28-9, before 27,845 fans who sat through a steady drizzle.

It is remarkable that the platforms of both parties contain planks, dealing with juvenile delinquency, and more so that one party deals With the situation as it is affected by the need for better detention and long-term placement facilities as well as the expansion and improvement of probation services.

A standard prop in any well-run office is the umbrella someone has left in the metal coat closet. It is obviously an old umbrella, sturdy and, despite its faded color, really much too serviceable to be thrown out.
Parents have themselves to blame when children talk back, according to Dr. Ralph K. Meister, director of the Mooseheart Laboratory for Children.

Many must have watched with interest and admiration, as we have, the steadily growing and always constructive influence of the League of Women Voters. The organization has won the respect of both political parties for its scrupulous nonpartisanship.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Britain s big nationally circulated newspapers suspended publication early today as a result of a strike of printers against The Daily Sketch. Most newspapers printed country and London editions and then shut down shortly after midnight.

The Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams was installed yesterday as minister of the Park Avenue Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) at Eighty-fifth Street. The church simultaneously celebrated its 144th anniversary.
President Eisenhower paid tribute yesterday to the memory of Wendell L. Willkie, for whom a special service of remembrance was conducted at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

ALLENDALE, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Kimberling, a 9-year-old bay gelding owned by the Kimperton (Pa.) Hills Farms, captured the working hunter championship as the fifth annual two-day horse show, for the benefit of the Bergen County cerebral palsy center, ended today at Recreation Park.

Fresh thinking and fresh efforts are needed for a satisfactory solution of the city's housing problems, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday. He announced that he was forming a Mayor's Committee for Better Housing to help him find the answers.

JAMES HETHERINGTON was hired at the New York race tracks eight years ago as recall man. He gets $12 each racing day to wave a white cloth flag to recall horses if the starting gate should foul and release some but not all of them.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 10 (UP) -- South Vietnam's long smoldering Government crisis broke into the open again today when Premier Ngo Dinh Diem announced his refusal to receive into his Cabinet Gen. Nguyen Van Xuan.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 10 -- Sir Winston Churchill, in high gear as a practicing politician and statesman, is one of the sights of the age. But in Blackpool he is just another attraction. Blackpool, its boosters say, has everything and, to dazed Americans, they seem pretty nearly right.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 10 -- Statistics just published indicate that West Germany has become one of the most news-literate nations in the world in the five years since the Allied licensing of the press was terminated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The Washington Redskins lost their third consecutive game today, but they gave music lovers a thrill with professional football's first symphony orchestra concert.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, citing success of the first "New York Summer Festival" as a business stimulant, announced yesterday that the bureau planned to enlist wide business and industry support for a "stepped-up" summer festival program next year.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson predicted tonight the Democrats would win control of the House of Representatives in November "by thirty or forty seats."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- The United States intends to "do something" about a pamphlet that advises employes of the United Nations to place their loyalty to the international organization ahead of that to their own countries.

THE National Broadcasting Company's series of color "spectaculars" is running into deeper trouble. Last night's ninety-minute attraction, "Sunday in Town," was as labored and heavy-handed a show as seen in many a day.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 10 -- Benny Howarth, head football coach at St. Mark's, and Jake McCandless, his assistant, were having one of those football gabfests today in the McCandless living room. The television set was tuned to a re-run of last week's U.C.L.A.-Maryland game.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII greeted more than 10,000 pilgrims who braved a light drizzle today to crowd into the central square of this village near Rome.
ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- The opening of a new link in the Buffalo-New York City Thruway on Oct. 26 will give the state the longest operating toll highway in the country.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 10 (AP) -The Coast Guard late today abandoned its wide-ranging sea and air search for further survivors of the freighter Mormackite.

Alyne Dumas Lee gave her third New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The soprano from Chicago had prepared an unusually interesting program, but one which proved too ambitious for her present equipment as vocalist and interpreter.

Despite gains in population in the last eighty years, the number of persons engaged in agriculture has risen but 1 per cent, according to a study on "The Growth of Physical Capital in Agriculture: 1870-1950" by Alvin S. Tostlebe, published today by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, the Democratic National Chairman, today challenged President Eisenhower's contention that the election of a Democratic Congress would lead to "a cold war of partisan politics."

Arthur Stockstrom has announced that on Nov. 1 he will turn over the presidency of Magic Chef, Inc., to Cecil M. Dunn, former president of R.C.A.-Estate Appliance Corporation, a division of Radio Corporation of America. Mr. Stockstrom will become board chairman.
St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday marked the seventy-fifth anniversary of its dedication with a pontifical mass of thanksgiving.
The practice of city firemen holding spare-time outside jobs, long tolerated even though it is against Fire Department rules, will receive formal sanction beginning tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns patched their pass protection pocket with a rookie fullback today, and it paid off with a 31-7 victory over the Chicago Cardinals in a rain-swept National Football League game before 24,101 in the Lakefront Stadium.
A symposium on mariners' contribution to knowledge will be held at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., tomorrow evening.

VIENNA, Oct. 10 -- Many members of the Hungarian Communist party were accused today by the Communist central newspaper Szabad Nep of the serious Communist crimes of "left deviationism and sectionalism." They had opposed Moscow's new policy of sponsoring "national fronts."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Franklin Institute of Pennsylvania said today it was awarding its highest scientific award -- the internationally known Franklin Medal -- to Dr. C.E. Kenneth Mees of Rochester, N.Y.

Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Joe Jones won the $25,050 Vosburgh Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Stymie, profiting by the crafty jockeying of Conn McCreary, moved between horses in the stretch to score by two lengths over Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Pet Bully.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Top-seeded Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, still playing far below the form that carried him to the United States singles title last month, was upset by the Mexican champion, Mario Llamas, 6 -- 2, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4, in the Pan-American tennis championships today.

The research council of the American Bankers Association has just published a new study which it hopes will dispel some of the confusion in the banking world over what constitutes sufficient capital funds.

Gloria Strassner, 'cellist, played a debut recital at Town Hall last evening. A product of the Juilliard School, Miss Strassner won a Fulbright Fellowship and a Leventritt grant for study abroad after her graduation in 1951, and in 1952 was solo 'cellist with the Baltimore Symphony.

Floyd Patterson, Brooklyn's contender for the light-heavyweight championship, outpunched Esau Ferdinand of San Francisco in the main bout of eight rounds at St. Nicholas Arena last night. Patterson weighed 169 1/4 pounds, three more than Ferdinand.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The banks of the Thames were lined today with gray steel cranes pointing silently skyward from London Bridge eleven miles downriver to Gallions Reach.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Army and Air Force revealed today the deadly potency of the "nerve gases," which can paralyze and kill in a few minutes. The services warned soldiers that their chances for survival depended upon speedy protection.

Rising retail coffee prices were called to the attention of the Federal Trade Commission about a year ago. The price of roasted coffee continued to rise until last Aug. 16 when the market broke sharply.
"Open House," an Arthur E. (Red) Patterson production designed to promote -- or provoke -- off-season interest in the Dodgers, had its premiere yesterday.
The operating deficit of St. Luke's Hospital amounted to $1,517,681 for 1953, J. Stewart Baker, the president, reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- A one-day tempest over the loyalties of United Nations employes apparently came to an end today.

BAYVILLE, L.I., Oct. 11 -- According to Bart Allen, you "could shoot scoters from a coal barge," and after spending three hours bobbing around in a gleaming car-top boat we are convinced that nothing that floats would frighten a "coot."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11 -- Maxwell Shane, the writer-director, has completed arrangements to make "The Brass Ring" in association with Edward Small, independent producer. Mr. Shane, who directed Tony Curtis' first important screen appearance in "City Across the River" for Universal, hopes to be able to borrow the star for the new film.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today reported a slight improvement in crop prospects in September, raising the total volume to a tie with 1951 for the country's fifth largest.
Parks Commissioner Robert Moses was attacked yesterday at a City Hall hearing on the 1955 capital budget as one who qualified himself as a recreation expert because he played water polo at college.

In The Times of Oct. 7 in the story of the meeting of the Regional Plan Association marking its twenty-fifth anniversary mention was made of the presentation of the association's first award to Lawson Purdy, 91-year-old first chairman of its board of directors.
OKINAWA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The United States Military Government cracked down today on Leftist members of the Okinawa Legislature.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Soybean futures made a big response to the unfavorable weather, registering gains in the early trade and holding strong throughout the session. Rain fell in most of the area where soybeans are yet unharvested, and will cause substantial delay in combining the remainder of the crop.

Senator Irving M. Ives, the Republican candidate for Governor, labeled his Democratic-Liberal opponent as a novice in state government last night. He said the state was too important and had too many complex problems to be turned over to one who did not understand its needs.
The dramatic design took the spotlight in a fashion show given last night at the presentation of the annual Coty American Fashion Critics Award in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A direct clash on veracity developed yesterday when former Deputy Chief Inspector Louis Goldberg -- two days after his retirement freed him from police rules of silence -- began telling his version of the events that led to his demotion to captain.
Pre-war Hungary -- if a valid conclusion may be drawn from but two examples -- had some excellent amateur cooks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Government today urged companies and workers involved in the Utah copper strike to end the month-long walkout and submit the dispute to a fact-finding board.

MANILA, Oct. 11 -- President Ramon Magsaysay's repudiation of the $400,000,000 reparations settlement with Japan has not produced, the expected resignation of Vice President Carlos Garcia as Foreign Minister.

Heavy liquidation yesterday sent wool prices into the sharpest decline in several years on the New York Cotton Exchange. The general liquidation touched off stop-loss ordering which further lowered prices. Tops fell 4.4 to 6.2 cents a pound and grease wool was down 4.1 to 5.5 cents.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The State Department reported today that it was making "outstanding progress" in reorganization, integration and unification.

International Cellucotton Products Company of Chicago announced yesterday an internal reorganization of its British subsidiary, Cellucotton Products, Ltd. Under the new arrangement, Kimberly-Clark Corporation of Neenah, Wis., manufacturer of paper and other cellulose products; Albert E. Reed Co., Ltd., paper and paper products concern in England, and International Cellucotton have each become owners of one-third of the stock of the reorganized company.
WINDSOR, Ont., Oct. 11 -- Members of the United Auto Workers International Union took up their vigil outside the Windsor plant of Ford of Canada today to enforce a strike.
Ten off-duty patrolmen from Precincts 10, 14 and 16 took seats around a scarred ping-pong table at Hudson Guild Neighborhood House yesterday afternoon for a course in utilitarian Spanish.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Mr. Reuther suggested to President Eisenhower today that Mr. Wilson retract certain statements he was quoted on in the Detroit press conference or retire from public life.

ARTHUR KOESTLER, the doom-haunted Hungarian who has written some of the most eloquent political literature of our time, has two major subjects that interest him equally: the nature and menace of communism and the fascination and wonder of his own personality -- so emotionally unstable and so obsessed by dogmas and theories.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Soviet-Chinese Communist communique broadcast by the Moscow radio:

Secretary of State John Foster Dulles praised the Italian nation last night for the "important contribution" it had made to the solution of the Trieste question -- "one of the most difficult and dangerous problems of our time."

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Tinker Air Force Base evacuated its hospital tonight during a violent storm with wind gusts of up to eighty miles an hour, hail the size of golf balls and at least one tornado.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 11 -- Sale of a 120-acre meadowland tract along Humboldt Avenue by the Central Railroad of New Jersey for a multimillion-dollar industrial development was announced today by Earl T. Moore, president of the Central.

Out of a total of nearly two and a half million federal civil service employes the Eisenhower Administration has "separated" 1,743 with "information in their files indicating, in varying degrees, subversive associations or membership in subversive organizations.''

Fire Commissioner Cavanagh has announced a change in the rules of the department to allow any fireman to work on an outside job during his off hours -- provided this "does not conflict with his duties or impair his efficiency as a fire fighter or compromise the department."

RICHMOND, Calif., Oct. 11 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon opened a three-day political tour of his home state today in a Congressional district where the Republicans believe they have an excellent chance to displace a Democrat.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- The new seven-nation European defense organization under which West Germany will be armed got a name today, the Western European Union.

The chain store has won popular approval and will, in the future, take an ever increasing share of the American retail food dollar, the twenty-first annual meeting of the National Association of Food Chains heard yesterday.

Streets leading to the Plaza Hotel were jammed with parked private cars and double-parked delivery trucks yesterday. And after struggling to the meeting of the American Management Association's forum on manufacturing, members of the 20,000-strong organization heard that street traffic everywhere would be better if they scheduled movement of goods across their shipping platforms as well as they did to and from their assembly lines.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 11 -- After twenty-two years in the political wilderness the Liberal party has recaptured the Presidency of Honduras.

Italians are joining with Americans today in celebrations in honor of the great discoverer, Christopher Columbus. In an old palace at Via Garibaldi 3 in Genoa, the reputed city of his birth, an annual party is scheduled for this afternoon in the Italo-American Association's center there.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Screaming prisoners of the South Dakota State Penitentiary here began rioting tonight. The convicts were holding three guards as hostages.
BUFFALO, Oct. 11 -- The Public Health Cancer Association today adopted a resolution urging people to stop smoking cigarettes, with the aim of reducing lung cancer.

WELLSBURG, W.Va., Oct. 11 (AP) -- A hearing on an injunction to halt sale of Follansbee Steel Corporation recessed today with the judge saying no evidence presented so far gives him grounds to intervene.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold defended his plan for the reorganization of the United Nations Secretariat today against criticism leveled by the budget "watchdog" committee.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Tuesday, Oct. 12 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, chief fighter for white supremacy in Africa, announced today that he would resign on Nov. 30.

NEWARK, Oct. 11 -- A spirited campaign between two strong candidates, both of Italian-American extraction, promises to be so close in New Jersey's Eleventh Congressional District that political observers hesitate to predict the outcome on Nov. 2.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 -- The fifty-fifth season of The Philadelphia Orchestra opened tonight in the Academy of Music, two concerts behind schedule because of a wage dispute.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Industrials were in good demand today. The best gains went to high-class equities but in general the undertone was firm.
DENVER, Oct. 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today ordered new import fees on almonds and filberts to protect the domestic market.
Behind-the-scenes Chinese-Soviet differences have apparently been at least temporarily smoothed over by the agreement announced yesterday. But concessions were the price Moscow has had to pay.

The violence which accompanied the desegregation of some of the public schools in Baltimore and Washington may have shocked many good Americans who favor social changes except when they involve physical violence.
Mrs. Robert F. Wagner took part yesterday in the dedication of new nursery school facilities at the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, 1880 Broadway.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Burma served notice today that she would use military force if necessary to deal with 6,000 Nationalist Chinese Guerrillas along her northern border.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Frank (Pinky) Higgins, the quiet Texan who had insisted on starting his managerial career at the bottom, today reached the top with his appointment as field boss of the Boston Red Sox.

The Hartford County, Conn., Metropolitan District announced yesterday plans for the sale of $4,500,000 of water and sewer bonds on Oct. 27. Of the total borrowing, $3,000,000 will be on two issues of water bonds maturing serially over forty years.

The State Congress of Industrial Organizations announced yesterday that it had endorsed the Democratic candidates for state office. It will stage a series of at least five and possibly more state-wide telecasts on their behalf.
"Fragile Fox," a war melodrama based on the personal experiences of its author, Norman A. Brooks, in World War II opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Belasco Theatre.

At a time when the international Communist conspiracy is making all free nations increasingly sensitive about the problems of loyalty and security an unnecessary issue has been raised in the United Nations concerning the responsibilities of its officials and employes to the world organization and their loyalty to their respective countries.
Most security and commodity markets throughout the country will follow the lead of the New York Stock Exchange and remain open today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass, Oct. 11 -- A 44-yeal-old expert on epidemic diseases has been appointed dean of the School of Public Health at Harvard University.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Winds increased over Haiti, eastern Jamaica and extreme eastern Cuba late today as Hurricane Hazel pushed north northeastward in the Caribbean.

EIGHTEEN years is a trifle old for "On Your Toes." The revival, which opened at the Forty-sixth Street last evening, serves to remind us of some of the facts of life. All of us remember that "On Your Toes" has a celebrated ballet, called "Slaughter on Tenth Avenue."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Following are excerpts from statements by Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State; Jules Moch, French delegate, and Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, in debate today before the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee on atomic proposals:
The United States economy, transferred into a stable, resilient and efficient one this year, should enjoy healthy growth in 1955, commercial finance executives were told yesterday.
PALISADES, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- In a quiet grove of oak trees here, just back from the Hudson River, man is coming to grips with the problem of finding 960,000 missing years.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 -- Industrial growth of the lower Delaware River Valley, which has been at an annual rate of $400,000,000 since 1949, will continue unabated.

MONROE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Averell Harriman appealed today to his Orange County neighbors for support in his bid for the Governorship, declaring, "It's what your friends and neighbors think that really counts."
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 11 (AP) -- France got into Laurel's international horse race today with Banassa, a 4-year-old filly that ran second to Sica Boy in the Arc de Triompe at Longchamp on Oct. 3.
DENVER, Oct. 11 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today by recess appointment named Gerald A. Drew, career Foreign Service officer since 1927, as the new United States Ambassador to Bolivia.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 -- The issue of desegregation of the public schools has come rapidly to the fore in the Maryland elections, following disturbances here that reached a peak last week, but now virtually have ended.

STONY POINT, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- A paroled convict who was quoted as saying he would "shoot it out" at the risk of his life rather than return to prison was captured here today by a state police corporal.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 11 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell defended today the handling of the nation's economy by the Republican Administration and asserted that the problem of going from war to peace conditions was being met successfully.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Mary E. Switzer, director of the Office of Vocational Rehabilitation, today announced that a new national program to train personnel in rehabilitation of the distabled would be inaugurated Oct. 18 at the Institute for Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, New York City.

AMONG the art exhibitions opening yesterday is one of recent paintings by Charles G. Shaw, at the Passedoit Gallery. While several of the canvases continue to exploit a vein Shaw has made familiar in the last two or three shows -- the use of color shapes in harmony to indicate a psychological mood rather than representation proper -- a number of the new paintings reveal an extension of aims.

"Yes," in answer to a rhetorical question by a recent correspondent, it is "really possible that the U.N. is still taken seriously" by many people. Not only are there many Americans who look upon the U.N. as our nation's best hope for a long-range peaceful world, but millions of people in all parts of the world share this faith.
The Campbell Kids are 50 years old, although they don't look it.

Guatemala has just had what could only by courtesy be called an election and a plebiscite. The voters, for the most part, had to stand before an electoral board and shout "Yes" or "No." In the present state of affairs, so soon after the anti-Communist revolution, it was hardly to be expected that more than a few hardy souls would step up and say "No" to the candidacy of President Castillo Armas.
DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- The Chrysler Corporation has "put $250,000,000 on the line" in creating its 1955 cars, Lester L. Colbert, president of the company, said today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 11 -The rigid import control policy designed to hasten Pakistan's transition from an all-agricultural to a semi-industrial economy has paid off.
The nation's steel mills are scheduled to operate this week at 72.3 per cent of theoretical capacity, which is calculated to produce 1,724,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings.

Eduard van Beinum and Rafael Kubelik, conductors of the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra, were formally greeted by Mayor Wagner yesterday in a brief ceremony at City Hall. The conductors and the 107 members of the orchestra landed yesterday morning for a tour of forty-three concerts in the United States and Canada.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins, using an aggressive, spirited style of play, battled the Montreal Canadiens to a 2-2 deadlock in their 1954 home National Hockey League opener tonight before 10,377 fans.
For two hours yesterday afternoon there was more joy packed into Madison Square Garden than perhaps could have been found in all the rest of New York.

WATERVILLE, Me., Oct. 11 -- J. Seelye Bixler, president of Colby College, announced today that J. Russell Wiggins, managing editor of The Washington Post and Times-Herald, had been selected as the 1954 Lovejoy Fellow at the college.
HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 10 -- Residents turned out today to join in dawn-to-dusk celebrations of the Vietminh take-over of Hanoi.
PARIS, Oct. 11 -- The London accord to arm West Germany was assured of approval by the French National Assembly when the Socialist National Council decided tonight to support it.

TORONTO, Oct.11 -- After a tense debate, the nineteenth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America agreed today to reconsider an earlier action curtailing the powers of its executive board. The vote for reconsideration was 366 to 204.

POMFRET, Conn., Oct. 11 -- Pomfret School's football squad, victorious over Gunnery in its opener last week, meets Kingswood School at West Hartford Saturday and Bill Parquette, the new Maroon-and-White coach, is looking for the unexpected.

Decorative fashion begins at the door in a new model house that will be opened today in the furniture showrooms of the Selwyn-Pomeroy Company, 824 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. There is an admission charge of $1 for the benefit of the Children's Day and Night Shelter in Brooklyn.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Oct. 11 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, today repeated his pledge to continue the farm price support program.
Princeton's football coach, Charlie Caldwell, indicated yesterday that he had not changed his convictions concerning certain current rules of the game.
Bingo was an important source of revenue to many religious, educational and welfare organizations in New York City until the police stopped winking at it and began frowning on it last month.
The money market was firmer yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 1 1/4 per cent before closing at 1 per cent.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 -- Following an abusive campaign against Generalissimo Francisco France in the officially controlled press, the Spanish Embassy has canceled a reception honoring the "Day of the Race" -- a celebration of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11 -The nation's gas utility and pipeline industry will spend more than $3,500,000,000 in the next four years for construction and expansion with 90 per cent of the expenditures going into natural gas systems.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt celebrated her seventieth birthday last night at a party that typified her life by compressing many activities into a short time.
UNION, N.J., Oct. 11 -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks made a strong plea here tonight for the election of Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The dispute that had caused the first shutdown of London newspapers since the 1926 general strike was settled this evening in time for the printing of tomorrow morning's newspapers.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 11 -- Dr. William Carlos Williams, one of the country's leading poets, today accused the Library of Congress of resorting to phantom disloyalty charges in an attempt to bar him from a poetry consultant's post that he had been invited to take.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman urged Brooklyn Democratic district leaders yesterday to roll up a huge plurality for the state ticket in Kings County so that the party candidates would be easy victors in the Nov. 2 election.

Two officials of a stevedoring concern told the Waterfront Commission yesterday that work stoppages had occurred recently on their Hoboken piers after they had refused to select a hiring boss proposed by the independent International Longshoremen's Association.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- After ten years of occupation Soviet military forces will evacuate the Chinese naval base of Port Arthur in 1955, the Moscow and Peiping Governments announced tonight in a joint declaration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Sir David Maxwell Fyfe, British Home Secretary, said today Britain had tightened some of its security procedures following disclosure of several risks in high places.

In summing up yesterday before a Federal Court jury in the seditious conspiracy trial of thirteen leaders of the Puerto Rican Nationalist party, defense counsel contended that the Government had failed to prove that the defendants had sought to overthrow the United States Government by force.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, made a tour of Manhattan yesterday starting at 207th Street and Broadway in a bus called the "Javits Bandwagon." He stopped off in the afternoon at seven points to make street corner speeches.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Robert J. Kane, director of athletics, said today that Cornell would lodge a complaint with the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials against an official's ruling during last Saturday's 13 -- 12 loss to Harvard.

Times have changed and business has flourished since the first United States Assay Office was established at 30 Wall Street a century ago. Superintendent Charles E. Dusenberry remarked yesterday, on the anniversary, that the "few millions" paid out and received during the first full year of operations was now "but a small day's work."
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 11 (UP) -- A Coast Guard board of inquiry convened today to determine why the freighter Mormackite sank so suddenly in the stormy Atlantic with the loss of thirty-seven lives.

ROME, Oct. 11 -- Arturo Toscanini will conduct one last opera before definitely laying down his baton. He will not, however, revisit the United States, where he had lived off and on for the last twenty-five years and had conducted the National Broadcasting Company Symphony Orchestra for the last seventeen years.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 5 to 17 points (25 to 85 cents a bale) net lower on active months.

THIS is the day when the American League must make up its mind what to do with its chief white elephant, the Philadelphia Athletics. The carcass has to be hauled away to Kansas City for a complete reincarnation job or left to rot where it is. It's as simple as that even though the club owners ducked the issue a fortnight ago and postponed any action until today.
BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- The right of Massachusetts school committees to close schools to allow teachers and pupils to attend a religious education convention will be tested in court.

Women headed by Mrs. Lewis Armstrong and including Mrs. Norbert A. McKenna and Mrs. Norbert A. Bogdan are furthering the success of the dinner dance and wine tasting, known as the Goddard Gala, to be held next Monday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
MUNSAN, Korea, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The United Nations command asked the Communists today to make a further search for 700 Allied war dead unaccounted for in last month's exchange of bodies.

The man who is popularly thought to have been the first visitor from the Old World to set foot on the New was not rewarded for his achievement and did not even know what he had accomplished. When Christopher Columbus sighted the Western Hemisphere 462 years ago today he was convinced that he had found a new route to Asia -- not a new world.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- The twice-postponed Westchester County Golf Association pro-and-amateur championship finished in a tie today when two pairs posted gross best-ball scores of 33, 34 -- 67 at Siwanoy.
OSLO, Norway, Oct. 11 -- The right of two leading Norwegian shipowners to compete with the Scandinavian Airlines System is being discussed here by the communications ministers of Scandinavia.
CHICAGO, Oct, 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ALBANY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- New polio cases are running at approximately 54 per cent of last year's level in countries outside New York City.
GENEVA, Oct. 11 -- The largest meeting on East-West trade ever convoked by the United Nations opened here today.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 11 -- One member of an Arab guerrilla band that ambushed Israeli military traffic on a lonely road in the Judaean hills this morning was killed by soldiers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Westchester officials were advised today by architectural consultants to vacate the entire group of outmoded county office and court buildings in downtown White Plains and build anew on a much larger site.
DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- Charles E. Wilson came back to Detroit today to make his first political speech of the 1954 campaign and, incidentally, to enrich Republican coffers by about $180,000.
A test of the city's 679 air raid warning sirens at 11 A.M. yesterday revealed that eighteen did not work properly, compared with nineteen on Sept. 13, the day of the last test.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- This city today began to pump and bail itself out of a multimillion dollar deluge of rain. Nature offered virtually no cooperation. Intermittent downpours during the day added to the near-record of 6.68 inches of rain that fell on the city and its southern and southwestern suburbs between last Saturday afternoon and dawn today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, chairman of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, asked President Eisenhower today who -- if anyone -- had "dared" to force the Chinese Nationalists to stop bombing the Chinese Red mainland.

Defense budget estimates for the next fiscal year, starting July 1, 1955, were being prepared in the Pentagon this week, prior to final approval by the Bureau of the Budget and the National Security Council.

Friday's donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 301 pints of blood. This included 121 pints given at the Federal Bureau of Investigation office, 346 Broadway, and ninety pints given at the New York Telephone Company, 104 Broad Street, to make a total of 182 for two days.
The Woodward Iron Company, the first corporation to announce operating results for the first nine months this year, yesterday reported higher earnings than those for the period a year ago.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- Israel has returned to the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission after having boycotted it for seven months, it was announced tonight.

In your otherwise excellent editorial "New Day in Europe" in the issue of Oct. 5 there is one sentence, the last, that deserves comment because it seems to support a misconception which already has too wide a currency.
DENVER, Oct. 11 -- President Eisenhower will make a bid for the midwestern farm vote in the Congressional elections with a major speech in Indianapolis on Friday night.
In industry-financed pension and welfare fund for radio and television performers was formally proposed for the first time yesterday by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A.F.L.

LINCOLN, Del., Oct. 11 -- On the eve of a court appearance, Bryant W. Bowles, founder of the National Association for the Advancement of White People, tonight made several new charges and statements in a speech to 2,500 members and sympathizers of his group.
Fordham University announced yesterday an increase of 5.5 per cent in enrollment compared with last year. The new total is 9,816. Of these, 953 are veterans enrolled under the G.I. Bill of Rights.
HAMBURG, N.J., Oct. 11 -- Representative Charles R. Howell asserted today that his Republican opponent could not disassociate himself from "the sorry record of the Republican party in New Jersey."

Today's new film is a British import, "The Yellow Balloon," at the Trans-Lux Normandie. The drama stars Andrew Ray, Kathleen Ryan and Kenneth More. The Marble Arch Production for Associated-British was written by Anne Burnaby and J. Lee Thompson, who also directed.

The Lehman Corporation followed a cautious investment program in the three months ended on Sept. 30. The company, a closed-end investment trust -- one which has a fixed capital -- doubled the percentage of its assets represented by cash and United States Government securities during the quarter.

Botany Mills, Inc., one of the nation's largest integrated producers of woolen and worsted fabrics, will acquire for merger Princeton Worsted Mills, a leading manufacturer of men's wear overcoatings and suiting.

It is a good thing that the world has in it so many persons who are gifted with the ability to add and subtract, to make change quickly and correctly, to measure accurately (an extraordinarily difficult feat, as anyone who buys new window shades discovers) and to balance check books.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- The Western powers set out today to clear up the obscurities in the Soviet Union's recently announced concessions on the question of disarmament and international atomic con trol.

A syndicate headed by Johnston, Lemon Co. is offering $8,000,000 of 5 per cent convertible capital debentures of State Loan and Finance Corporation, a Washington, D.C., holding company whose operating subsidiaries make small loans to individuals.
Bobby Dykes, Miami, Fla., middleweight, gained a unanimous decision over the favored Ted Olla of Milwaukee in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.
Mayor Wagner hung a wreath of palms and magnolia leaves on the facade of the Marble Collegiate Church yesterday in honor of its centennial anniversary.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Republican State Chairman Samuel L. Bodine announced tonight that Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, would be unable to speak for Clifford P. Case, candidate for United States Senator, on Oct. 15 as planned.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Four high schools with segregation problems were invited today by the New Rochelle High School to send students here to see how an integrated school operates.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 11 -- Senator John F. Kennedy's tacit refusal to endorse personally the Democratic candidate for the other Massachusetts seat in the Senate exploded with delayed action today.
The police attacked by land and sea yesterday to break up a dice game on a lower East Side pier. Thirty-one longshoremen were arrested while fifteen players scrambled away.

Stocks sagged in a heavy market yesterday with the volume, 2,100,000 shares, virtually unchanged from Friday's level of 2,120,000. Losses were general, mostly among the standard issues, and were the widest in seven weeks.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 11 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's party moved tonight to quiet French fears about a revival of the German general staff.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The Conservatives have just concluded an annual conference that has answered all their questions except the two most important: When will Sir Winston Churchill retire and what is the date of the next general election?

Many collectors were on hand when the doors opened yesterday for the six-day run of the New York Antiques Fair at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. The pickings are rich at the outset for that kind of buyer and the field is uncombed.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 11 -- India and Ceylon have agreed to settle within the next two years the status of nearly 1,000,000 residents of Indian origin living in Ceylon.
Merger of Oliver United Filters, Inc., and the Dorr Company of Stamford, Conn., under the name of Dorr-Oliver, Inc., will be considered by stockholders of the two companies on Nov. 3.

YONKERS, Oct. 11 -- The Farmstead Acres' Quick Chief from Brookville, L. I.; tied the world record of 2:03 for 2-year-old pacers on a half-mile track when he won the $18,975 Twin Futurity Preview by seven lengths before 23,381 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Reds-in-Government issue, already prominent in the campaign, got a new lift today.
The Ivy League and the Big Ten are heading into as wide-open scrambles for the championships as they have had in years, and things start popping this week.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- Management of five downtown department stores today submitted a new wage contract offer to A.F.L., Local 249 General Teamsters, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union in a move to end their eleven-month-old strike.
MOSCOW, Oct. 11 (Reuters) Russia is going to give up her holdings in joint Soviet-Bulgarian business enterprises, the Soviet news agency Tass reported tonight.

NEWARK, Oct. 11 -- The contest for the seat in the Twelfth Congressional District in New Jersey is between the 61-year-old Republican incumbent, Robert W. Kean of Livingston, and the Democratic candidate, Martin S. Fox, a 30-year-old lawyer of Newark.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The American Nuclear Society, the first wholly professional organization of scientists and engineers working in the atomic energy field, was formally established here today.

William F. Styler Jr. has been named controller of Deep Rock Oil Corporation, Tulsa, Okla., succeeding Allyn R. Bell Jr., who has resigned to become controller of General Crude Oil Company, Houston, Tex. Mr. Styler continues as assistant to the president, in addition to his new duties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Federal Trade Commission charged the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange today with unlawful practices in restraint of trade resulting in substantial increases in the price of coffee.
Five managerial jobs have changed hands in the major leagues since the last week of the season. Two other pilots are in shaky positions, leaving nine reasonably secure for the 1955 campaign.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 11 -- Economics Minister Iskak Tjokrohadisurjo, whose policies are under heavy firs froth all sides, denied today that the Government had any intention of devaluing the rupiah.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- In what could be a history-making meeting in baseball, American League club owners and representatives will gather in Chicago tomorrow to try to solve the plight of the debt-ridden Philadelphia Athletics.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 11 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas today charged "representatives of the Church" with having openly intervened in yesterday's elections for a constituent assembly.

UNITED NATIONS N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Following is the text of a statement today by Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, on the Report on Standards of Conduct in the International Civil Service issue by the International Civil Service advisory Board:

Ludwig Baumann-Spear's, retailers of home furnishings, will close its building at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street and move its main store operations to 22 West Thirty-fourth Street shortly after the beginning of the year.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 11 (AP) -- A specially called grand jury will hear next Monday charges that Joseph S. Petersen Jr. improperly obtained secret documents "with intent or reason to believe" they would help a foreign nation.

A lieutenant in the German army, known to the Russians as Erwin Germanovich and as Pepi, was captured by the Red Army at Stalingrad in January, 1943, and spent ten years in prisons and forced-labor camps in the Soviet Union.

Four days before Friday's midnight truck-strike deadline, Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., ordered yesterday a complete shake-up of the union's negotiating committee.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 11 -- The Chilean Government has instructed its Ambassador in Washington, Anibal Jara, to get a clear cut statement from the Eisenhower Administration as to its policy on copper prices.

Speaking yesterday before the Illinois, State Federation of Labor at Peoria, Secretary of Labor Mitchell provided his audience with an unusually illuminating picture of what lies behind the monthly statistics on employment and unemployment.
Six victims of communism gave a House group yesterday eyewitness stories of fourteen years of Soviet atrocities in the Ukraine.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 12 (AP) -- The "Big Three" of the American automobile industry are awaiting word from a Federal district judge as to whether they will have to defend themselves against a $1,250,000 anti-trust suit.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A Department of Defense spokesman announced yesterday a contract of approximately $1,000,000 will be awarded to the Battelle Memorial Institute in Columbus, Ohio, to assist in a new Government titanium program. J.H. Garrett, chairman of a new defense group set up on titanium research and development, said details of the contract now are being worked out with Battelle.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 12 -Chile's Catholic National Conservative party tonight passed a vote of censure against the Government of President Carlos Ibanez del Campo for steps it has taken against a leading Communist newspaper editor.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 12 -Westchester County officials agreed today to aid in bringing additional scheduled airline flights to the Westchester County Airport as a convenience to Westchester and Fairfield residents and as an "extremely important factor in Westchester's growth as a management center."
Recessions no longer "feed upon themselves" and snowball into depressions, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation, in a major blow to the British aircraft industry, has decided to buy a fleet of DC-7 airliners in the United States, American Aviation Daily reported today.
Any fashion worries that the tall girl may have had since the long, slim look arrived were banished in yesterday's showing of Peg Newton's fall and winter collection at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The free world scored a resounding triumph yesterday when the French National Assembly endorsed unconditionally the Pact of London, calling for a Western European Union that is to embrace a rearmed Germany within a strengthened North Atlantic alliance.
The Independent Citizens Committee for Javits formally opened its campaign headquarters yesterday at 399 Madison Avenue with a brief ceremony attended by 100 persons.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 12 -- The prospect of achieving sovereignty has increased pressure in West Germany to reconcentrate and recartelize heavy industry and banking.

Fred Finger of 378 Van Brunt Street, Brooklyn, has won the first prize in an essay contest on "Progress and Poverty" Seventy-five Years Later" conducted by the Henry George School of Social Science, 50 East Sixty-ninth Street.

In Robert Alden's excellent series on weather forecasting he discusses briefly those occasions when Weather Bureau personnel step across the line into the field Of private meteorology and issue special forecasts to private business firms.
The question whether bingo is an innocent game or a harmful one interests psychologists, sociologists and psychiatrists as well as theologians and politicians.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Clifford P. Case declared here tonight that "we must have complete unity" if the United States is to avoid a third World War. Such unity has been assured, he insisted, by the confidence which the American public has placed in the Eisenhower Administration.

CELESTE HOLM, a most sprightly and personable artist, appears to have been badly trapped in some situation silliness currently clogging the C.B.S. television channels at 9:30 on Sunday evening. The title of her program hardly could have been more apt: "Honestly, Celeste!"

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Iraq today blamed the Dutch Reformed Church of South Africa in large part for racial segregation, practiced in the Union of South Africa and in the mandated territory of South-West Africa.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Three hundred rioting prisoners of the South Dakota State Penitentiary gave up two guard hostages and returned to the cells late today. Their surrender to a "face-the-consequences" ultimatum ended a twenty-three-hour rebellion that flared up at the supper hour last night.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Inspector Jean Dides, one of the central figures in the inquiry on the leakage of French defense secrets, appeared today before a civil magistrate in Versailles. M. Dides was called to answer charges of harboring an escaped prisoner and of complicity in procuring a false passport.

ROME, Oct. 12 -- Premier Mario Scelba and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino asked the Chamber of Deputies today to approve the compromise agreement that returned the city and port of Trieste to Italian administration.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Butcher hogs dropped 50 cents while sows tumbled 25 to 50 cents on the livestock market today. A top price of $18.75 was a new low top since early 1953.
DENVER, Oct. 12 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that he never had found Charles E. Wilson "in the slightest degree indifferent to human misfortune."

GEORGETOWN, Del., Oct. 12 -- The Attorney General of Delaware pledged in court today that the Governor and the state's two United States Senators were prepared to lead ten Negro children by the hand into the Milford High School if the court ordered the school board to readmit the pupils.

In the past it has been the Chinese Communist leaders, Mao Tse-tung, Chou En-lai, and others, who have made the long pilgrimage from Peiping to Moscow. Two weeks ago, however, came news that the reverse pilgrimage was being made by a party including three of Russia's most powerful leaders -- Khrushchev, Bulganin and Mikoyan.

This is the proper season for the autumn cold, and everyone quite naturally has one. The result is as usual, with the sound of the sneeze being heard in the land, and the unfolding fall colors being seen vaguely, as through a burning mist of tears.

THE "cold front" that moved down on the prairie provinces last week, dusting some of the northern portions with snow, started the ducks and geese southward from Manitoba, Alberta and Saskatchewan, according to the late report from Ducks Unlimited.

Thee thirteen members of the Puerto Rican Nationalist party who have been on trial for seditious conspiracy to overthrow the Government of the United States by force were found guilty last night in Federal Court.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Run-offs will be held Oct. 24 in nine of Honduras' seventeen political subdivisions because the results of Sunday's Presidential and Congressional elections were inconclusive, officials announced today.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- An offhand remark at a press conference yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, mentioning bird dogs in a discussion of unemployment, had blossomed today into a major political issue with wide repercussions.
Referring to the question of Cyprus now pending for discussion before the United Nations may I say the following:
PARIS, Wednesday, Oct. 13 ( UP) -- France and India announced today that they had agreed on a method for settling their long dispute over ownership of the small French possessions in India.

NORMAN BROOKS' "Fragile Fox," which opened at the Belasco last evening, is a slice of life that looks like a play. It is the story of a combat captain who welshes on his men during a tight squeeze in Belgium in the last year of World War II.

YONKERS, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Shamrock Mary, owned by Norman S. Lynch of Frankford, Del., and driven by Joe Hylan, nipped Ben Turlington's Up Top in a photo finish to win the $3,500 Pelham Pace on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Army tore the wrappings today from a new recoilless rifle designed to make the infantryman a match for any tank in the world.

PORTSMOUTH, R.I. Oct. 12 -- Strange things were happening in Rhode Island today. The temperature was in the mid-80's standard-brand gasoline was selling at 17 cents a gallon, lilac bushes were budding and Portsmouth Priory's football squad was at a picnic.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Former President Truman accused the Republican party tonight of using "slogans and publicity techniques" to misrepresent the past and the present.

Indian summer weather put the Indian sign on retail stores yesterday as record heat discouraged shoppers. Traditionally the first big selling day for cool-weather apparel such as women's coats and suits and men's regular-weight clothing, Columbus Day this year saw the 85-degree heat melt the prospective sales to a point well below last year's dollar figures.
Reduced sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Industrial Rayon Corporation for the three months as well as the nine months ended Sept. 30.
DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- Construction of expressways, freeways and turnpikes throughout the country was described tonight as slowly but surely solving countrywide traffic congestion problems.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 12 (UP) -The Rokeby Stable's Blue Banner caused considerable confusion in the stretch run of the $33,300 Wanda Stakes at Garden State Park today. She finished first, but was disqualified with the victory going to the Woodland Farm's Blue Sparkler.
Thirty thousand Railway Express Agency employes will receive wage rises and longer vacations under an agreement announced yesterday between the company and the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, A.F.L.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- American League club owners tonight authorized a switch of the Philadelphia Athletics to Kansas City, but must wait until Monday to learn whether Roy and Earle Mack will sell their stock in the club.
More hard-working Austrians, who have lifted their country's economy from the post-war nadir to a sound basis, are going to get a chance to ride in American automobiles.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The Socialists' virtual unanimity today for the London accord restored a unity in the party that was lost when it split almost evenly in the vote rejecting the European Defense Community.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Louis E. Wolfson, industrialist-financier seeking control of Montgomery Ward Co. announced today that he and his family and friends now hold more than 500,000 shares of Ward stock.

I was glad to see you carry on the front page of The New York Times on Oct. 6, and follow it up with an editorial the next day, the recommendation of the special committee appointed by the New York City Board of Education that $300,000 be allocated for an expanded program of high school athletics.

The New York Knickerbockers will play the College All-Stars and the Harlem Globetrotters will meet the Washington Generals on the afternoon of Saturday, Oct. 23, at Madison Square Garden, in addition to the previously scheduled basketball double-header involving the same teams that evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to dismiss protests that some minority stockholder groups had filed to the "agreed system plan" for reorganizing the company.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Wheat and corn were under pressure today, with considerable local selling at times. The Government's October crop figures were regarded as a little bullish, but longs took profits freely, causing weakness.
A bouquet and a brickbat were tossed at New York City's pedestrians yesterday.
A method of predicting weather conditions five to seven days in advance through a daily study of the rays emitted by the sun's corona was reported last night by Trans World Airlines.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Donald Campbell, 33-year-old son of the late speedster, Sir Malcolm Campbell, announced today he planned to ram his jet-propelled speed boat through the mysterious "water barrier" at 200 miles per hour -- a speed that he believes killed an Italian who tried it last Saturday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- Volume 27 of the "Great Soviet Encyclopedia," a reference work that is not yet halfway through the Russian alphabet but already outnumbers the "Encyclopedia Britannica" by three volumes, is being distributed today to subscribers in Moscow.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Six months of summer yacht racing on Long Island Sound was concluded with the annual Columbus Day regatta today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Lavender Hill, Mrs. Charles Silvers' 5-year-old mare, gave an impressive performance in taking the Ladies Handicap at Belmont yesterday. Ridden by Stanley Small, the powerful Lavender Hill moved from absolute last to a positive first in the mile-and-a-half event for fillies anal mares.

Directors of the American Motors Corporation yesterday elected George Romney president and chairman of the board to succeed the late George W. Mason. Formerly executive vice president, Mr. Romney, 47, also was named general manager of the corporation, a consolidation of Hudson Motor Car Corporation and the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, of which Mr. Romney was executive vice president at the time of the merger last April.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -The Government announced today the lease of an aluminum forgings plant at Erie, Pa., to the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation.

Members of the Women's Guild of the Central Presbyterian Church have arranged a Country Fair Bazaar for the benefit of Presbyterian World Missions. The fete will be held on the afternoon and evening of Nov. 4 on the sixth and seventh floors of the parish house of the church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Wednesday, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Delegate E.L. Bartlett, the Democratic incumbent, took a nearly two to one lead over his Republican opponent, Barbara Dimock, for Alaska's seat in Congress in early election returns last night.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12 (AP) -A reorganization plan under which the Erie Railroad would buy the New Jersey and New York Railroad has been sent back to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of amendments.

Ten leading film industry publications will be honored for "their contributions to the American ideals of freedom, equal opportunity and fair play" at the annual Joint Defense Appeal luncheon of the Motion Picture Division and Cinema Lodge of B'nai B'rith on Oct. 27, at the Astor Hotel.
