LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Representative London newspaper critics received the "Girl on the Via Flaminia" coolly. They did not completely condemn Alfred Hayes' play, which opened tonight at the New Lindsay, the tiny club theatre, but the praise was really faint.
The stock market drifted lower yesterday with tobacco stocks under pressure and with general interest small because of the Columbus Day holiday. A slight recovery in the closing hour cut some losses.
Fifteen members of past United States Olympic track and field teams were honored last night at the Waldorf-Astoria at a dinner sponsored by the New York Chapter of the United States Olympians.

Cottonseed oil prices eased yesterday on the Produce Exchange, wiping out most of the gains registered on Monday. Trade was featureless but hedge selling lowered prices 12 to 17 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on forty-one tank cars.
Formation of a labor committee for the election of Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for Governor, was announced yesterday by three officials of units of the American Federation of Labor.
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- French organized labor examined today the Government's new measures to raise the lowest paid workers' wages and decided they were only a starting point.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Following are tape-recorded questions and answers dealing with unemployment from Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson's press conference here yesterday, as released by the Michigan Republican State Central Committee, and a statement issued today by Mr. Wilson:
PAWLING, N.Y., Oct. 12 (AP) -- An 18-year-old New York City boy was accidentally shot and critically wounded today by one of his companions while hunting near Governor Dewey's farm here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -Representative Edward H. Rees called on the Eisenhower Administration today to spell out in public detail the operation of the Government's employe security program, the center of a new campaign controversy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Herbert Morrison, deputy leader of the British Labor party, said today the armament of West Germany would enable the West to negotiate on "a reasonable basis of equality" with the Communist world.

Events tonight: "The Love for Three Oranges," City Center, 8:15 o'clock; Concertgebouw Orchestra, Eduard van Beinum conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Perry O'Neil, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Fernando Germani, organist, Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 8:30; Marie Schumacher, organist, The Studio, 145 West Forty-sixth Street, 9:20; Isidore Cohen, violinist, New School for Social Research, 8:30.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 16 points (5 to 80 cents a bale yesterday.
Gerald Moss of Modesto, Calif., and Mike Green of Miami Beach were selected yesterday to accompany the United States Davis Cup team to Australia in December.

The board of examiners is the "bulwark of the merit system" in the teaching profession, Arthur Levitt, president of the New York City Board of Education, declared yesterday. He spoke at the luncheon meeting of the sixteenth annual convention of the American Association of Examiners and Administrators of Educational Personnel, which opened at the Statler Hotel.
SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The spirit of discovery captured this village on Columbus Day. But where the Great Navigator looked for land, the citizens here sought stray $100 bills.

Many parties will be given at the annual benefit luncheon and fashion show of the American Women's Voluntary Services to be held today in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Ogden L. Mills, honorary chairman of the beneficiary, heads the benefit committee, and Mrs. Robert L. Clarkson is vice chairman.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The International Wheat Council, a forty-seven-nation body that administers the International Wheat Agreement, opened its sixteenth session here today.
The extent of the improvement of the economy in 1955 will depend upon the amount of money spent by the Government, an economist said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The United States indicated today it might support the controversial plan advanced by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to overhaul the top level of the United Nations Secretariat.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 12 -- Republicans, who in the 1952 Eisenhower landslide almost won a victory in the Fourteenth Congressional District in New Jersey, are trying again. Compared with that of the Democrats, their campaign is feeble, but there are enough factors to bolster their hopes.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 12 -- Kenneth S. Adams, chairman of the huge Phillips Petroleum Company, deplored today the decision of the United States Supreme Court which gave the Federal Power Commission regulatory jurisdiction over the price of natural gas produced at the wellhead by hundreds of independent operator's in the South and Southwest.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 12 -The United States is considering a three-way deal under which it would buy Turkish chrome ore and export surplus wheat to West Germany. The transaction would have the effect of settling part of Turkey's trading debts to Bonn.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The National Assembly approved today the armament of West Germany as a sovereign and equal state in the North Atlantic alliance and in a European coalition under the Brussels treaty.
DENVER, Oct. 12 -- The Olympic Games are one of the means by which some understanding of fair play and justice can be developed among nations," President Eisenhower said today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Despite Army's tremendous scoring spree against Dartmouth and its decisive defeat of Michigan, Earl Blaik says that the cadets are heading into a buzzsaw in their football game with Duke at Durham, N.C., Saturday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The United States declared today that the "ray of hope" created by the new Soviet proposals on disarmament and atomic control had been "considerably dimmed though not extinguished" by Soviet explanations offered yesterday.

EGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, in talks to workers in Atlantic County today, made repeated attacks on Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson's recent analysis of unemployment.
DENVER, Oct. 12 -- President Eisenhower has added an outdoor luncheon at his Gettysburg farm for Pennsylvania Republican candidates to his schedule before the Nov. 2 election.
The eleven-year-old United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., last night saluted its elder educational colleague, Columbia University, on the latter's 200th anniversary.

A special program in observance of United Nations Day will be presented over the N.B.C. television and radio networks on Sunday, Oct. 24, from 2:30 to 3:30 P.M. The program will originate in the U.N. General Assembly Building here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 12 -The tenth general assembly of the Inter-American Press Association closed today after a message had been read from an Argentine newspaper man who reported that the police had kept him from leaving his country to attend the meetings.

EXCEPT for A.B. Guthrie's "The Big Sky" and "The Way West" I can think of no novel about the Old West published within the last fifteen years as good as "The Last Hunt,"* by Milton Lott. This is the real thing, a gritty, tough, exciting story reeking with the pungent smells of dead buffalo and of dirty men.
A new, solid cherry group of furniture by Statton is notable for its versatility.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Some State Department officials saw in the new Soviet-Chinese Communist agreements today evidence that China and the Soviet Union were drawing closer together.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Sales of Series "E" and "H" Savings Bonds set a nine-year record in the first three quarters of this year, according to the Savings Bonds division of the Treasury.

Open crown hats may not be the most practical headgear for winter, but they were among the most fashionable hats presented yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, an organization of New York hat manufacturers.

There is a growing trend in production of washable men's outer apparel made of flannel and worsted-type fabrics, according to the textile fibers department of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. It has been made possible by development of many new blends of man-made and natural fibers as well as combinations of all man-made fibers, du Pont officials said.
The Symphony of the Air, formerly the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra, will play a concert without a conductor at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, Oct. 27.
Stockholders of A.C.F. Industries, Inc., will vote at a special meeting Nov. 23 on recapitalization, the company announced yesterday.

Charles E. Wilson of Detroit and Washington seems to have a special talent for saying the wrong thing in the wrong way at the wrong time. His famous remark about "what's good for General Motors" will live long in the annals of political ineptness. Now it has been supplemented by his unfortunate reference to the unemployed in surplus-labor districts.

Airwork, Ltd., one of Great Britain's largest independent air carriers, has appointed John E. Muhlfeld as president of its new North American organization, Airwork Atlantic. The company will be general agent for Airwork's all-cargo trans-Atlantic service.
UNITED NATION, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Following arc excerpts from a statement by James J. Wadsworth of the United States today in the debate on atomic control in the General Assembly's Political Committee:

The International Longshoremen's Association demonstrated its crude physical power a few days ago by closing down the Port of New York through a wholly unnecessary and unexplained strike, called without warning in the middle of the night. Now, apparently, the union is ready to flout the laws of New York and New Jersey in an equally crude effort to dictate who shall work on the waterfront.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -Owen Lattimore, writer and lecturer on Far Eastern affairs, pleaded innocent today to an indictment accusing him of falsely denying he ever followed the Communist party line or promoted Red causes.
The International Longshoremen's Association has filed unfair labor practice charges against the Waterfront Commission.
FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, commenting on the controversial "bird dog-kennel dog" remarks of Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today:

One important thing the nine Powers failed to do in London was to make some stipulation about the style of uniform the West German Army will wear. This point is not so silly as it may sound. The public relations value of the traditional German uniform (especially the helmet) is absolutely nil.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- America's giant meat packing business today was described as an industry riddled with unsound management policies and perhaps not worthy of its reputation of utilizing everything from livestock but the squeal.

HONG KONG, Oct. 12 -- Mao Tse-tung and other top-ranking Chinese Communist officials honored the Soviet mission tonight at a dinner given in Peiping by Soviet Ambassador Pavel F. Yudin. They also celebrated a new series of Chinese-Soviet accords on joint international policy and economic cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a big increase in Government-guaranteed wool prices next year with the aim of increasing United States wool production 30 per cent above this year's output.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- A lawyer's prayer, written by Dr. Samuel Johnson, was read today at the funeral service for Robert H. Jackson, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

TRENTON, Oct. 12 -- With the slogan "Drop a dollar in the hat -- help elect a Democrat," women of the party will conduct a New Jersey-wide drive for funds on Oct. 22, the Democratic State Committee has announced. The funds raised will be used in the campaign to elect Representative Charles R. Howell to the United States Senate and a Democratic majority in the House of Representatives.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Art Larsen, the temperamental former American national champion, had a heated argument with officials today, but bowed to Mexico's Mario Llamas in the semi-finals of the Pan-American tennis championship.

VIENNA, Oct. 12 -- The Austrian Government told the Soviet Union today it would welcome another conference on a state treaty. Austria added, however, that such a conference would have no chance of success unless the conclusion of a treaty was accompanied by the withdrawal of all occupation troops.

One of the current fall fashion mysteries is what has happened to the often predicted long-hair coiffure. Now that autumn is here and leading hair stylists are presenting their new designs, not a single chignon or page boy cut has been shown.

Frank Jay Gould, financier and alumnus of New York University, has made a gift of $1,000,000 to the university endowment fund. This brings to $3,000,000 the amount he has given the university in the last two years.
MIAMI, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Hurricane Hazel left a toll of death and destruction in Haiti today as it rolled through the Windward Passage toward the Atlantic Ocean.
"The Tender Trap," opening at 8 o'clock this evening at the Longacre, marks the initial attempt of several persons in that particular field of make-believe.

"The Magnificent Mitscher," a biography of Vice Admiral Marc A. Mitscher, whose aircraft carriers led the attack across the Pacific in World War II, has been written-by Theodore Taylor. It will be published by Norton on Monday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The United Nations Commission for Asia and the Far East has urged that the vast power potential of wind be harnessed for the production of electrical energy, especially in areas remote from supplies of conventional fuel.
A 27-year-old amateur airman had a thoroughly embarrassing time yesterday when he tried to take aloft a homemade balloon for the benefit of Federal aviation officials and a television audience.

Consolidated net income of American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., was $5,594,000, or 77 cents a share, in the first half of 1954. This compared with $6,563,000, or 91 cents a share, in the like period last year. The figures appeared in the June income statement, issued yesterday.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 12 -- Massachusetts Republicans are pinning their hopes on increasing their party's margin in the national house on contests in the Second and Fourth Districts. Both districts went Democratic within the last decade after years of Republican domination.
Operators of the private bus lines in Queens have renewed their offer to take over the linees operated there by the New York City Transit Authority.
The tide of homeward-bound tourists reached full flood in September, according to the monthly customs report issued here yesterday by Robert W. Dill, Collector of the Port.

YONKERS, Oct. 12 -- Passengers here were pleasantly startled today when bus drivers began a campaign of salesmanship and sweetness to woo them back from their television sets and their drives in the family car.

"Aida" was presented by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center last evening as part of the city-wide observance of Columbus Day. The performance was sponsored by the newly formed Italo-American Committee for the New York City Opera, Fortune Pope, chairman.

The annual fall party for members of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and their guests, held in conjunction with ground-breaking for its Garden of Fragrance for the Blind, will be held on two successive nights next week, Wednesday and Thursday.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- British Government securities joined industrial shares in a fresh advance of Stock Exchange prices here today. Sentiment appeared to be little affected by the dock strike or by Wall Street's weakness, though the volume of business fell slightly.
THE great kettle-drum searchlights that laid shifting runways on the skies above Times Square two nights ago can do strange things sometimes.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 11 -Frenchmen describe the French mission that has been left in Hanoi as an experiment at coexistence with the Vietminh. In keeping consulates open and functioning here, the United States and Britain are sharing in the experiment.
Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, attacked yesterday the record in Congress of his Democratic opponent, Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 12 -- Joseph S. Petersen Jr. was accused today of straying "just one step short of treason."
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Oct. 12 (UP) -- A panel leader told delegates to the National Catholic Rural Life Conference today that the nation needed "more teachers trained in rural ideas."

The problem of unemployment hit a political boiling point yesterday, fired up by attacks, criticisms and explanations for Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilsons comparison of job-seekers with hunting bird dogs or yelping kennel dogs.

George Morton Levy, general counsel to the Old Country Trotting Association at Westbury, L.I., has threatened legal action against television stations showing a film on harness racing scandals prepared by the Democratic State Committee.

IT was shortly after the fourth and last game of the world series. American Leaguers were wandering around dazedly, hardly able to comprehend what had happened. More shocked than most, perhaps, was Joe Cronin, the general manager of the Boston Red Sox.
Mayor Wagner prepared last night to take a direct hand in efforts to head off a strike of 30,000 truck drivers in the metropolitan area at midnight Friday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Democratic Senate Campaign Committee is helping foot campaign bills for party candidates rated by the committee as having good chances of winning Republican seats.
GENESEO, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Governor Dewey declared today that his three terms had been "a golden era in the advance of education in this state."

Government purchasing agents have become increasingly cost-conscious and are turning more and more to standardization as a money-saver, according to Roger E. Gay, president of the American Standards Association and of the Bristol Brass Corporation of Bristol, Conn.
Averell Harriman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, promised yesterday that, if elected, he would use every resource at his command to revise the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.

Turbine difficulties that developed late Sunday when the Greek liner Olympia was under way here have caused an indefinite postponement of her next departure, officials of the Greek Line said yesterday. The ship arrived here Monday afternoon, six hours late.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- A total of 99,824 men and women have fled from the Soviet world in the first half of this year, the United States declared here today.

The first day of the Feast of Tabernacles, or Succoth, a Thanksgiving holiday for Jews, was celebrated yesterday. In sermons in New York synagogues, rabbis emphasized the need for religious belief to combat evil forces.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 9 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, leader of the Opposition in the Australian Parliament, has precipitated a major crisis in the Labor party involving his own future as its leader.

At a progressive luncheon of epicurean proportions, a delegate from this department recently previewed some of the delicacies to be served at the Goddard Autumn Gala next Monday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BUFFALO, Oct. 12 -- A new scientific study indicating that unhappy, ineffective and upset persons make up about one-third of the adult population was presented to the American Public Health Association today.

Harold E. Stassen called last night upon Christian laymen to have in the early stages of the peaceful use of nuclear energy, "a deep appreciation of our churches in relation to our way of life and the impact it has had on the rest of the world."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 12 -- Dr. Daniel F. Malan is expected to be succeeded as Prime Minister by Nicolaas Christiaan Havenga, Finance Minister, or Johannes Gerhardus Strydom, leader of the Transvaal Nationalists.
CLINTON, Md., Oct. 12 (UP) -- An abandoned jet fighter plane killed a mother and her two small children in a flaming dive today after the pilot had fallen to his death in an unopened parachute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- State Department officials said they were "encouraged" by the vote of confidence won today by Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France, even though it was only a preliminary and limited expression of parliamentary opinion.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 12 (AP) -The Brookmeade Stable's Gandharva broke the Keeneland track record for six furlongs today, covering the distance in 1:10 1/5 to win the featured $5,000 Columbus Purse before 7,500 opening-day fans.

Averell Harriman revised his up-state speaking schedule yesterday to avert an open clash between his Democratic and Liberal supporters in Rochester, a city that has a sizable Democratic and Liberal vote.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- A nation-wide investigation into business practices of freight forwarders will be undertaken by the Federal Maritime Board.
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 12 -Resident Chinese Reds and anti-Communists, with about equal organizations, are fighting for control of Burma's Chinese population of about 300,000.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Baseball fans from Mayor William E. Kemp down to the small fry on the corner lots tonight acclaimed the American League's approval of a shift of the Philadelphia Athletics to this city.
By Presidential proclamation this is National Nurses Week, an official recognition of the important part that nurses play in the care of the sick and disabled.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Drying winds and the first sunshine this city has seen in three rain-drenched days combined today to help dry out a sodden Chicago.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 12 -- The Nassau County Democratic party brought the Long Island Rail Road into its political campaign today, charging that a hoax had been perpetrated on the people through Republican participation in the commuter line's affairs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today a new $67,000,000 construction program designed to expand its uranium-processing facilities in three states.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -There was a rumor circulating in Washington tonight -- obviously started by a Democrat -- that Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson, former president of the General Motors Corporation, invented the automatic transmission for automobiles so that he would have one foot free to put in his mouth.
The Weather Man and Christopher Columbus combined talents yesterday to convert the heart of Manhattan into a vast playground.
The closing week of this year's state campaign in New York may amount to a re-play of the 1952 Presidential election finale with President Eisenhower and Adlai E. Stevenson trading verbal blows.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Robert Aldrich, producer and director of "The Way We Are," has made a deal with the Distributors Corporation of America to finance and distribute the film, which will star Joan Crawford.

TOKYO, Oct. 12 -- Acting Premier Taketora Ogata rejected today a move by the Soviet Union and Communist China aimed at weakening Japan's ties with the United States. In a joint declaration in Peiping yesterday Moscow and Peiping proposed the restoration of diplomatic relations and an increase in trade with Japan.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (Reuters) -The world lost 223 merchant ships last year as a result of collisions, fires, wrecks, foundering and other causes, it was disclosed today.
Vicente Escudero, the Spanish gypsy dancer, will return with a company of ten dancers and musicians for a New York engagement beginning Feb. 1 at a theatre yet to be announced.
Trudeau Sanatorium, the country's oldest private establishment for the treatment of tuberculosis, will close Dec. 1 because its continuance is deemed no longer useful or economically feasible.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12 -- Dr. Paul H. Buck, former dean and university provost, will become librarian of Harvard College and director of the Harvard University Library next summer.

McCann-Erickson, Inc., was named yesterday by the Bulova Watch Company to handle its $4,000,000 account, effective on Jan. 1. The account had been handled by the Biow Company some thirty-three years, a relationship that ended abruptly just three weeks ago.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 12 -- The election race in New Jersey's Thirteenth Congressional District is three-cornered. The outcome, it is believed, will be determined by the relative strength of the political parties in this consistently Democratic area rather than by the campaigns of the respective candidates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -The price of coffee, which has political as well as economic significance, became the subject for renewed Senate inquiry today in an avowed effort to impose Government trading regulations.

Richard Kay, 'cellist, was heard in recital at Town Hall last evening. A native New Yorker, Mr. Kay made his debut at the same hall in 1950. He has played in the Longines Symphonette, the Little Orchestra and at the Prades Festival in Spain.
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The vote of confidence in Premier Pierre Mendes-France's policy on West German armament showed many groups in the National Assembly had recovered their unity.
The same forces that won out on New York's crime-soaked waterfront are taking over another vital unit in the city's distribution lifeline, the general trucking industry.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- An engineer who complained that his wife had threatened to put an axe through their television set, their radio and him when he tried to watch a boxing match has received a divorce here.

TORONTO, Oct. 12 -- Centralization of authority within the United Lutheran Church in America was virtually completed here today when its nineteenth biennial convention conferred broad powers of veto on the church's Executive Board.
Schweppes, Ltd., has set 1960 as the target date for its first profitable year here, although it might show a favorable return by 1958, Franklin Collins Hooper, managing director, said yesterday.

The Reynolds Spring Company, Jackson, Mich., has acquired the assets, patents and inventory of A.W. Haydon Company, Waterbury, Conn., manufacturer of direct current timing devices for the aircraft and other industries.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 12 -- One way to prevent headaches is not to "blow your top," physicians attending a symposium at the convention of the New York State Academy of General Practice were told today.

TIBETAN painting must be to Westerners one of the least familiar of art's worldwide manifestations. So, though the orientalist will be in a better position to profit from it than the average person, the exhibition of seventy-three Tibetan paintings at Wildenstein's is an event of unusual interest.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, came to Carnegie Hall last night, after a wage dispute that had prevented its concerts of last week in Philadelphia. Permitted only an hour's rehearsal for its New York appearance, the orchestra played ravishingly.

Richard Childs' severe arraignment of how judges are selected and elected is distressingly persuasive -- so persuasive that one wonders how it has happened that we do have so many good and able men on the bench. But how good is the remedy which he espouses?

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Pilot models of low load electrical generating plants on truck trailer and rail car chassis were displayed today by General Motors' Electro-Motive division. The units, to be manufactured in Electro-Motive's suburban LaGrange plant, are designed especially for use by utilities for the temporary increasing of power supply to fringe areas.
DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Four officials of teamster unions in the Detroit area were sent to prison and fined today for shaking down employers for bribes.

WAYNESBURG, Pa., Oct. 12 (UP) -- The entry of a handpicked team of United Mine Workers mediators into a seniority dispute tonight ended a strike that had made idle some 12,000 coal miners in fifteen western Pennsylvania pits.

WELLSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 12 (AP) -- A Brooke County Court hearing for an injunction to halt the sale of the Follansbee Steel Corporation is in recess today, awaiting appraisal of Follansbee's physical assets by a company hired by six stockholders who filed the suit.

MORIOKA, Japan, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Fourteen West German trackmen outclassed a field of 103 Japanese today in the second meet of their swing through Japan. The Germans won thirteen of fourteen first places.
Christopher Columbus would have been proud and impressed yesterday if he could have seen the big Fifth Avenue parade commemorating the 462d anniversary of his arrival in the New World.
CAIRO, Oct. l2 -- Twelve men and a woman were accused today of being members of an Israeli spy organization. The charges were made public by the Egyptian Military Prosecutor's office.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 -- Leaders of Local 249 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., today prepared a list of proposed changes in the wage contract offer made by the five downtown department stores to end an eleven-month strike.

The people of Honduras confounded the prophets of doom and voted peacefully and freely on Sunday for a new President, Vice President and the fifty-six members of Congress. This will give heart to those who persist in believing that democracy is progressing steadily throughout Latin America despite obvious and frequent setbacks.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 12 (AP) -Three crewmen who survived the sinking of the freighter Mormackite testified today they had heard no orders to abandon ship and saw no effort made to lower lifeboats.
Two extensive investigations of the Government's intelligence activities are now in progress in Washington and elsewhere.

Thirty thousand and more truck drivers -- out of 175,000 in metropolitan New York and New Jersey -- may halt work in the teamster strike threatened for tomorrow midnight. City leaders warned yesterday that crippling effects could reach across the country.
A 10 per cent increase in wages was included among "new" demands served upon East and Gulf Coast shipowners yesterday afternoon by the Masters, Mates and Pilots, A.F.L.

Dr. Niels Bohr of Denmark, who ranks second only to Einstein among the world's greatest living physicists, said here yesterday that the "hope of mankind" lay in the collaboration of nations in harnessing atomic energy for human welfare.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Vladimir Cerny of Czechoslovakia won the 300-meter swimming event of the modern pentathlon world championship tonight, but Sweden and Russia shared first place in the team standings.

Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, faces a challenge -- and an opportunity -- of great portent for the people of the New York metropolitan area and for his own union as well. Developments of the past few days have made it difficult, even dangerous, for him to dodge it.

Many parties were given at the annual dinner dance, the Jewel Gala, held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark headed the executive committee for the fete, Mrs. Edgar W. Leonard was chairman of the dinner committee and Mrs. M. Dorland Doyle was chairman of the ticket committee.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Authoritative sources said today that differences over the types of major weapons whose production is to be controlled by the Brussels Treaty Organization must be settled by the foreign ministers of the nations involved.

Mrs. William Woodward, a member of the executive committee for the Seven Crown Ball, entertained at a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 9 East Eighty-sixth Street. Members of the various committees for the ball were present to discuss final plans for the fete, which will be held on Nov. 2 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Jo Copeland is known for her personal chic. Her trim figure, smart coiffure and sophisticated clothes stand out in any public gathering. All of this is reflected in her designing. For two decades, Miss Copeland has been one of the inner circle of New York's top designers.
Investment banking syndicates will offer to investors today new issues of public utility securities having a market value of more than $14,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Leo A. Rover, United States Attorney here, accused Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl today of personal prejudice in favor of Owen Lattimore and against the Government.
The advertising agency handling the Democratic State Committee's television film on harness racing moved yesterday to meet the demands of a Buffalo station as a condition for showing the film today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 13 -- The General Electric Company unveiled a big quiet room here today. The copper-covered chamber is in the heart of a 150-foot sound test laboratory that will be used for studying the sound of power transformers.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Strikes and pending wage claims, symptoms of widespread industrial unrest, are threatening Britain's booming economy, now at the highest level since World War II.
A $15,000 suit against the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra will be taken to the New York Supreme Court by the National Concert and Artists Corporation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union formally told the United Nations today that it was satisfied with the Italian-Yugoslav agreement on Trieste. This apparently meant that the Russians did not intend to bring the matter up before the Security Council where it has been a cause for acrimonious debate.

The newspaper accounts of the District Attorney's investigation of the circumstances leading to the shocking fatal stabbing recently of an elderly nurse by a 19-year-old boy on a subway train indicated that the attack was made while this young assailant was in a state of complete intoxication.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 13 -- Both of Delaware's United States Senators today disavowed the courtroom pledge in Georgetown yesterday by Attorney General H. Albert Young that, with the Governor, they would personally lead ten Negro children back to the Milford High School if the Chancery Court ordered the reestablishment of integration.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A $1,000,000 libel suit has been filed in Federal Court against The New York Daily News. It is an outgrowth of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's statements to newspapermen after closed hearings in his 1953 Army Signal Corps investigation.

Three detectives exchanged shots last night on the West Side with a fugitive gunman who was wanted on a bail-jump charge involving robbery. The hoodlum escaped through a police cordon that covered several blocks.

OCILLA, Ga., Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Negro contractor said today his short-lived candidacy for City Councilman in this south Georgia town resulted in a "night of terror" for his family and an effort to shoot him by a man he described as a uniformed policeman.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Soybean futures registered a big recovery from early low spots today as big operators who sold yesterday turned buyers. But trade was dull in the grains.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., Oct. 13 (UP) -- The reputed boss of this town's underworld and his partner pleaded guilty today to leasing places for gambling. They were fined $1,000 and sentenced to ninety days in jail.

THE waterfowl season will get under way at noon on Saturday in New York, with the exception of Long Island and that part of Westchester County south of the Hutchinson River Parkway, and reports from upstate indicate that the ducks have been moving from the north in large numbers during the past week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Pakistan will probably be promised about $40,000,000 in an emergency economic grant during the official visit here of Prime Minister Mohammed Ali, which begins tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 13 -- Management of the five struck department stores were preparing an answer tonight to the request of union leaders for changes in the proposal made to them Monday to end their eleven-month dispute.

The second annual Velvet Ball for the benefit of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc., will be held tomorrow night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The co-sponsor of the fete is the Velvet Institute of America. Mrs. David Gimbel is chairman of the benefit committee and Mrs. Paul S. Ames and Mrs. Frederick Cammann are co-chairmen.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 13 -- For the third successive day, the Opposition newspaper Halkci today challenged Premier Adnan Menderes to give a detailed report on the outcome of his economic talks with West German leaders in Bonn last week.

The Democratic party is making plans to emphasize bingo as a campaign issue in areas where the game has been popular and was an important source of charity revenue before the police closed the games last month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Oil companies today offered the Federal Government nearly $130,000,000 for the right to produce oil, gas and sulphur from submerged, lands in the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana.
United Medical Service, New York's Blue Shield, announced yesterday the election of two new members to its board of directors.
A commercial air carrier which climbed from insignificance to a place among the so-called Big Five will commemorate its twentieth anniversary tomorrow.
Roy Campanella may undergo further surgery on his crippled left hand, Brooklyn Dodgers officials said yesterday.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 13 -- Sir Hartley Shawcross, a member of the British Parliament, asserted today that it would be naive to think that communism could be stopped by making it illegal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, said today the Eisenhower Administration had redeemed its pledge to restore public confidence in the Department of Justice.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct, 13 (AP) -- Mr. Bartlett said today "Alaska almost always has indicated the way the nation will vote in November."

The Inter-American Press Association has just completed its tenth annual conference, which this year was held in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Each year brings new proof of the vigor and steadily growing influence of this organization.

BUFFALO, Oct. 13 -- The flight to suburbia for the last two decades has been made with an appalling lack of planning. This was reported here today at the eighty-second annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution today awarded nursing scholarships to three Negro girls.

The increasing use of glass in modern architecture is bringing about a new relationship between indoors and outdoors that affects lighting, according to Richard Kelly, architectural and lighting consultant. He addressed members of the Electrical Women's Round Table at their monthly dinner meeting last night at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

DENVER, Oct. 13 -- Leonard W. Hall, chairman of the Republican National Committee, has been in touch with the temporary White House on the political controversy whipped up by Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson's remarks on dogs and unemployment.
WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Through the years, football coaches have been heard to say:

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 13 -- Efforts to picture Democratic Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota as a Communist sympathizer have been begun in a series of late campaign attacks by an "independent-liberal" Senatorial candidate.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The sources of the Homeric fables in "The Iliad" and "The Odyssey" can be traded to the 5,000-year-old civilization of Crete, one of the oldest in the world, a group of classical scholars said tonight.
Robert Ardrey's new play, "Sing Me No Lullaby," dealing with a rich, young Midwestern aristocrat who is defeated in his first political crusade, opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Phoenix Theatre.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet but steady yesterday and prices were unchanged to 4 points higher than on Tuesday.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight the alternatives to President Eisenhower's policies were socialism and laxity toward communism.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 13 (UP) -- Mel Leavitt, J.W. Brown's seasoned campaigner, turned back six other 3-year-olds today while scoring a one-and-one-half-length triumph in the $5,000 Skeeters Purse at Garden State Park.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Four Southern high schools have accepted an invitation to send students here to see for themselves how the integration of Negro pupils has worked in New Rochelle High School. A fifth school declined with thanks, asserting that "our problem is not caused by our students in any way."
GENEVA, Oct. 13 -- Dental ailments are "the most universal, the most common and the most widespread" of all the ills affecting mankind, the World Health Organization reported today.

Three corporations and fifteen individuals were accused by New York State yesterday of having swindled the public out of more than $250,000 through the sale of worthless uranium and television securities.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 13 -- Sam Rayburn, former Speaker of the House of Representatives, predicted here today that the Democratic party would win control of the House in November by "twenty to forty seats."
BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 13 -- Colombia's first integrated steel mill was formally dedicated today by the President of the republic, Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla.

All but about fifty of the 200 passengers who were to have sailed yesterday aboard the delayed liner Olympia, have been accommodated on other ships, officials of the Greek Line said yesterday. Arrangements for the others, all from the Boston area, are still in process.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 14 (AP) The Peiping radio said today that the Soviet Union itself proposed to withdraw its troops from the Manchurian naval base of Port Arthur.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Herbert Morrison, Labor party official and former British Foreign Secretary, appealed today for an Arab-Israeli settlement that would bring "real peace" to the Middle East.
Despite sharp gains by a number of specialties, the stock market as a whole proved easy yesterday.
An emphasis on light and space marks fifteen wallpapers in a new collection available through decorators at Wilton E. Owen, Inc., 513 Madison Avenue.

What today's weather will be like is anybody's guess, including the weatherman's. But don't be surprised if it snows before the day is out or if the thermometer registers a hundred. A snowstorm, of a scorcher, or one right after the other, would be a logical climax to the kind of weather we have been having lately.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Poland protested today against a United States decision to restrict a Polish correspondent at the United Nations to mid-Manhattan.
With a paralyzing strike set for midnight tomorrow, 750 embattled truck operators vowed last night that they would take a strike rather than capitulate to union demands.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 13 -- An official spokesman of the Dutch Reformed Church denied today a charge by Awni Khalidy, Iraqi delegate in the United Nations, that the church was to blame for apartheid, or racial segregation, in South Africa and the mandated area of South-West Africa.

Factoring -- the purchase of a manufacture's accounts receivable -- has spread far beyond the textile field, where it has been prevalent for 150 years, Walter Kelly of Commercial Factors Corporation told the Midtown Executives Club yesterday at a luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr., Marine Corps Commandant, told his troops today to learn how to cut cake with pomp and ceremony.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Senate Banking subcommittee wound up its hearings on coffee prices today, plainly set to recommend that coffee trading be brought under Federal regulation.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 13 -- The new West German military establishment of 500,000 men is to be known as Die Streitkraefte, "the military forces." The names Reichswehr and Wehrmacht, identified with the Weimar Republic and the Nazi Third Reich, respectively, are not to be resurrected.

A tight supply situation, caused by strikes in mines and processing plants, resulted last month in the smallest domestic deliveries of refined copper since January, 1953. Producers' stocks of copper were reduced to the lowest level in several years.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 13 -- Seven Chinese school children, including two girls, lost an appeal today against three-month jail sentences for refusing to disperse on police orders during demonstrations earlier this year against a national service call.
Ted Kluszewski of the Cincinnati Redlegs equaled a major league record for first basemen in 1954 by leading in fielding percentage for the fourth consecutive season.

Losing to Boston University by a 55-20 score last Saturday shocked Fordham's football team. The defeat was not unexpected, but the margin was. Coach Ed Danowski did not think that any foe could pile up so many points against a squad that he regarded as capable in all respects except reserve strength.

The strange capsizing of the modern freighter Mormackite seems all the more tragical because such sea disasters in the American merchant fleet are infrequent. This was no wartime production-line vessel, but a high-quality cargo carrier of the C-2 class, designed years before the war to improve the country's roster of ships with the latest developments in safety and navigation equipment.

Arthur Krock in his column of Oct. 11 relates the events at William and Mary when several prominent Virginians boycotted a celebration in honor of the memory of Chief Justice John Marshall, because the present Chief Justice was the principal speaker.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France conferred in private today with Gen. Charles de Gaulle about French foreign and domestic policies.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Britain's Press Council has disclosed that complaints it has received about newspaper practices here have dealt mainly with alleged invasion of privacy, the treatment of crime news and the treatment of sex.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Canada proposed today that the General Assembly ask the United Nations Disarmament Commission to "seek an acceptable solution of the disarmament problem." It also asked that the commission report back to the Security Council and the Assembly "as soon as sufficient progress has been made."
Despite minor misadventure, members of two of the world's eminent symphony orchestras drew into Grand Central Terminal early yesterday morning in a spirit of jovial camaraderie.

Chesapeake Industries, Inc., a holding company, has called a special stockholders meeting for Nov. 3 to act on the proposed acquisition of the Colonial Trust Company and four affiliates for up to $5,000,000 worth of Chesapeake stock.

Ronald E. Martin was convicted yesterday by a jury in Brooklyn Federal Court of participating in the theft of $190,319 from a Floral Park, L.I., bank on Aug. 18, 1953. A jury of six men and six women took four and one-half hours to reach an agreement on the two-count indictment of armed robbery and conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A Democratic cry of "yoicks" now resounds against Charles E. Wilson, and some Republicans have taken down the panels in the path of the hunt. But the American Kennel Club, nearly every boy in the quail country and the faithful companions of these boys in the field should also be pursuing the Secretary of Defense for this remark at his press conference in Detroit on Tuesday:

The Times of Oct. 5 carries a letter from Julius G. Rothenberg asking for scholarships for evening students. As the administrative officer of an evening college, I find myself in agreement with his arguments.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. used Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson and Governor Dewey as clubs to bludgeon the Republican party today for what he called "callousness to unemployment" and "corruption."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet tomorrow at 3 P.M. to make up an Israeli complaint against Egyptian interference with Israel-bound vessels in the Suez Canal.
LONDON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The Foreign Office disclosed today that Britain and the Soviet Union had replaced military attaches ousted from their respective capitals last May on mutual.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Governor Dewey asserted today that Averell Harriman should be able to hire speech writers who could make him sound more than "this ignorant opponent" of Senator Irving M. Ives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said tonight that the same kind of defective piping that caused an explosion in the first atomic submarine, the Nautilus, had been found in the land-based prototype for a second submarine.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A task force working in cooperation with the Department of Commerce has developed possibilities for at least 500 new jobs in the Lawrence, Mass., surplus labor area.
Chintaman Deshmukh, India's Finance Minister, expressed the belief yesterday that his nation's basic friendship for the United States would persist, with or without economic assistance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Library of Congress announced today the purchase of the largest collection of negatives by Matthew B. Brady, famous Civil War photographer, still remaining in private hands.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Christopher Chataway of Britain broke the world record for 5,000 meters (3 miles 188 yards 2 inches) in a London-Moscow track and field meet tonight.

Events tonight: "Falstaff," City Center, 8:15 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Mischa Elman soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Katrina Aisporo, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Composers Group of New York City, Mason and Hamlin Salon, 3 East Forty-third Street, 7.
Enforcement has been one of the weak links in this city's traffic control chain, one of the nation's experts said last night.
ATLANTA, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Georgia's Supreme Court ruled today that squirrels were not vermin.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- The plight of Arab refugees on United Nations relief rolls remains far from a settlement, the the world organization was reminded today.
The use of music in the treatment of mentally and physically handicapped children was described yesterday at the fifth annual conference of the National Association for Music Therapy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Calvin Griffith, vice president of the Washington Senators, tonight took direct issue with the Chicago announcement that the American League had given official approval for a shift of the Philadelphia Athletics' franchise to Kansas City.

Bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange slipped last month to the lowest average level since May, the Exchange reported yesterday. The Sept. 30 figure was $100.53, against $100.62 at the end of August and $100 on May 31.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The stark shape of a pine tree dead for thirty years has been preserved for posterity as a memorial to Britain's aviation pioneering at Farnborough.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, defended yesterday the state's handling of rent-control laws, declaring: "It's been honest, compared with the shambles the city made of them."
The Waterfront Commission refused a license yesterday to a pier hiring boss on the ground that his selection had been forced by the International Longshoremen's Association.

A decline last week of 568,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 151,550,000 barrels, compared with 152,118,000 a week earlier and 140,287,000 a year ago.

A two-story factory building at King and Ferris Streets in Brooklyn has been leased by the Pal Products Manufacturing Company from the New York Dock Company. The transaction was negotiated by the Brevoort Management Company as broker.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 13 -- Both the Republican and Democratic candidates for Representative from the First Congressional District are, in a sense, running for re-election.

Writers of books, and especially of books that require considerable research and consultation with authorities on the subject written about, often acknowledge in a preface help and encouragement received from others.

SIR PERCY SPENDER, the Australian Ambassador to the United States, made a remarkable statement at the dinner for the United States Olympians the other night. He said in effect that the world would be a lot better off and much closer to a lasting peace if the politicians and diplomats turned their jobs over to the athletes.

The election of Fred A. Ferroggiaro as chairman of the board of the Bank of America and of Jesse W. Tapp as senior officer for the Southern California area were announced yesterday by S. Clark Beise, president of the world's largest bank.
A new punch that is almost a meal in itself is at once festive to serve and moderate in cost. Mrs. Imogene Frost developed it, and in so doing combined her own interests with those of her husband.

The election of G. C. Riegger as presiden, t of the Pemacel Tape Corporation to ucce'ed G. O. Lienhard, who bedomes chairman of th bord,'vas arinouncd yesterday. Gen. Robert W. ohnson, chairman of Johnson Johnson, the parent company, made the announcement. Mr. Lienhard is also chairman of the ChiCopee Manufac7
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted two former officials of a local painters' union on charges of extortion and conspiracy to obstruct interstate commerce by extortion.

Record-breaking weather -- summer in the midst of fall -- continued here yesterday, with a high temperature of 85 degrees at 2:05 P. M. The figure was six points above the previous high for the date, set in 1879.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Following are excerpts from statements made today by Paul Martin, Canadian Minister of Health and Welfare, and Sir Percy Spender of Australia in the debate on atomic-energy control in the Assembly's Political Committee:
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The coffee house, which flourished in the days of Dr. Samuel Johnson (1709-1784), has come back to London after more than a century and a half of eclipse.

American industry set out yesterday on a campaign to break Americans of the habit of tossing litter into streets and out of car windows. Under the corporate name of Keep America Beautiful, representatives of twenty-three national industries called for an end of littering and discussed ways of making it unpopular.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The first United States bomber designed to fly faster than sound has been ordered into production, the Air Force announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, tonight expressed to "the American people" his regrets for what he called his "inept remarks" about dogs and unemployment. "I want to say that I am sorry," he told a $100-a-plate Republican dinner attended by a capacity 1,600 persons.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 13 -- Jawaharlal Nehru disclosed today that he intended to retire as Prime Minister and president of the ruling Congress party. This has touched off intense speculation as to the future composition of the Central Government and the party organization.

After giving it a rest last spring and fall, the New York City Opera last night restored Prokofieff's "The Love for Three Oranges" to its repertory. It was given in the stylized production devised by Theodore Komisarjevsky and designed by Mstislav Dobujinsky and first presented by the company in the fall of 1949.
A Baptist minister has purchased a half-hour of radio time from the National Broadcasting Company to advocate abstinence from the use of alcoholic beverages.
VAN NUYS, Calif., Oct. 13 (AP) -- "Who the hell did that?" television listeners heard tonight as Vice President Richard M. Nixon came to the end of a political speech at the Valley Junior College.
Concern over increasing unemployment in the city was expressed yesterday by Mayor Wagner in a forty-four-page "midyear report" on progress made by his Administration since he took office Jan. 1.

Republican and Democratic political figures and labor groups in this area fired more sharp attacks yesterday at Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson and, in some cases, angrily demanded his resignation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- An investigation was ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission today into charges that Riss Co. of Kansas City, Mo., one of the country's largest motor carriers, had been "entertaining" customers at a Canadian fishing camp.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 13 -- Melvin Smith, Negro student who gave up a room at the home of Prof. Bernard Beckerman here after hearing threats that a cross would be burned on the front lawn, was elected president today of the freshman class at Hofstra College.
BOONTON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Representative Charles R. Howell called upon his Republican opponent for United States Senator today to stop preaching "sermonettes" and to explain where he stood.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay announced approval today of an "emergency short-term contract" for sale of Falcon Dam power to the Central Power and Light Company of Texas.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Clifford P. Case today characterized as "words of a demagogue" Democratic charges that the Republican party had assumed a callous attitude toward national unemployment. He also struck back at opposition attacks oh the foreign policy of the Eisenhower Administration.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Industrial issues registered widespread small losses today, reflecting investors' reaction to th dock strike and other labor disputes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that he was "supporting all of the Republican candidates with one exception" -- Clifford P. Case, the nominee for Senator from New Jersey.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 12 -- Turkey is seeking to persuade Premier Nuri es-Said of Iraq to abandon his proposals for a broad Middle East defense organization in favor of direct links with Turkey and Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture will hold a public hearing here on Nov. 9 to determine how much sugar Americans are expected to need in 1955. The department controls domestic marketings and imports of sugar under legislation designed to stabilize prices and supplies for the mutual interest of producers and consumers.
Some synthetic detergents that have been available up to now only in the form of flake, powder or liquid soon may be had in bar form.

As has happened so often in the past, the first Western exploration of the latest Soviet disarmament proposal has begun to dim the early hopes aroused. There is still enough unknown territory in the Soviet plan to warrant a continuation of the discussions now under way in the United Nations.

Today's new film is "White Christmas," the first feature to be made in Paramount's wide-screen Vista Vision process, with Bing Crosby, Danny Kaye, Rosemary Clooney and Vera-Ellen heading the cast of the Irving Berlin musical in Technicolor, at the Radio City Music Hall.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, starting an investigation into registration frauds, said yesterday his agents had "uncovered an apparent pattern of illegal election practices in the city.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The United States Army Northern Area Command banned today mixed after-midnight parties in bachelor officers' quarters. This was part of a drive to enforce "reasonable deportment" among those who lived alone.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Tennessee Valley Authority said today its power system earned a net profit of $28,820,395 on an $890,000,000 investment in the 1954 fiscal year ended June 30.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 13 -- A former royal secretary and two former royal pages were sentenced today to death for implication in the murder of King Ananda Mahidol in 1946.

YONKERS, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Tara Boy, a 7-year-old Gem Hanover gelding owned and driven by Scotty Welch, registered his fifth straight triumph tonight in the feature race on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway.
A sit-in strike at the plant of the American Safety Razor Corporation at 315 Jay Street, Brooklyn, ended at 4:30 P.M. yesterday when the striking employes walked off the premises.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 13 -- Robert L. Garner, Vice President of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said today the bank was prepared to "assure" Pakistan that India would pay the costs of constructing canals to replace the water diverted to India.

An organization was announced here yesterday which would in effect encourage a boycott of imports from countries that receive American economic aid but fail to raise wages closer to this country's standards.

The thirteen-story structure at 52 East Nineteenth Street, southwest corner of Fourth Avenue, which is occupied largely by the printing trades, has been sold by the Tishman Realty Construction Company to William Kaufman, realty investor and builder.
GENEVA, Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union has made it clear at the current United Nations meeting on East-West trade that it does not intend to pay the trade debts of its European satellite countries.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- A plan to make the Saar territory a protege of the Brussels Treaty Organization was discussed here today by Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France, and Johannes Hoffmann, Premier of the Saar.
The intended victim of a kidnapping thwarted his captors last night in an automobile in Queens.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Political slumber is diminishing in the Rip Van Winkle country on the Hudson slope of the Catskills as the race for Representative in the Twenty-eighth Congressional District enters its last lap.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Waterborne movement of chemicals on the country's inland and coastwise waterways increased from 7,148,311 tons in 1949 to an estimated 12,495,344 last year and the upward trend will continue, F.G. Moore, general traffic manager of the Columbia-Southern Chemical Corporation of Pittsburgh, said here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Jewish Thought as a Factor in Civilization," the third in a series of reports giving the position of five major religions on the question of racial discrimination, is the title of a pamphlet released here today.

The famous Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam made its New York debut last night in Carnegie Hall, under the leadership of Eduard van Beinum, with a concert that will long be remembered in this city. The setting of the event was emblematic of its distinction.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. will place on the market today the first public issue of shares of a new investment company -- Incorporated Income Fund. The new company was formed last month by the management of Incorporated Investors, twenty-eight-year-old investment company.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati defeated Sven Davidson of Sweden, 9 -- 7, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, to reach the final of the men's singles in the thirteenth Pan-American tennis tournament today. Trabert will play Mexico's Mario Llamas for the title tomorrow.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 13 -- The Government announced today that it opposed special privileges for any religion in the new Consitution.

A plan to move farm surpluses more quickly was set up at the closing session of the convention of the National Association of Food Chains at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. Albert Eisner Jr., of the Eisner Grocery Co. of Champaign, Ill., chairman of the association's committee on agriculture, showed an insignia to be used in the 15,000 member stores whenever there is a commodity in need of quick sale.

The Defense Department's streamlined production allocation program, evolved last January, was one step nearer to reality in the Northeast today as a result of a special forum held here yesterday. The meeting was organized by the Army and by the Assistant Secretary of Defense, Supply and Logistics, T. P. Pike.

In any major political campaign the headquarters of the rival contenders are always haunted by a number of ghosts, sometimes under a fancier title and sometimes with none, whose judgments and backgrounds are relied upon heavily by the candidates.

ARNOLD TOYNBEE, the most influential A living historian, has been my inconstant companion since midsummer, when I began my explorations of the four fat, weighty volumes of his deeply religious "A Study of History"* that are published today. These books, with the six in the same majestic cycle that already have appeared, bring us within sight of the end of a singularly grandiose enterprise.
BERLIN, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, left East Berlin by plane today for Moscow after an eight-day visit to East Germany.

The investigations of union welfare funds have gone far enough to show the urgent need of Government regulation to curb existing abuses and protect the interests of the 12,000,000 union members whose welfare is directly concerned. It has become perfectly clear that the administration of the $17,000,000,000 cannot be entirely self-policed.

ARNOLD TOYNBEE, the most influential A living historian, has been my inconstant companion since midsummer, when I began my explorations of the four fat, weighty volumes of his deeply religious "A Study of History"* that are published today. These books, with the six in the same majestic cycle that already have appeared, bring us within sight of the end of a singularly grandiose enterprise.
BERLIN, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, left East Berlin by plane today for Moscow after an eight-day visit to East Germany.

The investigations of union welfare funds have gone far enough to show the urgent need of Government regulation to curb existing abuses and protect the interests of the 12,000,000 union members whose welfare is directly concerned. It has become perfectly clear that the administration of the $17,000,000,000 cannot be entirely self-policed.

Potato prices tumbled the 1/4-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday from the previous trading day's closing price on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The volume was 2,099 car lots (45,000 pounds to a car), the largest in the history of the exchange.

TORONTO, Oct. 13 -- The nineteenth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America ended a week-long session here today after having authorized its executive board to develop plans for new and more adequate denominational headquarters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- Universal is planning still another musical, "The Second Greatest Sex," which brings to five the number of such pictures the studio intends to make next year. The new venture is described as "an American folklore type" musical comedy set in Kansas in the Eighteen Hundreds. Charles Hoffman is writing the screen play, which will be bolstered by ten musical numbers. Albert J. Cohen has been designated as the producer.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Averell Harriman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, launched today his first sustained campaign tour of crucial upstate counties by sharply criticizing Republicans for what he called their "callous" indifference to growing unemployment.

The New York office of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that the Air Force had contracted with the company to authorize immediate production of the speedy F-104 jet fighter plane. The number of planes ordered was not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- A former undercover informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the Communist party testified today that he had been threatened and called a "stool pigeon" because he had planned to expose Reds in eastern Pennsylvania.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Thursday, Oct. 14 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek of Nationalist China saw Walter S. Robertson yesterday and entertained him at dinner, but the reason for the United States Assistant Secretary of State's visit still was a secret.
DENVER, Oct. 13 -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins said today that President Eisenhower had given him the "impression" he would appoint a career jurist to the Supreme Court vacany.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 13 -- Unofficial reports said today Hurricane Hazel razed whole towns, took a toll of hundreds in dead and injured, and caused untold damage in its sweep across Haiti's southwestern peninsula.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The Board of Trade published today revised lists of strategic items that British exporters may not sell to the Soveit bloc countries at all or only in limited quantities. The new order becomes effective Oct. 2.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 13 -- Alaska's Democratic candidates swept to victory today on a flood of landslide votes that shattered Republican control of the Territorial Legislature and returned E.L. (Bob) Bartlett as Delegate to Congress.
DENVER, Oct. 13 -- A Presidential board of inquiry has reported to President Eisenhower that a union-company deadlock continues at the atomic plants in Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky.

Witnesses before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Communist Aggression charged yesterday that the Soviet Union was guilty of diplomatic duplicity and persecution in two Transcaucasian countries, Armenia and Georgia.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Never Say Die, the American-owned-and-bred winner of the Epsom Derby and Doncaster St. Leger Stakes, will become England's highest-priced stallion next season.
Two hundred engineers for the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company (Hudson Tubes), operating between here and New Jersey, will vote today on whether to go on strike.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 13 -- A desperate fight to save the Moore-McCormack freighter Mormackite was waged by her officers and crew before the 6,200-ton vessel capsized and sank last Thursday with the loss of thirty-seven lives, according to testimony today of surviving crew members.

MAMRONECK, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Steve Doctor, husky driving range instructor from East Meadow, L.I., led the field today in the opening round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship.

MONTREAL, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Aluminium, Ltd., announced plans today to double the authorized capital of the company and to make a substantial increase in the productive capacity of a new aluminum plant at Kitimat, B.C.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Surgeon General Leonard A. Scheele estimated today that there were 389,600 professional nurses in this country.
Samuel A. Peck's 3-year-old colt Batfish, who had been going nowhere in no great hurry, bobbed up yesterday as the winner of the feature race at Belmont Park.
The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday reported a net income of $33,575,088 in the first nine months this year -- highest for the period in its forty-three years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Industrial output during the first half of 1954 was up sharply virtually everywhere in the non-Communist countries except in North America, where it continued to decline, the United Nations' Monthly Bulletin of Statistics reported today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Hard cash and club owner caution made the difference between Kansas City and Los Angeles as the new home of the Philadelphia Athletics.

MONTREAL, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings built up an early two-goal lead, then fought off a furious last-period assault by the Montreal Canadiens tonight to gain their third straight National Hockey League victory, 3 -- 2, before 14,518 fans.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 13 -- Labor in the United States, in cooperation with the free trade unions of Latin America, is backing a quiet fight against communism in Honduras.

BUFFALO, Oct. 13 -- High-ranking officers of the United States Army and the New York National Guard attended a testimonial dinner here tonight for Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, Commanding General of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division of the Army Reserve.

The Australasian pearling industry is the subject of a book by Norman Bartlett that Coward-McCann will issue Monday under the title "The Pearl Seekers." It is a chronicle of the divers who risk their lives thirty fathoms down and of "the dealings and double-dealings of the dealers and pearl doctors."

SO it was hot last night! "The Tender Trap," which opened at the Longacre, did not make the evening much more agreeable. The joint product of Max Shulman and Robert Paul Smith, it is a ready-made comedy about a New York bachelor who finally submits to matrimony.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union has advised Yugoslavia that it will raise no obstruction when the Trieste agreement is presented to the United Nations.

Inmates of Sing Sing Prison, Ossining, N. Y., will contribute to the Red Cross blood program today and tomorrow. Bloodmobile visits today are scheduled also at the New York Port of Embarkation, Brooklyn; the National City Bank Club, 20 Exchange Place; the New York Telephone Company, 13-11 Bayport Place, Far Rockaway, Queens, and the Nassau County chapter of the Red Cross, 264 Old Country Road, Minneola, L.I.

Charges of coercion and oppression against former Patrolman William Rudolph in connection with an arrest he made in 1949 were dismissed yesterday by a split decision in Special Sessions Court. The patrolman had been convicted of the charges in November of that year.

WAINSCOTT, L.I., Oct. 13 -- A Government allotment of $3,500 to permit the Army Corps of Engineers to start a long-range erosion control survey on Suffolk County's South Shore barrier beaches, was announced today by Representative Stuyvesant Wainwright.
C. Herbert Skinner gives some cogent reasons why a Democratic Congress should be elected this fall both for the good of the President and the nation. May I add two more excellent reasons.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- Guided missiles bearing nuclear warheads are "only a matter of time and ballistics," John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner in Germany after the war, declared here today. He addressed nearly 5,000 members of the American Gas Association at their annual convention.

"Beyond Adventure," a book about Robert E. Peary, Carl Akeley and Roy Chapman Andrews, will be published Oct. 27 by Duell, Sloan Pearce. It has been written by Mr. Andrews, who describes the hazard and hardship, suffering and frustration he and the two other explorers faced in expanding the scientific frontiers of the Gobi Desert in Outer Mongolia, the North Pole and the jungles of Africa.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France is seeking to revive some major provisions of the European Defense Community treaty, which his criticism helped to defeat in the French National Assembly.
Two supertankers will be launched within the next several days by two American shipyards.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., Oct. 14 -- You don't have to be dirty to run a gasoline station, according to Anthony Parranenti, who operates one at North Jerusalem Avenue and Bellmore Road here. Today he set out to prove this point.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Democrats held to their overwhelming Alaska victory margins today while political observers tried to analyze the factors that made it a virtual landslide. The answer was elusive.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 14 -- The Third Congressional District -- Southern Nassau -- has not sent a Democrat to the House of Representatives since 1912, when all of Nassau and Suffolk Counties and part of Queens composed one district. The split in the Republican party caused by the Bull Moose movement made the victory possible.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benton established 1955 cotton acreage allotments and marketing quotas today at the lowest level permitted by law.
DENVER, Oct. 14 -- Sixty-four roses graced President Eisenhower's desk in the temporary White House today as he reached his sixty-fourth birthday.
One hundred and thirty-two members of the police force will be promoted today in a ceremony to be held at 11 A.M. in the line-up room at Police Headquarters.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Alaska's first big uranium rush was on today with airborne prospectors pouring into the Happy River area (cross on map).

NEW HAVEN. Conn., Oct. 14 -- It may be because of the uncertainty whether Dennis McGill will be in shape to play, but Jordan Olivar believes Yale and Cornell are evenly matched in their football game in the Bowl Saturday. This is the same Jordan Olivar who rated his team as favorite over Columbia last week.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 14 -- An appeal for "fair play" in public life was sounded at the opening here today of the fifty-ninth annual convention of the Jewish War Veterans.

Shipboard, a 4-year-old son of Battleship, won the $28,050 Grand National Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. The crowd of 17,822 rather expected the victory, for Shipboard was the 5-4 favorite. Albert Foot rode the winner, who is owned by Montpelier.

Schenley Industries, Inc., plunged boldly last night into the sale of twelve-year-old and eight-year-old bourbon whiskies. Though Scotches and brandies have long boasted such ages, this is the first time in modern American distilling that such brands as the Schenley 12 and the eight-year-old Champion have been merchandised.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 14 -- Executives of the Colgate-Palmolive Company and city officials joined today in the official opening of the company's multimillion-dollar warehouse for soap and soap products.
The largest bank merger in the history of New York City was approved yesterday by stockholders of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

Potato futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange reached a record volume yesterday for the second consecutive day. Volume was 2,122 carlots (45,000 pounds to a car), compared with 2,099 on Wednesday. The heavy trading resulted from the Department of Agriculture's estimate of larger-than-anticipated crops.

Under the headline, "There is no miracle drug for the biggest child killer -- the traffic accident," the Advertising Council has issued a kit of illustrated ads for use in newspapers. In his letter offering free mats, Ted Rowe, volunteer coordinator of the campaign and advertising manager of International Business Machines Corporation, writes:

Failure by the United States to push toward a more liberal trade policy "could endanger our whole economy," Winthrop W. Aldrich, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, cautioned last night. He spoke at a dinner of the New York Board of Trade at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Navy has ordered a study of its system of supply, contracts and other matters that might have bearing on how the wrong kind of pipe came to be installed in the atomic submarine Nautilus and in a test engine being built for a second nuclear submarine.
The Citizens Union, announcing its recommendations in the Manhattan contests for the State Legislature, has given full endorsement -- its highest rating -- to ten incumbents and two other candidates.
