The Composers Group of New York opened its tenth anniversary season with a program in the Mason and Hamlin Salon in the G. Schirmer building. First performances of works by Paul Giasson, Robert Fairfax Birch and Harry Hewitt were offered.

OFFICIALS in the new Ohrbach store in Thirty-fourth Street called in a succession of experts last week to find out why the street lamp just to the right of the main door wouldn't light. Consolidated Edison came and found it didn't own the light. The Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity had a look and also disclaimed it.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Twenty helicopters from the United States aircraft carrier Saipan today began dropping medicines, food, clothing and other necessities in areas of southern Haiti devastated by Hurricane Hazel.

The people of this city have lost a good neighbor and the library profession an able and inspiring leader in the death, in mid-career, of Ralph A. Beals, director of the New York Public Library. He had spent earlier years teaching, and turned to library administration in 1940.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 14 -- The congress of the West German Trade Unions, representing more than 6,000,000 workers, has decided to enter the political arena against the Government coalition and the industrial managerial class.

The United States Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the 1953 conviction of thirteen secondary Communist leaders on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Nationalist China declared today that Burma could do "whatever it sees fit" in dealing with thousands of Nationalist "irregulars" who refuse to leave their jungle camps in northern Burma.

Seventy-eight local housing authorities sold yesterday issues of temporary loan notes totaling $208,524,000 at interest costs ranging from 0.62 to 0.9 per cent. The notes, which come due in four to thirteen months, are backed by Public Housing Administration subsidy contracts.

Undefeated Boston College will meet the Fordham eleven tonight at 8:15 in the Polo Grounds. The powerful Eagle line threatens to give the Rams as much trouble as the Boston University squad, which crushed Fordham, 55 -- 20, last week.

Corliss Lamont, author and educator, was indicted yesterday on a charge of contempt of Congress. He had refused to answer questions at an executive session of the investigating subcommittee of which Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, is chairman.

The seventh annual Bachelors Ball, a subscription dance for debutantes of recent seasons and bachelors between the ages of 22 and 35, will be held this year on Dec. 18 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. The event will be preceded by a buffet dinner in the Crystal Pavilion of the Sherry-Netherland.

If the trend of business at a given time is determined not by one index but by the general direction that most indices are pursuing, it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that if things are moving in any particular direction these days then that direction is certainly not downward and probably not even sideways.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The stock markets today overcame initial nervousness caused by labor troubles, regained many early losses and in some cases closed higher.
Renewed faith in the United Nations was expressed yesterday morning at the closing session of the 147th annual meeting of the Baptist Missionary Convention of New York State.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 14 -- Iran's spree of buying on credit all over the world has been checked.

ARMY plays Duke at Durham on the morrow. It's a game of considerable importance but it cannot begin to match in significance the Army-Duke affair of a year ago. That was a milestone because it marked the rebirth of West Point football and the restoration of the Black Knights to their proper place as a gridiron power.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, the second-seeded player from Cincinnati, today won the men's singles championship of the Pan-American tennis tournament with a 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2 victory over the 22-year-old Mexican champion, Mario Llamas.
A city-wide strike of school bus drivers may be staged Monday.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower is reviewing secret operations of the United States Central Intelligence Agency in Europe on the basis of a confidential report from Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, U.S.A.F. (retired), an authoritative source disclosed here tonight.

Former Deputy Chief Inspector Louis Goldberg asserted yesterday that Stephen P. Kennedy, now chief inspector, "caused consternation" and fear of spying when the Brooklyn morals squad was started. But Mr. Goldberg said he blocked Mr. Kennedy's proposal for a separate investigating unit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
May I call your attention to one highly appreciated area of courtesy being extended by taxicab drivers to women in New York City during this period of rampant crime.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia came back in state today for a visit to the country where he took refuge, eighteen years ago, from the first of the Fascist aggressions. The conquering Lion of Judah, Elect of God, Might of the Trinity, was greeted by Queen Elizabeth II at Victoria Station.

Mergers in the textile industry have not created monopolies in any sense, according to J. Spencer Love, chairman of the board of Burlington Mills Corporation. Few of the recent combinations have given to the merged companies more than a small fraction of the business available, he held, and in the case of Burlington Mills the company accounts for only 2 per cent of total textile output even after recent acquisitions.
Future gains in the control of cancer will depend largely upon the pharmaceutical industry, in the opinion of Dr. Cornelius P. Rhoads.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The Soviet Union agreed conditionally today to join the West in asking the United Nations Disarmament Commission to resume its efforts toward an agreement on disarmament and international control of atomic energy.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Senator Irving M. Ives expressed concern publicly today over apathy by upstate voters to the campaign for the Governorship.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Unusual golf on the part of Steve Doctor, a driving range instructor from East Meadow, L. I., enabled him to maintain the lead in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today.
An impressive and well-staged exhibit of costumes will open today at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 14 -- Communist China and Ceylon have concluded another deal calling for sale of 225,000 pounds of crepe rubber at a 'price above the current world rate. This is in addition to the 50,000 tons of sheet rubber which Ceylon will exchange for 270,000 tons of rice under the Sino-Ceylonese five-year trade agreement.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., will place on the market today a new issue of $12,500,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds of Wisconsin Public Service Corporation.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York started last night its campaign for $16,950,000 in behalf of its 116 affiliated social welfare and medical health agencies.
DUBLIN, Ireland, Oct. 14 -- Two pronouncements indicate that responsible political parties here will seek to solve the partition problem between Northern and Southern Ireland along cooperative lines.

The Government will continue stockpiling strategic and critical materials "just as rapidly as supplies become available and without creating undue hardship for the civilian economy," Arthur S. Flemming, Director of Defense Mobilization, said yesterday.

Applications for the Dec 11 examinations will be accepted up to Nov. 12. Unless otherwise indicated, candidates must be United States citizens and New York State residents. Maximum salaries are reached by five annual increases unless otherwise noted. For further information, write to the New York State Department of Civil Service, State Office Building, Albany.

PAGO PAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- William Willis attempted his raft voyage to "show that a lone man can conquer the ocean and the fury of the elements with his bare hands and the most rudimentary means of navigation."
ROME, Oct. 14 -- The Government committed Italy today to helping Italian-administered Trieste in such a way that the Triestines would never regret their reunion with Italy.
Mrs. Helen Watson, a tiny, gray-haired gentlewoman from Cleveland, who came to New York two weeks ago on a visit, is observing the city from a vantage point reached by few sightseers.
The consuls general of thirty-eight countries went up to the Bronx Zoo yesterday to see how some former residents of their countries are getting along.

Hurricane Hazel, a tropical storm that may be the worst so far this year, was sweeping steadily northward early today toward the Atlantic Coast. Official warnings advising special safety precautions were issued.

An ex-convict who the police believe may have information on the whereabouts of Elmer (Trigger) Burke, waterfront hoodlum who escaped from a Boston jail Aug. 28, was arrested near his home yesterday afternoon.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The United States refused today to accept a copy of a complaint from Chou En-lai, Communist China's Foreign Minister, to Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations. In his message the Peiping leader repeated and expanded charges that the United States had committed armed aggression against Formosa.
The 5-month-old nephew of a fugitive who escaped during a pistol battle with detectives Wednesday midnight was wounded accidentally six hours later as the police searched his parents' apartment.
The nation's largest closed-end investment company, the Tri-Continental Corporation, reported yesterday that it had established a new investment position in the automotive industry.

The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Oct. 25 for an issue of $10,000,000 of public improvement bonds dated July 1, 1954, and maturing serially from July 1, 1955, to July 1, 1966.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 14 -- Seriously concerned by wide differences in world copper price quotations, the Chilean Government is attempting to seize what it believes to be a golden moment to obtain higher prices.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Sixteen horses today staged a four-mile turf race that has become a 288-year-old monument to the fact that King Charles II liked horse racing almost as much as he liked pretty girls.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $255,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
A fire in the heart of Coney Island yesterday destroyed four abandoned buildings that had housed seventeen concessions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 703,193 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 18,690 cars or 2.6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 100,873 cars or 12.5 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 139,604 cars or 16.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
By gradually increasing his holdings during the past three years, Col. Henry Crown, Chicago industrialist, yesterday became the sole owner of the Empire State Building at 350 Fifth Avenue.
PAGO PAGO, Samoa, Oct. 14 -- William Willis, riding alone on a tiny balsa raft, arrived off here today after having drifted 6,000 miles from Callao, Peru. The voyage took almost four months.

The sixth annual Audio Fair, a display of the newest developments in loudspeakers, amplifiers, tape recorders and other sound-reproducing devices, opened yesterday afternoon at the New Yorker. The 141 exhibits, displayed on four floors of the hotel, represented an increase of twenty-five over last year's total at the exhibition, according to Harry N. Reizes, managing director of the fair.

BOSTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Boston took third place in the National Hockey League tonight when Lynn Patrick's Bruins defeated his brother Murray's New York Rangers, 5 -- 3, before 7,431 at the Garden. The Rangers fell to fourth place.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 14 -- Voters in Nassau County's wealthy North Shore communities and the heavily populated central section have a choice between two young attorneys for Representative from the Second Congressional District.

Although the trend to the straight line continues in garment silhouettes, shoe shapes have swerved off on an asymmetrical line judging from examples in the resort and holiday collection shown yesterday at Delman's, 754 Fifth Avenue.
The New York City Transit Authority has retained a public relations consultant at a $2,000-a-month fee for an indefinite period.

The New York City Opera Company will offer a revival of "Der Rosenkavalier" at the City Center Wednesday evening. The work is being restaged by Leopold Sachse; Joseph Rosenstock will conduct. Wilma Spence will be heard as the Marschallin, Frances Bible as Octavian, Laurel Hurley as Sophie and William Wilderman as Baron Ochs.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 14 -- President Syngman Rhee attempted today to limit the number of Korean newspapers. The effort was immediately opposed by leading publishers here.
BUFFALO, Oct. 14 -- Accidents, which are the leading cause of death in the early years of life, constitute a major public health problem that can be solved, it was declared here today.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Oct. 14 (UP) -- Willie Shoemaker broke his record for the Tanforan meet today by winning the first five races on the eight-race program.
BUFFALO, Oct. 14 -- Governor Dewey challenged the Democrats to state whether they would have preferred continuing the Korean war to weathering what he pictured as mild economic readjustment.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 14 -- Prime Minister U Nu suggested today an extension of United States economic aid to Southeast Asian countries under a formula that would include Burma indirectly. The Rangoon Government stopped direct United States assistance to Burma last year.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 13 -- The head of the French delegation in Hanoi was understood today to be discussing the possibility of French credits to the Vietminh, which ousted France and her forces from North Vietnam.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 14 -- Premier Ralf Toerngren resigned today after the Agrarian and Social Democrat Ministers in his coalition Cabinet had refused to support his emergency economic program.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- In its first opinion of the new term, the Supreme Court set aside today its previous action disbarring Abraham J. Isserman, a Newark, N.J., lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- One of the most interesting developments of American life in the second quarter of this century is the increasing scope and editorial quality of the union labor press. It remains partisan for what it conceives to be the rights of organized labor to special economic and legal privileges.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Mississippi Power and Light Company, indirectly a party to the Dixon-Yates contract, filed a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today denying charges of its former treasurer, J.D. Stietenroth, that it kept "two sets of books" and had inadequate financial reserves.
HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 14 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, deep in Democratic territory, predicted tonight that millions of Democrats would vote to give President Eisenhower a Republican Congress.

TWO events gave special significance to the concert that Dimitri Mitropoulos directed as conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony concert last night in Carnegie Hall. One was the first American performance of Shostakovich's Tenth Symphony.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Consolidated Foods Corporation stockholders at their annual meeting were told that the company late today acquired Gibbs Co. of Baltimore, a food canner.
BUDAPEST, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Bjoern Thofelt of Sweden, son of a former Olympic pentathlon champion, won the modern world pentathlon title today by finishing high in all events but first in none.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Egypt told the United Nations today that she was following a deliberate policy of broad tolerance toward ships going through the Suez Canal to and from Israel.

IN honor of the Columbia University bicentennial, the National Academy of Design is opening to the public today an exhibition based on work in its own extensive collections -- portraits of and work by men who were leaders in the development of American culture.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Butchers grade of hogs gained 15 to 25 cents while sows were up 25 cents in an active trade today. The market was aided by the fact that salable receipts, totaling 7,500 head fell 1,500 under the advance estimate, Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

WAIT until the third act and Robert Ardrey has something stirring to say in "Sing Me No Lullaby," which opened at the Phoenix last evening. He has written a very complicated play about the spiritual malaise of America today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The Army Times said today that "doubting Thomases" were wondering whether the story of his wartime "cloak and dagger" experiences as told by a Republican member of Congress was not a hoax.

New local-government bond issues totaling $1,496,629,366 will come up for approval on Nov. 2 at election day referendums, according to a survey by The Daily Bond Buyer, trade newspaper of local-government finance.

Department stores sustained a slight decline in sales but a severe drop in profits in the first six months of 1954, according to a survey by the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The earnings of specialty stores also shrank.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 14 -- Vice Chancellor William Marvel of the Chancery Court today ruled that the ten Negro students dropped from Milford High School had a "clear legal right" to be reinstated.

The Museum of Modern Art and the C.B.S. television network will join in a special program tomorrow evening to report on the relation of modern art to everyday living. The program, entitled "Dimension," will be presented from 6:30 to 7 o'clock over Channel 2.

The Bradley Container Corporation announced yesterday that it would be the first packaging concern to use an electron beam process for sterilizing already packaged drugs, pharmaceuticals and other products.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that the Securities and Exchange Commission lacked authority to pass upon fees paid by a holding company to a financial adviser hired during reorganization of a subsidiary.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The Ministry of Labor intervened tonight in an attempt to settle London's crippling dock strike.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 14 -- India and Communist China signed today a comprehensive trade agreement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Republicans are still moaning low about that doggy in Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson's window, but there is very little historical evidence that the unbright sayings of politicians really decide the outcome of elections.

The football Giants' offensive line-up in the early stages of the game with the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds on Sunday will depend upon where the Giants get possession of the ball, their coach, Jim Lee Howell, said yesterday.
Stocks rocked yesterday under the most determined selling attack since Aug. 31, rallied briefly and then fell again to close near their lows for the day on the New York Stock Exchange.
J. Raymond McGovern, the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, charged yesterday that the Democratic state candidates were presenting "a distorted picture" of unemployment to get votes.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Higher education faces the greatest expansion in the nation's history. Within ten years the college and university enrollment is expected to reach 4,000,000, a 50 per cent increase over the current study body.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies dipped into the minor leagues -- and for the fourth time into the New York Yankee organization -- today and tapped Mayo Smith to lead the National League baseball club in 1955.

The recent announcement by the Administration that 6,926 federal employes had been dismissed as security risks between May 28, 1953, and June 30, 1954, with 1,743 of the total involving subversive associations or activities, presents misleading picture which needs more clarification than it is presently being afforded by both parties.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -- Joseph I. Breen, Hollywood censorship high commissioner since 1934, was retired today at his own request.

Many young women from New York and various cities in the country will be presented formally at the intercity Mistletoe Debutante Ball to be held on Dec. 30 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The fete will serve as a benefit for the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 -- Capt. Charles F. May, first vice president of the Masters, Mates and Pilots Union, A.F.L., said today his union's negotiations with the Pacific Maritime Association "are deadlocked." He added, however, that "no strike is imminent."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Repercussions from Secretary Wilson's dissertation on dogs still echoed along the political front today.
ONE of the contemporary theatre's treasured vials of vitriol, "The Man Who Came to Dinner," was diluted on Wednesday evening over C.B.S. color television to a bottle full of stage "pop."

A famous New York hotel has been acquired by the Sheraton Corporation of America, which last month purchased the operating rights to the Astor Hotel here. The Astor deal included an option to buy the Times Square block after two years.

DENVER, Oct. 14 -- President Eisenhower will lend a hand to New York Republican state and Congressional candidates but a major speech in New York in the final days of the campaign appeared somewhat doubtful today.

NEWARK, Oct. 14 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, late this afternoon canceled, suddenly and without explanation, all of his speaking engagements for tonight.

THE week-end offers a variety of opportunities for the hunter who is willing to spend a few hours in travel, for the upland game season is in full swing in the northern zone, and the duck season will open at noon tomorrow except on Long Island and lower Westchester County.

"Some progress" was reported yesterday as East and Gulf Coast shipowners and representatives of the Masters, Mates and Pilots Union, A.F.L., negotiated against a contract deadline of midnight tonight.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Averell Harriman today carried his campaign into the normally Republican southern tier of counties of New York State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Continuance of construction activity at a record level and a large volume of retail sales highlighted the nation's economic picture last month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A waste-free meat at 32 cents a pound would be something of a find. According to the calculations of the city's Department of Markets, this is the current cost of medium-sized eggs, high in the same kind of protein as meat and with no waste but their thin shell.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The status of the Philadelphia Athletics' franchise tonight was a lot like the nursery rhyme -- Button, Button, Who's Got the Button?
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Charles Godchaux has sold his holdings in Godchaux Sugars, Inc., one of Louisiana's largest industries, to a group acting through Fahnestock Co. of New York.
TOKYO, Oct. 14 -- United States military authorities are considering independent action soon if the deadlock over the overvalued South Korean hwan remains unbroken.

Two pitchers and an outfielder were added to the Dodgers' roster yesterday, bringing the total to forty-three. Three are on the National Defense list, which still leaves the club with the legal limit of forty men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized Western Maryland Railway Company to revamp its corporate structure by issuing new securities to be exchanged for its outstanding common and preferred stocks.
BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- The United Fruit Company's general office here received word today of heavy damage to its crops in four Latin American countries as a result of heavy floods and winds.

After more than eight hours of unbroken negotiations, a three-member peace committee appointed by Mayor Wagner decided at 4:15 A.M. today to put off until 11 A.M. its drive for a formula for settlement of the crippling truck strike scheduled for midnight tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. asserted tonight that more than half the mileage of state highways was classified as "below tolerable," according to Dewey administration statistics.

The skeleton at the feast in London, when German rearmament and sovereignty were decided, was the Saar. It is still capable of spoiling that banquet, because without an agreement on the Saar there can be no binding rapprochement between France and Germany and hence no over-all European settlement.

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday rose to 9,193,000,000 kilowatt hours from 9,158,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Oct. 10, 1953, was 8,307,000,000 kilowatt hours.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday. Active months moved 2 points off to 10 points up.

Today's new film is "The Bob Mathias Story," a Mathlon Production and Allied Artists presentation based on the athlete's life, featuring Mr. Mathias and Melba Mathias, his wife, in the principal roles, supported by Ward Bond, Howard Petrie, Ann Doran, Diane Jergens and Paul Bryar, at the Palace.

Complaints about overcrowding and the lack of adequate facilities in the public schools in Manhattan and Brooklyn were heard yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The occasion was the commission's second public hearing on its proposed 1955 capital budget of $814,587,730.

In your editorial "The Act of London," published on Oct. 4, you note quite correctly the historical turning point. But when you get to the uncertainties the pact faces in the French Parliament, you recognize one-half of the problem. The other half not given is Soviet anticipation of the inevitable.
GENEVA, Oct. 14 -- The International Labor Office was asked today to bring about international labor-management agreements in the European iron and steel industry.

A growing bond of mutual trust now appears to be encouraging economic cooperation among the Western and free Asian nations. This was the keynote at the opening yesterday of a two-day Far East Conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
In a recheck of the registration in New York City, the Board of Elections reported yesterday that 2,463,056 men and women had qualified for the election on Nov. 2.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- French and Saar authorities were understood today to have agreed on continuing the close economic relationship between the Saar and France. They also were said to have agreed on the desirability of placing the Saar under international supervision that could be exerted by the seven powers allied under the Brussels Treaty -- France, West Germany, Britain, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

Reflecting the sharply reduced operating rate from a year ago, earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, declined in the three and nine months periods that ended Sept. 30 from the corresponding periods a year ago.

There is a note of healthy realism in the reaction of official Japan to the honeyed words of the most recent joint Soviet-Chinese Communist communique. Moscow and Peiping talked in a general way about restoring diplomatic relations with the Japanese and dangled the usual bait of a lucrative trade with Red China.
One out of every three families in this country may have some kind of a power boat by 1964.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, whose remarks about bird dogs and kennel dogs and unemployment touched off a political storm, said tonight he was through with political speechmaking between now and the Nov. 2 elections.

Now that school is under way it is difficult not to believe that courses in salesmanship aren't being taught during the day, sandwiched somewhere between more orthodox elementary school courses such as arithmetic and "social studies."

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Oct. 14 -- Experience in the line "will be the deciding factor that will make our team go," Coach Roger DesRoches declared today as he sent his twenty-four-man Canterbury School squad through a drill in preparation for Saturday's clash with Gunnery.

A plot of 30,000 square feet at the northwest corner of Northern and Parsons Boulevards, in Flushing, Queens, has been purchased by the Horn Hardart Company for improvement with a restaurant and retail food shop.

Representative Jacob K. Javits Republican candidate for Attorney General, charged yesterday that his Democratic opponent, Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., was no true fighter for civil rights.
Bigger payments to the jobless are likely if the Republicans win the New York State election, Senator Irving M. Ives declared last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A cease and desist order to end price fixing in the wholesaling of stationery and other fine paper as well as wrapping papers was issued by the Federal Trade Commission today.

A record $140,691,000 was earned by the General Electric Company in the first nine months this year. A substantially smaller tax bill enabled the giant electrical manufacturer to lift earnings 20 per cent over a year ago despite a 7 per cent drop in sales.
I read your editorial "Segregation; What Next?" in your issue of Oct. 3 and was shocked that you could write with such bias.

President Eisenhower called upon American industry and leaders in technology last night to aid in the development of the proposed atomic pool aiming to harness the vast energy of the atom for the building of a better world.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, arrived today for a week's consultations on the defense of the Middle East, South Asia and Southeast Asia.

YONKERS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Medley Hanover, a one-eyed 3-year-old filly driven by her owner, Eugene Pownall of Orlando, Fla., won the featured Glenwood Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight by a nose in 2:05 3/5.

The C.I.O. took much needed and courageous action last week when its executive committee appointed a special committee, under the chairmanship of Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, to look into, and crack down on, any maladministration of welfare funds among its member unions.

A World War II memorial statue, rejected as unfit in 1945, has quietly won city approval and Parks Commissioner Robert Moses has won another argument -- after nine years. Behindthe-scenes pressure from Vice Admiral Alfred C. Richmond, who took over last summer as Commandant of the Coast Guard, started a chain of events that revived the memorial.

Behindthe-scenes pressure from Vice Admiral Alfred C. Richmond, who took over last summer as Commandant of the Coast Guard, started a chain of events that revived the memorial.
New borrowings by tobacco interests were the major influence in a $42,000,000 rise in New York City banks' business loans during the week ended on Wednesday.

Two committees have been formed to assist in arrangements for the varied social events being planned in connection with the sixty-sixth National Horse Show. The event will open at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 2 and continue through Nov. 9.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A high Hungarian Communist says "many comrades" have been unjustly tried and sentenced on false charges by the State Security Office (Secret Police) in recent years.

The hamburger is a mainstay of the amateur and veteran cook alike. A pound of it can feed two expansively or, when incorporated in a spaghetti sauce, a party (unexpected perhaps) of ten or more. It knows no season (though a variety of seasonings), no class, no age group.
NORTH WILDWOOD, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Representative Charles R. Howell charged today that his Republican opponent was ignoring the issue of unemployment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Facing a Congressional investigation of its proposed controversial power contract with the Dixon-Yates interests, the Atomic Energy Commission has sought the Attorney General's views on its legality.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 14 -- A Coast Guard operations officer, and a vice president of the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., today recommended that all merchant ships be required to carry large "float-away" rafts with radar reflectors.
BOSTON, Oct, 14 -- The papers of four generations of the Adams family, said to be the most important private collection of source material on American history, are to be published.
BOONTON, N. J., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Fred Baker of Maplewood and Bob Crowley of Essex Fells won the qualifying medal in the New Jersey pro-pro tournament today with a best-ball 32, 33 -- 65.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- The three Western High Commissioners have protested to the Russians about the "buzzing" of a British airliner in the Berlin air corridor last month, a high commission spokesman said today.
A Brooklyn television repair service outfit charged, with defrauding customers of $350,000 annually was the target yesterday of the District Attorney's office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl said today that he would hear arguments on Oct. 22 on whether he should disqualify himself from further participation in the Owen Lattimore case.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 -- William O'Dwyer, former Ambassador to Mexico, told a Congressional investigating group today that the two biggest steps the United States could take to combat Communist infiltration in Latin America would be to boast less in the region and give it more economic assistance.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 -- The five downtown department stores disclosed tonight the terms of a new revised wage contract offer to Local 249 of the General Teamsters, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, A.F.L., as the settlement for their eleven-month strike.
For twenty-seven minutes and $5.85, plus tax, Lloyd Jordan, the head coach at Harvard, and Lou Little, his Columbia counterpart, exchanged compliments over the long-distance telephone yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- South Africa protested today against an Iraqi charge here Tuesday that the Dutch Reformed Church was in part responsible for racial segregation in the Union and in mandated South-West Africa.

ON June 15, 1215, in a field at Runnymede, the triumphant barons forced King John to sign the Great Charter, Magna Charta. Six Weeks later the King's Chamberlain, the Lord Warin fitzGerold, returned to his manor of Stogursey in Somerset and informed his 13-year-old daughter that her marriage was arranged. Margaret took the news calmly.
Sales and earnings of the Continental Can Company reached new highs for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Wheat displayed considerable strength today, especially in the deferred futures, which were stronger than the December contract. Commission buying was more active, and there was a little mill buying which induced some local short covering.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos of Baltusrol won chief honors in the Garden State Women's Golf Association's last one-day tournament of the season with a two-over-women's-par 37, 40 -- 77, at the Essex Fells course today.

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame challenged yesterday the often-repeated contention of officials of the Brooklyn Public Library that the library was a "stepchild" of the city in budgetary, appropriations.
MOSCOW, Oct. 14 -- One phrase -- "peaceful coexistence of socialism and capitalism" -- occurs again and again these days in Moscow commentaries on Soviet foreign policy.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 15 -- Senator Matthew M. Neely is pushing 80, but he isn't being pushed much by a younger Republican opponent in his drive for a fifth term in the United States Senate.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal telephone subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $524,416,776 in the twelve months ended Aug. 31. This was equal to $11.84 a share on A.T. T.'s outstanding capital stock and compares with a net of $452,146,107, or $11.47 a share, in the preceding twelve months.

The log of hurricanes preceding Hazel so far this year shows that Carol, which swept over Long Island and New England an Aug. 31, was the most devastating. It caused sixty-eight deaths and property damage of $500,000,000.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 -- An immediate inquiry into why the United States had given no cash assistance to the anti-Communist regime in Guatemala was promised today by Representative Patrick J. Hillings, Republican of California.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Allan B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, said tonight that he appreciated President Eisenhower's, recognition of the improtance of expanding markets for farm products.

The Board of Estimate deferred action yesterday on a proposal by Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley for inclusion of $10,000,000 in the 1955 capital budget to finance public parking lots and garages in all boroughs except Richmond.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Steve Doctor, the driving-range instructor from East Meadow, L.I., became the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association champion today.
The plans of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to build six new recreation centers next year for a total cost of $8,000,000 were assailed and defended yesterday before the City Planning Commission.

The six-story apartment house at 2186 Cruger Avenue in the Bronx has been purchased by a client of Marvin L. Levitt, lawyer, for cash above mortgages of $325,000. The seller was a client of the law firm of Barry Katzman.

John B. Kelly, vice president of Philadelphia's Fairmount Park Commission, was honored at a luncheon yesterday by leaders of the theatrical profession for his efforts in creating Philadelphia's municipally operated summer tent theatre, the Playhouse in the Park.

The traditional large New York taxicab, like every vehicle, has an inside and an outside. Its inside could accommodate with ease six passengers if the seat next to the driver were used -- seven or even eight if passengers sat close. This, despite the fact that the average hack payload is a fraction under two people and the fact that this city's agonizing traffic situation has not been helped by the traditional cab's outsized outside.
The Young Republican Club of Columbia University is in a turmoil because its executive committee has endorsed the party's state ticket except for Jacob K. Javits, candidate for Attorney General.

NEWARK, Oct. 15 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for Senator from New Jersey, resumed his campaign today, after thirty-six hours in seclusion, with what turned out to be a triumphal tour in this area.

What is there in autumn more comforting to a man than an open fire -- in its place -- a big chair and a reasonably good book? Add to these a window with a wide vista of earth and sky and you have a combination hard to beat. But not impossible.

The first major settlement affecting defaulted dollar bonds of pre-war German corporations took place yesterday. Nine successor companies to Vereinigte Stahlwerke (United Steel Works) took over responsibility for four old bond issues of the pre-war Ruhr steel and coal mining cartel, including obligations of the Rheinelbe Union, an affiliate.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 -- Universal is hopeful of being able to coax Percy Kilbride back to work as Pa Kettle. The studio has hired Richard Wilson, who left a year ago after producing "Ma and Pa Kettle at Home" and "The Golden Blade," to prepare another episode in the comedy series.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Representative Charles Brownston, Republican of Indiana, told waiters today he had intended no reflection "by comparing them with the Democratic Cabinet under Truman."

Governor Dewey made a double-barreled attack last night on Averell Harriman and Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. He charged that the latter had disqualified himself from any office through his "Hollywood scenario" rendition of harness racing and gangster murders.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's farm speech last night at Indianapolis as recorded by The New York Times:
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 15 -- President Eisenhower appealed to farmers tonight to help maintain a Republican Congress.

I am neither a lawyer nor a politician. I am, I believe, a member of that sizable body of voters which votes for those candidates who seem best qualified to fill the post they seek. I vote without regard for party labels. I am an Independent.
Negotiators for East and Gulf Coast shipowners and the Masters, Mates and Pilots Union, A.F.L., reached agreement early today on terms of a new contract.

Deere Co., second largest producer of agricultural equipment in the nation, had a net profit of $16,305,458 in the nine months ended July 31, compared with $19,975,483 in the similar period a year earlier. Sales declined to $256,549,110 from $305,504,364.
MIAMI, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Miami's hard-running sophomore, backs took charge in the second period tonight to overpower Mississippi State, 27 -- 13, in a struggle between two bruising ground attacks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Kerr-McGee Oil Industries, Inc., of Oklahoma City says it named the wrong tracts by mistake in twelve bids Wednesday totaling $15,014,000 for oil and gas leases in submerged lands off Louisiana.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 15 -- After his return from an official visit to Communist China in December, U Nu, Prime Minister of Burma, one of the nations of the so-called Asian "neutralist bloc," would like to visit the United States.
Gifts to charities of about $60,000,000 were disclosed yesterday in an accounting settling the estate of Mrs. Mary Stillman Harkness, widow of Edward S. Harkness, financier and philanthropist.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The year's most vicious hurricane carried its woes on north tonight after leaving at least six persons dead in Maryland and blacking out all of the eastern shore.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 15 -- Hurricane Hazel swept past this Navy city today taking at least one life, injuring scores and causing extensive property damage.

Curtis High's football team can become the first in the city to clinch a Public Schools Athletic League sectional championship by defeating Far Rockaway today on the Seahorse field in Queens. Curtis already holds three-touchdown triumphs over the other teams in the section, Adams and Flushing.
Britain will produce 100,000 kilowatts of electricity from atomic energy for industrial and household use within the next two years, a British expert forecast here yesterday.

The merger of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company became effective at the close of business yesterday, according to N. Baxter Jackson, chairman of the merged bank, to be known as Chemical Corn Exchange Bank.
The backlog of financing facing the new capital market is shrinking.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Disaffection among dairy farmers and the scheduled decontrol of residential rents in the city of Binghamton just before election are threatening to make serious inroads into the usual Republican pluralities in the Southern Tier.

ACCORDING to an old but unauthenticated story, a man who made elaborate plans for making a kangaroo census of Australia gave up after a few days, explaining that his idea was excellent but impractical, because the kangaroos would not remain still long enough to be counted.

The National Schools of Design, an organization representing forty art schools, will hold its 1954 conference here and near here for three days, beginning today. Most of the sessions will take place at Eighth Street and Fourth Avenue, at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, which, with the Parsons School of Design and Pratt Institute Art School, will be the host organizations.
The Pakistani Government announced yesterday a new economic policy carefully designed to attract foreign investment in the industries of the seven-year-old nation.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Lieut. Hoyt S. Vandenberg Jr., son of the late United States Air Chief of Staff, parachuted from his F-86 Sabrejet ten miles south of Frankfurt today when it exploded or caught fire at 8,000 feet.

Commodity futures on the New York exchanges drifted irregularly yesterday on generally light volume. Trading was marked by balancing of holdings for the week-end. The threat of a truck strike had a steadying influence on some prices.
A total of 743 pints of blood, the largest thus far this month, was collected on Thursday by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The stock markets overcame today a combination of factors that caused dealers to lower prices at the start of business.

The threat of Hurricane Hazel forced postponement of last night's scheduled clash at the Polo Grounds between Fordham's football, team and unbeaten Boston College. The contest was reset for this afternoon at 1:30 o'clock.

Sugar Ray Robinson, who gave up his world middleweight championship in December, 1952, to enter the entertainment world as a tap dancer, formally announced yesterday that he would attempt a pugilistic comeback.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The Negro population in Britain is increasing rapidly, and its assimilation is a complex problem.

Gilbert Miller revealed yesterday he had engaged Robert Lewis to direct Agatha Christie's murder-mystery, "Witness for the Prosecution." A much-sought-after director, Mr. Lewis will begin putting the Christie drama through its paces on Nov. 1.

LONDON, Oct. 15 (Reuters) -- Italy has rejoined the International Wheat Agreement -- but with an import quota of only 100,000 metric tons, it was announced yesterday. The decision was announced at the conclusion of the International Wheat Council's three-day conference.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The Royal Navy is about to complete construction of three Tiger Class cruisers. These may be the last cruisers armed only with guns to be built for Britain's fleet.

CAIRO, Oct. 15 -- Authorities have closed MENA, the Egyptian explanation news agency, without public explanation. The action was reported to have been taken because the agency was held respossible for the misquotation of a Cabinet minister on Egypt's relations with the Sudan.

The labor difficulties of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N.J., have been ironed out and the company is once again in the running for a $28,000,000 Navy contract for the construction of four destroyer-escort vessels.

The American Merchant Marine Institute reports "fabulous" success with its three-month-old campaign employing stickers to publicize the American shipping industry as a market for the country's farm and factory production.
The American Association of Port Authorities will discuss at its annual convention this month what its members call a serious deterioration in Federal channel maintenance.

PAGOPAGO, American Samoa, Oct. 15 (AP) -- William Wilis -- one man against the sea -- reached Samoa today after 115 days on a thirty-four-foot raft. During the drifting voyage his water gave out and his stove failed. He lived in large part on raw food from the sea.
As a representative of 10,000 postal clerks employed in the New York Post Office I read with great interest your editorial of Oct. 12 entitled, "Wanted: Public Servants."

Police Commissioner Francis W.H. Adams announced yesterday the biggest shake-up of top police officials since he took office ten months ago. He also reiterated that the city must have more policemen immediately.

Now shown amidst the elegant bric-a-brac of Bonwit Teller's gift shop are the first food products that department store has offered in many years. The items have a familiar look to this department, for they are from the New Boston (Mass.) Inn.

The Thompson-Starrett Company, Inc., international engineering and construction company, announced yesterday the election of John E. Kalinka as president and chief executive officer, succeeding J.R. Van Raalte, who was made executive committee chairman.

Many New Yorkers have a Robsjohn-Gibbings taste but a limited furniture budget. The problem of decorating a home pleasantly without mortgaging incomes to time payments is faced by many young homemakers.

May I mention what strikes me as a relevant point in connection with the discussion of Secretary Wilson's notorious "bird dog" speech? This speech alone would go far to explain why the Republican party appears to be losing at the polls. There are countless Americans who associate Republicans with blind pursuit of money and power that paralyzes their human imagination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company today asked the Federal Power Commission to reconsider an order authorizing the American Louisiana Pipe Line Company to build a $130,000,000 line into Michigan.

BUFFALO, Oct. 15 -- Breakfast, lunch and dinner for the average American contains 184 micrograms of DDT, the insecticide, the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association heard today.

Music, particularly jazz, has a beneficial effect upon psychiatric patients awakening from electrical shock treatment, the fifth annual conference of the National Association for Music Therapy was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today approved the sale of 17,500 tons of Government-owned copper to industrial users to relieve severe shortages caused by strikes in copper mines and refineries.
Three persons were killed last night as hurricane Hazel swept past the Metropolitan area uprooting trees, cutting off power and communications and disrupting transportation.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 15 -- An undefeated Yale eleven plays host to Cornell, a three-time loser, in the Yale Bowl tomorrow. It will be the seventeenth meeting of the two rivals in a series dating to 1889.
The first general truck strike in six years hit the metropolitan area at 12:01 A.M. today.
Plans to raise $5,000,000 for supermarket construction through the sale of 100,000 shares of a new $50 par preferred stock were announced yesterday by the Penn Fruit Company, Inc.

PELHAM N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Hurricane Hazel's early rain and wind this evening caused the Pelham Tercentennial Committee to postpone an outdoor pageant that was to have celebrated the community's 300th birthday.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Hurricane Hazel battered the Carolinas with destructive winds and water today, killed at least six persons, injured scores and left eight or nine unaccounted for. Damage was in the millions.

The basic writings of the great philosophers from the Middle Ages to the present will be made available by the New American Library in January in a series of paperbound volumes to be called "The Mentor Philosophers." Each of the six volumes, to be published over a period of two years, will be edited by scholars here and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Walter S. Robertson, Assistant Secretary of State, denied today that he had gone to Formosa to ask Chinese Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek to halt attacks on the Chinese mainland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission issued today trade practice rules designed to protect purchasers against false claims in the sale of recently developed chemical soil conditioners.

The announcement by Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, that he has under consideration a new study program to consist half in engineering courses and half in the social sciences underlines again a trend in higher education that has gained momentum since the Second World War.
A conference on religion and medicine will be held at Columbia University today under the auspices of the P. and S. Club (Physicians and Surgeons).

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Hurricane Hazel was accompanied here by torrential rains, whose maximum force was diminished only slightly by the storm's overland passage. Even west of the Blue Ridge -- outside the hurricane belt -- the rain deluged the parched countryside.

What is surely one of the lowest points yet reached anywhere in the current political campaign has been achieved by the enemies of Clifford P. Case, the distinguished citizen who is running on the Republican ticket for Senator from New Jersey.

Although the complaints and criticisms that pre-adolescents characteristically aim at their families often may be unwelcome or unpleasant, they can serve a valuable purpose by helping the parents to "stay flexible," Dr. Peter Neubauer said yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- A sharp fight developed in the Radical party's congress in Marseilles today between the followers of Premier Pierre Mendes-France and the conservative elements in the party supporting Leon Martinaud-Deplat, party chairman since the liberation.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told a story yesterday about Andrei Y. Vishinsky, the Soviet Union's permanent delegate to the United Nations. At a luncheon given in her honor at the Advertising Club by Isaac Liberman, president of Arnold Constable, Mr. Liberman introduced Mrs. Roosevelt to the fifty guests as "the first lady of the world."

The New York Football Giants yesterday signed Rnss Carroccio, 235-pound guard from Passaic, N.J., and former University of Virginia player. To make room for Carroccio, Jack Stroud, starting right guard, was placed on the injury list for thirty days.

Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., rejected yesterday an industry plea that he assume personal command of union efforts to hammer out a settlement before last night's strike deadline.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson tonight charged the Eisenhower Administration had "sentenced to death by slow strangulation" the nation's water and power policy that was fifty years in the making.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Private eyes and other phone-tappers should find eavesdropping harder from now on. A tamperproof telephone wire, designed to balk not only direct hook-ups but induction coils, was patented this week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- If a mass of cold air lying to the west of Washington had moved eastward faster, Hurricane Hazel would not have moved inland so far, the Weather Bureau said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- Hurricane Hazel, still packing 100-mile-an-hour gusts of wind, roared into Pennsylvania early tonight, killing at least three persons as it blasted a destructive path across the state.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 15 (AP) -- A Superior Court jury tonight found Frederick Hammer guilty of assault with intent to kill his estranged wife, Andrea Luckenbach Hammer, shipping heiress.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 15 -- Proposals to revise and remodel drastically the future program of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization were received with apparent approval today at the meeting here of the United States National Commission on UNESCO.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The nation's capital weathered the big winds of hurricane Hazel tonight. The storm passed on to the north leaving downed trees, power and phone lines.

Separates, a favorite fashion, have been adopted for women who wear white uniforms in their work. An innovation in dress for nurses, laboratory technicians, etc., these styles by Tiffiny were shown yesterday at Macy's.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Adm. Arthur W. Radford said tonight that United States air power was "second to none" but warned that recent Soviet aviation development, particularly in long-range jet bombers, left no room for "complacency."

If Defense Secretary Wilson were more subtle it might be possible to doubt the earnestness of his apology over the "unfortunate mistake" he made in "bringing up those bird dogs at the same time I was talking about people."
