The following is a round-up of new furnishings for children's rooms that may be of interest to the homemaker:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- India expressed serious concern today that Ahmed S. Bokhari of Pakistan might have "an unconscious bias" in administering the United Nations post of Under Secretary for the Department of Public Information.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 15 -- Shigeru Yoshida, Japanese Premier, and Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, announced jointly today that they had reached "complete agreement" in the talks held during the former's four-day visit to this country.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- The Soviet Union asked the United Nations General Assembly today to take up its charges of United States aggression against Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent to 109.7 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for farm products and processed foods were responsible for the increase as the index for all other commodities remained unchanged.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia presented a pair of elephant tusks to the Lord Mayor and Corporation of the City of London today.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 15 -- Five individuals and three publications received bronze medallion awards of the Southwest Journalism Forum here: ...
ROME, Oct. 15 -- Pope Pius XII told 100 of the leading police officials of the world today that it was their duty not only to catch criminals but also to contribute toward their redemption.
The following books of a religious and an inspirational nature have been issued recently:
The Abington Township, Pa., School District Authority announced yesterday that it would take bids on Nov. 4 for $5,950,000 of revenue bonds due on Nov. 1 from 1956 to 1994.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Oct. 15 -- Seven thousand school children in this resort city will be inoculated with gamma globulin tomorrow in an effort to head off a possible polio epidemic.

Lumber production in the week ended ltst Saturday was 10.8 per cent above that in the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 6.2 per cent and orders were down 2.5 per cent.
CAIRO, Oct. 15 -- Anthony Nutting, British Parliamentary Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, returned to Cairo today with plans to speed a formal British-Egyptian accord on the Suez Canal zone.

The term "sovereignty" has become a "bogy," Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, president of the United Nations General Assembly, told 300 guests last night at the annual dinner and ball of the United Nations Correspondents Association.
Corliss Lamont, author and philosopher, was released in $2,000 bail yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan after he had pleaded not guilty to a charge of contempt of Congress.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15 -- In a small wooded park that stands in the shadow of the great walls of the Kremlin an orderly throng of Soviet citizens, with a sprinkling of foreigners, now gathers every morning.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Hurricane Hazel was quite a record breaker for the Navy as well as the Weather Bureau.

SCULPTURE, paintings and drawings by the West Coast artist Raymond Puccinelli make up his first New York showing at the Coeval Gallery. Puccinelli is a traditionalist chiefly interested in the feminine figure and in animals, but he tempers his realism with a kind of poetic idealization.
SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Representative Charles R. Howell shook hands with hundreds of factory workers today during a tour of Somerset County's industrial belt.

DETROIT Oct. 15 (AP) -- The University of Detroit, playing for the fourth consecutive time on a field slowed by mud, defeated Villanova, 20 -- 0, tonight on sparkling punt returns by Lee Riley and Bob Burgmeier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Canadian Army will test-fire the Nike, the United States guided missile designed for anti-aircraft work, at Fort Churchill, Man., next January and February to determine the effect of extreme cold on its complex working parts.

TORONTO, Oct. 15 -- Herbert Carter, coal merchant and a leading citizen of Frankford, Ontario, was discharged from jury duty yesterday. Mr. Carter, who had balked at taking the oath to try a Belleville murder case, explained today that he objected to capital punishment.

Two buildings on plot 50 by 84 feet at 261-63 Pearl Street, southwest corner of Fulton Street, have been purchased for cash by Charles F. Noyes from Lawrence and Simon Ottinger, Sylvan E. Rosenthal and George O. Baer, trustees.

The trouble with Charles Rosen's recital last night in Town Hall was not so much the playing as the program. Few -- very few -- pianist's are sympathetic to all fields. Mr. Rosen, a talented pianist whose tone and intellect admirably suit a certain type of music, concentrated largely on another.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- The creation of a series of community colleges and technical institutes over the country was proposed today by Dr. Carroll V. Newsom, New York State Associate Commissioner of Education.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Navy's on-again, off-again plan to build a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier is on again.
Hughes Aircraft Co of California, in the Amoco Building, 555 5th Ave -- Cushman Wakefield Inc, agents.

Three new buildings, designed to house a dome-shaped auditorium, faculty club and executive offices, will be erected on the twelve-acre plot of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. They will cost about $2,000,000.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Sir Walter Monckton, Minister of Labor, announced tonight that he would set up a court of inquiry into the causes and circumstances of the dock strike that has led to the shutdown of this port.
Construction of a prototype of a portable atomic power plant for military use is expected to begin early next year, it was disclosed here yesterday.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 15 -- Rhode Island doctors were urged by their leaders today to advise patients to discontinue cigarettes.
School bus drivers voted last night to accept a 50-cent-a-day wage increase.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Rural Electrification Administrator Ancher Nelsen said today that power cooperatives in Colorado, Wyoming and Nebraska may be granted up to $40,000,000 in added Government loans to increase their steam and generating facilities.
BUFFALO, Oct. 15 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for Governor, concentrated today in campaigning through this industrial area on citing his aid to labor.

"Tales of Hoffmann," brilliantly restaged, with handsome new sets and costumes, well-sung and well-acted, was a stirring performance under the inspired direction of Thomas Schippers at the City Center last evening.

DETROIT, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Additional new model change-over shutdowns will cut this week's car truck production to 64,721 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. The agency said Ford, Lincoln-Mercury and Buick went down for change-over this week, joining already idled Cadillac, Packard and Kaiser-Willys.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 15 -- Army's football squad, routed from New York by way of Akron, Ohio, to circumvent Hurricane Hazel, landed here tonight for its game with Duke tomorrow just before darkness settled on an airport blacked out by a storm which raised havoc in this area earlier in the day.
Dwellings dominated the trading in Brooklyn in transactions reported yesterday by brokers in that borough.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- One of Neville Chamberlain's close collaborators asked today for reconsideration of the judgment on the Munich surrender in the light of post-war compromises with Communist power.
Cleaners, shippers and Madison Avenue office tenants were preoccupied with statuary yesterday.

QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Chamber of Deputies today gave Interior Minister Camilo Ponce a vote of confidence when it rejected a Liberal-Socialist motion of censure over his closing of the independent newspapers El Comercio and Ultimas Noticias.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Small Business Administration was urged today to authorize its regional offices to grant loans up to $100,000 to small business enterprises without consultation with Washington. The authority, if finally approved, would double the limit now sanctioned for independent action by regional officials.

Now that we are in the last quarter of 1954 data are beginning to become available for an estimate of this year's progress on that most controversial of economic problems, East-West trade. And, as is so often the case in these matters, the assessment depends upon looking at both sides of a complex picture.
Hurricane Hazel cut a path of death and destruction across eight states and the District of Columbia yesterday, from South Carolina to the Canadian border.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 15 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was faced today with a possible rebellion over domestic affairs within his four-party coalition. A spokesman for the third largest Government party, the Refugee party, gave notice that if the Government did not grant its social demands by the end of October, it would withdraw from the coalition.

Having just returned from a short duty tour (forty-five days) in French Morocco with the Air Force, I feel obliged to voice a general criticism of the American press handling of news from that country. According to American newspapers the specter of another Indochina hangs imminently over Morocco.

Parties -- social ones -- are playing a prominent part in the campaign of Anthony Akers, who is seeking election to the House of Representatives in the Seventeenth Congressional District in Manhattan.
Net income and operating revenues of the Arkansas Power and Light Company increased in the twelve months ended Aug. 31, the utility announced yesterday.

Events today: "Madama Butterfly," City Center, 2:30 P.M.; Jean Graham, pianist, Town Hall, 3; Concert Artists Guild, Steinway Hall, 3; Elizabeth Fitzgerald, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; "Die Fledermaus," City Center, 8:15; Quartetto Italiano, Hunter College, 8:30.
Some of the keenest scientific minds in the country are hard at work trying to make chicken feathers act like goose feathers.
Paul A. Pfeffer was indicted for first degree manslaughter yesterday in the fatal bludgeoning on Aug. 23, 1953, of Edward S. Bates, a seaman.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Averell Harriman, Democratic candidate for Governor, promised today to institute a system whereby publicly owned utility companies would compete against and thus hold down the prices charged by private producers of electric power.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Following are translations of documents submitted to the United Nations General Assembly today by the Soviet Union in connection with its charge that the United States had committed aggression against Communist China.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Ten Philadelphia business men, working against the clock, dug into their pockets today for $3,750,000, which they said would at least match Arnold Johnson's Kansas City offer and keep the Philadelphia Athletics here.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 15 -- In a glittering wave hundreds of discreetly jeweled women swept deep curtseys as Don Juan, pretender to the throne of Spain, and his family entered the thronged ballroom of his daughter's debut in Estoril Parque Hotel tonight.

VIENNA, Oct. 15 -- The United States High Commissioner, Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., refuted a Soviet accusation today in the Allied Council that Austrian veterans' meetings were a camouflage for nazism. He proved that evidence submitted by the Russians was itself the work of a former Nazi.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- A major drought that could rival the "dust bowl" conditions of the Nineteen Thirties is building up in the Southern and Central States, the Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay, said today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 15 -- The Chancery Court decision ruling that the ten Negro children were entitled to be re-admitted to Milford High School underlined today the involvement of the close Senatorial race and the segregation issue.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 15 -- The signing of an Israeli-Jordanian "arrangement" for "suppression or prevention of hostilities in the Jerusalem area" was put off today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Wheat prices reacted today from yesterday's rally, but there was some commission absorption on the declines. July wheat showed a stronger tone, apparently reflecting investment buying on the probability that the winter wheat crop will be comparatively light next spring as a result of the cut in acreage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The State Department vigorously disputed today allegations that the United States had "neglected" the new anti-Communist Government of Guatemala.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Hasty House Farm's Hasty Road and William G. Hells Jr.'s Heiioscope head a field of twelve 3-year-olds named for tomorrow's $25,000 added Benjamin Franklin Handicap at Garden State Park.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The United States, Britain and several Caribbean countries pushed big scale relief operations in southwestern Haiti today in the wake of Hurricane Hazel's terrific battering.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 15 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer is considering a plan that would recognize France's special economic interests in the Saar but reserve West Germany's political and territorial rights.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Britain declared today that the Soviet Union's concept of the supervision of control of disarmament and atomic energy seemed "incompatible" with the British-French proposals.
DENVER, Oct. 15 -- President Eisenhower will inject himself into the political arena of New York next Thursday.

The role of the corner drug store, with the pharmacist behind the counter dispensing health-giving drugs, was described yesterday at the closing sessions of the pharmacy conference at Columbia University.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Brazilian coffee exports during the first quarter of this coffee year, July-September, were only 1,981,292 sacks, the lowest in nearly forty years.
The Waterfront Commission held a public discussion yesterday on proposed new pier hiring regulations, and found that neither management nor labor liked them.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15 -- Harvard, fresh from its 13 -- 12 upset of Cornell, will try to continue its winning streak when it meets Columbia at Harvard Stadium tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Leaders of the country's two most powerful labor groups predicted tonight a merger of their organizations "certainly before the end of 1955."
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 (UP) -- A choking, eye-searing smog blanketed the Los Angeles metropolitan area today for the ninth straight day and brought on a state of near-emergency.
THOSE who like to discover an underlying trend in contemporary painting may be thoroughly disconcerted by the variety of styles manifested in six current one-man exhibitions.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru left today for Communist China. Newspapers and politicians called his trip a "historic mission."

The Inter-American Press Association has announced the awarding of five Mergenthaler cash prizes of $500 each for meritorious achievement in Latin-American journalism. These prizes, four to individuals and one to a newspaper, are intended to be the Latin-American counterparts of the Pulitzer Prizes.

EVELYN WAUGH is one of the sharpest of all the English social satirists since Thackeray. And, since the proper business of satire is the impalement of the snob, Mr. Waugh has had a field day in the bountiful modern day that produces snobs, as Russell Lynes has pointed out, in such improbable variety and in such seedy or dramatic settings.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Members of the Armed Services are going to get a doubled ration of milk under a program aimed at easing the pressure on the Government's dairy price support program.

Averell Harriman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, will return from an upstate tour this morning and head a motorcade through Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties. He is scheduled to arrive at La Guardia Airport from Massena, N.Y., at 10 A.M.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- Several hundred persons living in homes close to the shore on the south side of Cape Cod and on the islands of Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket were ordered to leave their homes for the night as a precaution against abnormally high tides expected after midnight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- United Nations members voted without dissent today to call on Nationalist Chinese "irregulars" in northern Burma to lay down their weapons and submit to internment.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active Yesterday. The close was irregular, 10 points lower to 2 points higher than on Thursday.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, in an address here tonight, urged the establishment of "a committee on internal security in every private organization in the country," as a necessity in the nation's war on communism.

Even the most inexperienced home craftsman has a good chance for success when fitting together the unassembled parts of some "knock down" furniture that has just become available. Only a hammer, nails, a screw driver and a ruler are needed from the home tool chest.

A world record of fifty years' standing for a six - furlong straightaway was broken yesterday at Belmont Park by Vestment of the Starmount Stable. Packing 115 pounds and ridden by Stanley Small, Vestment covered the distance down the Widener chute in 1:07 4/5, beating eighteen rivals.

Elston Howard, star catcher and most valuable player in the International League this year, was purchased by the New York Yankees yesterday and is expected to become the first Negro to wear a Bomber uniform after the start of an American League season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Justice Department said today it had launched aggressive new drives against organized crime and communism.

Sales in the nation's chain and mail order stores in September were 1.1 per cent greater than in September, 1953, according to a survey by The New York Times. Last month they were off by 1 per cent; in July they showed a gain of 2.2 per cent.

YONKERS, Oct. 15 -- Thirty-eight women began play in the final one-day tournament of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association today at the Hudson River Country Club before the event was canceled because of heavy winds and rain.

Ann Miller will be co-starred by Metro-Goldwyn Mayer with Howard Keel in "International Review," a revue type musical now in the script-writing stage. Also at M-G-M, Jarma Lewis, who recently played a bit role in the studio's biblical spectacle "The Prodigal," has been placed under term contract and assigned to the lead opposite Jeff Richards, another newcomer, in "The Marauders," a Western.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 15 -- "Dangerous navigation conditions" were blamed on inadequate Congressional appropriations in an address given here today by Sterling St. John Jr., of Washington, consultant to the National Rivers and Harbors Congress, who is one of the representatives of that organization attending its New England regional conference here.

ABLANY, Oct. 15 -- The State Law Department went on record today in opposition to any change in court procedure that would permit litigants to appeal their cases without a printed record of the proceedings in the lower courts.

REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., Oct. 15 -- The hurricane gave the state of Delaware a bad time today. The worst appeared over at about 8 P. M., but there were four persons dead and damage to the rich poultry industry in the southern part of the state virtually was incalculable.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, wound up three days of intensive political conferences up-state today with the prediction that his party would carry the state by a 500,000-vote margin.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 15 (UP) -- President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla issued today a revised anti-libel decree-law embodying virtually all of the suggestions offered by newspaper publishers to tone down his original law.
After losing further ground in the early trading, stock prices recovered selectively yesterday and showed mixed price changes at the close. The railroad issues were strong.

Like other men of his calling, James Quinn, a trumpet player, has sensitive lips -- and sensitive ears. For three solid years he froze every time the vibrating refrigerator compressor went on in Peter Cyprus' florist shop next door.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 15 -- Mrs. Harold Sykes Jr. of the Nassau Country Club was re-elected president of the Women's Cross County Golf Association at the annual meeting held at her club today.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Jean Mons, Secretary of the Committee of National Defense, was removed from office by Government order today. M. Mons had been suspended from his duties two weeks ago and charged with negligence in connection with leaks of defense secrets taken from the committee's documents.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Carmen Basilio, 151, of Canastota, N.Y., welterweight contender, used speedy hooking combinations of rights to the body and lefts to the head tonight to pound out a decision over Allie Gronik, 151 1/2 of Detroit in their nationally televised ten-rounder.

The White Wing Ball, the annual benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, will be featured by a fashion show with young women of society acting as manikins. The dinner dance will be held next Friday in the ballroom of the Ambassador under the sponsorship of Evyan.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 -- A political science professor and a professional politician are fighting it out in a Baltimore Congressional campaign.

How solid is the Moscow-Peiping axis? This was the key question raised last week in the wake of the Peiping announcement on the agreements -- including one for the evacuation of Port Arthur by the Russians -- reached during the high-level Sino-Soviet negotiations of the past three weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Clarence Henry, heavyweight boxer under indictment in New York on a charge of attempting to fix a fight, underwent an operation Thursday for a retinal detachment in his left eye.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Freddie Annon, Ryewood professional, turned in a sub-par solo of 34, 36 -- 70 at the Dellwood Country Club today, to spark the winning and second-place teams in the second annual United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Charities benefit pro-amateur tournament.

NINE times since the end of the war the British have said to other countries of Europe that they would stand by them. In the Brussels Treaty the British gave a guarantee against German aggression; in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization they gave one against Russian aggression.

IF anyone wonders why C.S. Lewis, author of "The Screwtape Letters" and other books for adults, has not published recently any works of the sort that first made him famous, part of the explanation is here.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Gordon Pirie of England beat Russia's Aleksander Anufriev in the three-mile race at the Northern Counties-Moscow track and field meet today, but the Soviet team ran away with the meet, winning sixteen of the twenty-three events.

Visits to private art collections and to distinguished offices and workshops have been arranged for the afternoons of Nov. 9 and Nov. 16 under the auspices of the Music Committee of the Greenwich House Music School. Proceeds from the events will be donated to the scholarship fund of the Greenwich House Music School.

IF the average late Victorian or early Edwardian had been told that in half a century England would become a land of opera composers, he would have expressed, first, disbelief, and second, dismay: disbelief because British composers had never shown much of a flair for serious opera, and dismay because in those days, opera of any kind was not considered quite "respectable."

AN English girl, Helen Astrup is the widow of a Norwegian sea captain who went down with his oil tanker in the early days of World War II. Together with her young daughter, Mrs. Astrup continued to live in Oslo and was there when the Nazis invaded Norway.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- The Franklin Institute will honor twelve men in the field of science at its annual medal day ceremonies here next Wednesday.
In the campaign of 1954 the grand strategy of the two parties stood out clearly last week.

AS a solution to the parking problem in urban areas, Gen. Louis W. Prentiss, District of Columbia Commissioner, recommends a strictly enforced ban to keep certain types of motorists off crowded city streets.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 -- Officers of Local 249, General Teamsters, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, A.F.L., will recommend the rejection of the peace proposal offered by the five downtown department stores to 750 striking truck drivers and helpers, it was indicated today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- During the course of the next ten years, a substantial rise in college enrollment, product of the heavy increase in births during World War II, will add new burdens to the already crowded facilities of colleges and universities.

GENEVA, Oct. 16 -- Representatives of Eastern and Western European Governments have agreed to examine improved payments arrangements and a better procedure for arbitration of commercial disputes. Both of these matters were selected by the United Nations East-West trade meeting that ended here today as important areas in which practical work to reduce the obstacles to trade could be done.
BOONTON, N.J., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Otto Greiner of the Knickerbocker Club and Emery Thomas of Forest Hill today retained the New Jersey pro-pro golf championship.

OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Fullback Paige Cothren led a charging Mississippi backfield that crashed its way through a Tulane line and gave the undefeated and untied Rebels their fifth straight football victory today, 34-7.
ATLANTA, Oct. 16 (UP) -- A pair of 155-pound sophomore halfbacks scored touchdowns today to give Georgia Tech a 14-to-7 victory over Auburn before a capacity crowd of 40,000.

DRAMATIZED in this book is the simple truth that the imaginative insides of human reverie can be more thrilling than the heroic outsides of action. All men experience this fact in certain blessed spots of time, but philosophers and poets think it admissible to acknowledge the fact and fitting to exploit the resulting potential.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 16 -- The Connecticut public, Expenditure council, a privately-financed organization that devotes itself to studying state problems, disclosed this week that it was undertaking a study of Connecticut's higher education needs over the next ten years.

HARTFORD, Oct. 16 -- One of the quietest state election campaigns in Connecticut's history continued on its leisurely course this week, with leaders of both major parties claiming victory on the basis of the apparent apathy.

R.K. Allen, a General Electric engineer, says that train wheels slip because an extremely thin, practically invisible, layer of oil, approximately one molecule thick, spreads over the running band of a rail at the onset of rain or when there is dew. Despite its thinness, this "monomolecular layer" can withstand pressures so high (up to 75,000 pounds per square inch) that ordinary locomotive-wheel loads will not break through it.

A nice nostalgic touch on the program of piano music played yesterday afternoon by Jean Graham in Town Hall was the including of the Chopin-Liszt "My Delights." Has anybody included it on a recital since Josef Hofmann was around?

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 16 -- Averell Harriman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, assailed the Republican party tonight for its alleged failure to cope with the educational and industrial problems accompanying the rapid growth of Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

An indefinite but gradually declining trend was established by the stock market last week. As a result all of the month's earlier gains were erased. Selected issues, however, continued strong and managed to close the week with moderate gains.

THE first person on the shore one morning "while the soft gray fog still hung in the sky" was Timothy Robbins. Most might think it would be a lonely place then but not Timothy. The sea and sand had a busy beauty all their own.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 16 -- Athletic Fields, the largest and most modern in University of California institutions, are approaching completion at the new Goleta campus of Santa Barbara College.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Unbeaten Ohio State came from behind today to beat Iowa, 20 -- 14, and cement the Buckeyes' grip on the Big Ten leadership in one of the most exciting games ever played in Ohio Stadium.

Far Rockaway's unbeaten football team scored its third victory of the season yesterday, turning back Curtis High, 22 -- 13, on the winners' gridiron in Queens. The loss was the first of the campaign for Curtis. The Staten Islanders have won three.

WHEN culinary inspiration burns low, the best stimulant is a new cookbook. These days it's not difficult to find one that will solve just about any cooking problem. In an all-round kitchen textbook, Betty Furness and Julia Kiene have done an excellent job for Westinghouse.
Kings Point trampled Wagner College yesterday, 26 -- 6, at Grymes Hill, Staten Island. It was the Seahawks' fourth consecutive loss of the Season.

" MADAMI" is the name by which Anne Eisner Putnam, a native New Yorker, is known to her Pgmy friends, natives of Congo Africa. After eight years of residence among them, "home" for Mrs. Putnam is where the pygmies and their beautiful, various and exciting country are -- not to omit mention of Mr. Putnam, who is a kind of Dr. Schweitzer to the pygmies.

IT seems incredible that the history of music could be compressed into so slim a book as this one. Yet this has been accomplished by Gertrude Norman in such a way as to make most interesting and illuminating reading.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 16 -It's a lucky thing no player accused Howard Eyth, field judge at today's Dartmouth-Colgate football game, of being asleep. It might have raised a doubt even in Eyth's own mind.

THERE is no sign of a truce, or a final decision, in the seemingly endless controversy of fall vs. spring planting of roses. Adherents of either season are well armed with facts and past performances. And to add to the melee there is a third group consisting of gardeners who hold spring and fall planting in equal esteem.
The man who applied the assembly-line technique of heavy industry to clothing three years ago is busying himself, with advertising.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- As straws continue to whirl in the political winds, little doubt remains in the minds of most observers that a positive Democratic trend exists today in almost every part of the country which, if uninterrupted, will result in a switch in the control of Congress after the elections on Nov. 2.

AUSTIN J. TOBIN, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, has predicted that by 1980 the metropolitan airports will be handling 45,000 air passengers a day. This will mean that more air-transport traffic will be flying over the New York area and that there will be more noise, Mr. Tobin said the reduction and control of aircraft noise would be the number one problem of air transportation during the next twenty-five years.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- President Eisenhower's personal popularity has slipped a little in Pennsylvania. In agricultural regions some farmers are saying that while practice will lower his golf score it won't increase their prices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The 1954 individual income tax forms and instructions -- necessarily bigger and more complicated but at least prettier than previous editions -- went to press this week.

THE fame (reputation is too chilly a word) of Arnold J. Toynbee is a phenomenon in itself worth noting in our modern English-speaking world. A Senator, launching what is formally a great debate, quotes him; a sports writer in a New York newspaper (not this one) uses him as a standard of comparison with Casey Stengel.
So many red flags are flying over Wall Street nowadays that the place -- figuratively, of course -- has the aspect of a Communist rallying ground or a blasting area.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Business in the Chicago area took a positive turn for the better in September, according to the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association. The report on the survey said it was the best in some time. Profits, backlogs of orders and employment turned upward after a long downtrend.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 16 (AP) -- India and East Germany entered a trade "arrangement" today granting the Communist regime the right to station representatives in India for the first time. But New Delhi firmly indicated it was stopping short of giving the German Reds diplomatic recognition.
American colleges in the Near East will benefit from the twenty-seventh annual theatre party of the Near East College Association on the evening of Nov. 29.

PRETTY soon now, folks for the first time will be able to hear the voice of William Faulkner whenever they want to. Caedmon Publishers, an ingenious and enterprising firm dedicated to putting on wax the voices of creative writers, managed somehow to convince Mr. Faulkner to make a disk date, and Mr. Faulkner (gallant Southerner) did not stand the girls of Caedmon up.

A large subscription has been reported for the annual Halloween Ball for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery. The event will be held on the night of Oct. 29 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Miss Louise Marock is chairman of the ball committee and Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, wife of Mayor Wagner, is honorary chairman.
MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- Substantial successes are being claimed by the Soviet Union in its drive to put more money in the pockets of consumers and more goods on the shelves of the country's stores.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16 -- Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati, said today seven out of every ten American universities and colleges reported moderate increases in total attendances of full-time students this autumn as compared with last.
HURTADO DE CORDOBA and his Spanish Ballet begin their second week at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre with matinee and evening performances today.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Calumet Farm racers finished one, two today in the thirty-ninth running of the $35,000-added California derby at Tanforan as Miz Clementine set a track record of 1:49 for the mile-and-an-eighth event, and Duke's Lea took second.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The gentlemanly decorum observed by all but a few uninhibited backbenchers over the past winter and spring is bound to vanish from the House of Commons when it reassembles next week. Both the Government and the Opposition know that a general election is in the offing, probably within a year, and Parliament is a stage that has the eye of every voter.

The recent announcement by the Chrysler Corporation that tubeless tires will be original equipment on its 1955 cars will relieve the curiosity of some 1,700 field interviewers of Alfred Politz Research, Inc.

VINCENT DREGA, financier, makes an enemy of Simon Gamble, super-scientist. As a result of their battle, Gamble throws the world into a state of suspended animation for three thousand years, intending to prove to Drega that a new civilization can be built on scientific principles rather than on free enterprise.

The article "Communique on the Illinois Campaign" (Sept. 26) is, in my opinion, excellent. Cabell Phillips has objectively captured the spirit of the contest between Joe Meek and Democratic Senator Paul Douglas.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Fullback Dick Bielski carried Maryland almost alone for 30 minutes on his broad back and churning legs before the rest of his team could get rolling to a 33-0 victory over North Carolina today.

ERIE, Pa., Oct. 16 (AP) -- The state police, deputy sheriffs and city police fanned through this port city of 130,000 today, arresting Mayor Thomas W. Flatley and twelve other persons on charges of taking part in a $20,000,000-a-year gambling racket.

ON Saturday, two days before the official public opening, C.B.S. television will take its audience on a preview tour of the new Whitney Museum of American Art. The museum is moving from downtown Manhattan to a new location at 22 West Fifty-fourth Street and will not open its doors to the public until Oct. 25.

MADRID, Oct. 16 -- A year ago last month the Spanish people learned that their Government had signed a bilateral agreement permitting the United States to build and expand some of Spain's air bases and port facilities. In exchange, they learned, they were to receive a first installment of $226,000,000 -- $141,000,000 for military aid and $85,000,000 for economic assistance.

WILLIAM WATTS BALL, the vigorous editor of The Charleston News and Courier, who died in 1952 aged 83, was, in his own state, the most influential journalist of his time. For nearly sixty years his paragraphs of pungent prose flavored the columns of South Carolina newspapers.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Once again France and Germany seek to end their controversy over the Saar, 900 square miles of territory that lies between their frontiers as a stumbling block on the road to Western unity.
Ask dentists and authorities on nutrition why teeth decay and most of them will answer "lactic acid decay." The explanation has not helped much to do away with tooth decay.

IN fiction, and perhaps in fact, the dilemma of the physician who must witness the sufferings of a hopelessly doomed loved one, when the means to end that suffering are easily at hand, is a peculiarly poignant theme. Upon this theme Dr. Loyal Davis -- one of the nation's outstanding neurosurgeons and widely known as a leader and teacher in the medical world -- has chosen to build a novel.

One cannot help but admire the article "Hands Across the Stage" by Fitzroy Davis. But to illustrate his point, Mr. Davis incorrectly used the Stanislavski story of the actress who had her hands tied behind her back by the director until her need to make a gesture became so urgent that She burst her bonds.

WE were surprised by the statement made by Louise Dickinson Rich in her review of "A Women in the Polar Night" by Christine Ritter that "Christine Ritter is one of the few civilized women ever to have spent a winter north of the Arctic Circle."

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Joe Graff's 24-yard field goal gave Georgia a 16 -- 14 triumph over weary Vanderbilt and snatched the Commodores' first victory from them in the waning minutes of a Southeastern Conference football game today.

THE productivity, or lack thereof, of Hollywood writing men is a constant source of dismay for the film producer who always is hungrily seeking the distinctively textured literary manna which is, after all, his staff of life.

WHEN Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the Shah of Iran, recently ordered the exile of a young tribal chieftain from the heart of the South Persian mountains, he opened a new chapter in the long-drawn, bloody feud between the royal family and the "state within the state" of the powerful Ghashghai tribes.
New York's banking line-up was altered radically last week. Inevitably, additional changes are due, as bankers ponder the implications of the shift.

ON Tuesday morning in Washington the Senate Subcommittee on Juvenile Delinquency will open two days of hearings on the volatile question of whether there is a connection between juvenile delinquency and the crime shows seen on television.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Senator Ralph C. Flanders said today that neither he nor Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had been asked by top Republicans to take part in the current political campaign, and added:
The Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., believes that "the city has no more need for its own TV station than it has for a hole in the head."

CATHERINE ORLOFF, whose letter about my article of Oct. 3 appeared in your section last week, has miscontrued my remarks about hands into a denunciation of "The Method" If she were familiar with the number of quotations from Stanislavski's "My Life in Art" I used in "Quicksilver," she would know I have a great deal of respect for him.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16 -- A tricky football maneuver in the fourth quarter led Columbia to a 7-6 victory over Harvard today. It was the season's first triumph for the Lions, who had bowed previously to Brown, Princeton and Yale.

PLAYWRIGHT Samuel Taylor, having weathered both hurricanes Carol and Edna at his Maine retreat, is back in town full of energy, optimism, and a brand new idea for a play. The adapter of "The Happy Time" and author of "Sabrina Fair" appears to have brewed a notion sufficiently stimulating to win for him Cornelia Otis Skinner as his collaborator, plus Miss Skinner's promise to appear in the play when it is completed.

He who travels west travels not only with the sun but with history. The flatboats went with the current westward, once the forefathers had crossed the Alleghenies, and the ox teams plodded westward all the way. Eastern streams were, relatively, short streams and eastern land routes paralleled the coastline.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -- Shipowner and longshore union leaders reviewed this week twenty years of collective bargaining on the West Coast waterfronts.

WAS it mutiny or was it murder? Though 112 years have passed since three men were swung to death from the yardarm of the United States Navy brig Somers, the question remains unanswered. The Somers affair, or tragedy, the only mutiny recorded in the American Navy, still has power to stir the emotions.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Bob Bauman returned to action at fullback today to provide the difference as Missouri beat Indiana, 20 to 14, before 22,500 fans.

A NATIVE of Ur in southern Babylonia, one Terah by name, begat three sons, two of whom were named Abram and Haran. Haran begat Lot, and thereafter died before Terah died. Now, some 4,000 years later, trilingual and brilliantly talented Maria Ley-Piscator, Vienna-born and writing in English, has turned out a heroic novel of panoramic sweep and concept, based upon the wanderings of Abram and his nephew, Lot.

DETROIT, Oct. 16 -- President Eisenhower's popularity apparently continues high in most of Michigan. The exception is the western part of the state which is blanketed by The Chicago Tribune and its radio and TV stations and was pro-Taft and is now pro-McCarthy territory.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 16 -- Retail trade was brisk last week and dollar volume ran sharply ahead of the previous week and modestly ahead of the same 1953 period. Contributing to the enlarged volume locally was the annual American Royal Show, which brought future farmers from all over the nation.
The commissioners of the Port of New York Authority last week awarded $346,195 worth of contracts for improvements at Teterboro Airport, the Hoboken-Port Authority piers and the Goethals Bridge.

SINCE peace came to Barsetshire and Angela Thirkell there must have been moments when both blanched at the prospect of being gallant and stiff-upper-lipped without an emergency to match. But neither county nor author ever betrayed a moment's hesitation about the post-war return to normal.

To the list of words symbolizing German military power there was added last week Streitkraefte. It means, literally, armed forces. It was coined last Tuesday in Bonn as the official name for the West German defense force due to come into being under the West European Union (W.E.U.) plan blocked out in London two weeks ago by nine Western foreign ministers.
Queens bus riders will have "adequate service" by the first of next year, a member of the New York City Transit Authority predicted yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 -- Striking an average for September, the Federal Reserve Bank showed department store sales in the St. Louis area were 3 per cent above a year ago. They were even with a year ago for the nine months to Sept. 30.

TORONTO, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Danny Lewicki, who failed to make good in four seasons with the Toronto Maple Leafs, scored a goal in the third period tonight that helped the New York Rangers defeat the Leafs, 4 -- 2.

ALTHOUGH changing leaves and fruit stands filled with rosy apples and colorful squash may mean fall to some, to others it is the reign of the king of fall flowers, chrysanthemums, that brings autumn to mind.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The major blunder of the Republican election campaign may prove to be not the unleashing of Secretary of Defense Wilson but the carefully planned strategy of turning the election into a vote of confidence in the president.

The world today is plagued with "a mental sickness because there is not enough spiritual content in our living," Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein declared yesterday in a sermon at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street.

THE mood of the forest, with its dim, filtered light, its hushed atmosphere, its soft mosses, its damp, decaying wood -- this forms the real subject of Jeannette Klute's gallery of fifty color photographs reproduced in "Woodland Portraits."

Religion and medicine must cooperate to treat the individual as a whole being, spiritually and physically, it was generally agreed yesterday by three clergymen representing the Roman Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths.
The work load for privately owned United States shipyards continued to fall last month, drawing closer to the vanishing point.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Feeling like a neglected stepchild, Hudson Valley communities will unfold their woes to state and county officials at a luncheon here Wednesday.

Distant lightning flashes "sing" in a radio receiver. An electrical storm in the Himalayas reaches this country piped some four octaves above middle C. Depending on whether it be at day or night, the recorded fury of an equatorial thunderstorm 10,000 miles away can sound like the thumping of a drum or like the warbling of a cage of canaries.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 16 -- Wisconsin came to life in the second half today to defeat Purdue, 20 to 6, with Billy Lowe providing the blow that broke the Boilermakers' spirit on a 98-yard pass-interception runback.
TOKYO, Oct. 10 -- Japan's much publicized program for an $80,000,000 unofficial barter trade agreement with the Soviet Union has become the object of increasing skepticism here.
DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 16 -- The devastation wrought in this area by Hurricane Hazel yesterday was duplicated today in a football way by a rip-roaring Army team.

Louis Waldman, president of the Brooklyn Bar Association, has directed an immediate investigation of the mass hearing of 11,000 Brooklyn landlords for alleged building violations in the Bay Ridge Magistrate's Court on Oct. 8.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Government would pay the Dixon-Yates interests $20,746,800 a year for twenty-five years for the controversial power plant projected at West Memphis, Ark.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Tom Gastall, Boston University quarterback, bombed Syracuse's highly rated pass defense with four first-half touchdown aerials today and then the undeafted Terriers withstood a second-half rally by the Orange to gain a 41-19 decision and their fourth victory.

GARDENERS need not necessarily wait until spring to plant their chrysanthemums. Fun-size plants can be set out in the garden now, for no perennial transplants as easily when in full bloom. In fact, they might be set out in the garden to add a touch of color where other plants have died down or soften the bare landscape around a newly built home.
HONG KONG, Oct. 16 -- Preparations are under way to establish a new Chinese industrial base at Paotow, western terminus of the Peiping-Suiyuan railway in North China.

IN the story of surgical progress, the past half century has seen more major life-saving advances than all of medical history before it. Of these, probably the most significant has been the development of thoracic surgery -- techniques by which operations are performed upon the vital organs of the chest, even the inside of the heart itself.

A PHOTOGRAPHY show and contest under the sponsorship of the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue, and several importers of Japanese photographic equipment, starts on Tuesday at the center, where it will run through Nov. 6.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago, on Nov. 7, 1929, the Museum of Modern held its inaugural exhibition in four pristinely simple rooms of the Heckscher Building on Fifth Avenue. This week, having become the most important single force in modern art in America, it begins a year-long anniversary celebration with a handsome show from its permanent collection in three floors of galleries and the garden of its marble-steel-and-glass mansion on West Fifty-third Street.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 -- William O'Dwyer said today he planned tentatively to fly to New York next Friday for a visit of four or five days, purely for pleasure and primarily to see old friends.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Southern California's Rose Bowl hopefuls displayed their dazzling backfield speed to the nation's television watchers today in crushing Oregon, 24 -- 14.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- A plan by which countries all over the world, including the Soviet Union, would participate in the filming of international television documentaries on a variety of subjects was disclosed here today.

THE future of the "woman with no past" asked payment in full for her crime. The present was a desperate reprieve -- a few days wrested from the police -- during which she might prepare for the ordeal ahead.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 16 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India arrived here today on the first leg of an Asian tour that may guide the future relationships of the so-called neutralist bloc with Communist China.

HALL Bartlett, youthful actor turned writer-producer-director, whose independent company, Hall Bartlett Productions, has such varied films to its credit as "Navajo," released in 1952; "Crazylegs," the drama in which professional football star "Crazylegs" Hirsch made his movie debut this year, and the forthcoming "Unchained," a prison drama shot in the jail without bars at Chino, Calif., is about to embark on another so-called "off-beat" subject.
Employer resistance to union demands began to crumble yesterday on the first day of the general truck strike in the metropolitan area.

READERS familiar with Frederick Pohl's two previous gleanings from the science fiction magazines will, I fear, find this crop a mild disappointment. Certainly, he has included superb stories by Alfred Bester, Frederic Brown, Philip Jose Farmer and C.M. Kornbluth.

SOME thousand miles northwest of Everest, on the high frontier between Kashmir and Pakistan, stands the most murderous mountain in the world. Its name is Nanga Parbat, and, over the years, almost as many men have died in attempts to scale it as on all the rest of the Himalayas combined.

ROME, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- If this Oneida County industrial city of 41,600 population is as good a political barometer this year as it has frequently been in the past, New York is due for its closest state election since 1938.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 16 -- Douglas R. Stringfellow, 32-year-old Republican Representative from Utah, admitted publicly tonight that his oft-told story of leading a daring "cloak and dagger" raid into wartime Germany was a complete hoax.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Ben Carrasquillo snagged three touchdown passes today to lead Lehigh University to a 20-6 victory over Gettysburg College at Taylor Stadium.
The months ahead will present the free world with an unusual sequence of opportunities to lower trade and investment barriers.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 16 -- Dr. Luther Evans, Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, said today that the eight cases involving the loyalty of Americans employed by his organization still were open.

Warm weather in the first part of the week and the wide publicity given to the approach of hurricane "Hazel" at the end of the week combined to keep department store sales about 8 to 12 per cent below those in the like week a year ago.

IN 1864 a delegation of Negroes from Baltimore journeyed to the White House and presented President Abraham Lincoln with a handsome Bible. In thanking the donors the President referred to the Scriptures as "the best gift God has given to man." Now, ninety years lager, these words of President Lincoln have been chosen as the theme for National Bible Week, sponsored annually by the Layman's National Committee the third week in October.
The working American-flag merchant fleet shrank by twenty-one ships in September, according to the Maritime Administration.

RASPUTIN, the Russian who was a notorious figure at the court of Nicholas II during World War I, was neither a spotless saint nor a monster. He was rather a Dostoevskian mixture of good and evil. The same might be said of Prince Felix Youssoupoff, who killed him.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Work crews began cleaning up an entirely nonpolitical "mess in Washington" today.

ALTHOUGH the new season has hardly settled down to work, the off-Broadway theatre has already distinguished itself. Congreve's "The Way of the World," rarely acted in New York, is having a prosperous engagement at the Cherry Lane; and "The Clandestine Marriage," by David Garrick and George Colman, is playing to capacity, audiences at the Provincetown Playhouse.

The other day The Times ran a picture of a new "anechoic chamber" opened by the General Electric Company in Pittsfield, Mass. The sight of it alone was enough to make phonophobes curl up in delicious slumber.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- President Eisenhower's popularity in the Middle West has not diminished among the great mass of voters from its peak of 1952. Among the old-line Taft Republicans, who never generated noticeable affection for Mr. Eisenhower, there exists a feeling of loyalty to him along strict party lines.

Eight hurricanes of Caribbean origin have swept northward this year -- six of them dangerous in their energy, devastating in their effect. Alice, Barbara, Carol, Dolly, Edna, Florence, Gilds and now Hazel. There is a reason for this seemingly facetious method of naming storms that blow down houses and take lives.

NEWARK, Oct. 16 -- Rudolph Halley, former chief counsel for the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, is among the 110 witnesses subpoenaed in the Government's income tax evasion trial of Albert Anastasia opening Monday.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 16 -- The premiere performance of the Long Island Symphony Society Orchestra was presented at the high school auditorium here tonight. Charles Jaffe was the conductor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The Defense Department is preparing to ask President Eisenhower to approve a billion-dollar legislative package to improve the status of service men and women and streamline the reserve forces, The Army-Navy-Air Force Journal said today.

Despite attacks on the United Nations, the world body is daily winning more friends, Mayor Wagner said yesterday at a conference on how to interest local communities in the affairs of the international organization.

THERE are signs in the public temper today of what child specialists term -- and with alarm -- a "back-to-the-woodshed" movement. Looking at the frightening rise in juvenile crime, outspoken citizens in many communities have demanded that sterner measures be employed with youthful offenders, that punishment, not "coddling," be the order of the day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower approved today the retirement application of Federal Judge Edward A. Conger of the Southern District of New York, effective next, Wednesday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 (AP) -Flood water's on the Ohio River moved toward Wheeling, W. Va., today hours after feeder streams had forced thousands of persons from their homes in western Pennsylvania. Damage was estimated in the millions of dollars.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Marquette's Warriors, apparently beaten by their mistakes, battered their way for three touchdowns in the final period through a tiring Holy Cross team to gain a 19-14 come-from-behind victory today at Fitton Field.

The Soviet representative in the United Nations, Andrei Vishinsky, in a recent statement on disarmament made to the General Assembly asserted that the Soviet Union stands squarely on the doctrine of the possibility of peaceful coexistence of states irrespective of differences in their social structure.

The storm that started as Hurricane Hazel swept northeastward past the Hudson Bay region of Canada early today with its death toll in this country and southern Canada at 118 and property damage in the millions.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 16 -- Stone-throwing election day mobs battled the police in the streets today, smashed into the United States Information Services library and set fire to the building. At least three persons were killed and forty injured in the rioting.

AUCKLAND, N.Z., Oct. 16 -New Zealand has opened the way for the resumption of tourist visits to the United States, suspended since World War II because of the dollar shortage. The Government has approved an allowance of $14 daily with a maximum of $280 a year for nonbusiness trips.

FOR any unfortunate who has missed such Kornbluth novels as "Take-Off," "The Syndic," "The Space Merchants" (this last with Frederik Pohl) I know of no better introduction to his remarkable work than this collection of his more recent short stories.

DURING the next few weeks thousands of sportsmen will hurry northward by train, airplane and automobile for their first hunting trip in the "big woods," and most of them will return to their homes disappointed, unsuccessful, or both.

TO cap the climax of what has already given every evidence of being a Spanish year, we are to have a visit from the greatest of them all, Vicente Escudero, in February, after an absence of two decades.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The General Assembly's Legal Committee has asked Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to try to persuade at least twenty nations to participate in a conference concerning the plight of people without a country.

A new one-year agreement was reached early yesterday between the Masters, Mates and Pilots, A.F.L., and the Committee for the Companies, and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts. Forty steamship lines are involved in the contract, which runs through Sept. 30, 1955.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France told the Radical party's conference today that his proposal for controlling international armaments "could be the germ for organization of world peace."

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Ample water is essential to the successful transplanting of perennials, shrubs and trees. If a dry spell follows, perennials should be soaked once a weeks. No matter what the weather trees and shrubs, especially evergreens, should be watered once a week until the ground freezes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -- Following is the text of an address by Adlai E. Stevenson tonight at a Democratic rally in the Civic Auditorium:
ABOUT the time that county fairs have run their course in most other states, those in Florida get under way. Between now and next March well over thirty agricultural shows will be held in the state.

THE "Add-a-Part" records introduced some years ago by Columbia had long been anticipated by eager-beaver young piano students who used to "race" Paderewski's recorded performance of the "Minute" Waltz as played on a hand-wound Victrola.

WHEN you finish reading Jacqueline Cochran's "The at Noon" you'll probably feel as if you had just been flying in a fast airplane. That is the way I feel now. Miss Cochran's autobiography takes you on a record-breaking flight from a log cabin in Florida to a supersonic dive in a jet plane.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The issue of domestic communism moves back into the forefront of the 1954 election campaign this week.
Resumption of the transportation of salt in bulk to this country by ship -- and now, for the first time, in large quantities -- is causing much concern among upstate salt producers.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Arkansas Razorbacks, a band of fast-moving opportunists, took a long jump toward their first Southwest Conference title in eight years, by smashing the Texas Longhorns, 20-7.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Paul Larson sparked a lethargic University of California football team today as he kicked and passed it to a 17-7 victory over Washington State in a Pacific Coast Conference game before 27,000 fans.

TO MARY MARTIN, the yen of an actress to play "Peter Pan" is a phenomenon as cosmic and as needless of rationalization as the unending love of one generation after another for making sorties to Never-Never Land in the tow of the immortal spirit.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Arthur Deakin, the most powerful figure in British trade unionism, today attributed London's dock and bus strikes to Communists. He accused them of attempting to wreck the union movement in this country.

Although there was extensive damage throughout Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, as a result of the storm Friday night, the eighteenth annual New York University interscholastic cross-country meet went off on schedule yesterday over a somewhat altered course.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Final responsibility for troop training and for the ground defense of the United States was concentrated today in the hands of Gen. John E. Dahlquist with his appointment as Continental Army Commander.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- The money is in the bank and a meeting tomorrow could establish to a certainty that the Philadelphia Athletics will remain in this city, where they were founded fifty-four years ago.

Herbert F. Krimendahl is a man who grew up in the tomato-growing area of Ohio and branched out into pork and beans, corn, peas, peaches and succotash to become perhaps the highest-paid president of a food canning company, Stokely-Van Camp, Inc.

CELEBRATING its twenty-fifth anniversary, the Museum of Modern Art will place on view Wednesday some four hundred paintings and a selection of sculpture, with about one-third of the works acquired since the beginning of the institution, installed in three floors of rearranged galleries.
Mrs. William Dick Sporborg has been appointed chairman of the Women's National Executive Committee for the American-Korean Foundation. Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie will be honorary chairman.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 16 -- The Yugoslav Communist leaders are embarking on an anti-trust campaign, attributing the widespread rise in prices to the monopoly position of leading enterprises.
Initial reports on earlier residential mail deliveries in three midtown Manhattan areas are "very encouraging," according to Acting Postmaster Robert H. Shaffer.

THERE seems to be some resentment of the fact that the new "A Star Is Born," which has Judy Garland and James Mason in the husband-wife movie star roles, is not an exact carbon-copy -- nor even a facsimile -- of the Janet Gaynor-Fredric March drama that blazed a fire-trail some seventeen years ago, casting a stark illumination upon the irony of fame in Hollywood.

CHRYSANTHEMUMS mark the close of the floral year. Their brilliant colors are in tune with nature's display of turning leaves and the rich bronze, yellow and red shades rival any of those seen during the summer.

OSTENSIBLY Norman Bartlett's book is an account of the origins of the pearl fisheries in the tropical waters of northern Australia. In fact, however, it is a farrago of wild and often brutal tales of the exploits of the nineteenth-century pearling luggers, and since many of these are related within the space of a paragraph or two the reader is left a little breathless at times.

NO living American has over so long a period touched the Chinese so helpfully as has John Leighton Stuart. He was born in China, the son of Southern Presbtyerian missionaries, and after his education in the United States returned to his native land as a representative of the church of his fathers.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of former President Truman's address this evening, his only scheduled 1954 campaign speech:

WITH European statesmen furrowing their brows and multi-plying their ulcers these days over at least half a dozen apparently insoluble problems, it is a pleasure to report that the constitutional monarchy of Liechtenstein -- sixty square miles of independent principality tucked squarely in the center of a troubled continent -- has absolutely nothing to make anyone stay awake at night tossing and brooding.

UNSEASONABLE weather, with high temperatures and rain, has had a depressive effect on retail sales lately. Declines in department store sales in New York, while not representative of the country as a whole, exemplified the losses resulting from freakish weather.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 16 -- West Virginia University, directed by Fred Wyant, rallied for two touchdowns in the final period today to preserve its perfect record by tumbling Penn State from the unbeaten ranks, 19 -- 14.
Re "Public Schools for Handicapped Children" (Sept. 19) by Dorothy Barclay:
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- Pennsylvania's vigorous gubernatorial contest headed into its last two weeks today with the Republican candidates for statewide office still "running scared."
BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Northeastern came back from a one-point halftime deficit today to swamp Hofstra, 39 -- 13, and end the Long Islanders' undefeated string at three games.

Women active in behalf of the Friends of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra are holding frequent meetings to further plans for the 1954 campaign to raise funds for the orchestra. The goal of the campaign, which will beopened formally on Oct.25, is $150,000.

AMERICAN rose hybridizers seem to have reached a crossroads in breeding and production of roses. And now these scientists are pondering a problem that could be summed up by the phrase "Where do we go from here?"

Judge Edward Dimock in Federal Court denied yesterday a Government motion to have thirteen second-string Communists, convicted on subversive conspiracy charges, sent to jail immediately. He continued them in $25,000 bail each pending appeal of the conviction to the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, returned to Washington today. His talks with Administration officials may produce about $.10,000,000 in additional United States economic aid to the young Asian republic.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I. -- Now that summer vacationists have stopped trampling the dunes of this teeming beach resort, the year-round islanders are buckling down to planning ways and means of saving their hurricane-pounded shores from the insistent Atlantic.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. tonight accused the state's Republican Administration of trying "to cast out evil with a broad brush of white-wash" in dealing with the harness track scandal last year.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The official oblivion to which Britain consigned Oscar Wilde, end-of-the-century playwright and poet, after his conviction in 1895 of homosexual offenses, ended today, a century after his birth.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 16 -- E.H. Crump, one of the nation's last old-time big-city political bosses, died here today at the age of 80 of a heart ailment.

STEFAN LORANT might be likened to Mark Twain's Connecticut Yankee, so far as his ingenuity at the court of Lincoln writers is concerned. Coming to America in 1940, he stepped into the Lincoln field which had been intensively cultivated for over two generations, and promptly corrected one of the long accepted dates on a Lincoln photograph by the obvious, but heretofore overlooked method of tracing its announcement in the contemporary press.

HANSON BALDWIN in his review of "MacArthur -1941-1951," by Charles A. Willoughby and John Chamberlain, says that "the historian of tomorrow will have to sift carefully through a mass of subjective chaff if he is to winnow the grains of objective truth."

YOUR correspondent Jerome Alexander recalls that the epitaph beginning, "Behold my friends as you pass by/As you are now so once was I" can be found in Old South Church Graveyard in Boston. He is in error.

PARIS, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- A French Army captain was charged tonight with an attempt against the external security of the state after having been questioned on the leakage of top secret information from the French National Defense Council.

Governor Dewey's televised address Friday night, in which he sought to link Democrats with the harness racing scandal and assailed the Democratic record on public housing, provoked reactions yesterday.

The Play Schools Association, which develops work-play programs for school-age children, will be the beneficiary of the Nov. 30 and Dec. 1 performances of "The Living Room," the Graham Greene comedy, which will star Barbara Bel Geddes at Henry Miller's Theatre.
RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Oct. 16 -- A civic celebration on Thursday will mark the seventy-fifth anniversary of Thomas Edison's invention of the electric light bulb.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Even when the civilian economy is humming smoothly, politicians are scarcely indifferent to the placement of defense contracts. As military spending is cut back, and the civilian economy fails to take up the slack, the argument over how to parcel out the reduced total of contracts can get pretty noisy.

" OLDTAWM" CONNALLY, as they called him on Capitol Hill, has produced an autobiography as direct as its title, as uninhibited as its subject. For thirty-six years he represented Texas in the Congress.

A group of persons who have been specializing in the economic problems of the Far East has been meeting here in New York for several days. They have reached a few broad conclusions and have made a few recommendations. But their own findings, viewed, against the news from the world economic front, serve to emphasize a point that they themselves were quick to make.

LONDON -- The recent discovery of the old Roman temple in the City of London during the excavations for a new block of buildings has provided local sight-seers with a brand new historic spot to visit. Although visually not overly impressive, the ruins of the ancient temple of Mithras, which were dug up on a site behind the stately Mansion House of the Lord Mayors of London, have been attracting queues of spectators.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -- President Eisenhower continues to enjoy tremendous personal popularity in the Pacific region. It is so great that he probably could be re-elected today despite the barrage of charges aimed at his Administration by the Democrats.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Construction of a 1,400-foot dam over the Hackensack River three miles southeast of here will be started next week. This will be the initial move toward creating a reservoir four and a half miles long with a capacity of nearly 6,000,000,000 gallons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Republican campaigners in the industrial East and the Midwest are expected to concentrate on the theme that wage-earners are better off under the present Administration than they ever were before. This was the word from White House advisers today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Junius Kellogg, 6-foot 8-inch member of the Harlem Globetrotters B team, has made "quite a bit of progress" since his near-fatal accident last April, but he'll probably never play basketball again.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The nation's airlines soon may get their first indication of how the Eisenhower Administration will apply its policy of minimum subsidy and maximum efficiency to their highly competitive industry.

CHICAGO -- The 1954 convention of the Photographic Society of America held here recently pointed up perhaps more clearly than at any previous meeting, the essentially amateur level of the society's membership.

THE next world championship match will be played in New York City in January. A British team, champions of Europe, will play against the masters' team, champion of the American Contract Bridge League.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 (UP) The Philadelphia Phillies announced today the purchase of first baseman Jim Westlake from the San Francisco Seals for a "substantial" sum of money plus the delivery of a player on option next year.
MOSCOW, Oct. 16 -- Sixteen members of the British Houses of Parliament met Georgi M. Malenkov, Soviet Premier, at the Kremlin today for an hour's talk on British-Soviet relations and other topics.

" If you got it, a truck brought it" is a truckers' slogan that applies with special force to the 15 million residents of the New York metropolitan area. Hardly a single commodity enters, leaves or moves within or near the metropolis that is not, at some stage of its transportation, handled by the area's 175,000 truck drivers.

AUSTRALIA'S blue-black 3 1/2-pence stamp to be issued on Nov. 17 to publicize the Commonwealth's "interests in the Antarctic and the development of scientific research in that region" has a design based on the emblem of the Antarctic division of the Department of External Affairs.

A drastic reorganization of the office of the Chief Medical Examiner, including a staff increase and substantial pay rises, is recommended by City Administrator Luther H. Gulick in a report to Mayor Wagner.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Now that the National Assembly has given qualified approval to the London plan for arming Germany, Premier Pierre Mendes-France will have more time to devote to what he considers his essential task. This is his program for the re-conversion and the modernization of the French economy.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 16 -The representatives of eleven Left-Wing parties holding sixty-one of Chile's 147 Congressional seats today "energetically protested the arbitrary detention" of eight top labor leaders by the Government last night.

The future of atomic and solar energy was discussed on opposite sides of the Atlantic last week. In Paris Prof. Farrington Daniels of the University of Wisconsin told an audience composed of French chemists and the staff of the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) that nuclear and solar energy would supply most of man's needs when coal and oil reserves were exhausted.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- The Citizens Public Expenditure Survey has urged its members to vote against a proposition on Nov. 2 that would permit the state to borrow an additional $200,000,000 for public housing projects.
Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain will be the guest of honor at two events late this month to celebrate Columbia University's 200th anniversary.

NO book of musical research has aroused so much attention in the German-speaking countries this last year as Siegmund Axnelson's "Beethovens Ferne und Unsterbliche Geliebte" (Standard-Buch Verlags A.G., Zurich).

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 16 -- Former President Truman tonight accused the Republican party of committing one blunder after another in its foreign policy and of surrendering to selfish interests in administering its domestic policy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle has completed a secret check-up on the "sensitive" operations of the Central Intelligence Agency.
SEATTLE, Oct. 16 -- Boeing Airplane Company is in an intensive drive to interest air lines throughout the world in its new, swept-wing jet transport, the Model 707.

TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, was hailed here tonight by 15,000 Bergen County Democrats who jammed the Teaneck Armory.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Bucknell's undefeated football team regained the Old Shoe Trophy today by scoring a 27-0 triumph over victory less Temple in the Owls' Homecoming Day before 7,500 fans.

IN his introduction to this collection William Sloane frankly states that his anthology is not designed primarily for the science fiction veteran, but rather for the rawest rookie, fearfully approaching the field for the first time.

BILLINGS, Mont., Oct. 16 -- Perhaps the most determined eleventh-hour Republican campaign in the country is now being started here in Montana in a frankly desperate effort to defeat the dean of Senate Democratic New-Fair Dealers, James E. Murray.

In a move that could become a set pattern this winter as the Yankees seek to bolster their pitching staff for 1955, the Bombers yesterday acquired a new hurler, then lopped off the name of an older hand.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Oct. 16 -- More than 3,000 Long Beach school children received gamma globulin injections today in Nassau County's first mass immunization to check an "explosive outbreak" of polio that hit five Long Beach residents within a five-day period.

Payments by American corporations for employe welfare benefits in 1953 were larger than ever before. Contributions for pensions, old-age insurance and other benefits reached new high levels. But contributions for unemployment insurance declined for the third successive year.

Superior manpower proved the decisive factor as Boston College's unbeaten and untied football team notched its fourth triumph yesterday by halting a game Fordham eleven, 21 to 7, before 13,676 onlookers at the Polo Grounds.

AUTOMATIC vending machines, those "silent salesmen" of the subways, are starting to talk back to customers at the drop of a coin and where they will stop nobody knows. A dozen of the new talking cigarette machines have just been put into service in Manhattan and more are on the way.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 16 -- Williams came from behind in the final minute of play this afternoon to edge Bowdoin, 27 -- 24, in a hard fought game. The payoff came on a 12-yard pass from Quarterback Charlie Shaw to End Ed Lauben. Prior to that the lead had changed five times.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Spectacular touchdown runs of 85 and 55 yards by fullback Bob Kisiel paced Amherst to a 33-13 victory over previously unbeaten Coast Guard today to run the Lord Jeffs' undefeated streak to thirteen games.

The importance of citizenship education has long been recognized by school and college leaders. Various institutions have attempted to develop programs to teach the concepts of responsible living in a democratic society.
