MEXICO CITY, Oct, 10 -- The decline of the Mexican Communists' power and prestige has been revealed in two recent events here.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 16 -- A ten-year construction program calling for an expenditure of $171,000,000 is being proposed by the State Department of Mental Hygiene to meet the estimated demands of California's mentally ill.

By far the most important art event in New York this week is the celebration of the Museum of Modern Art's twenty-fifth anniversary. For this occasion the museum will open, on Wednesday, a newly installed exhibition of paintings and sculpture from its collections.

SEVENTY-FIVE years ago this Thursday, a little group of men sat watching a fragile lamp whose glowing light was, as a contemporary news account described it, like "the mellow sunset of an Italian autumn."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 16 -- Tennessee is supplying three of the top campaigners for the Democratic party this fall, and what will come of this situation is a matter of much speculation in the state.
DETROIT, Oct. 16 -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson's "bird-dog" analogy with the unemployed has sharpened interest in an otherwise apathetic Michigan election campaign.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Michigan, outplayed most of the game, seized the only break it got today and made a touchdown and conversion stand for a 7-0 Wolverine victory over Northwestern.

EARLY this year the Soviet Government rejected flatly the Western stand that German reunification must begin with free all-German elections. But a few days ago in Berlin Foreign Minister V.M. Molotov hinted his Government is now perhaps ready to reconsider.

NORFOLK, Conn. -- Travelers who think of mountain climbing as an arduous pastime might like to scale a few peaks the easy way this autumn, using the family automobile over most of the route instead of the traditional equipment favored by hardier mountaineers.

BUFFALO, Oct, 16 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for Governor, proposed tonight to "humanize" the state's personal income tax law by permitting additional deductions in especially burdensome situations. Mr. Ives said this was one of the first things he would do if he became Governor.

REGARDLESS of what readers may regard as the salient features, the outstanding fact about "The Stars At Noon" (see Page 5) clearly is that it's a book at all. Writing is a sedentary and leisurely trade, as everyone knows, while Jacqueline Cochran is about as sedentary as an excited dervish.

Deliveries of goods in top demand has become the No. 1 problem of manufacturers, according to resident buying offices. They report that pressure for quick shipments last week under the threat of a trucking strike further complicated the situation.

Herbert Morrison, former British Foreign Secretary, called on Mayor Robert Wagner of New York City recently and told him New York is "probably the noisiest city in the world." In Chicago this week, noise experts will hold a symposium on noise abatement.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 16 -- A Toledo man who knows a good thing when he sees it is making a handicap book this year on the Congressional race in the Ninth Ohio District, which includes this industrial city and its suburbs.

HOLDING fast to the rock of tradition, Knoedler's has opened a new second-floor gallery of American art with a still, small selection of still lifes. Back in date to before the Civil War the pictures go. And many of them, though painted with a high degree of skill, are by unknown artists who probably felt their humbler accomplishments were hardly respectable enough to be compared with the work of academicians.

WACO, Tex., Oct. 16 (AP) -Billy Hooper led Baylor to a 34-7 triumph over Washington today, the quarterback passing for three touchdowns and scoring another himself.
DETROIT, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens retained first place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 1, before 13,328 fans at Olympia Stadium.

SEATTLE, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Fred Hutchinson, the former Seattle sandlot pitcher who resigned as manager of the Detroit Tigers, signed a contract today to pilot the Seattle Rainiers of the Pacific Coast League.

DURHAM, N.H., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Halfback Jim Flynn raced 77 and 27 yards for Delaware touchdowns today as the unbeaten Blue Hens defeated New Hampshire, 19 -- 13. It was New Hampshire's first loss in four games.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y. Realization that medical science and improved standards of living are slowly but surely conquering one of mankind's most devastating diseases came sharply to this world-famous tuberculosis center last week with the announcement that the Trudeau Sanatorium will close its patient-care facilities on Dec. 1.

IN the next two decades probably no part of this unstable and changing world is going to be the scene of so many crises, alarums and excursions (and the cause for so much anxiety in Washington) as the logical area of Chinese Communist expansion -- Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- During the President's long absence from Washington -- about eight weeks -- he suspended the news conferences he holds with great regularity when at is post in the capital. His answers to the wide range and often dough texture of the questions have been marked by candor that is unusual m the circumstances, and doubtless these events will now be resumed and be of similar character.

OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Heinz Futterer of West Germany sprinted 200 meters around a curve in 20.8 seconds today. His time was better than the German and European records by one-tenth of a second but the race was run with a brisk wind.

A HUNDRED years ago this month one of the most famous and disastrous episodes in military history took place. Britain, France and Turkey were at war with Russia; a battle was being fought outside the little fishing village of Balaclava. Someone blundered and the dashing and brilliant British Light Cavalry Brigade, the most perfect body of troops to leave the shores of England, received an order to charge to almost certain death.

Perhaps out of delicacy Harold Clurman in his discussion of the Broadway audience, "Light on 'That Big Black Giant'" (Sept. 26), had nothing to say (though he does lament the absence of theatre bars) about the well-established American institution: the pre-theatre dinner, with its prefacing cocktails and nearly always added liquid refreshments during and after the meal.

THE SEARCH," which makes its debut over the C.B.S. television network today from 4:30 to 5 P.M., is an attempt to make the tremendously varied activities of American colleges and universities not only comprehensible, but interesting and exciting. PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- For some time the Chamber of Commerce and others have been saying that department store sales here are not as bad as weekly figures for center-city stores have indicated. For instance, mid-city department store sales were down 6 per cent in July.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- An eleven-goal scoring spree marked the 6-5 victory of a young Manchester United team over Chelsea in one of the top English League soccer matches today. Denis Viollet, Manchester inside forward who has been tipped for international honors, led his team to the head of the first divsion with three goals.
MILFORD, Del., Oct. 16 -- Like so many communities in the path of Hurricane Hazel, this neat and leafy little town primarily was concerned today with cleaning up.
The making of reproductions of antique furniture at a shop here will be turned to the advantage of orphaned children for the remaining eleven weeks of the year.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- There seems little doubt in New England this week that President Eisenhower, personally, is just about as popular as ever. But how much of this popularity will rub off on Republican candidates on Nov. 2 without his name on the ballot is not clear at this point in the campaign.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 -- The Archdiocese of Baltimore, primal see of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, is to have a new $8,500,000 cathedral. It is being built with a bequest from the late Thomas O'Neill a department store owner.

ON Dec. 2, 1942, a cryptic message sent from Chicago -- "The Italian Navigator has reached the New World" -- signaled the beginning of the Atomic Age. The world's first controlled release of nuclear energy had been achieved.
The Mount Holyoke College Club of Westchester will sponsor a tour of Westchester residences on Thursday from 1 to 5:30 P.M.

Dolores Mari, who has sung Micaela, Sophie, Gilda and Mimi with the New York City Opera, sang her first Cio-Cio-San with the company yesterday afternoon when it presented the second of the two productions of "Madama Butterfly" on its schedule for the fall season at the City Center.

WILL the tactics employed by Republican or Democratic managers -- or both -- of this year's campaign for party control of Congress merit the appraisal of history as "dirty"? By the standards of past political contests in this country which were "dirty" by any definition the answer is -- not so far.

President William V.S. Tubman of Liberia landed in New York yesterday for an official visit of three weeks in the United States. WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- James C. Hagerty, press secretary to President Eisenhower, withheld comment tonight on Mr. Stringfellow's repudiation of his claims to wartime action behind enemy lines.

On the eve of the ninth annual meeting of tile American Cancer Society, its president Dr. Alfred M. Popma, reported yesterday that the cancer death rate among women "has leveled off and begun to drop."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 -- The worst of the periodic sieges of smog that have afflicted Los Angeles ever since World War II brought discomfort and exasperation for the 2,000,000 citizens to a corresponding crescendo this week.

This year has seen none of the dust storms and dust-created sunsets that occurred during the spectacular droughts of the Nineteen Thirties. None the less, as Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay said on Friday, serious drought conditions that could result in the creation of "dust-bowl" areas are again building up.

CHICAGO -- A warm tribute to the American amateur photographer and the announcement of a nationwide contest for amateurs were the response of Henry R. Luce, founder and editor in chief of Time and Life, to his receipt of the Progress Medal Award at the recent honors banquet of the Photographic Society of America at the conclusion of its 1954 convention here.

ELSA SCHIAPARELLI, long synonymous with fashion innovation, chicesse, persuasive perfumery, and an aberrated shade of pink, has written "in her own characteristic English," as her publisher styles it, an autobiography-biography.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Rejected, co-favorite in a field of seven, won the $100,400 Hawthorne Gold Cup by two lengths today.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 16 -- A South Korean official accused the United States today of having tried to cripple the country's industry and to cause economic chaos in retaliation for the deadlock over currency exchange.

DETROIT, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Bobby Layne, shaking off a sore shoulder, fired three touchdown passes tonight to lead the unbeaten Detroit Lions to a 35-to-0 victory over the Baltimore Colts before 48,272 fans at Briggs Stadium.
High Gun all the way -- that's the five-word story of the running of the $82,250 Jockey Club Cup race before 38,229 customers at Belmont Park yesterday.
The Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, which is celebrating its sixtieth anniversary, will open its annual drive for funds on Oct. 26 with a cocktail party and tea at Gracie Mansion.

HIGHBROW, lowbrow, upper middlebrow, and lower middlebow -- the lines between them are sometimes indistinct, as the lines between upper class, lower class and middle class have always been in our traditionally fluid society.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared tonight that attempts by the Eisenhower Administration to "reconcile the irreconcilable" had led to a catastrophic loss of American moral and political prestige in the non-Communist world.

The cure for that insidious disease, "summer doldrums," may have been found in New York City's retail trade. Announcement last week that the New York Summer Festival will be continued in 1955 was welcome news to retailers. Sales bounced up this summer in the first year of the promotion to "sell" the city as a vacation spot.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 16 -- There was no evidence in the Missouri Basin states this week that President Eisenhower's personal popularity had changed in any degree. It was still high, still solid, and still apparently transcending party lines.

FEW towns have a bird or wildlife sanctuary of their own but any month of the year anyone in New Canaan, Conn., may visit the Bird Sanctuary and Wildwood Preserve in this town. Located on Old Stamford Road, the sanctuary comprises eighteen acres of fenced woodland and four miles of winding trails where some of the rarest of native ferns and autumn wild flowers vie with migrating birds for attention.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 -- Pitt demolished Navy's hopes of continuing among the country's unbeaten football teams with a surprising 21-to-19 triumph today.

BEANIE TATUM is back in another adventure near his home in the Great Smoky Mountains. His mischievous puppy, Tough Enough -- a birthday present in the first book -- has grown increasingly unpopular with the huge Tatum clan.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 16 -- William and Mary executed 86 and 77-yard touchdown runs today to defeat Rutgers, 14 -- 7, before 9,500 at Rutgers Stadium.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 16 -Nassir Khan, titular leader of the Ghashghai tribal confederation in Southern Iran, asked today for moderation in the hostile feelings between the Central Government and his nomad followers.
WHEN Theodore Tilton brought Henry Ward Beecher into court in 1875 on the charge of alienating his wife's affections, he raised the curtain on one of the most sensational trials in American history.

Mrs. Philip Bastedo and members of her committee have plans well under way for the Nov. 5 benefit performance for the Union Settlement of the musical "On Your Toes," which opened Monday at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre.
WATERVILLE, Me., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Tufts scored once in each period to defeat Colby today, 28 -- 14.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 16 -- After staying put since 1739 on the site where it was built, a full-size barn complete with 24-inch floor boards and two sets of large doors is slated to travel through the main street of 314-year-old Southampton.

AT one fell swoop, Bartok Records has plugged about half a dozen holes in the Bartok discography. A seven-disk release covering the late Hungarian master's output from the early years of the twentieth century until the year of his death, affords a new perspective on music that up to now has seldom been heard in this country.

THE core of a travel book is likely to be the personality of the traveler. In this case, many of the places Karl Eskelund and his Chinese wife visited were not exceptionally remote or exotic in themselves. What the author has done is to present himself pretty convincingly as one of those persons who were really born to wander -- informally, adventurously, and with very little money.

" INDIA, one often hears, has many lessons to learn from the West. It will be a good day when the West realizes that it has lessons of much greater importance to learn from India." This is the sort of well-intentioned cliche that turns up somewhat too frequently in John Seymour's account of his travels through India in 1952, from the tropical province of Travancore-Cochin in the south to the dusty plains of the north.

THESE 1,400-word chapters were first turned out for Sunday editions of The Trenton (N.J.) Times-Advertiser. Novelist John O'Hara says a fourteen-page contract stipulated that he should write as he pleased but mainly about books and authors.

IT could be truthfully said that more hardy plants are raised by cuttings than by any other single method. Nurserymen rely rather heavily on them to replenish their stocks of trees and shrubs and gradually home owners are becoming more proficient in their own attempts at propagation.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 16 -- For the last two years Virginia Democrats have been out to "redeem" two of the three Congressional Districts captured by the Republicans in President Eisenhower's election victory of 1952.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 16 -- Officials of the deposed regime of Jacobo Arbenz Guzman "stole" 5,000,000 quetzales from the Government in one operation this year, the Attorney General charged today. The quetzal is on a par with the dollar.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The United States denounced the American head of a United Nations agency today for not having immediately dismissed eight United States citizens who had received adverse loyalty reports.

ON display in "Tactical Exercise" are the qualities that have gained Evelyn Waugh his reputations. He has had two or three reputations, each based on an equally enthusiastic incomprehension. A coterie loved him seventeen years for being a heartless and light-minded satirist of the ruling classes.

TO me the most thoughtful and suggestive article in the extraordinarily comprehensive survey of American literature recently issued by The Times (London) Literary Supplement is the one entitled "The Dominant Theme of Violence: Man Versus Nature and Society."

NEVER trust an "accidental" death in the past. As soon as someone in a mystery novel observes casually, "Poor girl; her brother died a year ago. Accident, of course," you can be sure that brother's death was really a murder, which will motivate the more overt murders yet to come.
MIAMI, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Rocky Marciano will undergo another examination by physicians on Thursday to determine if his injured nose has healed sufficiently to risk a title defense this winter.

THE odds posted above pawnshops are all wrong, away off the beam. New York folklore has it that the three gilt balls over the door mean that the odds are 3 to 1 that you'll never get back the stuff you are about to hock.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- John D. Rockefeller 3d joined civic and medical officials this afternoon in laying a cornerstone for the $4,400,000 Phelps Memorial Hospital, on Albany Post Road, at the North Tarrytown-Ossining boundary.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Unbeaten Minnesota, marching back to grandeur under a new regime, beat punchless Illinois, 19-6, with a strong ground attack today for its fourth straight victory.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- Shortly after the close of the American Revolution the father of our country was called to the University of Pennsylvania to receive an honorary degree. On his visit to this great institution of learning he was inspired to create the university in the nation's capital that now bears his name.

Paintings, French eighteenth century furniture and other works of art collected by the late Katherine Deere Butterworth of Moline, Ill., will be sold this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

If Jimmie joins a gang, becomes a holy terror in the neighborhood, runs away from home and clashes with the police, psychiatrists and welfare workers often succeed in tracing the cause to a miserable home life, the conditions that prevail in the slum where he lives and plays, or the insecurity that is the consequence of race prejudice.

IN 1880, Boston, known locally as the Hub of the Universe, was 250 years old. To many of her patriots, the next two decades were going to be the hardest. For, in the Eighties and Nineties, the struggle for American reform, and all the paradoxes faced by American reformers who retained nostalgic images of past ideals then collapsing, became nationally prominent.

JAMES MASON, self-described dilettante actor, just the other day declared he has officially retired from a long career as a regular motion picture performer. The man, who has specialized in moody heroes and appealing heavies, now states that henceforth he will enjoy his newly proclaimed leisure and will accept only those film parts which offer his talents a challenge.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The talks between French and Tunisian officials on internal autonomy for Tunisia have run into snags on two major point, France's military and judicial prerogatives in the North African protectorate.

HOUSTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Southern Methodist's Mustangs combined second-half goal-line stands with the passing of Duane Nutt and the running of Don Mc-Ilhenny tonight to open their Southwest Conference campaign with a 20-6 victory that maintained their Houston jinx ever the Rice Owls.

THE Taconic State Parkway is now seventy-two miles long, twelve new miles of four-lane concrete having been added to its northern end yesterday. The parkway, which starts at Hawthorne Circle, used to end at Route 199 near Lafayetteville.

A tight supply situation is likely to develop in the cotton market toward the end of the present season. With the demand expected to be about 1,000,000 bales more than the yield from the current crop, the surplus from previous crops will have to be drawn upon to meet the deficit.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 16 -- The central executive council of Hizbullah, an Islamic organization of former guerrillas, announced today its support of the Southeast Asian defense treaty.
Copper shortages may extend into January as a result of a long series of strikes that interrupted operations in mines, mills, smelters and refineries.

VIENNA, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Voters in half of Austria will elect 214 deputies to regional legislatures tomorrow. The voting could result in nation-wide elections should the Socialists win a thumping majority.

I'D boarded the Dublin train at Mallow. In the compartment there was the usual smell of ancient upholstery and coal-dust, the inevitable faded view of Blarney. Over in one corner sat a big bull of a man with a red face, opposite him a wizened little fellow with a wild nest of hair in each ear and a book the size of the Bible propped against his meager front of tweed.

EINSTEIN'S general writings have been thus far available in two major collections in English, "The World As I See It" (1934) and "Out of My Later Years" (1950). "Ideas and Opinions" contains the most interesting and important selections from those two books, some of them revised or retranslated, others from the Swiss collection which appeared last year, and a few additional pieces.

ALTHOUGH a writer of light verse, David McCord must be an intellectual of some sort. "Odds Without Ends" proves it. Who but an intellectual would in the first place speak familiarly of Pandora, she of the studied classical allusion?

Professional football will make its 1954 bow in New York today. The "new look" New York Giants, featuring a dynamic offense, will meet the Chicago Cardinals at 2:05 P.M. in the first of six Giant home games at the Polo Grounds.

ITALIAN and Yugoslav officials in New York indicated last week that they expected the London agreement dividing Trieste between Italy and Yugoslavia to put an end ultimately to the Adriatic port's activity as a stamp-issuing area.

STEVE OWEN wrote a book last year, a delightful and eminently readable autobiography, "My Kind of Football." His entire philosophy of coaching was wrapped up in one blunt sentence: "I would rather win by 3 -- 0 than lose by 38 --36."

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 16 -- Riddled by Navy and then Army in successive weeks, Dartmouth's eleven reared up this afternoon and gave undefeated Colgate some disquieting moments. Its efforts, however, were not sustained and the favored Red Raiders posted a 13-to-7 triumph.

AMONG the literary legacies of the late Margaret Wise Brown are these two Little Golden Books, dissimilar in mood, yet each bearing the characteristic stamp of her style and imagination. "The Little Indian" uses the same antiphonal pattern that made "The Little Fireman" and its successors so popular.
Further tributes were paid yesterday to members of the crew of the U.S.S. Bennington for outstanding performance of duty during the explosions and fire aboard that Essex-class carrier last May 26.

THERE is a definite doubt in my mind as to the necessity for winter protection of established roses in the New York area. Personal experience stands behind this attitude toward established rose bushes.

ROME, Oct. 16 -- In an interview granted to the Belgrade correspondent of the semi-official Italian Ansa agency after the solution of the Trieste problem President Tito of Yugoslavia clearly revealed his intention of following a policy of equidistance between East and West.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 16 (UP) -- William G. Helis Jr.'s Helioscope, who set a track mark while winning the Olympic Handicap at Atlantic City in his last start, sped to a three-length triumph today in the $30,550 Benjamin Franklin Handicap at Garden State Park.

NO mother who launches her daughter at a multiple-debutante party could be blamed for worrying -- or even maneuvering -- lest the other white dresses were more alluring, and the other faces more enchanting.

Luisillo, a young Mexican who was an apprentice bullfighter at 14 but soon switched to dancing, will give New Yorkers a look at his art when his Ballets Espagnols arrive at the Mark Hellinger Oct. 31.
DETROIT, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Optimism is the rule at the auto industry's factories and well down into a large part of its merchandising organization.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 16 -- Negotiators for the Western Big Three and the West German Government agreed today on a draft for a treaty to end the occupation and give the Federal Republic full sovereignty.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Oklahoma, gunning for a national championship and a seventh straight Big Seven title routed Kansas today by using every man in a thirty-six-man squad to score a record-smashing 65-0 victory.

Norwich University scored 28 points in the second half to break a 7-7 halftime tie and coast to a 35-13 victory over Brooklyn College on the loser's field yesterday. Brooklyn has not won in its last twenty-three games.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Dick Allen, a sophomore doing double duty for the injured Bobby Lance, quarterbacked both Florida units to a 21-7 victory over Kentucky today. The triumph put the Gators in a commanding position in the Southeastern Conference race with a 3-0 record.

HONOLULU -- Right now it is spring down under the Equator, the beginning of the best time to visit Australia and New Zealand for a refreshingly different travel experience. Fast air travel has brought these countries within thirty hours' flying time of the West Coast and less than two days from the Eastern seaboard.

A POET cannot help being of his age, the diction and the idiom see to that; but, if he be a poet at all, he should be before his time. Now none of us can speak of the future times, so, as history repeats itself, there need be no paradox in placing Max Eastman in the reign of Charles II and likening him most to Dryden who was of that age.

MADRID, Oct. 15 -- Leaders of Spain's Protestant communities have appealed to the Minister of Justice to make it possible for members of their congregations to contract marriages in accordance with the provisions of the civil law.

THE theatre in Dublin cannot be said to have a season proper. There is no rising crescendo of interest commencing in the autumn and dying down in the late spring. Theatrical activity remains at an almost constant level the entire year round with, perhaps, the first week in August quickening its pulse to some extent.
YONKERS, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Faber Hanover, an 8-to-1 chance driven by Billy Haughton, won the $6,000 Sunnyside Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight by a neck over Royal Pastime.

WHEN VERNON J. PICK recently sold his uranium find in neighboring Emery County to Atlas Corporation for $9 million, the question that naturally arose in this rocky southeast comer of Utah was: "Is Steen next?"

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 16 -- The final draft of Pakistan's constitution went to the printer today. With the exception of some clauses that reaffirm and secure the Islamic character of Pakistan, the 292 articles are a set of secular laws for the administration of a democratic parliamentary form of government.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Oct. 16 (UP) -- John Popson raced 103 yards with the second-half kickoff today and scored two other touchdowns to lead Furman to a .31-20 victory over The Citadel before 8,000 at Furman's homecoming.

Your paper has rather frequently criticized various provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act (McCarran-Walter Act). Recently on several occasions, and again on Oct. 10 (in the case of a Yugoslav youth), you reported on that alleged "deficiency" of the law which bars Communists from coming to the United States temporarily as visitors, students, merchants, participants in various international conventions, etc.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (UP) -- U.C.L.A.'s football team, led by Primo Villanueva, handed Stanford University its worst defeat in history today, as the Bruins ran up a 72-to-0 score before 70,555 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

NOT many women are teaching theology in American seminaries, and not many teachers of theology, men or women, are writing books comprehensible and meaningful to the average reader. Notable on both counts is Georgia Harkness, Professor of Applied Theology at the Pacific School of Religion and author, among other books, of "The Modern Rival of Christian Faith," "Toward Understanding the Bible" and now THE SOURCES OF WESTERN MORALITY (Scribner's, $3.50).

THE Cold War and the continuing world crisis are the fault of the United States as much, if not more, than that of any other nation. Such is the impression one might get from "The United States in a Changing World" -- a review of American history followed by a lengthy indictment of our foreign policy since the end of World War II.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Quarterback Albert Elmore, Jr., son of an Alabama Rose Bowler, threw passes for three touchdowns and Corky Tharp raced 96 yards for another today as Alabama drubbed Tennessee 27 to 0 before 41,800 fans.

THERE is magic in milk these days. A powder has appeared that, when combined with water, gives a liquid milk instantly in a kind of presto-chango process. This immediately soluble powder is the latest edition of that familiar product, dry skim milk, or as it is technically termed, non-fat dry milk solids.

THE German composer Werner Egk has just completed an opera, "Irish Legend," which will have its first performance at the 1955 Salzburg Festival, according to Carl Miller of Associated Music Publishers, Mr. Egk's representatives in this country.
TORONTO, Oct. 16 -- Hurricane Hazel's last fling in Ontario and western Quebec left thirty-six known dead today.

Supreme Court Justice Percy D. Stoddart in Queens has signed a show-cause order temporarily enjoining the Board of Elections from placing on the ballot the name of Robert N. Rose as the Liberal party's nominee for Congress in the Fourth Queens District.

IT wasn't long ago that the English intellectual was among the foremost travelers and adventurers in the world. In fact, the English prided themselves on the type: Trelawny, Byron, Doughty; women like Lady Hestor Stanhope and Gertrude Bell.

THROUGHOUT his career the poetry of Mark Van Doren seems to have attracted uncritical praise, some of it certainly disingenuous. Five extremely rash statements decorate the jacket of his "Selected Poems." He is certainly not the American poet "most representative of his nation and his times.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- History, in five languages, is being written at the United Nations at the rate of 260,000 words a day.

A group of Yale Law School students who feel that the voice of conservatism is being drowned out today by spokesmen for liberal ideas have arranged a series of five lectures to be presented this fall on "The Role of the Conservative in Today's World." The students sponsoring the lectures are members of the Conservative Society of the Yale Law School.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 16 -- Brown drew it as close as possible against Princeton today. Trailing with less than two minutes left in the final quarter, the Bruins flashed a scoring run and added the extra point to win by the score of 21 to 20.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 16 -- Notre Dame sloshed through the mud and rain today for a 20-19 triumph over Michigan State before 57,238 fans as Jerry Planutis missed the potential tying point on his conversion try with sixty-five seconds to play.

The New York Public Library will hold two recorded concerts this week, both on Wednesday. One, from noon to 2 P.M., is the weekly event of listeners' requests and will include de Falla's only opera, "La Vida Breve." At 8:15 P.M. the monthly concert will be in honor of Charles Edward Ives, American composer who died last spring.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Yale's finest football squad in recent years stood revealed in its full capacity today in a smashing 47-21 triumph over Cornell in the Bowl.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Nebraska, displaying an unexpected aerial attack plus a potent running game, defeated Oregon State, 27 -- 7, today before a capacity crowd of 39,000.

AFTER fifteen years of marriage to Kate, Fred Bogner, telephone operator at a Catholic religious organization in a West German town, decided he couldn't take it any longer. Not that he didn't love his two young children -- so quiet they frightened their parents -- and he knew he needed Kate more than she needed him.
Hedging transactions in commodity futures are dealings by which persons or corporations protect themselves against price fluctuations in the product in which they deal.

Fourteen junior high school students who have won prizes in the fifth annual United Nations essay contest will be entertained at Gracie Mansion tomorrow at 2 P.M. by John Golden, theatrical producer, and Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, the Mayor's wife.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 17 -- Commando tactics were used by a band of twenty-six Irish Republican Army terrorists in a raid on a British Army barracks at Omagh in County Tyrone early today.

ERIE, Pa., Oct. 17 (UP) -- Mayor Thomas W. Flatley admitted today in a signed statement that he received $450 to $550 a month for sixteen months in payments originating from persons he had "suspected" were running numbers rackets in his city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Adrian Burk cut loose today with one of the greatest passing shows in football history, throwing a record-equalling seven touchdown strikes to drive the Philadelphia Eagles to a 49 -- 21 victory over the Washington Redskins.

Clifford P. Case declared yesterday that the Adelaide Case mentioned by Bella V. Dodd, former Communist, as a member of Communist-front organizations was not his sister. The Re publican candidate for the Senate in New Jersey disclosed, however, that his sister had informed him that she had had a previous association with a "left-wing study group."
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The British have installed an intricate wave-measuring instrument on two research ships in the hope that one day they will be able to harness some of the colossal power of the sea.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- San Francisco's dynamic running power, as displayed by Joe Perry, Hugh McElhenny and John Henry Johnson, today brought the unbeaten Forty-niners from behind to down the Chicago Bears 31 -- 24.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, sparked by Al DelVecchio's sharpshooting, beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 5-2, at the Stadium tonight before 7,984 fans, and kept the Chicago entry in the National Hockey League race victoryless for the season.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 17 -- With never a thought of politics, and purely for sport, the Buckram Beagles turned their packs of kennel-fed hounds loose here this afternoon to begin their twentieth annual season of hunting the hare.

The acquisition of a seventeen-block blighted area at Seaside, Rockaway, in Queens, as the site for a $23,000,000 privately built housing project was recommended yesterday by the city's Committee on Slum Clearance.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve-months amount to $77,335,809,605. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

THERE are twenty-nine short stories in "More Stories by Frank O'Connor." Nearly all of them are good of their kind and a dozen or so are excellent. This happy state of affairs is only to be expected, for Mr. O'Connor is one of the ablest living masters of the short story and one of the most distinguished of living Irish writers.

Maria Moors Cabot gold medals will be awarded to five Western Hemisphere journalists for their part in the "advancement of international friendship in the Americas." The awards will be made at a special convocation Friday at 3 P.M. in Columbia University's Low Memorial Library.

Public hearings have been concluded here by the Temporary Commission on the Courts on the subject of establishing a central administrative office for New York State courts. One witness, appearing on behalf of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, produced a chart showing the "unproud" record of the city's courts.
The first mass production of radios utilizing transistors instead of tubes will be started Oct. 25 by the Regency division of the Industrial Development Engineering Associates, Inc., Indianapolis.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 17 -- The Utah Republican state chairman said today there was "more reaction in favor than against" Representative Douglas R. Stringfellow after the 32-year-old veteran admitted making up a fantastic story of heroic war-time exploits.
The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale told 2,400 listeners yesterday that if they anticipated good days ahead, they would certainly have them.

Three major roles changed hands over the week-end at the City Center and a fourth and lesser part successfully introduced a new member of the New York City Opera in the person of John Reardon, a young American baritone.

To give, to fill a need, is the gratifying experience of volunteer workers at Metropolitan Hospital on Welfare Island with its 1,150 beds and patients ranging from new-born babes to very old people. Volunteers with all sorts of abilities can be of service, with training given on the job when required.

Until two years ago, citizens in the small Chilean city of San Felipe were not getting enough protein to assure proper bodily growth and maintenance. Per capita intake was 30 to 40 per cent short of the minimum recommended allowance of that nutrient.

BUFFALO, Oct. 17 -- The upstate vote may be 300,000 to 400,000 larger than New York City's in this year's election because of new suburban housing developments, both in the metropolitan area and upstate. Ordinarily the two are almost equal.

HONG KONG, Oct. 17 -- Prime Minister Nehru's visit to Hanoi was interpreted by the Vietminh radio today as a possible "first step" toward the development of diplomatic, economic and cultural relations between India and Ho Chi Minh's North Vietnam regime.

The Travelers Aid Society of New York, seeking $360,000 for services to persons in New York's terminals, has enlisted the advertising profession. William R. Baker, chairman of Benton Bowles, Inc., and of the advertising committee for the drive, announced over the week-end those who would help him.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The strike that has shut down the Port of London spread today to Liverpool. After a stormy meeting, dockworkers there voted to quit at 8 A.M. tomorrow in support of the London dockers.
WHILE the city mercifully escaped the worst of hurricane Hazel Friday night, the Stork Club was hit by a different storm Saturday evening. Poor old Sherm Billingsley never had quite such a night.
The creation of four new bureas in the city's Department of Personnel was announced yesterday by Personnel Director Joseph Schechter, chairman of the City Civil Service Commission.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 -- Steel activity last week continued at a pace somewhat better than many steel people had expected. Part of the pick-up was due to heavier demand from auto makers.

Marathon runners not only are hardy athletes, but they also are apparently adept at dodging traffic. Tops in those departments yesterday was Bill Welsh of the Millrose A.A. He took the individual title in the senior Metropolitan A.A.U. modified marathon conducted through the streets of Greenwich Village.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Spending in the Seventh Federal Reserve District as measured by volume of checks drawn on banks declined 3 per cent in September from the level of a year ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago reported today.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Both major party candidates for Representative in Westchester's Twenty-seventh District are lawyers, and there the similarity ends.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- If the votes of women and newcomers in Westchester were not of such growing significance, Representative Ralph A. Gamble of Larchmont could spend the next fortnight in his New York law office waiting for the ballots to be counted.

Two five - story apartment houses containing twenty suites on lot 44 by 102 feet at 43-45 East Seventy-second Street have been sold by Howard J. Horwood and George Popkin to an investing client of Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., brokers.

TOM HAMILTON undoubtedly feels like the father who said to his son before spanking him, "My boy, this is going to hurt me more than it hurts you." But he didn't flinch or duck his moral obligation. Painful though it might have been, Tom went ahead with the chastisement.

Dr. Basil C. MacLean, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday that he felt "it would make more sense" to provide more help to nonprofit, public-supported institutions than to build additional space for free beds in city hospitals.
J. Raymond McGovern, Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, predicted yesterday that a Democratic victory would result in a state sales tax.
The privately owned United States-flag merchant fleet has fallen below the 15,000,000-deadweight-ton mark for the first time in more than two and a half years.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. today said that predominantly Republican upstate counties had lost out on state improvement programs because the Republican Administration regarded them as "safe."
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- The French Ministry of Finances announced today that French exports to foreign countries had reached a more satisfactory stage and notably as regards industrial products.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Foreign Operations Administration has signed contracts with forty universities to carry on technical assistance in twenty-six foreign lands.
Ship charter rates continued to climb in almost all sectors last week, and cargo shippers apparently were convinced the rise would hold.
The Rev. Dr. Robert D. Hershey cautioned Christians yesterday against seeking a religion "capable of being analyzed or proved."

Cotton futures prices moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange last week. Nearer deliveries lost ground while more distant month contracts gained moderately. At the week's close, active futures were 11 points, or 55 cents a bale, lower to 19 points, or 95 cents, higher.

BONN, Germany, Monday, Oct. 18 -- The population of Soviet-occupied East Germany was mustered to the polls yesterday to acquiesce in Communist rule. A.D.N., the East Germans' Berlin news agency, said last midnight that about 99 per cent of the eligible voters had cast their ballots and the same proportion had endorsed the single list of unopposed National Front candidates for the Volkskammer (Parliament).
LONDON, Oct. 17 (Reuters) -- The reorganized British Cabinet is now composed as follows:

Stiffer prison sentences should be given to convicted Communist subversives, Assistant Attorney General William F. Tompkins said yesterday. He is head of the Internal Security Division of the Department of Justice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A sampling survey of approximately 100 "battleground" districts indicates that, as of this week-end, the Democrats are slightly ahead in their drive to capture control of the next House of Representatives.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Choppy fluctuations within a rather narrow range marked trading in grain last week.

The New York County Lawyers Association issued yesterday its appraisal of the qualifications of candidates for judicial office in the forthcoming elections. The appraisals were made on the basis of reports by the association's Committee on the Judiciary and Committee on the Municipal Court.
ROME, Oct. 17 -- Americans traveling by air to foreign countries in 1955 will be able to do so at about the same fares as this year.
A Norwegian floating factory ship is the first to sail for next l year's whaling season in the Antarctic.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 17 (UP) --The Republican National Chairman, Leonard W. Hall, said here today that former President Truman, in attacking the Eisenhower Administration's foreign policy, had shown that "his memory is certainly short."

A newly published letter by Vincent Van Gogh was described yesterday as further confirming the authenticity of the self-portrait, "Study by Candlelight," which is owned by William Goetz. A twenty-month controversy had led to a Treasury Department ruling on Sept. 20, 1950, that the painting, was an original Van Gogh and entitled to duty-free import.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 17 -Fred Annon of Ryewood, who shared yesterday's victory, repeated with a different partner today in the second phase of Dellwood Country Club's second annual charity pro-amateur golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Merger waves sweep through American industry at intervals and a sizable one is now at the threshold of the Justice Department's Anti-Trust Division.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 17 -- The stock market here was active again last week under the influence of American buying of Royal Dutch. The issue jumped from 487 to 527 on Thursday, before a sharp setback was seen.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The stock markets in the last week have given another remarkable demonstration of their almost complete indifference to what under more normal circumstances would be considered bad news.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Edouard Herriot, 82-year-old chief of the Radical party, speaking at a dinner ending the party's congress in Marseilles today, virtually bestowed the mantle of Radical leadership on 47-year-old Premier Pierre Mendes-France.
The home seamstress may bring the design talents of international couturiers into her own sewing room with today's patterns.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Three major defense plant projects representing private investment of more than $75,000,000 were approved for Federal tax assistance today.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 17 -- In an effort to break the deadlock over South Korean currency, the United States Army announced tonight that reserve gasoline supplies would be made available immediately for sale on the open market.

The ideology of the United States as expressed by its flag and its standard-bearers was re-emphasized yesterday by the Military Order of the World Wars at its thirty-third annual Massing of the Colors.

We are not inclined, offhand, to concur in the judgment of India's Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, that his current trip to Red China is possibly the most important event of the decade. Sir Henry Clinton, commander in chief of the British Army from 1778 to 1782, spent the last twelve years of his life writing an account of his "ill-starred" military career in North America. He died before his manuscript was ready for the printer and it remained unnoticed with his papers until purchased by William L. Clements in 1925.

The talented Joan Field, absent from local platforms for about five years, gave a violin recital last night in Town Hall. It was an evening of fluent playing. Miss Field is not a "big" violinist, nor does she pretend to be, but within the framework in which she holds herself she is the mistress of some real artistry.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins scored with less than two minutes to play tonight to earn a 1-1 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs in a fierce contest that brought the seldom seen "penalty shot" for the first time in six year's at Boston Garden.
Agitation for Federal control of futures trading in coffee, with a Federal Trade Commission hearing called for Dec. 14, has aroused protests from the traders in Beaver Street.

Pioneer Youth of America, a thirty-year-old organization that maintains a camp for children of working parents, will be the beneficiary of the Jan. 6 performance of "Quadrille," starring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, Edna Best and Brian Aherne.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Republican and Democratic spokesmen vied today for any partisan credit to be found in the worldwide lull in fighting.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 16 -- Brazil needs 640,000 new automobiles in the next eight years, according to a report made public here today. The possibility of factories to build them here and to save the need of importation has aroused keen interest, in view of the chronic dollar, shortage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower attended services at the National Presbyterian Church today. They then viewed a special religious exhibit in a room of the church.

TOKYO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- General Hull said today that the Army would start immediately to sell gasoline and oil in South Korea to get the hwan it needed. He announced the move after a meeting here with Ellis O. Briggs, United States Ambassador to Seoul.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A marble memorial tablet was transferred recently from the old to the new State Department Building, where it honors those diplomatic and consular officers "who while on active duty lost their lives under heroic or tragic circumstances."

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- In its drive for increased agricultural production, the Soviet Government today offered substantial inducements for new collective farm settlers, including those going to recently opened areas of Kazakhstan and Western Siberia.

The New York City Transit Authority announced yesterday changes in schedules of trains in conjunction with the opening of the hook-up between the IND division and the B.M.T. Culver line on Saturday. This will give a continuous ride between the Bronx and Coney Island.
BUFFALO, Oct. 17 -- Senator Irving M. Ives plans to concentrate during the remaining two weeks of his campaign for the Governorship on an effort to attract votes in the New York City area.

NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 17 -Two boys and two girls, students of Southern High School in Baltimore, arrived here today to spend a week seeing for themselves how integration of white and Negro students works at New Rochelle High School.
Two race horses were killed at Belmont Park's training track yesterday when they collided head-on after the rider of one had been unseated.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Oct. 17 -Long Island faces a serious teacher and building shortage. Immediate attention is essential if adequate facilities are to be provided for the rapidly expanding population of Nassau and Suffolk counties.
The Riegel Paper Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net income of $1,319,508 for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Sept. 26, compared with $1,178,121 for the corresponding period of 1953.

President Eisenhower slashed red tape yesterday to authorize immediate Federal emergency aid to hurricane-stricken areas of North Carolina and South Carolina.

A diversified attack, featuring fake hand-offs, brought the Giants a 31-17 victory over the Chicago Cardinals in the New York home opener of the National Football League yesterday at the Polo Grounds.
DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The market for new passenger cars in 1955 will require production of nearly 5,600,000 units, the annual Crowell-Collier survey indicated today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -- The National Planning Association said today that New England had a "sound" economy despite loss of textile business and heavy unemployment in some areas.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Harold Macmillan succeeded Earl Alexander as Minister of Defense in a change in the British Government announced today by Sir Winston Churchill. There were twenty-three other alterations.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- An eight-man Philadelphia syndicate today purchased control of the Philadelphia Athletics, ending the 54-year-old dynasty of the Connie Mack baseball family.

With an exquisitely performed program, the Quartetto Italiano opened this season's Concert Series of Hunter College in that school's auditorium Saturday night. The greatly gifted musicians of the quartet provided for the capacity audience interpretations as near perfection as one is likely to encounter in the world.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Four lighthearted balloonists out for a Sunday ride landed safely near here this afternoon after proving there is more than one way to beat the Sunday traffic.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Jordan picked her first Communist-tagged Deputy in yesterday's riot-torn parliamentary elections, which left eight persons dead and forty-four hurt.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Lard for October and November delivery has been strong the last few days, with active absorption by commission houses, which would indicate considerable short covering. LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Harold Macmillan, Britain's new Defense Minister, fought in France during World War I. He is 60 years old.

Columbia University's year-long campaign on behalf of "man's right to knowledge and the free use thereof" continues. Powered by the breakaway running of Pete Murphy and the line bucking of Bob McCauley, Chaminade downed Cardinal Hayes, 6-0, yesterday in a Catholic High School Football League game at Randalls Island.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. yesterday reported record net earnings of $4.74 a common share for the first nine months this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Interstate Commerce Commission officials said today the commission had decided to permit the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad to go ahead with a proposed 10 per cent increase in commutation fares between New York City and New Jersey points.

The administrative board of the International Association of Universities visited the Bronx campus of Fordham University yesterday. THE Supreme Court ruling that baseball is a sport and not a business received substantiation from an unexpected source over the week-end. The hijinks in Philadelphia demonstrated with convincing clarity that baseball conducts its affairs in the most unbusinesslike fashion imaginable. The City of Brotherly Love is now stuck with the Athletics for at least another year.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 389 pints of blood on Friday, including 103 pints taken at Abraham Straus, 420 Fulton Street, Brooklyn. CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- An opening slump in soybean futures was the trade reaction to favorable weather over most of the country. Corn futures also wilted in reflection of the improved weather. Soybean futures were off as much as 7 cents in the early trade.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 -- The motion-picture industry is "enjoying the fruits of a two-year investment in engineering and applied research," Herbert Barnett, president of the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers, said today in opening the society's seventy-sixth semi-annual conference at the Ambassador Hotel.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 (AP) -- John A. Hall, managing editor of The Jamestown Post-Journal, today was elected president of the New York State Associated Press Association. He succeeds Hugh W. Robertson, a vice president of The Westchester Newspapers, Inc.

The six-story loft building on lot 50 by 100 feet at 28-30 West Twenty-second Street has been purchased by Duo Equities, Inc., from Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Lorber. An investor bought the fifty-nine-family apartment house at 1821 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, from Morris Davis through Wishnow Horowitz, brokers. The property is assessed at $150,000 and was sold for cash over mortgages of $131,000. The buyer was represented by Jacob Pantell, lawyer.

Speaking before the annual convention of the American Bankers Association, Walter Williams, Under Secretary of Commerce, declared that "net personal income poured into family coffers this summer at a rate of $253 billions a year, the highest ever achieved."

Mrs. Carle C. Conway will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 1 Sutton Place South for members of the Women's Division of the Travelers Aid Society of New York, of which Mrs. Conway is chairman. WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Secretary of State Dulles discussed with President Eisenhower today plans for the conferences in Paris this week on the defense of Europe. The Secretary leaves for Paris tomorrow.

Hale, manager of the Bethlehem Cornwall Corporation, a subsidiary of the steel company, and W.C. Lenhardt, plant engineer at the company's Cornwall iron mines in nearby Lebanon County.

A book on the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., is planned for publication shortly by Bookman Associates. Written by Robert D. Leiter, a labor economist, "The Role of the Teamsters Union in the American Economy" deals with the impact of the union on "all aspects of American life" and discusses its leadership and internal relationships.

An underwriting syndicate consisting of Kuhn, Loeb Co., Blyth Co., Inc., Kidder, Peabody Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will place on the market today a new issue of $20,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent bonds of Texas Power and Light Company due in 1984.
Election of Hickman Price Jr. to the new post of vice president in charge of sales for Willys Motors, Inc. was announced yesterday by S.A. Girard, vice president and general manager.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush was on record today as warning Congress that the Administration's security risk program had demoralized the scientific community and had hindered the nation's weapons research programs.

Top industrial and government officials will discuss current problems in the transportation field at the ninth annual meeting of the American Society of Traffic and Transportation on Oct. 29 in Washington.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 18 -- Iraqi Premier Nuri al-Said hinted today that Turkey and Iraq would soon announce decisions to forge closer bilateral ties in the interest of strengthening Middle Eastern security.
DETROIT, Oct. 18 -- Two out of three of the nation's 3,300,000 miles of streets and highways were described today as inadequate.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Averell Harriman pledged today that he would start fighting unemployment in the state as soon as he was elected on Nov. 2.

The second 100 per cent stock dividend in three years was declared yesterday by directors of the Trane Company, La Crosse, Wis., producer of air conditioning, heating, ventilating and heat transfer equipment.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 18 -- The Government of President Carlos Ibanez del Campo entered a major struggle with a hostile Congress tonight.
MONTREAL, Oct. 18 -- This navigation season may wind up as the longest and strangest in St. Lawrence history, shipping officials predicted today.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- More than 8,600 dockers in Liverpool, Britain's second port, and at Birkenhead, across the Mersey River, quit work today in sympathy with the strike that has tied up the Port of London.
OTTAWA, Oct. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Trade Minister C.D. Howe said today that the United States curb is "not too serious."

Cocoa prices tumbled the daily limit of 1 cent a pound in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by lower quotations in London, easiness in the actuals market and heavy supplies of cocoa at all levels.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 18 -- Israeli and Egyptian Army representatives will meet in a desert rendezvous on Thursday to discuss the Bat-Galim affair.
Quick Lunch of the Wheatley Stable made a fine closing bid to take the Lloyd's Neck, the classified handicap that served as the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18 -- A major task of the nation's leaders, industrial as well as governmental, is to see that the impact of business fluctuations is minimized, Walter Williams, Under-Secretary of Commerce, told bankers, here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Next summer, in all probability, you will be able to take powdered tomato juice on that camping trip. Just add four cans of water to one can of the tomato juice powder, let it stand five minutes -- and there you are!

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The United States, Britain, France and Canada agreed today to accept two of the four amendments that the Soviet Union wants to make in a resolution calling for the revival of negotiations on disarmament and atomic control.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A Federal grand jury ran out of patience today and charged Clyde L. Powell, ousted Federal housing official, with criminal contempt of court for refusing to answer questions.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The last pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association season ended in a tie today at Wykagyl. Pat Circelli, Ridgeway professional, and M.R. Buchman, Fairview, deadlocked Doug Ford, Kiamesha Lake, and Hudson River's Charles Meaney with net best-balls of 65.
A deep-well cooker that could be used to bake, boil or fry was a new feature of the de luxe Crosley ranges shown yesterday at the St. Moritz Hotel.
DETROIT, Oct. 18 -- A guarded prediction that "we are again entering a phase of economic expansion" came today from President Eisenhower's chief economic adviser, Dr. Arthur F. Burns.
CAIRO, Oct. 18 -- Britain and Egypt successfully completed tonight negotiations for a treaty ending their long dispute over control of the Suez Canal zone.

The board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art reported yesterday that the parade of art viewers through the museum's remodeled galleries reached a record figure of 250,000 a month in the first six months of this year.
Mrs. Stefan Issarescu, the Princess Ileana of Rumania, will be the guest of honor at a luncheon to be given today by Baroness W. Langer von Langendorff at the Carlton House.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Treasury announced tonight that bids had been accepted for $1,500,256,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills. The average price was 99.745, equivalent to an annual discount rate of 1.009 per cent. This was the highest since Sept. 16, when the rate was 1.024 per cent.

General Stores Corporation filed yesterday in Federal Court hare a petition asking for an arrangement with its creditors. The petition, filed by the law firm of Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston Rosen, listed assets of $3,254,529 and liabilities of $1,849,894 and declared that the company was unable to pay its debts as they matured.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The net amount the United States may be called upon to contribute to the 1955 United Nations budget is likely to be about $1,000,000 more than the present contribution.

The heroine of all the city's Girl Scouts was decorated with the Bronze Cross, praised by officials of Scoutdom and songwriter Irving Berlin and courted by the Boy Scouts yesterday. She then outlined her immediate plans -- she will return to her home in Little Rock, Ark., to sell cookies.

A disconcerting little tangle has been discovered in the skein of the recently approved Cargo Preference Bill. The measure, now Public Law 664, makes mandatory the movement of at least half of all Government-financed cargo in privately owned United States vessels, if such tonnage is available at "fair and reasonable rates."

With the fall season already launched, an interesting new trend has appeared in fur designs -- the black and white color duet. An outgrowth of another trend this season, that of trimming fur with a contrasting fur, this new fashion lends itself particularly well to elegant wraps to wear after five.

The reshuffle in Sir Winston Churchill's Government comes pat. Parliament is opening a new session today that may be the last before the general election, which must take place by October, 1956. As it is not customary to see the five-year statutory term through to the end, the elections are expected for next October or, at the latest, the following spring.

Operations of the nation's steel industry this week are estimated at 73.6 per cent of rated capacity, the highest since the estimated 74.3 per cent for the week of Feb. 15, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

A new one-story industrial building at 133-20 Twenty-third Avenue, in Flushing, Queens, has been leased by Wrapture, Inc., manufacturer and printer of plastic closures, from the Porter Operating Company. The transaction was negotiated by the Greiner-Maltz Company as brober.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- President Eisenhower put a limit on imports of barley during the year ending next Sept. 30.
Seven small fires in less than five hours within a fourteen-block area in Brooklyn early yesterday led the authorities to suspect arson.

OTTAWA, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Because a Canadian journalist had refused to disclose his sources of information, the nation's Supreme Court upheld unanimously today a lower court's decision preventing him from making any defense in a libel suit. The case, involving fundamental conceptions of press freedom, is said to be without precedent in Canada.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 18 (AP) -- More demonstrations in various parts of Jordan were reported today in the wake of the country's bloody election week-end -- despite Government claims that "all is quiet."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- A proposal was made today that the United Nations appoint a mediator to deal with the Union of South Africa on the touchy question of the treatment of its Indian minority.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- New information about an underwater mountain range across the top of the world has been reported by a Soviet expedition. The group has been working for six months within the Arctic Circle and has established two observation posts on floating ice in the Arctic Ocean.

PITTSBURGH, Oct 18 (UP) -- A football fan was accused today of refusing to take off his hat when the National Anthem was played. He was held for grand-jury action on charges of desecration of the flag and resisting arrest.
LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Princess Margaret will fly to the Caribbean Jan. 31 for her month's tour of the British West Indies, an announcement from her residence, Clarence House, said tonight.

TORONTO, Oct. 18 -- Toronto and its northern outskirts today continued to count the toll of Hurricane Hazel, which stood at eighty-five persons dead, 1,500 families homeless and $100,000,000 property damage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Justice Department will ask the Interstate Commerce Commission tomorrow to ban all racial segregation in interstate travel.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The stock markets here remained firm today despite extension of the dock strike. The only noticeable effect of the stoppage was a slight fall in business and in the price of motor shares. The motor industry is hardest hit by the strike because more than half its exports are shipped from London.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 18 -- Deerfield Academy, unbeaten in football last season, seems to be on its way to another successful campaign. The Big Green defeated Vermont Academy and Hotchkiss in its two starts this year and today appeared to be packed with the enthusiasm which is such a necessary ingredient for a successful eleven.
The Government filed yesterday in Federal Court a $124,122 tax lien, including interest and penalties, against the National Committee to Secure Justice in the Rosenberg Case.

SINCE Jerry Herman is only 23 years of age, his midget revue, "I Feel Wonderful," is probably to his credit. He has written all the music and lyrics for a show composed almost exclusively of music and lyrics, and put on at the Theatre de Lys last evening.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Recent demonstrations against integration of Negro and white children in the public schools of Washington and Baltimore were attributed to adult "ruffians" and "agitators" today by pupils from those schools.
One hundred and thirty members of police plainclothes squads were sent back to patrol duty in uniform yesterday and will be replaced by uniformed men.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 -- The Palace Hotel was bought today by the Sheraton Corporation of America.

Ozan Marsh, California pianist who made his debut here in 1939, last night devoted his fourth New York recital to the music of Liszt. He played at Town Hall and the big works of the relatively brief program were "Funerailles," "Apres une lecture de Dante" and the B minor Sonata.

When representatives of the Western Powers meet in Paris beginning tomorrow to translate the Act of London into formal agreements to strengthen the Western defenses by including in them a rearmed Germany they will have before them another Soviet demonstration that they have no alternative except to proceed along the charted course.

NEWARK, Oct. 18 -- Representative Charles R. Howell hammered away today on the theme that workers, farmers and small business men in New Jersey were suffering from "an economic slump" because the Republicans had failed to bring forward an adequate anti-recession program.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., Oct. 1 -- In this the third city of the Soviet Union, which has a population of more than a million, there are only twenty Russian Orthodox churches open for worship.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 18 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas decreed today emergency taxes to raise 6,200,000 quetzals in revenue. The quetzal is on par with the dollar. The new taxes will be collected only once.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Production of milk in the United States next year will equal or exceed this year's record output, but the dairymen's income will be slightly less, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
"Sands of the Negev," by Yigal Mossensohn, the first Israeli play to be performed here in English, opens tonight at the President Theatre at 8 o'clock.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People strongly criticized yesterday the head of one of its branches for inviting Bryant W. Bowles to address a three-day state conference of the N.A.A.C.P.

Governor Dewey yesterday turned over to Park Commissioner Robert Moses a deed to twenty-four acres at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. Mr. Moses promised the city a new bathing beach by next summer within reach of the subway.
MADRID, Oct. 17 -- It was a beautiful cloudless day throughout Spain today, but the farmers did not enjoy it. Their fields and cattle were suffering from one of the worst droughts in this century.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday 6 to 16 points net lower than on last Friday, with the far months showing the most weakness.
The State Attorney General moved yesterday to thwart the reported revival of a method of fraudulent registration that he said had not been attempted in city elections in more than twenty years.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 18 -- The West German Government was confident tonight that the Saar question would be settled this week in Paris by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France.

GEORGETOWN, Del., Oct. 18 -- The ten Negro students who were dropped from the rolls of Milford High School on Sept. 30 were temporarily enrolled at the William C. Jason, all-Negro, High School here this morning.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Texas Democratic leaders today gave Gov. Allan Shivers an armful of new weapons to make Texas what he called a "pivotal factor" in national politics.

Management may indulge in wishful thinking when it comes to furnishing a projection on the economic outlook. But the men who handle the books, it is presumed, base their predictions on facts and figures. There should be more than moderate interest, therefore, in a survey taken at the current meeting of the American Institute of Accountants in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

September was the first month since June, 1953, that production of rayon and acetate filament yarn and staple in the United States topped output of the same month in the previous year, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 18 -- Representative Douglas R. Stringfellow, Republican of Utah, whose purported record as a World War II "cloak and dagger" hero was exposed last week as a fabrication of his imagination, withdrew today as a candidate for re-election.
Fair warning: A new product has only one chance in five of succeeding.
Oklahoma led the United Press board of coaches' college football ratings yesterday for the third straight week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Bishop J. Bromley Oxnam of the New York area of the Methodist Church repeated under oath today his statement that Harvey Matusow, a frequent witness in Congressional investigations of communism, has told him he "had borne false witness."

The City College Institute of Film Techniques announced yesterday the opening of its sixth annual City College Robert J. Flaherty film award competition for the "outstanding creative achievement in the production of factual films."

The fleet of eight long-range DC-7C's that the Scandinavian Airlines System (S.A.S.) is buying from the Douglas Aircraft Company of Santa Monica, Calif., will be delivered during the summer of 1956, it was announced yesterday by Tore H. Nilert, president of the airline.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The General Assembly's Social Committee voted today to establish an international fund to help 350,000 European refugees become self-supporting by 1959. The refugees are under United Nations care.

The Consolidated Railroads of Cuba reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a consolidated net loss of $2,825,195. This contrasts with a net loss of $2,505,382 in the preceding fiscal year.

A 15-cent increase in the quarterly dividend was voted yesterday by the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, which reported a rise in net earnings for nine months to $17,785,724 from $13,560,587 in the 1953 period.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 18 (UP) -- Laffango, ridden by Sam Boulmetis, sprinted to a two-and-a-half length victory today in the featured six-furlong race at Garden State Park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, who swore off political speech-making as a result of the uproar over his recent "bird-dog kennel-dog" remarks, changed his mind today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to determine whether Representative Ernest K. Bramblett of California was properly convicted of defrauding the Government by padding the payroll of his Congressional office.

If you feed a tarantula mealworm beetles and are otherwise kind to it, it will make a very good pet. The authority for this is the American Museum of Natural History where some tarantulas, black widow spiders and scorpions go on exhibition today.
Shares of common stock of the Campbell Soup Company will be offered for public sale within the next month for the first time, the company announced yesterday.
Holes big enough to drive several thousand trucks through were cut into the front of employer resistance yesterday on the first business day of the general trucking strike in the metropolitan area.

A career in radio and television means more to Joe Garagiola than catching for the world champion Giants. The 28-year-old backstop told that to the New Yorkers last September when he was acquired from the Chicago Cubs. He reiterated his stand yesterday, informing the Giants he had applied for voluntary retirement from baseball.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower welcomed William V.S. Tubman, Liberia's visiting President, at the White House today as the head of a nation in which Americans "have taken a very deep and abiding interest."
All those little chores we put off in the spring stare us in the face now that fall is actually here.

Because New York still stubbornly clings to the antiquated system of annual personal registration thousands of our citizens will lose their vote on Election Day because of failure to register. Yet the blame for the poor turnout at the registration polls cannot be laid merely to that overworked, glib phrase, "voter apathy."
The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission strongly criticized yesterday the decision of a commission examiner opposing a Negro woman's complaint of discrimination on a North Carolina bus.
AGRA, Greece, Oct. 17 -- A hydroelectric power station of 40,000-kilowatt capacity was formally inaugurated here in western Macedonia today.

The World Parliament of Religions has arranged a "birthday pilgrimage" to the jungle hospital of Dr. Albert Schweitzer in French Equatorial Africa. The famed author, philosopher, musician and missionary physician will be 80 years old Jan. 14.

The Amalgamated Laundry Workers' Health Center, which opened its doors yesterday, is not only a boon to the 18,000 workers whom it will serve, but a bench mark in labor union progress that deserves wide public recognition. Located in a large, modern two-story building at 222 East Thirty-fourth Street, the center provides the whole range of diagnostic and therapeutic services to the members of the union free of any charge.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 18 -- About 280,000 of the 13,000,000 voters in East Germany did not vote or otherwise register protest against the Communists in yesterday's election.
"Blue-chip" stocks represented in the market averages yesterday rebounded from the pressures of last week and made good gains -- but the market as a whole held about even.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- President Eisenhower tackled today a week's schedule crowded with travel, conferences and speeches. Talks set for New York Wednesday and Thursday nights have been expanded to full-dress size. They are billed as nonpolitical.

Merger of the Bank of Hicksville, L.I. into the Meadow Brook National Bank, also of Nassau County, is proposed by the managements of both institutions, it was announced yesterday by Henry G. Eisemann, president of the Hicksville bank, and by Augustus B. Weller, head of the Meadow Brook institution.

Fifty projection units for hotel closed-circuit television have been purchased by Theatre Network Television, Inc., from the General Precision Laboratory, Inc., Pleasantville, N.Y., a subsidiary of the General Precision Equipment Corporation.
Governor Dewey said last night that there was "an increasing degree of irresponsibility" in political campaigns and "an unlovely growth of the use of distortions and outright falsehood."

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for Governor, left unexpectedly tonight for New York. An aide announced that Mr. Ives would have a statement for release at 9 A.M. tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The first juror in the wife-slaying trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard was seated late today after the osteopath's lawyers had failed in efforts to delay the trial because of "detrimental" publicity.

Today the Museum of Modern Art begins the year-long celebration of its twenty-fifth birthday. In its quarter-century it has become a lively and integral part of New York city life. During the war the New York Defense Recreation Center listed it as the fourth tourist-serviceman attraction, topped only by the Statue of Liberty, the Empire State Building and Rockefeller Center.
