PARIS, Oct. 18 -- A kind of four-act diplomatic drama extending over about five days will begin in Paris tomorrow. Its main purpose will be to bring West Germany fully into the Western alliance by giving it approximately complete sovereignty and an armed force tied to the North Atlantic defense system.
VILLUPURAM, India, Oct. 18 -- Elected representatives from French India voted today for merger with India. The enclaves involved are Pondicherry, Karikal, Mahe and Yanam.
Paddy Young, Greenwich Village middleweight, gained a unanimous decision over Jesse Turner of St. Louis in the main event of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Furniture painted by well-known modern artists is on view in the salons of Leleu, top French interior decorator and cabinetmaker.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Martinique Hotel at Broadway and Thirty-second Street has been sold by the Hotel Martinique, Inc., of which Frank W. Kridel is president, to Martinique Associates, Inc., of which Robert Selby, Al Schwartz and Robert Sillins are directors.

New studies that greatly discount the importance of inheritance in the two most common forms of cancer in women were presented here yesterday. They were discussed at the annual meeting of the American Cancer Society in the Biltmore Hotel.

A move on the part of motion-picture exhibitors throughout the nation to meet the threat of pay-as-you-see television and "preserve free home television for the American people" has been inaugurated. The action was the result of a meeting last Friday in Chicago of leading film showmen representing, according to a spokesman for the group, 95 per cent of the organized exhibitors of the country."
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- A program for expansion and modernization of the Ford Motor Company's plant in Britain to cost 65,000,000 ($182,000,000) over the next five years was announced today.

Prof. George Y. Shevelov, a Ukrainian educator who fled the Soviet Union in 1944, has been appointed associate professor of Slavic philology at Columbia University, Edgar C. Miller, dean of the university's Graduate Faculties, announced yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Bill Terry, who earned a niche in baseball's Hall of Fame with the New York Giants, returned to the sport after a thirteen-year absence today as president of the South Atlantic League.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsement of six of nineteen incumbent Assemblymen seeking re-election in Brooklyn. The organization said its endorsement means that it "recommends the candidate with enthusiasm."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The State Department and the West German diplomatic mission announced today plans for an official visit to Washington by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer beginning Oct. 27.
Rayon took many guises at a luncheon fashion show in the Hotel Plaza yesterday.

New York City is planning to borrow $21,555,000 on Nov. 4 on an issue of bonds maturing serially in three annual installments on Nov. 1 of the years 1955, 1956 and 1957, City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday.
From 150 to 200 regional shopping centers will open in the next five years, the members of the board of directors of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers were told yesterday.

Mrs. Ada Holding Miller, president of the National Federation of Music Clubs, today announced a special Steinway Composition Award to be offered by the federation in connection with this week's observance of "Steinway Week," marking the 101st anniversary of the piano manufacturing company.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 13 -- Earnest-faced boys and girls, wielding clicking knitting needles, climbing about in play sculpture mazes or tossing steaming flap-jacks produce some of the intriguing sounds, sights and smells of the Child and Home Exhibit currently on view here.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Counsel for Governor Dewey today notified Harold T. Garrity, Democratic leader of Westchester, that there was "absolutely no basis" for Mr. Garrity's demand last week that District Attorney Samuel Faile be removed from office.
HONG KONG, Oct. 18 -- Prime Minister Nehru got rousing welcomes in Canton and Hankow today as he arrived by plane from North Vietnam to begin his state visit to Communist China.

A suit for damages against Budd Schulberg, the writer; Elia Kazan, the director, and the producers and distributors of the film "On the Waterfront" was filed here yesterday in Supreme Court on behalf of Monticello Film Corporation.

West Point cadets will parade on Baker Field at 1:10 o'clock Saturday and about the same time Annapolis midshipmen will pass in review on Franklin Field, Philadelphia. Then the Army caissons are expected to go rolling against Columbia and Navy to go sailing down the field against Penn in two of the week's top football attractions in the East.
The use and the misuse of drugs is the theme of an advertising campaign being scheduled by the Peoples Drug Stores, a chain that filled more than 2,700,000 prescriptions last year.

Women headed by Mrs. Henry Ittleson and including Mrs. A. Felix du Pont Jr. are aiding in furthering the success of the dinner to be held on Nov. 8 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the National Association for Mental Health.
Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday at Columbia University that "free access to science means also free access to national responsibility."

NOEL COWARD'S "Tonight at 8:30," presented in color on Monday evening over N.B.C. television, was far from a happy choice of vehicle for the television debut of Ginger Rogers. To her assignment the motion-picture star brought an earnest eagerness to please, but the subtlety, delicacy and perception of Mr. Coward's character vignettes seemed largely to escape her grasp.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Federal Trade Commission accused seventeen health, accident and hospitalization insurance companies today of "false and misleading" advertising.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of the main agreement signed today by Britain and Egypt regarding the Suez Canal base:

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 19 -- Vietminh forces are receiving no build-up of war materials from Communist China, M. J. Desai, Indian chairman of the International Armistice Control Commission for Vietnam, said here today.

Today's new film is "Beau Brummell," a romantic drama in color, starring Stewart Granger and Elizabeth Taylor, filmed in England by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, at Loew's State. Sam Zimbalist produced and Curtis Bernhardt directed.
PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The snag in the conversations between Dr. Konrad Adenauer and Pierre Mendes-France over the Saar today disappointed the West German delegation to the talks here.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 19 -- Royce Flippin, junior tailback in Princeton's single-wing formation, broke two bones in his right wrist in a scrimmage today and will be out of the line-up for several weeks.
KOBE, Japan, Oct. 19 (AP) -- West German track stars won fourteen of eighteen events against Japanese in international goodwill competition at Kobe and Matsuyama today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- While a Federal grand jury weighed an espionage complaint against Joseph Petersen Jr., the Netherlands Embassy formally stated today that he had been exchanging "secret intelligence" with its agents for years.
Club women in various parts of the country are waging war against crime and sex "comic" books by simple and direct methods, the president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs said yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Although Jean Desses refreshes his collection by only a dozen new models this midseason, these twelve show the way the fashion wind is blowing, that is, toward the general acceptance of a lowered waistline.
Hundreds of Staten Island bus passengers have been delayed by a slowdown in bus service during the evening rush hour the last two days and face what will probably be an even worse situation today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The United States, voicing doubt that the General Assembly was legally justified in adopting last week a two-thirds voting rule on the South-West Africa item on the agenda, provoked a procedural snarl in the Assembly's Trusteeship Committee.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The four-power conference between France and the three states of Indochina, which began here Aug. 26, has reached a deadlock as a result of a dispute between the Vietnamese and Cambodian delegations.
CHICAGO, Oct 19 -- When Chicagoans receive 2,500,000 traffic tickets a year, then they will become fully traffic conscious.

Six additional representatives of Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation yesterday were elected directors of the Marion Power Shovel Company, of Marion, Ohio, at the first meeting of the latter's board since Merritt-Chapman acquired a majority interest earlier this month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it has on file a non-management proxy statement in connection with the proposed sale of Follansbee Steel Corporation assets to Fred W. Richmond of New York.
Colette Marchand has been engaged as principal dancer in the newly formed Paul Szilard Ballet, which is to begin a tour of the Orient in Japan late in November.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Government engineers believe the Thames could be insulated against the disastrous flood effects of abnormal tidal surges by dropping a 2,000-foot controllable barrage gate across the lower reaches of the river.

Mary Martin is back! At 8 o' clock tonight, the star who gained renown for her performance in "South Pacific" will begin an engagement, announced for sixteen weeks only, in the title role of "Peter Pan" at the Winter Garden. Twice before she yearned to do the famous part, but something always intervened.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Except for the absence of Mike Zeigler at left halfback, Army's starting line-up for the game with Columbia at Baker Field in New York Saturday will be the same as for the highly successful invasion of Duke last week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- The discord between the heads of film studio music departments and the Screen Directors Guild of America over the use of the term "director" on picture credits is due for airing in Superior Court, Los Angeles.

Cheese manufactured in the Netherlands is to be heavily promoted in this area in the first such broad-scale advertising campaign in this market. Last year the New York metropolitan area consumed 80 per cent of the Holland cheese imported by this country, and the advertising therefore will be concentrated here.
YONKERS, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Rebel Land, driven by Bill Fleming, closed fast tonight to win the pace which headlined the Grand Circuit program at Yonkers Raceway.

There are several charges which may be leveled at the Republicans because of their recent "security risk" shenanigans. They have tried to held wink the people by lumping Communists, fellow travelers, and "security risks" in a single category. It is seems reasonable to suspect that they have used the term "security risk" cover cases which would ordinarily called "incompetent" or "undesirable."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it had asked Colonial Airlines to postpone its call for merger bids from Eastern and National Airlines.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 19 -- Premier Nuri al-Said of Iraq left Istanbul today after a ten-day visit that the Turkish Government hopes will be a milestone on the road to rapprochement with its Arab neighbors.

Varied divertissements have been planned for the fifth annual Fall Frolic, a dinner dance for the benefit of the Hemophilia Foundation. The fete will be held on Friday night in the main ballroom of the Pierre. Mrs. Andrew W. Shuman is chairman of the committee in charge of the arrangements for the event. Robert Lee Henry of Syosset, L.I., is president and co-founder of the organization.
ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Oct. 19 -- Adlai E. Stevenson attacked leaders of the Republican Administration in a speech tonight before 1,600 Democrats.
The strikes of truckmen here and dockers in England have had only a negligible effect on shipping, although both have helped to confuse the maritime picture here.
Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said last night that the Democratic Congressional campaign had been "a total blank" to date.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France was reliably reported tonight to have said he could not sign agreements for West Germany's entry into the North Atlantic Treaty or Brussels Treaty organizations this week unless there also was a satisfactory accord on the Saar.

The appointment of Bernard F. Gimbel and Charles S. Munson as co-chairmen of the 1955 Greater New York March of Dimes campaign was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. Laurence S. Kennedy was named general chairman of the drive last month.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The ending of the bus strike encouraged investors' hopes of an early settlement of the dock dispute. With yesterday's firmness on Wall Street and more good company statements, the stock markets were much more cheerful and active.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Following is a county-by-county breakdown of the registration totals:

State Supreme Court Justice D. Ormonde Ritchie denied yesterday a petition by Thomas A. Dent, Democratic candidate for Congress in the Fourth Queens District, that Robert N. Rose be ruled off the ballot as candidate of the Liberal party.

Mrs. Thomas J. Watson will give a tea tomorrow in her home at 4 East Seventy-fifth Street for members of the committee and their friends who are furthering the success of the performance of "Fragile Fox" on Oct. 28 at the Belasco Theatre for the benefit of the Institute of World Affairs.
The Democratic incumbent in the Sixth Congressional District in Queens is having a lively fight with a Republican candidate known for his strong vote-getting record.
The stock market extended its recovery yesterday, with rails notably strong. Some of the steels and aircrafts also made good gains but motors and oils were sluggish.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Raymond A. Hare of Manchester, Iowa, was named today by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, to be Director General of the Foreign Service.
GALLIPOLIS, Ohio, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Ohio River was cresting below flood stages at all downstream points today.

A total of 467 pints of blood was contributed on Monday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Included were 126 pints given at St. John's University's downtown division, 96 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, and 105 given by employes of Food Fair Stores, Inc., at the Flushing Young Men's Christian Association, 138-46 Northern Boulevard, Queens.
Senator Irving M. Ives charged last night that Averell Harriman, his Democratic opponent for Governor, had been linked to a "shocking" pier scandal first made known in 1930.
The Seventh Congressional District in Queens promises a close contest between a Democrat-Liberal running for re-election against a Republican newcomer.

This is a week of high drama on the European scene. The Saar, German sovereignty and rearmament, the expansion of the Brussels Treaty Organization, the revision of NATO's powers -- these subjects and more are to be crowded into a term of four or five days.

ALONE of all who bid for seats in the white man's government this fall, Paul Gorman Reilly takes political precept from the ancient utterances of Dekanawidah the Wise, who was companion, or walking shadow, to Hiawatha.
New issues of industrial and public utility common stock and convertible preferred stock valued at more than $5,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The new issues are as follows:
Sixteen awards in the annual Diamonds U.S.A. competition were presented at a luncheon in the Hotel Plaza yesterday.

The New York Society of Kentucky Women will hold their forty-sixth annual card party on the afternoon of Nov. 9 in the ballroom of the Pierre. Proceeds will be used to provide scholarships for Kentucky mountain children at the Hindman Settlement School.
Newark, N.J., borrowed nearly $10,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of bonds to finance various public improvements.

PEIPING, Oct. 19 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India stepped out of an Indian Air Force plane at Hsiyuan Airfield here today to begin what he is said to regard as the most important foreign mission of his life.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 19 (Reuters) -- The United States Far Eastern Command announced today it would pay its South Korean civilian employes in United States dollars and was immediately accused "by the South Korean Government of "blackmarket dealings."

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 20 -- The librarian of Lafayette College, Theodore E. Norton, who was identified last week before a Senate subcommittee as having been once a member of the Communist party, resigned his position at the college today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 19 -- The ten Negro pupils seeking readmission to Milford High School won another legal victory in Chancery Court here today. However, their re-enrollment now is impossible before next Monday and is likely to be deferred for weeks.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Metal fatigue, invisible and perhaps undetectable, caused the destruction in the upper air of a Comet I jet airliner off Elba last Jan. 10, an official investigation indicated today.

The card at Belmont Park yesterday was featured by the Tea-Maker Handicap, a classified sprint that was presented in two divisions. The results of both sections were pleasing to the traditionalists among the 18,209 fans on hand, for one winner was sent to the post by 80-year-old Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons and the other carried the colors of F. Ambrose Clark, the same patron of the thoroughbred sport who owned Tea-Maker.

An issue of $30,000,000 of stock of a new Canadian investment company -- Keystone Fund of Canada, Ltd. -- is to be offered to investors today by the Keystone Company of Boston, principal underwriter for the $261,454,800 family of established Keystone funds.
A jest about "sometime in life you've got to forget your principles and do what's right" marked the appearance of Averell Harriman and Irving M. Ives on the same platform last night.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 19 -- Utah Republicans today moved into one of the shortest House campaigns in memory in an effort to win the state's First Congressional District.
Ground breaking ceremonies for the contemplated theatre building of the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy will take place on Sunday at 4 P.M. in Stratford, Conn.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The United States declared today that the disarmament debate in the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly had shown that differences between the Soviet Union and the free world were "almost but not quite as great as ever."

As I weigh the qualifications of the two candidates for the office of New York State Attorney General I am appalled by the utter lack of experience, training and ability of the Democratic nominee. At the same time there is no question whatsoever of the competence and fitness for office of the Republican candidate.
CAIRO, Oct. 19 -- Britain and Egypt tonight concluded an agreement designed to restore control of the Suez Canal zone to Egypt and to preserve the military base there to defend the free world.

A two-lane, one-way viaduct from Franklin D. Roosevelt (East Side) Drive to the Willis Avenue Bridge over the Harlem River was opened yesterday. The new roadway, leading from the Drive's northbound lanes at about 122d Street and going under the Triborough Bridge, was tried out by an official motorcade after Mayor Wagner and Hulan E. Jack, Manhattan Borough President had cut a ribbon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Central Intelligence Agency won "a creditable job" rating today from a special study group acting directly for President Eisenhower.

As one whose bebumped he would discourage even the best phrenologists may I record my praise of the Fifth Avenue Association for crusading for higher awnings. Being one of the many in New York who are of a dreamy disposition, hardly pass a week without addition to my head.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday it would not endorse Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz for re-election to Kings County Court. Judge Leibowitz has the nominations of the Democratic, Republican and Liberal parties, and there is no contest.

A syndicate of sixty-four banking houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $75,000,000 of New York Telephone Company refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds due in 1989.
Trustees of Wagner College adopted yesterday a statement criticizing fraternities or sororities that exclude persons from membership because of race, religion or national origin.
DETROIT, Oct. 19 -- Teen-age drivers came in for good words today at the opening of the fifty-second annual meeting of the American Automobile Association.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Lefty James, Cornell coach, gave his football team some new plays today. The squad ran the new plays against the freshmen in scrimmage.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Sir Walter Monckton, Minister of Labor, reported to the House of Commons today on the strike of dockworkers in London and other ports. He said it was seriously hurting Britain's export trade, endangering food supplies and threatening to cause unemployment in other industries.

TEL AVIV., Israel, Oct. 19 -- Israel expressed concern tonight over "important accretion of strength which Egypt has obtained overnight" as a result of the British-Egyptian agreement for evacuation of the Suez Canal zone.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs fell far short of expectations today and. prices averaged about 25 cents higher. Salable arrivals at 7,000 head compared with an advance estimate of 13,000. Today's report of the livestock marketg here by the Department of Agriculture Iollows:

ALTHOUGH hunting has the spotlight there are a number of fishing items of interest, including the "photo finish" that enlivened the closing day of the annual Martha's Vineyard striped bass derby. On that day, a Massachusetts angler entered a bass that topped the previous entries by a little over a pound.
Plans for greater utilization of the planes it uses in trans-Atlantic operations were announced yesterday by K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines.

The Rohm Haas Company, manufacturer of a diversified line of chemicals, increased its earnings 83 per cent in the first nine months of 1954 and surpassed its profits for every full year in the company's history.

HONG KONG, Oct. 19 -- In a statement broadcast by the Peiping radio, Mr. Nehru said that old historic contacts between China and India were being revived at a time when these "great countries" were facing "similar problems."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a corporation that has established for its employes a stock purchase plan to which it contributed must bargain about the plan on request.

AMONG the widely known artists exhibiting this week is John Koch, whose recent paintings are at the Kraushaar Gallery. In portraits, still-lifes and interiors with figures Mr. Koch has attained popularity. His vein is sentimental realism, and within it he again proves that he is technically a very knowing painter.

Jimmy Foxx, one of the greatest stars of them all in his time, has been the moving spirit behind an organization to take top-ranking major league baseball players into every corner of the country to talk to boys' groups about baseball and the community. The object is to combat juvenile delinquency by giving the boys something better to think about.

NEWARK, Oct. 19 -- In a setting of brilliant ecclesiastical pageantry and ritual, the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart was formally opened here today. An assembly of 2,000, including seven archbishops, twenty-five bishops, two abbots and 500 priests of lesser rank, participated in the ceremony.

A candidate for State Supreme Court justice was found "not qualified" last night for the post by the Association of the Bar of New York City. "Professional qualifications were unduly subordinated to political considerations" by the party selecting him, the group asserted.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Pakistan and India clashed today over the appointment of the recently resigned chief of the Pakistani delegation to a top-level post in the United Nations Secretariat.
Following are the texts of Senator Irving M. Ives' television and radio speech last night and of Averell Harriman's reply:
Two officers of a Brooklyn electronics corporation pleaded not guilty yesterday to an information accusing them of selling used radio and television tubes as new.
Norma Webb, a Delta Air Lines hostess who has spent part of her salary and all her free time promoting international understanding, will leave New York for Europe today to see some old friends.

SUFFIELD, Conn., Oct. 19 -- Jim Williams, Suffield Academy's football coach, is not much of a moviegoer. This afternoon, however, as he briefed two assistants prior to a ninety-minute workout, he confessed he had become bleary-eyed from viewing motion pictures.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The Western powers will be able to move toward improved relations with the Soviet Union when the European unity now nearly completed has been achieved, Anthony Eden declared today.

The economic struggle against global communism must be made the paramount factor of United States foreign policy, Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, declared last night at a dinner given by the Citizens Conference on International Economic Union.

In your issue of Oct. 8, in an editorial on "Mr. Menon's Myopia" (V.K. Krishna Menon, Leader of the India Delegation to the U.N. General Assembly) you quoted him as condemning the Southeast Asia Defense Treaty as an "instrument of aggression."
Three famed Paris modistes arrived in New York this week on a mission of millinery diplomacy.

CANBERRA, Australia, Wednesday, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Labor members of Parliament continued Dr. Her. bert V. Evatt as party leader today by a vote of 52 to 28. The vote came after a heated five-i hour debate in which the organization's right wing sought to re-! move Dr. Evatt from his post.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- Seven Western Ambassadors withdrew last night from a dinner party in Moscow when they discovered that representatives of Governments not recognized by their countries had been invited.
The Metropolitan Opera yesterday announced the cast for "Andrea Chenier," which will be revived Tuesday evening, Nov. 16, as a benefit sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild.
Krishnamachari Balaraman, correspondent here for The Hindu of Madras, India, has been elected president of the Foreign Press Association for the 1954-1955 term.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The formal ending of seventy-two years of British rule, over the Suez Canal Zone was accepted here in a mood of resignation. Commentators acknowledged tonight that the agreement with Egypt was the best that could have been obtained in the circumstances.

Election of W.M. Kelley as president of the Reserve Mining Company was announced yesterday by C.M. White, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, which with the Armco Steel Corporation jointly owns Reserve Mining.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The trouble-plagued world basketball tournament, scheduled to begin Saturday with teams from twelve nations participating, will be played in the new Marcana gymnasium if the 35,000-seat arena is completed.

Debutantes of this season, headed by the Misses Marna R. Ashforth and Katherine T. Ogden, co-chairmen, and including Miss Barbara Look, are aiding in the plans for the tea dance and fashion show for the benefit of the Judson Health Center.

YIGAL MOSSENSOHN is regarded as the leading playwright in Israel. His "Sands of the Negev," which opened at the President last evening, ran for more than two years at the Habima Theatre. Presumably the Habima troupe acted it with authority and insight, and with a coordination of style and movement conspicuously lacking in the English-speaking version here.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Illinois Racing Board decided today to require fingerprinting of all persons licensed to participate in horse racing at Illinois tracks and their employes.

West Germany's horse show team of three riders and a non-riding captain arrived at New York International Airport, Idle-wild, Queens, yesterday for the events to be held in New York, Harrisburg, Pa., and Toronto.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- The number of voters eligible to participate in the Nov. 2 election will be 3.4 per cent lower than the comparable total in 1950, the last time a Governor was chosen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee today made public sworn testimony that Henry A. Wallace and Glen Taylor had headed the Progressive party ticket in 1948 "with full knowledge" the party was under Communist control.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Wally Thom retained his British and European welterweight championships tonight by knocking out Lou Lazar, but Dai Dower of Wales took the British flyweight crown away from Jake Tuli on a decision.

Twelve New York Stock Exchange specialists will undergo next Tuesday night a highly unusual test of their ability to keep their heads and be pleasant under all circumstances. Three hundred women will invade the trading floor at Broad and Wall Streets and conduct a simulated Exchange session for one shrill but educational hour.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- After two postponements because of an injured hand and a case of mumps, Kid Gavilan finally is ready to defend his world welterweight title against Johnny Saxton of New York tomorrow night at Convention Hall.

The autumn with its beautiful colors of foliage is the best season for hiking in the woods. Near New York there is no better place for walks and hikes than the Harriman Interstate Park, between Bear Mountain and the Suffern-Harriman Road, with hundreds of miles of marked hiking trails.
Former President Herbert Hoover said last night that "the daily losses the Government suffers disposing of property with one hand and acquiring the same thing with the other are beyond belief."
BREMERHAVEN, Germany, Oct. 19 (AP) -- ...German.manned naval craft ntered Dutch coastal waters today on the first international assignment giventhE potential West German Navy.

New York State's "three-knockdown" rule, which requires non-title bouts to be stopped if a boxer goes down three times in one round, will be reviewed at a meeting of the State Athletic Commission on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, today suggested Government policing of television programs or appointment of a "TV czar" to guard against anything that might tend to foster juvenile delinquency -- an idea promptly challenged by the television industry.

Leaders of forty-three fraternal, civic, labor and veterans' organizations and officials of the Crusade for Freedom attended a dinner last night at the Statler Hotel, prior to emplaning for Germany this morning to inspect the facilities of Radio Free Europe.

The Quiet Heet Manufacturing Corporation, Newark, N.J., has elected John D. Small as president, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Abrams, chairman of tile board. Mr. Small was chairman of the Munitions Board, United States Department of Defense, from 1950 to 1952.
WOONSOCKET, R.I., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Two Rhode Island newspaper editors have protested the nomination of Gov. Hugh Gregg of New Hampshire for a Freedoms Foundation award.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 19 (UP) -- Civil Aeronautics Administrator F. B. Lee said today additionnal funds should be appropriated to improve the nation's airport facilities in the interests of national defense.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Studies are being conducted here to promote mental health among United Nations staff members, particularly those from outside the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -A quiet campaign is being fought to right what its backers regard as a major wrong: The fact that the world's greatest participation sport, fishing, has no place in the Olympics.
NEWARK, Oct. 19 -- Representative Charles R. Howell charged today that the Republican leadership had violated the spirit of the Full Employment Act of 1946.

A debt of more than a sixty-six years' standing will be lifted from the backs of the Lehigh Valley Railroad's owners on Nov. 24. C.A. Major, president, in a letter to stockholders yesterday, notified them that on that day the company would redeem $2,489,000 of Pennsylvania and New York Canal and Railroad Company's 5 per cent bonds, due in 1969.
The plans the tobacco industry has made to finance scientific studies of the "possible cause-and-effect relationship between smoking and lung cancer" were made public here yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19 -Unemployment is "a matter of the greatest concern to everyone in this Administration," Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey said today. The Secretary, who spoke at the eightieth annual convention of the American Bankers Association, with nearly 7,000 banking executives in attendance, said:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- An eighteen-point legislative program, to be worked for on a nonpartisan basis, was approved today by delegates to the annual convention of the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers.
An elevator operator was arrested by New York detectives in San Francisco yesterday on charges of having killed a man here thirty-five years ago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- A moderate volume of mill buying spurred short covering and commission support in wheat today, and prices continued to advance. But hedge pressure sent corn lower and oats futures also declined.

An upsurge in automobile sales next year was forecast yesterday by E.C. Quinn, president of the Chrysler division of the Chrysler Corporation. He spoke at a preview of 1955 Chrysler cars at the Astor Sheraton Hotel. Three thousand dealers, salesmen and representatives attended.

Merger of the A.F.L. and C.I.O. has long been a dream of leaders in both groups who see greater strength in unity. But only last week has it become a practical -- even an early -- possibility. This welding of ten million and four million members into an integrated body has potentialities for American labor, and the public, that call for clear appraisal.

A New York Rangers hockey team that General Manager Frank Boucher considers improved by 20 per cent over last season will make its first Madison Square Garden appearance tonight. The opposition will be from the Boston Bruins, who share third place in the National Hockey League standing with the New Yorkers.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 19 -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo scored a major victory over left-wing opposition elements in Congress today. Two of his Ministers convinced Congressional leaders that his decree placing a greater part of the country under a state of siege should receive further study in committee.

The resignations of two top executives of the John W. McGrath Corporation, one of the nation's largest stevedoring companies, were announced yesterday by John W. McGrath, the president. Mr. McGrath said the resignation of his brother, Richard J. McGrath, and Paul J. Keeler, executive vice president and vice president, respectively, would be effective Nov. 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 --resident Eisenhower said today that the age of nuclear weapons made clear "there is no longer any alternative to peace" if the world was to be happy and well.

The Isthmian Steamship Company has leased an additional 300,000 square feet of Brooklyn waterfront and is proceeding with a construction program that will provide one of the largest and most modern terminals on the Atlantic Coast.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Eisenhower Administration urged today the abolition of all forms of racial segregation on railway trains operating in interstate commerce.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 19 -- Television research is making progress in developing electronic light, a new form that promises to bring about an even more far-reaching revolution in lighting than did the fluorescent tube.

A committee of women and one of artists could, if they would, make New York City a fit place in which to live, according to Philip Johnson. He spoke yesterday at the Women's City Club of New York, 277 Park Avenue.
Maurice Rentner's collection of fall fashions was shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Bonwit Teller.
Liquidation, hedge selling and stop-loss ordering forced cocoa down the 1-cent limit for the second day on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Ship safety spokesmen from the Gulf, the Great Lakes and the West Coast opened the three-day annual meeting here today of the Marine Section of the National Safety Council. The meeting, attended by 200 marine and Government officials, is being held in conjunction with the forty-second National Safety Congress and Exposition.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Bergen County has traditionally been known as the Gibraltar of New Jersey Republicanism.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, with prices of active months off 6 to 8 points (30 to 40 cents a bale).

THERE have been two dynasties in the history of the New York Rangers. The first one virtually came with the franchise more than a quarter of a century ago. It featured the Cook brothers and Frank Boucher and Ching Johnson and other fabled heroes who went on to Stanley Cup glory.
Eighteen American concerns and six Swiss organizations were charged yesterday with violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act and the Wilson Tariff Act in the jeweled watch trade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Fourteen Washington news correspondents were barred from the Liberian Embassy's reception to the President and Mrs. Eisenhower tonight after the White House had decided their presence would invade General Eisenhower's privacy, make him restive and prove embarrassing to him.

Richard M. Huber of Princeton, N.J., has been chosen for a Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust fellowship to complete a history of the idea of success in America. Mr. Huber, 32 years old, is a graduate of Princeton and taught there in 1946 under a Woodrow Wilson fellowship.
Adults will feel like taking candy from the baby -- or at least from a small child -- when they see the ingenious packages Tobler of Switzerland is introducing for the young set.
Outfielders Willie Mays of the New York Giants and Orestes (Minnie) Minoso of the Chicago White Sox, a pair of right-handed hitters, are the major league slugging kings for 1954.
The Manhattan Trio -- Ernest Ulmer, pianist; Oliver Culbentson, violinist, and David Wells, 'cellist, made its debut last evening at Town Hall.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Over Soviet protests, a United Nations committee voted today a fourteen-day postponement of consideration of two Soviet bloc charges aimed at the United States.
BUFFALO, Oct. 19 -- Even among Republicans, the prevailing opinion here is that the Democratic state ticket will make a stronger showing in Buffalo and Erie County this year than four years ago.

MIAMI, Oct. 19 -- Increased mobility of manpower and fire power will figure in some changes being made in the Army, but mental mobility, above all, will be a prerequisite for successful military operations, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway declared here today.

The General Cigar Company, Inc., Lancaster, Pa., which has profitably produced a five-cent cigar by means of a patented process, "homogenized tobacco leaf," is now offering the process for licensing to manufacturers here and abroad.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Germany's entry, Baal, was scratched today from Laurel's international horse race on Nov. 3 and his recent French conqueror, Norman, replaced him.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- The Eisenhower Administration is giving Soviet Russia twelve months to demonstrate the sincerity of its announced policy of seeking peaceful trade with the rest of the world, a Department of Commerce spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Navy confirmed today that Dr. Edward U. Condon had been cleared by the Eastern Industrial Security Board for access to classified information.
The spirit and most of the body went out of employer resistance to a union-imposed truck strike settlement yesterday.

Wave Hill, 120-year-old estate in Riverdale, the Bronx, where Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother of England, will stay during her visit to New York next week, is abuzz with preparations for the royal retinue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- National, state and local governments spent nearly $111,000,000,000 in the 1953 fiscal year, an increase of 9 per cent over the previous year, the Census Bureau reported today.

Your editorial and Arthur Krock's column of Oct. 7 maintain that temporary downward economic adjustments must be tolerated because over the long run our economy continues to grow. This is an interesting thesis, but it shows no concern for the millions of people who suffer during the short run.

A message from President Eisenhower describing the artist's freedom to create as "one of the pillars of liberty" opened ceremonies yesterday celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Museum of Modern Art.
NEWARK, Oct. 19 -- Clifford P. Case charged tonight that the Democrats said nothing and did nothing about unemployment in 1950, when more persons were out of work than at present.

ROME, Wednesday, Oct. 20 -- Premier Mario Scelba and his Government obtained their fourth vote of confidence in as many weeks when the Chamber of Deputies, shortly before 5 o'clock this morning, approved the Italian compromise with Yugoslavia on Trieste.
The 131st season of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences as a cultural and educational center will begin tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The academy is operated by the institute.

A seventeen-hour all-star television program in behalf of the annual campaign for United Cerebral Palsy will be presented over Channel 7 beginning Saturday at 10:30 P.M. More than 100 performers will participate in the program, which will continue until 3:30 o'clock Sunday afternoon.

In The New York Times yesterday it was inadvertently stated that The Newark Star-Ledger published last week a story "quoting sources close to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy," Republican of Wisconsin, as saying Miss Adelaide Case had been identified as a former member of Communist-front organizations.

Twelve hundred police will guard President Eisenhower during his two-day visit in this city, beginning with his scheduled arrival in the Presidential plane at La Guardia Airport, Queens, at 1:40 P.M. today.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Because the expenditure of a small fortune and two months' hard work has brought little success, Ian Douglas 'Campbell, eleventh Duke of Argyll, has suspended his hunt for treasure.

Choruses at the New York City Center Opera come in two sizes, jumbo and junior. The junior complement of sixteen youngsters was chosen from the city's public schools for acting and chorus roles in "Carmen," "Tosca" and "La Boheme."

Well, all the wood has now been split and stacked, so let the winter come. From a point near the kitchen door it stretches out to the base of a near-by tree, but a spot, it must be admitted, which lies considerably this side of infinity.

In a laudable effort to continue the disarmament discussions on the chance that Soviet Russia might yet join in banishing the specter of atomic war the Western Powers have now embarked on the road of concessions to Soviet demands to a point which seems to call for warning signs of dangers ahead.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 19 -- Indonesian authorities have detained three more Chinese anti-Communist leaders, raising the total of those under investigation to seven.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The American League's formal ap proval of the Philadelphia Athletics' new deal failed to materialize again today.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The extension of Harold Lahar's contract as football coach at Colgate University for five years, until June 30, 1960, was announced today by William A. Reid, director of the division of physical education and athletics, following the October meeting of the Colgate board of trustees.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- About twenty prominent Soviet officials, including three Deputy Premiers, were present Monday evening at the dinner from which seven Western ambassadors withdrew.
The building at 10 West Eighth Street, for decades the home of the Whitney Museum of American Art, will become next month the headquarters of the National Recreation Association.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Averell Harriman predicted tonight that a "desperate" Republican opposition could not defeat him with mud-slinging."

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Oct. 20 (UP) -- Dr. Henry T. Heald, Chancellor of New York University, today questioned the "rigid control" of the medical profession over medical school courses. He spoke at a convention of the Association of American Medical Colleges.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (UP) -- The head of the Philadelphia syndicate that staged a last-minute drive to keep the Athletics from moving to Kansas City tonight branded a threatened law suit against his group "unwarranted."

President Eisenhower turned over part of his radio and television time last night to a crooner -- Eddie Fisher. Mr. Fisher had come too late from a television show to sing "The Star Spangled Banner" at the American Jewish Tercentenary dinner at the Sheraton Astor Hotel, but he never got a better show business break.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Thursday, Oct. 21 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali was summoned home from Washington last night.
The aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 159,799 shares between Sept. 15 and Oct. 15, the Exchange reported yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20 -- With Royce Flippin out of action as a result of a fractured right wrist suffered in practice yesterday, it will be up to Dick Frye to carry the offensive load for Princeton in its game with Cornell at Palmer Stadium on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The former head of Washington's police narcotics squad and his principal assistant were acquitted today of charges that they took bribes to protect a narcotics peddler.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission took the position today it would be "dangerous" and undemocratic for the Government to censor television shows.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer to investors today a new issue of $18,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent bonds of Louisiana Power and Light Company due on Oct. 1, 1984.
YONKERS, Oct. 20 -- A field of eight will go to the post tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway in the fifth Gotham Trot of one mile and a half for a $29,375 purse.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, announced approval today of a Bureau of Reclamation Report on the Washoe project in Nevada and California. He forwarded it to interested state and Federal agencies for comment. If they approve, the report will be sent to the President and Congress.
BERLIN, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A tour of Soviet-run East Berlin by Senator Margaret Chase Smith ran afoul of Communist police today and four members of her party were held for an hour.

"SUCCESS often is the worst thing that can happen to a coach," said Joe Lapchick, puffing contemplatively on a cigarette. "He stops paying attention to the details and looks to the bigger and more attractive things like coordinating the machine he already has. A coach should always pause and take stock of himself.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Clifford P. Case asserted today that in the eyes of the Nation and the world the Nov. 2 election would be a plebiscite on President Eisenhower and his program.
A modern health center, where 18,000 laundry workers in the metropolitan area will receive free medical services, was officially opened yesterday at 222 East Thirty-fourth Street.

Two non-fiction magazines in "book form" will soon be made available. On Monday, Pocket Books will publish the first volume of a quarterly entitled "PB No. 1," edited by Franklin Watts. The magazine, in the Pocket Books format, presents "fresh ideas and information, sincere points of view and statements of opinion by authorities in their fields."

The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday it was seeking Atomic Energy Commission approval to withdraw from the atomic power development group that Dow organized in 1951 with the Detroit Edison Company.

Accommodations for 206 students will be provided in two four-story residence halls to be erected in Brooklyn by Pratt Institute. The general contract has been awarded the William L. Crow Construction Compaany. Work is to be started at once and the buildings are scheduled to be ready for occupancy in time for the fall term next year.

Directors of the New York Air Brake Company yesterday elected Charles T. Zaoral as president to succeed Bernard Peyton, who becomes chairman of the board, effective Nov. 1. Mr. Zaoral, vice president in charge of operations and a director for the last two years, joined the company in 1952.

Despite frequent criticism that the schools today do not teach the three R's as effectively as they used to, a recent test has shown that the typical high school senior reads faster and better than the average member of the local Board of Education of comparable I.Q.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, last night accused his Democratic-Liberal opponent, Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., of trying "to cover up his Congressional delinquency."
The city moved yesterday to persuade teen-agers that they should not amuse themselves by sending in false fire alarms.

A luxury look reinforced by hand-decorated details is very much a part of the decorating picture this fall. This fact was reaffirmed by a model apartment that will be opened to the public tomorrow and by two collections of contemporary furniture introduced here this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- United States reluctance to undertake bold new measures for the economic development of Latin-American countries has injected a note of gloom into preparations for the forthcoming inter-American Economic Conference.

For seventeen years the world has been privileged to hear and share in an instrument of musical perfection: the orchestra created by the National Broadcasting Company for Arturo Toscanini. Thus it came as a shock to the orchestra members and to the music-loving public when last spring the Maestro decided to bow to his 87 years and "retire," and N.B.C. decided to "disband" the orchestra.
RED BANK, N. J., Oct. 20 -- The twenty-fourth annual race meet of the Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association will be held Saturday at Woodland Farms, the estate here of Amory L. Haskell.

In his talk before the Economic Club in Detroit Dr. Arthur Burns, head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, recalled how greatly thinking had changed in recent years concerning the economic role of Government.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 705 pints of blood Tuesday. The Masonic Grand Lodge, 71 West Twenty-third Street, gave 249 pints. At the H.C. Bohack Company, 48-25 Metropolitan Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, 185 pints were donated. The 104th Field Artillery, New York National Guard, at its Jamaica armory, gave 133 pints.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs again were below expectations today and 2,000 below the advance estimate.

Peach-colored tweeds, brilliant or delicate in hue, were emphasized in a collection of Irish clothing shown yesterday at B. Altman. Fashions by Irish designers Sybil Connolly, Irene Gilbert and Neille Mulcahey were displayed for the benefit of the Central Remedial Clinic, an Irish charity for children who have had polio.

That municipal off-street parking is an effective way to relieve congestion in our nation's cities (and incidentally to remove a serious obstacle to their continued economic progress) should by now be completely removed from the realm of debate-especially after so many communities have found their way back to business health after just such a development.

An extra dividend of $1,62 1/2 cents a share along with the regular quarterly of 62 1/2 cents a share was declared yesterday by the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc. This brings the total dividends to $6.75 a share since the stock was split two-for-one in May.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 20 -- The leaders of the four parties in Chancellor Adenauer's governing coalition left for Paris tonight by train to consult the Chancellor on the trend of the Saar negotiations.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address here last night at the American Jewish Tercentenary dinner, as recorded by the New York Times:

Speedier and more aggressive, the New York Rangers made their first appearance of the National Hockey League season at Madison Square Garden a winning one last night. Following four games on the road, Coach Muzz Patrick's men never trailed en route to a 6-2 triumph over the Boston Bruins on home ice.
Members of the Florence Hoberman Philanthropic League of Brooklyn will give their annual luncheon and theatre party on Saturday for the benefit of children suffering from cerebral palsy.
Henry A. Wallace strongly denied last night he had any knowledge in 1948 of charges that the Progressive party he then headed was under Communist control.

Electronic computers, rapidly growing in popularity, are destined to become the most powerful management tool yet devised, it was predicted yesterday by representatives of their manufacturers and of companies using them.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- Today, on the tenth anniversary of the liberation of Belgrade, three leading Soviet newspapers recalled the event in articles and pictures notably friendly to Yugoslavia.

A Federal grand jury returned three indictments yesterday naming fifteen men and a women as members of a ring that handled $500,000 in stolen women's apparel. The sixteen were charged with receiving, or possessing or transporting the merchandise for sale in various parts of the country.
Theatre and evening coats were the sparkling highlights of the fashion show presented yesterday by Russek's at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 19 -- A United States plan to help combat communism in Asia by lending surplus grain to needy countries is likely to boomerang among the producing areas of this region, according to views widely held here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that a nine-company association, known as Rocky Mountain Nuclear Power Study Group, would explore the feasibility of atom power plants for the West.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Queen Elizabeth II today conferred a Knighthood of the Garter, Britain's first order of chivalry, on Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary and Sir Winston Churchill's probable successor as Prime Minister.
The truck strike ended last night. Industry leaders, their ranks riddled by defections, yielded to the strikers' take-it-or-leave-it demand for a "package" wage increase of 25 cents an hour.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Arnold Johnson, Chicago industrialist who wants to move the Philadelphia Athletics franchise to Kansas City, said tonight that he was considering a suit for "substantial" damages against the Philadelphia syndicate that bought the club.

"THE 20TH CENTURY CAPITALIST REVOLUTION,"* by Adolf A. Berle Jr., brings serene principles to bear on our queasy age of atomic damnation. This is a challenging study of the great corporations' power for good or evil in a free society. And of the dynamically evolving world that created and shaped them in ages beyond the wildest dreams of our ancestors in their green and pleasant lands. Mr. Berle begins with a parallel and a parable.
MONTREAL, Oct. 20 -- The first bids have been selected for construction work on the Canadian section of the St. Lawrence Seaway project and work will start immediately.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- A succession of witnesses testified today to the normality of the earlier stages of the last flight of the Comet airliner lost over Elba in January.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The stock market continued its buoyant trend today, and despite growing labor troubles on the docks, demand for industrials broadened, some of them reaching new price peaks.

Lovely Wave, the longest-priced member of the field in the $15,070 Dark Secret Handicap, carried the lightest weight over the mile-and-three-eighths turf course to register a neck victory at Belmont Park yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -- A projection system developed by the Radio Corporation of America for the showing on theatre screens of television pictures in color as well as in black and white was described last night to the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers meeting here.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 20 -- A cemetery for Soviet and Yugoslav soldiers who died in the liberation of Belgrade ten years ago was opened today. In it are buried 711 Russians and 1,381 Yugoslavs.
Colorado Springs, Colo., borrowed $10,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of utilities revenue bonds maturing serially on Nov. 1 from 1957 to 1982.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Capt. Hans Hansen a United Nations port expert, left for Yemen today to help the little country set up a modern seaport.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, is seeking authorization from the leaders of the four parties in his coalition for a compromise with the French on the Saar. He will meet these leaders tomorrow.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Most coffee prices rose the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit and cocoa quotations the 1-cent limit yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Volume was generally heavier with zinc registering the most sales since June 17 and rubber since Sept. 8.

Scholars and laymen joined last night at Riverside Church to pay tribute to John Dewey on the anniversary of the liberal philosopher's birth. The meeting, of which the John Dewey Society was the sponsor, was part of Columbia University's bicentennial celebration.
Representatives of 1,600 big and little manufacturers holding some 7,000 Air Force contracts were told here yesterday to spread the work by subcontracts to small business concerns.

Once upon a time there was an affliction which put people into a melancholy stupor so that they craved to dance all the time. (This was long before the mambo). It cropped up in the region of Taranto, Italy. And it is because of such insane behavior, brought on by these attacks of tarantism, it now appears, that the unaggressive, not-very-poisonous-to-man tarantula has such a bad name.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Leo A. Rover, United States Attorney, asserted today that lawyers for Owen Lattimore had no right to ask Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl to dismiss an affidavit of prejudice the prosecutor filed last week against the jurist in the Lattimore case.

Young resident members of the New York Southern Society, the Maryland Society and the Texas Club have arranged a cocktail dance for this afternoon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for the benefit of the relief fund of the New York Southern Society.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization will continue keeping a tight check on the machine tools it is holding in reserve for any war emergency, O.D.M. officials said today.
GENEVA, Oct. 20 - This country was seething with anger today at what it regarded as the latest United States move against the Swiss watch industry.

The four-story building containing fifty-three apartments at 8320 Bay Parkway in Brooklyn has been sold by the Herud Realty, Inc., to the Rockfield Realty Corporation. Lennard Sons were the brokers and Schultz Garber were attorneys for the seller.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Drawing out strongly at the finish despite his top weight of 133 pounds, Mrs. Add L. Rice's Pet Bully today captured the $24,050 Princeton Handicap at Garden State Park. The winner was a length and a half in front of Mrs. Jan Burke's Squared Away and J. W. Rodgers' Duc de Fer was third.
TRENTON, Oct. 20 -- Several witnesses testified at a public hearing here today that the Englewood Board of Education had segregated Negroes in revising its school district boundaries.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 20 -- Admiral Felix B. Stump, Commander in Chief in the Pacific, said today that United States Navy patrols had made contacts in the Pacific with the Communists' submarines, as well as other Red vessels.

The late Victorian period is the favorite style era for a woman who, over the last half century, has observed and reported every change in the field of fashion. She is Mrs. Edna Woolman Chase, whose book, "Always in Vogue," written in cooperation with her daughter, Ilka Chase, is published today.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 20 -- The Vietminh take-over of North Vietnam has followed the pattern of the early months of Chinese Communist rule in China. As the Chinese Reds did in 1949 and 1950, the Vietminh regime has established its control with discipline, orderliness and moderation.

A union shop that would greatly strengthen the port position of the independent International Longshoremen's Association was offered yesterday by dock employers. A union shop long has been the goal of workers on the turbulent New York waterfront.
VIENNA, Oct. 20 -- A New York family has disappeared from the Soviet sector of Vienna and apparently has gone East.
Republican chances are not bright in the Ninth Congressional District of Brooklyn, where the party is trying to unseat Representative Eugene J. Keogh, the Democratic-Liberal incumbent.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Democrats nationally are "hopelessly split" on the campaign issue of eliminating discrimination from employment, Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight.

Net income of American Airlines, Inc., for the nine months ended with September, totaling $5,465,777, was less than half the $10,987,017 earned in the corresponding period last year partly because of a twenty-four-day strike in August, according to the report issued yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The buying movement in wheat lacked steam during much of today's session, the market receding 1 cent or more from early tops as many local operators took profits on the long lines. Outside demand lagged in wheat, but in coarse grains there was a somewhat better demand.

Lavishly jeweled taffeta, gold lame, re-embroidered lace and misty brushed wool paisley were some of the rich fabrics used for holiday fashions by Gothe, shown at the Pierre Hotel yesterday by Jay Thorpe.

President Eisenhower declared last night that the "persistently aggressive design" of the Soviet Union and Communist China "shows no evidence of genuine change." The United States will "not be misled" by proposals aimed to delay free nations' defense efforts, he said.
The basic provisions of the Dixon-Yates contract as outlined in Anthony Leviero's article in The New York Times of Oct. 17 calls for a review of the issues.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 20 -- The United States Government will erect a three-level pavilion and a 25,000-square-foot open-air theatre on a 60,000-squarefoot site at Thailand's annual Constitution Fair, it was disclosed today. The fair will open on Dec. 8.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Government laid plans today to challenge Soviet boasts of inventive and productive skill at trade fairs throughout the world.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Enrico Cipolaro, one of Yale's crack linemen some ten years ago, was hoarse today as he talked about the prospects of the New York Military Academy football squad. He attributed the hoarseness to the amount of exhorting and cheering he had to do last Saturday as the Cadets beat Drexel Tech's freshmen, 25 -- 7.

Van Wyck Brooks made various comments in your columns Oct. 16 concerning what he described as Secretary Wilson's "notorious 'bird-dog' speech." He compared his own impression of Mr. Wilson's performance unfavorably with Clement Attlee's "un-Republican dealings with the peoples of Asia."

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 20 -- One of the liveliest off-year campaigns in this state's memory was nearing its climax this week with Minnesota Democrats claiming a pronounced late season swing in their direction.
More than 2,000 passengers on three Long Island Rail Road trains were delayed yesterday for periods of roughly half an hour each as the result of three mishaps.
CAIRO, Oct. 20 -- Egypt began today a two-day holiday to mark the signing Tuesday of the agreement with Britain calling for the return of the Suez Canal zone to Egyptian control within twenty months.

FAIR LAWN, N.J., Oct. 20 (UP) -- Gene Woodling, New York Yankees outfielder and manager of the Jimmy Foxx Youth Program, today named the first four teams of players who will tour the nation to help combat juvenile delinquency.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The Soviet Union rejected today the principal provision of a compromise on the atomic-energy item on the United Nations agenda.

"A Stone for Danny Fisher," a play by Leonard Kantor based on the novel of the same name by Harold Robbins, will have its local premiere this evening at the Downtown National Theatre, Second Avenue and Houston Street, at 8 o'clock.

"Hit-and-miss" planning of advertising will cause four out of five retailers to miss important traffic and volume in ten of the next twelve months, it was asserted yesterday by Edward H. Burgeson, director of the retail department, Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Eisenhower and most of his Cabinet, disturbed by reports of apathy among the voters, have started a last-minute campaign to get out the vote Nov. 2. Although there seems to be general agreement that the Democrats are running ahead at the present moment, both Republican and Democratic national headquarters here concede that all predictions can easily be upset by the party that wins the get-out-the-vote race in the remaining time.

Senator Irving M. Ives sought to drive home last night the thesis that Averell Harriman had demonstrated in private business his unfitness to handle the billion-dollar business of the State of New York.

Spokesmen for domestic producers of jeweled watches praised the Department of Justice yesterday for its anti-trust suit charging eighteen American concerns and six Swiss organizations with conspiring to restrict watch trade.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- How to strike "pay dirt" in the stock market by a careful reading of the business and financial pages of a newspaper commanded the respectful attention of 300 Dutchess County residents in suburban Arlington High School's auditorium tonight.
BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- New Englanders were told today that they have a greater incentive than any other section for the production of cheap electric power from nuclear fuels.

Was he really acting wisely when he endangered his political career by sponsoring and fighting for an anti-discrimination law? Or should he have played it safe by merely sponsoring anti-discrimination teas and touring selected areas with a barrelful of sympathetic shibboleths? Irving Ives will get his answer Nov. 2.
"The Detective," a Columbia comedy starring Alec Guinness and based on G.K. Chesterton's "Father Brown" stories, has been scheduled to have its American premiere at the Fine Arts Theatre on Nov. 1.

A drop last week of 622,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 150,928,000 barrels, compared with 151,550,000 a week earlier and 140,618,000 a year ago.

Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India, declared yesterday that the possibility that the United States might lose touch with the rest of the world was as great a danger as that of a Russian attack.

THE Brooklyn Museum will open to the public today an extraordinary exhibition entitled "Masterpieces of African Art." More than 200 examples of sculpture, ivory, gold work and textiles drawn from public and private collections in this country and Europe are included in the showing.

The Public Education Association's 1954 award was presented last night to Roy E. Larsen, chairman of the National Citizens Commission for the Public Schools, for "his distinguished service to public education throughout the country."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- Johnny Saxton of the Borough of Queens on Long Island gained the welterweight championship of the world tonight by defeating Kid Gavilan of Camaguey, Cuba. By a decision that was most surprising, Saxton ascended to the 147-pound throne on a unanimous vote.

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday declined to 9,117,000,000 kilowatt hours from 9,193,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Oct. 17, 1953, was 8,365,000,000.

Radio networks and stations will broadcast a speech by Queen Mother Elizabeth of England at the Columbia University Bicentennial Charter Day dinner next week, but up until yesterday no live television coverage had been scheduled.
John T. McManus, American Labor party candidate for Governor, charged last night that the Democratic and Republican parties were "planning a new world war" through the rearmament of Western Germany.

There is a pleasant sense of romance and a decided fitness in seeing Anthony Eden become a Knight Companion of the Most Noble Order of the Garter. Winston Churchill, his illustrious compeer in the same Order, was for so long the "Great Commoner" of our century that it took months to get used to calling him "Sir Winston."

"DER ROSENKAVALIER," which has been absent from the City Center repertory for a short time, returned last night. The production is termed a revival, but the sets, costumes and staging are much as they were.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 20 -- Republican leaders have high hopes that they will be able to carry the city of Rochester for their state ticket this fall and to pile up twice as big a lead in Monroe County as they did four years ago. Some Democrats privately share this view.

This immediate period is full of "history" -- the sort of events that historians like to fasten upon as milestones in the passage of the years. One such will surely be Oct. 20, 1954, when the Suez Canal Zone passed out of the control of Great Britain and into the hands of Egypt.

Jan Kajdukiewicz, a Polish interpreter at Panmunjom, Korea, who escaped from the Communists, said last night that everyone in Poland thought as he did and would escape from behind the Iron Curtain if they had the opportunity.
Traveling in incongruous fashion -- coupled fore and aft to freight cars -- the first car of 200 ordered for the New York City subway system arrived in Hoboken yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- A resolution urging the Episcopal Church to "witness against all forms of racial segregation and discrimination" was adopted today by the Twenty-fifth Synod of the Episcopal province of Washington.
Apple growers in four states were hit hard by Hurricane Hazel last Friday. Some 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 bushels were tumbled from trees in Virginia, West Virginia, Maryland and Pennsylvania.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 20 (UP) -- Gen. Thomas D. White, Air Force Vice Chief of Staff, said today that formidable modern weapons probably would make any future war "as short in time as it will be terrible in destruction."

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 20 (UP) -- City College of New York and Miami (Fla.) University were placed on probation for a year and two other schools were reprimanded by the executive council of the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for rules violations.

YOU will find thousands of upland gunners who will argue until their voices fail that the grouse is the most challenging game bird, but hardly two of these enthusiasts will agree on the qualities and characteristics most desired in a "good" grouse dog.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Only the United States and Canada have entered wholeheartedly into the spirit of the Reciprocal Trade Program, Dr. C. T. Murchison, spokesman for United States textile interests, told a Government organization known as the Committee on Reciprocity Information.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 13:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Navy, in searching for a cheap high-altitude target against which to test its guided missiles, has come up with a rocket-carried parachute named "pogo."
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- A sharp attack is now being made in the Soviet press on authorities who have failed to carry out the Communist party's program for universal education.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth boarded the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth at Southampton tonight. Soon after dawn tomorrow she will sail for New York to begin a month's tour of the United States and Canada. She will arrive in New York Tuesday evening.

A decorative motif simulating the garden terraces at the Royal Chateau in Versailles in the era when it was serving as a residence for the Kings of France, will form the background for this year's Versailles Ball on Oct. 28 in the Starlight Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 20 -- The United States is rushing 30,000 tons of wheat to Turkey to prevent critical bread shortages in Istanbul and other major cities.
TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- Japanese officials say Premier Shigeru Yoshida is prepared to ask the United States for a sharp increase in economic and military assistance.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Harold Wilson, who was President of the Board of Trade in the Labor Government, charged today that United States consular officials in Hong Kong had threatened action against British business men there who did not stop "trading of a particular kind."

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 20 -- President Eisenhower, hailed today in a Latin oration as the giver of "atoms for peace," replied in blunt English that there would not be much of a world left unless war was prevented in this atomic age.
ROME, Oct. 20 -- Italy's Communists were on the defensive today.
The Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsements of candidates for Supreme Court vacancies in the First, Second and Tenth Judicial Districts.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 20 -- Ten Puerto Rican Communist leaders were arrested here and in New York today in a swift Government move designed to "cripple" the Communist conspiracy in this island commonwealth.

PEIPING, Oct. 20 -- Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Chou En-lai of Communist China, the Prime Ministers of two countries containing more than two-fifths of the world's population, met tonight to promulgate a significant pan-Asian point of view.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A 100-year-old pecan tree on the lawn of George Washington's estate, Mount Vernon, was added today to the toll of Hurricane Hazel last Friday.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- France displayed one of her greatest talents tonight to members of the United States delegations attending the conferences here -- the art of cuisine.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 20 -- The Congressional elections this fall will be the closest off-year contests the nation has ever had, William F. Knowland, Senate Majority Leader, predicted today.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The North Atlantic Council is expected to establish Friday a new pattern for European defense with German participation.
Two mysterious viruses causing serious infections of the liver (hepatitis) have so far eluded all efforts to isolate them and their control is for that reason "extremely difficult."

One of Benjamin Franklin's most famous letters was auctioned yesterday for $2,650. In it the statesman said: "The French are an amiable people to live with. They love me and I love them. Yet, I do not feel myself at home, and I wish to die in my own country."

Today is the seventy-fifth anniversary of the invention of the electric light. In three quarters of a century Thomas A. Edison's incandescent lamp has become so much a part of the way of life that lack of it -- "a blackout" -- has become a symbol of war.

A city citation for engineering improvement in the Port of New York was awarded yesterday to George W. Rogers, head of the corporation bearing his name, one of the harbor's oldest and largest dock and engineering contractors. It was presented by Mayor Wagner in a ceremony on Pier A, in the office of Marine and Aviation Commissioner Vincent A. G. O'Connor, on the occasion of the eighty-fifth anniversary of the George W. Rogers Corporation.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 20 -- The texts of President Eisenhower's address at Trinity College, and of the college's citation of him for an honorary degree, follow:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- The National Association of Securities Dealers announced today it had dismissed its February, 1950, complaint against the Cleveland investment firm of Otis Co. and two of its principal officers, Cyrus S. Eaton and William R. Daley.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Archaeologists have unearthed what they believe to be part of the stock of a goldsmith who worked in a hill fort at Down-patrick, Northern Ireland, about 2,300 years ago.

STANTON, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Representative Charles R. Howell went barnstorming today, literally, seeking out voters at work on farms and in stables in his quest for support in semi-rural Hunterdon County.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- More than 200 ships of the Atlantic Fleet started today on a major exercise, designed to test the readiness of their crews for action in the event of war.

Two different methods for selecting judges in Greater New York have been advocated in recent letters to The Times. In the issue of Oct. 6 Richard S. Childs, vice chairman of the Citizens Union, proposed that judges nominated by the Mayor or Governor run for election against independent candidates.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- Twelve scientists, whose fields of study range from photography to steel, were honored tonight at the Annual Medal Day ceremonies of the Franklin Institute.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 20 -- Israeli and Jordanian Army representatives said today they wanted to see the tension along the demarcation lines reduced. Their desires were expressed at a meeting of the Mixed Armistice Commission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- An inside story of how the Government's security-loyalty program has been handled probably will not become available to the public until after the elections.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 20 (UP) -- A virtual boycott of Brazilian coffee by United States importers today brought from Brazil's President a threat of stringent restrictions on American imports.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The pedestrian came under fire today at the forty-second National Safety Council Congress.

The president of the American Cancer Society called yesterday for a drive to stamp out cancer quacks, who, he said, are "filling our cemeteries with tombstones as monuments to the inefficacy of their treatments."
