Speculative buying of men's suits would be a definitely unwise move on the part of retailers but excessive caution will result in lost sales next spring, according to Jerome I. Udell, chairman of the board of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., producer of Gramercy Park Clothes.

Gala, says the English dictionary, is a French word out of the Italian meaning festive attire. Larousse says it is a "grande fete" linked with something official. Paris is perhaps the greatest producer of galas, and there all the meanings are generally included.

NEWARK, Oct. 20 -- A decrease of almost 12 per cent in the registration in New Jersey for the November election was disclosed today by current official figures from the county clerks' offices in the state's twenty-one counties.
Prices of cotton futures dipped 2 to 8 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Since the Democrats are seeking in this campaign to exploit whatever discontent with the Eisenhower Administration there may be, they are probably more concerned over reports of mass apathy than are the Republicans, who hope these reports mean that discontent is confined to small, unconnected arias.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Eisenhower's Advisory Committee on a National Highway Program is expected to recommend the formation of a Federal road authority to carry out a $101,000,000,000 highway program for the next decade.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 -- Adoption by other states of compulsory drunken driver test laws, patterned on a New York statute, was unanimously opposed today at the annual meeting of the American Automobile Association here.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The British Cabinet discussed today emergency measures the Government would have to take to maintain essential services if the dock strike continued much longer. No decision was announced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast a near-record supply of livestock feed grain for the 1954-55 season today but said there would be "critically short" supplies in some areas.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The United States Embassy was attacked today on charges of using the British police on the Lattimore case and turning Scotland Yard into an auxiliary of the Republican National Committee.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Greater recognition of Hudson Valley needs was asked of Federal, state and local officials today at a luncheon of the Hudson River Conservation Society.
A former Democratic Representative who wants to return to Washington is pitted against a young Republican who has never sought public office in the Eighth Congressional District in Brooklyn.

Alvin Dark, the fellow who did so much to help the Giants win a pennant and a world series, and Roy Campanella, whose crippled left hand may have cost the Dodgers the flag, dominated the news on the local baseball front yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20 -- A nationwide advisory committee of corporation executives and bankers has been formed to assist Princeton University in analyzing problems concerning corporation support of Princeton as a privately endowed institution.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- R.A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer said tonight Britain hoped and believed that President Eisenhower's declared aim of more liberal trade policies would be carried into effect.

HAMILTON, Ont., Oct. 20 (Canadian Press) -- An admiralty court may be asked to determine whether a $40,000 square-nosed tug that was towed into Hamilton during last week's hurricane is the salvage prize of a tanker captain and his crew.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 20 (Reuters) -- A former Agrarian party premier, Dr. Urho Kekkonen, formed today a new coalition Government of Agrarians and Social Democrats to end a week-long Finnish Cabinet crisis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption averaged 33,278 bales for each working day in the September period. This compared with an average of 36,075 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 33,372 for the August period this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Joseph Sidney Petersen Jr. was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on two counts charging violation of the espionage statutes and one count charging illegal removal of secret government documents.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20 -- The reduction of nearly $14 billion in proposed Government expenditure programs since President Eisenhower took office is the largest cut of its kind in any such period of the nation's history, the director of the Bureau of the Budget told bankers here today.

Rail stocks continued their upsurge yesterday, pushing through to a new high for the year. Industrials followed, and the New York Stock Exchange market made its widest gain since the beginning of September and closed at the best level since Oct. 11.
A floating art gallery that sailed into New York about a week ago is open for public inspection on the Hudson River, off Seventy-ninth Street.
Joining in the latest round of coffee price cuts, two big chains yesterday reduced prices of their own private brands.

Reflecting a 15 per cent decline in sales, net income of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation for the first nine months this year fell to $63,145,879 from $78,897,595 earned in the corresponding period a year ago.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- E.B.N. (Bud) Mitchell, representing the Royal Corinthian Yacht Club, defeated Samuel G. Barton of the host American Y.C. in the first test of a four-out-of-seven Anglo-American international match-race series on Long Island Sound this afternoon.
IF Mary Martin is satisfied, so are the folks out front. The musical version of "Peter Pan," which opened at the Winter Garden last evening, is a vastly amusing show.
VIENNA, Oct. 20 -- An article by Premier Imre Nagy, published today, expressed trenchant criticism of "dictatorial leadership by one person" in Hungary during the previous five years.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Shipping safety leaders elected today John D. Rogers, vice president of the Esso Shipping Company, as general chairman of the marine section of the National Safety Council.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The United States, Britain, France and West Germany reached substantial agreement tonight on the documents to liquidate the occupation of West Germany and grant it sovereignty.

The Columbia football team, which was at full strength for the first time Tuesday, enjoyed the situation for only one day. Two of the Lions' starting players were forced out of practice action with injuries yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Post Office Department delivered to the public "today a new set of "humanized and simplified" postal regulations.

A culinary visit to eighty-four countries with brief "travelogues" and a few typical recipes from each land is provided in Miss Myra Waldo's "The Complete Round-the-World Cookbook," published today by Doubleday.

Delays in rush hour bus service on Staten Island were cut to less than ten minutes last night, a Transit Authority spokesman said, despite the refusal of fifty-four drivers to work "voluntary overtime" which became mandatory when an emergency was declared at 4 P.M.
Wind-borne radioactive matter would make all areas vulnerable to hydrogen bomb blasts in the event of an enemy attack, Val Peterson, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan canceled today plans for a visit to Canada and will fly home tomorrow.

With ground-breaking set for next Sunday for the new $8,000,000 Aquarium at Coney Island, the City Planning Commission approved yesterday a map officially laying out the park area around the new attraction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Zionists in this country, pressing for a reversal of United States policy toward the Middle East, have introduced the issue of Israeli-Arab hostility into the Congressional election campaign.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The Israeli point of view, as put forth by diplomatic sources here, is that diplomatic negotiations with Britain would be welcome to define the Israeli-British relationship following the British-Egyptian treaty on the Suez Canal base.

The Paris conference is rolling to a grand and impressive climax. Western European Union, with Germany and Italy joining Britain, France and the Benelux countries, has taken shape. The Allied occupation of Germany is to have a new status, while Germans achieve virtually complete sovereignty.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Pennsylvania's hopes of victory over Navy in their football game at Franklin Field Saturday rest in part on the shoulders of Gary Scott -- specifically his injured left shoulder.

The second of three men suspected of an unsuccessful attempt to hold up a Queens bank on Oct. 7 has been arrested in San Leandro, Calif., the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced here early today.

ROBERT CASADESUS, the French pianist and one of the foremost virtuosi of our period, celebrated the twentieth anniversary of his first appearance as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society at the concert given by that organization, last night in Carnegie Hall.

Despite substantially larger sales, net earnings of the American Cyanamid Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries declined to $19,697,317 in the first nine months of this year, from $22,628,469 in the 1953 period.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady yesterday, 1 point higher to 6 points lower than on Wednesday. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange continued moderate and fluctuations were narrow.

A historian last Night painted a dark picture of the depersonalized and specialized individual of the modern era. But he tempered his diagnosis by saying that "we are not living under a reign of terror, and it is a little earlier than we think."
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The rise in the stock markets quickened today with advances by Government funds and industrials. South African gold mining shares were a weak exception.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 21 -- A proposal for non-Government construction of a $250,000,000 dam by United States power concerns 200 miles inside the Canadian border on the Columbia River has been unveiled here.

The growing rapprochement between Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union apparently reached a new peak of warmth this week when the tenth anniversary of Belgrade's liberation was observed in both countries. The Yugoslavs paid tribute to Soviet soldiers who had died in that battle, while the Soviet press published friendly articles which hailed the "glorious Yugoslav Army" for its contributions during World War II.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A task group representing scrap dealers and steel makers met today at the Department of Commerce to discuss the increase in exports of iron and steel scrap.

It has frequently been pointed out that when the "war babies" now packing the classrooms of our elementary schools reach the level of higher education in the Nineteen Sixties our colleges and universities may be confronted with a teacher shortage even more serious than that faced in our public schools.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. charged last night that the killing of a proposed tax on harness racing tracks in 1946 was tied to the sale of track stock to three state Republican leaders in the same year.
Many parties will be given at the fifth annual Fall Frolic, a dinner dance, to be held tonight in the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Hemophilia Foundation, Inc.

ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- A new four-and-a-half-mile section of Route 17 between Chester and Goshen (heavy black line on map) will be open to traffic tomorrow without ceremonies. The section is part of a superhighway extending from New York City to the Catskills, which is scheduled for completion next summer.
One of the most affable -- and lopsided -- Congressional races in the state is drifting along in the Eleventh district, which sprawls across Brooklyn and Queens to the city line.

Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey asserted here yesterday that the Eisenhower Administration had transformed a "dangerously artificial" economy into a "healthy" one by the timely and flexible use of monetary policy.

The National Urban League charged yesterday that the Federal Housing Administration was violating the "broad principle of non-discrimination" by guaranteeing mortgage loans for housing that is not open to Negro occupancy.

An article in The New York Times of Oct. 16 reported that the United States High Commissioner, Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., refuted a Soviet accusation in the Allied Council that Austrian veterans' meetings were a camouflage for nazism. The report also stated that he proved that evidence submitted by the Russians was itself the work of a former Nazi.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- A steel falsework, or pre-construction frame, as high as a sixteen-story building was floated twelve miles down the choppy Hudson River today and set in place with arithmetic-class precision. The job was a step in building the $60,000,000 New York-Buffalo Thruway Bridge from South Nyack to Tarrytown.

SINCE John D. Rockefeller died, in the springtime of 1937 and for years before, John D. Rockefeller Jr has tried patiently to put down the tenacious legend that the old gentleman dieted through his autumn and winter years on crackers and milk exclusively.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 21 -- Three American fighters against polio will share this year's Nobel Prize for medicine and physiology.

Instead of letting these insulting political speeches befog our minds it is well to ask ourselves whether or not it is important to support President Eisenhower right through to the end of his term in office.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Two sisters died of suffocation in a fire in their home here today while their mother was out shopping. Two policemen and a fireman were treated for smoke inhalation.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Oct. 21 -- Mrs. Cuyler S. Patton of Scarsdale Golf Club retained the Betty Reid Bowl by winning the annual post-season tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Association at Shawnee Inn today. Carding a 44, 44 -- 88, the best score of the two-day event, Mrs. Patton totaled 183 for the thirty-six holes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- A set of standards for color photography in television has been established and will be made available early next year to the broadcast industry by the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The twenty-fifth synod of the Province of Washington of the Episcopal Church decided today a proposal to revise the Lord's Prayer was "too big to handle" and voted to send it to the church's liturgical commission.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 21 -- Egypt objected to examination of the Bat Galim incident by the Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission at an emergency meeting today. Another meeting was set for Saturday. Israelis called the Egyptian action "a filibuster."

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 20 -- Nothing has been so damaging to United States prestige in Burma or so much help to the Burmese Communists as the operations of Nationalist Chinese troops in the northern Burma border area, according to international opinion here.

Cocoa futures rose the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. It was the second day that the market showed substantial strength. Only 197 contracts were traded and more than 200 unsatisfied bids were reported at the close.

President Eisenhower rode yesterday with Senator Irving M. Ives and Governor Dewey through forty miles of New York City streets. In the tour he made public appearances with the Republican candidate for Governor at five state or Federally aided projects in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

Most of the passengers using the Long Island Rail Road yesterday to get out of the city during the home-bound rush hour period were delayed five to twenty-nine minutes. The cause was a stalled train, which blocked passage under the East River.

Christmas may be more than two months away by the calendar, but the tinsel and the toys are beginning to appear in many shops before Thanksgiving has had its chance to be celebrated.

Floyd Patterson of Brooklyn, the fourth ranking world light heavyweight, will make his Madison Square Garden debut as a professional tonight when he meets Joe Gannon of Washington in the scheduled eight-round feature bout.

"Tales of Hoffmann" had its second performance of the season at the City Center last evening, with Frances Yeend performing in the roles of Olympia, Giulietta and Antonia, a tour de force not attempted here, according to City Center spokesmen, since Vina Bovy performed it at the Metropolitan in 1937.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee said today party leaders, including state and Congressional officials, would cover twenty-six states in a drive for victory in the Nov. 2 elections.

Having called attention to its artistic motivations, the recently organized New Repertory Theatre is striving to reach its goal as quickly as possible. Reliable sources report that the first of three presentations is almost certain to be "Children of Darkness," a highly regarded literary drama of 1930.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Oct. 22 -- Gen. John E. Hull, United Nations commander, and C. Tyler Wood, economic coordinator, conferred yesterday with President Syngman Rhee and officials of his regime. They continued the conference today.

ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- The recent shift in Republican campaign tactics is being generally interpreted as the start of a drive to cut down the prospective stay-at-home vote in predominantly Republican districts on Election Day.

We speak with restraint when we say it was a great day for New York yesterday as cornerstone ceremonies officially made reality out of dreams in the case of the Coliseum at Columbus Circle. There were times -- long gaps of no progress and at others active opposition -- when it seemed that this one would never come true.

WRCA-TV, the renamed outlet hereabouts of the National Broadcasting Company, appears to have booked a winner at 7 o'clock Monday evenings in the new "Sherlock Holmes" film series starring Ronald Howard, son of the late Leslie Howard.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 21 -- The Majlis, or lower house of Parliament, ratified the international oil agreement today by 113 votes to five, with one abstention. Nine Deputies were absent.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Buying activity broadened in all Board of Trade pits today, with soybeans and wheat leading upturns.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) -- Mr. McLean also testified that the high rates charged by the Dixon-Yates subsidiary forced him to make toast one piece at a time.

The annual awards of the American Cancer Society were presented here last night at the annual dinner of the society at the Roosevelt Hotel. Seven hundred members from the society's sixty divisions throughout the nation attended.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Britain today told Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, it had been "highly improper" for him to circulate a letter from the Mayor of Nicosia, Cyprus, complaining of British rule.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The United Nations General Assembly refused again today to oust the delegation of Nationalist China._
HAROLD ROBBINS' novel, "A Stone for Danny Fisher," is now a harsh crime play by Leonard Kantor. It opened last evening at the Downtown National Theatre, Second Avenue at Houston Street.

YONKERS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Katie Key, the country's leading trotting mare, won the $29,375 Gotham Trot tonight after the pace-setting Faber Hanover had broken stride in the final yards of the mile-and-one-half event.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 21 -- Leaders of the country's medical profession gathered on the University of Minnesota campus today to assist in the dedication of the $12,000,000 Mayo Memorial.
An underwriting group headed by F.S. Moseley Co. will place on the market today 60,000 shares of $10 par common of the Package Machinery Company at $25 a share.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Establishment of a United Nations fund to help 350,000 destitute European refugees to become self-supporting, was approved, 44 to 5, today by the General Assembly.

GENEVA, Oct. 21 -- Foreign Minister Max Petitpierre summoned Miss Frances Willis, the American Ambassador, to his office today to inform her of the strong views of the Swiss Government about recent American actions damaging the watch industry.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Oct. 21 (UP) -- A leader of the Congregational Christian Church today criticized churches for condoning segregation and said that Christianity was the "most materialistic" of all faiths.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- In an effort to reflect the international flavor of the United Nations, dishes with exotic names often are included on the menus of the restaurants at headquarters here. The flavor, in culinary matters at least, turns out to be somewhat bland.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Oct. 21 (Reuters) -- More than a thousand Swedish longshoremen today packed a Swedish court and let loose a volley of boos at company officials who were suing them for allegedly breaking a wage agreement through an unofficial strike.
Thank you for your recent editorial explaining the wonderful work of the Inter-American Press Association.
Helen Clifford of William Fox has a happy way of turning out fashions that are just the right blend of elegance, high fashion and pretty flattery.

Representatives of four Hudson River towns yesterday told Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority, that church bells would toll for an hour on Sunday as a warning of destruction from a proposed Thruway spur.

MONTREAL, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs made two opening-period goals against the Montreal Canadiens stand up to register their first National Hockey League victory of the season, 3 -- 1, before 14,404 fans tonight. The Canadiens dropped to second place as a result.

Leading ladies of history have been fashion innovators in textiles since Louis XIV first cast a wandering eye, in the opinion of John Kent Tilton, director of the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles. The taste of a Du Barry or a Josephine often decided the patterns of draperies and upholstery materials in the home of their contemporaries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Federal Court of Appeals took under advisement today the appeal of the Communist Party from an order of the Subversive Activities Control Board requiring it to register as a Moscow-dominated organization.

Rush-hour bus service on Staten Island last night was "somewhat better" than on Wednesday night, a Transit Authority spokesman reported. However, a series of conferences failed to end the labor dispute over the transfer of twenty-nine drivers.
RICHMOND, Calif., Oct. 21 -- A Congressional battle in California's Sixth District is drawing national attention because of the inherent question it poses:

Policies on the use in advertising and packaging of the flags of various foreign governments differ sharply from one nation to another, the National Better Business Bureau reported yesterday. It said in issuing a supplement to its "Do's and Don'ts in Advertising Copy," however, that what action might be invoked against advertisers violating the rulings of other countries was not entirely clear.
The Southeast Asia Association, Inc., will give a program of "Dances of Southeast Asia" for the benefit of Indian Flood Relief at Carnegie Hall on the afternoon of Oct. 30.

WASHINGTON, Conn., Oct. 21 -- The key to the Gunnery School football team's future success lies in the line. That's how Coach Roderick Beebe Jr. analyzed his squad's prospects while sending the boys through a forty-five-minute drill today in preparation for the game with Berkshire here on Saturday.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Robert the Organization for European the organization for European Economic Cooperation, said today Europe's general economic situation was more satisfactory now than at any time in its history.
The volume of business loans from New York banks was virtually unchanged last week, advancing $2,000,000 net after repayments of $33,000,000 by sales finance companies.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet representative to the United Nations, today postponed his answer to a final compromise offer by the Western powers on the method of handling the disarmament question.

THE deer season opened yesterday in five northern counties in Maine, and apparently there was no shortage of local and visiting hopefuls on hand to celebrate the event, for 1,200 sportsmen turned out at the annual "hunt breakfast" at Old Town.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Fulfillment of President Eisenhower's pledge that the United States would give Egypt economic add military aid if she came to terms with Britain on the Suez Canal issue will begin next week.
PARIS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The text of a communique issued after today's nine-nation conference on putting West Germany into the Western defense system:

The C.I.T. Corporation announced yesterday a new finance plan for industrial equipment which it described as geared to the new and faster depreciation schedules provided in the tax law signed by President Eisenhower in August.
The new management of the New York Central Railroad hopes to end 1954 in the black for the year, according to its president and chief executive officer, Alfred E. Perlman.

A monkey demonstrated yesterday that a new arrival in New York can get around better than some old-timers. The nine-pound monkey, which arrived from India on Monday, led the police on a chase among fire escapes and building ledges on Vesey Street between Broadway and Church Street.

Multitudes of colored toys will decorate the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria this evening for the Toy Ball, a benefit for the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, and the Free Milk Fund for Babies.

There are two ways of looking at this season -- the season of darkness. One can say it is too bad that night comes so soon, for all the autumn garden work and other chores now have to be done on week-ends.

Box holders for the sixty-sixth National Horse Show were announced yesterday by Walter B. Devereux, new president of the National Horse Show Association. The show opens at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 2 and will continue through Nov. 9.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The International Association of Machinists, A.F.L., said today that 20,000 ground crewmen and mechanics on six major airlines might go on strike "at any time on or after Nov. 19."

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 21 (AP) -- South Carolina's sophomore quarterback, Mackie Prickett, today flashed the form that had humbled mighty Army a month ago and led South Carolina to a 13-8 victory over Clemson in the fifty-second State Fair football meeting of the ancient rivals.

May I, though only a very small item in the scheme of things (an English housewife), add my assurance that the majority of people here are far from anti-American. Those that are have probably never met an American. As someone said recently, "a sure cure for anti-Americanism is to meet Americans."

Cabbage -- the most popular vegetable in this country next to potatoes -- has many relatives that are allied to it both by strain and savor. In other words, not all that grows in the cabbage patch is cabbage.

HIDALGO, Tex., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The secretary general of the Communist party in Puerto Rico, who vanished last June and allegedly went "underground," was arrested today by three agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as he crossed a bridge into this border town from Mexico.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 21 -- Business has gathered sufficient momentum so far this fall to assure a prosperous 1955, in the opinion of financial and industrial leaders here for the fall meeting of the National Business Advisory Council.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 21 (UP) -- A 61-year-old New Yorker, who sailed a raft 6,000 miles alone across the Pacific in 115 days, told today how he almost lost his life when he tumbled overboard in a bare-handed grapple with a man-sized shark.

With one trowelful of cement each, Robert Moses, Mayor Wagner and half a dozen other public officials and business leaders set the cornerstone yesterday for the New York Coliseum, the $35,000,000 expo sition and convention hall being built at Columbus Circle.

To the relief of Coach Jim Lee Howell, Charley Conerly was back in action yesterday as the New York Football Giants practiced in preparation for Sunday's game with the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds. The ace quarterback of the Giants had missed Wednesday's drill because of an attack of influenza.

An extra dividend of $1 and the regular quarterly dividend of 62 1/2 cents a share were declared yesterday on the common stock of the Gillette Company, whose nine months earnings exceeded any prior full year in its history.

FIFTY years of ceaseless and fertile artistic productivity have led the sculptor Archipenko to the present large retrospective of his work at Associated American Artists. This is no less than his 110th exhibition, his latest appearance in the country where, in 1913, he made his debut.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Robert Casadesus soloist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Faust," City Center, 8:15; Ingrida and Karina Gutberg, duopianists, Town Hall, 8:30; New Art Wind Quintet, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

DETROIT, Oct. 21 (UP) -- Red Kelly scored three goals tonight, the first Detroit defenseman ever to achieve the "hat trick," and lifted the Red Wings into the National Hockey League lead with their 5-to-3 victory over the Boston Bruins.

One of radio's oldest programs is leaving the air. "Let's Pretend," a children's show that has been running for twenty-four years, will have its final broadcast tomorrow from 2 to 2:30 P.M. over the C.B.S. network.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 21 -- The United States has granted Iran $12,000,000 more according to the newspaper Kayhan, which quoted a "high finance ministry official."

As President Eisenhower emphasized in his Trinity College address on Wednesday, war no longer involves just the two alternatives of victory or defeat. It threatens, as a third grim possibility, universal destruction for the victor and the vanquished alike.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, said tonight that "if Tammany could lay its hands on the State Treasury for four years, it would put the state in debt generations.

President Eisenhower announced last night that his health reinsurance program -- shelved by the House of Representatives last July -- would be resubmitted to the next Congress as "the logical alternative to socialized medicine."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- An Arkansas banker today termed the Arkansas Power and Light Company a "most corrupt and ruthless" arm of the controversial Dixon-Yates public utility group.
The House of Rest, founded eighty-five years ago in Manhattan as a tuberculosis sanatorium and merged in 1930 with the Sprain Ridge Hospital, Yonkers, will close Oct. 30.
Net income and operating revenues of Florida Power and Light Company increased in the twelve months ended Sept. 30, the utility reported yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 21 -- The Democratic party in Hudson County is free from internal strife this year for the first time since 1949. It was in that year that John V. Kenny replaced the late Frank Hague Eggers as Mayor of this city and began his assault on the once powerful political machine of Mr. Eggers' uncle, Frank Hague.
DETROIT, Oct. 21 -- An eight-hour wrangle over organization policy on Federal fuel and oil taxes developed today at the closing session of the convention here of the American Automobile Association.
President Eisenhower affirmed for the third time yesterday his support of Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey.

Gerald Durrell, English zoologist, animal collector for British oos and author of "The Overloaded Ark," has a new book on biking's list for publication next Thursday. Called "The Bafut beagles," it is an account of another of Mr. Durrell's expeditions into Africa -- in the realm of the ton of Bafut.

President Eisenhower has given the "most authoritative and responsible answer possible to t Zionist opposition to arms assistance for Arab countries, according to Henry A. Loeb, treasurer of the American Council for Judaism.

Teamster union leaders, taking a sober second look at their victory in the truck strike here, considered yesterday the advisability of procedural changes to protect local haulers against a union-inspired economic squeeze.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 21 -- Caleb Mills, the "father" of free schools in Indiana, was honored today at the 100th anniversary convention of the Indiana State Teachers Association, which drew 16,000 here. More than 1,800 Hoosier high school teachers and pupils took part in a pageant that paid tribute to leaders in the association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration announced today that eleven employes of its headquarters staff had been suspended under charges of "improper activities."

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Improved distribution, development of new markets and vigorous selling can solve many farm surplus problems, Raymond C. Firestone, executive vice president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, asserted today.

Directors of Foremost Dairies, Inc. have ratified the contract to purchase the outstanding common stock of American Dairies, Inc., of Kansas City, Mo., Paul E. Reinhold, Foremost board chairman, announced following a board meeting yesterday.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that its finance committee, aided by a group of financial advisers, had decided not to recommend at this time any specific plan for selling any of the stock the foundation holds in the Ford Motor Company.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery urged today that the Western powers should maintain their ability to start a "tremendous nuclear bombardment" of the East the moment they were attacked.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Dave Beck declared today that he was kowtowing to nobody in his mastery of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L.
MANASQUAN, N.J., Oct. 21 (AP) -- All Manasquan schools were ordered closed tomorrow after a second Manasquan High School football player became ill with polio.

KIEV, U.S.S.R., Oct. 1 -- One of the most ancient and attractive cities of the Soviet Union is getting a new look.

TOKYO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Germany's ace track athletes coasted to easy victories over Japanese teams in meets at Hiroshima and Takamatsu tonight.

More money was received from more persons by the Salvation Army in New York last year than in any other year in its seventy-four-year history here, Commissioner Norman S. Marshall announced yesterday.

Recognition of Red China is the issue that most sharply divides the Republican and the Democratic-Liberal candidates for the House of Representatives in Brooklyn's Tenth Congressional District, Abraham Sher, the Republican, favors de facto recognition.

CAIRO, Oct. 21 -- A new effort to unseat the anti-Government leadership of the ultranationalist Moslem Brotherhood, which has declared uncompromising opposition to the Suez Canal Zone agreement with Britain, is under way here.

MADRID, Oct. 21 -- United States contractors were invited today to participate in construction of about 600 miles of a pipeline system designed to service the air bases and port facilities the United States is building in Spain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The [Hoover] Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Federal Government made it clear today it had no connection with Lieut Gen. James H. Doolittle's recent investigation of the Central Intelligence Agency and said it was going ahead with its own "top-to-bottom" inquiry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended with last Saturday totaled 721,402 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
CARE, which has delivered $165,000,000 worth of rehabilitation packages to needy persons throughout the world, celebrated its ninth anniversary yesterday at a luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Two-thirds of Britain's overseas trade has been brought to a standstill by the dock strike, but there was no hope today of a quick settlement.

The British woolen industry is making a concerted effort to maintain its advantage in the American market over fabrics imported from other countries. The National Wool Textile Expor tCorporation of Great Britain, a privately operated association of woolen mills in the United Kingdom, has started a promotional campaign here to popularize British woolens.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 -- A hearing began today on a petition for an election to determine whether a single union should represent all unlicensed seagoing personnel of West Coast ships.
This might be a good week to consider serving loin pork chops, sliced bacon, picnic shoulder or round steak.

The membership of the Young Republican Club of Columbia University yesterday repudiated a previous stand by its policymaking executive committee and gave its full support to the candidacy of Jacob K. Javits for New York Attorney General.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 21 -- Influential political forces gave their support today to Governor General Ghulam Mohammad who rescinded an order disqualifying four key figures from participating in government affairs for three to six years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby said today the American people were "more interested in health, education and welfare than in any other phase of Government operation."

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Jack L. McNight's 6-year-old Gay Count came from off the pace in today's Delaware Township Handicap at Garden State Park to win the mile-and-a-quarter run before 15,808 fans.

The annual Boys Club Ball for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza attracted a large gathering of members of society, as well as persons prominent in business and civic life.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman made a sharp attack yesterday on the Republican National Administration because of its alleged failure to revise the immigration laws.

The Queens County Grand Jury handed up a presentment yesterday in which it asked that the State Legislature amend the Penal Code so as to make it a felony if a false alarm of fire results in serious injury or death.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported tonight by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The White House finds it 'regrettable" that J. Bracken Lee, Republican Governor of Utah, has refused to issue a proclamation of United Nations Day Sunday.

Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, entered New York State politics yesterday to report that he had investigated bribery charges against Averell Harriman three years ago and had found them "entirely unsubstantiated."
The text of the address by President Eisenhower at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A memorandum on the detection and prevention of employe misconduct, secretly distributed to Federal agency heads four months ago, was made public today by the Budget Bureau.
Smith, Barney Co. and associates offered yesterday $2,700,000 of water system supply revenue bonds of Holland, Mich., at yields ranging from 1.4 to 2.9 per cent.
The International Longshoremen's Association has "revised" certain of its contract proposal and will resubmit them to waterfront employers today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 21 -- The Indonesian Government handed to the Netherlands today a note in which it categorically rejected a Dutch accusation that Indonesian authorities had maltreated thirteen Dutch nationals detained earlier this year on a charge of endangering state security.
The following bulletin, published recently, may be of interest to parents:

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP). Prices of butchers hogs averaged about steady today, while sows sold steady to mostly 25 cents lower. For the third straight session arrivals did not measure up to the advance estimate, totaling 500 fewer than expected.

The political season is upon us and for the next few weeks will predominate on news outlets. Stress has been laid on the part that our President is to play on behalf of the Republican candidates for both houses of Congress.

The newly crowned welterweight champion of the world, Johnny Saxton, who scored a narrow victory on Wednesday night against Kid Gavilan in Philadelphia, "squeaked" through with another one yesterday in Manhattan Traffic Court.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $417,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 21 -- Two court hearings bearing on the Milford school segregation case will be held in Dover tomorrow.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 -- The Ohio Senatorial race looks like a photo finish.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 21 -- Osvaldo Koch, Justice Minister, declared today that Chile was the new focal point of Communist penetration in Latin America.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 21 -- France relinquished today the 140-year-old rule over her Indian possessions. She signed an agreement with India transferring the four settlements of Pondicherry, Karikal, Mahe and Yanam to the New Delhi Government.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Vitriolic words from states south of here were flung today at the Washington and Baltimore high school pupils who have been learning how 1,200 white children work and play with 400 Negroes at New Rochelle High School.

In 1846 the Rev. William A. Muhlenberg decided that something must be done for "the sick poor." He set aside half a Sunday morning collection of $30 to build the great hospital that is now St. Luke's. If he were alive, he would note with amazement how the institution has developed since the cornerstone of its first building was laid a century ago.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The American Yacht Club of Rye took a 2-1 lead over England's Royal Corinthian Yacht Club in their match-race series when Sam Barton led E.B.N. (Bud) Mitchell in both of today's contests.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democrat, charged tonight that Clifford P. Case, his Republican opponent for the United States Senatorship from New Jersey, had a voting record as a member of Congress replete with "curious inconsistencies."
ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Oct. 21 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon denounced today what he called "a vicious whispering campaign" against President Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.

May I extend congratulations to New York City for its remarkable system of beautiful parks and public gardens. Certainly your residents are proud of such achievements. The farsightedness of those who had the vision to secure lands for Central Park and to develop it deserves great credit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A large cocoon in which a downed aviator can ensconce himself and be picked up by a moving airplane was patented this week by two officers of the All American Engineering Company, Wilmington, Del.

YONKERS, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Philip Scott, a 6-year-old bay, won the Pacoy Memorial free-for-all pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight, scoring by one and one-quarter lengths over Torrid in 2:02 2/5. Chuck Vole finished third.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd, retired, 67-year-old polar explorer, said today that defense officials were planning another and larger expedition to Antarctica after a reconnaissance trip by the icebreaker Atka.

The Ann-Ess Realty Corporation has sold the thirty-nine-family apartment house at 910 Dinsmore Avenue in Far Rockaway, Queens, to the N.S.N. Realty Corporation. The property occupies a plot 123 by 234 feet and is assessed at $120,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (AP) -- After a week of closed-door meetings and public announcements the question of the final sale of the Philadelphia Athletics continued unsettled today as a battery of lawyers worked on the intricate business details.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 22 -- Adlai E. Stevenson charged tonight that Vice President Richard M. Nixon had "repudiated" President Eisenhower on the issues in the 1954 Congressional campaign. The 1952 Democratic Presidential candidate declared:
BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The Council of Ministers met today to approve an executive decree restricting imports to save dollar reserves in the light of dropping coffee prices.

William C. Seabrook, publicity director of the Holland-America Line, received in the mail about a month ago a beautifully carved piece of what he took to be ivory. It came from Dr. G.A. Catalani, a former sea-going physician who maintains contact with the company from his present abode in Surabaja, Indonesia.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 23 -- Leaders of the United Jewish Appeal heard a special report here today that underscored the urgent need of 460,000 Jews in several areas of the world, particularly in Tunisia and Morocco. These needs, the report said, had reached "emergency proportions."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today invited commercial banks to provide $1,150,000,000 of farm price support funds until next Aug. 1.

Events today: "The Love for Three Oranges," City Center, 2:30 P.M.; Katherine Bacon, pianist, Town Hall, 2:30; Ehlin Burton, pianist, Mason Hamlin Salon, 3 East Forty-third Street, 3; "La Traviata," City Center, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Grant Johannesen, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

Two five-and-a-half-story apartment buildings on plot of 150 by 150 and 100 by 100 feet at 73 to 83 Vermilyea Avenue and 611 to 619 Academy Street, in the Dyckman section of upper Manhattan, have been sold by Walter L. Rothschild to an investing client of M. Wertheimer.
A handful of pivotal issues made good gains in Wall Street yesterday, but the market as a whole followed an irregular course.
TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Japanese plans for a fisheries agreement with the Soviet Union appeared today to have exploded.

An extra dividend of 75 cents and the regular quarterly of 75 cents were declared yesterday by the Texas Company which attained the highest earnings in its history for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

In what has been rightly called a "landmark" case the National Labor Relations Board has decided that the terms of employe stock-purchase plans to which employers contribute are matters akin to "wages" and "conditions of employment" on which a union can compel collective bargaining under the Taft-Hartley Law.

MONTREAL, Oct. 22 (AP) -- William S. Kirkpatrick, vice president of the Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company of Canada, Ltd., says that "for some time our firm has been exploring the possibility of establishing a chemical and fertilizer plant in the Pacific Northwest States."

A majority of the motion picture theatre owners along Forty-second Street west of Broadway will keep their marquee and lobby displays within the bounds of good taste, but without any kind of censorship, voluntary or otherwise.

The staff of the Neurological Institute, a unit of the Presbyterian Hospital at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, paid tribute yesterday to Dr. Edwin Garvin Zabriskie on the occasion of his eightieth birthday.
The Thirteenth Congressional District in Brooklyn is so solidly Democratic that its representative is walking, not running, for re-election.

Colorful ceremonies in the City Council Chamber at City Hall yesterday marked the ninth birthday of the United Nations. Officials spoke, prizes were awarded and groups of school children appeared in the traditional costumes of many nationalities.

All coffee futures except the near - by December position tumbled the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The drop followed three days of substantial strength. The near-by month ended 75 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower. The volume was 93,250 bags.

Chrysanthemums that adorned lawns and gardens as late as Thursday sat in milk bottles and more artistic containers yesterday in the Museum Building of the New York Botanical Garden. The flowers formed the tenth annual show of regional chapters of the National Chrysanthemum Society arranged in cooperation with the garden in Bronx Park.
Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican candidate for Governor, asserted yesterday that he thought "the labor leaders are very stupid in the attitude they are taking toward me."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) The Navy ordered its older officers to sign a new loyalty oath today. They must swear they are not guilty of subversive conduct and do not belong to any subversive organization.

The Fordham University cross-country team defeated Yale, 26 -- 29, at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday. Val Simmons of Fordham finished first, covering the five-mile course in 26:54. Eric Seiff, the Yale captain, was second, 100 yards behind.

Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan has cut short his visit here because of the political crisis which has arisen during his absence from Karachi. The immediate cause of this crisis was the action of Pakistan's Governor General, Ghulam Mohammed, in lifting an order forbidding four of the Prime Minister's political foes from holding public office, a move whose potentialities include even the fall of Mohammed Ali's Administration.

Sgt. Henry Wittenberg, who won the light-heavyweight wrestling championship in the 1948 Olympic Games, submitted his resignation from the Police Department yesterday. He requested that it become effective immediately.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points lower to 1 point higher yesterday with a fair volume of business.
ROME, Oct. 22 -- A crackdown on communism is being planned by the Government and will probably be discussed by the Cabinet at its first meeting next week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- For the fifth consecutive year, net public and private debt in the United States increased to a new high in 1953.
Hundreds of private cars continued to augment bus service in the rush hour last night at the St. George terminal of the Staten Island ferry as bus drivers again refused to work overtime.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 6 per cent above that of the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 8.2 per cent and orders 0.1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, said tonight that he was acting on a request for information from Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, when he disclosed yesterday that he had found Averell Harriman "entirely innocent of wrong-doing" three years ago after investigating bribery charges against him.
One of the finest football teams in the land will come to town today with its cheering section of 2,400 leather-lunged voices.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 22 -- The New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers called today on the State Legislature to ban the publication and distribution of so-called comic books, pictures, films and similar media carrying indecent, obscene and crime material.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 22 (Reuters) -- A 32-year-old Australian housewife admitted today that while she poured tea for United States Senators visiting Dr. Herbert Evatt, Australian Labor party leader, during World War II she listened to their conversations and reported them to the Communist party.

The Air Force said yesterday that Secretary Harold E. Talbott planned to confer soon with Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey on state opposition to opening Newark Airport to flights of military jet planes.
HONG KONG, Oct. 22 -- The head of China Engineers, Ltd., here, confirmed today that this British company had been blacklisted and its dollar assets in the United States frozen.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct 22 -- Dr. Rudolph N. Schullinger, attending surgeon at Presbyterian Hospital in New York, was elected a charter trustee of Princeton University at the board's meeting today.

MIAMI, Oct. 22 (AP) -- An angry Miami football team, its bowl hopes blasted by a National Collegiate Athletic Association decree, virtually killed the post-season ambitions of another team, Maryland, by slashing to a 9-7 victory over the favored Terps before 50,000 fans tonight.
The American Cancer Society proposed yesterday a conference of Federal and voluntary public health agencies on the health problems in smoking.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "The Runaway Bus," a British-made comedy with Frankie Howard, Margaret Rutherford and Petula Clark heading the cast, is at the Trans-Lux Normandie. The import, written, directed and produced by Val Guest, is being released here by Kramer and Hyams, Inc.

While public attention at the moment centers on the efforts of the nation's elementary schools to accommodate the tidal wave of new students, university administrators quietly seek ways and means to provide for the flow when it reaches them a decade hence.
Colleges, foundations, insurance companies and investment trusts together own 14 per cent or more of the common shares of thirty-three of the largest American corporations.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Nina Ricci's lace cocktail suits and frocks, with bodices transparent at the back right down to the waistline, are pretty and bewitching. Such designs, included in her new collection, are enhanced by the element of surprise -- as when the wearer of a strictly tailored black lace suit turns around to reveal the lace design etched against her back.
In a recent speech Vice President Nixon said, "We're kicking Communists, fellow-travelers and security risks out of the Government. Not by the hundreds, but by the thousands."

Whether or not the anti-poliomyelitis vaccine of Dr. Jonas Salk can immunize the country's children will be decided when the experts have evaluated the results of the past summer's large-scale inoculations. The vaccine holds out so much hope that the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will acquire 25,000,000 cubic centimeters of it at the cost of $9,000,000.
BUTTE, Mont., Oct. 22 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon charged here tonight that the Communist party was determined to infiltrate the Democratic party.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- The North Atlantic Council put together today the design for bringing to life the new Western European Union and adding the strength of a sovereign West Germany to the North Atlantic alliance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent to 109.4 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The figure is based on the 1947-49 average as 100. A 1.5 per cent decline for farm products accounted for the major part of the decrease as the processed foods index fell only slightly and the index for all other commodities remained unchanged.
Every business man his own management consultant!
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- In the State Department and the Pentagon there was no effort tonight to minimize the seriousness of the Korean payments deadlock.

France has many pages of glory in her history, but India was not one of them, and it is best for all concerned that this chapter should be closed. On Thursday in New Delhi a French representative signed an agreement transferring France's four settlements of Pondicherry, Karikal, Mahe and Yanam to India.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Twenty-two Polish seamen who repudiated communism after their ships had been seized by Chinese Nationalists in Formosa will receive sanctuary in the United States.
RIDGEFIELD, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Clifford P. Case asserted today there could be no effective civil rights legislation with the Democratic party in control of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today approved the United States delegation to the ninth annual session of the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs opening at Geneva next Thursday.

The Secretary General of the Organization of American States, Dr. Carlos Davila of Chile, called yesterday for wider recognition of Latin America's importance to the United States and an increase in the exchange of' inter-American news.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 22 (UP) -- A jury was seated tentatively today to hear the case of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, accused of his wife's murder.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- George Washington and William and Mary played to a 13-13 tie in a Southern Conference game tonight before 12,000 at Griffith Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The scheduled airlines asked President Eisenhower's Cabinet Committee on Transportation today to make a study of railroad problems.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- West Germany and Japan signed a new one-year trade agreement today calling for $102,000,000 in trade and liberalizing Japanese exports to Germany. A West German mission has been here several weeks negotiating the agreement.
Arthur Holden in a letter to you published Oct. 19 urges support of Proposition 2 on Election Day on the grounds that the public housing program "* * * should not be interrupted * * *."
An art collector and critic said yesterday that modern art had been "more generously and sensitively supported" in the United States than anywhere else in the world.
The International Longshoreman's Association continued pressure on waterfront employers yesterday to gain control of hiring bosses on New York's docks.
The "Battle of Brooklyn" will be fought this year in the Twelfth Congressional District.
RYE, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- When 5-year-old Brien O'Shea stopped to watch some workmen fell a tree here yesterday, one of them feared he would be hurt and told him to "go home."
Two parent-child "fun" books, published recently, may be of interest to both mothers and fathers:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The nation's railroads suffered a sharp cut in income during the first eight months of 1954, much of it resulting from competition that is "subsidized" by the Government, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 22 -- The Moslem League convention scheduled to be held Oct. 31 to Nov. 3, was tonight put off because of the "very strained political atmosphere," the Executive Committee of the league announced. The convention will probably meet in January.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission's technical staff proposed today that the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, refund $38,893,225 plus 6 per cent interest to forty-eight natural gas utilities in six Midwest states.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The Labor Department reported today that the number of persons drawing unemployment benefits had dropped to the lowest level since last December. There was an upsurge in the auto industry, particularly in Michigan, which reported a drop of 21,000 in insured unemployment.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold raised the possibility today that tourists visiting the United Nations ultimately might be footing part of the educational bill of a number of students from all parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- After listening calmly to a scathing attack upon his impartiality, Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl reserved judgment today on pleas that he disqualify himself from presiding at the perjury trial of Owen Lattimore.

HONG KONG, Oct. 22 -- A Chinese Communist news agency charged tonight that United States naval vessels "protected" Chinese Nationalist warships on several occasions while the latter bombarded the southeast China coast with more than 1,200 shells from Sept. 3 to 30.

New securities totaling more than $500,000,000 will be sold in the public market next week. Offerings of corporate securities will be slightly larger than the scheduled sale of tax-exempt municipal and state issues.
A long-standing business quarrel between brothers-in-law, partners in a chain of women's specialty shops, ended yesterday in murder and suicide.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, predicted last night that his party would carry New York on Election Day by 800,000 to 900,000 votes. And the Republican majority coming down to the Bronx line will be "the smallest since 1934," he declared at his Biltmore Hotel headquarters.

ALBANY, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, said today that, if elected, he would "do my best" to destroy what he described as gangsterism and corruption in New York City.
PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Finance Minister Edgar Faure told the National Assembly's Finance Committee today that France was planning to make a sharp reduction in the military budget for 1955.
Many top executives of Canadian Corporations expect their country's economy to remain good for some years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today reported record stocks of corn and wheat and near-record supplies of other foods and livestock feed grains in storage Oct. 1.

Lawrence R. Troiano's King Commander won the $16,325 Temple Gwathmey, the steeplechase handicap that marked the final day of the two-day meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at Belmont Park yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The first serious break in the solid strike of 44,000 dock workers was made tonight. A delegate meeting of permanent dockers employed by the Port of London Authority decided to recommend that all the 2,000 Port of London Authority men should resume work on Monday.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson today criticized those who "rattle the atomic bomb" in an attempt to scare citizens of this and other nations.

The Erie Railroad reported yesterday that its net income for the first nine months amounted to $4,407,123, equal to $1.18 a common share before capital and sinking funds. This compared with $9,367,876, or $3.21 a share, for the similar period last year.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 22 -- Unemployment in the country fell below the 3,000,000 mark this month for the first time this year, James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, told members of the Business Advisory Council here today.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Eight years of Republican sidetracking of adequate taxes on harness race tracks deprived the state of $25,000,000 for schools, Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. asserted today.
VIENNA, Oct. 22 -- The Hungarian economy is to be reorganized to make Hungary what she was before -- a country whose basic export was food.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Three members of the syndicate that wants to buy the Athletics said tonight they would fly to Chicago tomorrow for the purpose of getting approval of the deal from the American League president, Will Harridge.

The Public Schools Athletic League contest between New Dorp and Lafayette at Madison Field, Brooklyn, and the Ivy Prep League game pairing Riverdale and Poly Prep on the latter's Brooklyn gridiron share the spotlight on the local school football program today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The State Department indicated today in a letter to Representative Isidore Dollinger, Democrat of Manhattan, that Israel might get more United States military aid.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 22 -- Adhemar de Barros, wealthy industrialist and former incumbent, has been defeated by anio Quadros in the election for Governor of the State of Sao Paulo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Treasury officials in charge of foreign assets here said today that funds of China Engineers, Ltd., and of W.C. Gomersall, its principal stockholder, would remain blocked until they were satisfied he was not a resident of Communist China.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Seventy-five young United States businessmen, came to the United Nations today to hear four Ambassadors make investment sales talks.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The pace of the market advance slackened here today, although prices remained firm. Profit-taking made movements more irregular, despite the renewal of heavy buying.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Princeton University's $375,000 student center, the product of a year's renovation of two well-known campus landmarks, will be formally dedicated at a short ceremony tomorrow.
Governor Dewey accused Averell Harriman last night of participating in the Nineteen Twenties in a securities transaction in which the Governor said American investors lost more than $5,000,000.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Oct. 22. (UP) -- Some 4,420 atomic production workers at plants here and at Paducah, Ky., voted overwhelmingly tonight to reject a pay increase, freeing them to strike Oct. 30.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 22 -- Life in China for Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian Prime Minister, has not been all shark fins and Peiping duck, according to reports from Indian correspondents; nor have his exchanges with Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier, been confined to toasts of ancient friendships over goblets of orange juice.

The thirteen-story store and office property known as the Kinney Buiding at 790 Broad Street, corner of Market Street, in Newark, N.J., has been purchased for investment by David Green. The buyer plans to add four floors to the present structure.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

A new work by Karl Stern, author of "The Pillar of Fire," for which he received a Christopher Award, will be published Thursday by Harcourt, Brace. The new book, titled "The Third Revolution," deals with the controversy between psychiatry and religion.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Model changeover shutdowns in the auto industry are nearing an end, with prospects that car and truck output will soon be in high volume. Commenting on this today, Wards's Automotive Reports said a new high week's production for 1954 probably will be set by mid-November.
PARIS, Saturday, Oct. 23 -- West Germany's entry into the North Atlantic alliance was approved yesterday by the fourteen foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Council.

BUFFALO, Oct. 22 -- Averell Harriman, in an angry and emotional mood, characterized today as a "smear" and a "contemptible lie" a Republican charge that he was going to cut state aid for education in several upstate communities.
The voter in Manhattan this year will be confronted with a number of judicial candidates to select from, ranging from the Court of Appeals down to the Municipal Court.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Wheat alone was strong on the Board of Trade today. Corn reacted from the late bulge of yesterday, while soybeans were under almost continuous pressure. With the exception of the May delivery, oats were inclined to drag, and rye lacked aggressive buying.

The New Art Wind Quintet gave the first of three Friday evening concerts last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. It was an enjoyable occasion. We don't hear the rich sounds of a wind quintet often enough these days, and we are apt to forget that much fine and original music has been written for the combination.

Cakes served with sauces were a favorite with grandmother, especially in the fall when appetites were primed for hearty desserts. Today's cook will like these sauced cakes for the same reasons her predecessors in the kitchen did.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 22 -- Gen. John E. Hull, United Nations commander, today termed his efforts to reach an understanding with South Korea on the currency exchange rate a "complete failure." He announced that he would defy Korean regulations by using United States greenbacks to pay Korean employes of the United Nations forces.

Eleven-year-old James Estabrook flicked a switch in his home in the Bronx one morning recently and heard the voice of Miss Helen D. Campbell, a teacher at Public School 90, speaking in her classroom a mile and a half away.
The United States Gypsum Company, producer of building materials, achieved new highs in sales and earnings for the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The Central Bank announced today it would allot dollar exchange for purchases in the United States or Canada of one-half of Argentina's newsprint requirements, which are 50,000 to 60,000 tolls a year.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 22 (UP) -- E.J. (Dutch) Harrison of Ladue, Mo., shot a one-over-par 73 in the third round today and retained the lead in the Ampol golf tournament with a 215, but Ed Furgol, United States open champion, was forced to leave the touring American squad because of an arm injury.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J. Oct. 22 -- New Jersey's Democratic Governor tonight attacked Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator as "the man who ran out on liberalism" and "the man who couldn't make up his mind."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 (AP) -- General Teamsters Local 249, key union in the strike of twelve A.F.L. unions against five department stores, said today that it would submit a proposed new contract to the stores Monday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- The Soviet Union joined the West today in sponsoring a new attempt to achieve disarmament and the prohibition of nuclear weapons.

It is time now to take one of the year's most depressing actions, that of closing the summer cottage. This surely is a mournful proceeding, and like others of its kind -- although not to its full degree -- the closing has been postponed.
Mae West and Bobby Clark may display their divergent talents in the contemplated new edition of the glittering and legendary musical, "The Ziegfeld Follies."

Plans have been filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings for a six-story nursing home for cancer victims at 65-71 Jackson Street. Eggers Higgins are the architects and the cost is estimated at $1,300,000. The building would replace one of two buildings erected in 1910 for the Dominican Sisters who now care for eighty-five patients.

In these days when our citizenry is compelled to fight for the right to have a job or to follow their professions, when the headline seekers ignorantly and maliciously attack the most elementary rights of free people in a free land, it is heartening to see that The Times so completely and prominently reports the more important stories of the day bearing on man's rights under our Bill of Rights.
