Three prominent clergymen of the Roman Catholic, Protestant, and Jewish faiths have written special prayers invoking God's blessing on the United Nations.

Department stores in the Second District continued to hold stocks down in September, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Inventories were 2 per cent below those of last year. It was the ninth consecutive month to show year-to-year inventory reduction.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York announced yesterday the election of the Rev. Dr. David Munroe Cory as executive secretary of its Brooklyn Division, succeeding the late Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter.
GENEVA, Oct. 22 -- Western Europe has suddenly been plunged into a massive automobile traffic problem.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 22 -- Jean Sainteny, French delegate general in Vietminh-occupied Hanoi, flew here today from the North Vietnam capital for a final conference with Guy La Chambre, French Minister for the Indochina States, before the latter's departure this week-end for Paris.
Following are the texts of Governor Dewey's television address last night, as recorded by The New York Times, and the reply by John P. McGrath, Democratic campaign manager:

An address by President Eisenhower at the National Security Industrial Association dinner in Washington will be presented over the N.B.C. television network on Monday from 10:30 to 11 P.M. On radio the address will be broadcast at the same time by the A.B.C., M.B.S. and N.B.C. networks.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 22 (UP) -- The refusal of four Nebraska state-supported teachers colleges to allow students to debate recognition of the Communist China Government touched off widespread discussion among educators today.
Within the confines of Ten Arlo, a Dutch hamlet, a striking experiment in social responsibility is making slow but measured progress.

The Symphony of the Air, formerly the N.B.C. Symphony, announced yesterday it had received good wishes and cash contributions from organizations in all parts of the country for the occasion of its conductor-less concert in Carnegie Hall next Wednesday.

Billy Talbert, captain of the United States Davis Cup tennis team, is hospitalized with infectious hepatitis, a liver ailment, and will be unable to leave with the rest of the squad for Australia on Nov. 5, it was disclosed yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Sam Barton of the American Yacht Club and E.B.N. (Bud) Mitchell of the Royal Corinthian Yacht Club, England, divided the fourth and fifth races of their international match-race series today sending the event into its final day with the American skipper holding a 3-2 advantage.
The State Attorney General's "challenge list" of persons whose right to vote appears questionable is already longer than it ever has been before.

Fluorine is a protoplasmic poison with the insidious property of becoming accumulated in the body when ingested even in trace quantities over a prolonged period of time. Normally active adults consume in a temperate climate one and one-half to three liters of water a day, but those engaged in labor, and particularly during summer months, may consume several times this amount.

A 5-year-old Queens girl was reported recovering yesterday from the dangerous bite of a black widow spider. A Health Department inspector on night emergency duty succeeded in locating the serum that serves as an antitoxin.

Thursday's collections for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 806 pints, the largest for any single day thus far this month. Included were 191 pints donated at Time, Inc., 9 Rockefeller Plaza; 185 pints given by military units at 70 East Tenth Street, and 147 at the New York Telephone Company, 228 East Fifty-sizth Street.

THE deer season will open in the Adirondack area of New York on Monday, and although the archers have been stalking whitetails in that area for the past two weeks, it is reliably reported that there are plenty of bucks left for the firearms brigade.

With a degree of mutual accommodation amounting to a diplomatic miracle -- and a hopeful augury for the future -- the Paris conference has completed the task set for it. It has translated the blueprint of London into an imposing structure of interlocking treaties and agreements designed to create a new Europe that would bury its ancient enmities and unite with the larger Atlantic community in the common defense of our Western civilization.

PARIS, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a communique issued today by the North Atlantic Council and of statements by John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Sir Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary:

Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Mayor Wagner joined last night in a double-barreled attack on the Republican party. They branded it a friend of "special interests" that has betrayed New York State and "discriminated" against New York City.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight urged all oil refineries in the Los Angeles area today to carry out a test shutdown to see how much they were contributing to the city's recurrent spells of stifling smog.
ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- The Republican state high command unveiled a new campaign issue today, one with which the party hoped to arouse its apparently lethargic upstate voters.

The College All-Stars, composed of eight All-America selections and two of the metropolitan area's leading players of last season, will meet the New York Knickerbocker quintet this afternoon and tonight at Madison Square Garden in the annual benefit for the Hearst Free Milk Fund.
Three new members were elected yesterday to the board of trustees of Tuskegee Institute, Negro school in Tuskegee, Ala.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Cracks in the metal structure, created during manufacture, may have speeded the metal fatigue believed to have been the cause of the loss of two Comet airliners.
The Pennsylvania, Lehigh Valley and Jersey Central railroads have asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for increases in their interstate commuter fares averaging 9 per cent.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 (AP) --The board of the Follansbee Steel Corporation refused today to consider an offer from an unidentified business group to buy 51 per cent of the corporation's stock at $21 a share.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Jimmy Dickey and Jack Patterson led Houston to a 28-7 victory over Villanova before 57,817 at Municipal Stadium tonight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 -- Warner Brothers will cut twenty-seven minutes from the three hours and two minutes running time of "A Star Is Born."
PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France dropped the problems of Western unity and defense for two hours this morning to explore the question of Moroccan nationalism.

Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told metropolitan area teachers yesterday that many of them were working -- under conditions that would call for a picket line in industry.

WASHINGTON Oct. 22 (AP) -- Despite widespread reports of apathy among voters, state election and party officials look for a probable vote on Nov. 2 of about 45,115,000, an increase of 2,800,000 over the previous record for a midterm election, in 1950.
DOVER, Del., Oct. 22 -- The Supreme Court of Delaware today in effect deferred for at least eight weeks the crisis over the enrollment of ten Negro students to Milford High School.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 22 -- While making an outward show of neutralism so as to avoid offense to Communist China, Burma is steadily developing relations with her anti-Communist neighbors, especially Thailand. Thailand was one of three Asian nations to sign the Manila pact for collective defense from which Burma remained aloof largely through fear of Chinese reaction.

THE merits of Leo Amino's sculpture -- constructions, plastics and wood-carvings -- at the Sculpture Center are easily perceived and enjoyed. He finds many clever things to do with his airy abstract shapes and he is an agile craftsman.

The problem of desegregation in the public schools is the topic of two reports that are to be presented today to a meeting of the executive committees of the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

Floyd Patterson of Brooklyn, the 19-year-old light-heavy-weight who aspires to a championship, made his professional debut in Madison Square Garden a notable one last night with a unanimous decision over Joe Gannon of Washington.
Stockholders of the National City Bank of New York subscribed to 98 per cent of the $131,250,000 of capital shares offered them a month ago to increase the National City's capitalization.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 22 -- Sands Point village officials will argue Nov. 4 for dismissal of a complaint filed in Supreme Court here charging that a Sands Point ordinance virtually outlaws churches and synagogues. The date was set yesterday after Village Attorney Oakie McKnight, who had twenty days to answer the charges, moved instead for dismissal of the case.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 22 (Reuters) -- An Italian newspaper man found guilty of having defamed the conduct of the Italian Navy in World War II and of having libeled individual admirals won his appeal today against conviction by a Milan lower court.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 22 (UP) -- The Senate Minority Leader, Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, said today that a proposed legislative program had been drawn up for use if the Democrats won control of Congress.
Plans were disclosed yesterday for the merger of the Nassau County Trotting Association and the Old Country Trotting Association into Roosevelt Raceway, Inc.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 21 -- The political outlook of the dominant local Republican organization appears to have undergone a complete reversal in the four weeks since the party's State convention was held here.

Army's swift-striking football legions will make their lone New York appearance of 1954 today, facing Columbia's varsity at Baker Field. With fair weather, a crowd of 30,000 is expected for the top collegiate gridiron attraction of the local campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Sidney S. McMath, former Governor of Arkansas, testified today he believed that his refusal to do the bidding of a private utility company cost him re-election to a third term in 1952.

The defending champions, Herman Goldberg and Sidney Ritter, yesterday afternoon won the 1954 metropolitan men's pair contract bridge championship. They out-pointed a seventy-eight-pair field here at the McAlpin Hotel.

Johnny Saxton, the new world welterweight champion, must make his first title defense against Carmen Basilio of Canastota, N.Y., the New York State Athletic Commission ruled yesterday. Any other engagement by the Brooklyn boxer, who won a decision over Kid Gavilan of Cuba in fifteen rounds at Philadelphia last Wednesday night, will not be recognized in this state.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- The state executive committee of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is expected to censure the president of the association's Peekskill branch for issuing a speaking invitation to Bryant Bowles, head of the National Association for the Advancement of White People.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The White House announced today that Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France, would visit the United States for at least two days next month. Murray Snyder, White House press secretary, said President Eisenhower would give a formal luncheon for the Premier Nov. 18, the day he arrives from a four-day stay in Canada.

ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that an employer could not interfere with labor union representatives who picketed his store peacefully in an attempt to recruit his employes, no matter how long the picketing continued.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- President Eisenhower returned today from one political sortie and will set out on another tomorrow.

There will be entertainment for children and adults at the ninth annual fair of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, which will be held Monday through Wednesday in the parish house, 2 East Ninetieth Street. Proceeds will go to the missionary work of the Episcopal Diocese of New York.

AS a Dutch writer and critic, I want to take exception to Mr. A.A. van Duym's letter and support the view of your critic Frances Keene. I think she is very much closer to the truth in stating that no important Dutch literature has been translated into English since Couperus.
Parent education is one of the most important weapons in the fight against mental illness, the fourth annual meeting of the National Association for Mental Health was told yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 -- Quarterback Jimmy Finks' passing and the accurate toe of Ed Kissell gave the Pittsburgh Steelers a 17-7 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles tonight and put them into a tie with the Eagles for the Eastern Division lead in the National Football League.

Last week the nation's electric light and power industry, private and public, reached the record generating capacity of 100,000,000 kilowatts. Generating facilities operated by industrial, mining, steel concerns and railroads for their own uses, produce an additional 16,000,000 kilowatts.

As usual, certain of the Off-Broadway theatres are doing revivals dredged up from the long-dead past. Why? With hundreds of new scripts waiting to be produced, the training ground of Eugene O'Neill digs up fossils.

ICE conditions at Thule in northwest Greenland during the summer of 1911 were bad, and the annual supply schooner failed to arrive. Peter Freuchen, the trader, was faced with a long, cold winter and the necessity of subsisting on local resources of food and fuel along with his customers, the Polar Eskimos.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 23 -- The Business Advisory Council, composed of 200 business executives, gave qualified approval today to President Eisenhower's foreign trade program.

A festive Baker Field homecoming crowd of almost 4,000 alumni and their guests heard Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, announce plans yesterday morning for the construction of a new $175,000 wing to the field house.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- After a dull beginning, New York's state election campaign took on new life this week as it entered the homestretch. Because of the change in nominating convention dates it is the shortest state campaign since 1938, the last time the Democrats won the Governorship.

CORNING, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Averell Harriman said today that he was "revolted" by what he called the "smears and distortions" of Governor Dewey and Senator Irving M. Ives, Mr. Harriman's Republican opponent for the Governorship.
CORVALLIS, Ore., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The U.C.L.A. juggernaut rolled to its sixth consecutive football victory today, trampling Oregon State, 61 -- 0.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Now that flowers are fewer, clean-up will make the garden more attractive. Pull up annual plants that are exhausted or show no signs of more bloom and cut off yellowed tops of perennials. Add top growth that is free of insects and disease to compost pile. Gather up stakes and, after they have been cleaned and dried in sun, store.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 23 -- Yugoslav authorities have made a concession to existing pressures for a currency devaluation, reinforcing rumors that the rate of the dinar will be doubled for foreign exchange.

THE legend "Produced by David O. Selznick" will appear for the first time tonight on television, preceded by the title "Diamond Jubilee of Light." A foreword to the show describes it as "a potpourri of dramatics, whimsicality and oratorical flight (with bits of music too) celebrating the birth of the electric bulb; paying tribute to the American individual and his offspring, and including some commentary on a few of the lights that guide them."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- The outcome of the contests for Pennsylvania's thirty seats loomed today as a major factor in the nation-wide battle for control of the House of Representatives in the Eighty-fourth Congress.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 23 (UP) -- Iowa's opportunistic Hawkeyes, led by a fleet halfback, Ed Vincent, romped over Indiana's hapless Hoosiers today, 27 -- 14, for their second Big Ten victory in four games before 29,000 Hoosier homecoming fans.

YONKERS, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Paige Direct, a 7-year-old Billy Direct stallion owned by Paige H. West of Snow Hill, Md., won the Hudson Pace in the last fifty yards in 2:03 1-5 on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

Government efforts to restore 1,500,000 deadweight tons of merchant shipping to commercial and military usefulness moved ahead last week. The Maritime Administration announced that it was studying bids to re-engine two Liberty ships with more powerful Diesel and steam turbine equipment.

Penn Military College's undefeated football team defeated Wagner College's non-winning eleven, 21 -- 12, yesterday at Grymes Hill, Staten Island. The victory was the third for the visitors. Wagner has lost five games.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 23 -- With only a week of campaigning left, there appeared to be no major shifts developing in Iowa's political thinking. Party officials were now more concerned with getting out the vote than influencing it.

I WAS interested and glad to read the constructive letter of Wells Richardson in your section on Oct. 3. Actors Equity approves of a huge union membership. All the usual fixtures appear on the 1955 schedule of major indoor track meets. The fourteen-meet schedule released yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris of the Amateur Athletic Union includes five straight Saturday nights of competition at Madison Square Garden.

Gertrude Samuels' objective and impressive report "Refugees to Israel, Five Years Later" (Oct. 3) struck a responsive chord. The U.N. official she quotes as expressing the hope that instead of retaliation more emphasis should be placed on rehabilitation would gain comfort from knowing that the 75-year-old world-wide vocational training organization, "World ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) Union," has devoted itself to this philosophy exclusively.

DOODLETOWN, N.Y. -- This alpine hamlet, cradled high above the Hudson River and hemmed on all sides by state parkland, is among the least visited of Revolutionary War locales although it is within fifty miles of New York City.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 23 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon blasted away tonight at what he called the alliance between the Communist party and left-wing Democrats to defeat Republican candidates for Congress.

A STORY of "Rare White Heron of a Single Flight" -- the New Zealand Maori natives' name for England's Elizabeth II -- is colorfully narrated and illustrated in "The Royal Tour," by Malcolm C. Dizer, a retired New York business executive.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 23 -- A big step in the implementation of the Geneva armistice agreement for Vietnam was taken when Hanoi was transferred recently from French to Vietminh hands. The Communist-directed Government of Ho Chi Minh, in its move from the jungle to the city, is achieving not only new prominence in the eyes of the world, but also a vastly better base of operations from which to pursue its domestic objectives.

REMEMBER the Maine? On the night of Feb. 15, 1898, in Havana harbor, 266 men went down with her when a terrible explosion tore the ship apart. The press set off a clamor for revenge and for armed intervention in Cuba.

A new course in current international problems is being offered at Pace College this fall. Among the topics to be included will be the meetings of the International Monetary Fund, the Commonwealth Finance Ministers in London, the Export-Import Bank, East-West trade, exchange rate practices and gold.

WHEN Dorothy Dandridge and Harry Belafonte (see top photo) appear on the Rivoli's screen next Thursday night as the leads in the all-Negro musical, "Carmen Jones," the occasion will not mark their initial film together.
ATLANTA, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Bradley Mills, an end, sparked Kentucky to a 13-6 victory over favored Georgia Tech today in a Southeastern Conference game before 34,000.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Undefeated Yale and Colgate played to a 13-13 tie in the Bowl today.

A 37-yard touchdown pass from Ronny Lattanzio to Joe Barresi in the final quarter preserved New Dorp's undefeated record yesterday. The Staten Island eleven subdued Lafayette, 19 -- 14, in a Public Schools Athletic League Division II contest at Madison Field, Brooklyn.

WHEN the Ballets Es pagnols Teresa and Luisillo open next Sunday evening at the Mark Hellinger Theatre for a four-week run, they will have the field somewhat unexpectedly to themselves, for Hurtado de Cordoba and his company cut short their local engagement at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last night.
RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- I.A. Daffin of Lititz, Pa., owns only one horse, a 5-year-old bay gelding named Coit. But Coit is a good one.

Women's changing role in society requires changes in the planning of education for women, according to a study by Dr. Kate Hevner Mueller. The study, "Educating Women for a Changing World" (University of Minnesota Press), notes that in the society of the future, women will play increasingly active roles as wage-earners and citizens, and less active roles as homemakers.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- There was little jubilation in the ranks of the West German delegation to the Paris conference on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, when agreements were reached on the texts granting the Federal Republic its sovereignty, membership in the new Western European Union, and in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
A retired patrolman and a publicity agent were charged yesterday with selling tiny, unofficial police badges on assurances that they would help buyers escape arrest for traffic violations.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 -- The Weather Bureau indicated today that some relief might be expected from the smog menace which has hovered over the city and vicinity for nearly three weeks.

Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for the sixth annual Post-Debutante Tiara Ball. The benefit, which will aid the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, will be held on Dec. 29 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Frederic H. Rahr is chairman of the benefit committee, Mrs. William E. Hill is vice chairman and among their aides is Mrs. Wickliffe W. Crider.
A NEW group of actors with an unusual theatrical technique is making a deep impression on Canadian audiences.

IN November, 1952, soon after Colette heard that she was to receive the Grande Croix of the Legion d'Honneur, she went, in her wheel chair, to view a movie about her life. When a newspaper man asked her about this film, she wanted to know whether he had seen it.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France will ask the National Assembly on Nov. 24, or soon afterward, to set a date for debate on ratification of the agreements on the Saar and on Western European defense that were signed today.

In a week of varied auctions, the most outstanding from the point of view of the picture collector is a sale of modern French and American paintings and drawings collected by the late Arthur Bradley Campbell of Palm Beach, Fla. The collection will be offered at 8 P. M. Wednesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Following are the texts of two statements today by Averell Harriman, Democratic candidate for Governor:

The Robert Roesler de Villiers Foundation, 1172 Park Avenue, New York City, announces a third annual contest for prizes to be awarded for contributions to the understanding, prevention or cure of leukemia, a fatal cancerlike disease characterized by an excessive production of white blood cells.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 23 -- The annual Buckram Beagles Hunt Ball will be held on the night of Oct. 30 at the Piping Rock Club here.

IT was a bright Saturday in early fall and as mother bustled about the kitchen sorting clothes for the washing machine she whistled a gay tune to herself, The family 8-year-old, busy with a late breakfast, suddenly put down his spoon and looked gravely about the room.

"The Changing Face of the East Side" (Oct. 3) was interesting; but the picture of the Rockefeller Institute area does not show a "footbridge to Welfare Island," as its caption says, but to Wards Island. Welfare Island is downriver several blocks and is crossed by the Queensborough Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Neither records nor memory can match the performance of the 1954 hurricane season, in which the only three of the season's eight major tropical storms to do real wind-driven violence to continental United States hit the Northeastern states.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Bernard Shanley, Presidential counsel said tonight he was convinced that President Eisenhower would seek reelection in 1956 "if the great majority of the people * * * want him to run." And he said he expected such a demand.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- In the view of West Germans, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer virtually surrendered the Saar to France today.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 23 -- Prime Minister Nehru's visit to Communist China appears to be strongly calculated to enhance India's role as a potential mediator between East and West. Another important aspect of the Indian leader's trip, which he himself has called "historic," is the emergence of Mr. Nehru as spokesman and advocate for other Southeast Asian nations in their relations with Communist China.
The re-election of Donald S. Stralem for the eighth successive years as chairman of the George Junior Republic Association was announced yesterday.

Western European Union has been adopted as the English title for the members of the expanded Brussels Treaty Organization, putting an end to the tentative title, "Bruto." The Western European Union has been formed as a counter-weight to another Union -- the Union (Soyuz) of Soviet Socialist Republics.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Following is the translation of a Soviet note to France, as broadcast from Moscow. (Similar notes were sent to Britain and the United States):

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- Unbeaten Ohio State scored four touchdowns in nine minutes today to rout previously unbeaten Wisconsin, 31 -- 14. Howard (Hopalong) Cassady supplied the spark that stamped the Buckeyes as revised favorites to win the Big Ten title.

Wells Richardson made a rather dubious case for a moratorium on admission to Actors Equity. The weakest link in his argument is, of course, the absurd contention that there is nothing easier to get than an Equity card.

The final meeting of the New York racing season opened yesterday at the Jamaica track, where 31,765 customers saw Elmendorf's Banta and Harry J. O'Shea's Good Call win the two divisions of the Correction Handicap.
NEWARK, Del., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Delaware's undefeated football team rolled over winless Connecticut today, 28 -- 7, before a record homecoming day crowd of 6,919.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- The status of West Germany was changed today, and with it the face of Western Europe, through the signing by fifteen nations of protocols to three treaties.

THE philatelist who specializes in American stamps has the outline of this nation's history in his album. The story of America's past is presented here by using large reproductions of all the commemorative postage issued since 1893 through the Columbia University Bicentennial stamp of this year.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Lenny Dawson, Purdue's star sophomore quarterback, passed for three touchdowns and kicked three extra points to lead his team to a 27-13 Big Ten victory today over Michigan State.

Administration.
FIFTY years ago this Wednesday -- Oct. 27, 1904 -- the New York subway started running Ground had been broken for it in March, 1900, under an initial contract of $35,000,000.

AN event occurs next Tuesday night that could only occur to the individual involved, and only take place in this country, in the troubled world of this day. It will be the recital of songs and chamber music by Alexander Gretchaninoff on the occasion of that composer's ninetieth birthday.

THE literary fascination of the sick for the well, particularly when the invalid is one with whom some identification is possible, is proverbial. But the pasteboard victim portrayed in the book "Chantal" -- ex-model, kept woman, arriviste and finally sister of mercy -- is so unmotivated, so implausible that the only real thing about her is her illness.

AS they say in parliamentary reports, "The debate continues" -- the subject being the fate of British films in the United States. Are they getting a fair showing? Do their relatively low earnings reflect a lack of popularity with the United States moviegoer or a repressive attitude by the big American companies?

Members of the New York diplomatic committee for the International Ball will be guests of honor at a reception tomorrow evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. F. Jerome McNulty at 410 Park Avenue. The ball will be held on Nov. 23 in the ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit oil the Wooden Church Crusade.

In a typical sixth-grade classroom in a public school in Brooklyn, there are thirty children from average New York homes. When these children, who are now 11 to 13 years of age, reach full adulthood, three will require a full lower denture, four will need a fixed or removable bridge and each will have an average of more than twenty-eight teeth that are decayed, filled or missing.

READ as nonfiction instead of as a novel, "Smash-Up" is an enlightening and sometimes frightening book. It is the story of what happens after an automobile accident, and it is told with documentary skill by the former barefoot mailman from Boca Raton, Fla., Theodore Pratt.
A survey of 45,000 graduates of Columbia University's Teachers College reveals that when making donations they rate churches at the top of their lists.

An elaborate divertissement entitled "Golden Shadows," in which young women of society will participate, will be a feature of the fifth annual Fan Ball to be held on Nov. 12 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund.

THERE are those who believe a Granite State countryman is as unyielding in his opinions as the below-the-surface rocks on which his plow snags when he is plowing the bean patch in the upper field. It isn't so much that northland men are refractory; in a flummoxing world we feel that solid citizens must take a stand to check certain social, economic and cultural tides that are running rampant.
Senator Irving M. Ives yesterday called Averell Harriman, his Democratic-Liberal opponent for Governor, a "heartless" employer and "union buster."
KINGSTON, R.I., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The University of Rhode Island routed Hofstra College, 46 -- 14, today with their second consecutive high scoring performance at Meade Field.
AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Bobby Freeman's passing and the strong running of Fob James and Joe Childress helped Auburn to a 33-0 victory over Florida State today.

IN this book with its annoying subtitle, Mortimer Smith continues the vivacious attack on public education that he begun a year or two ago with "And Madly Teach." As a responsible citizen, as a parent of children in school, he is alarmed by a situation that is perennially alarming: the obvious deterioration of humanistic teaching in the primary and secondary grades.

KONINKLIJKE LUCHTVAART MAATSCHAPPIJ is the formidable name that was given to the world's oldest airline when it was founded in the fall of 1919. Fortunately, the airline, which last week celebrated in New York the thirty-fifth anniversary of its founding, is now much better known as K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 23 -- Illinois rebounded from four straight defeats today to defeat Syracuse 34 -- 6, before 41,820.
A Brooklyn grocer demonstrated last night that the gift of gab is as much of an asset as a loaded gun when he talked two youthful thugs out of more than a half of their loot.
EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Oct. 23 (AP) -- J.W. Conrad, a second lieutenant from Gary, A.F.B., Tex., won the Air Force's world-wide golf tournament today with a record-breaking 72-hole score of 281.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl refused today to disqualify himself as presiding jurist in the trial of Owen Lattimore on perjury charges.
Crisp clear weather combined with heavy promotions to put retail sales in New York City in the last week from 6 to 10 per cent ahead of the same week a year ago, according to merchants' estimates.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Another riot broke out in Missouri's trouble-ridden state prison today. One convict was killed and thirty-six were hospitalized.

A NEW horse story by Walter Farley has become an annual treat for his readers. "The Black Stallion's Sulky Colt" trots right in on schedule, Mr. Farley's tenth high-tension novel on his favorite subject. This is the story of five men and a colt -- and of a Hambletonian.

ONE hundred and eighty-three miles of the New York Thruway will be opened to traffic Tuesday, carrying the concrete toll expressway from Buffalo down to Newburgh, sixty-one miles from the New York City line.

A VETERAN hand with historical fiction, F. van Wyck Mason has turned from the American Revolution to the war between North and South, projecting a group of four related novels. "Proud New Flags" was the first of the series, "Blue Hurricane" is the second.

AT this time of year flower lovers who dread the devastation done by the killing frosts can comfort themselves by making plans for the winter garden indoors. And it won't be necessary for them to be satisfied merely with foliage plants during the austerity season, either.

ONE of your illustrations to the review of "John Ruskin" by Joan Evans you entitle "John Ruskin's Wedding" by John Everett Millais. This Victorian goody is certainly by Millais, but its proper title is "The Ghost." Gere and Ironside's "Pre-Raphaelite Painters" says about it: "The widow who in Millais' 'Ghost' unthinkingly betrothes herself a second time is stayed at the altar by the spectre of her first love."

ANOTHER $1,000,000 has been added to the budget of "Moby Dick," thus bringing the cost of John Huston's version of the Herman Melville classic to $4,000,000, it was disclosed last week by Alfred W. Crown, president of Moulin Productions under whose aegis it is being filmed.

FOR many years certain people have thought of Elsa Maxwell as some kind of an international joke -- something on the order of one of those celebrities made up out of whole cloth, during periods of lean lion-hunting, by cafe society.

POCATELLO, Idaho, Oct 23 -- Idaho's Senatorial campaign, up to now conducted on a comparatively restrained basis, exploded this week with quasi-official charges that Glen H. Taylor, Democratic candidate, in 1948 knowingly accepted Communist support.

THIS second volume in a projected series, of which the first, a study of colonial art in America, appeared in 1947, is both a chronicle and an interpretation. As a historian James T. Flexner possesses modern insights into human motives and behavior, modern perceptions of those formal and expressive qualities in works of art which do not depend on literal representation.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 23 -- The fight over desegregation of the Lakeview Avenue school in downstate Milford is in a condition of uneasy truce. A renewed crisis appears inevitable, although by action of the State Supreme Court yesterday it has been deferred at least eight weeks.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- The Manchester Guardian today examined recent political statements by President Eisenhower and concluded that he and Vice President Richard M. Nixon "should resign at once" if the Democrats won the Congressional elections Nov. 2.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- With an election dead ahead, something called the "pocketbook nerve" is getting more than usual attention.
An A.W.O.L. Marine led the police on a wild noontime chase over backyard fences near the Bronx Police Headquarters yesterday before he was shot in the hip and captured.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Southern California's Linden Crow capitalized on California fumbles and scored three touchdowns today to lead the Trojans to a 29-to-27 victory before 66,342 frenzied fans in Memorial Coliseum even though California's Paul Larson gave one of the greatest college passing exhibitions ever seen here.
MEYERBEER: Torch Dance in B flat; GLAZOUNOV: Concert Waltz in D Major, Op. 47; Belgian Radio Orchestra, Franz Andre conducting (Telefunken, ten-inch). Competent recording of pleasant works.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- The new weapon that the military leaders of the free world have been demanding for four years, a West German army, was promised to them today.

"OMNIBUS," the ninety-minute program of the TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation, returned last week for its third season on the C.B.S. network (5 P.M. Sunday). All things considered, the premiere was on the superficial side and lacked real imagination or substance.
Advertising promotion is very much like a many-tiered chocolate cake.

JUST before the Giants collided with the Redskins in Washington a fortnight ago, Jim Lee Howell, the new coach of the Polo Grounds tenants, crossed paths with George Preston Marshall, the owner of the Capital Braves.

Twenty-five years ago this Friday it was Wall Street's misfortune to be the focus of all the ills that must befall a business community trying to promote rather than produce itself into greater prosperity.

DETROIT, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Jack McIntyre scored two goals and assisted on another tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to their first victory of the season, a 4-2 decision over the Detroit Red Wings.

AS they close the machine at the end of the only typewritten page which does not at the bottom bleakly say, more, working novelists may contemplate certain possible results. Fame can be there -- or lie around the corner for next time -- or Hollywood contracts, the lecture platform, maybe even money.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23 (UP) -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. said today that the United Nations in its nine years had played a decisive part in winning five major victories for the free world over communism.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- An anemic textile industry coupled with curtailment of employment in metal working plants throughout the Mohawk Valley from Utica to Albany appear likely to reduce the usual Republican pluralities that area.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 23 -- The construction of a physics research laboratory and the future erection, when funds are available, of a biology laboratory were announced this week by Yale University.
THE LADY ELIZABETH BOWES-LYON -- Her Royal Highness the Duchess of York -- Her Majesty the Queen Consort -- Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother: one woman in her time may play many parts.

VINES, although they are a specialized group of plants, still rank among the best-sellers in a nursery. The number of vines in popular demand seems to be fewer than twenty years ago, but as a Long Island nurseryman said last week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Army announced tonight that it had ousted fifteen soldiers on charges of misconduct while they were war prisoners of the Chinese-Korean Communists. None was named.
Re-enacting a scene of half a century ago, city, civic and transit officials will mark the fiftieth anniversary of New York City's first subway on Wednesday.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- A long diplomatic and political struggle came to an end today with the signing of agreements to rearm Western Germany under limitations and control by bringing her into a new organization called the Western European Union and into the North Atlantic alliance.
A waterfront terminal operation of a type previously unknown in the Port of New York will begin this week on municipally owned Pier 13 at Stapleton, S.I.

A new series of free art lectures at the New York Public Library will open at 6:15 P.M. Tuesday at the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building with Simon Lissim speaking on "Influence and the Artist."

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 23 -- A two- touchdown short-ender, Fordham fought Marquette to a 14-14 tie today in an intersectional football game before a near-capacity homecoming crowd of 19,500 at Hilltop Stadium.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 23 -- Israel's strategic position in the Middle East as a democratic nation and as an integral part of free world defense planning was emphasized here tonight. At the same time, Western policy in that area was scored as detrimental to Israel's security.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Erich Ollenhauer, West German Socialist leader, accused Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today of deviating from an agreement made with West German political leaders when he made a Saar settlement with France.
THE international music festival has proved a potent magnet for tourists. One by one the countries of Europe have begun staging them, and next year Greece is planning to enter the competition.

MONTREAL, Oct. 23 (UP) -- The sharpshooting Montreal Canadiens temporarily derailed the Ranger express as they crushed New York, 7 -- 1, before 14,214 National Hockey League fans in the Forum tonight.

ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 23 (UP) -- A second-string backfield enabled crippled Virginia Tech to roll on unbeaten and untied today with a 6-to-0 victory over Virginia -- the fourth Atlantic Coast Conference team beaten by the Gobblers this year.

WAYS and means of improving marketing procedures were closely scrutinized last week at the annual Boston Conference of Distribution. One of the healthiest characteristics of American business is a willingness to examine its procedures, talk about them not only in closed corporate council, but in industry conclaves, and then take action that will put into operation the remedies that are suggested.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Undefeated Boston College won its fifth straight game today as it rolled over out-classed Springfield, 42 -- 6.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 23 -- Burmese leaders refer to this country's "neutralism" as "realism," and assert that it is "fundamentally different" from the middle-of-the-road policy pursued by Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Representative Chet Holifield charged today that the Dixon-Yates utility group might make as much as 20 to 30 per cent profit on its investment under its controversial power contract with the Atomic Energy Commission.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Two new villains from the United States turned up this week among the familiar characters who are featured every day in the Soviet press.

CAPT. PHILIPPE TAILLIEZ is Commander of the Undersea Research Group of the French Navy. "To Hidden Depths" is the account of his personal adventures as a diver and leader of the group of celebrated free-swimming undersea explorers who did so much to promote the present fad of "aqualung" diving.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 23 -- French commercial dealings with the Vietminh in North Vietnam were understood today to depend on more definite manifestations of goodwill and more precise commitments than the Ho Chi Minh Government has given.

CAREFUL and correct planting of camellias is an investment which yields returns as long as the bushes live. Much more can be accomplished for their future growth and development by proper care in their planting than by any amount of later cultivation.

The French revolutionaries attempted to establish the rights of man on reason alone, and planted the seeds of their own failure.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 23 -- The Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs has scheduled an all-day civil defense conference for Monday at the Cathedral House here.

Dr. John von Neumann, since 1933 Research Professor at the Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, and one of the world's outstanding mathematicians, played a vital role in the development of the hydrogen bomb.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The political campaign in Cook County was complicated today by a dispute over a tape recording played in the office of Illinois' Republican Governor, who said it was the voice of the Democratic candidate for sheriff.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 23 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said upon his return to Bonn tonight that the negotiations in Paris had concluded with results satisfactory to everyone concerned.

Mozart's A minor Rondo, Beethoven's "Appassionata" Sonata, the Preludes of Debussy's Book II and Schumann s "Carnaval" are among the finest works written for the piano, and Katherine Bacon's recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hail served as a reminder of their inexhaustibility.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- The debutante season in the New York Metropolitan area opened tonight when the sixty- sixth annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball was held here in the Tuxedo Club. The attendance tonight was the largest since before World War II.
Middletown, Conn., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Amherst broke a four-year string of tie football games with Wesleyan today with a 14-0 victory over the Cardinals before a Homecoming-Day crowd of 5,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- For more than eight years now the United States and the United Nations have been living as host and guest. That is a delicate relationship to last for eight years. Housekeeping problems were bound to come up, and every one of them has been well-publicized -- from loyalty investigations to parking tickets.

The bond market here is unfolding a spectacular statistical commentary on Germany's post-war industrial recovery. Dollar obligations of the pre-war Reich are being bid up in price day after day. Bonds which were quoted at 2 to 10 points in 1941 are now commanding prices up to 163.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused President Eisenhower's No. 1 economic adviser today of "unsound and irresponsible economics" and of "politically expedient economic optimism."

THIS is a final report on The London Observer's debate regarding the life expectancy of the novel. It began, you may recall, with Sir Harold Nicolson's contention that the art of fiction, if not actually dead, is at least in a state of suspended animation which may be expected to continue until the times are such as to permit its revival.

THE genius of the young Jefferson, author of the Declaration of Independence at 33, was, as Abraham Lincoln remarked, that he, "in the concrete pressure of a struggle for national independence by a single people, had the coolness, forecast, and capacity to introduce into a merely revolutionary document an abstract truth, applicable to all men and all times."

WILLIAM PLOMER'S first novel, "Turbott Wolfe," appeared nearly thirty years ago in London, and yet "Museum Pieces" is only his third novel to appear in the United States. This is a pity, for he is a remarkably able novelist: intelligent, witty, with a true sense of style, and possessing in real measure Meredith's comic spirit.

AN extraordinarily interesting book is this memoir by the woman who was dean of Barnard College for thirty-six years, and was many other things besides. Like so many of her generation, she journeyed out of a Victorian childhood to a most responsibile position in the great world, and this in itself is always a fascinating story.

EVERY fall the lovers of the detective short story come into their own, with the annual publication of the prize-winning stories from Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine and of a group of stories by members of Mystery Writers of America, Inc. Normally these two are the best mystery anthologies of the year; and 1954, despite stiff competition from David C. Cooke's annual "Best Detective Stories," is no exception.

HONG KONG, Oct. 23 -- An era of good feeling is being officially encouraged in the midst of Communist China's renewed emphasis on "peaceful coexistence." Softer tactics in Peiping parallel the reported "new look" in Moscow.
The 1954 campaign of the American-Korean Foundation has raised $1,000,000 in cash and $6,000,000 in materials, Dr. Howard A. Rusk, former president and new chairman of the foundation, has announced.
Columbia University's bicentennial celebration will go into its third major phase this week, concentrating on the university's relationship with the world.

IN writing "The South in American Literature, 1607-1900," Jay Hubbell, Professor of American Literature at Duke, has not only had to gather into their proper periods Southern men of letters, he has had to exhume most of them from a double neglect -- the neglect of their own region and the general American scene.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23 -- The official United States policy placing emphasis on "the Sunday punch" of the Strategic Air Command, with consequent neglect of air defense, was criticized in a report here today.

THE Guatemalan crisis which culminated in a truce signed at San Salvador at dawn on July 2 was the most important test United States policy has faced in Latin America in half a century. Nor is it by any means certain that the application of that policy in the climactic days of the insurrection will be a long-range success.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- There's still plenty of gold in "them thar hills" of the West -- and more and more tourists are snagging on to it. In fact, holiday prospecting is rapidly becoming a major, and sometimes profitable, vacation pastime.

ONE twenty-four-hour period when, throughout the nation, there will be no highway fatalities, injuries or accidents is the goal of Safe Driving Day, which has been scheduled for Dec. 15 by the President's Action Committee for Traffic Safety.

SHEILA KAYE-SMITH translates the age-old debate between faith and reason into a quiet and thoughtful novel, which digs deep into the nature and soil of England. The scene is a small village in Sussex, where, at the turn of the century, Henry Chamberlain begins to watch from his parsonage window.

Rabbi Hyman Judah Schachtel of Houston, Tex., said yesterday that the United States Supreme Court ruling outlawing racial segregation in the public schools was "obviously good" because it "brings us closer to our fellowmen in a spirit of brotherhood."
THE retirement of Joseph I Breen after twenty years of riding herd on movie morals will not result in any fundamental changes being made in the motion picture Production Code.

IN the interesting, important and provocative book under review Adolf A. Berle continues his study of the corporation begun in his and G.C. Means' classic volume "The Modern Corporation and Private Property."

DUTCH painting of the seventeenth century, popular in the United States at the turn of the twentieth century, has been neglected in recent years. This art, primarily created for and supported by wealthy, bourgeois patrons, dealt with tangible, materialistic aspects of the world. These reassuring portraits of the life, the place, the possessions and the people are not unlike the subject-matter of Impressionist painting, which appeals to a parallel audience in our time.

THERE are few more characteristically American themes than that of the man who goes from the town to the city to seek his fortune and finds that he has left a part of himself behind. And there have been few writers, since Thomas Wolfe opened it up in his vital, intense and wordy way, who have handled it so deftly and entertainingly as Hamilton Basso in "The View From Pompey's Head."

In the fall of 1929 threatening clouds had begun to make their appearance on the Wall Street horizon as early as September. In the weeks that followed there were to be many days of wild unsettlement on the stock market, but when the deluge came it was not one crash but an almost unbroken series or crashes extending from Oct. 23 through Nov. 13.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of the new production of "On Your Toes," on the night of Nov. 4 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre for he benefit of the New York Botanical Gardens. Mrs. Richard S. Meredith and Mrs. Charles G. Stradella are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.
Two officials of the small German town of Wesel have come to America to show a "sister" community how a town can emerge from near-total destruction within a decade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Following is the text of the memorandum issued today by Judge Luther W. Youngdahl in answering charges that he had acted with bias and prejudice in the perjury trial of Owen Lattimore:

ONE of the objectives in the forthcoming American expedition to Antarctica is to check on the status of the stupendous ice fields and glaciers of that little-known continent. The particular point of inquiry concerns whether the ice is melting at such a rate as to imperil low-lying coastal areas through raising the level of the sea in the near future.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 -- Corny Salvaterra, hobbling on an injured leg, scored a touchdown on a 1-yard sweep with thirty-nine seconds remaining today to give Pittsburgh a 14-7 victory over Northwestern.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Michigan's Wolverines, sparked by Tony Branoff, a halfback, upset Minnesota, 34 -- 0, today to loom as a sudden and serious contender for the Big Ten title.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 23 -- Lehigh University parlayed a tricky forward-passing attack and two Rutgers fumbles into a 33-13 victory today.

The New York Giants, who made such a favorable impression in their home debut last Sunday, will be on display at the Polo Grounds again today. Their opponent is the Washington Redskins. Kick-off time is 2.05 P.M.
CAMDEN, N.J., Oct 23 (UP) -- Helioscope, the pride of New Jersey racing fans, turned aside strong stretch runs by two New York invaders to win the $62,100 Trenton Handicap today at Garden State Park.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 -- Steel ingot production in the Cleveland-Lorain district increased to 82 per cent for an eight-month high and representing a gain of 2 per cent over last week's revised figure of 80 per cent. It also marked the sixth consecutive week of expanded output at a level well above that of the summer.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Soviet failure to promise more than reexamination of the question of free all-German elections appears to insure rejection by the West of the latest Soviet proposal for a four-power conference on Germany.

A NEW regime took command of the San Francisco Opera Company with the opening of that organization's thirty-second season five years ago. This new regime promised much and it fulfilled every one of its commitments, often more brilliantly than anyone expected.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 23 (UP) -- Two plays that came like bolts from the blue -- a 56-yard punt return and a 30-yard pitchout run -- carried Mississippi State to a 12-to-7 upset victory over Alabama today before 30,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, fighting censure charges, today asked Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, to testify before the McCarthy subcommittee and tell who had been "culpable" in the Peress case.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the names of ninety-six persons who had accepted appointment to the Mayor's Committee for Better Housing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Eisenhower announced today that twenty-one officials of the Federal Housing Administration had been dismissed and 200 indictments had been obtained in the Government's investigation of housing scandals.

No one could ever have doubted that the birth of a united Western Europe, if such an event were at all possible, would be accompanied by pangs and uncertainty. Even now, we cannot be sure of what lies in the future. We can be sure, however, that when Premier Mendes-France and Chancellor Adenauer reached an agreement yesterday morning on the Saar a victory was won for the cause of freedom, of justice and of peace.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 23 (UP) -- High Voltage, the 3-5 favorite, upped her ranking as the best 2- year-old of her sex this year by winning the Sehma Stakes today.

The International Brotherhood of Longshoremen, A.F.L., which unsuccessfully fought the independent International Longshoremen's Association in a year-long struggle for control of this port's dock workers, yesterday reported its "fourth straight win" over the marine division of the United Mine Workers of America in the port of Philadelphia.
A devastating Army running attack that piled up 532 yards ruined homecoming reunion day for Columbia alumni yesterday at Baker Field.
THREE important talks on varied subjects of interest to photographers are scheduled locally for this week.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor charged today that "the Democrats have never known the answer to unemployment and their record proves it."

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Adlai E. Stevenson today accused the Illinois and national Republican parties of lowering the election campaign to a "cheap, sordid, ugly slugfest of slogans, charges and epithets devised to submerge the issues upon which America's future depends."
LONDON, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- Manchester United drew against Newcastle, 2 -- 2, to maintain a 1-point lead in the first division of English League soccer today.

WHEN we are tourists in Europe, even the steepest Appennine, the most jolting charabanc or the town with the most questionable inn are never obstacles to the pilgrimages we undertake in order to see a single great painting.

TRENTON, Oct. 23 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, predicted today that the Democrats would score "a sweeping victory" in New Jersey because of Republican inability to cope with unemployment.
HAVANA, Oct. 18 -- Watchers for political hurricanes have had poor pickings in Cuba during the current Presidential campaign, which ends Nov. 1 with general elections.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Capt. Joaquin D'Harcourt of Mexico won the preliminary international jumping event of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight in a jump-off with ten other riders, including the entire Mexican team.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The break in the dock strike failed to develop today. It is now expected that, should the stoppage continue past Monday, the Government will use troops to move the most important cargoes.

MOSCOW, Oct. 23 -- Contrary to all regulations, many farmers in the Soviet Union did not participate in socialized agricultural production last year, according to an article in the current issue of the Communist party journal Communist.

THE publication of Jeannette Klute's "Woodland Portraits" (Boston: Little, Brown Co., $20) is a significant event in photographic literature and a heartening gesture of encouragement toward those who believe in and work for the freest use of the color medium in photography.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Crude petroleum output in this state during August was at the lowest level in several years, according to figures compiled by the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University.

RICHMOND, Oct. 23 -- Along with business and industry generally, department store trade in the Fifth Reserve District received a severe jolt as the aftermath of the hurricane which brought heavy damage in the coastal states. Shopping habits have not yet reached normal, a week after the storm.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 -- President Eisenhower, at a gathering of Pennsylvania Republican Congressional and state candidates on his farm today, gave them thumping personal endorsements. He termed his action a matter of "self-dispensation" from his usual rule of not indulging in personalities of the Congressional campaign.

SIXTY-SIX years ago George Eastman first perfected roll film and made famous the slogan "You press the button. We do the rest." Although photography is not quite so simple as Mr. Hoke indicates, he helps to make it easy for beginners.
GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- The forthcoming tariff and trade conference in Geneva will be of critical importance for the cohesion of the Western community of nations.

THE twentieth anniversary of U.S. Camera Annual is celebrated in the 1955 edition (New York: U.S. Camera Publishing Corp. $6.95), just out. It is a conscientious effort to present a reasonably diverse cross-section of contemporary photography at its best.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the Anniversary Cocktail Dance, at which the New York Diet Kitchen Association will celebrate its eighty-two years of service to the needy children of this city. The event will take place in the St. Regis Roof on Nov. 4.

IN shady spots in the garden where grass will not grow, groundcovers are an invaluable landscaping aide. Although such standard cultivated groundcovers as myrtle, pachysandra, ajuga and the ivies flourish in shade, there are also many wildflower kinds that may be used in shady areas.

STARTED at eighth floor of Audio Fair. Worked down. Annual event at New Yorker Hotel. Four days, ending last Sunday. Very crowded. Very noisy. Very hot, Happy sponsors. More exhibitors than ever before. More attendance.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Undefeated Hobart College rolled over Union College, 32 to 21, today. Hobart's Turoski carried the ball 59 yards across the Union goal on an off-tackle play immediately after the opening kick-off.

The members of forty-three standing committees and fifteen special committees of the New York County Lawyers Association were listed yesterday by William J. O'Shea, president of the organization.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Without a first or second-string tailback to make its single-wing offense go, Princeton was no match for Cornell today at Palmer Stadium. The Ithacans, on the other hand, made the most of a surprisingly strong ground attack, ripped off more yardage in one game than they had in their first four and stormed to a 27-0 upset victory.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 23 (UP) -- Robert Lampron, 16, died today at City Hospital of a head injury suffered in his first high school football game yesterday

ANY anthology worthy of the name these days includes at least one story by Fredric Brown; this collection of seventeen tales demonstrates why. A handy man with a word, a plot, or a deft and insidious story development, Mr. Brown shows that he is also a master of the vignette with the shock, or surprise, ending.

When World War II ended, the campuses of United States colleges and universities were flooded with former servicemen, taking advantage of the G.I. Bill of Rights. The bill, enacted in 1944, gave every academically qualified veteran the means of getting a college education -- free tuition up to $500 a year, plus monthly maintenance grants ranging from $75 to $120.

NEW rattan furniture introduced at the wholesale summer furniture markets in Chicago this week proved that the tropical vine called rattan, one of man's first furniture materials, still has unexplored potentials. The modern treatment of rattan -- the bending of heavy ridged canes into supports for tables, sofas and chairs -- is less than a century old.

The Citizens Union has issued its thirty-fifth annual "Voters Directory" containing names and brief biographies of 405 candidates running in the New York area for state, national, local and judicial offices.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Sam Barton, representing the American Yacht Club, defeated E.B.N. (Bud) Mitchell of the Royal Corinthian Yacht Club of England in the sixth race today to win the match-race series, four races to two.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- Most leading retailers in New England attended the retail distribution conference this week in Boston. Many of them were asked their views of retail business for the remainder of 1954. Practically all said they expected to sell as much goods in the fourth quarter of this year as in the same period of 1953, while a number predicted gains ranging from 1 to 5 per cent over a year ago.

CHEERFULLY admitting that it might be anachronistic, Katharine Gibson deftly weaves an old nursery rhyme through a story of Isabella, the very young bride of Richard II. The cat who goes to London to see the Queen is Boots, a proper mouser, belonging to a shepherd boy, Sparrow.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 17 -- Like a homely girl about to inherit a fortune, Turkey is courted by European trading nations ready to overlook her present shortcomings for a share in her future prosperity.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Steel production in the Chicago area dipped to 3,861,000 net tons during the third quarter of this year, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. The total was down sharply from the same period last year when 4,509,200 net tons were produced for one of the highest quarterly figures recorded here.

Dr. von Neumann is one of the greatest mathematicians alive today, a man who has made fundamental contributions to mathematics and related fields which already have assured his name a high place in the history of contemporary science.

Senator Irving M. Ives carried the Republican Gubernatorial campaign into Brooklyn yesterday after announcing that he would soon report on "Chapters 4 and 5" in the record of Averell Harriman, his Democratic opponent.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 24 -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., has developed a process for manufacturing high-strength felt from its Dacron polyester fiber, it was made known here over the week-end.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The United Nations and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were described today by Sir Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, as keystones of Britain's foreign policy.
TOWNSEND, Mass., Oct. 24 (AP) -- A thief made off with this town's biggest thing on wheels today -- a bright red fourteen-ton fire engine.
Pan American World Airways will begin on Nov. 1 a through service from California to Brazil on which passengers need not change planes on the 7,000-mile trip.

EL ALAMEIN, Egypt, Oct. 24 -- On the desert battlefield where British Commonwealth forces won one of the most decisive victories in history twelve years ago, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein unveiled today a memorial to those who fell here and throughout the Middle East.

There is sad news today. The International Finance Section of Princeton University has announced that the current issue of "Survey of United States International Finance" -- which covers the calendar year of 1953 -- is to be the last.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 24 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today called upon Representative Robert L. Condon, Democratic nominee for Congress from California's Sixth District, to clear himself of security charges or to resign as a candidate.

The immortal charge of the Light Brigade at Balaclava, which occurred a century ago this (Monday) morning, was launched and reached its fated end under the eyes of a French general, Pierre Jean Francois Bosquet.
The charter market remained in high gear again last week as rates and ship demand combined to cheer tramp ship operators.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 24 -- The Free Democratic party, second largest in Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition Government, joined the Opposition Social Democrats today in criticizing the Saar agreement signed in Paris yesterday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 24 -- Military headquarters reports the capture today of the self-styled Field Marshal Kaleba and three companions of the Mau Mau fighting forces, one of whom was a woman. They were caught asleep in a cave on Mount Kenya.

Marshall B. Gurney, recently retired from the United States Navy after twenty-eight years' service, largely in the naval air force, will head the new Aero division of the General Bronze Corporation, fabricator of light metals, radio and electronic products.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, the boxer with more best-in-show titles to his credit than any other dog, added another to his string today in the sixteenth event of the Troy Kennel Club.

Completion of the details of the purchase by the Penn-Texas Corporation of the assets of the Bayway Terminal Corporation, operator of a deep-water industrial terminal at Elizabeth and Linden, N. J., was announced yesterday.

WHATELY, Mass., Oct. 24 (UP) -- A group of Western Massachusetts farmers, protesting against low market prices of vegetables, distributed free today twenty tons of cabbages, onions and potatoes at a "give-away" that turned into a bipartisan political sideshow.
A sign in one office that burglars broke into Saturday night read: "Before You Louse Something Up -- Think."

Nat Holman, recently reinstated as head basketball coach at City College, yesterday charged Albert B. Moore, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, with making a "libelous statement" and called for a "prompt retraction."

ORIENT, L. I., Oct. 24 -- Farmers of eastern Suffolk County are turning to techniques developed in the Netherlands in an effort to restore fertility to 600 acres inundated by salt water during Hurricane Carol on Aug. 31.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Fun is fun, but seniors at Dwight Morrow High School here admit that pulling false alarms is not, even on Halloween. So when Northern Valley Post 208 of the Jewish War Veterans asked the senior class for volunteers to help guard this city's 253 fire alarm boxes on Halloween, upward of 100 came forward.

The executive committee of the American Jewish Committee adopted yesterday a resolution holding that American arms should not be sent to the Middle East "unless it is certain that they will be used to strengthen the security of the area and not promote aggression or create military imbalances."

BROCKVILLE, Ont., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Nearly half the 13,000 population of Brockville (cross on map) was moved out of the city by civil defense workers today in the first voluntary evacuation exercise ever carried out in Ontario.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Y.A. Tittle quarterbacking with a cast on his broken left hand, touched off the explosive fury of the San Francisco 49ers for a 37-31 victory today over the Detroit Lions, champions of the National Football League.
Black widow spiders seemed to be turning up right and left yesterday after newspaper reports that a Queens girl had been dangerously bitten by one.

PARIS, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Paulo A. Cunha of Portugal said today Indian pressure on Portuguese enclaves in India was causing a permanent state of tension and "maintaining a dangerous situation" for the peace of Asia.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 24 -- Prof. C. Goedhart, a leading Dutch economist writing in the Amsterdamsche Bank's quarterly review, said last week convertibility on fixed rates of exchange -- now in the making -- could be maintained only under the following conditions:

Benjamin Strong, president of the United States Trust Company of this city, speaking before the convention of the American Bankers Association in Atlantic City last week, discussed what to him was the "big change" in American investment policy in the last fifty years.

Atlantic Coast shipbuilding yards are unanimously agreed that the Government's $460,000,000 building and repair program falls far short of the needs of national defense and the industry that must supply the ships in any future war.
STRATFORD, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Preliminary steps on the construction of a permanent Shakespeare theatre in this community were taken here today in a sylvan setting on the banks of the Housatonic River.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -- A committee on visual arts has been formed under the chairmanship of John Nicholas Brown of Providence, R.I., a former Overseer of Harvard, the university announced today.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- James A. Farley, long-time Democratic leader threw his support tonight to Averell Harriman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor.

Ralph Levy, Columbia Broadcasting System producer-director, has completed filming a musical adaptation in color of Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol," tentatively scheduled to be given Dec. 23 on the Chrysler "Shower of Stars," 8:30-9:30 P. M. over Channel 2.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Otto Graham passed for one touchdown and sneaked across for two more today to guide the Cleveland Browns to their tenth straight victory over the winless Chicago Cardinals, 35 -- 3.
The Rev. Canon Victor J. Pike, Chaplain General to the British Armed Forces, asserted yesterday that Christ's crucifixion had made the cross "the highest symbol of service and sacrifice."

Parents visiting prep school campuses this time of year often are astonished at the amount of soccer they see. Teams are to be found at every level. They either engage in competition against other schools or take part in club matches.
NEWTOWN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- The massive form of the longest, highest and heaviest dam in Connecticut stands astride the Housatonic River two and a half miles east of here.

A total of 1,093 vessels measuring 8,613,000 net tons, or 913,000 tons of merchant shipping more than in the same month a year ago, passed through the Suez Canal in August. This fleet, according to the Suez Canal Company's latest report, carried cargoes weighing 8,194,000 metric tons.
PARIS, Oct. 24--Premier Pierre Mendes-France told the French in a broadcast today that the Saar agreement had opened the way for a fruitful economic partnership between France and West Germany.
After Jan. 1 most city employes no longer will have to sign payrolls when they receive their semi-monthly checks.

Ronald Hodges, who gave a debut recital last night in Town Hall, is a pianist of uneven attainments. At his best, he was capable of some flashy playing and an occasional sensitive turn of phrase. For the most part, however, his playing could have stood more musical character and more technical discipline.

Since 1946, when CARE's first food package was unloaded in Le Havre, France, the operations of this non-sectarian, nonpolitical agency have encircled the globe, its packages going to sixty countries. Now, on its ninth anniversary, it prepares forty different kinds of food and textile packages, and "self-help" packages that range from Braille writer kits and technical books to Korea hand tools and India and Greek plows.

Puccini's "La Boheme" had two Rodolfos last night at the City Center. Davis Cunningham, the tenor who sang the part through the first act, found himself unable to continue, so Jon Crain, who was standing by as understudy, took over and sang the role through the three final acts.
Prices of cotton futures eased in trading last week. Active contracts at the week's close showed net losses ranging from 20 to 32 points, or $1 to $1.60 a bale.

When what is now called western music first came into the world, it had the dawn-like freshness of something that had scarcely touched the earth, and on Saturday night the New York Pro Musica Antiqua gave an audience an idea of how that freshness blew through England in the reigns from Henry V to Henry VIII.

In a letter published Oct. 20 Dr. William L. Bennett comments on your use of the word "tolerance" in your editorial on Oct. 12 titled "A Victory for Tolerance." He says, "Tolerance implies a superior and inferior relationship," and "is a situation which we in America could well do without."

Last September Governor Meyner of New Jersey signed a bill calling for a referendum in the forthcoming election on a $25 million bond issue to create a state medical-dental school and health center. The voters of New Jersey must decide whether or not the center will come into being.
Let's remove one albatross from President Eisenhower's neck. We can do this by refusing to return Representative Frederic Coudert to Washington.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 23 -- The Congressional campaign, in the upper Middle West and Mountain Belt at least, has now come down to two clear issue patterns.
The Giants concluded the "soft touch" phase of their National Football League schedule with a 24-7 victory over the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
John P. McGrath, Democratic campaign manager, accused Governor Dewey last night of deliberately distorting the facts about Averell Harriman's financial connection with Polish mines.
Welfare Commissioner Henry McCarthy praised yesterday the child care agencies of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York for their pioneering efforts in combating juvenile delinquency.

French sardines with an unusual savor are the newest imports of Cresca Company, Inc. One type is packed in butter, another with sliced truffles and a third with lemon slices and juice. Prepared especially for the importing firm by sardine factories in Brittany, the tinned fish are available at B. Altman and Gimbels.

South Africa each day is becoming less African and more American, or possibly Canadian or Australian. That is the way it looks on the surface to the newcomer despite Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan and his policy of apartheid, or racial segregation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Those familiar yellow stop signs at traffic intersections soon may be red and white, according to a recommendation by the National Joint Committee on Uniform Traffic Control Devices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Eisenhower today called members of his Cabinet to the White House tomorrow night for a report from Secretary of State Dulles on the agreements on West Germany signed in Paris yesterday.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Monday, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A United States Air Force C-47 with twenty-one persons aboard was reported missing today over the Mediterranean Sea.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that the output of edible vegetable oils and lard this season might be about 300,000,000 pounds above estimated domestic use and commercial exports.

A new wrinkle: Originally, the brokers weren't to get any tickets for "Fanny" until after Jan. 15, a rare step in the annals of ticket distribution. David Merrick and Joshua Logan, sponsors of the musical drama arriving Nov. 4 at the Majestic with Ezio Pinza and Walter Slezak starred, felt the theatregoing public was entitled to first call. And that's what happened.

The Concert Society of New York opened its second season yesterday with the first of the sixteen concerts it will give during 1954-55 at Town Hall. The event began shortly after 5:30, for the society continues to utilize the concert hour it inherited after the demise of the New Friends of Music.

The seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Monica, Seventy-ninth Street, east of First Avenue, was observed there yesterday with a solemn jubilee mass at which Cardinal Spellman presided. There was a capacity congregation of 1,800.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 24 -- Governor General Ghulam Mohammed declared a state of emergency throughout Pakistan today.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A three-man Austrian expedition has conquered Mount Cho Oyu, the world's seventh highest peak, reports to Katmandu said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- American service men will be subjected to tougher discipline designed to prepare them in possible eventualities to cope with such brutality as was inflicted on American prisoners of war by the Communists in Korea, Defense Department officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- A Post Office spokesman said today that there was nothing unusual about the number of postmasters who had been dismissed since the Republican Administration took office.
The letter to The Times of the Scandinavian newspaper correspondent Gunner Leistokow, with reference to the recent dismissal of three Hunter College professors, penetrates through form to substance.
