Foreign exchange passed through a quiet and uneventful week. Business was in good volume, but so far British sterling was concerned it fell slightly under that done during the height of the dollar demand in London several weeks back.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Bishop Fulton J. Sheen said today that Roman Catholics wanted to make Christians out of the Russian people, not exterminate them.

Authorities in drama, dance and music have been named to serve on advisory panels for the purpose of sending representative American attractions abroad under a plan fostered by the State Department and to be carried out through the American National Theatre and Academy. The list, announced yesterday, includes:

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Coast Guard said tonight that it had received radio reports from a Honduran ship, the Launa, that she was "in a sinking condition" about ninety miles northwest of San Salvador in the Bahama Islands.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Ed Furgol, surprise winner of the United States Open, today was designated 1954's "golfer of the year" by the Professional Golfers Association.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Dr. John von Neumann, nominated to the five-man Atomic Energy Commission, predicted yesterday a long waiting period before atomic energy could be used economically.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- Increased emphasis is placed on foreign policy in slogans for the thirty-seventh anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution, which appeared today on the front pages of all Moscow morning newspapers.

Tenants were warned yesterday not to sign any applications of landlords to the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission without making certain that all facts were properly reported on the application form.
Clement D. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, defined the American free enterprise system yesterday as a profit-and-loss system.

Refusing to waver before their league-leading rivals, the New York Rangers registered a 4-to-2 triumph over the Canadiens of Montreal last night at Madison Square Garden. The victory was the Blues' second in two games on the local rink in the National Hockey League season, and the outcome was cheered by the greater part of a crowd of 13,270 fans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Eisenhower declared tonight that Americans must "jealously guard" their foundation in faith.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Democratic control of the next Senate by a narrow margin was indicated today in a state-by-state electoral survey by correspondents of The New York Times.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The prospects for early settlement of the dock strike that has tied up London and a number of other British ports receded today when strikers here voted not to return until the employers agreed that all overtime work be voluntary.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The thing that changed Republican election campaign strategy into an all-out attack on the Democrats was The New York Daily News poll on the gubernatorial race in New York.
Twenty-eight persons prominent in communication, public opinion and international affairs have formed a voluntary committee to emphasize the importance of an overseas information program.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Kathy Copps and her 6-year-old brown gelding, Bravo, teamed to capture the lion's share of the blue ribbons at the Saddle Tree Farms horse show today. In events where the horse was judged, Bravo gained three blues and the division championship.

Newspaper linage in fifty-two cities showed slight losses both for September and for the first nine months of the year, according to figures from Media Records yesterday. The losses were 0.3 and 1.7 per cent, respectively.
OTTAWA, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Federal authorities are planning to tighten the Government's control over the export of water power to the United States.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 24 -- In a letter to Premier Ngo Dinh Diem, President Eisenhower has expressed the hope that "indispensable reforms" would be carried out by South Vietnam in connection with the receipt of United States aid.
More people were being treated for mental illness last year than ever before in the nation's history, the National Association for Mental Health was told last night.

Net assets of the Massachusetts Investors Trust, the oldest and largest open-end investment company, reached $695,642,528 at Sept. 30. This was equal to $24.84 each on the 28,000,028 shares outstanding, which are owned by 118,684 shareholders.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- In the last week there has been no faltering in the stock markets. The pace of the upward movement in security prices has increased to such an extent that only on one or two occasions this year has the rise in industrial shares equaled that of the last few days.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24, (UP) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles will face an unexpected crisis on his return tomorrow from conferences in Europe and a swim in Bermuda.
Autumn provided ideal weather and Coney Island the proper setting yesterday for ground-breaking for the first stage of the projected $10,000,000 city Aquarium.

NEWARK, Oct. 24 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, said today that President Eisenhower had not associated himself with the Republican leadership in New Jersey because of the scandals connected with the Republican regime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan said in a recorded interview released today that the dispute between India and Pakistan over water rights was "very serious" and might cause a war if not settled soon.

All automobile owners of New York City are undoubtedly aware of the great problems of traffic control in that area, but it seems to me that their efforts to solve them are sterile. Too much reliance is placed on the hope that some miracle worker in the form of a Traffic Commissioner will do the trick.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 24 -- President Eisenhower will have the backing of industry if he asks the incoming Congress to broaden unemployment insurance coverage, according to views expressed here today by members of the Business Advisory Council.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Republican leaders may ask President Eisenhower to make a whirlwind speaking tour in an attempt to win the mid-term election.
TOKYO, Oct. 24 -- Japanese defense authorities have asked that 10 per cent of the nation's budgeted expenses next year go into the build-up of military forces.

The Fifteenth Congressional District is the largest in area in the city. It takes in all of Staten Island's fifty-seven square miles -- almost three times the size of Manhattan -- then skips across the Narrows to bite a large, irregular-shaped wedge out of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet appeal yesterday for new four-power talks on Germany was considered by some observers here to be a response to recent speeches by the French Premier, Pierre Mendes-France.
The seeds of modern political democracy were "planted in the Protestant Reformation," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India is seeking precise safeguards against Communist subversion in South and Southeast Asia during his visit to Communist China, diplomatic sources said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 24 -- Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administrator, arrived this afternoon at a time when Yugoslav economic difficulties are acute. The question of continued United States aid is in the forefront of Yugoslav planning consideration.
LONDON, Monday, Oct. 25 -- The Warsaw radio announced this morning that Hermann Field, an American jailed in Communist Poland, had been released from prison and cleared of the charges against him.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Strong winds swept smog out of the Los Angeles basin today and removed the need for Gov. Goodwin J. Knight's demands that oil companies close refineries.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,335,592,605. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
SAIGON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower in his letter said he expected the South Vietnam Government to carry out "needed reforms" in exchange for increased direct aid.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP) -- High-powered running by Paul (Tank) Younger and Dan Towler bowled over the Chicago Bears and gave the Los Angeles Rams a 42-38 victory in a National Football League game today.
A FINE SHOW! That was "Light's Diamond Jubilee," seen last night for two hours over most of the country's television stations.

IN the Book of Isaiah the questioner called out: "Watchman, what of the night? Watchman, what of the night?" And the watchman said: "The morning cometh and also the night." In other words, yes and no; reasonable expectations will probably be fulfilled, but there is no reason for particular optimism.
If the voters of the Fourteenth Congressional District in Brooklyn follow tradition, Democratic Representative John James Rooney will be re-elected to his seventh consecutive term in the House.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Government prosecutors said today they would confer tomorrow to decide the Government's next step in the perjury case against Prof. Owen Lattimore.

NEWARK, Oct. 24 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator, declared today that the Democrats were doing a lot of talking about unemployment while he was content to do something about it.

The contract bridge team of Mrs. Peggy Adams, Murray Schnee, Fred Bickel and Dave Strasberg, all of New York, last night won the open team-of-four championship, final event of the 1954 annual Metropolitan Contract Bridge Championships.
A leading missionary sought yesterday to allay the fears of many persons in this country that India and its Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, are Communistic.

SCOUTS from Navy do a private eye job on Army in every cadet game, warily watching for weaknesses that the midshipmen can exploit in the service classic a month hence. It took Columbia to reveal an alarming crack in the Black Knight facade. Not until the West Pointers clashed with the Lions at Baker Field on Saturday did anyone realize the hopeless inadequacy of the Army third team.

Don Kissinger scored three touchdowns as Xavier High School routed St. John's Prep, 41 -- 6, at Randall's Island yesterday. The victory was Xavier's third in tour games. St. John's has won two of five.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- The wheat market showed a strong price trend last week, with more commission accumulation than for some time. The May delivery made a new high for the crop year. Buying of wheat appeared to be predicated on unfavorable crop reports from various parts of the world.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, asserted yesterday that a former law partner of Governor Dewey had obtained enactment of a law making it "harder for minority stockholders" to sue for damages.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 24 Tjong Hoen Nji, Indonesia's leading Chinese anti-Communist, was secretly flown under guard today to Macassar, capital of Celebes, for possible deportation from there.

Most teen-age girls, despite the popularity of bobby socks and baggy flannel shirts, have a strong fashion consciousness. This they prove when they engage friends in hour-long conversations on what to wear to the next big school event.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- World-wide observance of the ninth anniversary of the United Nations today pivoted upon the first public concert ever staged at headquarters of the world organization. Nearly 3,000 persons filled the General Assembly hall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The United States Office of Education announced today that it had set aside $28,431,784 to help 109 school districts in "Federally affected" defense areas construct school buildings and additions.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The Green Bay Packers came from behind in the third period today to defeat the Baltimore Colts, 7 -- 6, in a hard-fought contest between the two Western Division tail-enders of the National Football League.

RUSH-HOUR moles paused in mid-scurry through Times Square subway station the other morning when the loudspeakers broke out with: "Passenger Brady. Passenger Brady. Please come to the dispatcher's office on the southbound platform."

People in general have adopted the obviously inspired idea of calling hurricanes by individual names. Seeing a telephone pole straddling two trees after the storm is over, one says quite naturally, "Look what Hazel did."

WASHINGTON Oct. 24 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, said today United States soldiers in World War II "were taught the Communist line by men wearing the American uniform" from the time they entered the Army until they were mustered out.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Census Bureau estimated today that the nation had a civilian population last July 1 of 159,084,000.

The Army football team that trampled Columbia may not be the best in the college ranks but is there any that excels it in the zeal, abandon and violence with which it runs, blocks and tackles? Where is there one more fanatical in carrying out assignments regardless of the physical impact?

In anticipation of next week's spook and goblin parties, some advice for keeping young celebrants safe is offered by the Toy Guidance Council. And a new booklet gives ideas on Halloween entertainment.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Viktor Schreckengost .of Cleveland won first prize in the eighteenth Ceramic National exhibit that opened yesterday at the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts.

Rarely is a youthful pianist encountered nowadays blessed with the sensitivity, the innate musicality and the ability to absorb the attention that was made known by Thomas Brockman in his third New York recital, given yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. has found himself confronted with a rift between his top uniformed command and spokesmen for the firemen's line organizations over whether firemen should be permitted to accept spare-time employment.

Barbara Ward of The London economist, known for her writings on economics and public affairs, has a new book on Norman's list for Nov. 8 that departs from her special topics. In "Faith and Freedom," Miss Ward explores the relation between political freedom and religious faith. The reviews the attempts by grants of both revolution and action to build societies without freedom.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- On the night of Nov. 2, Adlai E. Stevenson, 1952 Presidential candidate and titular head of the Democratic party, will seat himself before a television set in his home at Libertyville, Ill., to learn the decision of the voters.
As far as I know no charges have ever been preferred against Senator McCarthy for his serious abuse of the franking privilege. All members of the Senate could be adversely affected by this abuse.
An international conference, bringing together men and women who have risen to distinction in various fields within the nations of the Western Hemisphere, will open here this morning.

Pakistan is going through something of a political upheaval. The Governor General has dissolved the constituent Assembly and dismissed the Cabinet. A state of emergency has been declared. Fortunately, the Governor General has called upon Mohammed Ali, Pakistan's strong and able Prime Minister, to construct a new Cabinet.

The Radio Corporation of America, one of the country's largest electronic, manufacturing and communications concerns, reported yesterday that its sales of products and services hit a new high in the first nine months of this year.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday that his challenge list contained a record 11,366 names of irregular registrants who must bring proof of their voting qualifications to the polls on Eelection Day.
Harry P. Morr, Democratic leader of the Fifth Assembly District in Brooklyn, was named yesterday as second Deputy Fire Commissioner by Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

WHEN a ragged old man is found dead of starvation in a dirty basement room and the police discover that he had $100,000 in the bank and as much more in his mattress regular newspaper readers are not surprised. They are accustomed to reading about pathetic eccentrics who withdraw from human contacts and prefer to live in misery rather than spend a small amount of their hoarded wealth.

The Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, burned the mortgage yesterday on St. Barnabas House at 304 Mulberry Street. A few minutes later he formally consecrated the St. Barnabas House Chapel.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 25 -- A "baby" African lion (eighty pounds of prowling curiosity) strolled casually out of his cage today, to the dismay of the neighborhood, for a close look at his new Long Island home. Consternation reigned for ninety minutes, but a suburban safari of residents, firemen and police managed to coax him back safely into his pen.
The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico borrowed $10,000,000 in the public market here yesterday on an issue of general improvement bonds at an interest cost of 2.1649 per cent.

All those who know and love the scenic and historic Hudson Valley are concerned over the threat to the charming villages of Piermont, Grand View and the Nyacks constituted by the proposed commercial highway link between the Thruway and the New Jersey Turnpike.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The eight-man Philadelphia syndicate seeking to complete the purchase of the Philadelphia Athletics was granted an extension tonight to await American League approval before paying the Mack family for the stock.

A series of one-minute films of "puppet shows" featuring the Democratic donkey, Republican elephant and Mr. or Mrs. John Q. Public will be spotted throughout the state on television for the rest of the campaign.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Optimism about a quick settlement of the dock strike that had kept the stock markets buoyant, despite its growing seriousness in the last couple of weeks, petered out today.
TRIESTE, Oct. 25 -- Yugoslavia's troops moved early today into a few square miles of arid, unproductive land she had won in the Trieste settlement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Republicans decided to keep Secretary of State John Foster Dulles out of the political campaign a month ago, but he proved tonight to be one of their effective campaigners.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- The five downtown department stores rejected as "ridiculous" today a peace proposal of leaders of Local 249, General Teamsters, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, A. F. L., calling for a 25-cent-an-hour pay increase and other benefits to end their eleven-month strike.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Wheat continued to display strength today, showing a capacity for absorbing profit-taking sales that was surprising to local operators. Some mill buying appeared in the pit but it was not of specially large volume.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I O., charged yesterday that transit service in this city was "the most inefficient in the world" and that plans were afoot to reduce it 25 per cent more after next week's elections.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Lou Boudreau, deposed manager of the Boston Red Sox, today tabbed the American League as "very weak" and oredicted that Ted Williams would be back playing for Boston next season.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Despite diplomatic pressure, Britain has failed to obtain an Egyptian commitment on free navigation for all shipping through the Suez Canal.
The Whitney Museum of American Art, a Greenwich Village landmark that vanished from its home scene a few months ago, is reopening today on Fifty-fourth Street, in the center of art activities here.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 25 (UP) -- Ty Shea, racing secretary, today counted up the probable starters for the $100,000 added Garden State Stakes next Saturday and predicted that sixteen 2-year-olds, would race for the richest purse in the history of the turf.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- A back-to-work movement began among London dockworkers this morning, but it was counterbalanced by the addition of Manchester to British ports affected by the strike, which began three weeks ago.

The unbeaten string of Carmelo Costa, Brooklyn featherweight, ended at twenty-six last night when he lost a split decision to Rudy Garcia of Los Angeles in the main event of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The persistent hope in some business circles that the Supreme Court might nullify state fair trade laws entered the "forlorn" category today as the tribunal rejected attacks upon the New York and New Jersey statutes.

We have given our support to Senator Ives as candidate for Governor and we also endorse his Republican ticket for the several state offices. We do this, first, on the ground that a Governor is entitled to an immediate Cabinet on which he can count for full cooperation in the tasks of government.
Averell Harriman derided last night Republican attempts to "smear" him as desperate "reaching for straws" and declared the chief issues of the campaign were still unemployment and farm prices.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, made a flying visit from Washington tonight for a television speech urging re-election of Representative Robert W. Kean.
The Eastman Kodak Company received the "gold oscar of industry" last night for its annual report to stockholders. The report was judged the best of 5,000 entries.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, and Arthur Levitt, Democratic candidate for Controller, shared the speakers' platform yesterday at the monthly luncheon-meeting of the Urban League of Greater New York.
PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Premier Pierre Meffd@s-France has begun important talks to enlarge his Cabinet and strengthen his majority in Parliament.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Erwin N. Griswold, Dean of the Harvard Law School, announced today that the school would institute a study of public opinion and persuasion in law practice.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A neighbor boy on horseback today found the missing three young sons of Bob Crosby, bandleader. The boys' disappearance before supper yesterday touched off an all-night search by ninety policemen in rugged hills near the Crosby home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Leland Olds, former chairman of the Federal Power Commission, declared today that the proposed Dixon-Yates contract was the first step to destroy the Tennessee Valley Authority as a yardstick for the utility field.
Another milestone in the postwar history of Europe was reached, at least on paper with the signing in Paris last week of the multilateral agreements providing for the armament of West Germany.
A New York couple who took to the woods discovered unexpectedly they had culinary talent. Evidence of it is a delicious blueberry jam now making its first appearance in local delicacy shops.

In its first eight months of operation, the Monthly Investment Plan of the New York Stock Exchange has attracted 23,000 investors. Keith Funston, president of the Exchange, announced yesterday that $6,700,000 worth of listed stocks have been bought in plans that, if completed, will contain $56,700,000 of original investments.

Women headed by Mrs. Bedell H. Harned and including Mrs. Alan T. Schumacher are active in the plans for the annual card party and fashion show for the benefit of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service, Inc., of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

Facts designed to influence decisions on tariff rates will be gathered by the United States Department of Commerce. It will assemble data on the essentiality of workers in industry in an effort to guide tariff changes to help the industries.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UP) -- The Department of the Interior today announced a reorganization of the Bureau of Mines to provide separate programs for health, safety and coal mine inspection.

A sharp attack by a Bolivian on the United States role in the Guatemalan civil war enlivened yesterday the opening of Columbia University's bicentennial conference on "Responsible Freedom in the Americas."

Within the past few days several moves have been reported in curbing the dangerous and wasteful false alarms of fire with which the city has been plagued. Last week Fire Commissioner Cavanagh and Assistant Superintendent of Schools Baldwin set up a pilot program in some of the Harlem schools to persuade teenagers not to send in false alarms.

RAMSEY, N.J., Oct. 25 -- A father and his son were killed and fifteen other persons were injured, three seriously, at 5:15 P.M. today when a commuter bus and a fuel-oil truck collided on Route 17 here. Rush-hour traffic piled up for an hour as a result of the accident, which set the engine of the truck afire.

Chico Varona of Havana out-pointed Johnny Bratton, who was making his first start in eight months, in the main bout of ten rounds at St. Nicholas Arena last night. Bratton weighed 155 1/4 pounds, five more than the Cuban welterweight.
Isidore Dollinger was first elected to the House of Representatives from the Bronx's Twenty-third District in 1948. He is extremely confident of another two-year term after the Nov. 2 election.

THOMAS SCHERMAN never quits trying. Starting his eighth season at the head of the Little Orchestra Society, which he founded, he showed at Town Hall last night that his zest for unhackneyed program-making has not diminished.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Sixteen Jewish organizations protested to Secretary of State Dulles today against arming the Arab states as long as they refuse to make peace with Israel.

WALTER B. DEVEREUX was thrown from a horse for the first time at the tender age of 6. Twelve years later he learned to play polo against cowboys, which is about as healthy a pastime as playing football in a rock quarry. A decade and a half ago he was chief nursemaid to seventy-five horses at National Guard maneuvers in Plattsburg with the lofty rank of stable sergeant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The boldest Democratic strategy in this campaign is to persuade the voters that, instead of invoking a "cold" partisan war between Congress and the Executive, their choice of Democratic majorities at the Capitol will have the opposite effect and actually be of assistance to the President in rounding out the programs on which his party will go to the country in 1956.

Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger and Arthur A. Houghton Jr. have been elected members of the executive committee of the Empire State Foundation of Independent Libral Arts Colleges. This was announced yesterday at a meeting of the foundation's board, held in the Columbia-Colgate Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Jozef Swiatlo, former official of the Polish secret police, declared today that his defection to the West had forced the Warsaw Government to clear Hermann Field, United States architect, and announce his release.

The nonstop transcontinental flights that caused a twenty-five-day strike by American Airlines pilots last summer will continue, under a "preliminary" arbitration award yesterday by David L. Cole, former director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 25 (AP) -- France's two representatives, Norman and Banassa, were flown in today on the first of three flights bringing horses to Laurel's international race on Nov. 3.

Robert Lehman's Countess Fleet had an easy time of it in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. Competing in a mile-and-a-sixteenth test against five others of her sex, the 3-year-old daughter of Count Fleet scored by a length over Stephen Messana's Old Baasket. C. V. Whitney's Carry The News was third.
The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that its operations had fallen off substantially this year because of a cut in defense orders.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 25 -- Delegates of Colombia and other coffee-exporting countries are reported en route here for a conference on how to keep coffee prices up, but nobody here will admit knowing anything about it.
Right after the Democratic State Convention last month, Averell Harriman consulted a physician because of a cold.

The general chairmanship of the Salvation Army's 1955 appeal in New York has been accepted by Burl S. Watson, president of the Cities Service Company. Mr. Watson held the same post in the 1954 campaign, in which the goal was $1,250,000 and the amount raised was $1,260,383.

The attention which you directed to the Woodrow Wilson Fellowships in your editorial of Oct. 22 is most encouraging. I sincerely hope it will help further to alert people to the need facing our American colleges and universities for promising young men and women to replenish the teaching profession.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- South Carolina voters today are puzzling over an unusual political question. By election day, they must decide how they stand on dueling.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 17 -- A rotating, motor-driven toothbrush from Norway, machinery gears from the Netherlands and a miniature vacuum cleaner from Germany are some of the thousands of plastic items on display here at the International Plastics Exhibition, which closes today.
ROME, Oct. 25 -- The Italian Government is extremely eager to ratify the Paris agreements creating a Western European Union -- but not before France does.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The United States repeated today its earlier endorsement of the principle of an international development fund, but proclaimed again its inability to participate at present.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Ernie Durando, 160 1/2 pounds, Bayonne, N.J., won a ten-round split decision over Bobby Dykes, 158 3/4, Miami, tonight, on the strength of an eight-round knockdown.
An international collection of fashions was presented yesterday by Bergdorf-Goodman at the Sheraton Astor Hotel for the benefit of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- The Jersey Central Lines announced today that new tariffs calling for an increase of about 10 per cent in its commutation fares have been filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington.

The fitted, draped bodice with narrow, high lines marking the bosom was one of the current trends in evening fashions noted at the Jay Thorpe presentation of Rudolf gowns yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Wool prices dropped sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops ended 4.9 to 5.6 cents a pound lower and grease wool was off 3 to 5.4 cents. The prices declined in sympathy with weakness in the Australian and South African auctions and lower quotations in the London market.
FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., Oct. 25 -- Senator Irving M. Ives opened the final week of the Republican state campaign today with charges that the Democrats were incapable of ending unemployment.

Despite some disagreement over details, the network of agreements signed in Paris is being hailed as a historic step that could initiate a new era. These agreements advance the unity of Western Europe, fortify the North Atlantic alliance and thereby strengthen the cause of peace and freedom.
MONTREAL, Oct. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Jean Drapeau, a foe of rackets, was elected Mayor of Montreal today.
The annual conference of the Society for Advancement of Management opening Thursday at the Statler Hotel will feature specialists in distribution and management.

The Shell Oil Company reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $26,109,365 after charges and taxes, or 95 cents a share on the outstanding common stock. This compares with $30,736,156, or $1.12 a share, in the third quarter of 1953.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Chairman Edward F. Howrey of the Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had ordered "a speedy but thorough investigation of the current wave of mergers."
Retail prices of eggs have declined again since last Friday. Large Grade A's now average 63 cents a dozen, considered unusually low for this time of year.

Of all the many reasons for welcoming Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, to the United States today the pleasantest is that she is so nice. To be a queen is a historic accident of birth or marriage. Even where the sovereigns reign but do not govern, as in Britain, it is a position of heavy duty and responsibility.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a lower court decision limiting the power of the President to discharge Government employes without cause.
LINDEN, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Clifford P. Case called today for the support of working men to help keep the Republican party open to labor.

The Imogene Coca television show is being put through a stage of reorganization in an effort to help it find the proper niche. A spokesman for the comedienne said yesterday that Miss Coca had asked the National Broadcasting Company to "take over" and produce the program.

HONG KONG, Oct. 25 -- A member of the Japanese Diet group that visited Communist China said today the delegation had been told by Premier Chou En-lai the Peiping Government wanted to establish "normal relations" with Japan on the basis of its five "coexistence" principles.

Two "great patriots and phenomenal men who made modern Peru and Chile" are the subjects of a narrative biography entitled "O'Higgins and Don Bernardo" by Mrs. Edna Deu Pree Nelson. In the middle of the eighteenth century, Ambrose Higgins left Ireland, and sought his fortune in Spain.
The first of two Notre Dame visits to the Atlantic seaboard and a heavy schedule of Conference games in all sections mark the college football program this week.
LONDON, 0ct. 25 (UP) -- Americans in Warsaw and along the Iron Curtain kept a sharp lookout tonight for Hermann Field.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 24 -- The United States will give Iran about $120,000,000 in technical and economic assistance in the current fiscal year, William Warne, United States Point Four director in Iran, said tonight.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 25 -- The Pakistani press hailed today the dissolution or Parliament by Gov. Gen. Chulam Mohammed and the reshuffle of the Cabinet by Prime Minister Mohammed Ali.

Police Commissioner Francis W.H. Adams announced yesterday the reorganization of the Traffic Division. It will be reduced from eighteen to twelve precincts. The change will make eighty-six administrative men available for active traffic patrol duty.

The Armco Steel Corporation, which now is operating at about 90 per cent of capacity, increased its net profit to $29,168,478 in the first nine months this year from $26,121,317 a year ago, despite substantially lower sales.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A cheap clay, shredded and baked until it resembles Chinese noodles, promises to ease or solve the problem of disposing of the deadly atomic waste products.
THE Blackfriars Guild, whose forte long has been serious devotional drama, hit on a happy change of pace last evening with a comedy, called "Slightly Delinquent."
Staten Island bus riders got a short-term compromise of normal service yesterday after a week of wrestling with a union-inspired slowdown.
The maximum term of ten to twenty years was imposed in Kings County Court yesterday on Thomas Wysokowski, 17-year-old convicted slayer of a Brooklyn man.
Stocks opened strong yesterday, began to crumble in the second hour and continued to break until the final thirty minutes, when there was a slightly steadier tone.

Of the 1,800,000 miles of hard surfaced roads in this country (exclusive of city streets), only half is suitable to support modern, high-speed traffic, Senator Charles E. Potter of Michigan declared yesterday.

ASBURY, Park, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, accused the Republican Administration today of "false economy" and advocacy of "a second-best prosperity."
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Mexican Army tonight took its second blue ribbon and the first leg of the international low-score competition at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
Whatever contest there is in the Twenty-second Bronx Congressional District centers about second place.

There are more "millionaire" advertisers than ever before. Thirty-one concerns joined the ranks of those spending $1,000,000 or more in seven major media combined in 1953. This makes the total of elite advertisers 255. All of this is to be reported in a tabulation in the Printers' Ink 1955 Advertisers' Annual, to be published on Friday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Two women were released from the Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard murder trial jury today in the first round of peremptory challenges that could wipe out the entire panel selected last week.

TOMS RIVER, N. J., Oct. 25 -- The football drought appears to be over at Admiral Farragut Academy. The Middies, who had won only twice in twenty-eight games over a four-year span, are unbeaten so far this season. There are some who have begun to talk in terms of an undefeated campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, eulogized his predecessor, the late Fred M. Vinson, today as an "eminent lawyer, legislator, administrator, statesman, jurist and, above all, great humanitarian."

HONG KONG, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- The British newspaper China Mail called today for strong British Government pressure on the United States to stop "gross and intolerable interference" with legitimate trade done with Communist China.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 25 -- Max Smith of Plandome and Vee Lawkins, unattached, clipped five strokes from par with a 30, 35 -- 65 score today for first place in the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro tournament at the Fresh Meadow Club.

The New York State Wholesale Beer Distributors Association was warned yesterday of a growing trend toward reduction in the number of breweries through merger or the elimination of the small, family-owned enterprise.
The football teams of Army and Navy were highly praised yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's.
Colorful towels as well as sheet and blanket designs are some of the new furnishings for the linen closet.

A trial lawyer told a state body investigating court delays yesterday that in suits against the city in 1952 he had collected $285,000 in excess of the amounts sought in settlement of the cases. Moe Levine, an attorney with offices at 15 Park Row, testified at a public hearing of the Subcommittee on Calendar Congestion and Delays at 270 Broadway.
The subcommittee on business and finance of the Mayor's Advisory Council recommended yesterday that a Department of Commerce and Special Events be established in the city government.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 25 -- Marshal Tito said today that in his opinion Moscow's foreign policy had changed and that the change was contributing to an easing of international tension. He rejected the suspicion that the move was a Soviet trap.

Events today: John Cartwright, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; "Der Rosenkavalier," City Center 8:15 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski conducting, Gary Graffman, pianist, Carnegie Hall; concert in celebration of the ninetieth birthday of Alexander Gretchaninoff, Town Hall; Grace Marschall-Loepke, composer-pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, all at 8:30.

The New York Rangers yesterday called up Louis Fontinato, fiery defenseman from the Vancouver Canucks, to replace the injured Allan Stanley. Fontinato will arrive in time for this afternoon's workout and will be ready for tomorrow night's game with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

POCATELLO, Idaho, Oct. 25 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon slashed directly today at the issue of communism in Government by naming five Democratic candidates for the Senate in Western states as "members of the Left Wing of their party."

"New York Philharmonic-Symphony Week," officially proclaimed by Mayor Wagner, was opened yesterday afternoon with a cocktail party and reception held in the home of Mrs. Richard S. Reem at 4 East Sixty-sixth Street.

Oscar S. Straus 2d, president of the Theodore Roosevelt Association, released yesterday a statement explaining why Ralph J. Bunche was the unanimous choice of the organization's executive committee to receive its distinguished service medal.
A meeting of the National Association for Mental Health heard yesterday that increasing research into schizophrenia was paving the way toward better understanding of "the great enigma of psychiatry."

The nation's steelmakers have scheduled operations this week at 74.3 per cent of theoretical capacity, equal to production of 1,772,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday.

Governor Dewey told a television audience last night that his Administration had brought new industries with payrolls of $80,000,000 a year into the state and had created 380,000 jobs in the building of highways and hospitals alone.
PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The French reaction to the protocols signed Saturday to admit an armed West Germany into the North Atlantic alliance has been mixed.

The Glenn L. Martin Company yesterday resumed the payment of dividends after nearly eight years with the declaration of $1 in cash, payable Dec. 13, and 10 per cent in stock, payable Dec. 15. The last payment received by stockholders was 75 cents in March, 1947.

FROM its intimate but long outgrown quarters on Eighth Street in three remodeled houses, the Whitney Museum of American Art has contrived to carry with it into new and modern quarters at 22 West Fifty-fourth Street a considerable part of the warmth and intimacy of character that endeared it to art lovers over its twenty-three years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- An Administration agriculture official asserted today that "we hope eventually to get the Government out of the food business, or at least substantially to reduce Governmental activities in that field."

Obviously the primary purpose of President Eisenhower's message to Vietnam was to strengthen a Government which is all too shaky. We are in a position in which we must encourage rather than admonish. If we have made it easier for the Vietnamese Prime Minister to solve his complex and frustrating problem of setting up a sound and responsible Government through the assurance of our support, so much the better.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Eisenhower foresaw tonight a $500,000,000,000 American economy in less than ten years and committed himself to the means of achieving it.
Kenya's Mau Mau rebellion involves such questions as who owns Africa and what life is about rather than who should govern. It is the question of social justice in the context of the primitive world.
There will be two off-Broadway openings tonight.
Following is the text of an address last night by President Eisenhower at the eleventh annual dinner of the National Security Industrial Association, as recorded by The New York Times:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- A recommendation by Mayor Wagner of New York that the state change its method of apportioning aid to education drew heavy criticism today at the annual meeting here of the State School Boards Association.

For the tenth consecutive month the number of persons on the public assistance rolls increased in September, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday. Without "a more rapid re-employment rate," Mr. McCarthy warned, the number will continue to rise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- W. Randolph Burgess, Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs, told today how "indirect controls of vast potentialities" were used to check inflation in this country without precipitating recession.
Operations of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, Inc., in the nine months ended with September resulted in a net income of $23,383,688 compared with $18,654,083 in the same period last year.

Henry W. Grunewald, Washington "influence peddler," and Daniel A. Bolich, former top tax official, were indicted yesterday in a tax-bribe case. The Government charged that $200,000 in bribes had passed.

Stockholders of the Hotels Statler Company, Inc., voted yesterday to liquidate the company. At a special meeting in the Statler Hotel here, approval was given to sell the hotel chain company assets to the Hilton Hotels Corporation.
ALCOA, Tenn., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Aluminum Company of America announced today plans to build a new $10,000,000 hydroelectric dam on the Little Tennessee River.

There was a disquieting advertisement in the papers the other day. It said in effect that Thanksgiving shortly is coming, and in order to play safe it would be well to begin thinking of the turkey. So far so good, for it never is too early to begin thinking of the Thanksgiving turkey.

A set of twenty LP records of contemporary music is being sent to each of 400 educational institutions in this country and 100 in Europe and South America by the Pittsburgh International Contemporary Music Festival. This was announced yesterday by Roy Harris, director of the festival.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed somewhat irregular yesterday, down 3 points to 8 points up, on a moderate volume.
Net income of the National Biscuit Company in the quarter, nine and twelve-month periods ending Sept. 30 exceeded those of the corresponding periods in 1953, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Library of Congress, now sorting some 3,000 negatives acquired recently from the vast collections of Matthew B. Brady, famous Civil War photographer, made available today three of the negatives so far catalogued.

Terms of a three-year agreement covering 3,000 department store drivers in the metropolitan area were disclosed yesterday by Burton A. Zorn, Counsel for United Parcel Service. The workers belong to four locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., in New York and New Jersey.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 25 -- A divided church is inadequate for a world that is in convulsion, Dr. Cleveland Kleihauer of Hollywood, Calif., told almost 10,000 delegates at the opening session of the international convention of Disciples of Christ tonight.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- This country's railroads, essential for national defense, are not now prepared to do the kind of job that would be thrust upon them should another war develop suddenly, James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said here today.

The new management of the New York Central Railroad, which took office June 14, cut operating expenses $10,342,108 last month to $46,169,262. With gross down $12,921,614 to $56,516,509, however, net income fell to $1,070,442, or 17 cents a share, from $3,572,484, or 55 cents a share, in 1953, the company announced yesterday.

YONKERS, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Stanley Dancer drove Bear Cat to victory in the featured $4,000 Broadway Pace tonight on the Grand Circuits program at Yonkers Raceway. Thomas Hat was second, and Knight's Princess was third.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet representative in the United Nations, denounced today the London and Paris agreements for the arming of West Germany. He asserted that Germany was "historically a hotbed of militarism and war," and that "the immediate neighbors of Germany" would be the first to suffer.

THE rifles began popping in the Adirondacks yesterday, and according to the estimates made by the Conservation Department, the deer herd is much larger now than it was when the original inhabitants of that area stalked the woods.

Acquisition of the H. Earl Clack Company of Havre, Mont., by the Husky Oil Company was made public yesterday in a joint announcement by the two concerns. At the same time it was disclosed that the Clack interests had acquired a "sizable" block of stock in Husky Oil.
The shape of things to come in airliners was demonstrated at La Guardia Airport yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 -- Three hundred delegates from nineteen Western Hemisphere countries gathered here today for a five-day convention of the American Association of Port Authorities. Today was given over mostly to registration.
Mayor Wagner and eighty other city officials attended a luncheon yesterday to open a drive among city employes for funds for the welfare activities of Histadrut, the Israeli federation of labor.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- New York State has solved the problem of findng jobs for its convicts who are eligible for parole and awaiting release, according to a report to a nationwide meeting of wardens and prison personnel here today.

The complexity of the current African scene and the dangers of over-simplification have been emphasized in the series of articles by this newspaper's correspondent Albion Ross. For most Americans mention of Africa conjures up either a vision of Premier Malan's strife-ridden, segregationist South Africa or a picture of the innocent natives of the jungle so beloved of the moviemakers who send their cameras to the Dark Continent.
The power of a municipality to establish its own flying regulations is being tested in an action in the Federal Court, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, declared tonight that the agreements signed in Paris Saturday meant strength and unity for Western Europe. He said they would create new possibilities for peaceable discussions with the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Oct. 25 (Reuters) The Moscow radio set out tonight to answer a tricky problem created by its own propaganda -- why there was such a fierce election struggle between the Democrats and Republicans in the United States when "no serious difference exists between them."

THE first telecast of a meeting of a President's Cabinet, seen last night over all networks, was very dispirited video. The artificial touch of the professional TV hand made it seem too much an unreal stage piece and too little an executive conclave.

Donations to the New York Regional Blood Program on Friday totaled 619 points of blood. Included were 180 pints given at Time, Inc., 9 Rockefeller Plaza, to make a two-day total of 371, and 120 given at the Suffolk Air Force Base, West Hampton, L.I.

With the extension today of "This Is Cinerama" into its 109th week on Broadway, something more than a mere long-run record for a motion picture in this area is achieved. What began as a cinematic marvel and a local sight-seer's "must" is now endowed with the chronological eminence of a landmark in the entertainment realm.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- Dr. Harold A. Murray, former president of the New Jersey Medical Society, and a number of Roman Catholic priests here have joined to oppose the $25,000,000 medical-dental school bond issue, which will appear as a referendum on the Nov. 2 ballot.
The Christmas Ball, an annual subscription event for post-debutantes, bachelors and young married couples, will take place on Dec. 18 in the St. Regis Roof.
A conference on "Responsible Freedom in the Americas" began yesterday at the International Center of the Carnegie Endowment and will continue all week. One can say already that it is a success.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- The scandal-peppered liquor regulation system in California was assuming the proportions of a big political issue today, with headaches for both the Republicans and Democrats.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 25 -- The Justice Section of the Indonesian Parliament has asked Justice Minister Djody Gondokusumo to postpone the expulsion from Indonesia of Tjong Hoennji, anti-Communist leader of the Chinese minority community.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A Columbia Broadcasting System official said tonight the broadcast of President Eisenhower's Cabinet meeting grew out of a tip to C.B.S. that the White House was receptive to such an idea.

SAIGON, Oct. 25 -- Government news agency reports from Haiphong today indicated that at least 5,000 refugees had fled Vietminh rule over the week-end. They left the Tonkin coastal provinces of Phatdiem and Buichu by putting out to sea at night in rafts, rowboats and fishing junks.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- Following are unofficial translations of the German text of the French-German declaration on the Saar released by the West German Government today and letters sent by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, to Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier, under the date of Oct. 23: ...

What should be our attitude toward the recent Russian proposals at the United Nations concerning arms reduction? The crucial question is: How far do you propose to disarm -- part of the way or all the way?
Following is the text of proceedings of the special Cabinet meeting in Washington last night, as transcribed by The New York Times:
The second showing of spring sportswear lines, presented by the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers, shows signs of being an even bigger hit this year than last year.

"This Is Cinerama," the first feature film in the Cinerama wide-screen process, will set a long-run record today when it starts its 109th week on Broadway. The Lowell Thomas-Merian C. Cooper presentation now at the Warner Theatre, will break the previous 108-week mark established by the English-made "The Red Shoes" at the Bijou Theatre.

The Strick Company of Philadelphia introduced yesterday what it said was the first refrigerated truck trailer to use reinforced plastic, not only for floor, wall and ceiling panels but also for structural load-carrying beams.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Johan Beyen said tonight that the Netherlands had received secret information of a "technical nature" from Joseph S. Petersen Jr., former employe of the United States National Security Agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Federal Government demanded today that Clyde L. Powell, former Federal Housing Administration official, be sent to jail for criminal contempt in refusing to comply with a court order to answer questions before a grand jury.

Dr. Peter Marshall Murray, president of the New York County Medical Society, charged here last night that closed panel medical groups had been unfair to young doctors attempting to start practice here.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- William Wyler's first production under his new alliance with Allied Artists will be "The Friendly Persuasion," according to the director-producer's current plans.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- A united Europe, bolstered by an armed West Germany, will form the basis for negotiating an understanding with the Soviet Union, two Western leaders declared today.
A strong Atlantic gale, which is pummeling ships at sixty-four to seventy-two miles an hour, will delay the arrival of Queen Mother Elizabeth here today by at least eleven hours.
The John Wanamaker store, a fixture on Broadway at Ninth Street for fifty-eight years, will close in January.
The Giants, tied with the Philadelphia Eagles and the Pittsburgh Steelers for the Eastern Conference lead in the National Football League, heard good and bad news yesterday.

Black widow spiders that may nest in rubbish heaps, under stones, in dark sections of garages and outbuildings and around cellar windows can be exterminated by an ordinary hand spray gun loaded with lindane, chlordane or DDT.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, the nation's eleventh largest insurance concern, announced today that it had sold its home office building at 300 Broadway to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark.

PARIS, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Sandy Saddler, the world featherweight boxing champion, scored a technical knockout over France's Ray Famechon when the Frenchman was unable to come out for the sixth round of a non-title match here tonight.

Shareholders of the American Can Company will receive an extra dividend of 15 cents a common share on Dec. 15, following the regular quarterly dividend of 35 cents previously declared for payment Nov. 15. Last year no extra dividend was disbursed.
The Congo is a business concern with a policy of the open door for everyone in the company, irrespective of color. No politics is permitted.
Michael J. Quill sent a tart telegram yesterday making it quite clear that, though uninvited, he wanted to attend today's civic party commemorating the fiftieth birthday of the city's subway system."
SAIGON, Oct. 26 -- Cambodia has become the first of the Indochinese countries in which the process of liquidating the Vietminh war has been largely completed.
The text of the address by Adlai E. Stevenson, as delivered in Brooklyn last night, follows:

An oil-carrying agreement signed by the Saudi Arabian Government and Aristotle Socrates Onassis early this year is under discussion between the two principal parties at the port of Jidda on the Red Sea, according to reports received in New York yesterday.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Oct. 26 (AP) -- America's leading jockey, Willie Shoemaker, was first on five of six mounts at Tanforan today, but he hit the winner's circle only four times.

Heavy buying and short covering pushed cocoa prices up the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by reports that Russia was purchasing larger supplies of cocoa beans.

YONKERS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Knight Commander, the favorite driven by Frank Safford, easily won the $4,000 Putnam Pace on the Grand Circuit program at Yonkers Raceway tonight. King Adam was second and Rebel Land third.

Up in Herkimer County, in the village of Van Hornesville, N.Y., this is the birthday of one of our leading citizens, Owen D. Young. At the age of 80 he likes to call himself a "returned farmer," as indeed he is, for at 65 he practiced what he preached and went back home, retired, to the place where he was born.

As we have observed here on more than one occasion, the criticism directed at the Eisenhower Administration most frequently in the economic field is the highly oversimplified one that it has not maintained a continuously expanding economy.
Statistics on the oldest mode of transportation, shanks' mare, have been gathered by the Scholl Manufacturing Company of Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Republican chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee brought United States policy toward Israel directly into the political campaign today.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation disclosed plans today for a $50,000,000 improvement and expansion program at its near-by Aliquippa work and Pittsburgh plant.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The Western powers and the Soviet Union decided tonight to sponsor a resolution referring an Indian resolution on disarmament to the United Nations Disarmament Commission for study. This means that the Indian proposal will not be debated in the General Assembly.
Irving McNeil Ives has made a career of public office for twenty-four of his fifty-eight years.
The City Housing Authority opened the lists for 100 city cleaners' jobs yesterday and found itself confronted by 735 men applying for the positions.
Articles made by patients in the rehabilitation workshop of Mount Sinai Hospital will go on exhibition starting tomorrow in the Carlyle Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The State Department announced tonight that the United States Embassy in Moscow, upon orders from Washington, had strongly protested the illegal detention and mistreatment of the wives of two Embassy officers.
LONDON, Oct. 26. (Reuters) -- During the first half of 1954, Britain earned a surplus of 154,000,000 ($430,000,000) in her trade with the world.
The metropolitan area's helicopter service is being expanded partly because of outbreaks of poliomyelitis and rabies across the country.

The power to settle personal injury suits against the city should be taken from the Controller's office and given to the city's lawyers, witnesses yesterday told the state commission investigating delays in the courts.
BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter, Republican, and his Democratic opponent State Representative Robert F. Murphy, began stepping up the tempo of their campaigns today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 26 -- Shimon Orenstein, Israeli business man who was condemned to life imprisonment in Czechoslovakia in 1953 for espionage and treason, has been released, according to a Foreign Ministry statement tonight.

While this year's onion crop does not equal the near-record harvest of 1953, reports from principal growing areas indicate that this ubiquitous vegetable will be readily available in the months to come. Right now onions are recommended by the City Department of Markets as one of the most economical offering at vegetable counters.

TRIESTE, Oct. 26 -- Italian troops entered Trieste today, and nine years and four months of British-United States occupation came to an end. A gale that buffeted the city upset arrangements for ceremonies, drenching the crowds and strewing the streets with tattered bunting and ruined umbrellas.

Airways stocks pushed to the surface of yesterday's gently vacillating market. Seven of them made new highs for 1954 and three turned up in the list of the ten most active stocks. One of these, Trans World Airways, rose 1 1/8.
Political broadcasts stirred more reaction in broadcasting circles yesterday than most of this fall's regularly scheduled programs.

WHEELING, W.Va., Oct. 26 (AP) -- United States District Judge Herbert Boreman issued today an order blocking until Nov. 1 a meeting of Follansbee Steel Corporation stockholders to vote on a proposed sale of the concern's physical assets to New York interests for $9,286,620.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 26 -- A report by a special National Assembly committee accused South Korea's economic coordinator, Paik Too Chin, and high Finance Ministry officials today of "improper practices" in financial matters.

Considerable economic benefits will accrue to the Brown Company, Berlin, N.H., pulp and paper producer, through proposed sale of its Canadian subsidiary's pulp, power and timber assets, according to a letter being circulated among stockholders.

BRISTOL, Conn., Oct. 26 -- Confidence ran high among Connecticut Democrats today as their candidate for Governor, Abraham A. Ribicoff, shook hands, signed autographs and hiked through the 148th town he has barn-stormed since July 1.

WILDFOWLING is reputedly one of the more rigorous if not vigorous, forms of hunting, but we have reached the conclusion that the rigors can be reduced by any shooter who dresses warmly and remains dry.

ROME, Oct. 26 -- Disastrous floods today struck an area about twenty-five miles southeast of Naples. The death toll stood at 263 tonight, including seventy persons unaccounted for at Marina di Vietri.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Mickey Shuman, dynamic 148-pound head football coach at the Peddle School, was not talking about his favorite sport this afternoon. He was confined to his room with a virus attack and was feeling miserable.
"Four main ingredients" for a good advertisement were listed yesterday by Maitland Jones, vice president Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles, Inc., at the agency, regular weekly discussion session.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- United States manufacturers increased their profits by 13 per cent in the second quarter of this year, the Government reported today.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Awards for outstanding achievement were presented by the National Rehabilitation Association tonight to Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, and Dr. Donald A. Covalt of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A prominent Washington farm economist said today the time had come for farm families to do longer-range planning on purchasing.
The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday an estimated net income of $128,000,000, or $3.65 a share, for the first nine months. Profits before taxes were placed at $17,000,000.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 26 (UP) -- In the first round of match play of the third annual North-South senior invitation golf championship today the medal winner, Thomas C. Robbins of Larchmont, N.Y., scored by 1 up over Ray E. Jones of Indianapolis.

The defense, formerly an integral part of the over-all success of the Cleveland Browns, has sagged. That is one man's opinion and his reason for the apparent decline of the once mighty Browns. And when that man happens to be Jack Lavelle, the longtime scout for the Giants, the words carry weight.

Three of America's best jockeys -- Ted Atkinson, Eddie Arcaro and Eric Guerin -- were rivals in two of the top races at the Jamaica track yesterday, making those events largely contests of riders rather than horses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today appointed an emergency board to hear a dispute between the Pullman Company and the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen.

The National Association of Educational Broadcasters, which is holding its thirtieth annual convention here this week, received a congratulatory telegram yesterday from President Eisenhower emphasizing the importance of the organization's role in education.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union, a lawyer, and Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon, who taught philosophy at the American University of Beirut, concluded today a poetical discussion of each other's professions.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 26 -- Marshal Tito, Yugoslav President, and Harold E. Stassen, United States Foreign Operations Administrator, explored today further Yugoslav economic and military links with the West.
Two new issues of public utility mortgage bonds will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates. They are:

BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 26 -- A pre-election "on again off again" Senate subcommittee hearing on communism, at which Glen H. Taylor, the Idaho Democratic nominee for Senator, was to testify, appeared today to be an extremely unlikely development.

The naming of Keith S. McHugh as general chairman of a campaign for increased contributions to the Community Service Society was announced last night at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt that began the drive.
An economics teacher was indicted yesterday for the theft of $92,675 he had received from friends and teaching associates to finance a scheme to sell household plastic articles to department stores.

Dr. Konrad Adenauer arrives in Washington today to pay his second visit to this country as Chancellor of Germany. He returns with an even greater reputation than before. He has long been recognized as the man who led his country out of chaos and despair following a disastrous war to a political and economic rehabilitation.
Next Tuesday, the voters of the Twenty-fifth Congressional District in the Bronx will elect a "liberal, progressive" man to serve them in the House of Representatives.
Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn opened the celebration of its 100th anniversary yesterday with a ceremony on the steps of Borough Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- Joan Crawford will report to Columbia early next year, possibly in February, to star in "The Queen Bee," based on a novel by Edna Lee about a Southern family dominated by an aunt who is referred to as the Queen Bee.

The importance of sending able legislators to Albany needs no argument. Many of the laws that bear most directly on our lives, the education of our children, expenditure and taxation policies of state and cities and a host of other conditions important to our welfare are written in the Legislature.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Averell Harriman today denounced the charge that his election as Governor would result in a cut in state aid to upstate schools.

A great field for advertising exists on the outside of retail cartons, a Packaging Institute forum was told yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel by William B. Banks, an executive of The Lord Baltimore Press.

As one of its contributions to the current music concerts of the New School for Social Research, Opera '55 last night presented the New York premiere of "The Veil," a macabre, sixty-eight-minute one-act opera by Bernard Rogers, based on an original libretto by Robert Lawrence.

Mrs. Joe Smith was introduced to nearly 300 volunteer workers for the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation yesterday as New York's Arthritis Mother of the Year. An arthritis sufferer, she told the meeting at River House, 435 East Fifty-second Street, that "it's a title I wouldn't wish on anyone."

Roy Campanella, who will be released from the Queens Memorial Hospital this morning, was highly optimistic yesterday not only about the complete recovery of his left hand, but about the 1955 pennant prospects of the Dodgers.
LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 27 -- Seven of Britain's leading writers, in a letter to The Times of London today, protested against the recent prosecution of authors and publishers for "obscene libels."
Dein-Bacher staged a dramatic almost all-mink showing of furs yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SEOUL, Oct. 26 -- The currency crisis was eased somewhat today when the Government unfroze hwan deposits of the United Nations Command in Korean national banks. Approximately 200,000,000 hwan ($1,100,000 at the official rate of exchange) on deposit in South Korean banks were tied up by the South Korean Government Sept. 30 when a disagreement arose over the exchange rate.

James F. Mersereau has been elected vice president in charge of the international division of Foster Wheeler Corporation, manufacturer and designer of complete steam generating units. Mr. Mersereau formerly was general counsel of the Export-Import Bank.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- It can be argued that if the Republicans lose control of Congress next week General Eisenhower may eventually have to alter his technique of being President in order to accomplish his foreign policy goals.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The Thruway unrolled to within sixty miles of New York City today as Governor Dewey dedicated a new 183-mile section from this city to Newburgh.
Thirteen leaders of the Puerto Rican Nationalist party received maximum six-year sentences yesterday on their conviction for seditious conspiracy.

A lyrical description of New York's first subway, contained in a souvenir program of the opening of the Interborough Rapid Transit line fifty years ago, is one of many curious items on view today in a subway anniversary show at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

Many dinner and supper parties will be given in the RendezVous of the Plaza before and after the pre-opening performance of "Fanny" on the night of Nov. 3 at the Majestic Theatre for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society.

Although gross operating revenues of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway dropped $75,555,064 to $392,088,155 in the first nine months this year, the company announced yesterday that net income was held to $41,788,112, or $7.65 a share. In the like period last year the road had a net income of $57,660,649, or $10.92 a share.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Ed Furgol, national open golf champion, reported a "100 per cent improvement" in his ailing right arm after a brief practice session at home today, but he said he was still concerned about the injury.
A major issue of debentures will reach the market today in the form of a $75,000,000 borrowing by Cortland Equipment Lessors, Inc., wholly owned subsidiary of Safeway Stores.

Proposition No. 2, which would make possible the loan by the state of an additional $200,000,000 of funds for slum clearance and housing for families of low income whom private enterprise cannot aid, is to be submitted to the electorate on Nov. 2. The public is entitled to the facts so that it may properly decide whether these vital aids should be summarily terminated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today corporations issuing public reports of dividend payments made cash distributions of $1,264,000,000 in September. This was 3 1/2 per cent more than in September. 1953.

Marshal Tito's major foreign policy address this week took, in effect, direct issue with President Eisenhower on the evaluation of present Soviet policy. Marshal Tito argued that a real change has taken place in Moscow's foreign policy and that the West should take advantage of this change to work out long-range solutions of international frictions.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- United States and British guarantees for the new statute for the Saar's status have not been requested yet, although the agreement reached Saturday by the French and West German leaders provided they should be requested by the Bonn and Paris Governments.

It was an evening for sentiment and memories. Alexander Gretchaninoff, who reached the great age of 90 this week, was honored at Town Hall last night in the only appropriate way to pay tribute to a composer: the entire evening was devoted to his music.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Oct. 26 -- Nine hundred women attended the fourth annual "Let Freedom Ring" Institute of the Peninsula Section, National Council of Jewish Women, this afternoon at Temple Beth-el here.
Antonino Rocca, Buenos Aires heavyweight, captured the feature wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night.
Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain arrived here last night to begin a twenty-four-day visit in this country and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The United States Government honored today an 8-year-old boy who produced a neighborhood show last August to aid the fight against polio and then himself was stricken by the disease.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Business activity remained on an even keel in late summer and early fall, with employment, production and consumer buying showing seasonal increases, the Department of Commerce reported today.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 -- A sustained merchant marine policy, instead of the "eccentric stop and go" system of the past, was advocated today by Senator John M. Butler as vital in the nation's defense.

Senator Irving M. Ives charged last night that a company with which Averell Harriman was associated "tried to do business with Hitler" in disposing of some mines in Poland. The Republican candidate for Governor made this accusation in presenting what he termed "Chapter 4 in the affairs" of his Democrat-Liberal opponent.
ONE day last summer Paul Richards was rambling along conversationally when a note of bitterness crept into his voice.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The Westchester County Golf Association drew seventy-four teams today for its season finale, a pro-amateur tourney at Knollwood. Six pairs shared bestball honors at 66, five under par, and placings were determined by matching cards.

SALERNO, Italy, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Floods in this area today destroyed the hamlets of Marina de Vietri, Caneloni, Molina, Alessia and San Cesario. Six other villages were without food or water and helicopters tried to aid them.
Members of the junior auxiliary committee for the literary auction to be held on Sunday night in the galleries of French Co. are meeting frequently at tea parties to discuss plans for the event.

The General Motors Corporation, world's largest manufacturing enterprise, rolled up the second highest sales and earnings for a first-nine-months period in its history. Net sales were within 9 per cent of the record volume achieved in the first nine months last year.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Sir Winston Churchill firmly rejected today the Soviet proposal for a four-power meeting on German unity before ratification of the agreements signed in Paris last week.

Members of the Alumnae of Marymount College in New York have arranged a tea dance to be held on Sunday afternoon at the Barclay for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the college. The Misses Natalie O'Brien and Barbara Wilding are co-chairmen of the benefit committee, and the Misses Barbara Nugent and Julia McNierney are co-chairmen of the patroness committee for the event.
PEOPLE in New York have known for a long time that Ansky's "The Dybbuk" is a wonderful play. It is pleasant to be reminded of its dark grandeur again.

Net income of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, dropped to $138,174,974 for the first nine months of this year. That was equal to $4.55 a common share and compared with $166,723,028 or $5.66 a share for the same period last year.

A New Delhi dispatch of The Times, London, printed in The New York Times on Oct. 23, reported that "differences of approach are reported to be the reason" for the fact that long private discussions between Mr. Nehru and Mr. Chou lasted twice as long as the talks they held in New Delhi last summer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Government agreed today to accept five World War II tankers from the Esso Shipping Company for an allowance credit against the construction of two modern supertankers.

The smoke of the electoral battle is being allowed to clear in Cuba as citizens prepare to vote on Nov. 1. There isn't much smoke and it wasn't much of a battle, but at least it heralds a return to the interrupted process of due elections.
U.C.L.A's Bruins wrested the No. 1 college football rating from Oklahoma yesterday in the closest weekly contest in the five-year history of the United Press rankings.
BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Jackie Blair, 134 1/2 pounds, Dallas, used a smashing straight right hand to battle heavily favored Lulu Perez, 131, Brooklyn, to a ten-round draw tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy resumed his attack today on Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Utah Republican. Mr. Watkins was chairman of the special Senate committee that recommended censure of Mr. McCarthy.
A new kind of fashion show -- parading safety rather than style -- was presented yesterday at the fifth annual Safety Institute for Parents and Teachers.

The boy and girl pictured here are wearing the same size T-shirts. These children's clothes are one of the most recent developments in garments of stretchable yarn. They are made of nylon or nylon and Dacron, may be washed by machine or hand and are said to need little or no ironing.
The New York Rangers, who have beaten every club in the National Hockey League except the Red Wings, hope to turn the trick tonight when they face the Detroit sextet on Madison Square Garden ice.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Before an overflow crowd of nearly 1,000 persons here today Adlai E. Stevenson criticized "Republican primitives" who take "a strong stand for a weak government."

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Cain Hoy Stable's Flying Fury, winner of the Champagne Stakes at Belmont Park, today took the feature at Garden State Park, gaining stature as a contender in the Garden State Stakes, the world's richest race, to be run here Saturday.
Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic national chairman, took Republicans to task yesterday for conducting a "smear campaign" and for televising a meeting of President Eisenhower's Cabinet.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- William M. Byam, 43 years old, an advertising executive and yachtsman, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning at 4 A.M. today aboard his 46-foot cabin cruiser, moored 500 feet offshore in Long Island Sound here.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and the market closed strong, 10 to 14 points (50 to 70 cents a bale) higher than Monday on active months.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Robert H. Field, manager for the Eastern region for Montgomery Ward Co., with headquarters in New York City, disclosed today that he has resigned from the company.
