Adlai E. Stevenson ascribed to the Republicans last night a "genius for mismanagement." This will be a major factor, he said, in returning control of the Senate and House of Representatives to the Democrats in next week's election.
By 1970 the Puerto Rican and non-white population will make up 28 per cent of the census of the City of New York, a sociologist predicted yesterday.

For the first time in its 162 years, the New York Stock Exchange last night surrendered completely to women. Three hundred of them invaded the trading floor and, assisted by fifteen "old pros" from the Association of Specialists, went through all the motions of conducting a market.
NEWARK, Oct. 26 -- Clifford P. Case charged tonight that his Democratic opponent had failed to explain where he stood on Americans for Democratic Action.
Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, unanimously authorized last night a strike vote in a dispute with eight New York and Long Island newspapers.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 26 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today made five speeches in this state for Senator Guy Cordon and the Republican candidates for Congress.
NAGOYA, Japan, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Herbert Schade of West Germany bettered his Japanese record today, running 3,000 meters in 8:23.6 before 30,000 spectators.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Three tentative jurors were excused without reason today at Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard's trial on a murder charge. The judge indicated that he might have to call a new list of Candidates.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, made his first strong attack today on his opponent in the campaign.

Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera from 1935 to 1950, will be intermission master of ceremonies for the closed-circuit telecast of the Metropolitan's opening night performance on Monday, Nov. 8.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A doctor still young in enthusiasm at the age of 76 is showing a medical convention his cairivibograph.
Unionized employes of the John Wanamaker store on Broadway at Ninth Street, which will close in January, announced yesterday that they were ready to buy and run the business.

Today's new film is "Black Widow," a murder melodrama in CinemaScope and color, at the Rox. The Twentieth Century-Fox release stars Ginger Rogers, Van Heflin, Gene Tierney, George Raft, Peggy Ann Garner and Virginia Leith.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer stopped over in Iceland a few hours today on his way to the United States. Premier Olafur Thors and members of his Government welcomed Dr. Adenauer and his party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Preparedness that would prevent panic in the new type of war was urged by President Eisenhower in an informal talk today to the Women's Advisory Committee on Civil Defense.

Your endorsement of Senator Ives can hardly prove persuasive to those voters who believe that election should depend not only on a man's political philsophy but on the kind of campaign he has conducted.
The Twenty-fourth Congressional District in the Bronx is one of those districts where a candidate doesn't really have to worry much about the issues -- if he's got enough Democrats on his side:
Averell Harriman declared last night that a Republican victory in the state election would present "the grave danger that a law to end rent control will be passed next year."

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Art Boland of Lynn, Mass., substituted in Cornell football practice today for Halfback Dick Jackson of Athens, Pa., who has been sidelined for two days with a minor ailment. Both are expected to see action against Columbia.

Offering a V-8 engine for the first time, the 1955 Chevrolet line was announced yesterday by the Chevrolet Motor division of General Motors Corporation. The new models are restyled and re-engineered from bumper to bumper.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 26 -- Navy's football forces, who achieved one of their prime 1954 objectives last Saturday when they defeated Pennsylvania for the first time since 1945, now are trimming ship in preparation for another, more difficult, mission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The "market basket" of goods and services usually bought by moderate income city families cost 0.3 per cent less in September than August.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge, campaigning for a second four-year term on the Republican ticket, entered enemy territory here today for a last sortie before the election. All day he was shaking hands with his fingers figuratively crossed.

A distinguished audience that included 1,200 civic and social leaders and students and faculty members attended last night the Columbia University Bicentennial Concert given in Carnegie Hall by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Leopold Stokowski conducting.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- France and West Germany announced agreements today to increase the commercial and cultural exchanges between the two countries. The agreements are part of what is officially described as an effort to substitute cooperation for the rivalry that has poisoned atmosphere in Europe for hundreds of years.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- At the present rate of increasing delinquency, one of every five boys coming of military age "in a very few years" may have a juvenile court record, a nationwide meeting of prison and correctional officials was told today.

At 8 o'clock tonight, when the curtain goes up on "The Traveling Lady" at the Playhouse, the Playwrights Company can point to a local representation of three dramas. The other two are "All Summer Long" and the long run "Tea and Sympathy," both from the pen of Robert Anderson.
Governmental and political threats to freedom in university education provided a main theme yesterday at the Columbia University bicentennial conference on "Responsible Freedom in the Americas."

Negotiations for a thirteen-year loan of $50,000,000 have been completed by Warren Petroleum Corporation, Tulsa, Okla., it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. The funds were used to retire about $38,000,000 of outstanding term loans and to provide additional working capital.
The State of Massachusetts borrowed $59,827,000 in the public market yesterday on bonds maturing serially from 1955 to 1989 at an interest cost of 1.911 per cent.

Despite the regrettably large number of automobile accidents on the nation's roads it is encouraging to learn from the National Safety Council that for the sixth time in seven years highway fatality rates decreased last year. Safety experts credit many factors for the lower death rates.

Three armed men forced their way into the town house of Mr. and Mrs. Minot K. Milliken at 186 East Sixty-fourth Street yesterday morning, held up Mrs. Miliken and three women servants, and escaped with $51,000 in furs and jewelry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A Federal Agriculture Department finance expert delved today into the old question of "how're ya gonna keep 'em down on the farm."
CAIRO, Oct. 26 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Egypt's 36-year-old Premier escaped assassination tonight.
Two ships, one flying the warm water flag of Morocco and the other bearing the sub-Arctic colors of Iceland, arrived for their first visits to New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The State Department reported today that Hermann Field, United States architect arrested by Poland more than five years ago, was now in a Polish sanitarium and did not intend to leave within "the immediate future."

NEWARK, Oct. 26 -- As the New Jersey political campaign entered its final week today, both Republican and Democratic leaders were predicting victory in normally Republican Essex, the state's most populous county.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The stock market here again was unsettled today by the continuation of the dock strike.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP) -- General Foods Corporation has completed negotiations for the acquisition of fifty-five acres here to be used as the site of a proposed enlarged food research center.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg, S.C., carded a four-under-par 71 today to capture the medal in the nineteenth annual women's Texas open golf tournament at the River Crest Country Club.
Ohio State, Oklahoma and U.C.L.A. ranked 1, 2, 3 yesterday in the weekly Associated Press college football poll.

ROME, Oct. 26 -- Salvatore Lucania, better known as Lucky Luciano, former New York vice king, has been summoned by the Naples police to appear before a Government commission. He is suspected of engaging in narcotics traffic and white slavery and of being "socially dangerous."
John J. Keane, 43-year-old suspended patrolman, interrupted his trial yesterday in Kings County Court to plead guilty to one count of perjury, as a misdemeanor.

Mayor Wagner, at City Hall yesterday, proclaimed the week of Nov. 1-6 as New York City Merchant Marine Industries Week. Rear Admiral Halert C. Shepheard, chief of the Office of Merchant Marine Safety of the Coast Guard, and John A. Carroll, commander of the Robert L. Hague Merchant Industries Post, American Legion, attended the ceremony.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it would begin non-stop service from Tokyo to Honolulu on Nov. 1. For the third successive winter season the airline will be able to conduct the fast flights by taking advantage of the high altitude jetstream and eliminating the usual stop at Wake Island.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 -- Port leaders from nineteen Western Hemisphere nations today heard arguments for increased international trade and pleas for greater inter-American cooperation at the forty-third annual convention of the American Association of Port Authorities.

JEANMAIRE, the Gallic imp with the boyish hair-do, has added one more medium -- television -- to her list of conquests. Her debut in the latest of the N.B.C. color spectaculars, "The Follies of Suzy," was a beguiling triumph of personality over vehicle.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 373 pints on Monday. The gifts included 129 from employes at the Procter Gamble Manufacturing Company, Port Ivory, S.I.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 26 -- The United Nations Truce Supervision Organization in Jerusalem reported today that Egypt had prevented an armistice commission from considering the dispute over the seizure of an Israeli freighter in the Gulf of Suez.

VIENNA, Oct. 26 -- Herbert Field Ward, New York violinist who after having been advised by the State Department to return to the United States disappeared instead from his hotel in the Soviet section of Vienna, has been flown to Warsaw with his wife and children, according to intelligence sources.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- At the age of 70, M/Sgt. Horst W. Tittel re-enlisted today for an additional six-year hitch in the Air Force.

Following the breaking of ground recently for a new million-dollar headquarters of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union in San Francisco, members of the union and shipowners also broke bread, and partook of other viands, at a dinner to take account of their labor-relations stock.

WASHINGTON, Oct.26 -- The Atomic Energy Commission confirmed tonight that the Soviet Union had been conducting a series of nuclear explosions since the middle of September. Confirmation was made in a statement by Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the commission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Sharp differences have arisen between the United States and France over policy in South Vietnam.

VIENNA, Oct. 26 -- Two former ministers in Hungarian Cabinets who were recently released from concentration camps have been rehabilitated. They were included in the council of the newly revived Hungarian National Front, a pro-Communist bloc.

A welcome artistic visitation, from across the Atlantic and from out of the past, arrives today at Knoedler's in the form of a selection of masterpieces of drawing from the Museum of Besancon in France. The exhibition will open tonight with a preview, to which admission will be $6 and then will remain open until Nov. 13 with an admission charge of 60 cents. The show is being held for the benefit of the museum.

The world's largest electric and gas utility, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $49,449,235 for the twelve months to Sept. 30, after all operating expenses and taxes. This was equal to $2.92 a common share, and compares with a net of $50,096,021, or $2.98 a share, in the preceding twelve months.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 26 -- An interim report on Document J by the Royal Commission on Russian Espionage was introduced in the House of Representatives today by Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies.
One of the biggest and most influential public utility holding companies of twenty years ago will soon submit to its "death sentence" at last.

Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for State Attorney General, said yesterday that he did not "question the integrity" of Averell Harriman, Democratic nominee for Governor, but that he did question Mr. Harriman's competency to run the state.

Discount houses were planning yesterday to continue "business as usual" even as fair trade adherents were hailing the refusal of the Supreme Court on Monday to review four decisions upholding New York and New Jersey fair trade laws.
ALBANY, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The State University of New York today announced a $6,200,000 program for dormitories to house 1,800 students.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon's attack on Representative Robert L. Condon of California has revived the issue here of public use of Federal Bureau of Investigation files.

Plans are being made at meetings here for a special sixtieth anniversary fund-raising drive under the auspices of the Women's Committee of the George Junior Republic for the benefit of the organization. The special 1954 drive for $36,000 will open on Nov. 13.

Champagne and a bottle-breaking ritual were to have attended the opening of New York City's first subway fifty years ago this afternoon. It was discovered, however, that certain schemers in the city intended to capitalize on the occasion by advertising the brand used (a New York State vintage, at least).

The B.F. Goodrich Company disclosed yesterday plans for spending $100,000,000 in the next five years for new and improved facilities -- largely for the manufacture and distribution of tubeless tires. More than $30,000,000 will be expended this year, according to Joseph A. Hoban, vice president of the tire and equipment division.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The White House confirmed today that President Eisenhower "would like to" make an eleventh-hour aerial tour of six to eight states in an effort to get out a big Republican vote for the next Congress.

CHINATOWN was crowded last Sunday when Moi Nai Gam, one of the community's elders was buried. Hundreds of Chinese, in from the provinces for Sabbath marketing or just for visiting, watched in respectful silence when great wreaths and stands of flowers were mounded in sleek open Cadillacs in bright October sun.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 26 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was virtually assured today before his departure for Washington that the Paris agreements would be ratified by the Bundestag.

The Ford Motor Company was described here yesterday as favoring enthusiastically President Eisenhower's recent recommendation for an addition of $50,000,000,000 for a highway modernization program, making available $100,000,000,000 over ten years.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 26 (AP) -- A 32-year-old Madrid jeweler tonight ended the Mexican domination of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show for Spain's first victory in international jumping competition as well as in the second phase of the three-day low-score competition.

Tony Trabert and Hamilton Richardson, members of the United States Davis Cup team, and two junior players, Jerry Moss and Mike Green, will leave Los Angeles by plane Nov. 5 for their Australian tennis tour prior to the Davis Cup play.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The eight-man Philadelphia syndicate seeking to purchase the Philadelphia Athletics should learn Thursday whether its bid has succeeded or failed.

WILLIAM BRANCH, a Negro playwright who made something of an impression with an earlier off-Broadway work, "A Medal for Willie," is tackling a major subject in his latest play, "In Splendid Error," which opened last night at the Greenwich Mews Theatre.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Union leaders who tried to persuade striking dockers to return to work were jeered and shouted down today.

HONG KONG, Oct. 26 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru denied today that any differences had arisen in the talks he had held with Premier Chou En-lai on his present visit to China, according to the Peiping radio.

Frederic R. Coudert Jr. has served his district well for eight years in the House after a useful term in the State Legislature. In his latter capacity, as your columns stated on Aug. 19, "Mr. Coudert, former chairman of the Rapp-Coudert committee in New York, has led the national fight to get Communists out of the schools." His legislative committee methods were a model of fairness and objectivity.
Geraldine Page is star of "The Rainmaker," a romantic play by N. Richard Nash opening at the Cort Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.

Nothing quite compares with Indian summer. Breathtaking are the red maples and sumachs, the purple and crimson oaks, flashing by as one drives north along the Westchester parkways, through the back hills of Connecticut, up into the heart of Massachusetts.
The law of diminishing returns is bringing to an end the era of the huge department store, a group of young executives in the credit industry was told yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27 (UP) -- Yale University announced the formation today of a memorial scholarship fund to honor the late Pudge Heffelfinger, one of the greatest of all players ever to wear the moleskins of old Eli.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Charles E. Bohlen, United States Amabassador in Moscow, will call on Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov tomorrow to protest further the detention by the Russian Police of the wives of two American diplomats.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 28 -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda printed interviews today with Soviet citizens who said they had witnessed the "hooligan act" of which Mrs. Sommerlatte is accused by the Soviet Government.

A decline last week of 842,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 149,834,000 barrels, compared with 150,676,000 a week earlier and 140,540,000 a year ago.
The Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound continued its efforts to change the area groupings for the Sears Cup eliminations at its annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club yesterday.

The operator of a wholesale egg company on the lower West Side pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to one count of a nineteen-count indictment charging that he stole $220,800 from a bank by loans obtained through fraudulent invoices and accounts receivable.

The American Gas and Electric Company system reported yesterday that it had a consolidated net income of $30,649,621 in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1954. This was equal to $2.39 a share on 12,848,789 common shares outstanding, and compared with a net of $30,618,647, or $2.52 a share on 12,165,640 shares, in the preceeding twelve months.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Hans Guenther Winkler, world equestrian champion, of Germany, a 27-year-old salesman, tonight won the individual international high jumping championship of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

THE striped bass fishing is crowding out the shooting news in some areas, and scattered reports from Rhode Island to Barnegat Bay indicate the big bass have moved inshore and are being taken from the beaches as well as from boats.
The closest finish at Jamaica yesterday was in the $30,950 Interborough Handicap. The Trio Stables' Laffango, with Eddie Arcaro in the saddle, scored a last-gasp, tip-of-his-nose decision.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman told a rally here tonight that Republican attacks on Averell Harriman, Democratic candidate for Governor, had boomeranged to the point where a Democratic victory on Nov. 2 was "in the air."

HAVANA, Oct. 27 -- Secret Service men of the Cuban Government and uniformed groups from the Army and police searched the whole island today for revolutionists and for stores of arms. The action followed the discovery in Havana last night of the biggest arms cache found in years.
WAUKESHA, Wis., Oct. 27 (UP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield said today the Democrats by crying depression "have tried to create a depression and have scared some people needlessly."

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Minstrel, a 66-to-1 shot owned by Lord Rosebery, senior steward of the English Jockey Club, outran three rivals in the last fifty yards today and won one of the closest finishes in the 115-year history of the Cambridgeshire Stakes.
THIRTY diverse examples of work by twentieth-century masters make up avery interesting group show at the Sidney Janis Gallery.
I count myself a friend of both candidates for the Governorship of New York. Senator Ives had an outstanding record in the Legislature of New York and has, in my opinion, been a good Senator.

HOLLYWOOD Calif., Oct. 27 -- Jane Wyman and Rock Hudson, who proved to be a winning combination for Universal in "Magnificent Obsession," will be teamed again by the studio in "All That Heaven Allows."

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The Government-appointed Court of Inquiry criticized today the union that caused the present crippling dock strike and said that the dispute could be settled through established industrial conciliation machinery.

The date of the performance of "Quadrille' for the benefit of the scholarship funds of the Rudolf Steiner School and the High Mowing School, which had been announced for the night of Nov. 1, has been postponed to the night of Nov. 14 at the Coronet Theatre.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The wheat futures market, especially the December delivery, showed pronounced strength today After an early dip when the March, May and July contracts were relatively weak. Commission buying was active late in the session, with some of the buying credited to mills.

The Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, dean of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Devine), decried last night the belief of "many people" that religion meant conformity. Actually, he held, "today the biggest threat is the pressure toward political conformity, toward a 'safe line' in one's views."

Dividend declarations provided most of the interest in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange, Despite generally favorable news, prices were heavy except for airlines and aircrafts and the day ended with moderate net losses.

Electric power production last week declined to 9,033,000,000 kilowatt hours from 9,117,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Oct. 24, 1953, was 8,306,000,000. Comparative percentages with the like two weeks of last year are:

Seldom, if ever, have the electorate of any state or commonwealth of our Republic had such an opportunity to perpetuate honest, sound, progressive government as is presented by the candidacy of Senator Ives as a successor to Governor Dewey. One can only hope that sober logic will supersede the philosophy of pie in the sky come Election Day.

BUFFALO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The administrator of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation predicted today that more than 36,000,000 tons of cargo would pass through the Seaway during its first year of operation.

Now that the dust of the Teamsters' strike has settled, it is easier to see what happened and what the future may hold in store. One thing is clear: the prospect spells confusion on both sides. The "settlements" haven't settled anything for long. Quite to the contrary, they have unsettled almost everything.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy demanded today that Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, give him more information about Maj. Irving Peress, former Army dentist. The Wisconsin Republican has termed Dr. Peress a "Fifth Amendment Communist."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Eisenhower gave his blessing today to the establishment of formal procedures for filling Federal job vacancies with applicants sponsored by Republican members of Congress and state party leaders.
A hundred-year-old red and yellow tallyho and a picket line competed yesterday with some success against the announced program marking the fiftieth anniversary of the city's subway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board, in a series of hotly disputed decisions, turned over to the states today responsibility for handling labor disputes in some concerns over which it previously claimed jurisdiction.
The cotton futures market here closed barely steady, unchanged to 4 points lower on active months, after a steady market on the New York Cotton Exchange all day.
Mayor Wagner urged last night the election of the Democratic state ticket to bolster the party's chances of winning the Presidency in 1956.

Forty-six competitors in Gaelic football and hurling arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Ireland yesterday for a three-week visit that will include games against New York squads at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

Two lawyers, one who is campaigning for re-election to a fifth term in the House of Representatives and one who is seeking a first term, are attracting considerable interest in the Seventeenth (Silk Stocking) Congressional District of Manhattan.

Operations of Procter Gamble Company in the quarter ended Sept. 30 resulted in a consolidated net income of $18,914,709, equal to $1.96 a common share, after domestic and foreign taxes of $21,185,000, the company reported yesterday.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The medalist and both 1953 finalists won their second-round matches today in the third annual North and South invitation senior golf tournament at the Pinehurst Country Club.

AMALFI, Italy, Oct. 27 -- A warm sun was shining brightly out of a cloudless sky today on this Riviera of the south. But it shone on a scene of frightful havoc and devastation caused by a cloudburst that struck Salerno's romantic coast less than forty-eight hours ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A flying, one-day campaign trip will take President Eisenhower to four cities on Friday. He will make airport speeches at Cleveland, Detroit, Louisville and Wilmington, Del., all in states where the Republicans are locked in battle for seats in a closely divided Senate.

It is still a little too early for northern fishermen to begin the picturesque operation of catching smelts with hook and line through holes carved in the ice. But first-of-the-season shipments of this cold weather piscatorial delicacy, caught by more conventional methods, already have arrived here.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 27 -- Moscow propaganda, as exemplified in the new edition of the Great Soviet Encyclopedia, has injured the Soviet Union in India by attacking the late Mohandas K. Gandhi as a "reactionary," among other things.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 20, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 27 -- John R. Murray, Federal Mediation Commissioner, today continued private talks in an effort to develop a new peace offer in the eleven-month-old strike of the American Federation of Labor, Local 249, General Teamsters, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, against five downtown department stores.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon stepped up his "dubious security risk" campaign against Representative Richard L. Condon, California Democrat, today as he began three days of campaigning in his native state.

Among the many distinguished personalities New York has had the privilege of honoring recently one of the most interesting is President William V. S. Tubman of Liberia. Mr. Tubman, after conferences with President Eisenhower, comes to this city today for one of New York's full-dress receptions, including a tickertape parade to City Hall.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 27 -- A wave of independent voting here in Union County, a normally Republican stronghold, last year carried to victory two Democrats, Gov. Robert B. Meyner and Representative Harrison A. Williams Jr. Simultaneously the full Republican county ticket and its state Assembly delegation were elected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A law partner of J. Howard McGrath, former Attorney General, testified today that Harvey M. Matusow, a frequent witness in Communist cases, had told him last April 30: "You should know that I am not to be trusted."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today re-indicted John David Provoo, a former San Francisco bank clerk, for treason, charging that he went over to the Japanese while a prisoner of war in World War II.

Hanry H. Reichhold, chairman of Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., White Plains, N. Y., announced yesterday that he and a group of associates had acquired "a substantial number" of shares in the Catalin Corporation of America and were seeking representation on the latter's board of directors.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. disavowed emphatically yesterday a suggestion that his supporters were seeking "bullet votes" for him in next Tuesday's election. On the contrary, he said, they are urging votes for everyone on the Democratic ticket from Averell Harriman, the candidate for Governor, on down.
New York waterfront employers offered yesterday to increase welfare and pension benefits for longshoremen by $1,330,000, which would bring the total of such contributions to $6,790,000 annually.

Thomas D'Arcy Brophy, chairman of the board of Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., yesterday was elected board chairman of the National Outdoor Advertising Bureau, Inc., to serve the unexpired term of Allen Billingsley, president of Fuller Smith Ross, Inc., who died recently.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that a successor to Robert H. Jackson as associate justice of the Supreme Court might be appointed from the ranks of the judiciary. Justice Jackson died of a heart ailment on Oct. 9.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Persons arriving from Honduras said today that armed supporters of Gen. Tiburcio Carias Andino had prevented Opposition voters from going to the polls in Sunday's run-off Congressional elections in several Honduran departments.
Camera and lighting rehearsals for the camera crew that will televise the Metropolitan Opera opening night performance on Monday, Nov. 8, have been going on since early this month.

Jules Eskin, 23-year-old 'ceiiist, was heard in his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. This debut appearance was his prize as the winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award for 1954.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- Plans for locating a $100,000,000 East Coast food distribution center here were announced tonight by the Greater Philadelphia Movement.

DETROIT, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The nation's auto plants shipped 4,959,297 vehicles to dealers in this year's first nine months, against 5,764,232 a year before, the Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 27 -- Earl L. Butz, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, said here today that by the end of this fiscal year the Commodity Credit Corporation would have commitments "probably well over $7,000,000,000, and could go even past $8,000,000,000."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Maurice Harper, unranked and virtually unknown boxer from Oakland, vaulted into the welterweight picture tonight when he gained a ten-round decision over the world's second-ranking contender, Del Flanagan of St. Paul. Harper weighed 146 1/2 pounds and Flanagan 150.

A brown rough-coated mixed-breed dog, mostly Irish terrier, paced a B. M. T. Brighton Beach subway express two miles yesterday, from Prince Street to Thirty-fourth. He brought it in thirteen minutes late and piled up all rolling stock behind.
A broad plan for improving high school education in this state to meet the increased needs of a changing society was made public yesterday by the State Board of Regents.
The Hilton Hotels Corporation's purchase of all the assets of Hotel Statler Company, Inc., was completed yesterday for $111,000,000.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Betsy Rawls, the defending champion, led a parade of favored professionals through lop-sided opening-round victories in the nineteenth annual women's Texas open golf tournament today.
Political leaders continued yesterday to campaign just as hard for free television and radio time as they did for votes.
FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Oct. 27 (UP) -- Baptist churches in Russia are "crowded to the doors," the president of the American Baptist Convention said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- The big, ugly gooney birds on Midway Island have troubled the aircraft that land and take off there for long enough. The Government has decided the gooneys must go.

Imitations of the seven historic crowns in the collection of Crown Jewels of the British Empire will be displayed at the Seven Crown Ball Tuesday, night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The fete will serve as a benefit for the mental health division of the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

The State of Virginia sold long-term bonds yesterday to finance the construction of the Hampton Roads Crossing, a bridge-tunnel project linking Norfolk with Hampton, and the erection of a bridge over the Rappahannock River between Grey's Point and White Stone.
A new international swimming award, to be presented annually by the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, was unveiled yesterday at the Lambs Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The Syracuse Nationals defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 84 -- 78, at the County Center tonight in the last exhibition game for both clubs before the opening of the regular National Basketball Association season Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Organized labor spokesmen attacked Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell today for his version of employment and other economic conditions in a political broadcast last night.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Large receipts depressed hog prices today. Salable receipts were 4,000 more than expected. Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today;

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 27 -- The students and faculty of the New Haven State Teachers College held their own Arbor Day today and within a few hours turned the drab new campus into landscaped grounds with more than 1,000 plantings.
The American League will meet at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at 10:30 this morning to decide the fate of the Philadelphia Athletics.
HORTON FOOTE has written a part in which Kim stanley gives a glorious performance. In "The Traveling Lady," which opened at The Playhouse last evening, she goes to the head of the class.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- There are only two excuses for secrecy in government, President Eisenhower said today -- in security matters and in certain cases where premature publicity would not be common sense.

Mrs. Henry B. Guthrie gave a tea yesterday afternoon in her home at 169 East Seventieth Street for members of the committee working in behalf of the second annual Christmas benefit for the Big Brother Movement. The committee has taken over nearly all the seats in the mezzanine of the Radio City Music Hall on the night of Dec. 16 and the afternoon of Dec. 20 to raise funds for the organization.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Stockholders of Follansbee Steel Corporation, prohibited by a Federal Court order from voting on proposed sale of the concern met for about an hour today and recessed until tomorrow at 2 P. M.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Manager Leo Durocher said today that if ever the New York Giants' franchise were shifted he would like to see it go to San Francisco. Durocher added, however, that such a move would be up to Horace Stoneham, the club's owner.

The regional Red Cross blood program collected 892 pints of blood Tuesday, the largest daily amount so far this month. The community of Bayside, Queens, gave 219 pints at All Saints Episcopal Church, 214-33 Fortieth Avenue.

With six years of experience and some very substantial achievements behind them, the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (better known by its short title of GATT) are gathering at Geneva this week for one of the most important tasks they have faced to date.

Christian Dior may have introduced a high flatter look in his Paris collection but in his New York presentation, shown yesterday by Bonwit Teller at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the story was just the reverse.

Those of us who have been shocked by Senator Ives' recent sustained and calculated attack on Averell Harriman have been disappointed that there has not been more protest against it by Republicans and independents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Atomic power offers a potential saving to the electrical utility industry of $1,000,000,000 a year in operating costs, Robert LeBaron, who has been retained by a new group of industrialists and financiers seeking investment in the field of atomic energy, said today.
The captain of a tender was believed to have drowned last night in the sinking of his forty-foot craft after a collision with a towed scow in Arthur Kill, between Staten Island and Linden, N. J.

The National Broadcasting Company is still faced with the possibility of a $100,000 loss in a television time sale because Bob Hope elected to make a trip to London instead of doing his program on Nov. 9.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 27 -- Shut out for the first time in seventy-seven games by Cornell, Princeton is giving special emphasis to the attack this week in preparation for Saturday's meeting with Colgate in Palmer Stadium here.
TOKYO, Oct. 27 -- Several Japanese delegations to Red China and the Soviet Union have returned home agreed that Japan should seek a rapprochement with her Communist neighbors.

If nothing else, the program of piano music that Maria Luisa Faini played for her Town Hall debut last night was as unusual as one will encounter in years of concertgoing. Only two or three of the pieces could be classified as standard -- Schumann's Symphonic Etudes and two Scarlatti sonatas.

The current unemployment situation finds the number of persons out of work at 2,741,000, which is approximately 4.2 per cent of the civilian labor force. This is not a static figure, for there has been an uninterrupted decline from the high of 5.8 per cent at which unemployment stood in February and March.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Federal Government is perfectly and splendidly protected in the power contract proposed for the Atomic Energy Commission to get energy for the Tennessee Valley Authority, President Eisenhower asserted today.

NEWARK, Oct. 27 -- Clifford P. Case of Rahway is a lean scholarly looking man, whose quiet manner, philosophical speeches and natural inclination for unostentatious campaigning hardly fit the mold of political orthodoxy.

The American Civil Liberties Union entered the case of Tjong Hoen-nji, the anti-Communist leader of the Chinese in Indonesia, yesterday with a request that the State Department permit Mr. Hoen-nji to enter this country.
Averell Harriman received the blessing of George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday during a day of campaigning aimed at the labor vote.
CAIRO, Oct. 27 -- Egypt's military rulers moved today to smash the fatanical and ultra-nationalist Moslem Brotherhood.

A woman who detectives said had admitted using $100,000 worth of narcotics in the last forty years was arrested yesterday in Harlem on a charge of possessing narcotics with the intention of selling them.
Dr. Edward Larocque Tinker, author and president of the Uruguayan - American Association, was honored in ceremonies yesterday celebrating the associations's second anniversary.

HARTFORD, Oct. 27 -- A young man literally greased the palm of Gov. John Davis Lodge this morning within three minutes' walk of the State Capitol. And everyone associated with Mr. Lodge not a few of whom witnessed the event, was pleased.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 27 -- Scholars on the faculties of universities should assume a greater interest in helping teachers and potential teachers among undergraduates, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, said today in his annual report to the alumni.

Successive pleas for a Marshall Plan for Latin America, and for a cessation of arms shipments there, stirred the third session Columbia University's bicentennial conference on "Responsible Freedom in the Americas" yesterday.

Expansion of inter-American trade will be supported by the United States at the forthcoming Rio de Janeiro economic conference, according to Henry F. Holland, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The paradox of the election campaign is that the central figure in the drama, President Eisenhower, still seems remote and vaguely annoyed by all the fuss.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -- The West German Government has informed the Organization for European Economic Cooperation that it foresees another period of great economic expansion and a boom in the consumer goods industries.

Gunman Uses Their Auto in Getaway After $159 Hold-Up Two women spent five terrifying minutes yesterday morning with a gunman who fled from a $159 hold-up of a butcher shop and forced his way into their automobile. After driving the car several blocks the bandit scrambled into an unoccupied small panel truck and escaped.
Casual and evening fashions shown yesterday by B. Altman at the Pierre Hotel featured a one-color theme with accents and accessories varying in tone and texture.
Your editorial "Our Next Governor," in your issue of Oct. 25, hit the nail on the head.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Eisenhower rejected today any idea of four-power talks with the Russians before the Paris agreements on West German armament and sovereignty were ratified.
Operations of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, manufacturers of Camel cigarettes and other tobacco products, resulted in a net profit of $34,467,000 in the nine months ended Sept. 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Egyptian Embassy accused American Zionists today of trying to "discredit" the United States Government.

The ensemble that was formerly the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, and that now, no longer associated with N. B. C., takes the name of The Symphony of the Air, gave a conductorless concert last night in Carnegie Hall, with electrical effect.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 27 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, campaigned inside and just outside factories here today as he charged that the Republican party had shown itself incompetent to cope with unemployment.
Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad -- the nation's largest railroad -- went out of their way yesterday to indicate that they believe the worst has been seen in the decline in railroad business.

Events today: Searle Wright, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; "Show Boat," City Center, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Raya Garbousova, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Lidia Mendelson, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Quartetto Italiano, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40; "La Traviata," Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:15.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The Inland Steel Company reported today that its net income in the first nine months of 1954 increased to $26,293,646, or $5.25 a share, from $24,049,317, or $4.91 a share, a year ago, despite a decline in sales from the record 1953 level.

Record sales and earnings were achieved in the first nine months of this year by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which declared yesterday its first extra dividend to stockholders since 1950. The year-end extra of 50 cents along with the regular quarterly of 50 cents on the common will be paid Dec. 1 to holders of record Nov. 8.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- United States diplomatic authorities remained calm today in the face of the Government shake-up in Pakistan, apparently confident it was based on domestic political considerations and did not foreshadow any change in foreign policy.
The mother of an 18-year-old Army private who died of polio at Camp Gordon, Ga., a year ago, filed a suit for $150,000 against the Government in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

VITALITY, both of touch and color, is the distinguishing mark of Seymour Franks' new abstract paintings at the Peridot Gallery. Now, apparently inspired by de Stael, he deals out slabs of richly encrusted paint-color and flings them all over his canvases, giving the effect of a riotously blossoming climbing plant that has had an overdose of vitamins.

The constantly-avowed Government policy of wanting more private capital invested abroad must be preceded by realistic revision of tax laws affecting foreign-earned income, it was asserted yesterday at an international trade forum.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Willie Shoemaker booted home four winners at Tanforan race track today for the second day in a row to lift his season total to 347 victories.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A voluntary code to take the horror, brutal crime and sex out of the nation's comic books has been signed by twenty-six publishers representing three-fourths of the industry's annual output, Judge Charles F. Murphy, who has been hired to police the code, announced today.

A close look at steamship operating subsidies will show that the actual cost to the country in the last analysis is "far less" that the gross subsidy figures indicate, a high Government official said here yesterday.

Directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in a special session yesterday at Burbank, Calif., voted to increase the quarterly dividend rate to 60 cents, to distribute a special dividend of 50 cents a share and to pay a 5 per cent stock dividend.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved unanimously today a resolution calling for a new attempt to reach agreement between East and West on disarmament and the prohibition of nuclear weapons.

The United States Atomic Commission's confirmation of a series of nuclear tests in the Soviet Union provides a somber background for the Communist disarmament proposals in the United Nations and for the current party line of "peaceful co-existence."

The Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth set a new record for quick turnaround in port yesterday when she sailed from West Fiftieth Street at 10:30 A. M., only 17 hours 45 minutes after docking here twelve hours behind schedule on Tuesday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Democratic leaders in the District of Columbia contended today that the 1952 district primary was a party affair and there was no intention of prejudicing voting rights in home districts.

Former Mayor William O'Dwyer came back to New York last night after an absence of three years and seven months. He said that he was permanently out of local and national politics but was keenly interested in international affairs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Bryant W. Bowles, who sparked recent anti-segregation moves at Washington, Baltimore and Delaware schools, was arrested today on charges of assaulting a Negro postman who delivers mail to his office here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, arrived here today and expressed his "deepest gratitude" to the United States for its help in winning for West Germany "final acceptance into the community of free peoples."
BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -- The Soviet Government has released fifty-six German prisoners of war. The men arrived in Berlin Monday from the prisoner-of-war camp Ramenskoye - Ilyinskoye near Moscow.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The French Socialist party decided tonight to call a national congress of the party Nov. 10 and 11 to consider participation in the Cabinet of Premier Pierre Mendes-France.

"Tales of Hoffmann" was done at the City Center last evening with Cornell MacNeil as Dapertutto, Margaret Willauer as Giulietta, Edith Evans as Nicklausse and Frances Bible as the Apparition of Antonia's Mother.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Floors of sawdust or broken rock held together with plastic, and walls of translucent easy-to-maintain materials, were suggestions for the home of tomorrow at the Plastics in Building Conference that opened here today.

Roomier interiors, lower body lines and increased engine power are offered in the 1955 line of automobiles announced yesterday by the Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation. It listed 109 new features and improvements.

MADRID, Oct. 27 -- Two militant Roman Catholics found guilty of having assaulted a Protestant pastor and damaged his chapel in Seville were sentenced to six months and fined the equivalent of $150 today. However, they will not serve their terms because they benefit by an amnesty promulgated recently.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 27 -- The rags-to-politics saga of Abraham A. Ribicoff was unfolded with noisy fanfare today in this city of his birth. The people loved it -- all 80,000 of them, Democrats and Republicans alike.

"The American Legion and American Foreign Policy," a study by Dr. Roscoe Baker, will be issued next month by Bookman Associates. The author, a Legionnaire, reviews the activities of the Legion as a legislative lobby and as a force shaping public opinion.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Israel asked today for an "urgent" meeting of the United Nations Security council to take up her charges of interference by Egypt with Israel-bound ships using the Suez Canal.

An issue of $100,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of the Continental Oil Company, the enterprise's first public financing since 1938, will be placed on the market today by a syndicate of investment houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co.

George King led New York University to its fourth cross-country victory yesterday in a dual meet with Columbia. King, undefeated this season, ran the five-mile Van Cortlandt Park course in 26:47 as the Violets won, 17 -- 43.

Ralph J. Bunche, whose selection for a distinguished service medal by the Theodore Roosevelt Association has been criticized by the former President's son, reminded the association last night that Roosevelt had been denounced as a radical.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The fight for political power in Pakistan is not expected here to result in a swing away from her decision to line up with the Western alliance.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 27 -- Tamizuddin Khan, president of the Constituent Assembly, said today he would challenge the legality of Governor General Ghulam Mohammed's summary dissolution on Sunday of the seventy-four-man House.

Unionized employes of the John Wanamaker store on Broadway and Ninth Street got official assurance yesterday that the management would consider any offer they submitted to buy the store, which is scheduled to close in January.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- In view of the President's unusual campaign activity in behalf of the return of a Republican Congress in his mid-term, and in view also of his many statements that the record of his Administration is the issue, his news conference hearers today were not prepared for what he said on this subject.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The United States split with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today on his proposed rate of salaries and allowances for top-level officials of the reorganized secretariat. The reorganization, calling for a maximum of sixteen upper-echelon posts, is scheduled to go into effect Jan. 1.
NEWARK, Oct. 27 -- Clifford P. Case declared today that the election of a Democratic Congress next Tuesday would circumscribe President Eisenhower in his fight against communism at home and abroad.

Governor Dewey raised a question yesterday as to Averell Harriman's eligibility to serve as Governor, if elected. The basis of the challenge was a statement the Democratic-Liberal candidate signed when he voted in the 1952 Democratic Presidential primary in the District of Columbia.
William V. S. Tubman, President of Liberia, will receive a "full-dress New York City welcome'' today, including a tickertape parade up lower Broadway to City Hall.

The weather did not smile on Queen Mother Elizabeth during her first full day in New York yesterday, but it failed to dim her own smile, or to interfere with her schedule of entertainment and sight-seeing.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Admiral Earl Mountbatten was appointed to command the Royal Navy today almost exactly forty years after his father was ousted from the position because of his German parentage.
YONKERS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Al Burton drove Fred Drachler's Verna of Bainbridge, N. Y., to victory in the 34,000 Tuckahoe Pace on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

Ken MacAfee was back in action yesterday as the New York Football Giants held a two-hour drill at the Polo Grounds in preparation for their game against the Browns in Cleveland on Sunday. The rookie end, one of the Giants' best pass receivers, missed last Sunday's game with Washington because of a wrenched back.
HONG KONG, Oct. 27 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru left Peiping by air this morning for a three-day tour of eastern and southern cities that is scheduled complete his state visit to China.
The only question about the contest in Harlem's Sixteenth Congressional District is whether Democratic Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. will be reelected by his usual overwhelming plurality.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Oct. 27 -- Suspension of two Army Signal Corps civilians on charges this month was disclosed here today. They were the first suspensions under President Eisenhower's security risk program since last April.

The gurgle of cider pouring out of a jug. The low clear call of a ring-necked pheasant. The hollow thump of a falling football. Steel-rimmed wagon wheels scraping over stones in pumpkin patches. Contented voices in front of that old friend the fireplace.

Roger Lewis, Air Force Assistant Secretary for materiel, told the Packaging Institute at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday how air transportability of Air Force supplies had simplified their packaging and was rapidly eliminating stookpiling.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Fashions for the holiday festivities ahead as well as some for late day wear now have been shown in two midseason collections here.

What creates or cripples self-confidence in children? What makes one youngster assured and poised in his daily dealings with persons and situations, another fearful, uneasy and strained? What can parents do to help a timid child?

HILLSIDE, N. J., Oct. 27 -- Reese Williams, now in his thirty-fifth year as football coach at the Pingry School, took one look at the rainy skies this afternoon and ordered practice indoors. The decision was not surprising since the school's playing fields were seeded recently and the athletic staff has been keeping a "weather eye" on them.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named the first Negro Air Force general today.

Maybe it's too soon to tell, but judging from what the New York Rangers showed last night, they are a pretty good hockey team. Opposing the Detroit Red Wings in a National League game at Madison Square Garden, the Broadway Blues rolled to a 5-to-2 triumph, scoring four goals before Detroit made one.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Committee on the Judiciary of the New York State Bar Association said today it had found two candidates for Judge of the Court of Appeals "outstandingly qualified," one candidate "qualified," and one candidate "not qualified."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. Most of the President's remarks are in indirect discourse, as required by conference rules. The White House has authorized direct quotation of several answers, however, and these are indicated in the text by quotation marks and direct discourse.
Senator Irving M. Ives reiterated last night the Republican charge that the Democrats in their state platform had indicated a softness on communism.

Fordham will leave by plane for Miami at 8 o'clock this morning for its game with the Hurricanes of Miami University tomorrow night in the Orange Bowl. Thirty-five members of the team and three coaches will leave La Guardia Airport in a Capital Airlines plane.
WHAT goes on here, anyway? The Book-Of-the-Month Club people seem to be holding some sort of a fall lit'ry festival of their own. Or is it a combination in restraint of trade? Hard to say.

TORRINGTON, Conn., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Sale of the business of the Hendey Machine Company, Inc., of Torrington to the Barber-Colman Company of Rockford, Ill., was announced here today, effective Monday. The price was not announced.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 -- Shipping subsidies, particularly of the operating differential nature, were viewed somewhat critically today by the Secretary of Commerce, Sinclair Weeks.

Senator Irving M. Ives and Representative Jacob K. Javits made public yesterday an appeal to Secretary of State John Foster Dulles that no arms be shipped by this country to Arab states in the absence of a Near East security agreement.
Television has so transformed the art of campaigning that Republicans estimate 70 per cent of their outlay here is going to television and radio. The Democratic guess goes as high as 80 per cent.
BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 27 -- Within three weeks there has been a remarkable change in Idaho's political atmosphere.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told a nation-wide meeting of prison officials today that their institutions might be less crowded if more babies had more love.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 27 -- The eighth day of the trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, accused of murdering his wife, dragged by in Common Pleas Court here today, still without a jury being chosen.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Oct. 27 (Reuters) -- Southern Rhodesia issued today an appeal for experienced hunters, wanted to help slaughter thousands of elephants spreading diseases fatal to both humans and cattle.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The stock market tended to improve today, although volume was still limited. Prices closed firm despite a late reaction in industrial shares.

Among the most important and confusing decisions that face the independent voter in New York and similar metropolitan areas every two years is the selection of his Representative in the United States Congress. In large cities the individual candidates for this significant office are frequently unknown by name or reputation to more than a fraction of the electorate, and so the vote is cast more often than not on a mere "party line" basis.
Cocoa prices yesterday rose the cent-a-pound limit in all positions for the second day on the New York Cocoa Exchange.
The lid sealing the financial side of the 85-year-old Campbell Soup Company was pried open for public inspection yesterday.
Following are the texts of Governor Dewey's address last night, as recorded by The New York Times, and Averell Harriman's reply:

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 27 -- Adlai E. Stevenson called today for Democratic votes at next Tuesday's election as a protest against what he called the Republican Administration's "trickle-down" theory of Government aid to the economy.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday estimated consolidated net earnings for the first nine months at a new record of $438,000,000, or $7.23 a share.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, charged last night that Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., his Democratic-Liberal opponent, was guilty of "a big cover-up" of his voting record in Congress.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The United States Navy is a fighting force equal to all the other major navies of the world put together, an authoritative naval publication said today. But the Soviet Union is building up "substantial forces" of cruisers, destroyers and submarines, it added.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- An internal British Labor party feud flared again today when the party's National Executive condemned as "scurrilous" an article in last week's Tribune.

VIENNA, Oct. 27 -- A sharp attack was published today in Szabad Nep, Hungarian Communist newspaper, on Ernoe Geroe, Vice Premier of Hungary. The criticism has raised the question whether the position of the second man in the Hungarian Communist party, like that of Matyas Rakosi, Secretary General of the party, was in danger.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The United States, represented by the Peoria (Ill.) Caterpillars, won the opening game of the final round of the world basketball tournament today with a 56-43 victory over the Philippines.

Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, voted overwhelmingly yesterday to strike at midnight Sunday if no satisfactory agreement is reached with publishers of eight daily newspapers in the metropolitan area.
The hardwood lumber industry has fallen on hard times in the region that gave it birth during colonial times, according to a man who knows.
Earnings of Trans World Airlines, Inc., climbed to a record $7,086,000 in the third quarter, lifting the net for the nine months above all annual profits in the history of the company.

Ted Williams of the Boston Red Sox and Stan Musial of the St. Louis Cardinals, a couple of baseball's great hitters, are running one-two in the lifetime batting averages among major league players who were active during the 1954 campaign.
NEWARK, Oct. 27 -- Two leaders in iron workers' and laborers' unions were indicted by the Federal grand jury today for alleged extortion of $15,000.

L. Judson Morhouse, chairman of the New York State Republican Committee, said here last night that he had received from President Eisenhower a telegram urging that "a tremendous vote" be brought out next Tuesday.

The regional Red Cross blood program collected 780 pints of blood Wednesday. Included were 231 at the American Telegraph and Telephone Company and Western Electric Company at 195 Broadway, 185 at Young Rubicam, 285 Madison Avenue, and 147 at the Guaranty Trust Company, 35 Nassau Street.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 (UP) -- A new type sealed-beam headlamp giving motorists as much as eighty feet more "seeing distance" will be adopted as standard equipment on all American and Canadian autos next year, the Automobile Manufacturers Association revealed today.
ATLANTA, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, wartime director of this country's atomic bomb project, said today it was inevitable that some atomic secrets would fall into Russian hands.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The golden age of American architecture was declared today to be in the offing if, and when, architects learned to take full advantage of new plastic materials.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury in Denver today indicted an official of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union on charges of falsely denying Communist affiliations. Named in the six-count indictment was Maurice E. Travis, secretary-treasurer of the union, which has its headquarters in Denver.

WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 28 (AP) -- A court order prevented a vote by stockholders of the Follansbee Steel Corporation on a proposed sale of the company's assets today -- just as it became known that Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland industrialist, also wanted to buy the business.
The Waterfront Commission moved yesterday to strengthen its rules against union interference in the naming of waterfront agents and pier superintendents.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Lawyers for Owen Lattimore filed in Federal court today a motion to dismiss the two-count indictment for perjury returned against him on Oct. 7.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower held out tonight the prospect of a "hopeless traffic jam" in Federal affairs if he does not have a Republican-led Congress for the rest of his term.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Red Cross said today that in ten of its forty-five blood donor regions funds had been so low that local hospitals had been required to pay for some supplies and transportation costs.

President Eisenhower has joined Prime Minister Churchill in turning thumbs down on Soviet Russia's attempt to wreck the Paris accords. Both heads of Government flatly reject, until the Paris pacts have been ratified and put into effect, the Soviet proposal for another Big Four conference on Germany.
I recognize your right to support any candidates you choose for political office, even though I question the reasons for your choice.
A political novice is opposing a Tammany Hall weteran for the House seat from the Nineteenth (lower Manhattan) District. Although the contest is not expected to be close, it has become exciting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- A. L. Wheeler, chairman of the Democratic Central Committee for the District of Columbia, refused today to make public the voter certification cards for the 1952 primary in which Averell Harriman cast a ballot.

THANKS largely to Geraldine Page and an excellent cast, "The Rainmaker," acted at the Cort last evening, turns out to be an enjoyable romantic comedy. It is the work of N. Richard Nash, who was in a portentous mood last year with a cosmic piece entitled "See the Jaguar."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Government today announced it would seek to recover almost $3,500,000 of alleged "windfall" profits from builders of the Parkchester apartment development in New Orleans.

By an extraordinary coincidence two judges named Hand sat at the same time on the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, each distinguished for learning and a profound intellectual grasp of the law and of the American tradition. One of them, Augustus Noble Hand, retired since last year, died yesterday at the age of 85.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Oct. 28 (UP) -- The second-ranking English two-year-old of the 1954 season, Corporal II, ran a disappointing seventh in his American debut in the Ormondale Purse at Tanforan today.
John T. Hunt, port agent here for the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., was arrested yesterday with two other men on charges of receiving bribes for issuing union books and seamen's working permits.

Stocks moved in a familiar pattern yesterday. After a relatively firm opening, in which General Motors and the airlines were strong, prices moved gradually downward most of the day. Prices slipped more rapidly near the close, when volume expanded, and the session ended with a moderate net loss.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- The American Civil Liberties Union charged today that the United States was putting pressures on employes of international agencies that would destroy their integrity.

IN view of the fact that Notre Dame has lost to Navy on an average of only once in each seven games, it's a bit astonishing to realize that the Notre Dame-Navy series now ranks as the oldest unbroken intersectional series in the country. The chances are that nothing can interrupt it now, but the going was rather shaky in the early days.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 28 -- Members of the State Board of Regents, holding their first meeting on Long Island in more than four years toured this area's rapidly growing communities today to see at first hand the need for expanded school facilities.

GUATEMALA, Oct, 26 -- The United Fruit Company has asked the Government to review the expropriation of its lands Ordered by the regime of former President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, with a view to recovering the lost property.

TRENTON, Oct. 28 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for United States Senate, scoffed tonight at charges that a Democratic majority in Congress would wage a "cold war" on President Eisenhower.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 28 -- Social Democratic party leaders are planning systematic opposition to the Paris agreements on West German armament and sovereignty and the Saar settlement with France. The fight will be waged on the national and state levels inside an outside the federal and state parliaments.

Operations of the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries in the first nine months of this year resulted in a reduction in net income to $30,761,101 from $40,141,929 a year ago despite substantially lower taxes.
A weakened Columbia football team will face an old rival in Cornell at Baker Field tomorrow.
Two members of the Soviet Academy of Sciences are on their way to this country to take part tomorrow and Sunday in the closing ceremonies of Columbia University's Bicentennial.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. charged last night that a St. Lawrence power "give-away" to an upstate utilities company was fifteen times as large as the controversial "Dixon-Yates" proposal involving Tennessee Valley Authority power.

Voters in New York City next Tuesday will be filling thirty-three places on the bench of our courts as one of their major responsibilities at the polls. The highest judicial body in the state, the Court of Appeals, is involved, as are the Supreme Court, the Court of General Sessions, the Municipal Court, the City Court and County Court in Brooklyn.
The wives of the four top Republican candidates in the state got together yesterday to demonstrate their methods of helping their husbands run for public office.

Local broadcasting executives always interested in hearing and sizing up the general views of a new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, had their first opportunity yesterday to meet Frank C. McConnaughey.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Landau was the center of interest anyway, since he belongs to Queen Elizabeth, but the English thoroughbred put on an extra show today by balking at being unloaded from the airplane after arrival for next Wednesday's international race.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- Hollywood film studio heads are breathing easier now that reports from around the country clearly indicate that the bottom did not fall out of the box office last Sunday night when "Diamond Jubilee of Light" was on all the major television networks for two hours.

Sooner or later Ernest Hemingway was certain to win the Nobel Prize, as yesterday he did, Mr. Hemingway has been writing publishable material for over thirty years; he has been an important figure in our literature since "The Sun Also Rises," which appeared in 1926.

Sentences ranging from fifteen to twenty-two and a half years were imposed in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday on three men charged with taking part in the robbery of $190,319 from a Long Island bank on Aug. 18, 1953.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 28 -- Egypt and Israel were condemned in turn today by the Mixed Armistice Commission for recent incidents along the border of the Gaza strip.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Defense Department announced today that the Army and the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics were placing about $1,000,000,000 worth of contracts this month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Lawyers consulted by this department today on the question of Averell Harriman's eligibility to run for Governor in New York or to serve if elected were inclined to the view that the Republican challenge on this point was what is known in their trade as a technicality.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Gen. Humberto Mariles scored a double victory in the international jumping competition today and kept Mexico at the top of the heap in the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- The Babsonpoll predicted today that the Democrats would win control of the House of Representatives by sixty-four seats in next Tuesday's elections. It said control of the Senate was a toss-up.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 28 -- The Iranian Senate ratified today the agreement with eight foreign companies that will restore the country's vast oil industry.

The President of Liberia took some advice yesterday from a well-known adviser to American Presidents. The visiting Chief Executive, William V. S. Tubman, modestly seconded a suggestion from Bernard M. Baruch that business men here invest in the west African republic.

Net income of the nation's second-largest steel producer, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, dropped to $84,453,837 for the first nine months of this year from the record $93,525,340 a year ago. This was equal to $8.30 a common share, compared with $9.25 a share for the like period last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 9 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 28 -- Indonesian authorities have released nine of the eleven Dutch nationals arrested last month. Police officials said a thorough investigation had proved their innocence but that the interrogation of the two others was continuing.

WHILE thousands of deer hunters are sighting in their rifles in preparation for deer hunting, a few more dedicated shooters are burning up ammunition in preparation for a trophy hunt. The latter will compete with marksmen from twenty-nine other countries at the International Shooting Union championship in Venezuela, Nov. 14 to 29.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Peoria (Ill.) Caterpillars gained an early lead and easily defeated France, 70 -- 49, tonight in the world basketball tournament.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Mayor Robert F. Wagner of New York tonight warmly endorsed Senator Paul H. Douglas for re-election as Senator from Illinois and predicted victory for Averell Harriman, the Democratic Gubernatorial candidate in New York.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Charles E. Bohlen, United States Ambassador to Moscow, had an interview today with Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, about the case of Mrs. Karl E. Sommerlatte, whose presence in the Soviet Union has been declared "undesirable" by the Foreign Ministry. Mrs. Sommerlatte is the wife of the third secretary of the United States Embassy.
Following is the text of the address by Averell Harriman in Queens last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The first steps toward a third straight National League attendance record for the Milwaukee Braves were taken today with a proposal for adding 10,500 seats to County Stadium.

THE word "frontier" has almost been appropriated by Americans for their own use. When we hear it, we think of Daniel Boone and Kit Carson and the better part of three centuries it took our ancestors to push the American frontier from one ocean to another. But brave men and women have pioneered on many other frontiers -- in South America, in Australia and the Pacific islands and in Africa.
A five-hundred-acre farm property in Dutchess County has been purchased for new home colony. Known as the Brinkerhoff farm, the property is east of Fishkill on Routes 52 and 82.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- The nation's prisons are being crowded by mental defectives who should be receiving medical treatment rather than punishment, the eighty-fourth annual Congress of Correction was told today.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The volume of business fell again in the stock market here as the dock strike dragged on. But the undertone remained firm and rises outnumbered falls.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Mrs. Eisenhower, with obvious pride, displayed a handsome new set of china plates at the White House today, while parrying questions about Tuesday's Congressional elections.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 28 -- Eleven United States Senators today campaigned in Oregon for Senator Guy Cordon or his Democratic rival, Richard L. Neuberger.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 746,007 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 24,605 cars or 3.4 per cent more than in the preceding week, 58,406 cars or 7.3 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of last year and 14,766 cars, or 1.9 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of 1952.
AN expensively staged musical comedy hit studded with stars, Equity-approved and with sets and lighting by Jo Mielziner is in the midst today of a three-day New York run.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Government has raised its long-term stockpile goal to $9,000,000,000, or $2,000,000,000 more than any previous figure given for the stockpile program.

Fifteen hundred unionized employes of the John Wanamaker store voted unanimously last night alternative proposals to seek continuance of the business in a "partnership" with the owners or to buy with the help of investment bankers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Gabriel Hauge, White House economic aide, voiced the belief today that the Government never again in this generation would need to resort to large-scale pump-priming to bolster the country's economy.

A portrait of Dr. William Samuel Johnson, the first president of Columbia College, will have its first public showing beginning Sunday in the Low Memorial Library of Columbia University. The picture, recently purchased by the Hirschl Adler Galleries, 270 Park Avenue, had been in the possession of direct Johnson descendants from the time of its execution in 1761.

A heavy newspaper advertising campaign in some 300 papers in 180 markets is being used to introduce the Borden Company's new Instant Starlac, a nonfat dry-milk product claimed by the maker to be instantly soluble.

Averell Harriman angrily denounced last night as "lies" the charges that have been made against him by Governor Dewey and Senator Irving M. Ives, based on his business activities before he entered Government service.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation yesterday took the wraps off a new process that the company believes will change production techniques in many industries concerned with temperature control. It is a method of creating tubing inside a sheet of metal.

TRENTON, Oct. 28 -- Adlai E. Stevenson tonight termed it "singular" that President Eisenhower, in his press conference yesterday, had contended he did not know about Republican use of the "Communist" issue against Democrats in this campaign.
Let me add a word of annotation to the few examples of Chinese translations in your special dispatch from the United Nations in the Oct. 17 issue of The Times.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Raya Garbousova, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "The Marriage of Figaro," City Center, 8:15; Albeneri Trio, Town Hall, 8:30; Composers Group of New York City, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Juilliard Orchestra, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30; "Don Pasquale," Amato Opera Theatre, 8:30.

CHICAGO, Oct 28 (AP) -- Hog prices advanced today even though salable receipts, totaling 10,000 head, were 2,000 more than the advance estimate. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
