MIAMI, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Miami's Hurricanes are three-touchdown favorites over the Fordham Rams in their football game tomorrow night, but there's no smugness in the Miami camp.

LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 28 -- Two French lawyers pleaded on opposite sides in an international law court here today. One was arguing for the French Government, the other in favor of a supranational body representing six nations of the European Coal and Steel Community.

MADRID, Oct. 28 -- Harold E. Stassen, director of the Foreign Operations Administration, held separate conversations today with the Spanish Ministers of Agriculture, Commerce and Industry. The conferences were said to have concerned steps designed to improve Spain's civilian economy, and not merely those, sectors that are directly related to the defense program.
Twenty-four years ago Sinclair Lewis put the name of Ernest Hemingway before the Swedish Academy. That was when Lewis received the first Nobel Prize for Literature awarded to an American.
A 41-year-old counterfeiter who was arrested last August as he was about to go into the business of printing "Lucky Bucks" found yesterday in Federal Court that his luck had not deserted him.

Outstanding results have been achieved by Egon Adler in a series of designs worked in mosaic for table tops and plaques. These are now on view at Living Today, 1398 Lexington Avenue. The designs exhibit a skillful blending of color and some striking abstract forms.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower set an early take-off for his four-state political airlift tomorrow to aid Republican Senatorial candidates.
Retailers, distributors and wholesalers in twenty-two diversified lines of business will continue to adhere to hand-to-mouth buying policies and do not plan to rebuild their inventories.

The Bankers Trust Company made a construction loan of $3,400,000 through Ivor B. Clark, Inc., broker, on the twelve-story air-conditioned office building going up at 156 William Street, northeast corner of Ann Street. The structure, designed for occupancy by insurance companies, is sponsored by the 156 William Street Corporation, headed by Irwin S. Wolfson.
Many parties will be given at the Halloween Ball, a dinner dance, for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery to be held tonight in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

Autumn has a way, sometimes, of making certain people feel their years. Not those ruddy-cheeked people who on Saturdays, jersey-clad and helmeted trot briskly into crowded stadia, their calves bulging with muscle and their hearts with optimism.

Although gross operating revenues of the Union Pacific Railroad dropped $38,364,461 to $355,165,396 in the first nine months of this year, the management reported yesterday that net income for the period was $47,638,404. In the like period last year, net income was $48,946,414.

Plans for building a five-story apartment house for twenty families in the Murray Hill section were announced yesterday in connection with the leasing of 27 and 29 East Thirty-eighth Street, between Park and, Madison Avenues, by Frances A. Engle and others to the 27 East Thirty-eighth Street Realty Corporation, representing Edward Kammerman and Louis T. Brooks.
UNION, N. J., Oct. 28 -- Automatic toll collectors will soon speed motorists on their way on the new Garden State Parkway.

George Romney, chairman and president of the American Motors Corporation, denied yesterday that a merger was contemplated with the Studebaker-Packard Corporation. Instead, there will be an over-all "product reciprocity" between the two organizations, he said.

TRENTON, Oct. 28 -- Representative Charles Robert Howell was once a registered Republican. His transfer of party allegiance was a direct result of an attempt by his father-in-law, a prominent local Republican, to whip up his interest in politics.
PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 28 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today charged Adlai E. Stevenson with unconsciously spreading Communist propaganda.

The Statue of Liberty had a "birthday" yesterday -- her sixty-eighth. The day was marked by afternoon ceremonies on Bedloes Island at which Dr. You Chan Yang of Korea emphasized his nation's intention to unite all Korea "in freedom."
Attractive, short jackets shown with slim dresses emphasized the ensemble, a fashion featured in the collection of Abe Schrader presented by Lord Taylor yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for Attorney General, charged yesterday that Democratic city administrations were responsible for dirty streets, increased crime, snarled traffic, bad transportation, inadequate schools and poor housing.
It was easier yesterday to pick a jammed detention-cell lock in the United States Court House than to break through Government red tape.
Hen, or fowl, a fine basis for salad, stew, or a fricassee, deserves a place of special attention on this week-end's marketing lists.
Consolidated net income of Standard Brands, Inc., and its United States and Canadian subsidiaries rose to $8,208,672 in the first nine months of 1954 from $7,265,072 last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower paid a warm compliment today to Vice President Richard M. Nixon, who has pitched the final Republican Congressional campaign almost exclusively on the so-called "Red issue."

A double honor went last night to Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, the television scientist and inventor and one of the most ardent yachtsmen on the metropolitan waterways. At the annual meeting at the Shelton Hotel of the Eastern Cruiser Association, Dr. Du Mont was elected commodore for the coming year to succeed William Edgar John, the founder and first commodore.

AN EXHIBITION that would make any art season memorable opens at the Metropolitan Museum tomorrow. A hundred paintings by more than fifty seventeenth-century artists of the Netherlands, drawn from public and private collections in this country and abroad will be shown until Dec. 19.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 28 -- The United States Army in Europe announced today that official West German representatives may attend United States troop exercises and weapons demonstrations in accordance with security regulations.
A simplified scoring system for boxing which would eliminate the New York method of awarding rounds will be proposed to the State Athletic Commission today by Chairman Robert K. Christenberry.

Propositions on the ballot are often ignored by a large number of voters. We feel that the two propositions on the ballot Nov. 2 should receive an affirmative vote. However, there is a caution to be observed on each of the propositions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 28 -- The Nobel Prize for Literature was awarded today to Ernest Hemingway. The Swedish Academy, which presents this laurel, said of the 55-year-old American author in its citation:

Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Belgian Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak praised last night the nine-power London and Paris agreements restoring sovereignty to Germany but agreed that the pacts were not equal in scope to the defunct European Defense Community.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a net income of $5,545,775 in the first nine months of this year and a September net income at the highest level in twenty-five years.
SALERNO, Italy, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Help poured in today for the shocked survivors of Italy's greatest flood disaster of modern times.
Support of a program for overhauling New York State's unwieldy court system has been pledged by the two major candidates for Governor.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- The ninth session of the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) opened today.

The annual Soph-Frosh Rush, a long tradition at Columbia College involving mock wars between freshhmen and sophomores, was suspended yesterday in penalty for a "panty raid" conducted Wednesday night by 200 Columbia men on Barnard College.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, accused the Columbia Broadcasting System and the American Broadcasting Company tonight of "blacking out" Democratic spokesmen. He urged them to reconsider their refusal to grant radio and television time to match appearances by President Eisenhower.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 28 -- Princeton's football fortunes, which reached a low ebb with the loss of tailbacks Royce Flippin and Dick Frye, plummeted even lower today when it was learned that a pair of reserves, Dick Emery and Jan Brecknitz, probably would be lost for the Colgate game Saturday.

The Oyster Bay, L. I., Union Free School District 23 sold yesterday $3,828,000 of bonds due from 1956 to 1984 to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.769 for obligations bearing interest of 2.7 per cent. On reoffering, the bonds were priced to yield 1 to 2.85 per cent.

Announcement was made here yesterday by their respective presidents of the proposed consolidation of Keller Tool Company of Grand Haven, Mich., and the Gardner-Denver Company of Quincy, Ill. Both are in related fields of the manufacture of pneumatic equipment and tools.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- The United Nations' members approved today a resolution that South Africa, India and Pakistan undertake "direct negotiations" to settle their dispute over alleged discrimination against South Africa's Indian minority of 350,000.

Albert Schiffers, assistant title officer of the Mineola office of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, who is retiring after forty-three years with the company, was honored last night at a dinner at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, L. I.
PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Paris welcomed Haile Selassie, Emperor of Ethiopia, today with the enthusiasm that this republican capital reserves for royal visitors.
States Marine Lines, one of the largest operators of American tonnage in world-wide cargo trade, is disposing of five Liberty ships, it was learned yesterday.
Two new projects to increase public interest in common stocks were announced yesterday by Keith Funston, president, in submitting the quarterly report of the New York Stock Exchange.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Mayor William E. Kemp of Kansas City said tonight, "we still will be awfully happy to have them," when informed of the American League owners' disapproval of a Philadelphia syndicate offer for the Athletics.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- The United States Embassy announced today the cancellation of a contract let under the offshore procurement program to a concern in which Communist labor unions have been gaining in strength.

Operations of the Otis Elevator Company in the nine months ended Sept. 30 resulted in net income of $6,689,057, equal to $3.34 a common share, compared with $6,179,807, or $3.09 a share in the corresponding period in 1953.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 -- A jury of middle - class people -- five housewives and seven family men -- was sworn in here today to try Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, an oesteopath, for the murder of his wife, Marilyn, at their home near here last July 4.

Today in the United States there are more than 1,500,000 Girl Scouts. The number of Scouts in the five boroughs of New York City has passed the 50,000 mark, but the organization has 10,000 more girls on its waiting list here. The number of members enrolled constitutes less than 10 per cent of the girls of Scout age -- 7 through 17 -- in the city.
With strong westerly winds of up to fifty miles an hour sweeping virtually the whole North Atlantic, a further delay in the arrivals of inbound liners was reported yesterday.
HAVANA, Oct. 28 -- Ernest Hemingway started out this great day for him by being unnaturally formal.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- The Ford Motor Company reported today a new high in total assets of $1,895,134,000 at the close of 1953.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Three fire chiefs and two firemen were killed today in an explosion at the Charles W. Berg Laboratories, chemical and oil manufacturers, 1827-29 North Fifth Street.

I read your editorial of Oct. 27 making recommendations for the State Legislature. You state in your editorial that you were not passing on the merits of first-time candidates, but only dealing with incumbents in office.
Plans for this year's Horse Show Ball, to be held next Friday in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, are nearing completion.
Two Italian youngsters, neither of whom has ever seen his baby sister, arrived here yesterday confident that American medical skill would restore their eyesight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A "slight touch of bursitis or some slight strain" gave President Eisenhower a bit of discomfort during his television address tonight.
Red and pink flowers and festoons of ribbons in the same hues provided a colorful decor for the second annual Versailles Ball held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Magistrate Evelyn Richman dismissed in Probation Court yesterday an action for criminal libel that had been filed against Jerome Fine, 32 years old, of 350 Central Park West, by Sgt. George Hartwell of the West 100th Street police station.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -- Dartmouth, the team that ruined Yale's hopes of winning the Ivy football championship last year, comes to the Bowl Saturday to engage a Bulldog eleven that is again riding high at the top of the league.

Between regular sessions yesterday of the Columbia University bicentennial conference on "Responsible Freedom in the Americas" John A. Krout, vice president and provost of the university, addressed the participants briefly.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The British Government will consider at a high level all future United States requests for help in cases comparable to the Lattimore case.
Following is the text of an address by President Eisenhower at a dinner last night of the Citizens for Eisenhower Congressional Committee, as recorded by The New York Times:

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Army today upheld the conviction of Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor for collaborating with the Communists in a Red prison camp, but shortened the life sentence to twenty years.
IT'S happened and it's wonderful: Walt Disney is on TV!

The outstanding, indeed the memorable, event of the Philharmonic-Symphony concert last night in Carnegie Hall was the profoundly perceptive and moving interpretation by Mr. Mitropoulos and his players of Vaughan Williams' Fourth Symphony.

Once upon a time, way back in September, there was hope that the developing state and national campaigns might be conducted along lines that would stick to the issues, deal candidly with the voters and avoid personal vilification and abuse.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $149,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Record earnings of $26,445,787 were achieved by the C. I. T. Financial Corporation in the first nine months, and prospects for the fourth quarter are "excellent," Arthur O. Dietz, president, reported yesterday.

So widely spread over the track were the three fillies at the finish of the feature at Jamaica yesterday, even those among the 15,335 turfgoers at the line were unable to call the winner. The camera decided that the Cain Hoy Stable's Fantan, on the extreme outside, had won the six-furlong dash.
"Show Boat," which had its first performance of the fall season at the City Center last evening, continues to be an engaging production as done by the New York City Opera Company.
Vince Martinez, Paterson welterweight contender, is favored to turn back Carmine Fiore, left-hook specialist from Brooklyn, in the main bout scheduled for ten rounds tonight at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Tax law experts said today the Internal Revenue Service's plan to indicate a taxpayer's income by colored stripes on his instruction form envelope probably was not a Federal law violation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Oceanic Steamship Company today announced plans to renew passenger service from California to New Zealand and Australia with two specially reconstructed ships.

A biography of Lord Byron compiled from reports of 140 individuals who talked with the poet and left a record of what he said will be published Nov. 16 by Macmillan. It has been titled "His Very Self and Voice: Collected Conversations of Lord Byron," The editor is Ernest J. Lovell Jr., associate professor of English at the University of Texas.
For the first time since her arrival in New York, Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain was seen yesterday by large crowds -- and they nearly mobbed her as she left the Empire State Building.

The possibility that the Philadelphia Athletics would be shifted to Kansas City returned strongly to life yesterday when the American League club owners refused to approve the Mack family's proposed sale of the club to an eight-man syndicate that would keep the team in Philadelphia.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith said today after a six-day visit to Moscow that she would not be "surprised" if United States - Soviet diplomatic relations were broken off "at any time by either side."

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Scholars specializing in the humanities received what must be for upper academic circles a brisk tongue-lashing from a scientist here this afternoon. This occurred at Arden House at the opening of a general discussion session on "The Unity of Knowledge," under the sponsorship of Columbia University.

Senator Irving M. Ives revived last night the case of a mortgage company of which Averell Harriman was a director. The Republican candidate for Governor charged that small investors lost $60,000,000 of $372,000,000 they placed in the company.

YONKERS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Bluett Hanover, owned by R. R. Kirby and J. B. Holloway of Harrington, Del., nosed out Hickory Doc in the Sawmill Pace on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Bluett Hanover paced the mile in 2:06 4/5.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Soybean prices soared today, while grains had an easy trend.
DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) -- F. L. Jacobs Company announced today purchase of Mills Industries, Inc., of Chicago, and Selmix Dispensers, Inc., of Long Island City, Queens, N. Y.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 28 (UP) -- Favorites forged ahead with a minimum of effort in the second round of match play in the nineteenth annual Texas Women's Open golf tournament today.
Last Sept. 25, a man came to the home of Dominick Stabile, 60-year-old bank guard, of 2319 Hughes Avenue, the Bronx. He asked Mr. Stabile to sign an "independent nominating petition for Flynn."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of a joint statement by President Eisenhower and Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, after their meeting at the White House today:

Next Tuesday the voters of New York City will elect thirty-two judges. These will include the Chief Judge and three Associate Judges of the Court of Appeals -- the highest court in the state. These thirty-two judges will serve from ten to fourteen years. Their salaries will total over $10,000,000.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The West Berlin City Assembly ousted Deputy Mayor Walter Conrad from office today for having refused a store license to a Jewish chemist and for allegedly having lied to the city government about the case.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 28 -- The Vietminh administration of Hanoi announced yesterday that it did not "recognize" the United States Consulate there. It considers Washington statements justifying the presence of the consulate in Hanoi as "unacceptable."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The White House has advised all departments and agencies that "qualified loyal Republicans of proven ability" should be placed in more Federal jobs.
The Transit Authority denied yesterday that proposed service cuts would be made "indiscriminately."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower has not stated his views, since occupying the White House, on appointing an Ambassador to the Vatican, but apparently he does not favor it at this time. His latest public expressions on the subject were made as a candidate.

An all-male jury was selected yesterday in General Sessions for the first-degree murder trial of John Francis Roche. As the jury and two male alternates were picked, the 26-year-old Roche urged James D. C. Murray, his principal defense counsel, not to work too hard to save him from possible execution.

Plans have been completed for the conversion of the Utica Theatre building at 1410 St. Johns Place in Brooklyn into a supermarket. The building, on plot 120 by 140 feet, has been leased by the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company from the Randforce Amusement Corporation through M. C. O'Brien, Inc., as broker.
Net profit of the Standard Oil Company of California in the first nine months this year rose to $154,920,656, or $5.15 a share, from $140,217,394, or $4.66 a share, earned in the 1953 period.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower joined Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, today in endorsing the reunification of Germany as a "legitimate demand of the German people."

NEWARK, Oct. 28 -- Clifford P. Case predicted tonight that the people of New Jersey would make it clear on Tuesday that they still preferred the leadership and program of President Eisenhower to that of Adlai E. Stevenson.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- A witness who said he had spied on American Reds for ten years named seventy-two men and women today as fellow members of the Communist party.

Made-to-order furniture, flooring, wallpaper, fabrics and other furnishings for interiors can now be assembled through one company, David Wider Associates, 515 Madison Avenue. The service is available through decorators.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 28 -- Associate Justice Felix Frankfurter delivered a talk on "The Role of the Supreme Court in American Life," at Smith College tonight. He inaugurated the annual Alice M. Holen lectureship on the elements of good citizenship.
ALBANY, Oct. 28 (UP) -- The state announced today that it would "shortly" start to build the New England section of the Thruway and expected to finish the first four miles by July 1, 1956.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 8 to 17 points yesterday. Business was somewhat quieter than earlier this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The State Department said today the Vietminh would commit a "flagrant violation" of the Indochina armistice agreement if it forced the United States to close its consulate in Hanoi.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 28 -- Making use of his extraordinary powers under the state of siege, President Carlos Ibanez del Campo last night ordered the arrest of one of Chile's best known journalists and radio commentators. The accusation involved his broadcasting of a story about possible Cabinet changes.

Coffee futures rose the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit yesterday in all positions except the near-by December on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The December option was up 60 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). Volume was 111,000 bags, the largest since Sept. 17. There were 120 unsatisfied bids at the close.

Repayments by public utilities totaling $73,000,000 accounted for a net decrease of $64,000,000 in New York bank loans to business in the week ended on Wednesday. In the corresponding 1953 week such loans were expanded by $52,000,000.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 28 -- The formation of Pakistan's first coalition Government began tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The United States is preparing a new emergency aid program for Haiti to speed her recovery from the recent assault by hurricane Hazel.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Noses were counted around the barns at Garden State Park today and the conclusion was reached that fourteen 2-year-olds would compete in the world's richest horse race Saturday.
Things would be vastly different in the Eighteenth Congressional District if Vito Marcantonio had lived to carry out his intention of running there to regain his seat in the House of Representatives.
Spokesmen for the New York Stock Exchange would just as soon pretend that nothing in particular happened on the Big Board just twenty-five years ago this morning.

A month-long series of special events marking the 100th anniversary of the dedication of New York's historic Marble Collegiate Church ended last night with a testimonial dinner at the Sheraton Astor Hotel.

Directors of the General Dynamics Corporation placed the common stock on a $4 annual basis with the declaration yesterday of an increased quarterly dividend of $1 a share for payment Jan. 10 to holders of record Dec. 14.

Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack has suspended the franchise of the A. C. A. Auto Sales and Service, Inc., to tow disabled cars off the West Side Highway. Mr. Jack acted after two officers of the concern had been convicted of petit larceny.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The leaders of the 43,000 dock workers, whose strike has halted or limited operations at eight British ports, rejected tonight a peace formula offered by the Ministry of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Navy announced today award of a $31,900,000 contract to the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N. J., for construction of four escort vessels.
The ghosts and the goblins will be lurking in unexpected places next Sunday evening when children again celebrate one of their favorite festivals, Halloween.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Karl Sommerlatte, central figure in a diplomatic incident involving the wives of two members of the United States Embassy staff, said tonight she expected to leave the Soviet Union next Wednesday. Well-informed sources said her husband would leave at the same time or shortly thereafter.

Representatives of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, and the Publishers Association of New York City discussed specific contract clauses yesterday in an effort to reach a wage agreement:

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- On the occasion of the thirtieth anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries, the Soviet Union appealed to France today to collaborate with it in opposing a "revival of German militarism."

A plan for members of the American Guild of Variety Artists to be employed as entertainers in military hospitals in the United States will be discussed in Washington with Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Foxcatcher Farm's Chevation, a 9-1 shot, made his bid along the outside as he hit the home stretch today and pulled away for a three-length victory in the $58,000 Yankee Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

The Red Cross blood program performs miracles in saving lives every day, John S. Sinclair, chairman, told the annual meeting of the New York Chapter yesterday. It takes half of the chapter's money, time and effort, he said, "but it is worth every bit of it in satisfaction."

NEWARK, Oct. 28 -- Orange juice that was extracted from tree-ripened oranges in Florida seventy-two hours before was placed on public sale in one-quart cardboard containers in northern New Jersey today. Home delivery price for a quart was 38 cents; store prices were 2 or 3 cents lower.
ROME, Oct. 29 -- The Cabinet today appointed Manlio Brosio, at present Ambassador in London, as the new Italian Ambassador in Washington to replace Alberto Tarchiani, who is retiring.
PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Two golfers, seeking relief from smog, today are blasting over brush and through trees along an impromptu forty-five-mile course through Angeles National Forest.

Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, commanding general of the Seventy-seventh Army Reserve Infantry Division, declared last night that "if we want the peace of freedom and independence, we must prepare for it, work for it, and deserve it."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, linked President Eisenhower today directly with a campaign of "smear and fear" and said that the President had "threatened the people to vote for his candidates -- or else."

Speaking before the National Conference of Business Editors in Washington on Thursday, Gabriel Hauge, President Eisenhower's assistant for economic affairs, discussed the Administration's economic policies generally, but placed his greatest emphasis on one basic principle in particular.
Adlai E. Stevenson, speaking yesterday before a wildly enthusiastic and jampacked rally in Manhattan Center, applied the whiplash of his oratory to Senator Irving M. Ives.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -Peru's Ambassador to the United States declared here today he believed trade between his country and America "should be a two-way street.
Strikes affected earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, but the outlook for the fourth quarter is good, C.R. Cox, president, reported yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29 -- The top-ranking elevens in the Ivy group, Dartmouth and Yale, will meet tomorrow in the Bowl.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Upstate communities have awakened in the last few days to "the grave danger" of Tammany Hall's gaining control of the state in Tuesday's election, J. Raymond McGovern told audiences in Westchester County today.

SHIRAZ, Ivan, Sept. 30 -- This is one of the last places where one would expect to find one of the most scientifically modern medical centers in the world. But two American doctors on the staff say there is none better in the United States.
SAN MATEO, Calif., Oct. 29 -Housing scandals that the Truman Administration failed to check now constitute the biggest scandal in American history, Vice President Richard M. Nixon charged today.

Two thousand unionized workers in the Sanitation Department marched on City Hall yesterday to complain about money and uniforms, but they never reached their objective, the meeting room of the Board of Estimate.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 29 (AP)--A fast-breaking Uruguay team caught the Peoria (Ill.) Caterpillars off balance tonight, but the United States entry finally gained a 64-59 victory for its fifth straight success in the world basketball championship.
The board of directors of the American Friends of the Middle East, Inc., has issued a statement protesting attempts to inject the Arab-Israeli conflict into the election campaign.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 29 (UP) -- The Opposition Radical party charged today that a total of 107 university students, arrested early this month, still were being held here and in Eva Peron City (La Plata).

HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Housing Administrator Albert M. Cole, declaring intensified Federal warfare on racial discrimination in housing, announced today that the Government would refuse Federal aid to cities that "default on their obligations to minority citizens."
The appointment of Theodore H. Lang as director of the city's newly created bureau of personnel relations was announced yesterday by Joseph Schechter, director of the Department of Personnel.
Governor Dewey told a television audience last night that Averell Harriman's election as his successor would be a disaster for the people of New York State.

Greece wants to be included among the few foreign nations now approved for flag transfer of uneconomic American merchant shipping, her Minister of Merchant Marine, George Voyadzis, said here yesterday.

"HE was 55 years old," Oliver Dyer wrote of Sam Houston in the United States Senate, "a magnificent barbarian, somewhat tempered by Civilization. He was of large frame, of stately carriage and dignified demeanor and had a lionlike countenance capable of expressing fiercest passions. His dress was peculiar, but it was becoming to his style.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy predicted today that the Senate, returning on Nov. 8, would vote to censure him. He indicated that he expected this action to be decisive. A Senate censure of one of its members is a rarity.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted two men, including a brother of Mickey Cohen, former West Coast hoodlum, on charges of conspiring to defraud the Federal Housing Administration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Following is a translation of an address by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, at a National Press Club luncheon today:
A proposal to simplify the scoring system for boxing bouts in this state was tabled, pending further study, by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday.
Informal agreement by the Board of Estimate on granting the city's 11,000 firemen an annual allowance of $100 to help meet the cost of uniforms was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner's office.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Connie Mack said tonight "no matter what the Macks say or do, the answer will be Kansas City" in the tug of war over the Philadelphia American League franchise.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The New York State Grange today called upon the Legislature to make a "complete investigation" of the State Education Department and to correct what it called "unlawful practices where they may exist."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Without dissent, United Nations members voted today to call on thousands of Nationalist Chinese "irregulars" to leave northern Burma or submit to internment.

Delegates of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs voted yesterday to condemn a paragraph in a report of the United Nations International Civil Service Advisory Board regarding the national and international loyalties of United Nations employes.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 29 -- Ten accomplishments of the Eisenhower Administration were listed tonight by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, as warranting the election of a Republican Congress next Tuesday.

Agreement was reached last night ending a two-week dispute between the New York City Transit Authority and its bus drivers on Staten Island. The drivers then voted, 149 to 87, to accept the agreement.
DETROIT, Oct. 29 -- A large crowd heard President Eisenhower's appeal today for a great turnout of voters on Election Day to support Michigan Republican candidates for Federal and state offices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (tP)-Americans are eating more'fat-, 'no matter what they ,hear from the health and beauty experts.
The top man in the United States Chamber of Commerce thinks that business failures will increase in the immediate future.

Announcement that the Federal Trade Commission has ordered "a speedy but thorough investigation of the current wave of mergers" underlines the Eisenhower Administration's concern over a dramatic development -- one that is also of great concern to business and the public.

Paper Tiger, with Conn McCreary giving one of his typical late-riding performances, took the $15,000 added Snark Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Opposing six others in the mile and a furlong test, Paper Tiger closed with a rush to score by a length and a half over C. V. Whitney's Fly Wheel.
We have read with interest Commissioner Stichman's letter replying to that of Ralph Brooks, representing the Federation of New York Taxpayers.

Former Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican of New Jersey, declared last night that voters should protest against the candidacy of Clifford P. Case for United States Senator by writing in votes for their own choices.

A sealed indictment charging seditious conspiracy to twelve Puerto Rican Nationalists was opened yesterday after the Federal Bureau of Investigation had rounded up the terrorist party leaders -- six here, four in Chicago and two in Puerto Rico.
GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- The Geneva trade conference has decided that tariff negotiations with Japan should start in February, 1955, probably Feb. 21.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 29 -- Two maps, one having the first known cartographic mention of America and the other indicating that Portuguese sailors were in the West Indies before Columbus have been acquired by the University of Minnesota's James Ford Bell Collection.

DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Marquette's battered line, ripped for 150 points in six games, made a magnificent stand inside its own 10-yard line in the final two minutes tonight to give the Warriors a 14-13 victory over the University of Detroit.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- The United States Embassy applied to the Soviet Government today for an exit permit for Mrs. Karl Sommerlatte, whose presence in the country has been declared "undesirable" by the Foreign Ministry.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange increased somewhat in October over the September level and was the heaviest for an October since 1950. Sales exceeded the 2,000,000-share mark in 15 sessions. The largest turnover was 2,554,163 shares, on Oct. 6.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Embattled minor league club owners will file suit Monday against Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick and the major league owners for invading the minors' territory with game broadcasts and telecasts.

In a group of decisions which deserve nation-wide attention the National Labor Relations Board has this week confirmed its previously announced intention to limit its own jurisdiction. Each case showed a three-to-two split along party lines, with the three Eisenhower appointees casting the decisive votes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -The program for home purchases by service men on active duty will start within a week, it was announced today by Norman P. Mason, the Federal Housing Commissioner.

The Soviet Government has been wooing India with great enthusiasm on a wide variety of fronts this past year. An Indian has been given the "Stalin Peace Prize" and a great fuss has been made in Moscow over the visit of a troupe of Indian dancers and other artists.
Roman Catholic voters in New Jersey were urged yesterday by official diocesan publications to oppose plans for a $25,000,000 state medical-dental school and health center.

POCATELLO, Idaho, Oct. 29 -Glen H. Taylor, Democratic candidate for the Senate, today filed a $100,000 slander suit against Ross Haworth, his former secretary, who charged in an interview yesterday that throughout his previous incumbency Mr. Taylor had consorted with and accepted aid from known Communists.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 29 -- Yale University is exploring means to raise funds for fellowships for promising young playwrights, Curtis Canfield, chairman of the Department of Drama, told 500 alumni at a convocation banquet tonight.

A "piggy-back" idea for sea transport will be translated into operation on Nov. 18 when the first Liberty shipload of truck trailers leaves New York Harbor for Puerto Rico for Trailer Marine Transportation, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Pentagon made known today that almost $5,000,000,000 in defense contracts had been placed by the three services in the four-month period since July 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.2 per cent to 109.6 (1947-49=100) over the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher prices for farm products were responsible, as average prices of foodstuffs and industrial materials declined fractionally.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission today awarded a silver medal to Theodore Henderson, 40 years old, of Tampa, Fla., for rescuing a 19-year-old girl whose auto had plunged into an alligator-infested canal.
One of the strongest spokesmen for fair trade has laid the future of the concept squarely at the doors of manufacturers of brand merchandise.

Activity in the new capital market will be slowed up next week by the Election Day holiday. Underwriters of corporate debt securities have no new issues scheduled for marketing and hence will have time to work off unsold balances of recent offerings.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- The United States plan for peaceful uses of atomic energy requires much clarification and elaboration, Dr. Pierre Auger, French physicist, said here today.

The New York Central Railroad plans to give Alfred E. Perlman, its president and chief executive officer, a ten-year option to purchase 32,000 shares of Central stock at $19.87 1/2 a share. Central closed on the New York Stock Exchange last night at $19.12 1/2.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- William V.S. Tubman, President of Liberia, appealed to the members of the United Nations today to surrender a part of the "national rights and powers" to help the world organization establish a lasting peace.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Army's football squad will meet Virginia in the first game between the two institutions at Michie Stadium tomorrow.

James D.C. Murray, principal defense counsel for John Francis Roche, who is on trial in General Sessions for first-degree murder, described the defendant yesterday as having a mind like "a scrambled egg." This condition, he said, was caused by Roche's "Tobacco Road" background.
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Robert Schuman, former Foreign Minister, is expected to decline an offer by Premier Pierre Mendes-France to become Ambassador to the United States.
A 61-year-old jeweler was wounded fatally in his store yesterday by one of two hold-up men who were trapped in the establishment for a short time after the shooting.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 29 -Some 1,500 to 2,500 cheering Republicans greeted President Eisenhower tonight as he gave a twenty-minute speech in a hangar at the New Castle County Airport about four miles south of Wilmington.

The Union Oil Company of California reported yesterday its net profit at $27,150,736 in the first nine months this year. This is equal to $3.98 a share on 6,658,464 common shares and compares with $28,006,699, or $4.11 each on 5,266,270 common shares, for the corresponding period last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Twelve Western nations, including the United States, introduced a resolution today endorsing a report by the General Assembly's Collective Measures Committee on the principles that should guide members of the United Nations in taking action against an aggressor.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Stock trading began hesitatingly on the Stock Exchange today in the face of dock strike developments, and business was quieter. But selective buying kept the markets firm.

Reformation Sunday will be observed tomorrow in many Protestant churches, with special sermons and services marking the 437th anniversary of the day Martin Luther nailed his famed Ninety-five Theses to the church door in Wittenberg, Germany.

In the Twenty-first Congressional District -- one of the few in the city where there's a real contest -- two forceful personalities are campaigning for the seat left vacant by Jacob K. Javits in his race for Attorney General. Each candidate has his own recipe for political success.

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., Oct. 29 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission's Grand Junction operations office said today that its leading problem had become finding sufficient mills to process the "phenomenal" amount of uranium ore being produced.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A recent downward trend in new unemployment insurance claims was interrupted last week, the Department of Labor reported today.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of help to the homemaker:
An injury-riddled Columbia football team takes on a fast-improving, rejuvenated Cornell eleven in an Ivy League contest at Baker Field today. The kickoff time is 2 P.M.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 27 -- A campaign in which Kansas Democrats have made their greatest effort in many years was ending this week with both major parties hopeful of changing the state's Congressional line-up and winning the race for Governor.

It is indeed disheartening to see a public figure like Senator Ives, who has generally had the respect of many independents, make such an ill-considered argument as that Harriman has not experience sufficient to fit him for the Governorship.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 29 -- The influence of the new mass media was given by Rudolf Bing tonight as a reason for the fact that opera has not branched out in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The scientist who won a Nobel Prize for inventing the cyclotron patented this week a cathode tube that he predicts will mean cheaper color television.
A fashion show within the famous jewel and style display that is the opening night of the Metropolitan Opera will be staged for the first time this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet Wednesday at 10:30 A.M. to take up Israel's charges against Egypt's interference with ships using the Suez Canal en route to Israel.

Irving Enkells, real estate operator, has resold the apartment house property at 116 Remsen Street in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn to an investing client of Norman Elson, attorney. The parcel comprises a five-story remodeled apartment building on Remsen Street and a carriage house on Hunt's Lane containing a garage and apartments.

The Electric Auto-Lite Company, supplier of automotive equipment, suffered a sharp drop in sales, reducing net earnings in the nine months ended with Septmber to $120,796 from $8,242,756 earned in the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The United States Government is skeptical of Soviet talk about "peaceful coexistence" between East and West. The reasons for this, as explained by the Administration's principal diplomatic architect, Secretary Dulles, are both idealistic and pragmatic.
Cocoa futures rose the cent-a-pound limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange for the third time this week.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Australia called today for the admission of Laos and Cambodia to the United Nations. Such a step would be a "logical" development arising directly from agreements reached at the Geneva conference last summer, Sir Percy Spender, the Australian delegate, said.

HAVANA, Oct. 29 -- The Cuban Government showed increased concern today as further bombings were reported and evidence was obtained that at least one experienced revolutionary leader had arrived in the island to head a subversive movement.

Vince Martinez, the sharp-punching welterweight from Paterson who is fighting his way to a championship bout, stopped Carmine Fiore of Brooklyn in the seventh round of their scheduled ten-round contest in Madison Square Garden last night.

PARIS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The French Academy of Medicine has formally authorized the sterilization of women who, because of bad health, might lose their lives if they became pregnant. The move is expected to raise a medical storm in largely Roman Catholic France.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Leaders of the British dock strike decided tonight to recommend a resumption of work on Monday, Mass-meetings of 44,000 strikers at the eight ports concerned will consider this advice tomorrow.

The National Jewish Welfare Board said yesterday that it would need substantially larger sums for increasing religious, morale and welfare services of Jews in the armed forces. The board is the Government-accredited agency serving these needs.

A youthful war veteran and a former Special Sessions Court Justice are the opponents for the House seat being vacated by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. The Congressional District involved is the Twentieth, a traditionally Democratic one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Details of an $8,500,000 Federal-aid program designed to prevent surface water from flooding Pennsylvania's anthracite mines were announced here today by Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, and Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Elwood Swisher, president of the United Gas, Coke and Chemical Workers Union, C.I.O., withdrew tonight authorization for production workers to strike at two key atomic plants until "I am convinced that efforts now being put forth have failed."
The flowers that riot through seventeenth century Dutch paintings have come to life in the exhibit of "Dutch Painting: The Golden Age," which opens today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 29 -Prime Minister Mohammed Ali suggested today a grave question of legality was involved in Governor General Ghulam Mohammed's decision to suspend representative government in Pakistan.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 29 -About 4,500 enthusiastic greeters -- a fair-sized crowd for Louisville -- traveled four miles to Standiford Airport today to hear President Eisenhower's eighteen-minute political address.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- With the deaths of four more firemen, the toll of the chemical explosion at the Charles W. Berg laboratories here rose to nine today.
The battle for control of the Follansbee Steel Corporation continued yesterday with new moves by opposing sides.

"American Heroes: Myth and Reality," by Marshall Fishwick, is planned for publication by Public Affairs Press the end of next month. The author, Professor of American Studies at Washington and Lee University, discusses such figures as George Washington, Robert E. Lee, John Smith, Daniel Boone and Henry Ford, analyzing the "heroic process" and the "idolatrous hero-makers."

TEHERAN, Iran., Oct. 29 -United States planes from Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Syria joined today in vast air and ground search for Prince Ali Riza, heir, presumptive to the Iranian throne, who has been missing in a light plane since 5 P.M. Wednesday.
The city started legal action yesterday to challenge the order issued in August by the Public Service Commission granting a 20 per cent fare increase on the Long Island Rail Road.

These are busy days for all of us. I certainly found them to be very busy ones for me, but I decided to make this trip today in order to urge upon all of us, all Americans everywhere, the importance of voting.

The two Soviet representatives to Columbia University's Bicentennial celebration, Prof. Andrei L. Kursanov and Prof. Boris A. Rybakov, arrived by air yesterday. They expressed the hope that "many American scholars will be able to attend the bicentennial of Moscow University" scheduled next year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Clyde L. Powell, former Assistant Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, was sentenced today to serve one year in jail for contempt of court. Although taken in custody immediately, Powell's stay in jail was brief.

A Cuban anthropologist turned the spotlight yesterday on the uncertainties of academic freedom in the United States. He declared that the rest of the Americas had to know the situation and the trend in this country if they were to be in a position to protect their own intellectual liberties.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 29 -Despite apathy among rank-and-file Republicans, Atlantic County is expected by impartial observers to produce next Tuesday a plurality of at least 12,000 for Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for Senator.
OTTAWA, Oct. 29 (Canadian Press) -- United States investors have been buying up Canadian stocks at a near-record pace.

The Board of Health adopted yesterday a regulation requiring a warning label on paint containing more than 1 per cent of lead. The purpose is to reduce the danger of lead poisoning among small children who might nibble at a painted surface.

The joint statement made by President Eisenhower and Chancellor Adenauer following their White House conference welcomes the Paris accords, including the special French-German agreements, as a new basis for a strong and united European community that will reinforce the defenses of the free world.
Two of Averell Harriman's key campaign assistants made separate defenses yesterday of his eligibility to serve as Governor if he is elected next Tuesday.
The 18-year-old American Labor party will be fighting for its legal life in Tuesday's election.
Ranked first in the country until beaten by Purdue's passes, Notre Dame today will make the first of two appearances in this section against one of the top football teams of the East.

After more than 100 men and women had tried to claim Rex, the subway dog, and had failed to rouse his interest, a small brown-haired young woman walked into a shelter of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals yesterday and sent him into an ecstatic wriggle.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has subpoenaed the records of the International Boxing Guild, an organization composed of managers of most of the major fighters in the country. A spokesman for the prosecutor refused to comment on the move, but it was learned that Mr. Hogan was interested in determining the truth of reports that a "boycott" existed against managers who were not members of the guild.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -President Eisenhower returned tonight from a 1,400-mile, one-day get-out-the-vote trip, exhilarated and confident that if "they only come out to vote, there is no question of the outcome."

The National Broadcasting Company has given the Republican party a half-hour of television and radio time tonight, presumably in answer to a demand by Leonard H. Hall, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

Bond issues running to $1,000,000,000 are likely to be floated over the next several years to finance needed highway construction in Michigan, according to an estimate given here yesterday by John H. Nunneley, Detroit bonding attorney.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Racing's history books tell of the days when purses, filled with coin of the realm, were hung at the finish line. The grabbing of same was done by the jockey who got there first.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Employes in twenty-six states are entitled by law to take time off to vote, and sixteen of the states have statutory provisions on paying workers for time they spend voting.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Gordon R. Clapp accused the Administration today of "calling in for counsel the worst enemies of the Tennessee Valley Authority to plan the future of T.V.A."

The four-story dwelling with garden and roof terrace at 236 East Forty-ninth Street, in the Turtle Bay section, has been sold by Kenneth Ives Co. to Arthur Stelzer through the office of Mable Detmold.
A choir festival was presented at Carnegie Hall last evening under the direction of Frieda Louise Andrews. The event was sponsored by The New York Age Defender, a Negro newspaper.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 29 -President Carlos Castillo Armas asked the constituent Assembly today to outlaw the Communist party in the new Guatemalan Constitution.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Soybeans again forged upward today and undoubtedly contributed to a more confident buying tone in the grain futures.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company announced today it was to receive more than $600,000,000 from the seven other oil companies in the consortium that will exploit Iran's oil wealth.

Swelled by the retirement of several large issues of public utility and foreign bonds, the total of bonds redeemed in October before maturity rose to $183,220,000 from $118,787,000 in the preceding month and $13,506,000 in October, 1953.

MONROE, La., Oct. 29 (UP) -- A 10-year-old fatherless boy who defended his mongrel dog against school officials with a shotgun tonight was ordered released from the State Reformatory and promised a private school and college educalion. His dog, Tipple, will go off to school with him.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- In the last five years life expectancy in India has been raised from an average of 27 years to 32.

After a rather shaky start, the Albeneri Trio, which celebrated its tenth anniversary season with a concert last night in Town Hall, settled down to its usual dependable music-making. The long program had one novelty in the form of Walter Piston's E minor Trio, a work that does not often grace the platforms today.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Progress toward European unity in the last seven weeks enables the West to take "dramatic steps" toward negotiation with the East and a relaxation of tension, Sir Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, declared tonight.
It seems incredible that news can continue to develop in respect to turkey, a native American bird that has been around in one form or another for a long time.

HONG KONG, Oct. 29 -- Two Australian women arrived here yesterday from a month's tour of Communist China and reported they had seen "fleets of recent model American cars" in every city they had visited.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Sumner H. Slichter, Lamont Professor of Economics at Harvard University, called today for, wage increases and other steps to insure recovery in 1955 from the business recession.

Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education, warned last night that, while educational television could be an invaluable aid to teaching, its future depended upon the quality of the teacher.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Sir Winston Churchill passed another milestone today when he completed thirty consecutive years as a member of the House of Commons.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 -- The Sheppard murder trial was suddenly recessed here today and the whole case thrown into confusion by the revelation that a juror may have been convicted of a sex offense eleven years ago.

The acquisition or impending publication of historical papers is always an occasion; and when two such nuggets as the papers of Gouverneur Morris and the Adams family are revealed almost simultaneously, historians and the general public, too, have cause for elation and anxious anticipation. Prof. Richard B. Morris, who is studying Columbia's recent acquisition of his namesake's documents, appraises them as "one of the most important disclosures of the last twenty-five years."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Daniel F. Malan, Prime Minister of South Africa, virtually went into retirement today, leaving management of the Union's affairs to Finance Minister Nicolaas C. Havenga, his probable successor.

MIAMI, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Miami's mighty running machine hit a new peak of offensive power tonight as the Hurricanes stampeded to a 75-7 victory over Fordham. It was the biggest score ever run up by a Miami eleven.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle said today that a poll of seventeen newspaper editors in New York State showed most of them think Senator Irving M. Ives will defeat Averell Harriman in a "close race" for the Governorship.
The Briggs Manufacturing Company will pay $32.263 a share to redeem and cancel 79 per cent of the 1,947,469 shares of its outstanding common stock.
Averell Harriman told a Democratic audience in Brooklyn last night that the New York City Transit Authority was a failure. Instead of improving service it was curtailing it, he said.
SAN MATEO, Calif., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, visibly angry, tonight held his audience overtime to deliver a tongue lashing to an unidentified heckler.
MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- Soviet propaganda made still another bid today for East-West negotiations on European security before the arming of Western Germany.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- A dispute involving the work status of one foreman today halted all dry cargo handling operations in the port of Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices dropped about 1.6 per dent between mid-September and mid-October.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, proposed today a four-point program based on the strength and unity of the free world and a nonaggression pact with the Soviet bloc.
WHAT with the number of small exhibitions now on view south of Fourteenth Street, it is evident that there's life in Greenwich Village yet.

The American Jewish Literary Foundation will hold a dinner tomorrow night in the Sheraton Astor Hotel in honor of Dr. Leo M. Davidoff, neurosurgeon and medical educator, and Isidore Lipschutz, industrialist and philanthropist.
A $50,000,000 suit was filed yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, by a stockholders' group against officers and directors of the Long Island Lighting Company.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Mexican Army team continued its domination of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight but Spain captured the biggest prize of all, the three-day international low-score competition.

In a recent letter to The Times Richard B. Sichel urges that Anthony Akers, the Democratic and Liberal candidate -- Americans for Democratic Action and the C.I.O. are, it is said, also supporting him -- be sent to Congress in place of Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., the Republican candidate.

FOR those who can take the wind and weather, there is still an opportunity to get in some bluefishing before these fish take their delayed departure. Reports on The Race and Plum Gut indicate that the big choppers are still present.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 29 -- The South Korean national police began tonight a round-up of black market money dealers here. The drive followed payments during the day to Korean employes of the United Nations Command of some wages in United States currency.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Education for women in the future presents special problems, Dean Helen G. Canoyer of the New York State College of Home Economics declared here today. Addressing the second Home Economics Alumnae Institute, she said:

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The French Cabinet approved today measures to hasten solution of the housing shortage. Premier Pierre Mendes-France has termed this one of the nation's primary economic and social problems.
BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- The first link in Boston's multimillion dollar central aerial highway was dedicated today with political overtones.
Queens have as much trouble as other women finding Christmas gifts for men, Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain revealed yesterday during a shopping tour of three Manhattan stores.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Faris el-Khouri, 86-year-old independent and Syrian delegate to the United Nations, emerged tonight as the Premier of a new coalition Cabinet.

Employes of The New York Times who belong to the Newspaper Guild of New York, C.I.O., have empowered their unit and local officers to call a strike against The Times in the event present negotiations fail.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. alleged in your letters column that I have misled the people about his voting record in Congress. His indignation would sound more genuine if he had accepted my challenge to debate this issue on TV at no cost to him.
FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., Oct. 29 -- A New York City policeman was charged with burglary today after he was seized crawling out of a window at the Midway Inn here.

Above all else, the blind person needs a sense of "belonging," Dr. Joseph Gerber, medical director, Office of Vocational Rehabilitation of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, said here yesterday.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Clifford P. Case sought today to reconcile supporters of former Senator Robert A. Taft who have been critical of Mr. Case's candidacy for the United States Senate.

An issue of $46,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance construction of the Greater New Orleans Expressway bridging Lake Pontchartrain will be put for sale on Dec. 8, according to announcement yesterday by the Louisiana parishes of Jefferson and St. Tammany, sponsors of the project.
Stocks fell yesterday to the lowest levels since Sept. 21, ending a week in which there were losses on four out of five days. The week's drop in The New York Times combined average was 4.26 points.
New financing in October declined from the month before but was sharply above that of a year ago.
BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Gene Conley, the 6-foot, 8-inch Milwaukee Braves' pitcher, today quit the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association to concentrate on his baseball career.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -The Office of Defense Mobilization today authorized the diversion of another 25,000 tons of refined copper from the defense stockpile for use by industrial consumers.

Sixteen charitable organizations were named among the beneficiaries in the will of Mrs. Helen R. Goodman, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mrs. Goodman died last Saturday. She had lived at the Croyden Hotel, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 29 -- Bolivia and Brazil signed an exchange agreement here today under which this country will receive petroleum products. This is one of a series of current developments indicating strong efforts to bolster ties between the two countries.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- The question of a treaty with Communist China is likely to be the most important issue in the general election that is expected to follow Premier Shigeru Yoshida's return from abroad.

Senator Irving M. Ives defended last night the Republican attack on Averell Harriman's business activities. Mr. Ives asserted that he had "never indulged in smear tactics." The Republican candidate also outlined, in a fifteen-minute television appearance, a program he would follow as Governor. This included a proposal to reduce the personal income tax for all persons who earn less than $100 a week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Several batteries of the Honest John rocket, a faster-than-sound weapon that can carry an atomic warhead, will be sent to Europe to help equip defenders against any Soviet aggression.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, President of Harvard University, told the Executives' Club today that attention being given to communism in higher educational institutions "is all out of proportion to the facts in the case."

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 29--Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, accused Republican office seekers tonight of wearing "Halloween masks" in an effort to persuade voters that the Republican party represented labor.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 -- An enthusiastic crowd of about 1,500 to 2,500 persons braved cold, threatening weather this morning to greet President Eisenhower at Hopkins Airport here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Reports that the Federal Communications Commission soon will take up the issue of box-office-in-the-home television have stirred theatre operators throughout the country.
Twenty-two Polish seamen who left families, friends and home for freedom arrived here yesterday from Formosa.
ROME, Oct. 29 -- The Italian Government became today the first of the European signatories of the Paris agreements for a Western European Union to present a bill to Parliament for their ratification.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were slightly easier yesterday, declining 2 to 13 points.
SAIGON, Oct. 29 -- The evacuation of one of the largest pockets of Vietminh troops in southern Vietnam to the north is scheduled to be completed tomorrow.

A single sealed bid was deposited yesterday in a steel box at the Transit Authority Building, 370 Jay Street, Brooklyn, offering to furnish and install the Times Square-Grand Central shuttle passenger conveyor system for $3,881,000.

The autumn gardener is a thrifty man. His chores are tidy and conservative. There are leaves to rake and heap in rustling mountains; tools to oil and sharpen; hose to wind and store away; tender plants to bring indoors against the frost.

Kermit Bloomgarden confirmed yesterday the postponement until next season of "The Lark," which will star Julie Harris as Joan of Arc. The attraction originally was to have made its Broadway debut in February. The production was deferred for "personal reasons," the producer explained, at the request of Miss Harris, who is now completing a film version of "I Am a Camera" in London.

The second in this season's series of "Five Enchanted .{usi' ( '! cal Evemn;s will be tile opening performance of the Ballets Espagnols tomorrow evening at the,Mark Hellinger Theatre. The Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund will be aided from the proceeds.

News from Cuba in recent days shows that tension is mounting as election time approaches. On Monday Cubans will vote for President, Vice President and many Senators, Representatives and municipal officers.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 27 -The Philippines, although it has not recognized Vietnam, is having an increasingly important influence on the affairs in this faltering, politically divided state.

Boys High's football team, the only eleven with an unblemished record, will play host to Brooklyn Tech, and New Dorp, bidding for an undefeated season, will meet Midwood at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, in the top games today on the Public Schools Athletic League schedule.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Pre-election reports of campaign expenditures indicate that the Republican State Committee is spending slightly more than the Democratic group.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 635 pints of blood on Thursday. Included were 120 at the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, 35 Nassau Street, making a two-day collection total of 267, and 124 at the Johns-Manville Corporation, 22 East Fortieth Street.

PLANTER mixes have had an amazingly rapid rise to fame -- just five years ago they were completely unknown. A planter mix, by definition, is a growing medium formulated especially for the culture of indoor plants.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 30 -- An appeal to the public to assist the police in searching for George Murch, 28-year-old carpenter who disappeared from his home at Goshen, N.Y., on Oct. 1, has been made by his mother, Mrs. Ralph Murch of 3 High Street here.

ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Andy Crevolin's suspension of three months ended today as the owner of Determine, Kentucky Derby winner, unlocked his stable for the fall meeting at Golden Gate Fields.
DECATUR, Ind., Oct. 30 -- Wilbur Shaw, president of the Indianapolis motor speedway and three-time winner of the 500-mile race, was killed with two companions in a plane crash near here late today.

WHEN Noel Coward's "Quadrille" opens on Broadway Wednesday, a couple of internationalists will be coming home after an absence of upward five years. They are, of course, Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne and "coming home" may be just an insular viewpoint from New York.

COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Oct. 30 -- Ursinus College's football team scored a 34-7 triumph over Wagner on Patterson Field today. Ken Walker, Ursinus captain, and Bob Famous, a freshman, starred for the winner.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- The voters will decide Tuesday whether they want the state to borrow $550,000,000 and use it for housing and slum clearance and for construction and rehabilitation of the state's mental hospitals.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Britain's striking dock workers voted today by overwhelming majorities to return to work Monday at all eight ports.

AN exhibition not to be missed by those who respond to art's most courtly manners is that of seventeenth and eighteenth century French and Italian drawings at Knoedler's. They are temporarily on loan from the cabinet of drawings in the Museum of Besancon in France and reflect faithfully the taste of the old-fashioned collector of the pro-French Revolutionary era.

RICHARD RODGERS will conduct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra a week from next Saturday night in a program of his own music. He will be accomplishing two things at once: gratifying himself and helping the orchestra.

Ireland's championship hurling and Gaelic football teams will display their talents today at the Polo Grounds in a doubleheader against representatives of the Gaelic Athletic Association of New York. Pre-game ceremonies will begin at 1:15 P.M., with the hurling contest to start at 2 P.M.

Twenty-two young women will make their debuts at the annual Yuletide Ball on Dec. 23 in the ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. The event will be a benefit for the Brooklyn Kindergarten Society.

IN the golden depths of the autumn a theatre shortage generally threatens Broadway with a happy crisis. When the new season is getting under way, usually there are not enough theatres available to house all the productions that want to come to town at the same time.

Problems and aspirations of the American maritime industry will be centered in Miami Dec. 5 to 10 when the American Merchant Marine Conference will meet in conjunction with the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 30 -- Gen. Charles L. Bolte, Assistant Chief of Staff of the United States Army, said here today he was deeply impressed with the smartness and efficiency of the Brazilian troops he inspected during his short visit.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 30 (UP) -- A sophomore, Frank Tamburello, replacing Charlie Boxold, ailing quarterback, directed Maryland on three touchdown drives, scoring twice himself, as Maryland routed the South Carolina Gamecocks, 20 -- 0, before 24,000 fans.

Cornell, its regulars benched throughout the second half, easily defeated Columbia, 26 -- 0, at Baker Field yesterday. Billy De Graaf, a slick ball-handler, fired three touchdown passes for the Ithacans as the Lions were blanked for the first time in sixteen games.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Texas came from behind with two touchdowns in the last half today to tie Southern Methodist, 13 to 13, before 52,000 fans.
PEORIA, Oct. 30 -- Mrs. Lucy Saye was still flustered many hours after receiving President Eisenhower's telephone call.

THE Leipzig Industrial Fair has become just about the only chance a Westerner has to visit what formerly was called the Soviet Zone of Germany and now officially is named the German Democratic Republic. The fair, though, makes Leipzig an interesting place musically at this time, for nothing is spared to make these two weeks as gala as possible for the thousands of visitors.
Electronic computers, widely used by the Government and increasingly popular with business, again will be called upon this year to forecast election results.

BONN, Oct. 30 -- A genuine effort is being made by the West German Federal Government to focus the public's attention on the historical necessity of putting an end to Franco-German rivalry and to create a relationship based on intimate political, economic, and cultural cooperation.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines returned to the capital this morning after a two-day tour of the important agricultural and oil-producing state of Tamaulipas, where there have been recent labor disturbances and grumbling over economic dislocations.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Quarterback Don King' celebrated his twenty-first birthday today by throwing a winning touchdown pass and halfback Ken Moore put icing on his cake by streaking 78 yards to a score on a punt return as Clemson edged Wake Forest, 32 to 20.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Duc de Fer, E.S. Brumfield's highly regarded 3-year-old, scored his eighth victory in eighteen starts this year by winning the $15,000-added Laurel Sprint Handicap today over a muddy strip.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 30 -Ohio political leaders and observers were inclining today to the opinion that the Democrats on Tuesday would win the Senate seat held for fourteen years by the late Robert A. Taft.

NOVELS of Negro life, like the proletarian novels of the Thirties, have come to embody several sets of easily recognizable stereotypes, ranging from the blind rebels of Richard Wright to the submerged heroes of Ralph Ellison.

The Department of Commerce and the Small Business Administration have jointly issued a paper-bound book which is entitled "Chemical Products and Processes." It contains 1,350 abstracts or brief descriptions of Government-owned inventions in the chemical field.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Spencer S. Overton, 56-year-old Baltimore building contractor, today won the third annual north and south invitation senior golf tournament by defeating John W. Roberts of Columbus, Ohio, 2 and 1.
BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 30 -- Undefeated Oklahoma, frustrated by fumbles for three periods, struck for two touchdowns in the final quarter to beat Colorado, 13 -- 6, today.
The alternate-side parking rule will go into effect on Monday in 180 square blocks on the East Side with fifty-eight miles of curb space.

In Cecil Woodham Smith's retelling of the story of the Light Brigade -- "The Light Brigade Still Haunts History" (Oct. 17) -- she concludes: "It [the charge of the Light Brigade] is remembered for the courage and discipline of the men who rode to certain death in perfect order.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Oct. 25 -- Federal leaders of the Social Credit party, which is in power in the provincial governments of British Columbia and Alberta, have visited the West Coast to give fresh impetus to the party's "on to Ottawa" movement.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 30 -- Two arrow-straight passes by Corny Salvaterra in the final half punctured West Virginia's perfect season and bowl hopes today as a resurging Pittsburgh eleven scored a 13-10 upset at Mountaineer Field.

IN its readable two-column quarto pages this large volume presents a wealth of material from the long Post file -- short stories, articles, poetry, pictures and even advertising. It is excellent reading from the very beginning -- a rich treasury indeed.

"INTERWOVEN as is the love of liberty with every ligament of your hearts," said Washington in his farewell address to his countrymen, "no recommendation of mine is necessary to fortify or confirm the attachment."
GORGAS, Ala., Oct. 30 -- The latest test in the eight-year-old experiment to mine coal through a gasification process got under way here last week.

THIS time of year the railroads turn their attention and their schedules to long-distance travel by those heading for long winter months in remote southern regions. The big railroad push in the weeks ahead will be, as usual, to Florida.

ONE of the criticisms most frequently made against the schools today is that they fail to teach reading adequately. But a test given recently by the Metropolitan School Study Council, a research affiliate of Columbia University's Teachers College, has revealed that the youngsters read as well as -- and in some cases better than -- their elders, who in this instance happened to be members of local Boards of Education.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Employment, payrolls and man-hours in Pennsylvania manufacturing industries turned upward in September for the first time since the decline started over a year ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 30 -- Northwestern's pass defense, steel-like for three quarters, suddenly collapsed in the fourth period today as Dave Leggett threw a 24-yard touchdown aerial to Bob Watkins to give No. 1-ranked Ohio State a 14-7 triumph.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va. -- It was twenty years ago this month, in October, 1934, that President Franklin D. Roosevelt came to Williamsburg to open formally the reconstructed Duke of Gloucester Street.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Defeated in prolonged litigation, this city of 75,000 is about to lose the automobile parking area in use for fifty years at the downtown railroad station.

Queen Mother Elizabeth solved a surprise curtsy from a uniformed elevator operator who took her up to see the offices of the British United Nations delegation yesterday, in the newly constructed, aluminum - faced building at 99 Park Avenue.

One hot campaign issue likely to grow even hotter after the election is the Dixon-Yates contract. Under this contract, the Atomic Energy Commission would authorize the Dixon-Yates utilities companies to construct a $107,000,000 steam plant at West Memphis, Ark., to feed 600,000 kilowatts of energy into the Tennessee Valley Authority power system.
BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 30 -Democratic party leaders are hopeful of capturing one national House seat in New Hampshire and two in Massachusetts in Tuesday's elections.

Anxious to do their share to help finance the new nine-story building at St. Luke's Hospital, the nursing students, nursing staff and nursing school alumnae of the hospital have arranged for a theatre benefit on the evening of Feb. 10.
