CHORE FOR THE WEEK: It is not too late to plant spring-flowering bulbs. All of them will bloom next year, although crocus, some daffodils and other early-flowering kinds will open a little later than normally. November is the best month for planting tulips. Summer-flowering lilies are set out, too.

The New York Football Giants will have the first real test of their mettle today when they face the Cleveland Browns at Cleveland. The game may be viewed locally on Channel 5. The kickoff time is 2:05 P.M.M

Cooper Union in New York City is emphasizing the humanities in its courses in order to give students a broader understanding of cultural traditions and cultural values. The school has introduced a required course in "Studies in Cultural Values," which combines a group of liberal arts subjects into a single course.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Princeton and Colgate played to a 6-6 tie before 23,000 in Palmer Stadium today. The Red Raiders came here unbeaten, but once tied (a 13-13 draw with Yale) and many felt they could beat the Tiger. But Charley Caldwell's Old Nassau squad, though cut by injuries to three of its regular backfield, put on a surprising show of strength.

THE man of letters has in our time a small but critical service to render to man; a service that will be in the future more effective than it is now, when the cult of the literary man shall have ceased to be an idolatry.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- Recognizing that most of its tourists from the United States arrive and depart by air, Haiti has devoted considerable attention to the air terminal of this city and the one at Cap Haitien on the north shore of the island.

The snows have begun to fall on the Western mountains, but the people are worried only that there may not be enough snow, not that there will be too much. They want more snow, much more. For snow is water, and water is their land's life blood. States and regions fight for water.

About 45,115,000 citizens are expected to vote in Tuesday's general election, according to the latest estimates of party and election officials. These will have the task of picking Governors in thirty-four states, choosing thirty-seven United States Senators and 432 members of the House of Representatives.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Oct. 30 -- Mariners on the West Coast are awaiting the contents of a report made by engineers recently on the possibilities of removing Ripple Rock, a serious navigation menace 125 mile north of here.

Members of the Woman's Association of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church will hold their third annual festival for the benefit of the organization's philanthropies on Nov. 18 and 19 in the Church House at 7 West Fifty-fifth Street.

STE. AGATHE, Que. -- This one-time "quaint French provincial" village, the first community in the Laurentian Mountains to be developed, beginning about forty years ago, into a summer home and winter sports center, is today as cosmopolitan as New Mexico's Taos or Idaho's Sun Valley.

There has been much concern of late regarding the expected critical shortage in qualified teaching personnel in colleges, as enrollments begin to rise during the forthcoming years. Efforts to anticipate and alleviate this shortage (such as the Woodrow Wilson Fellowship Program, the Ford Foundation funds) by encouraging qualified students to continue their studies with the goal of entering college teaching as a career, have recently been instituted.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Oct. 30 (UP) -- A Federal judge today dissolved a Taft-Hartley injunction binding 4,500 atomic production workers not to strike, but a union spokesman said no early walkout was planned.

IT isn't necessary to look at the same old philodendron with heart-shaped leaves and trailing stems in the same place year after year. It is possible to have varied and interesting house plants in almost any location.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- However much President Eisenhower may insist that his own prestige is not at stake in next week's election, as he did at his press conference on Wednesday, the simple fact is that both his prestige generally and his leadership of the Republican party are quite heavily involved.

ACCORDING to tabulations of the American Automobile Association, a new record in winter vacation travel is indicated by the number of motorists who already have taken off for Southern resorts and by the thousands of requests for highway information on routes leading into cold-weather sports areas.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Eisenhower announced today the shipment of $8,585,000 worth of surplus food and grain for the relief of victims of last summer's flood in Europe.

IT used to be said that "you don't direct a Charles Laughton picture; you just turn the cameras on and let 'em rip." The worm -- if that isn't an offense -- has not turned much. Charles Laughton -- behind the cameras for the first time as director of Paul Gregory's initial production, "The Night of the Hunter" -- seems to have justified a reputation for individuality.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Eisenhower set a political precedent here today by using the White House telephone to ask ten stanch Republicans to get out and vote next Tuesday. He asked each of the ten to do the same for ten others, and so on.

BACK in the Dark Ages of professional football a quarter of a century ago, Bill Owen, Steve's lil' brother, was a tackle for the Giants while Ken Strong was a wondrous triple-threat halfback for all-but-forgotten Stapleton. It was fourth down and Strong moved into punt position. The ball snapped back from center, straight and true.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Tobin Rote tossed three touchdown passes to Max McGee and the Green Bay Packers took advantage of two intercepted passes, a fumble and a fourth-down Philadelphia gamble to upset the Eagles, 37 -- 14, tonight in a National Football League game before 25,378 fans at Connie Mack Stadium.
An exhibition of 150 paintings, prints and personal possessions of John James Audubon will open Thursday evening and run through Nov. 8 at the Kennedy Galleries, 785 Fifth Avenue.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Tony Saddler kicked the extra point that gave Muhlenberg a 14-13 football victory over Delaware today, ending a ten-game Delaware winning streak.
GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- For the first time in more than a quarter of a century Europe is having a steel boom not directly dependent on war, preparation for war, or rumors of war.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 -- The Democrats will make one of their most significant comeback bids in next Tuesday's voting in California.
The practice of "legal robbery," which was followed in the time of Noah, still exists in society and may be the cause of an atomic cataclysm, Rabbi Manuel Saltzman declared here yesterday.

It is somewhat puzzling that after the first unsuccessful attempt to detach the Saar permanently from Germany during the years following the First World War, the statesmen of the West should now hail a plan that not only seems to duplicate the first attempt but shows promise also of duplicating its failure.

With Italy and West Germany setting the pace, television in Europe has progressed in the last twelve months, according to Ernest A. Marx, director of the international division of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc. He has just returned from an extensive fact-finding survey of television in six European countries.
Bill Fleming's last-quarter touchdown and plunge for the extra point enabled Tilden High to tie Far Rockaway, 13 -- 13, yesterday on the Queens school's field.

CHRISTMAS used to come to the kitchen a month ahead when provident home cooks baked that festive tradition -- the fruit cake. "That was Christmas," says one New Yorker we know, affectionately recalling the preparations made years ago in his house.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Those who go to the polls next Tuesday are supposed to decide a contest for control of the machinery of Congress between the "Republicans" and the "Democrats," but actually their choice will be between two groups of political factions gathered for material reasons under two general party labels. The use of these labels, "Republican" and "Democrat," is essential to getting office, from that of President down to dog-catcher.
Averell Harriman charged the "Dewey machine" yesterday with a "sordid scheme" to avoid defeat.

The cruel practice of lopping off noses as punishment, first reported some five thousand years ago, still continues among Pakistani tribes, says Dr. Ralph Blocksma of Grand Rapids, Mich. He ought to know, because he practiced for five years at the United Christian Hospital in Lahore, Pakistan, where he repaired amputated noses.

WHILE most people go on cruises to relax and be lazy, some, who are collectors, take their hobbies along with them, and these have a special kind of fun that the others often envy. From our hopping about the Caribbean Isles on cruise ships and freighters we have observed many collectors at work and, in fact, their example has helped us to enjoy our trips.

BEFORE Tokyo was Tokyo (that is, "Eastern Capital") it was Yedo ("Estuary Gate"). The Japanese knew its people as the Yedokko -- the Yedo tribe -- and sobersided historians of the seventeenth century gave them an unenviable reputation.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Middlebury scored at least once in every period today to down Norwich, 38 -- 26, in the sixty-first meeting of the two state opponents. Middlebury and the University of Vermont now are tied for the state title with one victory each.
WHAT better ingredients for a mystery than a setting in New York a hundred years ago, a secret room and a somber man from India? And an idol, of course -- a little golden figure in a mosaic box.

May I express my very warm approval of William S. White's excellent article "The Eighth Lively Art -- Politics" (Oct. 3). The "untouchability" of politics has become an unfortunate American folkway, no little blame for which lies with the American newspapers.
The rapid growth of credit unions during recent years has made them "big business," requiring stricter regulation by the supervisory authorities, banking leaders believe.

ON the second Sunday of November, two years back, Norman Vincent Peale's "The Power of Positive Thinking" first appeared on this section's best-seller list. That was a month after its publication. For a time it hovered on the middle rungs, and then, with the spring, it shot to the top of the ladder in the "General" category.

I am an adolescent or, as described in Lester Rand's discussion of today's teen-age fads, speech, mannerisms and modes of dress -- "Kaleidoscope of Teen-Age Fad" (Oct. 17) -- I am one of those who are, "all in all, pseudo-sophisticate teetering on the edge of growing up.

Two seriously handicapped young persons won "Handicapped Oscars" last week for outstanding performances in a documentary moving picture titled "Three to Make Ready." It portrays the operation of a rehabilitation center for the crippled.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 30 -- In touching a match next Thursday to a canceled $1,000 bond, Town of Greenwich officials will mark the muncipality's "deliverance from debt" -- its final payment on its bonded indebtedness.

HOLLYWOOD. METRO has set about weaving, with an enthusiasm and purposefulness that must have stunned, as much as it flattered, studio sales representatives around the world, the story fabric of a musical that promises to be the most ambitious yet conceived by Hollywood minds.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Fullback Tom Tracy broke repeatedly through and around North Carolina's line today to lead Tennessee to a free-scoring 26-20 football victory.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Unbeaten Trinity College exploded for four touchdowns in the second period and three in the fourth to overwhelm Coast Guard Academy, 42 -- 6, on Trinity Field today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -The Republican national chairman, Leonard W. Hall, said today Democratic leaders "are frantic at the big swing toward the Republicans in the last ten days."
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- By the margin of a point after touchdown, Army defeated the University of Virginia, 21 -- 20, today in one of the season's most exciting football games.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Florida fumbled nine times today but one 'Gator bobble rolled into the Mississippi State end zone and a sophomore tackle, Buster Hill, pounced on the ball to give his butter-fingered teammates a 7-0 victory.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The United States today offered Guatemala $6,425,000 in economic and technical aid to keep communism from getting a new grip on the Central American republic.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 30 -- A large plurality for Senator Irving M. Ives over Averell Harriman, but smaller margins than usual for Republican candidates in several other contests are expected in Tuesday's election in Suffolk County.

In the opinion of one of the world's leading authorities on air transportation, the major domestic airlines of the United States have developed to the point where they can begin successful operations entirely free of Government subsidy.
PERTH, Australia, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Australia and America finished even at one match apiece in the first round of the International Lakes Cup Golf competition at Lake Karrinyup, near Perth, today.

JACK PAAR, the gentle humorist and confirmed worrier who stars in "The Morning Show" from 7 to 9 o'clock five days each week, has demanded that C.B.S.-TV put a new clause in his contract. He wants a new freedom -- the right to be let alone.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Shareholders of the Follansbee Steel Corporation met today to consider one of several proposals to buy the company but recessed to Monday without transacting any business.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 -- Soon after Election Day most of the 1955 model automobiles will be on display in dealers' showroom and the battle for automotive leadership -- and survival -- will be in full swing.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 30 -- Brown University score a 34-6 victory over Lehigh University today before 6,500 fans in Taylor Stadium. It was the first game between the rivals since 1949.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Rutgers ended its football victory famine today by surprising Temple, upset conqueror of Brown, 25 -- 0, with a makeshift backfield that ran like a pack of wild horses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- There are some consolations about the election: it will be over Tuesday; and it will settle, not the fate of the Republic, as the candidates say, but merely the fate of a few remarkably undistinguished and easily expendable politicians.

NEWARK, Oct. 30 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for Senator from New Jersey, said today the election of a Democratic majority to Congress would place control of twenty-three out of thirty-four committees in the hands of Southern Democrats.

ANYONE who has played bridge against opponents whose skill varies widely -- palookas at the bottom, experts at the top -- has probably observed that he plays well against the palookas and badly against the experts.

A LONG-TIME resident of New Mexico, Lucille Mulcahy has written an appealing story of a Spanish-American family, focused on 15-year-old Pita's growing-up. On the very day that her first invitation to a ball arrives, a family crisis blows her hopes sky-high.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Primo Villanueva led the powerful U.C.L.A. Bruins to their seventh straight triumph today as he scored two touchdowns and passed for a third in a 27-6 victory over California.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 30 -Nassau County's 512,122 prospective voters, potentially one of the state's most decisive election forces, are faced with the task of weighing bitterly exchanged Republican and Democratic campaign charges and warnings of political corruption.

SAVANNAH, Ga. -- Motorists following the Atlantic shore down through Georgia to Florida this winter will find a number of changes along the route of U.S. 17, the Coastal Highway. Principal among these is the new $14,600,000 Eugene Talmadge Memorial Bridge across the Savannah River here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 30 -- An influential Rio de Janeiro newspaper charged today that the United States had made next month's inter-American economic conference here a futile gesture.

OCTOBER witnessed continuing recovery in business activity, without spectacular gains. If business follows the pattern etched on production charts in the last seventeen years, activity in November will show some improvement over that in October, elections notwithstanding.

Visits of members of the British royal family are infrequent, but of the making of books on British-American relations there is no end. The presence here of Queen Mother Elizabeth happens to coincide with the publication of "The Coming of the Revolution," by Prof. Lawrence Henry Gipson in Harper's New American Nation Series -- a subject of inexhaustible interest to Americans but something of a bore to the British.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Organized labor's political lieutenants have not been so confident in ten years.
OLATHE, Kan., Oct. 30 (AP) -- An Air Force jet reconnaissance plane crashed in a flaming power dive about eight miles southwest of here last night, killing three of the four crewman.
New Yorkers will elect four judges of the Court of Appeals on Tuesday, with three of the seats certain to go to present members of the state's highest tribunal who have multi-party nominations.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Every tourist coming to Florida's west coast this season will soon become aware of the new bridge across lower Tampa Bay from St. Petersburg to Palmetto and Bradenton, officially known as the Sunshine Skyway, built at a cost of $22,500,000, and fifteen miles long.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 30 -- With a sardonic tongue in his cheek Vice President Richard M. Nixon offered to help Adlai E. Stevenson's nation-wide telecast from New York tonight by giving him six national issues to discuss publicly.
CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Collecting cash at the rate of more than $1,400 a second, Mrs. Russell A. Firestone's Summer Tan, the 11-to-5 favorite, won the $269,965 Garden State
EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 30 -- Grover S. Slayter got "quite a surprise" at 9:02 this morning when President Eisenhower called.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The United States, represented by the sharpshooting Peoria Caterpillars, produced a high scoring and tight defensive display today to defeat Canada, 84-50, in the world basketball tournament.

THE career of John P. Marquand actually stretches over thirty-three years, for a story of his appeared in The Saturday Evening Post in 1921, and it is divided into two almost exactly equal parts by the publication of "The Late George Apley" in 1937.

BERLIN, Oct. 39 -- The news agency Deutsche Presse Agentur reported today that the Allied Security Board had granted permission to rebuild the biggest shipbuilding yards in Germany -- those of Blohm Voss in Hamburg.

Applications for 1955 golf permits will be available, beginning tomorrow, at the borough offices of the Parks Department. The permit, costing $15, will be valid Jan. 1 and may be used at any Parks Department course open for play.

FROM the passenger's point of view choosing from the great variety of winter cruises available is a simple and speedy matter. In many cases it involves little more than a telephone call to a travel agent.

THE appearance of Ellen Glasgow's autobiography nine years after her death in 1945 is a literary event of signal importance. For from the mid-Twenties to the end of her days Miss Glasgow enjoyed the distinction of being -- along with Edith Wharton and Willa Cather -- one of America's three foremost women novelists of her time.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 -- The City of (soot-bedraggled) Angels unlimbered a new weapon against its periodic choking smogs this week: a political whirlwind.
United Neighborhood Houses of New York, Inc., a coordinating agency for fifty settlement houses and neighborhood centers, will benefit from a theatre party on Thursday night.

Two hundred years ago today King George II gave the royal assent to a charter establishing a tiny college on a tract of land extending from Barclay Street to Murray Street and from what is now Church Street to the North River. There were ten trustees, eight students and a president.
The stock market trend was down last week, The New York Times index of fifty representative issues falling 4.26 points to 227.69.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The White House said today President Eisenhower would greet personally a score or more "typical applicants" for naturalization here Nov. 9 to dramatize mass citizenship ceremonies throughout the nation two days later.
FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Land's Corner and Bab's Whey gained more than ordinary distinctions in winning jumping races at the Essex Fox Hounds Hunt meeting over a color-splashed countryside today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct 30 -- In a breath-taking finish during which it lost the lead in the final quarter only to regain it with less than four minutes to play, Syracuse's eleven downed Holy Cross, 25 -- 20, before 20,000 at Archbold Stadium today.
ROME, Oct. 30 -- The Government has won the first round of its fight to obtain prompt ratification of the Paris agreements on the creation of a Western European union.

MEXICO CITY -- The sudden flood of American travelers to Mexico, probably a record during the past summer, pushed back the invisible curtains that kept most tourists on well-worn paths, and as a result several new areas will be looking for tourists this fall and winter.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 30 (UP) -- John (Pop) Ryan manager of Orlando Zulueta, Cuban lightweight, filed an official protest today against the unanimous decision awarded Dick Howard, Canadian champion, in a bout last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The United Mine Workers Journal today accused Secretary Mitchell of using "funny figures" to convince voters the unemployment situation was improving.

ALTHOUGH everyone likes to have flowers around the home, it is sometimes discouraging to find that they do not last very long. However this need not always be the case for there are a few tricks here and there that will greatly lengthen the life of cut flowers.

Joe Lapchick's New York Knickerbockers began their ninth professional campaign last night by halting the champion Minneapolis Lakers, 94 to 83, in a National Basketball Association clash at Madison Square Garden.

The National Horse Show will take over Madison Square Garden on Tuesday and hold it for an eight-day period of color and competition. All the afternoon sessions will begin at 2 o'clock and all the evening at 7:45. There will be at least some competition every morning, attended usually only by those with a direct interest.

HOUSTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Tricky Dicky Moegle scored three touchdowns and set up another to spark Rice Institute to a 34 to 13 victory over Vanderbilt University today in a home-coming game marred by fumbles and heavy penalties. A crowd of 28,000 saw the game.

The Fourteenth Street shopping district suffered a solar plexus blow when Ohrbach's moved uptown, but its scrappy merchants are fighting hard to make a comeback.

The Big Sisters, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the Thanksgiving show and the motion picture "White Christmas" on the afternoon and evening of Nov. 26 at Radio City Music Hall. LIKE her memorable and widely quoted collection of definitions, "A Hole Is to Dig," Ruth Krauss' new book draws its inspiration directly from children. OAXACA, Mexico -- Although countries like Greece and Egypt have long monopolized the spotlight on the ancient world, Americans on a Mexican holiday this season have the chance to visit pyramids, tombs and dead cities just as intriguing as those of the Mediterranean and Middle East countries.

Macomber (252 U.S. 189), decided in 1920 -- where the dividend is declared in common stock to holders of common and there is but one class of stock outstanding.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers, English League champions last season, went to the top of the first division today when they defeated Newcastle, 3 -- 2. The Wolves raced into a 2-0 lead in the first fifteen minutes.

SOME people are complaining that our seasons and our climate are changing so that without a calendar you cannot tell summer from autumn. We would file a similar complaint this fall morning, not against the seasons but against the calendar which seems to be moving faster now than it did, say, ten years ago.

MIAMI BEACH -- This is the time of year when hospitality is relatively inexpensive and moderation is the keynote of this year-round playground that is synonymous with luxury and fabulous prices.

Northwestern University has received a grant of $30,000 from the Carnegie Corporation to develop its general education program. The fund will support studies aimed at creating a purposeful four-year-program of general education for all under-graduates.

One of the most far-reaching retreats from Soviet economic policies ever decreed in a satellite nation has been ordered in Hungary, Budapest radio broadcasts reveal. The entire price, wage and production pattern of the Hungarian economy is to be drastically reorganized in an effort to speed up food and consumer goods production while cutting back heavy industrial output.

The Hudson Guild, one of New York's oldest Neighborhood Houses, will be the beneficiary of the Nov. 8 evening performance of "The Tender Trap," starring Robert Preston, Kim Hunter and Ronny Graham, at the Longacre Theatre.
SUMMIT HILL, Pa., Oct. 30 -- Seated in her home in this anthracite town of about 5,000 population, Mrs. Frances Tyahala, 22 years old, held a telephone conversation with President Eisenhower today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 30 -- The Corps of Engineers hopes to begin work early next year on plans for a huge power, navigational and flood control dam on the lower Cumberland River with a dual-purpose canal linking the Cumberland and Tennessee rivers.

About 5,000 American men, women and children in settlements in the desert, a third of the way around the world from home, sat down to a hearty American breakfast this morning. They had coffee, of course. There were fresh eggs with the ham, although there isn't a hen within hundreds of miles.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- The State Education Commissioner has ruled that the New York City Board of Education must pay back wages that include increases to an undetermined number of substitute teachers for either one or two summer vacations.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The chairman of the State Thruway Authority retorted tonight "absolutely false" to a Democratic report that the Thruway would be closed the day after election to complete construction.

FROM the early days of female higher education -- when it was considered more seemly for a lady to seek a Maid of Philosophy Degree than a Bachelor of Arts Degree and more seemly still to seek a bachelor and forget the degree -- to the present academic year when girls are dressed like kilted Scotsmen, college girls and their clothes have been a perennial source of puzzlement.

THE Fourth Symphony of Vaughan Williams, which is on the Philharmonic program today, in honor of the composer's presence here at Cornell as visiting professor, is a work of a special individuality. It stands outside of any of the other symphonies of this composer in its substance and manner.
A group of exiled Polish merchant marine officers now living in New York is trying to put the free Polish colors to sea once again.
SEATTLE, Oct. 30 -- The Seattle police were called at 7:30 tonight to investigate a reported attempt to poison Vice President Richard M. Nixon in his hotel here.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30 -- India has accepted the invitation of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to participate in further water talks with Pakistan.
BUFFALO, Oct. 30 -- Some relief for Buffalo's acute shortage of downtown parking facilities has been provided by an open, shell-type garage fitted with hydraulic hoists.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- From Jacksonville to the Keys, the east coast of Florida is one big beach playground, stretching for hundreds of miles and encompassing, in the winter, the cool briskness of non-swimming weather around Jacksonville and the sun-tanning warmth of small fishing and bathing towns in southern Florida.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Although official circles still have their sights raised, there is a general feeling in this little country that, with 100,000 visitors a year, Bermuda's tourist trade is about at its zenith under existing conditions.

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- It was just onto 300 years ago, in 1655, that the Spaniards finally capitulated to the English who had been harrying the Dons for some eighty years, and Jamaica became a British possession.
VANCOUVER, Wash., Oct. 30 -- A four-state public electric corporation, with the St. Lawrence Seaway as its model, has been proposed for the Columbia River region.
Election of Mrs. Alfred Winslow Jones and Mrs. Harry S. Jacobson to the board of directors of the Henry Street Settlement has been announced by Winslow Carlton, president of the settlement house.

In new and modern quarters next to the Museum of Modern Art the Whitney Museum opens a new chapter in its service to American art. Adjoining photographs show visitors on opening day in the main floor sculpture gallery and painting galleries on the second floor.
IN the frenetic field of video, where the stomach ulcer is regarded as a minor misfortune that often is symptomatic of genius, Steve Allen is a study in serenity.

Twenty-six times in this century the American people have gone to the polls to choose a new Congress. In most of that period the swing of the political pendulum was ponderous and wide. Three times (after 1910, 1918 and 1930) there were overturns in the House that proved to be harbingers of eras of national dominance by one party or the other.
CANTON, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Hobart College scored 14 points within five minutes late in the fourth period today to break a 6-6 tie and defeat St. Lawrence, 20 -- 6.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 30 -- Pittsburgh, often characterized as the "key city" in the campaign to rid the Ohio River of pollution, is to have a sewage disposal project to cost an estimated $87,000,000 to $100,000,000.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Big Bill Murakowski, who didn't start because of a leg injury, smashed through Illinois for two touchdowns today and Purdue kept its Big Ten championship hopes simmering with a 28-14 victory.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -Willie Mays will be one of the major tourist attractions of the Puerto Rico winter holiday season. Willie, known affectionately here as well as in New York as the "incomparable" for his center fielding for the Giants in the world series, has signed up to play for the Santurce team in Puerto Rico's five-team big league.

Roosevelt Jr., Democratic candidate for Attorney General, said yesterday Power Authority Chairman Robert Moses had not answered clearly questions on negotiations between the power authority and investment houses for a bond issue for the St. Lawrence and Niagara Rivers power projects.

New York State's Attorney General last week filed a complaint against the citizenry: Not only are they eager to be defrauded by dealers in phony stocks; they let pride keep them from filing complaints against the sharpers.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Fred A. Hartley, write-in candidate for Senator of the Republican groups opposing Clifford P. Case, predicted today that Mr. Case would run more than 100,000 votes behind the rest of the Republican Congressional candidates in the state.
While extra crews, celled to work at 3 A.M. yesterday, toiled in a chill rain to complete the job, formal ceremonies opened the extension of IND subway service to Coney Island.

DALLAS, Oct. 30 -- Department store sales in the Southwest improved in September and the first half of October, but sales for the first nine months trailed last-year figures by 3 per cent. September sales were 5 per cent above August and 1 per cent above September last year.

ATLANTA, Oct. 30 -- Retail trade again advanced briskly in the Southeast last week, with demands for apparel and a variety of Christmas goods pushing department store sales in most centers to peak levels for the year. Sales of new homes is continuing at high levels and this in turn is resulting in substantial demands for home furnishings and appliances.

EL PASO, Tex. -- It isn't necessary to go to Africa, or even the wilds of South America, for really rugged adventure. For the vacationist who is willing to sacrifice comfort for thrills and some of nature's fanciest handiwork, there are the Barrancas Del Urique (the canyons of the Urique River) in northern Mexico.

More than 1,400 hotel owners and operators, representing 6,000 major hostelries, throughout the country, will gather here on Thursday for the forty-third annual convention of the American Hotel Association. It is the first convention to be held by the group in New York since 1941 and will continue through Saturday.

Senator Irving M. Ives asserted last night that the "one overpowering issue" of the campaign for the Governorship was the choice between a Republican administration and one directed by Tammany Hall.

The big underwriting houses are breathing easier, now that the new issue of $130,000,000 of National City Bank stock has been marketed successfully. THE "office grapevine" -- that familiar American institution which peddles news and gossip wherever a working force totals more than one -- is being gravely studied these days. New management specialists, known as communications experts, are trying to find out why grapevines exist, how they function, and what, if anything, to do about them.

WRITTEN as the portrait of an age, "The Literary Situation," like Malcolm Cowley's "Exile's Return" of twenty years ago, has almost equal interest as a portrait of the author. PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The refusal of Robert Schuman, former Foreign Minister, to accept the Ambassadorship in Washington has postponed for a few days a reorganization of the French foreign service. The change has been in preparation for some time.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 30 -- Nebraska, looking eagerly to industry to balance its agricultural economy, has found a new battle cry in "decentralization."

IN our truly all-time favorite novel, Herman Melville tells how Captain Ahab orders the capture of a Right Whale in order to balance the Sperm Whale attached to the starboard side of the Pequod. A BY-PRODUCT of the fabulous energy of Theodore Roosevelt, this little book consists entirely of three letters. One was written to Secretary of State John Hay in August, 1903, giving a full account of a trip the President had made to the West the previous spring.

TONIGHT will see the opening of the Ballets Espagnols Teresa and Luisillo at the Mark Hellinger Theatre for a four-week season. The curtain tonight will be at 8, though on other evenings the hour will be 8:30.

NEWARK, Oct. 30 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, accused the Republican Administration today of having abandoned its 1952 pledges to the American people. WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Air Force tonight announced new aircraft orders totaling $135,000,000, almost all for light jet bombers believed to be the fastest of their class in the world.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Georgia Fullback Bobby Garrard intercepted Bart Starr's fourth quarter pass in the end zone to end the gravest threat of the game as Georgia and Alabama, two futile Titans of the Southeast, fought to a 0-to-0 tie before 30,000 fans.

THIS is a strange novel, perhaps because it is about strange people, in that they differ from the rest of us who call ourselves normal. And yet (as the reader will quickly learn from this sensitive and deeply perceptive story of the homosexual and his underworld) the "queer" make up a substantial segment of the population, a million males in England, at least two million in the United States.

THE two big group shows in which one can most quickly see "what gives" in American painting are, I think, the Whitney Annual and the Chicago Art Institute show. It is time that since these are both selected by the respective museum staffs, they represent personal taste.

Police Commissioner Francis W.H. Adams has ordered a survey to determine the educational background of each member of the police force.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Arkansas Razorbacks, brilliantly alert for every break and stubborn on the goal-line, defeated upset-minded Texas A. and M., 14 -- 7, tonight to remain one of the nation's football powers and the leader of the Southwest Conference.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The elaborate project signed here last Saturday to strengthen the Atlantic Community and its European defenses by bringing in West Germany is based upon the assumption that French and Germans can at last become allies with some confidence in each other.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Mexican Army team tonight closed out the Pennsylvania National Horse Show as it opened it -- with a blue ribbon and a record for the nine-year history of the competition.

DEL RIO, Tex., Oct. 30 -- The International Boundary and Water Commission has selected a site for the second of three international dams on the Rio Grande. Subject to the American and Mexican Governments, it will be built about fifteen miles upstream from here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- H. Struve Hensel, Assistant Defense Secretary, criticized today as "naive" suggestions made by some British officials that the free world should deal with Communist China.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Duke, three touchdowns behind and seemingly badly beaten as late as the third period, staged a whirlwind finish on Fullback Bryant Aldridge's plunges to down Georgia Tech, 21 to 20, today.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Virginia Tech marched 47 yards in the fourth period today for a matching touchdown and extra point to stay unbeaten but no longer untied in a 7-to-7 draw with William and Mary.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Boston University, tumbled from the ranks of undefeated football teams a week ago, bounced back tonight and inflicted the same dose on Bucknell, defeating the Pennsylvanians, 20 -- 7.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 30 -- Finance Minister Lee Joong Jap said tonight, after an all-day meeting of the National Assembly, that 500,000,000 hwan would be made available as soon as possible to the United Nations Command so that Korean, employers of the United Nations forces could be paid in the national currency.
Mediation efforts took place last night and early today to prevent a strike at midnight today by deliverers against eight metropolitan newspapers.
A surprise gift of $1,000,000 from Frank J. Gould, financier, to New York University was announced at the dedication of the $1,500,000 Gould Student Center on the University Heights campus yesterday.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A missing United States Air Force C-47 transport plane with all twenty-one passengers dead was found today smashed against the side of a mountain high in the wind-swept French-Italian Alps.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 -- Standing amid the publicity that has surrounded the Court of Common Pleas here for the last fortnight, one appreciates the "professional" opinion that the Sheppard murder case is the most sensational in Cleveland's modern history.

Next Tuesday's elections, if they follow precedent, are likely to show a gain for the opposition party -- that is to say, in this instance, the Democrats. A small shift in the Senate, a somewhat larger one in the House of Representatives, would create a situation which President Eisenhower deplored in his speech of Thursday evening.

NASSAU -- There was a time when any announcement about the winter season in the Bahamas (which opens on Dec. 6 this year) actually meant the winter season in the town of Nassau itself. So far as the winter visitor was concerned, Nassau and the entire Bahamas archipelago were one and the same thing.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Both Democrats and Republicans in Illinois have declared a shift of voters from city to suburban areas a portent of victory on Tuesday.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. -- Deep in the Salem part of this hyphenated city a $3,000,000 project to restore an old Moravian settlement is under way, and already there is enough to see to make a visit worth while.

We are told by the critics that "The Boy Friend" is a great show because it is a duplication of the musical of the Nineteen Twenties; two weeks later we are told that "On Your Toes" is disappointing because the book is out of the Nineteen Thirties.
WHILE chrysanthemums still reign, the last big shows of this season get under way this week. The first of these is the Chrysanthemum Show of the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society.

LEROY GORE is in his own words a "thoroughly conservative Republican country editor" who supported Joseph R. McCarthy for the Senate in 1952. He is, however, one of those Republicans who in the course of last winter became alarmed over Mr. McCarthy's record.

BACK in 1900, Flora Gregg, a young school teacher in Oklahoma, first heard of the Havasupai Indians, a small Arizona tribe hidden away in a branch of the Grand Canyon. She was of pioneer stock and it seemed to her that visiting an untouched people and helping them adjust to the inevitable white invasion of their canyon fastness would be another kind of pioneering.

STONE HARBOR, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Clifford P. Case addressed fifty key Republican leaders of Cape May County today and expressed confidence that the voters would "give me and the Republican party a vote of confidence" on Election Day.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Relics found last summer show that human society flourished in the Canadian Arctic for at least 2,000 years before the coming of the Thule Eskimos about 1,000 years ago, archaeologists reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The United States Information Service has ordered all employes in its Washington headquarters to drop their regular work Monday and spend the day personally recruiting qualified persons to fill a "critical shortage" of overseas propaganda specialists.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United States seems to have adopted a new tactic in foreign policy. It goes under the heading of "good partnership."
CHEROKEE, Iowa, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Senator Gillette, who is seeking re-election, refused to day to reveal whether or not he would vote to censure Senator McCarthy.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 30 (UP) -- King Ranch's High Gun, the hero of this year's Belmont Stakes, arrived from New York today for his engagement in the $65,000 Washington, D.C., International race at Laurel next Wednesday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Republican pluralities of up to 75,000 in Westchester County next Tuesday were predicted today by leaders of the party. Independent crystal gazers questioned only the size of the lead.
BOSTON, Oct. 30 -- Unheralded Xavier University knocked Boston College from the ranks of the unbeaten, 19 -- 14, today with a touchdown in the last 90 seconds at muddy Fenway Park before 4,972.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -The Army-Navy-Air Force Journal said today there was a good chance that Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, would be retained in that post when he reaches the retirement age of 60 in March.

WHEN George VI moved into Buckingham Palace after the abdication, the gloomy pile awoke to life. Flowers brightened the apartments. The long corridors echoed to children's laughter. Dogs pattered to and fro.

Day after tomorrow New York State will elect a Governor, other state officers and a state Legislature as well as the largest Congressional delegation in fife country. Historically, New Yorkers are hard to predict. For the last twelve years the state has been Republican (Thomas E. Dewey); for twenty years before that it was Democratic (Al Smith, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Herbert H. Lehman).
PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Winter vacationists arriving in the Palm Beach-Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood region without advance reservations this year are assured of living accommodations.

"THE SEARCH," presented at 4:30 o'clock on Sunday afternoons over the C.B.S. television network, holds every promise of being one of the season's outstanding accomplishments. It illustrates most hearteningly that "educational television" need not be set apart in academic isolation but can hold its own on merit as a rewarding and exciting experience in viewing.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The University of Vermont surged for two touchdowns in the second half and, thanks to the accurate place-kicking of extra points by Al McLam, defeated the University of Massachusetts, 27 -- 25, today as 7,500 fans cheered their favorites in a slashing rain.

RICHMOND, Oct. 30 -- Spurred by more seasonal weather, department store sales last week registered a 22 per cent increase over that week last year and cut the 1954 deficit to 1 per cent. The gain was spread uniformly over the entire district.
The first Jewish prayer books ever to be issued in both Hebrew and English Braille will be available for next fall's High Holy Days.
OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Miss Betty Miller, 34-year-old unemployed clerk, was called by the President today.

ABADAN, Iran, Oct. 30 (AP) -- United States, British, French and Dutch tankers took on Iranian oil today as the new international agreement for operating Iran's long-idle petroleum industry went into effect.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 -- Ralph Guglielmi pitched a 46-yard touchdown pass in the second quarter to Jim Morse and then recovered a Navy fumble in his end zone to save the victory for Notre Dame today in the wet, slippery field of Memorial Stadium.
"WHAT Makes Sammy Run?" Budd Schulberg's fine dissection of a Hollywood producer and his coterie, which has piqued the interest of movie men before, again has caught the fancy of film-makers.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 30 -- Shaving mugs and lather brushes, neck dusters, hair brushes, powder puffs, finger bowls and styptic pencils will join the off-key quartet as a thing of the past in Tennessee barber shops.
A battle centered on efforts of California fig growers to have quotas placed on imported figs is reaching a decisive stage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The laws of mathematics put strict limits on President Eisenhower's chain-phone-call plan and the Democrats' rival "walkathon" proposal to get out the votes.

The community as well as university students is now to be permitted to use the services of the expanded guidance center at the University of Toledo. WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- A Defense Department report said today that all-Negro units had been abolished within the military and that the integration had been carried out ahead of schedule without any "untoward incidents."

IT has often been said (in this reviewer's home, at least, and perhaps elsewhere) that if Stephen Longstreet, a jack of many trades, were to abandon such diversionary pursuits as cartooning, painting and the writing of musical comedies to concentrate on the writing of novels, he could not fail to produce a novel that would be both important and enjoyable.

THE native Vermonter is a thrifty being who considers more than the least possible outlay, whether it be paid in cash or speech, a violation of Green Mountain ethics. In consequence his purchases and his utterances are ruled by a frugality no other breed surpasses. No one has reported more accurately the laconically devastating comments of the outwardly cool, if inwardly overheated, Green Mountaineer than Keith Jennison.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The rising population of the United States is threatening to overcrowd its schools for mentally retarded children, just as it is overcrowding the regular public school system, according to Dr. Isaac N. Wolfson, director of the Newark State School here.

AT last, eighty years after the death of John Stuart Mill, we have a definitive and delightful biography that could scarcely be improved. The book, dealing with the personal as well as intellectual history of one of the most remarkable men of the nineteenth century and based on much new material, is in fact an intellectual history of that century.

DENVER, Oct. 30 (AP) -- James G. Patton, national president of the Farmers Union, said today that the Eisenhower Administration was preparing to dismantle the Federal soil conservation program and shift responsibility for soil conservation to state governments.

The arrival in Vietnam of a Philippine medical team made up of seven doctors and three nurses who will help in meeting the refugee problem is a significant event. This is not Government assistance, since the Philippines has not yet recognized the Vietnam Government.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 -- A new fishing law that, as now written, is giving United States fishing interests considerable concern has been submitted to the Mexican Congress. It is expected to be debated and adopted by the end of November.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Penn's football team stirred the hopes of 33,126 football fans at Franklin Field today by scoring the first touchdown of the game in the first period.
CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- John Glezen scored one touchdown and set up another as Hamilton defeated Kenyon, 27 -- 6, in a football game today.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The University of Rhode Island and the rainy weather, in that order, ruined homecoming day at Springfield College today as the Rams registered a 13-0 football triumph.

NOVICE flower arrangers, sometimes awed by the accomplishments of the experts, are timid about trying their own hand at it. But there is an easy way to go about it and, just as in learning anything, the basic rules should be mastered first.

An aria by Alessandro Bonci, one of Caruso's rivals in the days of the now defunct Manhattan Opera Company, will open the weekly recorded concert on Wednesday between noon and 2 P.M. at the New York Public Library Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

A comprehensive effort to improve the teaching of citizenship in schools and colleges of the United States has been in motion under the guidance of Teachers College, Columbia University. More than 700 city and county school systems, in thirty-eight states, are participating.

IN Carl Carmer's excellent review of "The Leatherstocking Saga," Mr. Canner notes that "those who would popularize living flesh-and-blood men gave them the attributes of Leatherstocking. Davy Crockett, half-history and half-legend, became another Hawkeye in coon-skin cap and fringed buckskin."

Adlai E. Stevenson called on voters last night to rebuke the Republican party for waging what he described as a campaign of "smears, slander, innuendo, and misrepresentation." A resounding victory for the Democrats in Tuesday's election not only will repudiate Republican tactics but also will go a long way toward restoring responsibility and fairness in government, he said.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 30 -- Prime Minister Nehru was given a somewhat critical reception when he arrived here this afternoon on his way home from a ten-day visit to Communist China. Intermixed with banners expressing praise and welcome were others that scored coexistence with communism and denounced the Vietminh and the Geneva armistice agreements.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee reported to the House of Representatives today that up to Oct. 15 it had spent $1,214,763 in the Congressional campaign. The Democratic National Committee reported expenditures of $1,031,669.
HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Grock the Clown said good-by to his public tonight. For the first time in half a century his performance brought sadness along with laughter.

Manhattan Adventure, a tour of private homes sponsored by the New York Wellesley Club as a benefit for its scholarship fund, will take place on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Led by a Queen, leaders of many nations joined last night to hail Columbia University for 200 years of international service since King George II of England granted its charter on Oct. 31, 1754.

The pace of cold war diplomacy slowed down last week after a two-month spurt. In that time both sides staked out positions likely to mark the dimensions of the international battleground for months to come. Western foreign ministers, in Paris eight days ago, signed agreements permitting, after parliamentary ratification, the rearmament and entry into NATO of West Germany and the settlement of the Franco-German dispute over the Saar.

CAIRO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Egyptian Government announced tonight the arrest of Hassan el-Hodeiby, supreme guide of the fanatical Moslem Brotherhood. He was accused of plotting to overthrow Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser's government with scores of assassinations.

WHEN the history of American progressivism for the first half of the twentieth century is written, the name of Donald Richberg will probably occupy an important, though not a major, place. "My Hero" is Mr. Richberg's latest volume of autobiography, superseding "Tents of the Mighty" of a quarter of a century ago; and it is an instructive and readable work.
TRENTON, Oct. 30 -- As the New Jersey political campaign nears its end, there is increasing evidence that the outcome of many of the contests is virtually unpredictable.

The Uniformed Firemen's Association and the Uniformed Fire Officers Association attacked yesterday a leaflet being distributed by the Nassau County Republican party as a "unwarranted slur on the members of the New York City Fire Department."

THE recorded version of Benny Goodman's 1938 Carnegie Hall concert, reputedly made from long-forgotten disks found in a closet in Mr. Goodman's home, can probably be credited with opening new vistas for the recording companies.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Minnesota rallied after the first quarter today and downed Michigan State, 19 -- 13, before a shivering Homecoming crowd to move back into the Big Ten title chase.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30 -- Dartmouth, with visions of repeating its 1953 upset of Yale, struck for a touchdown the first time it had the ball today. The unbeaten, once-tied Bulldogs retaliated by scoring twice in the second period to win, 13 -- 7, before 30,000 chilled spectators in the rainswept bowl.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Don Lussier, a sophomore, scored three touchdowns on a muddy field today to lead Worcester Polytech to its fifth straight football victory, 26 -- 6, over Rensselaer Poly.

KODAK TRI-X, an exceptionally fast panchromatic rollfilm in 35mm and 120-620 and 4x5 filmpack, which has been variously rated from the official "conservative" A.S.A. 200 to as high as A.S.A. 800 in the field, will be introduced tomorrow by Eastman Kodak Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The American Zionist Committee for Public Affairs reported today that 315 candidates for the Senate and House of Representatives had opposed sending arms to the Arab states "under present conditions."

KNUTE ROCKNE, a master psychologist, always handled three members of his famed Four Horsemen backfield with the utmost delicacy and consideration. But he never stopped prodding Sleepy Jim Crowley, his favorite. Perhaps he just wanted to keep him awake.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- The Giants flunked their first real test in the National Football League today, bogging down in the second half and dropping a 24-14 decision to the Cleveland Browns. An 83-yard pass play touchdown from Frank Gifford to Eddie Price early in the fourth period was all that saved the New Yorkers from a heavier defeat.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 31 -- Residents of this quiet Great Neck peninsula village can walk abroad tomorrow night without thoughts of a lion jumping at them from behind every bush and tree.

Not to be overlooked was his intent observation of the Irish lads kicking and catching a soccer ball.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Sufficient Democratic gains to control the House, with a tight battle for the Senate, were indicated today in a final week-end pre-election survey of forty-seven states.
ROME, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A procession of Roman Catholics from all parts of the world moved across Rome today, accompanying an ancient painting of the Virgin Mary for coronation by Pope Pius XII.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The pro-longed dock strike, to end tomorrow, found some reflection in the stock markets last week and began to affect sentiment over a much wider business field than that confined to financial London. The Stock Exchange setback was almost negligible, however, when put against the almost riotous progress of recent months.

In Brooklyn yesterday, nature's growth cycle produced the yearly high spot for Frank Weber, gardener. The annual Fall Indoor Chrysanthemum Show opened in the Prospect Park greenhouse, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, and eight months of nursing young plants came to fruition.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 31 (AP) -- A cruising Civil Air Patrol plane, which itself crashed minutes after the discovery, today found the burned wreckage of a private plane in which three persons died on a flight from La Guardia Airport in New York to Bradley Field in Windsor Locks.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa made public yesterday his first annual report, a 422-page printed document, which he said "clearly shows that the credit of the city of New York is sound."

Television viewers and radio listeners are in for a heavy dose of politics today, including last-minute appeals from President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Detroit Lions capitalized on every break today, came from behind twice and beat the Los Angeles Rams, 27 to 24, in a penalty-ridden game before 74,342 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

In Washington and probably in Moscow two theories regarding "peaceful coexistence" are constantly debated. These might be described as the Dulles theory and the Radford theory. The Secretary of State believes we can coexist with the Soviet Union and ultimately outlast it.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Three destroyers and a submarine were damaged in two collisions in heavy seas early today while engaged in anti-submarine warfare exercises about 270 miles east of Norfolk. There were no personnel casualties, an Atlantic Fleet spokesman said.
A frustrated hunter headed sadly for his Brooklyn home last night, after a fruitless ten-hour search through Queens for his prize hunting dogs.

One of the oldest pieces of statuary in Central Park, retrieved from its initial place in a wooded section of the Ramble and reconstructed, was unveiled in its new position west of the Mall yesterday.
TRENTON, Oct. 31 -- Both major political parties tonight predicted substantial victories for their candidates in Tuesday's elections.

A four-engined Navy Super-Constellation with forty-two persons aboard is missing and "presumed lost" on a trans-Atlantic flight, the Navy announced last night. All available ships and planes were engaged in a vast search and rescue operation covering a path 120 miles wide from the New Jersey coast to the Azores.

SHIRAZ, Iran, Sept. 29 -- The nomadic tribes, with their vast herds of camels, sheep and goats, are trekking southward past this city along centuries-old migration routes. This year they are carrying the first major addition to their equipment since they acquired firearms -- portable schools.

The Municipal Broadcasting System, which operates the city's non-commercial radio station WNYC, has asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to reverse a decision by the Federal Communications Commission.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 31 -- Four United States noncommissioned officers stationed at North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters in Izmir (Smyrna) have been arrested by Turkish police on charges having insulted the Turkish flag, reports received here today said.
The end of the twenty-eight-day British dock strike will offer this week the first challenge in several months to the staying powers of the now energetic charter market.

With the debut last night of the Ballets Espagnols of Teresa and Luisillo at the Mark Hellinger Theatre, Hispanic relations hereabouts took a decided turn for the better. This is by no means just another of those Spanish dance recitals, but is a fresh and lively evening in the theatre, with the accent strongly on the theatre.

To help give all New Yorkers the finest hospital care in the world, the seventy-fifth anniversary campaign of the United Hospital Fund of New York is now in full swing.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 31 -- The Scandinavian countries have named a Cabinet-level committee to explore the possibilities of creating a joint Scandinavian market and increasing the competitive power of Nordic production in the world market.

TEHERAN, Oct. 31 -- The Soviet Union has agreed not to molest search planes that cross its border inadvertently in a massive air and ground hunt for Prince Ali Riza, heir presumptive to the Iranian throne. He has been missing in a small air-craft since 5 P. M. Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Arnold Johnson, the Chicago industrialist who has been trying to buy the Philadelphia Athletics' American League franchise, went home today after issuing a statement that left the future of the ball club just as confused as ever.

As soloist in the Mendelssohn Piano Concerto in G minor, Ania Dorfmann reached new heights at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Saturday night in Carnegie Hall. The esteemed artist received excellent support from the orchestra, which was in top form and splendidly directed by Dimitri Mitropoulos.

A panel of six metropolitan high school students was divided yesterday on the wisdom of lowering the voting age to 18. But its members agreed that those who now enjoyed the franchise did not exercise this right sufficiently or intelligently enough.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31 -- In only three years, the over-all sown area in Kazakhstan, second largest republic in the Soviet Union, will be more than tripled.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Oct. 29 -- The food resources of the sea will some day hold the key to man's survival, James Sinclair, Federal Minister of Fisheries, warned in a speech here during the first annual meeting of the International North Pacific Fisheries Commission, which ended today.

The five-story dwelling on lot 22 by 100 feet at 55 East Eightieth Street has been sold by Mrs. Lyndon Hadley to Dr. Louis B. Rosenblatt for occupancy as a home and office. Francis R. Jaffin was the broker.

ARDEN, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- An English field trial champion, Ludlovian Bruce of Greenfair, today won the open all-age stake for English springers, feature event of the closing day of the thirtieth field trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association.
CHRISTOPHER COATES, the aquariist, is stuffed to the gills right now with details for stocking the $10,000,000 aquarium for which earth was turned the other day at Coney Island.

A new edifice for the Church of the Open Door was dedicated yesterday afternoon at Gold and Nassau Streets, Brooklyn. The congregation has the support of the New York City Mission Society, the Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York and seven cooperating Protestant denominations.
Clifford P. Case predicted yesterday that he would be elected United States Senator from New Jersey despite the smears he said he had suffered during the campaign.

The champions of Ireland's national sports, hurling and Gaelic football, broke even in rugged engagements with two New York All-Star fifteens selected from New York's Gaelic Athletic Association before 28,000 happy fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Harlon Hill, a towering end who can run like an antelope, caught a 46-yard pass from Ed Brown and loped 20 yards for a touchdown with 25 seconds to go today to give the Chicago Bears a 31-27 victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners.

HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- Cubans have many headaches these days and sugar is giving them one of the worst. They know that United States sugar producers are out to cut Cuban sugar exports to America in 1955 and have a good chance of succeeding.
The New York Foundation has made grants in the four-year period, 1950 through 1953, of $2,131,206 in the three fields of health and medicine; social welfare; education and civic affairs.

Ch. Wei Tiko of Pekeboro, a red pekingese imported from England in August by Rose Marie Katz of the Roh Kai Kennels, Syracuse, was the chief winner yesterday at the Progressive Dog Club's twenty-second annual show for toy breed dogs.

After an eight-year absence, Edna Bockstein returned to Town Hall last night to give a piano recital. One interesting novelty was on her program -- Bach's Trio Sonata No. 5 in C, usually played by organists, which she transcribed for piano.

The retirement of Bushrod B. Howard as a director of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) was announced here yesterday. Mr. Howard, who has served the organization for thirty-four years, is an authority on domestic and foreign tanker operations.

British sterling and the Canadian dollar enjoyed a good week so far as turnover was concerned. However, it was not productive of any wide swing of rates and the net improvement noted was confined to minor fractions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Olivia de Havilland will be starred as George Sand in "Lelia," the Andre Maurois biography of the nineteenth-century French author who also figured importantly in the political life of her day.
We summarize here our recommendations regarding questions and candidates to be voted upon tomorrow.
RIO DE JANIERO, Oct. 31, -- Brazil's critical financial situation is becoming more acute and the perennial question of coffee production and coffee prices is the main factor in the development.
A state-approved plan to wipe out the "commission racket" in union welfare funds has been put into operation by a 30,000-member union in this city.

It is very gratifying for me to note that in one of its editorials your newspaper, has pointed out the realistic and intelligent viewpoint taken by the Japanese Government in its relationships with the Communist bloc of Asia.
Two plans for advertising advertisting were developed over the week-end.
HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- The Superior Tribunal tonight denied Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin's petition for postponing the Cuban elections for a minimum period of ten days.

Three thousand members of the Salvation Army and their friends took over the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon to greet their international leader, Gen. Wilfred Kitching, who has been visiting this country since September.
A foot patrolman commandeered a Fire Department battalion chief's radio car last night for a successful six-block chase of a fleeing hit-run driver up Park Avenue.
East Side, West Side, all around the town, New Yorkers may no longer be dancing the light fantastic, but they are going in for more rides ad games.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Lard future prices on the Board of Trade showed a strong tone last week. Hog receipts have not been large enough to meet the expectation of many lard operators, although running larger than a year ago. This encouraged short covering.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 31 -- The opposition Moslem party, generally regarded as the largest political group in Indonesia, has called upon President Sukarno to dissolve the present shaky Government of Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo in the national interest.

An unusual auction, one at which bargains were not being sought, netted a tidy sum last night for a group with a cause. The sale, arranged by the American Friends of the Allied Circle, had a number of remarkable features besides the fact that the auction-goers were not out to get things as cheaply as possible.

Martin Luther's act of defiance 437 years ago in nailing his Ninety-five Theses to the church door in Wittenberg, Germany, was commemorated yesterday in an atmosphere of reverence and hope at St. Paul's Lutheran Church, Crotona Avenue and 178th Street, the Bronx.

There wasn't much that the New York Rangers could claim credit for in their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. Making almost as many mistakes as their cellar-dwelling foes from the Windy City, the Broadway Blues managed to salvage a 1 to 1 tie out of the proceedings.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 31 -- New Jersey's most colorful political rally -- the annual pre-election get-together of the Hudson County Democratic organization -- mixed political romance with its speeches today.
The two Soviet scholars who arrived here Friday to attend the Columbia bicentennial were interested participants in the final ceremonies yesterday in the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
MIAMI, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Disciples of Christ ended its 105th international convention today with a communion service at which an estimated 6,000 delegates received the traditional bread and wine.

PIERMONT, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Clergymen of five churches in this area announced to their congregations today that they had joined in answering a letter received from Governor Dewey on Thursday. They voiced resentment toward a statement by the Governor that the ministers were "being misled by political partisans."
Construction of a plant to manufacture neoprene synthetic rubber near Montague, Mich., was announced yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. Completion is scheduled for late in 1956.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, accused Republicans yesterday of "slander and distortion" in their campaign to win the Governorship.

Director of the American Home Assurance Company and the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company have recommended a merger of these two companies, according to William S. Youngman Jr., chairman of both companies.

Irving Miller's attack on the American Council for Judaism, reported in The Times Oct. 23, is characterized by the same inaccuracy and distortion that have provided the basis for Zionist attacks on American Middle East policy.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 (UP) -- There was much legal discussion today of the alleged criminal record of a juror chosen in the murder trial of Samuel H. Sheppard.

Clarence B. Randall, chairman of the board of Inland Steel, will present his personal views on United States foreign economic policy in the Walgreen Foundation lectures beginning today at the University of Chicago. His text will be presented in book form Nov. 15 by the University of Chicago Press, entitled "A Foreign Economic Policy for the United States."

MONTREAL, Oct. 31 (Canadian Press) --Distillers Corporation-Seagrams; Ltd., including whollySowhed subsidiaries in Canadaand the United States, had net profit in the year ended on July 31 of $3,5,840,162, or $4.09 a share, comlared with $37,890,561, or: $4.32 ,a share, in the preceding year. "Figures are in American' dollars.
Football's Halloween special was Army 21, Virginia 20. The goblins have been enjoying a field day week after week of the zany season but they put the prophets on the rack Saturday as seldom before.

Two steel dump scows, which will employ remotely controlled and hydraulically operated discharge doors, have been ordered for the Moran Towing Corporation. The new craft, believed to be the first of their type, will be constructed at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island shipyard.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Soybean futures had the center of the stage last week, with big advances registered, but the grain futures also developed unexpected strength, with higher prices registered all around. In soybeans the bullish features were more apparent than was the case in wheat, the holding attitude of the growers being the main feature of the soybean situation.
Mayfair Industries, Inc, aluminum folding chairs, in 601 Madison Av -- Mrs. Harry L. Cort, broker.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Ollie Matson, racing 91 yards for one touchdown and catching an 18-yard pass for another, led the revitalized Chicago Cardinals to their first league victory of the season today in a resounding 17-14 upset of the Pittsburgh Steelers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Two members of the Senate anti-monopoly subcommittee said today they would ask Congress for an appropriation of $1,000,000 next year to carry on the group's work.

As long as babies continue to be born, people will be thinking up new ways to clothe them. The diaper stage in particular taxes the ingenuity of mothers and manufacturers, and seldom does a season pass without someone inventing a new version of this garment.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Fairfield County, identified on the political map as the Fourth Congressional District of Connecticut, on Tuesday will re-elect Representative Albert P. Morano of Greenwich, a Republican, for a third successive term, if the prevailing public opinion can be trusted.
Improvements in the ancient problem of cargo handling and consequent reduction of time spent in port was forecast here yesterday by Louis S. Rothschild, Maritime Administrator.

All voting throughout the state at tomorrow's general election will be done by machine, in contrast to that in 1952, when the heavy turnout compelled some communities outside this city to supplement the mechanical recorders with paper ballots.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Private enterprise in "easing human misery and oppression" was praised today by United States Ambassador C. Douglas Dillon in addressing the ninth annual conference of the American Joint Distribution Committee, meeting at UNESCO house.

While the Supreme Court's ruling against segregation of races in the public schools is still a generalization unsupported by a court order, segregation in the armed services is legally extinct. This is the gist of a report prepared by James C. Evans for the Department of Defense and made public Saturday.

There are few spectacles that can compete for ceremonious splendor with the opening of the National Horse Show. The world series, the Kentucky Derby and the Army-Navy football game have their own special brands of spine-tingling pageantry, but these are of the more frenzied variety.
The nation's undefeated and untied collegiate football teams was reduced to thirty-seven -- including seven major schools -- yesterday.

WHEN "The Halls of Ivy" made its original appearance on the radio, many a listener was thoroughly stunned. The program's story line and dialogue were so literate and amusing that the effect on an audience was not unlike an introduction of Gilbert and Sullivan on "The Hit Parade."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Bits and pieces of evidence -- concededly not conclusive -- indicate that this is Dwight D. Eisenhower's last election campaign as President.
Indonesia, which plans to revise its foreign investment laws next year, has undertaken a systematic investigation of what foreign companies would require before investing in that country.
Three new films, including an import from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Oct. 31 -- For the first time in the colorful history of Hudson County a woman may become the Mayor of one of its communities.

There was an unwonted radiance on television yesterday afternoon. It was shed more by Mozart's music than by the presentation in color, although the latter element was of a high order. The occasion was the season's first telecast by the N. B. C. Opera Theatre, and the opera was "The Abduction from the Seraglio."
PEIPING, Oct. 28 -- This is a city where anything may turn up, where anyone may suddenly appear round the corner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Foreign Operations Administration announced today that it had simplified the rules governing its investment guarantee program "to encourage a larger flow of private capital" abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The President and Mrs. Eisenhower today attended services at St. John's Episcopal Church and heard a minister pray for God's guidance in the coming election and assert the need for religion in politics, education and science.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 31 -- The eighty-piece Israel Philharmonic Orchestra played today amid the scaffolding and bare concrete of a partly finished auditorium in honor of their benefactor, Fredric R. Mann of Philadelphia.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam said here tonight that Protestantism was one of the world's strongest bulwarks against communism.

An appeal for "the restoration of religion to a position of centrality" in the field of higher education was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary.
Foreign governments needing United States dollars are back in the private financial market here, after a long absence.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Arthur Knapp Jr. made a successful start in his quest of a fifth straight Larchmont Yacht Club winter title by winning today's inaugural championship regatta of the twenty-fourth frostbite season on Long Island Sound.

Once more "A Moon for the Misbegotten" is on its way to Broadway after stumbling twice. Look for Eugene O'Neill's drama of bitter disillusionment to open in March at the Bijou, rented through the cooperation of the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Navy is developing a new electronic-age mine hunter to combat the deadly pressure mine and its potential threat to Allied control of the seas, naval experts said today.

The major party candidates for Governor defended yesterday the political leaders supporting them. Each contended, however, that in the event of his election he alone would make final decisions as Governor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Vic Janowicz' first National Football League field goal helped the Washington Redskins snap their five-game losing streak today, giving them a 24-21 victory over the Baltimore Colts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Reorganization of all financial management functions of the Post Office Department into a single unit becomes effective tomorrow.

The second program of the Concert Society yesterday afternoon in Town Hall introduced to this country the Quintetto Boccherini in a program of three works -- Boccherini's Quintet in D (Op. 18, No. 5), Malipiero's Symphony for Five Strings and Schubert's Quintet in C.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 -- On the basis of trade reports current last week there is every indication that the improvement in steel activity will not be a short-lived one.
The coloratura soprano Erna Sack, whose records are sought-after collectors' items, sang a recital at Carnegie Hall last evening. It was her first appearance in this country since 1937.

The truism to say that for good international relations nations must know and understand each other applies most strongly to the peoples of the United States and the Soviet Union. Unfortunately the degree of personal knowledge and relationship between these two peoples today is infinitesimal.

Columbia University's bicentennial ended yesterday with a cathedral ceremony. Scholars and statesmen from both hemispheres heard hope expressed there for the fulfillment of "the dream of peace that is as old as mankind."

The United States Senate will be recalled to its special session one week from today. The purpose of this session is to entertain and presumably act upon the committee report on the censure of Senator McCarthy. Now the White House has announced that there will be forwarded to this session those recently concluded security pacts, both European and Asian, that require Senate confirmation.
