Last week representatives of the thirty-four countries that now adhere to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (usually referred to by its shorter title of GATT) foregathered at Geneva preparatory to starting a week today on what could well be the most difficult task they have faced in the six-year history of that body.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman revealed yesterday that a Senate investigation would begin here "in the near future" to determine whether a private utility company might obtain a monopoly on the St. Lawrence power project.

A sharp denunciation of the Egyptian Embassy in Washington for a "flagrant violation of diplomatic proprieties" in issuing a public statement last Thursday was made yesterday by Dr. Emanuel Neumann, chairman of the executive committee of the Zionist Organization of America.

There was a violent accident at the corner of Broadway and 116th Street on Oct. 24. A woman was very seriously injured and lay unconscious and bleeding in the middle of the street while helpless crowds gathered. The police and ambulance were summoned immediately, but there was a twenty-minute wait before their arrival.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The College of William and Mary today announced plans for observance all next year of the 200th anniversary of the birth of one of its most famous students -- John Marshall, Dr. W. Melville Jones will be executive director of the anniversary program.
The threat of a pre-election strike of 4,300 newspaper drivers evaporated yesterday, seven hours before the strike deadline.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 31 -- Current opinion is that the new Canadian wheat crop will fall below 300,000,000 bushels and that no more than half will grade No. 4 Northern or better, according to the Board of Grain Comissioners.

The first scholarship award of the Times Square Club, an organization of Masons employed by The New York Times, was set up yesterday at a meeting of the club in the Sheraton Astor Hotel. The award was fixed at $150 and is to be presented annually.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Britain's 44,000 striking dockworkers are to return to their jobs tomorrow morning, but it was estimated today that it would take three or four weeks to get the eight affected ports back to normal operations.
PALMDALE, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Jim Rogers beat Leonard Nash in a golf game here yesterday. Rogers shot a brilliant 576 and Nash carded a 578.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- One of Britain's best test pilots was officially declared today to have included secret information about British military planes in his autobiography, published last week.

YOKOHAMA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Heinz Futterer of West Germany equalled Jesse Owens' world record of 10.2 seconds for the 100-meter dash for the second time in two weeks today and tied his own European record of 0:20.8 for 200 meters.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 31 -- Premier Fazlollah Zahedi sponsored a bill, given priority in the Majlis (lower house of Parliament), today that would provide the death penalty after a court-martial conviction for a wide category of subversive activities, including leadership in and propaganda for Communist organizations and groups opposed to Islam and the constitutional monarchy.

Five men were arraigned in Felony Court yesterday in connection with the robbery of the town house of Mr. and Mrs. Minot K. Milliken at 186 East Sixty-fourth Street last Tuesday. Of the $77,000 in furs, jewelry and clothing taken, $53,000 worth has been recovered, the police said.

Any trip through the suburbs is pleasant these late afternoons and early evenings, for once again the smell of burning leaves passes across the land. Children rake up the materials after school, very often with no thought of payment beyond the bonfire privileges, and even cooks who might better be tending the roasts step outdoors for a bit of stirring around which they think of as raking.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The merger of Studebaker and Packard is already showing benefits, James J. Nance, president of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation, said today.

At first glance, "How to Sell Your Way Into the Big Money"* seems to be little more than a glorification of that new and annoying class in our society, the Expense Account Millionaires. Apparently there is no higher goal conceivable by Vincent F. Sullivan of The Daily News (N. Y.) than a lifetime of association with the corporation executives who can sign $51 checks for two lunches.

Allen M. Dorfman, whose Chicago insurance agency was criticized by a Congressional committee investigating racketeering in union welfare funds, lost his right yesterday to act as an insurance agent in this state.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- A chemical compound reported to be effective in controlling overpopulation has been developed in India, Dr. Clarence J. Gamble of Milton, Mass., reported today.

A cake, if it smacks of butter and spices and is laden with raisins and citron, can make a festivity of almost any occasion. Such was, and is, the round, raised loaf New England housewives once baked in brick ovens as a traditional Election Day treat.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Trade negotiations between France and the Soviet Union will soon be under way.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- A new Civil Defense observation post was dedicated today by this community, which has had spotters on twenty-four-hour duty since July, 1952.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Manufacturers received more new orders for goods in September, largely military items, than in any month since the business downturn started in mid-1953, the Commerce Department reported today.
Dwellings form the bulk of properties passing to new hands in the latest deals reported in Brooklyn.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Charles Briggs of Utica was elected president today of the Empire Typographical Conference as it held its seventy-second semi-annual meeting here. He succeeds Ellis W. Brown of Ithaca.

MOSCOW, Oct. 31 -- At 9:30 this morning all bonds of the series No. 39522 of the Second State Loan for Restoration and Development of the National Economy of the U. S. S. R. were retired. That number was the first drawn in the lottery that ran all day in the auditorium of the Palace of Culture of Metro (Subway) Builders in Moscow.

WHEN Ellen Glasgow died in 1945 at the age of either 71 or 72 (there was some confusion about her birth date) the world of American letters lost one of its few indisputably major novelists. Miss Glasgow brought to the writing of fiction a shrewd sense of social realities, a charming gift for ironic comedy and impressive insight into character.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Civil Aeronautical Administration investigators tried to determine today whether mechanical failure, the only thing that ever stopped Wilbur Shaw on an auto race track, caused the airplane crash that killed the Indianapolis Motor Speedway president and two companions Saturday.

An unusual number of uncertainties appeared yesterday to be clouding the outlook for tomorrow's state election in New York. Some forecasters were predicting a close contest, but they appeared to mean that it was impossible to weigh the effect of many factors bearing on the outcome.

When the proposed capital budget for 1955 is reported to the Board of Estimate today by the City Planning Commission we assume it will contain, as it certainly should, the $8,000,000 sought by the Park Department for a half dozen more indoor recreation centers.
The Republicans may know the effect of their chain telephone get-out-the-vote drive from election returns before they know it from the telephone companies, it appeared yesterday.

ABADAN, Iran, Oct. 31 -- The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company's tanker British Advocate pulled away from the refinery quayside here today with 11,500 tons of fuel oil bound for Trincomalee, Ceylon. It was the first Iranian oil in upward of forty months to move freely into world markets.

PERTH, Australia, Oct. 31 (AP) -- America's temperamental Tommy Bolt caused an uproar in the Australia-United States golf match at Lake Karrinyup today when he threatened four times to walk off the course.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The House of Representatives has boasted through the generations that it was "closest the people." Its champions have described its membership as "the people themselves," an all-inclusive cross-section unmatched, perhaps, by any other national legislative body.
The first mobile seagoing oil rig capable of drilling for offshore oil in 100 feet of water will be commissioned in Beaumont, Tex., waters today.

The Columbia Gas System, Inc., announced yesterday that a huge new supply of natural gas would become available today for homes and industries in the area served by the company. The fuel will flow through the newly built Gulf Interstate Gas Company pipeline from Louisiana to the United Fuel Gas Company of Charlestown, W. Va., a Columbia affiliate.

DENVER, Oct. 31 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight he would "take on" Adlai E. Stevenson on a nation-wide telecast from Denver tomorrow night to answer "the most scurrilous attack ever made on a President of the United States by a major political figure."
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- With attention centered on ratification of the new accords for Germany's rearming, the French National Assembly will convene Tuesday.

Following is the text of the convocation oration on "The Common Ground in Humility," which was given yesterday by Dr. J. Bartlet Brebner, Gouverneur Morris professor of history, at the third Columbia University bicentennial convocation:

A richly colored, stained-glass window depicting the eternal sanctity of motherhood was unveiled yesterday by Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain at a service of morning prayer in the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
Following is the text of the address by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, at the university's third bicentennial convocation yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The chairmen of the Democratic and Republican National Committees agreed today on at least one thing -- they still were poles apart on the campaign issues of the national economy, corruption and internal security.
Employes of sixty-five wholesale salt-water fish dealers went on strike last midnight, limiting -- but not cutting off -- the city's favorite Friday food supply.
Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain, born Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon and holder of other titles since then, acquired yesterday her first American title -- Doctor of Laws.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, and his Republican opponent, Joseph T. Meek, tonight both predicted victory in their Illinois Senatorial battle next Tuesday.
Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany, ending a short visit to this country, spent part of his last day in New York yesterday at a morning mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The consolidated net income from regular operations of the Sinclair Oil Corporation for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 was $52,896,384, or $4.29 a share, P. C. Spencer, president, reported over the week-end. This compares with $47,505,509, or $3.87 a share, in the similar period last year.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 31 -- Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, said today his visit to Communist China had led him to believe that "the people of China are anxious to have peace and to avoid war." He said he had been assured that the Communist Chinese Government did not wish to interfere in other countries' problems.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 31 -- An early start on construction of the proposed $60,000,000 Inter-American Cultural and Trade Center here was virtually assured this week-end when the Center Authority signed a preliminary contract with two New York investment bankers to provide private financing.
From 5,000,000 to 5,500,000 men and women in New York State will go to the polls tomorrow to choose a Governor and other state-wide officers.
THE Second Avenue Theatre, last stronghold of the Yiddish stage on the street whose name it bears, opened its new season Saturday night with a musical play, "Wish Me Luck!"
The welcome mat at Melrose Houses in the Bronx was out yesterday for President William V. S. Tubman of Liberia and Governor Dewey.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Iona Prep's undefeated team clinched the 1954 Catholic High School Football League championship today by downing Archbishop Stepinac of White Plains 20 -- 6. The Irish, the only un defeated team in the league, finished the circuit schedule with five triumphs.

Cotton prices in the domestic market softened a bit last week, but the volume of business improved. At the close of the market on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 3 to 14 points from the previous week's close.

DENVER, Oct. 31 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today shrugged off as the work of a mentally unbalanced person the telephone call that reported that his dinner had been poisoned in the Benjamin Franklin Hotel in Seattle last night.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,336,029,605. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

ATLANTA, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Nine soldiers said to have witnessed brutal disciplinary measures taken by a second lieutenant against recruits have been recalled to testify at a high-level investigation, the Army said today.
LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United Nations Ambassador, returned tonight to plead the cause of home-state Republicans seeking election Tuesday.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Dr. Paul M. Gross, president of the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies, has reported "sound progress" at the Institute in the eighth annual report transmitted today to the Oak Ridge Council.

Religiously mixed marriages usually should not take place, Canon Bernard C. Newman declared yesterday. He offered this advice in a sermon in Trinity Protestant. Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, where he is vicar.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Christian Dior's sensational H-line will soon be paraded against the background of the stateliest of all the stately homes of England -- Blenheim Palace, birthplace of Winston Churchill and county seat of the Dukes of Marlborough.

Opening night at the Metropolitan Opera, at 8 P. M. a week from today, will consist of selections from four operas. The entire program will be televised over a closed - circuit network. Three operas will be given during the first week -- "Die Meister-singer" on Thursday evening, "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" on Friday evening and "Madama Butterfly" on Saturday evening.
Yesterday marked the opening of a celebration of the 125th anniversary of the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Eighty-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The observances will end next Sunday.

Two prize hunting dogs that disappeared from a car in Queens Sunday and prevented their master, Frank Grimm, 49 years old, of 63 Stewart Street, Brooklyn, from completing his rabbit foray, were returned yesterday amid a chorus of happy yelps.

President Eisenhower has stressed the importance of "spiritual strength and vitality" in young people in a message for National Catholic Youth Week, now being celebrated. His letter was sent to the Catholic Youth Organization, 122 East Twenty-second Street.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Stockholders of the Follansbee Steel Corporation voted overwhelmingly today to sell their assets to New York financier Frederick W. Richmond, a deal that residents of Follansbee, W. Va., say will make their community a ghost town.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan denied a motion today to dismiss an indictment charging Claude Mack Lightfoot, Illinois Communist leader, with violation of the Smith Act. This law forbids teaching or advocating the overthrow of the Government by force or violence.

Ramar, the scrappy, 80-pound, untamed African lion cub that upset the residents of Kings Point, L.I., a week ago when he escaped from his cage for ninety minutes, was settled in his new home in the Central Park Zoo yesterday afternoon.
Adlai E. Stevenson charged last night that the Republicans had sought to make "a partisan issue of war and peace," and suggested that their campaign had reached "new depths in the pursuit of office."

MAin 4-5091 was a busy number yesterday. Extension 2, on which E.J. (Buzzie) Bavasi, the vice president of the Dodgers says "hello," rarely stopped ringing. If the veep did nothing else he earned his day's salary just answering local and long distance calls.
PONDICHERRY, India, Nov. 1 -- India took over the four French enclaves of Pondicherry, Karikal, Mahe and Yanaon in a brief ceremony here today.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, received the Order of the Cherub from the University of Pisa yesterday afternoon. It was presented at a reception for the Italian representatives to the university's third bicentennial convocation.
For a few hours at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday it must have seemed like old times to William O'Dwyer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- David S. Teeple, a central but little known figure in the behind-the-scenes controversy over atomic security, has resigned from Government service.

One seldom hears of an election being "stolen" in recent years. There are a number of reasons for this. One agency that can share the credit through being vigilantly on guard is the Election Frauds Bureau set up in 1943 by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein soon after he took office in Albany.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A plan for partial liquidation of the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company was approved by stockholders at a special meeting here today. With 91 per cent of the outstanding D and C shares represented at the meeting, the vote was 416,859 in favor of the plan recommended by directors to 209 against.

Every governmental inquiry into union welfare fund operations has made it clear that the payment of millions of dollars in commissions and service fees to agents who perform little or no real service has been a fertile source of corruption. For example, the State Insurance Department hearings a month ago disclosed that one agent had collected $36,276 from two relatively small funds without ever meeting the officers of the unions he was supposed to represent.
If the Fifth Avenue Association has its way the local municipal ordinance prescribing awnings and such projections be at least six feet off the ground will be changed to enforce a seven-foot minimum.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 1 -- A spokesman for the Southeastern Europe headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at Izmir (Smyrna) said today four United States airmen had denied charges of disrespect toward the Turkish flag.
TORONTO, Nov. 1 -- Dominion Foundries and Steel Company, has opened North America's first Oxygen Steel plant in Hamilton, Ont., it was announced today.
Following is the text of an address by Adlai E. Stevenson over the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network last night.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- The settlement of three trade disputes, in two of which the United States was the complainant, was announced here today by the contracting parties to the General Agreement oft Tariffs and Trade.
Frankie Ryff, unbeaten Bronx lightweight, scored his fifteenth straight triumph last night by gaining a unanimous ten-round decision over Henry Davis at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.

The Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc., has signed up its first non-United States member company. The new affiliate is the Union Miniere du Haut Katanga, a big Belgian metals mining concern. It owns and operates one of the world's leading uranium mines, the Shinkelobwe mine in the Belgian Congo.

We wish to join with what we believe to be the great body of our citizens in declaring that this country views not so much with fear as with horror any possible renewal of global war. Yet, even so, we hold that the mere avoidance or cessation of open warfare is not the supreme and final good.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau announced today the appointment of Gordon Dunn of Chicago as chief hurricane forecaster at Miami, Fla. He succeeds the late Grady Norton, who won fame in the Miami bureau for his plotting of the big storms. Mr. Norton died Oct. 9.

Virtuosity is not all, but it can carry one a long way. It helped Leonard Pennario to tick off a number of successes in his piano recital at Town Hall last night. There were places where his playing had a brilliance that filled the hall with excitement, and under the spell of such technical prowess one felt that this young American could do just about anything he wished.

ROME, Nov. 1 -- In one of the most impressive and solemn ceremonies of his pontificate, Pope Pius XII brought the Marian Year to its climax this morning. He symbolically crowned the Virgin Mary Queen of Heaven and proclaimed the Feast of the Queenship of Mary.

A tradition-steeped contest pairing the non-winning forces of Manual and Erasmus at Tilden Field, Brooklyn, and the match between Stuyvesant's unbeaten eleven and Clinton at Randalls Island head the local scholastic football program today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Arnold Johnson today tabbed his chances of buying the Philadelphia Athletics as "excellent," disclosed for the first time the identities of his partners in the transaction, and declared he was ready to spend "another million dollars for players."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had risen to the highest point in about seven weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered a $1,300,000-a-year increase in railroad rates on freight shipped within North Carolina. The I.C.C. said intrastate freight rates in North Carolina are "abnormally low" as a result of the expiration of a general 15 per cent increase last Feb. 28.

The $30,000 added Frizette Stakes, with the Wheatley Stable's High Voltage as the "featured performer," will be the main attraction at the Jamaica Race Track today. Listed for its seventh running, the Frizette is for 2-year-old fillies who will be asked to run a mile and a sixteenth.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) -- High Gun, conceded the best American chance to stop the foreign invaders, was withdrawn from the $65,000 Washington, D.C., International race today because of an injury and C.V. Whitney's Fisherman was substituted in the starting line-up.
HAVANA, Nov. 1 -- Cuba completed today the most confusing and frightening election in her history. Cuban and United States informants agreed that the island was in for a time of grave trouble.
Floating mines are still a menace to waters of the western Pacific nine years after the end of World War II, according to the Navy's Hydrographic Office.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Tuesday, Nov. 2 -- An espionage ring of twelve Pakistani nationals has been uncovered by the police intelligence division.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- The wreckage of a Vickers Viscount airliner, which crashed north of here yesterday killing three top Australian pilots, burst into flames again today as aviation experts left for the scene. The fire was soon put out.

Four Puerto Rican Nationalists who pleaded guilty to seditious conspiracy charges received six- year suspended sentences yesterday and were placed on probation for five years by Federal Judge Lawrence E. Walsh.
GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- West Europe's exports to East Europe registered a 43 per cent increase in the first half of 1954 compared with the corresponding period of 1953.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service intervened today in the labor-management dispute that had closed the Port of Philadelphia to all dry cargo handling since Friday.

Applications for 1955 golf permits, each costing $15, are now available at the five borough offices of the Parks Department. The permits will become valid Jan. 1 and may be used at any department course open for play.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 1 -- The impending retirement of Dr. Daniel F. Malan as Prime Minister Nov. 30 already has enhanced the prospects of a rapprochement between two bitterly warring white factions in South Africa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Army, reshuffled its organization in the Far East today, naming Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor commander of all United States ground forces in Japan and Okinawa, as well as Korea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today authorized the Scandinavian Airlines System to operate planes from California across the North Polar regions to points in Norway, Sweden and Denmark, and vice versa.
Clifford P. Case declared last night that President Eisenhower's program would be "stopped dead in its tracks" unless a Republican majority was returned to Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- A note of harmony crept into the otherwise bitter, partisan Congressional election campaign tonight as the capital's voteless Republicans and Democrats staged a protest torchlight parade down Pennsylvania Avenue.
Following are the texts of Election Eve broadcasts last night by Vice President Richard M. Nixon from Denver and President Eisenhower from Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

A pictorial story of how "American dreamers, wizards and inspired tinkerers" converted a wilderness "into the wonder of the world" will be published Nov. 10 by Simon Schuster. The 130,000 words of narrative, written by Mitchell Wilson, is illustrated with 1,200 drawings, engravings, photographs and paintings.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A thousand more hogs than a week ago were absorbed today, but prices generally were 25 to 50 cents a hundredweight lower.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Egypt protested today that an Israeli letter calling for a Security Council meeting on Suez Canal restrictions on shipping contained "gross errors."
Sixty-four Negro educators have expressed faith in the ultimate results of the Supreme Court's desegregation decision and have urged colleagues not to "be a party to any plan designed to nullify" it.

THIRTY pieces of sculpture and a score of drawings by Henry Moore -- all of work done in the period 1951-53 -- make up the new exhibition at the Curt Valentin Gallery. This was one of the exhibitions Mr. Valentin had planned last spring before he left for Europe, where he died in August.

Cocoa prices continue to soar on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market closed 77 to 100 points (hundreths of a cent a pound) higher yesterday, the fifth consecutive trading session of substantial rises.

YONKERS, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Despite the first cold night of the meeting, 18,111 fans turned out at Yonkers Raceway tonight as Thomas Hat, owned by Alex Parsons of London, Ont., and driven by Cecil Champion, won the $3,500 Peekskill pace.
Three of the nation's leading manufacturers of tires have raised tire and tube prices 2 1/2 per cent to 5 per cent.
One of the scripts generating more than unusual interest in Broadway managerial circles these days is a drama entitled "A Quiet Place," written by Julian Claman, television producer and writer.
Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a year-end dividend of $2 a share, payable on Dec. 10.
The Concord Baptist Church of Christ has sold the three-story two-family dwelling at 400 Putnam Avenue in Brooklyn to Ralph E. Brewster. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Now the tumult and the shouting dies and it is the day to vote. The polls are open from 6 A.M. to 7 P.M. today, ready to receive you as you do your duty and exercise your privilege as a citizen. If you are the average citizen it is one of the few days of the year when you have or use the opportunity to participate in the Government you live under.
Striking workers at the Fulton Fish Market sought yesterday to exploit the "divide and conquer" strategy that proved so successful in the general trucking strike here two weeks ago.

DO you know anything about Hobbits and their habits? Neither did I until a few days ago when I encountered them in "The Fellowship of the Ring,"* a romantic fantasy by J.R.R. Tolkien. Hobbits are something like dwarfs and more like people. They seldom reach three feet in height. Their feet are bare and very hairy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Leaders of the eleven-month-old strike of Pittsburgh department store workers conferred today with officials of their parent union, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, accused the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee tonight of distributing a piece of "malicious fakery." He said this was a spot radio announcement that told listeners that Moscow "orders" the defeat of Republican candidates.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The ten persons President Eisenhower telephoned Saturday in a drive for a big voter turnout are passing the word along with gusto.

A search armada of about 200 planes and thirty surface vessels failed for the second day yesterday to find any trace of the Navy Super Constellation that disappeared on a trans-Atlantic flight early Sunday with forty-two persons on board.

The fact that few New Yorkers eat lamprey would be the last reason in the world to discourage Jack Simon, the food buyer of Bloomingdale's, from ordering it for his department. The eel-like fish, prepared as the cooks of the Bordeaux region do it in red wine, is one of the new products from France appearing in that department store.

TRENTON, Nov. 1 -- Dr. Harry L. Stearns said today the school boundaries in Englewood were revised to alleviate overcrowding and this was done without considering whether maximum integration of the races had been achieved.
UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Four deaths in two accidents today increased to five the number of persons killed on the New York Thruway since the first section was opened to toll traffic last June 24.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Nov. 2 -- The Peiping radio said this morning that Chinese Communist planes "heavily bombed" the Nationalist-held Tachen Islands [cross on map] off the Chekiang coast at 11 A. M. yesterday.

The men's clothing industry operated at 70 per cent of capacity in the first nine months of this year, a decline of 15 per cent from the rate in the 1953 period, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A.

OTTAWA, Nov. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Two of Canada's oldest chartered banks, the Dominion and the Toronto, today received Government permission to submit an amalgamation agreement to shareholders next month.

The top men of the Kremlin hierarchy like to think in grand terms of enormous projects involving hundreds of thousands or millions of people. Every now and then a debacle interrupts this lofty dreaming and then bitter charges of "gigantomania" fill the Moscow air.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Heinz L. Krekeler, West German Ambassador, said today that seven prominent business men and educators in the United States had agreed to sponsor a German institute in this country to foster cultural relations between the two nations.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- Dr. Louis Bauman of 17 Linwood Road, a specialist in internal medicine with offices at Harkness Pavilion, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, New York, died here today in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 74 years old.

The Ukrainian Academy of Arts and Sciences in the United States sincerely welcomes the articles and editorials concerning Ukrainian life and culture which have appeared in The New York Times. However, there are certain inaccuracies in the article, "Twenty of Kiev's Churches Found Open," by Clifton Daniel in your Oct. 19 issue.

NEWARK, Nov. 1 -- Former Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. urged New Jersey Republicans tonight to write in his name on their ballots tomorrow instead of voting for Clifford P. Case, the party nominee for United States Senator.

Tung-Sol Electric, Inc., filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington a registration statement covering a proposed issue of 100,000 shares of convertible preferred stock of $50 par value.

After a brief visit to Communist China, where an ancient civilization based on ethical precepts is being scrambled with an outdated and amoral aberration from the West, Prime Minister Nehru of India emphasizes the truism that the "Chinese people" want peace.

The famed Baku oil region, the Soviet Union's chief petroleum source for almost a century, is showing sights of exhaustion. Pravda has revealed that alarm over these signs has resulted in a major purge of economic officials in charge of the area.

Miss Emma Valentine, born in New York a hundred years ago, celebrated the turn of her own century yesterday by eating two portions of birthday cake and coffee ice cream. The second helping was an indulgence allowed in honor of the day.

THE waterfowl season will open at noon tomorrow in Long Island and Connecticut, and although black ducks are reported to be quite plentiful, the scaup, which provide most of the shooting in both areas, have not yet arrived in real numbers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Industrial strikes dropped to a postwar low during the first nine months of this year, the Labor Department reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Philip Young, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, said today that the commission would move against any violations of the Civil Service laws.

A jury of eight women and four men sitting before Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Cox returned a verdict of $563,000 in a negligence case last Saturday night in favor of eleven tenants of the seventy-two-year-old, twelve-story building at 47 West Street.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 1 -- Armed troops were dispatched from here to the dark Mazandaran jungles bordering the Caspian Sea today as a ground search was intensified for Prince Ali Riza, younger brother of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlavi and heir presumptive to the Iranian throne.

HONG KONG, Nov. 1 -- An answer to the question of how soon the Peiping Government intends to collectivize the land in Chins has been given by Teng Tzu-hui, head of the Chinese Communist party's Rural Work Department.

There's a plan afoot to bring back old-time radio. Following the pattern of other radio stars, Bing Crosby has discarded his half-hour weekly show and will resume shortly with a quarter-hour series five evenings each week.
The Football Writers Association of New York will honor Lou Little, Columbia coach, with a special award in recognition of his twenty-five-year tenure on Morningside Heights.

DENVER, Nov. 1 -- The Denver Post announced today it would offer a prize of $10,000 for the best original, romantic play on the first discovery of gold in Colorado in 1858. The play will be produced at the Central City Festival of 1958 marking the found

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Mike Turnesa of Knollwood and Mike Fetchick, of the Mahopac Country Club scored a best-ball of 32, 33 -- 65 at the Vernon Hills Country Club today to win the Westchester pro-pro championship, final event of the Westchester P.G.A. tournament season.
Price increases and decreases on 1955 Chevrolet and Pontiac cars to be sold in this city were reported by dealers yesterday.
U.C.L.A. shot into the No. 1 place yesterday and became the third leader in three weeks in the Associated Press football poll.

HONG KONG, Nov. 1 -- After rechecking last year's census the National Bureau of Statistics in Peiping declared today mainland China's population, largest in the world, was 582,603,417, as of June 30, 1953.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 1 -- The British Central Africa Federation is in a turmoil over the multi-racial experiments that have been vogue in British Africa in recent years.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Louis E. Wolfson, Jacksonville, Fla., financier and promoter, moved today to force Montgomery Ward Co. to change its system for the election of its board of directors.
MILL NECK, L.I., Nov. 1 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney won the sweepstakes award today in the fiftieth anniversary fall flower show of the North Shore Horticultural Society.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves reported today the sale of 10,418 season tickets for 1955, a new high in advance for the National League's top drawing club the past two years.
Stony Wold (N.Y.) Sanatorium will be the beneficiary of the Tip Top Ball to be given Friday in the St. Regis Roof by its Auxiliary Number Five.
DENVER, Nov. 1 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon gave out a prepared statement today taxing the Democrats with using "the Big Lie technique" as their major strategy.

The President of Liberia has discovered that protocol and politics do mix -- especially in an election week. In view of that, a perplexed President William V.S. Tubman canceled "controversial" trips to Hyde Park and Harlem yesterday. Instead he toured Rockefeller Center.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Ralph Dupas, fourth ranking lightweight contender, tonight scored a technical knockout over Carlos Chavez of Los Angeles, in 1:44 of the seventh round of a scheduled ten-round fight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Prof. Walter Hallstein, West German Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, said today that "we certainly have to talk to Russia" about the recent Paris conference.
William H. Sparr Jr. has been placed in charge of the steel section of the nickel sales department of the International Nickel Company, Inc.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and subsidiaries today reported consolidated earnings of $81,444,000 for the first nine months of 1954, as compared with $88,634,000 for the similar period of 1953, a decrease of 8.1 per cent.

The voters of New York State can take comfort from one constructive area of agreement between the major candidates for Governor. Senator Ives and Mr. Harriman both promise their support, though in differing ways, to the advancement of Permanent Personal Registration.
New York is scheduled to welcome today a distinguished guest, Prime Minister Yoshida of Japan. We are confident that his trip will be of benefit to our country and to his.

On Sunday Dr. Ali Amini, Iranian Finance Minister, went aboard the tanker British Advocate at Abadan and handed sailing papers to Skipper F.W. Mann. A few minutes later the ship cast off her lines and started for Trincomalee, Ceylon, with 11,500 tons of fuel oil.
If women have equal rights they should take equal responsibilities, according to a present-day champion of women's suffrage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today approved a settlement under which Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, Houston, Tex., will withdraw a proposed $5,657,662 annual wholesale natural gas rate increase and cut rates $433,973 a year effective as of Sept. 1.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 1 -- The Commander in Chief of Sweden's armed forces believes that an isolated war against this country is unlikely.

HAVANA, Nov. 1 -- The Cuban people voted today in an atmosphere of unexpected calmness after the turbulent events of the last few days, which had left them with only one Presi dential candidate, Gen. Fulgencio Batista.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Miss Patricia Lee McGlohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robin Hollie McGlohn of Coral Gables, Fla., and Balem, Para, Brazil, was married here this afternoon to James Stotter 2d, son of Raymond Harold Stotter of Los Angeles, formerly of New York and Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Stotter.

Basketball practice got under way at five local colleges yesterday. With the official opening games about a month away, returning letter men and hopeful candidates for varsity positions worked out at C.C.N.Y., Columbia, Fordham, Manhattan and N.Y.U.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The United States urged today that in any future aggression United Nations members aid countries wanting to provide troops but unable to equip them.
MONTREAL, Nov. 1 -- Montreal's seven large English-management department stores remained open today despite a municipal law ordering them to close on Roman Catholic feast days.

NEWARK, Nov. 1 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, tired but confident, faced the television cameras for more than three hours here tonight. As the Democratic candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey made his final plea for votes, party leaders jubilantly predicted his election by an overwhelming plurality.

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that "we do not understand" the statement by Vice President Richard M. Nixon on the question of a half-hour of free radio and television time that he had requested.

Brisk business activity last month showed that the September pick-up was more than a "flash in the pan," according to the monthly report of the National Association of Purchasing Agents' business survey committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The United States Information Agency resorted today to extraordinary measures to fill 109 vacant jobs in its overseas staff, or more than 10 per cent of the authorized staff of 964.
The nation's steel-makers scheduled operations this week at the highest level of the year to date -- 75.7 per cent of theoretical capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday.
Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Continued debate on report of Collective Measures Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- If the Democrats shall carry Congress tomorrow in such fashion that practical politicians in both major parties will construe the result as an outright defeat for the Administration and the politicians in Congress will trim their sails for 1956 to the wind of 1954, what course will President Eisenhower adopt to take the partisan Republican label from the remainder of his legislative program?

PLANDOME, L.I., Nov. 1 -- The team of Frank Slate, Camden, and Fred Gronauer, Sands Point, shaved six strokes from par with a 66 today to win the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro tournament at the Plandome Golf Club.

Queen Mother Elizabeth of Great Britain visited a day care center in Manhattan yesterday, but the children, 3 to 5 years old, were too young, or too American, to be impressed at having a royal personage in their midst.

Deeper understanding of the nature of the mysterious forces that hold atoms together will await the collection of a great deal of new information about the action of cosmic rays on particles in the earth's upper atmosphere, Professor Werner Heisenberg reported yesterday.

Teachers in the health service fields of medicine, dentistry, optometry, podiatry and allied professions have undoubtedly felt elated, as I did, in reading your timely editorial of Oct. 22 "Wilson Fellowships." Well-meaning citizens, concerned with an adequate supply of qualified teachers in higher education at all times, are indeed in accord with you on the need for alerting the general public to the teacher-training problem.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 1 -- Turkey made today, one of her strongest bids in recent years for the support of Egypt and other Arab states in the creation of an effective Middle East defense system.
Strength for steels and a scattered list of specialties in the late hours gave the last pre-election stock market a good gain yesterday.

U.C.L.A., needing only two victories for a perfect season, widened its lead over Ohio State yesterday in the United Press college football ratings, while Mississippi and Miami (Fla.) advanced to the top ten.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. today declared a regular quarterly dividend of 60 cents a share and an extra of the same amount, payable Jan. 3 to holders of record Nov. 26.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Masaka, a 9-year-old stakes-winning daughter of Nearco, sold tonight for $105,000, the highest price ever paid for a thoroughbred broodmare at an American auction.

I would like to express my appreciation of your editorial of Oct. 25 concerning my nomination by the President to the Atomic Energy Commission. This editorial is the most heartening welcome any nonpolitical person may hope for at his first contact with public life.
College football enters upon the last month of the season offering a program loaded with attractive games.
A manufacturer of gold watch cases and his company were found guilty yesterday by a Federal Court jury of filtering $230,000 in gold into the black market.

Election day is a regular and pointed reminder of the individual's responsibility of citi zenship. As regularly as election day, for the last seventy-five years the annual United Hospital Fund appeal has been an other reminder of a citizen's obligations.

"The Last Time I Saw Paris," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's adaptation in Technicolor of the F. Scott Fitzgerald story, "Babylon Revisited," has been booked into the Capitol, where it will have its premiere on Thursday night, Nov. 18.

October donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 12,126 pints of blood. Last Friday 606 pints were collected, including 166 at St. John's University in Brooklyn, 124 at the General Aniline and Film Corporation, 435 Hudson Street, and 119 at the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, East Eighty-thrd Street and Ditmas Avenue.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 1 -- Four Hoboken police officers and two former city officials, under indictment for more than eight years on charges of conspiracy to oppress eighteen members of the city's police force, went on trial in Hudson County Court today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 -- The state moved today to remove one juror from a full panel of fourteen already sworn for the trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard for the murder of his wife.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Eisenhower made a final, dispassionate appeal to the people of the United States tonight to vote in tomorrow's Congressional election.
The Master Singers, an a cappella chorus of twenty voices, made their debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening under the direction of Joseph Liebling.

Two hundred fifty delegates of the independent International Longshoremen's Association joined in a pledge yesterday to close all Atlantic, South Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports if one of the ports was forced to strike as the result of failure of current contract negotiations.
Net income of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were 10 per cent below results achieved in the corresponding period of 1953, it was announced yesterday.

Chinese military, or para-military, activity in several areas of Asia tends to refute Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's optimism, upon his return from a visit to Peiping, about Communist China's peaceful intentions.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, Nov. 1 (AP) -- United States Army wives unable to adjust themselves to life overseas can return home now at Government expense.

Through the development of new foreign sources of iron ore and processes for beneficiating low-grade domestic ores, American industry "has faced and is overcoming" the serious problem created by the depletion of high-quality ores in this country, Felix E. Wormser, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, said here yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The favored United States team and Brazil each scored a lopsided victory tonight to remain undefeated and tied for first place in the round-robin final round of the world amateur basketball championships.
Averell Harriman broke tradition for wind-ups of Governorship campaigns yesterday with a 700-mile air tour to get in his last licks upstate against Republican "smears" and "falsehoods."

A new one-story building at 41-39 Twenty-fourth Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Evans Color Laboratories, Inc., from Alfred R. Puccinelli. The Greiner-Maltz Company and Abbott Adams, Inc., were co-brokers in the transaction. The lessee specializes in color photography for the advertising trade.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- The British press, in stories from its correspondents in Washington, switched today from predictions of a Democratic sweep to cautious hedging on tomorrow's balloting in the United States.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The "vast outpouring of American assets to aid the world" is about at an end, Clarence B. Randall, chairman of the board of the Inland Steel Company, and former chairman of the Federal Commission on Foreign Economic Policy, declared here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Federal Extension Service, after forty years of service, plans to step up its counseling of young fathers and their wives.

The polls in New York State will be open from 6 A.M. to 7 P.M. today, with all persons in line at the closing hour entitled to cast ballots. Persons who normally work on Election Day during the time the 10,436 polling places are open are legally entitled to two hours off to vote.

The morning mail that arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday was unusually glamorous, even for that hostelry. It brought the return of a $29,000 diamond and platinum clip, from an anonymous finder who seems to have a charitable turn of mind.
Churches that over-emphasize their "liberalism" in an effort to attract university students were criticized yesterday by Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The New Jersey Highway Authority today announced it would sell, on Nov. 16, $20,000,000 of bonds, secured solely by tolls on the Garden State Parkway.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The head of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency said today that the agency lacked funds to carry out its 1954 operations or to make a start on next year's program.

Visitors to tse thirty-first annual Women's International Exposition will find everything on display from champion cats to a collection of hand-made quilts. The show opened yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain was the guest of honor last night at the Commonwealth Ball given in the Seventh Regiment Armory by the Associated Commonwealth Societies.

Mayor Wagner extended the city's formal welcome to the personnel of five international horse show jumping teams at City Hall yesterday. While the ceremony was in progress and long after it, horse vans, some of them the size of freight cars, were commonplace in the vicinity of Madison Square Garden.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- President Eisenhower is prepared to ask Congress to authorize a United States contribution to the United Nations Technical Assistance Program for 1955.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP) -- "The largest November output in all automotive history (509,000) is being programmed by passenger car builders as most of them roll into high gear on '55 model production," Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
DENVER, Nov. 1 -- Following is the text of a statement issued today to The New York Times by Vice President Richard M. Nixon:
MARION, S.C., Nov. 1 (UP) -- Salvagers hauled a ghost of the Old South from its watery grave today. It had been hidden for almost ninety years.

ALEC GUINNESS adds another cordial character to the long list of those he has contrived with his new British film, "The Detective," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts. This time his clever creation is G.K. Chesterton's Father Brown, the English priest and amateur detective, saver of souls and preventer of crime.

Reports from Washington and the domestic and foreign markets seem to indicate some easing in the problem of food surpluses that has perplexed Federal officials. Hard dollars are beginning to appear for purchases from abroad of grains from the bulging bins of the United States.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Scattered gains offset by several sharp losses in late dealings among the leading industrials reflected the stock market's reaction to the fresh dock labor dispute today.
Six social workers who studied care of the aged in Europe last summer related their impressions for 150 fellow-workers yesterday afternoon.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Eight veterans of the 1952 Olympics and other international matches and five newcomers were named today to represent the United States in the world rifle and pistol championships at Caracas, Venezuela, Nov. 16-27.

Patrolmen Thomas Sherlock and Joseph Kirkpatrick of the Bathgate Avenue Station, the Bronx, collapsed early yesterday after carrying three children to safety from a smoke-filled apartment house at 3810 Third Avenue in that borough.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Jewish welfare leaders reported today substantial economic and social progress among Jews in Israel and Moslem countries. They added, however, that this progress had been offset by a feeling of insecurity over what is felt to be a danger from surrounding Arab populaces.

BOB CHRISTENBERRY, the chairman of the boxing commission, has just offered a new plan for scoring prize fights. But whether or not it ever gets to first base depends, oddly enough, on who wins today's Gubernatorial election. If Averell Harriman moves into Albany, Christenberry moves out of the chairmanship in favor of a deserving Democrat.
Forty-five million citizens are expected to go to the polls today in mid-term elections that will determine the control of Congress for the next two years.
The next few weeks will see a giant splurge of automotive advertising. Newspapers, magazines, radio and television will be carrying appeals as the various manufacturers show their 1955 models.

Senator Irving M. Ives declared last night that the voters in today's election had the choice between "good, liberal, forward-looking government for the next four years" or "the historic evils of Tammany Hall."
The American whalemeat season is drawing to a close for the year.
FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 1 -- Exploratory dives to wrecked ships in the Atlantic Ocean along the South Shore of Long Island are being conducted from here by a group of underwater enthusiasts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Negro physicians now can become members of the Medical Society of Virginia. The House of Delegates, the society's governing body, voted last night to admit Negroes to membership.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Grain futures as well as soybeans showed considerable strength today, but there was also free profit taking at times. Corn was especially strong as shorts covered. There was colder weather with snow over much of the belt.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Poland opposed today a move in the General Assembly's Special Political Committee for the prompt admission of Laos and Cambodia to the United Nations.
New York City's department stores leaped various hurdles in October to come up with creditable sales figures, according to a survey by The New York Times.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 -- Property exceeding $1,000,000 in value was left to the immediate members of his family by Charles P. Skouras, Greek-born theatre magnate. The will was filed for probate today in the Superior Court.
LONDON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Bob Hope topped the American stars in the Royal Command variety performance tonight before Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh.

A total of 18,957 registered voters whose qualifications appear doubtful will be challenged to prove their right to vote if they appear at the polls today in the city and the suburban counties of Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk.

Martha Stone, described as the fugitive underground leader of the Communist party in New Jersey, was picked up yesterday in a Bronx restaurant by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. She was charged with membership in an organization advocating violent overthrow of the Government.
HART'S LOCATION, N.H., Tuesday, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Democratic candidates led today as the ten registered voters in this tiny mountain village completed balloting shortly after midnight.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 1 -- A strike of 5,000 production workers of the Singer Manufacturing Company here got under way at midnight. The workers, members of Local 461 of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O., voted this afternoon to go out tomorrow unless the company agreed overnight to their bid for a 10-cent-an-hour increase and improved pension rights.

The City of New York made disbursements yesterday for redemption of debt and payment of interest amounting to $109,283,677. Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said it was one of the largest operations in the financial history of the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that four railroads operating in northern New Jersey should be permitted to increase their monthly commutation rates for intrastate travelers by about $1.50.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Casting players in movies is becoming a problem of increasing concern to producers. Hollywood is probably the largest concentration of acting talent in the world, but when it comes to the point of selecting the right performer for a particular role there is a definite scarcity of such individuals.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 -- With a backlog of 90,000 advance orders, Cadillac expects to sell 150,000 of its 1955 cars, James M. Roche, general manager, said today. This will be a record output, he added. The 1954 model sales total was 123,600, also a record.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UP) -- One atomic scientist called on the United States and Russia today to halt hydrogen bomb tests and another said the United States should hold such tests within its continental boundaries.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday. Active months moved 7 points higher to 1 point lower than on last Friday.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Nationalist terrorism suddenly spilled over into Algeria last night from the adjoining French protectorates of Tunisia and Morocco.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The 44,000 dock workers whose strike tied up operations in eight British ports reported back this morning, but within an hour a fresh dispute was threatening to immobilize the Port of London again.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has sent congratulations to the Rev. Adelhelm Hess, Roman Catholic priest at Conception, Mo., on sixty years of "unselfish, devoted service to our country" as a volunteer weather observer.
New linens to brighten holiday tables and kitchens are appearing in many shops as the Christman season approaches.
The International Longshoremen's Association here is discussing retaliatory action against steamship company members of the Philadelphia Marine Trade Association for their "lockout" of longshoremen.

The Gibbs Corporation, a shipbuilding company in Jacksonville, Fla., has won the first annual advertising award of the American Merchant Marine Institute, according to an announcement yesterday by Walter E. Maloney, president of the institute.
PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Reinforcements from France were rushed today into mountainous regions of eastern Algeria to restore calm shattered yesterday by terrorist uprisings that cost nine lives.
Mickey Mantle, who has been the Yankees' "star of the future" these past four years but who has yet to report for spring training in one piece, may make it in 1955.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Allie Reynolds, the New York Yankee pitcher, who ripped a 16-stitch cut in the index finger of his pitching hand last week, will "have more of an idea" tomorrow whether the injury will affect his pitching.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- News of the elections went to all corners of the globe tonight, courtesy of the United States Information Agency.
High winds and intermittent heavy rains harassed voters in the city and its environs yesterday as they went to the polls.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- Harrison E. Salisbury's recent series of dispatches about the Soviet Union in The New York Times, were denounced today by News, monthly English - language review published in Moscow, as containing a "multitude of untruths."
Averell Harriman appears to have been elected the first Democratic Governor of New York since Thomas E. Dewey broke the Smith-Roosevelt Lehman succession twelve years ago.
REHOVOT, Israel, Nov. 2 -- Chaim Weizmann, the chemist who was Israel's first President, was extolled today at a memorial service as continuing to guide the development of the country.

CHERRYFIELD, Me., Nov. 2 -- This may not have been the worst opening day, weatherwise, in the history of Washington County, but the oldest deer hunter residing here was unable to remember an opening that was as wet.

The regional blood program of the American Red Cross announced yesterday that 425 pints of blood were received on Monday. Of this amount, 217 were donated by officers and crew members of the U. S. S. Ticonderoga at the Naval Shipyard in Bayonne, N. J.
Work on a $48,000,000 canal project that will enable deep-sea shipping to enter Lake Maracaibo in Venezuela from the Caribbean is progressing on schedule.

IRVINGTON, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Proposed charter changes were rejected today in three of four Essex County municipal elections. In Irvington, a proposal for a Mayor and five-member Council to replace the present Town Commission was defeated by a two-to-one vote.

A heavy Democratic-Liberal vote in the city yesterday gave Adrian P. Burke, New York City Corporation Counsel, a lead of 125,025 votes in the state-wide contest for associate judge of the Court of Appeals. But 1,004 of the state's 10,436 districts still missing were, early this morning, all of them upstate.
BOSTON, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall and Gov. Christian A. Herter, both Republicans, rallied to gain leads early today in the Massachusetts election.
A great national struggle for control of the Senate, one of the closest in the history of the United States, remained undecided early today.
DES MOINES, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Iowa's top-ranking elective Democrat, Senator Guy M. Gillette, failed in a bid for a third term in yesterday's general election.
MANCHESTER, N. H., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- New Hampshire Republicans elected two United States Senators, two national House members and a Governor yesterday.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion of the Montreal Canadiens is determined to win the National Hockey League scoring title this season -- even if he has to beat his boyhood idol to do it.

The New York Teachers Guild has on various occasions taken the welcome opportunity to commend The New York Times for its public-spirited support of public education. In particular, your stand on behalf of higher salaries for teachers and for school building construction has been enlightened and forthright.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 2 -- Henry F. Holland, Assistant Secretary of State for Latin American Affairs, predicted today that the outcome of the United States elections would have no effect on United States and Latin-America relations.

BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Maryland appeared certain early today to re-elect Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin in his bid to become the State's first two-term Republican Governor. Governor McKeldin took an early lead over Dr. Harry C. Byrd, Democrat, who retired as University of Maryland president last January to run for office.

Magazine distribution is approaching what Bernard P. Gallagher, consultant, calls a "revolution." In his monthly letter to publishing executives he says that the publishers of the big popular magazines are considering the formation of their own distributing, wholesaling and servicing organization, or, as an alternative, buying out and changing the functions of the American News Company.
Representative Charles R. Howell, on the basis of unofficial and incomplete returns, appeared early today to have been elected United States Senator from New Jersey.

Alben W. Barkley proved his vigor and his toughness during the campaign; now he has proved once again -- if proof was necessary -- that he still has irresistible voting appeal. Any Senatorial candidate on the Democratic ticket in the Blue Grass State has an enormous advantage because Kentucky is, of course, normally Democratic.
Averell Harriman appeared early this morning to have won election as Governor in the closest electoral contest New York State has had in modern election history.

New Yorkers soon may be able to evaluate accurately what the local economy gained in direct and indirect income from the handling and processing of the 140,000,000 tons of foreign and domestic maritime commerce here last year.

For the first time in many seasons, fashion interest in the evening wrap or theatre coat is being revived. Easily explaining this new-found interest is the fresh styling and imaginative handling that have gone into new designs.

The harsh, head-spinning interchange between auctioneer and bidders at the fruit auction conducted downtown by the Brown Seccomb Company is largely unintelligible to outsiders. The noise would have meant little to us when we visited there recently if we had not been told beforehand that some of the first of this season's chestnuts from Italy were being sold.

Sari Biro, who has not appeared here since the fall of 1949 when she undertook the formidable task of playing nine piano concertos in a series of three orchestral concerts, returned last night to Carnegie Hall. This time, though, the Hungarian-born pianist confined her efforts to a standard recital of conventional dimensions.

Many parties will be given at the anniversary cocktail dance for the benefit of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association to be held tomorrow afternoon in the St. Regis Roof. The occasion will mark the eighty-first anniversary of the founding of the association, which maintains clinics in three of the city's neediest districts, that give free care annually to more than five thousand infants and children of pre-school age.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota and chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, agreed today to hold hearings into Government charges that Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl was biased in favor of Owen Lattimore, Far East expert.
The taste of victory turned to dust in the mouth of New York State Democrats last night.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Senator Matthew M. Neely, Democrat, who made President Eisenhower a campaign issue by calling him the "worst President in United States history," won early today the fifth Senate term of his fifteen-year political career with a steadily increasing majority over Republican Thomas B. Sweeney.
The city is to spend $21,000 to become a patron of the musical arts and at the same time encourage college students here to love music.

DENVER, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Lieut. Gov. Gordon Allott, the Republican Senatorial candidate, scored a surprise victory last night over John Carroll, the Democrat who had been favored to succeed Senator Edwin C. Johnson.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The "relentless, unscrupulous" left-wing People's Progressive party of British Guiana cannot be trusted with a democratic Constitution, the British Government has decided. As a result, tile House of Commons was told today, the South American colony will "mark time" without renewed self-government for an indefinite period.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- A new "entente cordiale" in fashion between France and Britain has been made official with the announcement that dates for the semi-annual style shows in London and Paris will no longer clash.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The new strike of London dock workers was settled today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Senator Estes Kefauver and Gov. Frank G. Clement, both Democrats, won re-election by overwhelming majorities in Tennessee today from an apathetic electorate voting in subfreezing temperatures and snow flurries.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 2 -- Edward P. Lawson arrived here today to become United States Ambassador to Israel in succession to Monnett B. Davis, who died at his post in Tel Aviv last Christmas Eve.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 2 -- The powerful Nassau County Republican party, which had promised a plurality of 100,000 votes for the state ticket, today gave Senator Irving M. Ives a plurality of 103,125 over his Democratic opponent, Averell Harriman, in the race for Governor.

ATLANTA, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (UP) -- A "private school" plan backed by Gov. Herman Talmadge and Gov.-elect Marvin Griffin met vigorous resistance among Georgia voters in yesterday's general election, and its fate remained in doubt pending final returns.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- United Nations members voted, 50 to 5, today over Soviet opposition, to continue the life of the Collective Measures Committee.
NINE painters, exhibiting two pictures apiece, are represented in this year's Emily Lowe Award Competition whose winning entries are now being shown at the Eggleston Galleries.

Now is the time for the storm windows, and it is a very depressing time indeed. Even the sight of them is deplorable, for they spell out the winter in letters no one can fail to see. So long as they lean against the storeroom wall, the season is summer.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Convair convertiplane, built for the Navy, made its first level flight successfully today, its manufacturers announced.

RALEIGH, N. C., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- W. Kerr Scott defeated Paul C. West, Republican, by a convincing margin in the only contested race for a Senate seat in North Carolina yesterday. The victory was expected.

THE most miserable man in America three Saturdays ago was Red Sanders, the coach at U. C. L. A. His team had just beaten Stanford, 72 to 0, and the Palo Alto Indians are coached by Red's close friend, Chuck Taylor.

Four years ago today, under the impact of Communist aggression in Korea, the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted a "Uniting for Peace" resolution which invoked the reserve powers of the Charter. The purpose of this action was to enable the United Nations to take collective military action against aggression even if the Security Council should be paralyzed by Soviet vetoes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 2 -- Finance Minister Eugenio Gudin has lost ground in his fight to get Brazil's finances and general economy on to a sounder basis. Such powerful opponents have lined up against him that there are reports he may be forced out of the Cabinet.
BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- Research will be the new goal of the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults which opened its thirty-first annual convention today with more than 1,000 delegates on hand.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 2 (AP) -- C. V. Whitney's Fly Wheel took command at the head of the stretch and drew away under strong urging by Sam Boulmetis to win the $25,000 added Quaker City Handicap at Garden State Park today.
The state propositions calling for $550,000,000 in new borrowings for slum clearance, housing and mental hospitals were approved by substantial margins yesterday.
Senator Irving M. Ives conceded defeat at 10:16 o'clock last night after mulling over the returns in a conference with Governor Dewey.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- In clear weather with temperatures ranging up to 60 degrees, Wyoming voters went to the polls yesterday to elect a Senator, a Representative to Congress and a Governor and all indications pointed to a record number of votes for an off-year election.

The autobiography of the late Alfred Duff Cooper, Viscount Norwich, is scheduled for publication Dec. 2 by Dutton under the title "Old Men Forget." In it the author tells of his career as a British civil servant and of his marriage to Diana Manners.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The stock markets here were unsettled today and despite a steadier tendency toward the close prices showed more losses than gains. Exceptionally, British Government funds were consistently firm and rose slightly.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Joseph B. Johnson, Republican retired industrialist, was elected Governor of Vermont in a tight race with E. Frank Branon, prominent dairy farmer, unofficial complete returns showed early today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Howard Pyle, Republican, seeking re-election to his third term as Governor for Arizona, and the Democratic nominee, Ernest W. McFarland, were in a neck-and-neck race today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A "task force" which has been studying the effects of the growing volume of iron and steel scrap exports this year will make its recommendations to the Department of Commerce here on Thursday.

Away much too long to suit their legion of fans, America's leading, acting couple, Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, will return at 8 o'clock tonight in Noel Coward's romantic comedy "Quadrille" at the Coronet.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said early today that some of the Republican candidates he figured would run close races against Democrats "aren't doing so well, and some are losing."

The American Labor party lost last night its fight for life as a legal party. Virtually complete figures indicated that the eighteen-year-old party had fallen more than 5,000 votes short of the 50,000 required to insure it a place on the ballot in future elections.

CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 2 -- Friendship between India and China is "essential for the peace and progress of Asia," Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today in his first public utterances on Indian soil upon his return from Communist China.

Cuba has just gone through one of the strangest and most potentially dangerous elections in her history. Americans, who finished their own electoral battle yesterday, have fortunately never seen anything like it. In the end, the result was foregone since Ramon Grau San Martin, only opposition candidate, withdrew at the last moment and Gen. Fulgencio Batista ran alone.
Many television and radio networks and stations dropped their regular program schedules last night to inform viewers and listeners of election returns as rapidly as they were compiled.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Eliahu Elath, Israeli Ambassador to Britain, cautioned the West tonight against supplying arms to Arab Countries and risking an arms race in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The United States Court of Claims held unanimously today that a twenty-two-year-old law pertaining to dual compensation did not apply to retired Army and Air Force Reserve officers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Arnold Johnson, Chicago financier, said today he would return to Philadelphia tomorrow to get "right back in the swing" on his effort to purchase the Athletics for Kansas City.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Medical Society of Virginia opened the way today for Negro physicians to become members.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Alben W. Barkley, former Democratic Vice President, unseated Republican Senator John Sherman Cooper on the basis of nearly completed returns in yesterday's general election.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Quarterback Leo McKenna dressed for a Dartmouth practice session today for the first time since he suffered a broken wristbone three weeks ago. Coach Tuss McLaughry said a decision would be made later in the week whether McKenna would be able to play Saturday.
MONTREAL, Oct. 31 -- Canada has started a fifty-year program of development and defense of her vast Arctic seas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Willie Troy, Washington middleweight, scored a technical knockout over Tommy Thompson, Quantico, Va., light heavyweight, in the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round bout tonight.

With the exception of a few contests, rain caused the postponement or cancellation of the scholastic football schedule in the metropolitan area yesterday. Many of the games had been put off from last Saturday for the same reason.
Army's attack, one of the most effective in the history of major-college football statistics, runs into the nation's most effective defensive line at the Yale Bowl on Saturday.
CHICAGO, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas was elected to a second term yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 -- Negotiators for the Philadelphia Marine Trade Association and the International Longshoremen's Association met today with Federal Mediator John R. Murry in an effort to end the five-day shutdown of dry cargo handling in this port.
The Election Frauds Bureau of the State Attorney General's Office reported two arrests in the city yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- An economic program keyed to make 1955 match or exceed 1953, the country's record year of business activity, has been framed by the White House.

HARTFORD, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff, Hartford Democrat, was elected Governor of Connecticut last night, defeating Gov. John Davis Lodge, Republican, by an unofficial margin of 2,916 out of a total of more than 924,000 votes.
MONTREAL, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Stock market prices strengthened irregularly in dull trading here today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican Majority Leader in the House in the Eighty-third Congress, was re-elected for his eleventh term yesterday. He easily defeated his Democratic opponent, James H. Berg, in Indiana's Second Congressional District.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The Middle East is the only area of particular importance where a serious effort to modify United States foreign policy may be made after today's elections; that is to say, should the Democrats succeed in regaining control of Congress.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- John Clunies Ross, 25-year-old "white king" of the Cocos-Keeling Islands, will retain his rights when Britain hands over the islands to Australian administration.
PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The French Cabinet decided today to ask Parliament to put off most major actions until Premier Pierre Mendes-France had returned from the United States toward the end of the month.
WILMINGTON, Del., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Senator J. Allen Frear Jr. led the Democratic state ticket to victory last night in Delaware with a 20,680 majority over Herbert B. Warburton, Republican.

In a pink and silver decor last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astroia, the Seven Crown Ball was held for the benefit of the Mental Health Division of the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Queen Mother Elizabeth of Great Britain had a typically American Thanksgiving dinner at noon yesterday at the home of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at Hyde Park, N. Y.
HONG KONG, Nov. 2 -- According to the Peiping radio, Chinese Communist gunboats shelled Paichuan Island, off the Fukien coast, at 9 o'clock last night.

Open house will be held on Monday by the Humane Society of New York at its renovated headquarters at 313 East Fifty-eighth Street. Visitors will tour the headquarters as part of the society's fiftieth anniversary appeal for the support of its hospital and clinic for animals.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 2 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge and Representative Albert P. Morano, both Republicans, carried Fairfield County today, as predicted. The winning margin for Mr. Lodge, however, was reduced to the critical point.

TOPEKA, Kan., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Kansas voters in President Eisenhowers boyhood home state elected Republicans yesterday to the Senate, five of six House seats and the Governorship. In the sixth House race, the Republican incumbent held a slight majority.
A surprising number of shoppers braved yesterday's cold rain to take advantage of special Election Day offerings by New York City's department stores.

RICHMOND, Va., Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Republicans held fast to two of the Virginia Congressional districts captured in 1952 but apparently dropped the third one -- the Ninth -- to the Democrats in yesterday's election.
Cesare Valletti, Metropolitan Opera tenor, made a distinguished recital debut last evening at Town Hall.
