WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Total consumer installment credit rose to $21,340,000,000 in September for the sixth consecutive month of increase, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Alec Guinness' next picture, to be made in England for release by Columbia, will be "The Prisoner." Previously the star was to have appeared in "Madame, Will You Walk," but this has been postponed indefinitely.
OTTAWA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics today discontinued operations in Ottawa, the base for their International League farm club.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 2 (UP) -- A special committee of the National Constituent Assembly proposed today that Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas be proclaimed Guatemala's constitutional president Saturday, for a five-year term. Prompt approval by the full assembly appeared assured.
The A. D. Juilliard division of United Merchants and Manufacturers will bring the Juilliard name back to prominence in the woolen and worsted fabric field, according to its sales officers.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- Mayor Anthony J. Celebrezze rebuked Police Chief Frank W. Story today for "darned poor police work" in allowing a juror with a previous conviction for a sex offense to be impaneled for the murder trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard.
Democrats gained probable control of the House of Representatives yesterday in the face of unexpectedly strong Republican resistance.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 2 -- Prince Ali Riza, 32-year-old heir presumptive to the Iranian throne, was found dead early today near the wreckage of a small plane in a ravine in the Elburz Mountains. The bodies of two others in the plane with him also were found.
President William V. S. Tubman of Liberia rounded out his New York City visit yesterday with a rainy inspection cruise in the harbor. He entrained at night for a week's tour of the South.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Rain and raw winds swept the Laurel race course today, promising a soft grass course for the seven American and foreign horses that will compete in the third running of the $65,000 Washington, D. C., International race tomorrow.
No trace was found yesterday of the Navy Super-Constellation that disappeared early Sunday on a trans-Atlantic flight with forty-two persons aboard.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that an "undue number" of atomic and hydrogen bomb explosions might have serious effects on the earth's atmosphere for about 5,000 years.

BOISE Idaho, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Senator Henry C. Dworshak, Republican incumbent, early today held a growing lead over former Senator Glen H. Taylor, who sought to make a comeback in yesterday's election.

The month just ended brought further evidence of business pick-up and strengthened confidence, with production rising a little and industrial buying more active, according to the National City Bank of New York's monthly letter on business conditions.
The annual series of opera broadcasts from the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House will begin Dec. 4 at 2 P. M. over the A. B. C. radio network.
AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 1 -- Jordan asked Britain, France and the United States today to stop diversion of the waters of the river Jordan by Israel.
SEATTLE, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- First scattered returns last night in Washington gave a Democrat slim lead for a seat in the House of Representatives now held by a Republican.
Your editorial "Heat Without Light" was a clear and incisive statement deserving the highest commendation.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson returned home from his campaign tour today and cast his ballot at the little village of Half Day, Ill., near his suburban farm home.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- An alert Democratic organization, with strong labor and independent voter support, yesterday won the Governorship of Pennsylvania for the first time in twenty years.

President Eisenhower and Chancellor Adenauer jointly declared on Oct. 28 that they view as "legitimate" the demand of the German people for reunification in freedom; that this aim "shall be achieved only by peaceful means"; and that "continued efforts toward this goal" must and will be made by the Federal Republic of Germany and the three Western occupying powers.
MADISON, Wis., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Gov. Walter J. Kohler, Republican, increased his lead in early returns in Wisconsin over his Democratic opponent, William Proxmire.

A washday revolution may be just around the corner for the Soviet housewife. If the Government agency involved keeps its promise, Mrs. Ivan Ivanovna may soon have such capitalistic "luxuries" as detergents, water softeners and perhaps even dry cleaning fluids.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 2 (UP) -- Former President Truman, cheerful despite raw, Cold weather, cast his ballot at 7 A. M. today and smilingly predicted the nation's voters would give "the right answer again."

The present experiment in desegregation is being conducted in the border states of Maryland, Delaware and West Virginia. These were not Confederate states and therefore escaped the horrors of Reconstruction. Any success in desegregation in these states is no indication of what we can expect when it is forced on the South.

SAN FRANCISCO, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Senator Thomas Kuchel, contender in one of the G. O. P.'s key defensive contests, was piling up a growing lead over Representative W. Yorty as the California election count progressed early today.
LINCOLN, Neb., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Except in one Congressional District, all Republican candidates for state and national offices took commanding leads early today.

The Democrats made a net gain of fourteen seats in its delegations to the State Legislature from New York City in yesterday's election, but failed to make inroads in the traditionally Republican upstate districts.
The national Democratic trend swept five additional governorships into the Democratic column and the Republicans made no gains in gubernatorial elections yesterday in thirty-three states.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Glen Alden Coal Company says it will tool-down from a production capacity of 5,000,000 to 6,000,000 tons a year to a 3,500,000-ton level, effective next spring.
The West German riders demonstrated with emphasis their nation's resurgence in horsemanship at the opening of the sixty- sixth National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday.
A distinguished audience witnessed the formal opening of the sixty-sixth National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden.

SANTA FE, N. M., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Early returns in New Mexico showed Democratic candidates leading in all major races, for United States Senator, two seats in the House of Representatives and Governor.

After five years of study a group of citizens appointed by the New York State Board of Regents has come up with a report that points the way to a much needed strengthening of the present high-school program. Although the schools are doing a much better job than many people give them credit for, the group notes that more needs to be done.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 2 -- Three reserve generals of the Belgian Army have been provisionally arrested on suspicion of irregularities in the construction of a gasoline pipeline of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The arrests were made under the bribery and corruption act.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Former Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, who was States' Rights candidate for President in 1948 and an open Eisenhower supporter in 1952, was elected to the United States Senate yesterday as a Democratic write-in candidate.

Two hundred years ago last month Joseph Francois Dupleix, who had dreamed of a great French empire in India, found himself homeward bound from Pondicherry, a ruined and discredited man. The French had decided to come to terms with the British, and Dupleix, who had fought valiantly if not too successfully against the East India Company commander, Robert Clive, was a political sacrifice.

To what extent the issue of state financial aid to localities influenced the result of yesterday's election in New York there is no way of determining exactly. But there is little doubt that it was important in many a voter's mind.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- The Soviet delegation revived today in the General Assembly's Special Political Committee its timeworn proposal for a "package deal" on admission to membership of fourteen applicant countries.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The United Jewish Appeal is providing more than $100,000,000 for reconstruction and welfare work in Israel during 1954, Edward M. Warburg, general chairman of the group, said here today. This is the largest amount ever given to Israel by the appeal in any year.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, who carried Rockland County by more than 14,000 two years ago, received a 6,434 plurality today over Averell Harriman in complete returns from the seventy-one county election districts.
Representative Jacob K. Javits won election as the state's Attorney General early today.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Democratic-Farmer Labor candidates for Senator and Governor took commanding leads in Minnesota early today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 -- California's couture set the pace yesterday for the annum resort-into-spring national press week with exciting openings, widely diversified in character but in accord on many points.

High Voltage was odds-on, she had a record of six victories in eleven starts, she had Eddie Arcaro in the saddle, and she finished out of the money. The Wheatley Stable's daughter of Ambiorix disappointed the majority in the crowd of 22,653 at Jamaica yesterday by her failure to perform better in the $53,125 Frizette Stakes for 2-year-old fillies.

The write-in victory by former Gov. J. Strom Thurmond in South Carolina is the first instance -- certainly in modern political history -- where a candidate whose name was not printed on the ballot has won in a major contest.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 2 -- The National Government took control today of the administration of Bahawalpur, largest of the ten princely states in Pakistan.
HAVANA, Nov. 2 -- Returns tallied so far indicate about 50% of the 2,867,000 eligible Cuban voters took part in yesterday's Presidential election.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The United States, which now takes 60 per cent of Canada's exports, may absorb an even larger proportion over the next twenty-five years, J. A. Calder of Montreal, president of the Canadian Manufacturers' Association, said today.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- For three and a half hours today, an East German building engineer poured out before a Communist court an admission of spying for the West that could mean the death sentence.
Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan, who left a seething political storm in Tokyo while he went on a good will tour of the world, arrived in New York yesterday for his official six-day visit here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- There wasn't a single bar-crasher at the United Nations today, despite the fact that the world organization was the only place in town where a man could buy a drink during voting hours.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Gov. Frank J. Lausche was re-elected Governor of Ohio yesterday for an historic fifth term. His Democratic running mate for the United States Senate, Thomas A. Burke, was running neck and neck with Representative George H. Bender, Republican.
DETROIT, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Senator Homer Ferguson, who received last-minute endorsement from President Eisenhower, faced a close finish in his fight for a third term early today.
MANILA, Nov. 2 -- With many Congressmen out of the country on various missions at public expense, President Ramon Magsaysay has asked legislative leaders for a detail accounting.

Research into antibiotics and other studies being carried out at the New York Botanical Garden are to be brought together in a new $642,723 laboratory. Funds for it have been made available by the New York Botanical Garden Corporation and the city.
BONN, Germany, Nov, 2 -- Handelsblatt, a leading West German economic newspaper, reported today that the Soviet bloc had concluded agreements to coordinate industrialization programs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A dramatic medical movie revealing how the life of a little girl apparently was saved by an ingenious operation inside the heart -- made possible by first immersing the child in ice cubes -- was shown to doctors here today.
A 45-year-old elevator operator who has confessed supplying pistols that he said were used in two killings was held without bail yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court for a hearing Nov. 5.

PORTLAND, Ore., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- A victory for Senator Guy Cordon, Republican, over his Democratic New Deal challenger, Richard L. Neuberger, appeared likely early today in the incomplete tabulation of ballots cast in Oregon's Senatorial election.
Averell Harriman's election as Governor of New York was greeted mutely by 300 to 500 persons in Times Square just after 9:30 o'clock last night.

A SOUTHERN lady who has come to live on the upper East Side learned during registration week that she would have to undergo a literacy test to vote in yesterday's election. After she had filled out a form, she timidly offered her college diploma as evidence of a degree of literacy.

A. K. U.-United Rayon Corporation of Holland yesterday called for redemption on Jan. 2 of all remaining outstanding 4 1/2 per cent convertible debentures. On Sept. 30 there was $3,020,000 principal amount of the debentures outstanding of an original issue of $5,260,000.

THREE weeks ago in this space I said that Milton Lott's "The Last Hunt" was the best novel about the Old West that I had read in the last fifteen years except for A. B. Guthrie's "The Big Sky" and "The Way West." Now it is my pleasant and surprising duty to report that I have read a Western novel that is better than Mr. Lott's.
Five more American-flag Liberty ships have been authorized Zfor transfer to the Liberian flag, the Federal Maritime Board announced yesterday.

STEVE ALLEN, the midnight Godfrey, seems to be making an engaging go of "Tonight," the network version of his local show of last season. His presentation, running for an hour and a half five nights a week, inevitably is uneven, sometimes very good and sometimes thoroughly sad.
The American people completed yesterday the closest, and in some way the weirdest, national election since Woodrow Wilson squeaked past Charles Evans Hughes for the Presidency in 1916.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Nov. 2 -- Protestant parishioners last year gave more than one and a half billion dollars to their churches, the Department of Stewardship and Benevolence of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. reported today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- Amid the appeals throughout the nation for every voter to go to the polls, The Cleveland Plain Dealer said today:
The electronic brain that did a remarkable job in forecasting the 1952 Presidential election results at 8:30 o'clock on election night predicted a Democratic landslide at 8:30 last night.

Democrats picked up one Congressional seat from the Republicans in this city yesterday. But they failed by only a slim margin in a spectacular effort to oust the veteran conservative Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr. in a district that last went Democratic in 1936.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The United States offered Iran today $127,300,000 in loans and grants to support the country until its own oil revenues can finance a "large-scale" development program.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A 29-point splurge in the last quarter gave a 91-84 victory to the New York Knickerbockers over the Milwaukee Hawks in a National Basketball Association contest tonight.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, captured Suffolk County in his race for Governor, polling 89,704 to 40,549 for his Democratic opponent, Averell Harriman, final figures from the county's 247 election districts showed early today.

Consolidated net sales of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., slipped to $752,692,412 in the fiscal year to July 31, and net income fell to $35,840,162, or $4.09 a share, according to the annual report sent to stockholders yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- A Republican tide swept across Westchester today. Every candidate of the party on state, county and local tickets received a plurality, although none approached the 145,171 record of Irving M. Ives when he ran for Senator two years ago.

A very interesting if interpretively uneven recital was given by Harry Shub, violinist, with Louis Shub at the piano last night in Carnegie Hall. We have heard few violinists of the younger generation who played with such tonal beauty and smooth and brilliant technique as he did.

United States commercial exports next year should be as good as or better than this year, according to views expressed yesterday at a round table meeting of the Foreign Credit Inter-Bureau. The forum, in which export and banking representatives participated, was held at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 3 (UP) -- China scored a major upset in the world amateur basketball championship tonight by defeating Canada, 74 -- 61, thus costing the Canadians their chance to finish third in the final round.

The nation's stocks of gasoline declined by 45,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 149,789,000 barrels, compared with 149,834,000 a week earlier and 141,292,000 a year ago.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 3 (UP) -- Allie Reynolds, New York Yankee right-handed pitcher, will consult with a plastic surgeon Friday, with high hopes of gaining complete recovery of a gashed finger on his throwing hand.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 3 (UP) -- Pennsylvania State University's address must remain State College, Pa.
In the cold months ahead homemakers perhaps will have to plan more consciously than in the summer to include green vegetables in their menus.
FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 3 (AP) -- The world pistol champion, Huelet Benner, set an American record for the international rapid-fire pistol event today.

VIENNA, Nov. 3 -- Two former Czechosolvak right-wing Socialist members of Parliament and a number of other Socialist leaders have been sentenced to long terms of imprisonment by the supreme court in Prague for alleged treason and espionage, a Prague radio broadcast said today.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Two towns in northeastern Algeria were reported tonight to be still under the gunfire of terrorist bands. The assaults were part of a wave of attacks in Algeria that began early Monday.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, said today "the results of yesterday's election show a clear lack of confidence on the part of the American people in the reactionary record of the Eisenhower Administration."

In the cold morning-after we wonder how many voters remember the names of the judges they voted for on Tuesday. Well, not many. Once again an examination of results -- generally good in themselves but based almost wholly on blind adherence to political party label -- shows that the selection process is all wrong.

Recent events in Pakistan, Egypt and Iraq should persuade the authors of our present Middle East military policy that their design requires review and that its critics are not necessarily obtuse, prejudiced or willfully captious.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Republican leaders in Westchester began looking around today for a new District Attorney in a hurry. The rush stemmed from the prospect of having a Democratic Governor appoint the new prosecutor if a candidate is not endorsed for appointment by Governor Dewey before the end of the year.

Your editorial "Heat Without Light," rebuking impartially both parties for disregarding the canons of "decency, honesty and fair play" in the recent campaign, was supra-partisanship at its best. The raucous recriminations which filled the air, the "sound and fury signifying nothing" which assailed the ear were not merely unedifying, but frightening as well.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The slimness of Democratic gains in Congress disappointed the labor leaders today, but they took hope from the pick-up of Governor seats.
Earnings of the Minnesota Mining Manufacturing Company in the first nine months rose 28 per cent from the period last year on a sales gain of 3 per cent.

The American Tobacco Company, the nation's largest domestic tobacco producer, increased its net income nearly 6 per cent to $31,735,000 in the first nine months this year from $30,010,000 earned in the 1953 period.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- A third trial of the $200,000 damage suit by Michael Jeffers, actor, against the Screen Extras Guild, A. F. L., was ordered today in Superior Court by Judge Allen W. Ashburn in setting aside a jury-directed award of $33,750 made last September.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 3 -- C. V. Whitney's 3-year-old colt Fisherman, who was put into the line-up two days ago in the role of substitute, won $50,000 of the $65,000 at stake in the Washington D. C. International today.
Wall Street, which had prepared stoically for a Republican disaster on Tuesday, greeted the election results yesterday with a burst of buying that added more than $3,000,000,000 to stock values.
A meeting of Polish-Americans last night called on the United States to protest in the United Nations the retaliation by Communist Poland against the families of seamen who had fled to the West.

The New York bond issue propositions of $350,000,000 for mental hospitals and $200,000,000 more to continue the state's program for low-rent slum-clearance public housing passed with plenty of votes to spare, which is cause for satisfaction. It is regrettable, of course, that the need for mental hospitals continues to expand, and regrettable too that expansion outruns ability to staff ably.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Heavy rain forced the Dartmouth football squad indoors today and the Big Green held a blackboard session. Quarterback Bill Beagle's hip injury was improved, but it won't be known before Friday how much help he will be to the team this week.
Cotton futures rose 1 to 9 points on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Another chapter in American shipping history seems to have come to an end with the striking of the white "E" house flag of the Eastern Steamship Lines from the last active unit of a once proud fleet of coastal passenger and cargo vessels.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3 -- By a narrow margin, local voters chose yesterday to abandon the proportional representation method of electing their City Council and instead to use the "limited" method by which each voter is restricted to six votes for the nine-member council.
Miss Virginia Pope, fashion editor of The New York Times, was honored at the seventh anniversary dinner of the Society of American Fashion Designers, Inc., last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The results of the closest Senate race in the history of New Jersey were still in doubt last night. As the hours wore on, it became apparent that the contest would not be resolved before Monday, and, perhaps, not before Nov. 30.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Edward Vollers, attorney for Arnold Johnson, said tonight the Chicago man was planning to remain in Philadelphia until he could return home with the Philadelphia Athletics' franchise or was turned down finally by the family of Connie Mack.
Swift arrival of returns from cities and the late appearance of rural tallies generated an unexpected statistical nightmare in the tally of voting results in New York and New Jersey Tuesday night.

The nation's voters approved bond issues totaling more than $1,000,000,000 in municipal and state-wide referendums held on Tuesday, according to unofficial and incomplete counts of the returns. Proposals totaling nearly $1,500,000,000 had been submitted to the voters.

Home laundering is a job much disliked by housewives, according to a recent survey by the United States Department of Agriculture. The task was studied yesterday by 400 home economists and teachers at an all-day laundry workshop.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 3-- Julian J. Appleton, a New York attorney, law teacher and author, died here yesterday of a self-inflicted bullet wound, the medical examiner said today.
The most powerful man in the Eighty-fourth Congress will be the new Speaker of the House of Representatives, "Minter Sam" Rayburn, "the squire of Bonham, Tex."
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov, 3 -- A legend in these parts is that Fairfield County holds the balance between victory and defeat for candidates for Governor. It was neatly confirmed yesterday.

IN the four years of their absence from New York, the Lunts have lost none of their grace, humor or skill. Their performance in Noel Coward's "Quadrille," which opened at the Coronet last evening, confirms their old standing as the royal players of our theatre.
The big point in Alexander Uninsky's recital last night in Town Hall was the Liszt Sonata, a work that can make or break a pianist.
Averell Harriman clung to a slim but uncertain lead in the Governorship race yesterday as the unofficial tally of the votes the cast in Tuesday's election neared completion.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 3 -- The Nassau County Republican party emerged virtually unscathed from the bitter campaign waged by the Democrats. In the race for Governor, Senator Irving M. Ives captured the county by a plurality of 100,392 votes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Early wheat trading registered small price gains today but the upturn met profit taking. There followed declines of 2 cents or more from the day's peak before the market again developed buying resistance.

MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- An exit visa has been granted Mrs. Karl Sommerlatte, whose presence in the country has been declared "undesirable" by the Soviet Foreign Ministry. A visa also has been given her husband, a third secretary in the United States Embassy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Jordanian Ambassador protested to the State Department today against plans for the new United States Ambassador to Israel to present his credentials in Jerusalem. The city is divided between Arabs and Israelis and is holy to the Christian, Jewish and Moslem faiths.

A plan for consolidating Glass Fibers, Inc., and the Fiber Glass and Corrulux divisions of the Libby-Owens-Ford Glass Company in a new organization to be known as the Glass Fibers Corporation, was announced yesterday.

When America's oldest federated charity, the United Hospital Fund of New York, was founded in 1879 as the "Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association," it represented eighteen nonprofit, volun tary hospitals in Manhattan, Bronx and Queens.

Pietro Scarpini, Italian pianist, will make his first appearance in this country at Carnegie Hall tonight as soloist with Dmitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in Prokofieff's Second Piano Concerto. The program also will feature the first American performance of "Greek Dances," by Niko Skokoltas, Greek composer.
General Foods Corporation voted yesterday to distribute a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock on Dec. 4.
The Democrats have regained control of the House of Representatives and apparently have won a very close struggle with the Republicans for the Senate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- A flicker of pride and hope in their future is stirring among the Indians of the Altiplano, a 12,000-foot plateau in western Bolivia, Dr. Edmundo Flores of Mexico reported here today. This hope is based upon redistribution of land under the agrarian reform decree of 1953, which has just been completed.
BONN, Nov. 3 -- The Soviet Government proposed today the release from Spandau Prison of Baron Konstantin von Neurath, Hitler's Foreign Minister until 1938.

PARAMUS, N. J., Nov. 3 -- The Rev. John Power of the Community of Roman Catholic Redemptorist Fathers of Mount St. Alphonsus, Esopus, N. Y., died here Monday in the Bergen Pines Hospital, after suffering a heart attack while motoring from Esopus to New York.

The recent Chinese Communist air and artillery attacks on Nationalist-held islands off the China coast and the continued increase in Soviet military strength in Asia have aroused some concern in United States military circles.
Democrats have wrested eight Governorships from the Republicans to win power and patronage in a majority of the states.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Wisconsin Democrats won one more seat in the House of Representatives, one more in the State Senate and twelve more in the Assembly. And they nearly gained the Governorship, too, in yesterday's election.

The second evening performance of the National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden attracted a large gathering of prominent persons. Many dinner parties were given at hotels and private homes before the show.
DENVER, Nov. 3 -- Colorado's voters finally made up their minds yesterday but by their actions they posed more questions than they answered.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Country suppliers sent in 1,000 fewer hogs than traders anticipated and turned the market strong to 25 cents higher today.

The Baird puppets are being dropped from "The Morning Show" by C. B. S. television. Bil Baird and his wife Cora, who conduct the puppet troupe, were notified yesterday of the cancellation, which becomes effective tomorrow.

Atlas Steels, Ltd., Welland, Ont., announced yesterday that its machine for the continuous casting of steel had formally started full scale production, and that its new mills for making stainless steel strip and welded tubing had been put in operation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 20 -- When a Swedish homemaker went shopping five years ago for an egg beater she was faced with more than a hundred fantastic shapes of molded wire -- most of them impractical and unusable.

The second and final volume of Philip Woodruff's biographical history, "The Men Who Ruled India," will be published Nov. 30 by St. Martin's Press. Entitled "The Guardians," the volume continues the history from the period immediately after the Mutiny of 1857 to the end of England's trusteeship on Aug. 15, 1947.
Pigeons on the steps of Brooklyn Borough Hall were among the interested spectators yesterday as firemen battled a blaze across the street in a vacant office building at 367 Fulton Street.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 -- A juror whose past had been resurrected was discharged from serving in the Sheppard murder trial today after he pleaded that he was near a nervous breakdown.

GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- In at least one important industrial sector -- steel -- the fear of the French that they always will be in competition with the Germans does not seem to be justified by recent developments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The chairman of the Republican and Democratic parties today looked at Tuesday's election -- and each saw in it signs of victory in 1956.

The six-story apartment house at 299 Adelphi Street in Brooklyn is under contract of sale by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, to Kerbel Zipes. The building, on plot 91 by 126 feet, contains seventy-one suites of one, two and three rooms.
The extraordinarily close Congressional election has given the Democrats control of the House and possibly the Senate, but the results bespeak no great triumph for either political party.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 3 -- Alben W. Barkley, the formidable "Mr. Democrat" of Kentucky politics who won a "big one" for his party in yesterday's general election, gave some advice today on what to do to win public office.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- There was much of the "morning after the night before" look about President Eisenhower's press conference today.

In rain and cold and on a muddy field, the New York Football Giants worked out for two-and-a-half hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday in preparation for their game against the Steelers in Pittsburgh on Sunday.
The Oct. 23 issue of The New York Times carries a report from Vienna, "Hungary Will Aim at Food Exports."

The H. J. Heinz Company is scheduling national advertising to run in December to make a claim of "first in quality" for its strained orange juice. The copy, a direct result of comparative research just completed, will include this statement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- United States citizens claiming damages for the death or injury of relatives in the British airliner shot down by the Chinese Communists last July were being notified by the State Department today of Peiping's offer to pay Britain $1,027,600 in damages.

CAMDEN N. J., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A. K. Gallagher and B. L. Williams' Mi-Marigold took the lead at the first turn and was never headed thereafter to win today's Earlton purse at Garden State Park before 12,681 rain-chilled fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The voting yesterday again revealed two minorities in this country so slightly less than the two majorities that most of the politicians of both parties who want to get or hold office could read into it a warning not to wage purely partisan politics in the next two years.

FARMINGTON, Mo., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Jess Stewart, editor of The Farmington Press, a weekly, failed in his editorial campaign for his own defeat as St. Francois County circuit clerk. He was re-elected yesterday.
The New York Legislature remains Republican by a considerable margin, but the Democrats gained enough strength to make things less one-sided and more interesting.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Sam Rayburn, slated to be the next Speaker of the House of Representatives, said today Democrats in Congress "won't hate Ike * * * as Roosevelt and Truman were hated."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Washington officials tonight were studying the forthcoming visit to this country by King Tribhubana Bir Bikram of Nepal and his two wives.

BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- New England contributed one new member to the Democratic line-up that will control the House of Representatives in the Eighty-fourth Congress as a result of yesterday's elections. Two of the new Democratic Governors also are New Englanders.

MONROE, La., Nov. 3 (UP) -- Joe Cooper, a 10-year-old boy who defended his dog with a shotgun, changed his mind today and passed up a private school and college education to remain here with his family.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Communist China has accepted Britain's claim for 367,000 ($1,027,600) in compensation for the airliner shot down last July 23.

THE veteran Charles Burchfield is represented by some of his freest and most atmospheric water-colors in the current show at the Rehn Gallery. Having long since abandoned grim Victorian houses and industrial subjects, he continues to devote himself to quite expressionist landscape impressions at different seasons of the year, from November snow in the long grass to a rural crossroad idle under July sun or magnified pussy-willows in a spring rain.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- A meeting of Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth is being arranged and will be announced shortly, informed circles here said today. The probable date is toward the end of January and Sir Winston Churchill will be host in London.

Dr. Pauling gained a reputation as a young man as a "chemist's chemist" when he undertook a study of what was, two decades ago, one of the most important but least understood of chemical questions -- that of how elements attach together to form complex compounds.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- In London a man may have legal right to risk his neck by boarding a bus anywhere he pleases. But it is not so in Newcastle.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 3 -- The Royal Swedish Academy of Science announced tonight that Prof. Linus Carl Pauling of the California Institute of Technology had won the Nobel Prize in chemistry. The medicine and literature awards also had gone to Americans.

The third quarter of the year saw the start of 17,781 new accumulation plans in mutual open-end funds. Most of the new subscriptions were by investors of modest means who add to their holdings out of current earnings in payments of $25 to $100.
The abundance of beef, the moderate cost of butter and the availability of skillets in many materials are three facts apparently unrelated that spell out delicious meals.
Representatives of 200 milk dealers in the metropolitan area and their 12,000 unionized employes reached a peaceful agreement yesterday on a general wage increase of $2.40 a week.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- A switch in the voting of the normally Republican rural counties played a large part in the smashing victories won by Pennsylvania Democrats in all state-wide contests.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- In the penetrating chill of a rainy afternoon Army scrimmaged in Michie Stadium today for Saturday's game with Yale in the Bowl at New Haven.

Negotiations are under way for the sale of the assets of the American Republics Corporation to the Sinclair Oil Corporation, T. Rieber, president and chairman of American Republics, announced yesterday. If the deal is consummated, he said, stockholders of American Republics may be asked to approve a plan for the liquidation of the company.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids Nov. 16 on $51,478,000 of short-term notes to continue the temporary financing of eight Federally aided projects. The notes are to be dated Dec. 7 and will come due on Feb. 4, May 6, and July 8.

The former paint shop of the Central Railroad of New Jersey in its repair yard at Elizabethport, N. J., has been leased by the Columbia Pulverizing Company. The one-story structure contains 30,000 square feet of space. It was leased through the George J. Wolf Realty Company.

The economy is likely to experience continued cross-currents "for some months ahead," according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in a study "Economic Patterns in 1954" published in its current monthly review.
NICE, France, Thursday, Nov. 4 -- Henri Matisse, famed French painter, died in his Nice apartment early today at the age of 84.
Five ingeniously contrived reproductions of crowns that are among the British crown jewels went on exhibition last night at the Cherry Lane Theatre, 38 Commerce Street.
LIBERTYVILLE, Ill., Nov. 3 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today he was pleased by Democratic gains in the off-year election but that they had no bearing on "my political future."
Dr. Arnold J. Toynbee suggested yesterday that the West put primary stress on spiritual rather than material factors in the psychological-warfare phase of the "cold war."

The Reynolds Metals Company, W. R. Grace Co. and a prominent Colombian indsutrialist, J. Mario Santo Domingo, plan to form a new company in Colombia to manufacture aluminum sheet, foil and other fabricated aluminum products.

A report that three voting machines in two Westchester County districts barred votes on the Liberal line for Governor and Lieutenant Governor was received yesterday at Democratic state headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 3 -- Matthew M. Neely's Democratic majority for re-election to his fifth term as United States Senator approached the 60,000 mark today.

PORTLAND, Ore., Thursday Nov. 4 -- Richard L. Neuberger, with a narrow but growing margin, appeared early today to be the first Democrat elected to the United States Senate from Oregon in forty years.

It is entirely possible that Secretary of State John Foster Dulles -- a gentleman of proved persuasiveness -- somehow may be able to convince] the efficiency-minded General Services Administration that it is party to a grave error.

SECAUCUS, N. J., Nov. 3 -- A 42-year-old pig farmer turned tavern keeper, who has run unsuccessfully five out of the last six years for public offices ranging from councilman here to President of the United States, may well have cost Charles R. Howell the election.

Lawrence Peter (Yogi) Berra yesterday signed a one-year contract with the New York Yankees for a salary estimated at $48,000, making him the highest-paid catcher in baseball and "probably" the highest-paid Yankee for 1955, according to George Weiss, general manager.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Maurice Couve de Murville, recently appointed representative to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, will accompany Premier Pierre Mendes-France to the United States this month and is expected to become French Ambassador in Washington.

Wool prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange in the sharpest decline in several years. Tops ended 5 to 6.3 cents a pound lower and grease wool was off 5.7 to 6.4 cents. Volume was heavy.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Baron W. van Boetzelaer van Oosterhout, Ambassador to France from the Netherlands, today opened the newly redecorated offices of the Holland-American Line as the shipping company marked its fiftieth year of operation in Paris.
Political observers were scratching their heads yesterday, trying to recall when so many elections across the nation were carried by so many thin margins. Some may not be decided for weeks.
The text of the Queen Mother's speech to the English-Speaking Union dinner last night follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House authorized direct quotation of the President's remarks throughout.

The American Labor party, whose differences from the Communist party have become virtually indistinguishable in recent years, was stingingly repudiated by the voters on Tuesday, a gratifying result indeed. The A. L. P.'s Gubernatorial candidate failed to poll even 50,000 votes out of the more than 5,000,000 cast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Army said tonight there was no "coddling of Communists" in the promotion and honorable discharge of Maj. Irving Peress, but disclosed that two officers had been "reprimanded" in connection with the incident.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 27, the Federal Reserve Bank reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- With the adoption of a $5, 000,000 bond issue for the erection of a 50,000-seat stadium, backers of the project moved today to try to get a major league franchise transferred to San Francisco.

RICHMOND, Calif., Nov. 3 (UP) -- The world middleweight champion, Carl (Bobo) Olson, 166 pounds, toyed with Garth Panter, 162, through seven rounds tonight and then scored a technical knockout in the eighth when Referee Joe Louis stopped the bout because of a cut eye suffered by Panter.

HONG KONG, Nov. 3 -- Chinese Nationalist B-20's struck again at Toumen Island, off the Chekiang coast this morning in an attempt to silence Communist guns trained on Nationalist-held Yikiang, five miles to the south.
You have to take your hat off to the New York City Ballet, which revived its production of George Balanchine's full-length version of "The Nutcracker" last night for a run at the City Center.
Confusing results from yesterday's off-year elections appear to have started the 1956 Presidential campaign long before its scheduled date.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Business expanded moderately and prices rose as the stock markets made a good start today to a new bookkeeping account. The improvement was ascribed to favorable company profit statements and the rise in the sterling area's gold reserves.
The election frauds bureau of the State Attorney General's office will start today an investigation of complaints of alleged irregularities in Tuesday's voting.
DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- New methods of training unadjusted boys at the Children's Village here reduced the number of runaways to sixty-two last month, compared with 118 in September.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UP) -- Two Democratic women scored upsets in Michigan and Minnesota in yesterday's election, raising feminine representation in the new Congress to a record high of at least fifteen.
ATLANTA, Nov. 3 (UP) -- Georgia and Louisiana voters approved amendments to their state constitutions to thwart any attempt to end segregation in public schools, election results showed today.

" Top level" talks today will determine action to be taken by the International Longshoremen's Association in connection with the "lockout" of the union's membership in the Port of Philadelphia, Capt. William V. Bradley, union president, asserted last night.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 3 -- Suffolk County Democrats analyzed election returns here today and saw hope for the future.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 3 -- Commercial banking's opposition to new savings bank branches is an attack on the "entire philosophy of mutual savings banking," bankers were told today.

DES MOINES, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Iowa Republican leaders said tonight that their all-out victory in yesterday's general election was due to the personal popularity of President Eisenhower, acceptance of his program and to his urgent appeals for Republican support.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 3 -- The wool check -- the total paid for the nation's crop -- this season will be nearly fifty million Australian pounds lower than last year, if present price levels are maintained.

ALL things remind Alben Barkley of good stories. His autobiography, published today, is called "That Reminds Me-----."* It should carry the subtitle: "A Toastmaster's Report to the Nation." For this is the most entertaining record of American politics we have had since Mr. Dooley. Through most of this century's decades Mr. Barkley has served Kentucky and his country ably as a Democratic Representative, Senator or Vice President.

ROME, Nov. 3 -- According to Pope Pius XII, the belief that "the Church's authority is limited to purely religious matters" is an error. Roman Catholics "must take an open and firm stand" against it, he added.
OTTAWA, Nov. 3 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent held out hopes today for an early solution of the constitutional tax problem bedeviling Canadian federal-provincial relations.

OGDEN, Utah, Nov. 3 -- Utah's new House member will be Dr. Henry Aldous Dixon, Republican, a political minute man. Dr. Dixon, president of the Utah State Agricultural College at Logan and former president of Weber College at Ogden, made the shortest campaign in Utah history -- two weeks.

Nine-month sales and earnings of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation were the highest in its history, Robert E. Gross, president and board chairman, reported yesterday. The earnings were $17,143,000, up 37 per cent from those of a year earlier and up $1,681,000 from the $15,462,000 for all of 1953.

An elderly man and woman were found dead of gas poisoning yesterday in the woman's three-room flat at 351 1/2 East Fifty-fourth Street. The police said they apparently had died accidentally as the result of an open gas oven jet in the kitchen.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Another unofficial strike upset the Port of London this morning after most of the men who struck Monday had gone back to work. But the employers, with fingers crossed, expected operations to be normal tomorrow:

LONDON, NOV. 3 -- The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, Ltd., announced today its intention to change its name to the British Petroleum Company, Ltd. At the same time, the company revealed a plan for distributing to stockholders four shares for each share now held.

DETROIT, Nov, 3 (AP) -- Michigan Democrats, led by Gov. G. Mennen Williams as he swept to a fourth term, ousted Senator Homer Ferguson Republican of Michigan, and two Republican representatives in Tuesday's balloting.

DOVER, Del., Nov. 8 (UP) -- Bryant Bowles, head of the National Association for the Advancement of White People, was held in $1,000 property bond today on a fugitive warrant charging him with passing a worthless check in Memphis, Tenn.
Lewis W. Douglas, form United States Ambassador Great Britain, asserted yesterday that there could be no great settlement of international problems or issues unless "we a united as one."

In an effort to keep pace with the fluctuating news of the contest between Mr. Harriman and Mr. Ives -- a contest so exceedingly close that a shift of about one-tenth of 1 per cent from one candidate to the other would have changed the outcome -- this page went through several changes in make-up yesterday.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Nov. 3 -- Five new voting machines, each capable of producing four carbon copies of printed totals, were secretly tested here yesterday for the first time under actual voting conditions.
Stock prices, as measured by The New York Times average of fifty representative issues, scored a net gain of $5.69 a share yesterday -- the biggest advance for any day since Sept. 5, 1939.

CHERRYFIELD, Me., Nov. 3 -- According to Vurn Tracy, who has guided us through the cedar swamps and beech ridges of this area for many years, the wet weather here for the last six months has led the local deer into the first step of their evolution into aquatic mammals.

Machine-made wallpapers from twenty - two manufacturers are displayed at the new Wallpaper Information Bureau, 509 Madison Avenue. The headquarters for the wallpaper council, the bureau displays collections of American-made papers as a service to decorators.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Cotton models for summer 1955, shown recently by the Boussac Fabric Company, capture the high points of the new fashions: elongated bodices, unemphasized bosom, mock low waistlines. Though not dressmakers, the company has employed expert designers to show that moderate-priced cottons can be as "couture" as far more expensive materials.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 3 -- The Federal Council of the Waterside Workers Federation ordered today a general strike on the Australian waterfront. The council acted after receiving reports from stopwork meetings in all ports hostile to the Commonwealth Government's proposed amendments to the Stevedoring Industry Act.
Julius Kayser Co., Inc., manufacturer of women's hosiery, lingerie and gloves, has acquired all the outstanding stock of Catalina, Inc., producer of men's, women's and boys' swimsuits and sportswear.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Virtually complete tallies of yesterday's voting showed today that Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, had scored a decisive victory in his bid for re-election to the Senate.

The first accurate descriptions of the physical characteristics of protein molecules, achieved in laboratories of the California Institute of Technology under the direction of Dr. Linus Pauling, have been hailed as a landmark by scientific researchers the world around.
MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- A call for the Soviet armed forces to be vigilant against surprise attack by "imperialist countries" was published today in the army newspaper Red Star.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President Eisenhower announced today the opening of a "new phase" of negotiations with the Soviet Union on atomic energy. He said he hoped this would be "more fruitful than the first phase."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 3 -- The Brazilian press found an angle of local interest in the United States elections in the defeat of Senator Guy M. Gillette of Iowa. It was reported on the front pages of two of the leading afternoon newspapers as a defeat of the leading enemy of coffee.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Twenty-seven lordships of the manor, each a page of English history, were auctioned today with their accompanying maps and documents. The Beaumont col lection of lordships of the manor fetched 9,855 ($27,594) at the auction attended by more than 500 persons.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Representative London newspaper reviewers expressed no enthusiasm for "The Immoralist," which opened tonight at the Arts Theatre -- a small private club theatre.

An agreement to purchase assets of the Brockway Motor Company, Inc., including its name, has been entered into by the H. B. American Machine Company, Inc. The agreement includes a five-year lease by H. B. of Brockway's Cortland, N. Y., plant with option to purchase.

The extraordinarily strong race that brought victory to Jacob K. Javits for Attorney General of New York, while Senator Ives, the head of the Republican ticket, was losing by a small margin to Averell Harriman, is one of the most significant results of the election.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- A compromise was reached today in a week-long controversy over the questions of just how -- and how much -- additional allowances should be paid to top-level officials of the reorganized secretariat. The streamlining of headquarters, calling for a maximum of sixteen upper-echelon posts, is scheduled to go into effect Jan. 1.

Shareholders of Chesapeake Industries, Inc., a holding company, at a meeting here yesterday approved the company's plans for acquisition of the Colonial Trust Company and four organizations affiliated with that institution.
France's top economic planners have advised their Government to build a 68,000-ton liner that would be the third largest ship in the world.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold endorsed today the $7,000,000 international community housing project planned for Briarcliff and Ossining, N. Y., where a cooperative of United Nations employes intends to acquire 120 acres as a site.
TORONTO, Nov. 3 (UP) -- Eric Nesterenko netted his first goal of the season with fewer than 90 seconds remaining tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 1-1 deadlock with the Detroit Red Wings.

New passenger helicopter service connecting White Plains, N. Y., and Stamford, Conn., with La Guardia Airport is being started this morning. The flights are timed to make connections with already existing helicopter service to other major metropolitan airports.

HONOLULU, Nov. 3 -- Democrats captured control of both houses of the Legislature for the first time in the territory's fifty-four-year history yesterday and nearly upset the favored delegate to Congress, Elizabeth Farrington.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Dr. Mahmoud Azmi, Egypt's chief delegate to the United Nations, collapsed in the midst of a speech to the Security Council today and died a little more than an hour later.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Apparently undismayed by the prospect of a Democratic-led House of Representatives, President Eisenhower vowed his cooperation today to keep the business of government going.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Nov. 3 (UP) -- The executive committee of the left-wing People's Progressive party said today that it would continue to struggle for independence from Britain.

The Appellate Division unanimously affirmed yesterday an award made by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer giving Jane Froman and Gypsy Markoff, entertainers, $9,050 and $9,580, respectively, in their suit against the Pan American Airways.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The Western Big Three have decided to introduce a resolution under which the United Nations General Assembly would endorse the United States program for the peaceful uses of atomic energy.
On a record total of midterm ballots, the Democrats moved up recovery road impressively yesterday.

Sauces based on butter have a richness that is particularly pleasing. Now that this table fat has declined in price such sauces might be made more frequently. One of them is mornay, basically a cream sauce to which cheese is added for distinctive savor. Vegetables served au gratin and also fish such as tuna may be prepared in this way:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced state acreage allotments for the 1955 upland cotton crop today.
West Germany's domination of the international jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden continued last night.
YONKERS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Chestertown Boy, owned by P. H. and William E. Thompson of Centreville, Md., easily took the Fleetwood Pace in the rain at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

HARTFORD, Nov. 3 -- Connecticut Democrats are in line to get one of the richest patronage hauls they ever have had in this state because of the election of Abraham A. Ribicoff of Hartford as Governor.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- on the urgent request of Premier Pierre Mendes-France, the French National Assembly scheduled today its debate on ratification of the Paris accords on West German armament and sovereignty for Dec. 14 to 17.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- The 1954 Democratic "trend" stooped at the California state line.
A study of pupil achievement has shown that students in the city's public schools score higher in school subjects than children elsewhere, the Board of Education said yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 3 -- The Israeli Foreign Ministry announced today acceptance of Arab proposals for release of the locked bank accounts and safe-deposits belonging to refugees of the Palestine war.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
The long-awaited and highly touted musical play, "Fanny," co-starring Ezio Pinza and Walter Slezak, arrives at the Majestic Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.

THE accident to Allie Reynolds' pitching hand may so cripple the Chief that he'll be unable to take to the mound again, a much too abrupt termination of his career. Yet this news does not carry the implication of disaster to the Yankees which would have been the case a few years ago. That's the cold-blooded, impersonal way of viewing it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named Gen. J. Lawton Collins today as United States special representative in South Vietnam. The President expressed concern about the "dangerous forces threatening South Vietnam.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 -- The seat in the United States Senate held for fourteen years by the late Robert A. Taft was returned to the Republican column yesterday by Ohio's voters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Army today dismissed the last court-martial charge against Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees, who at one time faced dismissal from the service for his writings about Korea.

A recanvass of ballots in New York's close contest for Governor started yesterday in some upstate counties. In this city, the Board of Elections said a re-examination of the 4,214 voting machines in the five boroughs would begin next Tuesday and probably take ten days.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's flexible farm price support program was generally credited by observers here today with having survived its first test of voter sentiment.
Lovely Wave, the 3-year-old filly that had been running in claiming races for so little as $6,000, scored an easy victory in the featured $10,000-added Piping Rock Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 3 -- South Carolinians, who bolted the Democratic party in 1948 and almost went Republican in 1952, demonstrated their independence again yesterday by electing a write-in candidate to the United States Senate.

The Society of Silurians, an organization of veteran newspapermen, announced yesterday that its top annual award for work by a New York newspaperman has been won by Guy Richards of The New York Journal-American.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Minnesota Democrats wrested control of the Statehouse after sixteen years of Republican rule today and sent Hubert Humphrey back to the United States Senate in a stunning Republican defeat.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Joseph C. O'Mahoney fought his way back today to the United States Senate in one of the tightest races in state history.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 3 -- William C. Cramer, 32-year-old attorney and World War II naval officer, today had been elected Florida's first Republican member of Congress since Reconstruction days.

Queen Mother Elizabeth of Great Britain received last night a fund of $433,481 raised in this country as a memorial to her husband, the late King George VI. The gift was presented at a dinner given in her honor by the English-Speaking Union at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Spokesmen for organized labor said today they were pleased and encouraged by the election results.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Retail discount outlets now account for an annual volume of $25,000,000,000, or 18 per cent of all retail trade, and the volume is steadily rising, according to the United States Chamber of Commerce.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 4 -To clear the way for advancement of Negroes in the Rhodesian copper-belt mines, the Rhodesian Selection Trust Company gave six months' notice today to the Northern Rhodesia European Mine Workers Union to terminate the agreement between the company and the union.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 4 -- The Navy's Sea Dart, an experimental twin-jet seaplane, fell to pieces in the air this afternoon before a stunned audience.

Happy the family with which fowl is a supreme favorite. For some weeks now, this humble bird, older and tougher than broilers and friers but an excellent basis for stews, fricassees, and salads, has been one of the outstanding "buys" in food. This week is no exception.

Eight communities throughout the nation rejected proposals to add fluoride to their drinking water systems, while two others voted in favor of the controversial chemical additive, election results showed yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Strong French armored forces today attacked terrorist bands in the mountainous Aures region of eastern Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 736,233 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,774 cars or 1.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 44,610 cars or 5.7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 125,883 cars or 14.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The stock markets were brightened today by another group of favorable company profit statements and by yesterday's advance on Wall Street. Buying was improved and net price movements were higher despite profit taking.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Democrats, in apparent control of the next Congress, may attempt to put out of business or curb two of the most controversial of Congressional investigating committees.

Speaking as one American living in Switzerland -- and I have reason to believe that some other Americans living here feel the same way -- I should like to register my protest against the action of the Department of Justice in its antitrust action against the Swiss watch industry as it operates in the United States.
Stoneware ceramics by Irene Hamel, keyed to fall and indoor living, will be on view at Pygmalion House, 10 West Fifty-fifth Street, tomorrow through Nov. 30.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Arnold Johnson of Chicago today bought the Philadelphia Athletics for Kansas City. Connie Mack, 91-year-old founder of the 54-year-old American League club, signed the final paper from a sickbed.

TRIESTE, Italy, Nov. 4 (AP) -Premier Mario Scelba bid today for closer Italian-Yugoslav understanding. Perhaps indicating renewed Italian interest in joining a Balkan alliance, he mentioned mutual defense in an Armistice Day speech hailing this city's return to Italy.
TORONTO, Nov. 4 -- Canadian Defense Research Board workers in suburban Downsview have perfected an instant bread-mix that should bring the art of bread baking back to many Canadian kitchens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Prospects for favorable action on President Eisenhower's liberal foreign trade program have been decisively enhanced by the Democratic Congressional victory. Whatever effects the party's victories may have on relations between Congress and the Republican Administration in other fields, it was clear today that foreign economic policy is the major issue holding the greatest hope for harmonious cooperation.
There will be "no let-up or change" in the Eisenhower Administration's domestic or foreign policies despite the shift in control of Congress, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. declared yesterday.
GENEVA, Nov. 4 --The posi-I tion of the United States delega-] tion at the Geneva trade corffe'-[ ence is considerably strong, er' !today than it was two days ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Six months after the Salk polio vaccine trials in the city, the Health Department and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis collected blood samples yesterday from 452 participating children in twelve public schools in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 4 -- The president of the New Jersey Home Builders Association charged today that "ruthless, arbitrary action exercised by local municipalities has practically stopped the building of houses under $14,000 and has created a dangerous and serious housing shortage for a large segment of New Jersey's citizens."

One of the outstanding events of the social season, the Horse Show Ball, will be held tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many of the 800 persons expected to attend will give supper parties at the ball, which will begin after this evening's performance of the Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

Hard times, signalized in the shipping industry by the flight of American-flag tonnage to the shelter of less expensive foreign flags, have written "finished with engines" for the last active liner of the Eastern Steamship Lines.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The nation's steel industry and dealers in iron and steel scrap today put it up to the Department of Commerce to decide if and when it should curb scrap exports.
For some months letter and speeches have held forth on the status of Cyprus, and pleas for its self-determination have been prevalent.

The French are having hard luck in North Africa. The flames of nationalism have now reached into Algeria, after spreading from Tunisia and Morocco. This is the first time that violent nationalism has reached Algeria and it can be a serious business for the French.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy called on the Senate's Special Censure Committee today to explain what he called an "imbecilic ruling" before the chamber begins its "lynch party" next Monday.
Dartmouth and Columbia were rated even yesterday by coaches of the rival elevens, which will meet for the twenty-fifth time in a game at Hanover, N. H., tomorrow.

Abraham Lincoln's historic Emancipation Proclamation abolishing slavery in the United States will be publicly displayed in New York Nov. 19 to 21. Dated Jan. 1, 1863, it bears the martyred President's signature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A Federal judge ruled today that the National Lawyers Guild must exhaust administrative procedures before it can take legal action to prevent the Attorney General from listing it as a subversive organization.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks posted their second victory of the season tonight, defeating the New York Rangers, 3 -- 1, to climb out of the National Hockey League cellar into fifth place.

The dispatch of General Collins to Vietnam as a special Ambassador of the President to pull together our varied activities there seems both necessary and sensible. There have been persistent rumors of a split between the French and ourselves on political policy for Vietnam. The French denounce these rumors as unfounded.
Fashion writers got the first whiff of the resort season yesterday afternoon when manikins wearing crisply designed hats by Gustavo breezed through his showroom at 59 West Fifty-sixth Street.

A gift that increases by more than 100 pieces of porcelain and pottery, the renowned R. Thornton Wilson ceramic collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be on exhibition next week when the museum's newly installed galleries of post-Renaissance decorative art are opened.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Maria Meneghini-Callas, American soprano appearing with the Lyric Theatre in the Civic Opera House, has been charged with breach of contract in a suit filed in Circuit Court here by a New York lawyer, who said he had sponsored her opera training.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Clark Griffith, president of the Washington baseball club, said today that he would continue to oppose the transfer of the Philadelphia Athletics' franchise to Kansas City.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings earned a hard-fought 3-2 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight despite the absence of the injured Gordie Howe, who missed his first National Hockey League game in almost six years.

IT was a Yale man, Harry Williams, who developed the tackles-back formation in football's antediluvian days. He wrote Walter Camp, the patron saint of the sport, and offered it to the Elis. Camp ignored the letter. So Williams offered it to Army and the Kaydets murdered a much better Navy team with the maneuver.

Fordham's Rams will leave for Morgantown, W. Va., this morning for their game with the Mountaineers at West Virginia University tomorrow. Their plane is scheduled to leave from La Guardia Airport at eight o'clock.
Loans to business by bank in the New York area underwent another decline for the week ended Wednesday, it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The State Department gave West Germany a check for $300,000 today to pay for a new German Embassy here.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Nov. 4 -- Senator-elect Alan Bible, only Democrat to win a top position in Nevada in Tuesday's election, today faced a contest for his seat by Senator Ernest S. Brown, Republican.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 4 -- A conference of United States and Mexican communications officials, out of which it is hoped a radio treaty will evolve, opened here this afternoon.

The death of Henri Matisse, still youthful in spirit at 84, removes from the art world another of the young rebels who lived long enough to be regarded as an old master. His life was an integral and important part of what has come to be known as The Modern Movement.
Larger nine-month earnings and an increased quarterly dividend were announced yesterday by the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The politically loneliest man in the United States Senate loomed today as a man or immense power.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- The largest crowd to see Notre Dame play this season is looked for Saturday at Franklin Field when the Fighting Irish line up against a team that has yet to score its first victory.
The city's widening narcotics problem has caused Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams to increase the Narcotics Squad from 130 to 200.

CHERRYFIELD, Me., Nov. 4 -- Two successive days without rain is considered a phenomenon here, in view of the weather man's recent performance in this area. The snow that was hopefully forecast appeared in the form described locally as a "drizzle."
In another dynamic session, stocks ripped through old records yesterday and closed near their new highs for the year and the upward movement.

The strike of 450 salt-water fish handlers at the Fulton Fish Market was settled at 7 P. M. yesterday. Dealers sought to get fish into the city in time to assure a near-normal supply of the favorite Friday food for today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- European diplomats were reporting to their capitals today that the Congressional elections would have considerably more effect on foreign affairs than they had expected.

Well-known men and women headed by Mrs. Stanley G. Mortimer Jr., and including Mrs. Montgomery S. Bradley are furthering the success of the preview of paintings and sculpture by members of the faculty and visiting artists of the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture to be held on Tuesday night at the Downtown Gallery.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 4 (UP) -Robert A. Taft Jr., who won election to the Ohio House of Representatives Tuesday, said today he would concentrate his efforts in the same areas that distinguished his famous father.
A hundred members of local Boards of Education in the metropolitan area had some anxious moments last night when they found themselves on the receiving end of a test.
The City of New York borrowed $21,555,000 from the National City Bank of New York and associates at an estimated net interest cost of 1.13 per cent.
Mrs. Theodore W. Hawes of Baltusrol Golf Club was elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the group's annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Shelton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A study undertaken for a joint Congressional committee predicted today that by 1965 the nation's economy would be half again as big as now. It said taxes would be lower, work hours shorter, wages higher and the nation's population would have grown to 190,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -A new list of grievances citing alleged "monopoly" practices by the major film producer-distributor companies in the marketing of movies has been sent by the Southern California Theatre Owners Association to Senator Andrew F. Schoeppel, chairman of the subcommittee on monopoly of the Senate Select Committee on Small Business.

The Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, has presented an award for "excellent use of newspapers as an advertising medium" to Deering, Milliken Co., textile manufacturer, in recognition of its successful marketing of Visa, a men's summer suiting blend of Dacron and wool.
At least three new Senators will be sworn in next Monday when the Senate convenes in a special session to consider a motion to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Two new drugs, as yet in very short supply, were announced today at the National Institutes of Health as apparently "three or four times more potent than cortisone" in treating arthritis and as having less side-effects.
The theory of "coexistence" between free nations and dictatorships was criticized yesterday by Dr. Salvador de Madariaga, author and statesman.

There was an interruption of West German victories in the international jumping competition at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon when Mexico's Capt. Joaquin d'Harcourt became a winner, but the German skein was picked up again at night.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Prof. Linus C. Pauling Nobel Prize winner for his discoveries in chemistry, relaxed with his wife here today but took time to condemn the treatment of scientists engaged in Government work.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 (UP) -- James Roosevelt, elected to represent the Twenty-sixth District in Congress, today disclosed he had received a "good luck" telegram from the Democratic National Chairman, Stephen Mitchell, two days before the election.
More than 150 paintings, prints and personal possessions of John James Audubon, American ornithologist and woodsman, went on display here last night.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 4 -Republicans today discussed the desirability of demanding a recount of ballots in the Oregon Senatorial election. Virtually complete unofficial figures today showed Richard L. Neuberger, Democrat, to have won from Senator Guy Cordon by upward of 2,000 votes. Close to 570,000 votes were cast.

A reclassification and pay plan for city engineers and architects, recently proposed by City Personnel Director Joseph Schechter, has been rejected by a labor union claiming to represent most of the affected employes.

George Auerbach's 3-year-old Errard gelding, Ergo, with young Ray Broussard riding, was a five-length victor in the feature at the Jamaica track yesterday. The 3-1 shot covered the six furlongs over a drying-out course in 1:12 3/5.
QUEBEC, Nov. 4 -- United States and Canadian birch forests are being killed by hotter and hotter summers, a Canadian forest expert said here today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 4 -- The outlook for an increase in savings bank earnings is "not promising," in the opinion of representative New York savings bank executives.

Official recanvasses of the vote cast in Tuesday's state election were under way yesterday in a dozen or more upstate counties. Others, including the one in New York City, are to start next week. The outcome of these official counts will determine whether the shaky 9,657-vote margin given to Averell Harriman, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, in unofficial tabulations will stand up.
Many older workers are retained productively in industry when their companies "redesign" their jobs or transfer them to other positions, a specialist in problems of aging employes said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $110,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
OSLO, Norway, Nov. 4 -- An impassioned plea for mankind to rise above the thoughts of war was made by Dr. Albert Schweitzer here today on receiving the 1952 Nobel Peace Prize.

WATERVILLE, Me., Nov. 4 (UP) -- J. Russell Wiggins, managing editor of The Washington Post and Times-Herald, said here today that the new law requiring "subversive" groups to register their printing presses was a departure from basic free-press principles.
Cocoa prices reversed field yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange and declined the cent-a-pound daily limit.

JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, Nov. 4 -- The announcement by Israel that she had agreed with representatives of the Arab Palestine refugees to free blocked bank accounts of the refugees aroused indignation among Jordanian officials today. It caused puzzlement elsewhere.

The United States was praised yesterday for having a "forward-looking" roadbuilding and traffic program that is the envy of European countries. TOKYO, Nov. 4 -- Many Japanese sources said today Japan might face harder sledding in attempts to obtain further assistance from the United States as a result of the Democratic margin in the Congressional elections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Reports of a $2,000,000,000 increase in the annual rate of personal income in September and of a continuing boom in the construction industry during October provided an encouraging picture of the economy today.

THE soloist at the concert given by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was Pietro Scarpini, a pianist of prodigious capacities, who played the little-known Second Piano Concerto of Prokofieff with whirlwind virtuosity and rhythmic drive.

Things are looking up for the consumer, a panel of experts agreed yesterday at the opening session of the Eighth National Home Laundry Conference at the Commodore Hotel. Members of the panel were a home economist, a scientist and a fabric manufacturer.

A 19-year-old youth who was said to have been kidnapped, held captive for almost three days and tortured in the basement of an uptown apartment house was rescued late yesterday by the police. His alleged torturers -- five other youths and a building superintendent -- were arrested.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Nov. 4 -- Premier Moshe Sharett laid before a United Jewish Appeal study mission today Israel's case against United States arms grants to Arab states.
Eleven strikers were arrested in Brooklyn at 5:30 P. M. yesterday after pickets had blocked a busy downtown street with automobiles.
A week of inconspicuous sightseeing, with friendly visits to American scholars, ends today for the two Soviet scientist-delegates to Columbia University's bicentennial.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Representatives of the 8,000 striking ship repairers in the Port of London said today that the workers in all German and Netherland ports had agreed not to handle ships diverted from London for repairs.
