Behrman was published. "The Worcester Account"* is the subject of today's "Books of The Times" column.
A Fifty-ninth Street stop for express trains of the Lexington Avenue I. R. T. subway was approved yesterday by the Transit Authority.

Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, president of Columbia University, and six members of the faculty paid tribute to the late Irwin Edman, Johnsonian Professor of Philosophy at a memorial meeting yesterday. Nearly 300 friends, colleagues and students attended the memorial in the rotunda of Low Memorial Library.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said tonight the Government coalition was in serious disagreement on the acceptability of the Saar settlement.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Justice George T. Vandermeulen of the State Supreme Court said today that two Attica State Prison guards had been suspended last year as a part of what he termed "the desire of the Commissioner of Correction to make somebody a scapegoat because of the Wicks-Fay incident and the Yonkers Raceway scandal."
Two acts of heroism -- one off the California coast last summer and the other off New York's Battery fourteen years ago -- were recognized officially in separate ceremonies yesterday.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 4 -- An ancient bronze statue of a Greek-Roman god, valued at more than $10,000, has disappeared from the Wadsworth Atheneum and is presumed stolen.

Evelyn Sachs, mezzo-soprano, made her recital debut at Town Hall last evening. The performance revealed that Miss Sachs has in her favor a voice of adequate range and pleasing quality, and musical intelligence.

Dorothy Kenyon, former Municipal Court Judge, who had agreed to debate a diplomatic question on the "State of the Nation" radio program, declined to go on the program yesterday after learning that it was sponsored by Facts Forum.

HONG KONG, Nov. 4 -- The Chinese Communists and Nationalists sent their planes out again today to bomb each other's positions on two islands north of the Nationalist - held Tachen Islands [cross on map] off the Chekiang coast.

THE gentlemen who run the newly merged $2,900,000,000 Chemical Corn Exchange Bank are all of a swivet this month changing stone, bronze, illuminated and painted signs on their ninety-eight offices in New York.
Corliss Lamont announced yesterday that he was giving $50,000 to start a "Bill of Rights fund for use during this time of crisis."

BOSTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A nationally known authority on speech says parents who wish to avoid stuttering in their children should "make speaking fun for the child, make it play rather than work." Dr. Wendell Johnson of Iowa, in his first report on the main findings of a study of how stuttering begins, said:
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Sir Winston Churchill announced to Parliament today that he would be host to the other Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth in London next Jan. 31.

TUCSON, Ariz., Nv. 4 (AP) -- Four men were killed and eleven injured tonight when a twin-engined plane from Ellington Air Force base, Houston, Tex., crashed and burned while attempting an emergency landing at Tucson Municipal Airport.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, today hailed Republican election victories in the farm belt as a vindication of his flexible price support program.

More than 12,000,000 thrifty Americans will receive about $1,080,000,000 in Christmas Club checks this month. This will be the largest Christmas Club bonanza, according to Edward F. Dorset, president of the Christmas Club a Corporation.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Possible negotiations with the Soviet Union and the financing of the French expeditionary force in Indochina are expected to be leading topics that Premier Pierre Mendes-France will discuss in Washington this month.
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- President Ed Doherty of the American Association indicated today that Denver might be the draft choice of the league if the Philadelphia Athletics are moved to Kansas City.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Wheat futures followed a choppy course here today but showed a strong tone in the late trading, with May and June at new. high prices on the crop.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 -- Pimlico opened its fall race meet today. The old place has a new look.

A 33-year-old ex-convict escaped from Brooklyn Police Headquarters yesterday, but was recaptured four hours later. The net result was another charge against him and the possibility that he will receive a seven-year prison term.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- After having seen the General Assembly in operation this afternoon, Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan expressed hope that Japan would be allowed to join the United Nations.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 4 -- Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo's nationalist-orientated Cabinet tonight underwent its second reshuffle since coming into power fifteen months ago and after seventeen days of political crisis.

Robert Drake of La Salle and Archbishop Stepinac of White Plains were the individual and team victors, respectively, in the annual cross-country championships of the Bronx-Manhattan-Westchester division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Democratic victories at the polls on Tuesday do not mean a return of a Roosevelt New Deal or a Truman Fair Deal in Congress.

For more than twenty-two years the name of Godfrey N. Nelson has appeared in the masthead at the top of this page. Today, with rules turned, it appears there for the last time. During these years Mr. Nelson served as Secretary of the New York Times Company, a position in which his sound judgment, his unfailing integrity and his wise counsel were of steady value to this newspaper.
CHULA VISTA, Calif., Nov. 4 -- The Navy drew back the curtains today on its "pogo" vertical-rising fighter plane, which can hover like a helicopter on take-off of landing.

A colony of two-family homes is planned on almost a whole block, of vacant land bounded by Underhill, Randall, Leland and LaCombe Avenues in the Bronx which was bought by Dila DiCroce, builders, from the estate of Frank Albers.

Gordon R. Clapp, who is no relative as far as I know, was connected so long with the Tennessee Valley Authority that he believes all the false fabric of the T. V. A. is now fact. The truth is that T. V. A. has cost the American people approximately two billion dollars and to date has paid back less than one hundred millions of dollars.
EVERYTHING has turned out fine in "Fanny," which opened at the Majestic last evening. No believer in false economy, Joshua Logan has heaped all the splendors of a huge show on top of it.
B. Altman Co. signed a lease yesterday paving the way for erection of a large suburban department store at Millburn, N. J.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The British Government heard and politely rejected today a protest from eight Arab nations against the intention to have John W. Nicolls, Britatin's new Ambassador to Israeli, present his credentials in Jerusalem rather than Tel Aviv.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain arrived this afternoon for a week's visit in Washington. She last saw the capital in 1939, when she and her husband, the late King George VI, were the first ruling monarchs to stay in the White House.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, who headed the Office of Strategic Services in World War II, today was named chairman of a committee of the American Bar Association making a survey of criminal justice.
Parents who are worried about the kind of education their children are receiving in secondary schools may be heartened by knowing that educators are too.
MONROE TOWNSHIP, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Samuel H. Lifshey, a pioneer prize-winning photographer, died last night in a fire that began in the fireplace of his home in the Outcalt section of this township.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler told the National Union of Manufacturers today that Britain was making good progress in her efforts to expand her economy without inflation.

The conciliatory tone of the President's post-election press conference was just what one would have expected of a man of Mr. Eisenhower's even temperament and high character. The note of moderation set by the Chief Executive, and also by the prospective Democratic leaders of Senate and House, was particularly welcome after the weeks of partisan abuse and vituperation that the country had endured from spokesmen of both political parties, from the Vice President down.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, one of the nation's largest operating utilities, announced yesterday that it is planning to issue new convertible debentures in January to help finance construction and expansion.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- India suggested today that signs of improvement in East-West relations warranted a new effort at breaking the eight-year-old deadlock over admission of new states to the United Nations.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The world of art today mourned Henri Matisse, one of France's greatest painters, who died in his apartment in Nice yesterday afternoon of a heart attack. He was 84 years old.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 4 -- The bill amending the Stevedoring Industry Act, which has precipitated a nationwide strike on the wharves, was explained tonight by Labor Minister Harold Holt.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Pietro Scarpini, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Oscar Shumsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Walter Hautzig, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Doris Hurnberg, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Oscar Brand, ballad singer, Hunter College Little Theatre, 8:30.
YONKERS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The fourth dead-heat finish of the year at Yonkers Raceway was registered tonight in the third race when the trotters M'Lord and Bunny Hanover hit the wire together.
Gen. Walter Bedell Smith has been elected president of the American Heritage Foundation, Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the foundation's board of trustees, announced yesterday.
Federal mediators will be asked to intervene immediately in the deadlock between longshoremen and their employers, although three weeks of the contract extension remain.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A coalition Government, with the Democrats in narrow command of its legislative arm, is in prospect from Tuesday's bitterly contested Congressional elections.

The Manhattanville Day Nursery and the Manhattanville Neighborhood Center have been merged as the Manhattanville Community Centers, Inc. Mrs. Frederick R. Rinehart has been named president, and Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, minister emeritus of Riverside Church, honorary chairman of the board of directors.

A little-noticed gain in equity values since the first of the year has been revealed in a summary of market prices for the shares of those stout old conservatives of the investment field the twenty largest stock life insurance companies.
The Reader's Digest said yesterday that it would open its American editions to advertising for the first time in its thirty-three-year history beginning next April.
ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- Holders of several hundred lucrative state "patronage" jobs were increasingly fearful today that beginning in January they would give way to Democrats.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 4 -- Assistant County Prosecutor John Mahon today opened the case against Dr. Sam H. Sheppard, 31-year-old osteopath, in the bludgeoning to death of his wife, Marilyn, last July 4. He accused Dr. Sheppard of committing the murder so he could marry Susan Hayes, 24, a medical technician, with whom the Prosecution said "he was infatuated."

The American Metal Company, Ltd, announced three items of good news to its stockholders yesterday: a copper-lead-zinc ore discovery in Canada, a rise in earnings, and increased quarterly and year-end dividends.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country on Tuesday's elections, as gathered by The New York Times, The Associated Press and The United Press:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Peoria Caterpillars, representing the United States in the world basketball tournament, breezed to their sixth straight victory without defeat today with a 74-30 romp over Israel.

Under Averell Harriman, if his election as Governor is ultimately confirmed, the Democratic and Liberal parties in New York are hoping to achieve a "broad political coalition" that will enable the Democrats to remain in power for many elections to come.

A survey of New England culture from 1600 to 1950 is the subject of a new book entitled "Yankees and God," by Chard Powers Smith. Mr. Smith is the author of thirteen books of fiction, poetry and history dealing with religious experience and American history.
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn announced yesterday a plan for a new broad highway link between Brooklyn Bridge and Atlantic Avenue to ease traffic congestion.

Celebrating a 150th anniversary at the same time with Columbia's 200th, the New-York Historical Society's latest Quarterly presents a review of past years in our city since 1805, by R. W. G. Vail, the society's director.

It looks as if Joshua Logan will stage "A Sea Shell" for the Theatre Guild as soon as he is free and clear of "Fanny," which had its premiere last night at the Majestic. That's the impression gathered yesterday from various sources.
The cotton futures market, on moderate activity, fell 4 to 15 points (20 to 75 cents a bale) here yesterday.

Appointment of Hoke S. Simpson of Larchmont, N. Y., as director of executive programs of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University was announced yesterday by Courtney C. Brown, dean of the school.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The United Nations General Assembly asked the five leading atomic powers today to make a new attempt behind closed doors to reach agreement on disarmament and the prohibition of nuclear weapons.
EAST LONGMEADOW, Mass., Nov. 4 (AP) -- State Treasurer Foster Furcolo, defeated Democratic candidate for the Senate, said today he had been "knifed" in Tuesday's Massachusetts election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Administration leaders said today that the Dixon-Yates contract was in the public interest.

The body of a 31-year-old former boxer, apparently a suicide, was found yesterday morning in shrubbery near Grant's Tomb. Several hours later his wife, who had been slain, was found in their East Side apartment.
Three battalion chiefs of the Fire Department were suspended last night by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. on charges of taking $100 bribes.
Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, held a lead last night of 3,308 over his Democratic opponent, Representative Charles R. Howell.

Demonstrating at once that the election results will have no effect on American foreign policy, President Eisenhower has initiated a new and, he hopes, a more encouraging phase in one of the most promising projects he has undertaken -- the creation of an international atomic pool for peaceful purposes.
Eighteen hundred employes'ofI the Jolin Wanamaker departmentl store at Broadway and Eighth Street got union aszurances last night that the chances for keeping the store open were "excellent.'' '

A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted two men and two corporations on charges of conspiracy to defraud the United States Department of Agriculture in the purchase of 445,220 pounds of dried milk from the Government.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- Within five years, 200,000 handicapped persons will be rehabilitated annually under the new Federal program, members of the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults were told today.

The Electric Bond and Share Company, once one of the nation's largest public utility holding companies, reported yesterday that its total assets were $149,564,200 on Sept. 30. This represents a gain of $19,827,200 since the beginning of the year.

TELEVISION'S coverage of the election returns on Tuesday night was probably not too bad in light of the general confusion arising from the close contests and unforeseen late shifts in tabulations. If some of the broadcasters got caught with their statistical projections showing, so did most of the assorted experts, both mortal and electronic.
The National Dairy Products Corporation, the nation's largest dairy producer, increased its earnings by 13 per cent to a record $29,109,930 for the first nine months this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A couple of years ago Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon was kicked out of a paddock by a horse. His complete recovery was demonstrated last Tuesday when he kicked an elephant out of the control room of the United States Senate.

Department stores in the second Federal Reserve District have been setting the pace for all of the nation, except the Boston stores, since the beginning of the year, according to an analysis by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The voting strength of the Liberal party is always of interest in post-election review. Analysis is of more than usual pertinence this year, perhaps, because of some remarks made by David Dubinsky, a top leader, to a party rally last May, when he asked members to consider "whether there is enough political, moral and financial strength in New York to support a party of quality without an early promise of quantity."
NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- The Clarkstown Board voted in an executive session today to amend the town's zoning code to bar monkey farms from the township.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Defense and atomic energy programs will require less steel and copper but slightly more aluminum in the first quarter of next year than they have in the closing three months of this year, the Government disclosed today.

BALBOA, C. Z., Nov. 5 -- Mineral oils, coal and coke, ores and lumber which have been four principal commodities shipped through the Panama Canal since 1952, maintained their competitive position in the first quarter of the current fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- President Eisenhower took part "Crusade in Europe" today as he signed a new international copyright agreement.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- Emphasis in the care of handicapped children should be on the "element of triumph over circumstances, rather than the elements of pitifulness and dependence," Dr. Margaret Mead, anthropologist of New York, asserted today.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- The reaction of the United States Senate to Patrick V. McNamara of Detroit, one of its new members, and of Mr. McNamara to the Senate are being awaited with keen interest in Detroit.
The stumps of trees of a sunken forest at Throgs Neck in Eastchester Bay, the Bronx, have been determined by the "atomic calendar" to be 2,830 years old, with a margin of error of 250 years.
Corporate activity in the new capital market is at a modest level right now, but no let-up is in sight for borrowings by state and local governments.

The newest method of food preservation -- sterilization by electrons -- is about ten years from commercial application, L. B. Sjostrom, head of the food and flavor laboratories of the Arthur D. Little Company, said yesterday.

In his astonishingly incorrect analysis of the Middle East situation and of American interests in that area, which appeared in The New York Times of Nov. 3, C. L. Sulzberger made certain statements concerning the Zionist attitude during the recent elections which we cannot permit to go unchallenged.

A broad, rubbly area on which a public housing development it to be built was dedicated yesterday to the memory of Senator Robert F. Wagner. The project, which will house 2,158 families, besides providing extensive reccreation facilities, is to be built by the New York City Housing Authority with Federal help.

CHERRYFIELD, Me., Nov. 5 -- Tonight the camp is fragrant with exotic odor of frying venison liver, for despite weather conditions that have made successful hunting almost impossible during the first week of the season, one member of the group managed to bring down a deer today.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The stock markets ended the week firm despite profit taking. Prices of industrial shares in particular recovered from an uncertain start.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger (Retired), was formally awarded the fourth star of a full general at a review at nearby Fort Jackson today.
LA PLATTE, Neb., Nov. 5 (UP) -- An airlift was used today to keep contact between the outside world and company officials encamped inside a strikebound nitrogen plant.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 5 (AP) -- William O'Dwyer today paid his first visit in three years to the man who appointed him Ambassador to Mexico -- former President Truman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The White House today announced details of President Eisenhower's flying trip to Boston Monday to address the National Council of Catholic Women.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The trustee of the Missouri Pacific Railroad was authorized today by Federal Judge George H. Moore to make interest payments totaling $66,014,788 on bonds of the Missouri Pacific system.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- The United States announced today its wish that a basis similar to that of United Nations specialized agencies be given to the proposed body thatis to develop the use of atomic energy for peace.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 5 -- A sit-down strike today by sixteen deck and engineering officers of the Egyptian cargo-passenger ship Mohamed Ali el Kebir prevented the unloading of the vessel's cargo at the Eighth Street pier here.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools in New York City, will discuss current problems of the educational system on "The Living Blackboard," a television program on WPIX on Tuesday between 1 and 1:30 P. M. He will appear in connection with New York's "Open School Week," during which parents will have an opportunity to visit schools attended by their children.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas said today the Democrats on the Senate Investigations Committee would not try to interfere with the plan of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to call Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, before the group for questioning.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 4.9 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 4.1 per cent and orders down 9.6 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Maurice Couve de Murville, French representative in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, was approved by the French Cabinet today as Ambassador to the United States.

With the parliamentary machinery of all the countries concerned being geared for swift ratification of the Paris accords, new trouble is being brewed by a revival of an issue that was supposedly settled in Paris -- namely, the Saar. Considering the high stakes involved, it would seem the height of folly to permit a new dispute over this tiny, even if rich, industrial area to imperil the accords themselves.
A 53-year-old valet employed by the Savoy Plaza Hotel was accidentally shot in the hand yesterday when he set off a fountain pen-type pistol in a suit belonging to a hotel guest.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Democratic spokesmen today challenged a Republican claim that Tuesday's "Farm vote" was a victory for the Administration's flexible price support program.
The annual Horse Show Ball, the highlight of social events given in connection with the National Horse Show, was held last night in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Many reservations have been made for the card party and fashion show for the benefit of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, which will be held Monday afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club.

Election of John L. Loeb and Mark J. Millard as directors of the Union Sulphur and Oil Corporation was announced yesterday by Richard T. Lyons, president. Mr. Millard will also serve as a member of the executive committee.

Prime Minister Yoshida of Japan spoke thoughtfully and conservatively when he paid his visit to the United Nations and was questioned about the problem of Japan's membership. Japan, he said, wished and hoped to become a full-fledged member of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.1 per cent to 109.7 per cent of the 1947-49 level in the week ended on Nov. 2, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. There were small increases for all the groupings in the compilation.
Corruption exists in the Police Department, but it must and will be rooted out, Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Arnold Johnson, owner-apparent of the Philadelphia Athletics, today left for Chicago "and a week-end of relaxation -- I hope" with only American League approval needed to clinch the transfer of the club to Kansas City.
The American Labor party's candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor appeared yesterday in Manhattan Traffic Court and were fined $150 each as "parking scofflaws."

YONKERS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Mr. Dean, owned by the Saunders Mills Stable of Toledo, won the $4,000 Woodlawn Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight, with Don Hall in the sulky. Titanic was second and Trustful Hanover third.
LIVINGSTON, N. J., Nov. 5 -- Patrolman Frank Porter was carried on a stretcher into his new house today, a house he had believed was nothing but the shell from which he had fallen Sept. 24.

A GERMAN pianist, renowned rather for technique and pedantry than for poetry or genius, said of a highly successful colleague, "He plays beautifully -- therefore is no musician!" But Oscar Shumsky, violinist, who played to a packed and applauding house last night in Carnegie Hall, is a violinist of superb equipment and also a master musician.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The White House announced today that Albert C. Beeson of California had notified President Eisenhower that because of the illness of his wife he would not be available for reappointment to the National Labor Relations Board.

The State Bridge Building Authority of Georgia announced yesterday that it would receive bids Nov. 18 on an issue of $10,635,000 of bridge revenue bonds. Dated Dec. 1, 1954, the bonds will come due on Dec. 1 from 1956 to 1970.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Following is the text of a letter to Lieut. Gen. Daniel Noce, chairman of the security hearing panel, from John Paton Davies Jr., explaining his views and activities while stationed in China a decade ago:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Charles Harris, 6 weeks old, with his parents and others faced wet and freezing weather in the open Maryland countryside tonight in a test of survival from a simulated atomic bomb attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Joseph Christopher O'Mahoney, the Democratic Senator-elect from Wyoming, is a short and solidly built man with a lantern jaw. His graying sandy hair and blue eyes beneath shaggy brows belie his 70 years.
BANBURY, England, Nov. 5 -- It is the price of pigs rather than the price of peace that worries rural England.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 -- The United States, British and French Governments accepted today the Soviet proposal to release Baron Konstantin von Neurath, Hitler's Foreign Minister until 1938, from the Spandau prison in Berlin because of his advanced age and dangerous state state of health. Von Neurath is 81 yeas old.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Johnny Antonelli, New York Giants' pitching ace, received a hero's welcome and a new Buick from his hometown fans here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Senator Albert Gore predicted today the next Congress under apparent Democratic control will kill the Dixon-Yates power proposal.

YONKERS, Nov. 5 -- Jerry Desio of Harrison and R. C. MacDonald of Kissena Park acquired the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association pro-pro championship today after a three-way sudden-death play-off at Hudson River in the closing event of the Westchester tournament season.

No one questions the good intentions of the traffic regulators in New York City, but one must respectfully question their results. It is well known that taxi drivers object very much to some of the one-way regulations and are refusing to go to certain parts of the city.

One of the few things that stood out sharply in this week's nationwide balloting was the sharpness of the cleavage between the voters in the big cities and in the small towns and rural areas. It was the returns from the rural areas that turned the results from what looked like a possible landslide into a nip-and-tuck fight right down to the finish.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 5 -- Returning to his capital today from a tour of Communist China, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said his visit to Peiping and conferences with Red Chinese rulers had convinced him that the "world situation is improving."

Today's new film is "The World Dances," a feature-length compilation of dances of all varieties, at the Fifty-Fifth Street Playhouse. The offering, directed and produced by Brooke L. Peters, is narrated by George Fenneman.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Morris Creditor, president of the West Virginia Coal and Coke Corporation, last night announced the sale of its 51 per cent interest in Paradise Collieries, Inc., to Investment Associates, Inc.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 5 (UP) -- A plastic surgeon told the New York Yankee pitcher, Allie Reynolds, today no skin graft would be needed on his pitching hand's gashed finger.

The thirteen-story building containing lofts and showrooms on lot 44 by 98 feet at 40-42 West Thirty-seventh Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has been purchased by the 40 West Thirty-seventh Street Corporation, Philip Weiss, president, from a syndicate represented by Leight Leight, attorneys.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Port of New York Authority urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to give New York railroad freight rates comparing favorably with Philadelphia and Baltimore on iron ore moving out of the respective ports.

One novelty was on the program of the piano recital that Walter Hautzig gave last night in Town Hall. It was Poulenc's "Theme Varie," listed as a first New York performance. It was typical Poulenc -- fluent, melodic, often irreverent, amusing and lightweight.

Bail totaling $75,000 was imposed in Felony Court yesterday on six teen-agers, a building superintendent and their alleged 19-year-old kidnapping and torture victim. The police said the latter had been held captive for three days in a basement while the others beat, burned and starved him into revealing where he had hidden $1,000.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Unusually adroit diplomacy has helped raise Britain's prestige in Europe to a post-war high during recent months. This perceptible trend coincides with the United Kingdom's economic recovery and also with deliberate American efforts to play a somewhat less audible role in Continental affairs.
Averell Harriman's razor-edged plurality for Governor was narrowed still further yesterday on the basis of official findings by Boards of Elections in seven counties outside of New York City.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture called today for a 10 per cent reduction next year in sugar beet plantings in a move to prevent overproduction.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., Nov. 5 -- The hottest horn here today is a B-flat trumpet bearing the notation "Made in Germany, U. S. S. R. Occupied Zone."
DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Chevrolet moved back into first place in the auto industry's production standing this week as new model production was stepped up.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 5 (AP) -- A Federal juror, charged with contempt of court after failing to appear for the last half of a United States District Court trial Wednesday, was sentenced to thirty days in jail today by Judge Leslie R. Darr.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Pittsburgh's Bob Baker, outweighing his opponent by 31 1/2 pounds, climbed the heavyweight division ladder tonight by overpowering Jimmy Slade of New York to win a unanimous ten-round decision at the arena.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 -- California designers, presenting their collections for National Press Week, have provided excitement aplenty for the seventy editors gathered from all parts of the country. The week closes tomorrow with a men's wear showing at the Coronado Hotel, Coronado.
Eleven thousand Sanitation Department employes will receive wage increases that will cost the city $2,500,000 a year.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (Reuters) -- The Soviet oil industry is producing ahead of schedule and the eastern oil fields in the Volga region and the Bashkir and Tatar republics, are now supplying more than half of the oil produced in the Soviet Union, Nikolai K. Baibakov, Minister of the Oil Industry, said today.

ONE of the most romantic and gifted of American artists and naturalists, John James Audubon, is honored in a large exhibition of his paintings, prints and memorabilia being held at the Kennedy Galleries for the benefit of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory in Bar Harbor, Me.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5 -- The Yale football team puts its undefeated record on the line tomorrow when it meets once-beaten Army in the Bowl.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Preliminary steps toward establishing a news censorship in event of war were taken by the Government today.

The Federal Civil Service Commission has before it a proposal to remove from civil service requirements and protection ten positions now held by career employes of the Railroad Retirement Board, no one of whom has had less than fifteen years of service with the board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- An appeal to the incoming Eighty-fourth Congress to measure up to the record of the Supreme Court and the Eisenhower Administration in the field of civil rights was made here today as the Board of Governors of B'nai B'rith opened its three-day annual meeting.

CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 5 -- A lanky farm boy from Warner, N. H., who absorbed a basic political philosophy in his father's barnyard forty years ago, was certified today as New Hampshire's junior Republican Senator.

Ammon Hennacy, associate editor of The Catholic Worker and author of the "Autobiography of a Catholic Anarchist," was found guilty in Lower Manhattan Court yesterday of sell ing both the periodical and his book without a license.

ERIE, Pa., Nov. 5 (AP) -- An Erie County grand jury today indicted Mayor Thomas W. Flatley, two Democratic leaders and twelve others on charges ranging from bribery and conspiracy to accepting bribes in connection with an alleged gambling syndicate.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 5 -- Ten Yale University undergraduates climbed to the top of the 216-foot Harkness Tower today and heralded the observance of the Centennial of Music Instruction with brass instruments. The "tower music" was a throwback of methods used to announce public events in Europe centuries ago.
Following is the text of Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams' remarks at the police promotion exercises:

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 4 -- Premier Adnan Menderes will pay an official visit to Egypt in the coming months to associate Cairo with Turkey's effort to create a collective security organization in the Middle East. He also is expected to visit Iraq, Lebanon and possibly other Arab countries at the same time.

The $50,000 added Roamer Handicap will be contested at the Jamaica race track today. It is expected that eight will compete in the mile-and-three-sixteenths test, the final stakes event on the New York calendar for 3-year-olds.

The literary magazines of today are but the modern versions of those published a hundred years ago, with one gasconading change. Each poem, each story or article now has the neatly blocked name of the author under its title.

The current bent of Broadway producers to test their products in London before unfolding them locally has caught the eye of Richard Charlton. Instead of presenting "The Open Window" here this winter, Mr. Charlton has decided on a West End presentation for the Lenore Coffee-William Cowen Joyce suspense play.

The demands of the International Longshoremen's Association in New York have again been "revised" and the union has asked for a meeting with the negotiators of the New York Shipping Association for Monday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock.

Short covering, commission house buying and dealer purchasing strengthened wool prices yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading was influenced by the news that the Australian wool auctions would be closed next week because of a dock strike there.

Events today: Richard Gregor, pianist, Town Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Ruth Budnevich, pianist, and Herbert Tichman, clarinetist, Town Hall, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony, Franco Autori conducting, Ruggiero Ricci, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Selma Schechtman, pianist, Town Hall; 8:30; Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, soprano, Hunter College, 8:30.
OTTAWA, Nov. 5 UP) -- Losses from bad weather and other hazards have cut Canada's wheat crop to 298,913,000 bushels, the lowest in eleven years, the Bureau of Statistics estimated today.

OTTAWA, Nov. 5 -- Food and equipment left behind nearly fifty years ago by Rear Admiral Robert E. Peary's expedition into the Arctic were used this summer by a joint United States-Canadian expedition studying ice conditions off Ellesmere Island.

The New Jersey Senatorial race continued unresolved last night, and it was becoming increasingly clear that a recount of ballots in at least a few counties would be demanded by Democratic leaders. Yesterday morning the leaders sent lawyers to nineteen counties in an effort to obtain court orders to impound ballot boxes and voting machines.

Eastern Air Lines reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $1,789,824, or 72 cents a share. This compares with $2,795,911 or $1.13 a share in the similar period of 1953. Gross operating revenues amounted to $127,915,987, an increase of 16 per cent over the $110,633,221 in the 1953 period.
A test that had all the elements of a race produced a first victory for a United States rider and his mount at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.
The city ferryboat Miss New York cruised upriver and down the Bay yesterday after an extensive overhaul.
United HIAS Service, Jewish international migration agency, announced yesterday a campaign in 1955 to raise $3,500,000. The campaign committee is headed by Reynold Greenberg of Philadelphia.
A high standard of community health is one of our greatest economic assets. Good col lective health means less absenteeism, better morale and greater efficiency in any kind of business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The United States is arranging a mutual defense pact with Nationalist China. It is understood to commit the Nationalist Chinese not to attack the Communist Chinese mainland except in self-defense.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- The I portwide shutdown of dry cargo handling, caused by a dispute !over the work status of a long{shore gang foreman, entered its second week t6day with no solu:tion in sight.

The New York Botanical Garden held a preview yesterday of its annual indoor chrysanthemum show. The title is "Reflection of Old Japan." Thousands of mums, from the large show types to the tiny button varieties, are on display.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- John Paton Davies Jr., a career diplomat for twenty-three years, was dismissed from the Federal service today on the ground of "lack of judgment, discretion and reliability."

ROME, Nov. 5 -- A sudden demand by the Right-Wing Socialists for a Cabinet shuffle has indefinitely postponed the Government's crackdown on communism. Such a crackdown was considered imminent at the beginning of this week.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 -- A West German Government spokesman said today that French-German conversations on the "execution, interpretation and possibly supplementation" of the Saar probably would take plate in Bonn next week.
Doris Hornburg, an attractive young lady with a beautiful soprano voice that is being ruined through lack of singing skill, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- America should go slow in preaching the value of free enterprise and competition abroad while it erects "unreasonable" barriers to foreign competition in its own markets, Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of Trans World Airlines, asserted here today.
Army makes its appearance in the Yale Bowl today for the renewal of one of football's most exciting and profitable rivalries after an interval of eleven years.

ALTHOUGH it is sometimes hard to express the genius of this Republic without sounding like a Fourth of July oration, Emily Davies comes through splendidly in "Profile of America,"* How does she do that? Why, by salting her narrative with just such quotations as the one above, which is an alarmed observation made by a French novelist after watching an American football game.
The mercury market is showing signs of weakness after a year-long price climb to the highest levels in history.

The Chrysler Corporation, third largest automobile producer of the nation, experienced a loss of $12,067,277 in the third quarter this year, reducing its net earnings for the nine months 93.3 per cent below the corresponding period of 1953.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 5 -- The outbreak of terrorism in Algeria has destroyed the widely held conviction that this French North African province was secure against the nationalist convulsions with which the French have had to contend in Morocco and Tunisia.

MONTREAL, Nov. 5 -- Montreal's new "reform" administration began its first day of office today. It promised to rid the city of vice, reorganize the police department and provide "just" government for the next three years.

A retail center is planned in Lodi, N. J., where a tract of eleven acres at Route 17 and Essex Street has been purchased by Ercole Tamburelli of Englewood, builder, from the Bruan Realty Company of Maywood. The sale was made through the Alexander Summer Company as broker.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 5 -- Dr. Giora Josephthal, treasurer and head of the Absorption Department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, asked the help today of the United Jewish Appeal to accomplish five basic tasks. He spoke before a mission of thirty-five U. J. A. leaders who are here to study Israel's needs.

The two Russian scientists who attended the closing events of Columbia University's bicentennial celebration began their homeward journey last night in an Air France plane from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 5 -- Federal charters may provide the only practical means whereby new mutual savings banks may be established, Hamilton Cheston, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Apparatus that nips airplane fuel-tank explosions while they are starting was patented this week by two British inventors.
Listed stocks on the New York Stock Exchange fell from an average value of $48.94 a share at the end of September to $48.06 at the end of October, the Exchange reported yesterday.

The National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association announced that Jerome H. Stanek was elected president at its annual convention in Dayton, Ohio, yesterday. He is vice president of the Stanek Tool and Manufacturing Company, Milwaukee.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Six more berths were nailed down today on the American rifle and pistol team that will represent the United States in the International Shooting Union world championships in Caracas, Venezuela, Nov. 15-24.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of Mr. Davies reply to Mr. Dulles statement:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Following is the text of a statement today by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative, on international cooperation in developing the peaceful uses of atomic energy and the report of the United States:

The value of all goods and services produced in the United States will probably rise 50 per cent during the next ten years, Dr. Gordon W. McKinley, chief economist of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said yesterday. He spoke at the annual finance conference of the American Management Association in the Roosevelt Hotel.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 5 -- Dr. Eugenio Gudin, Minister of Finance, said today that despite the strong forces fighting the reforms he has suggested to stabilize Brazil's financial position, there was no question of his leaving the Cabinet.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement today by Secretary of State Dulles in connection with the dismissal of John Paton Davies Jr.:

Twelve members of the International Boxing Guild, a managers' group, and promoters of various fight arenas here, yesterday were ordered by Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, to appear at a hearing next Friday.

Firm intentions to prevent West German armament, concentrated efforts to see the withdrawal of American troops from Europe and the retention of the European status quo impressed a recently returned British delegation as the primary Russian objectives at this time.

Since the I. L. A., in the N. L. R. B. election, received the right to represent the New York dock workers the major burden of cleaning out gangsterism and racketeering on the docks has fallen to the Waterfront Commission. The defeat of the A. F. L. union, dedicated to that end, eliminated the best hope of doing the job thoroughly and quickly.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Nov. 5 -- Bernard A. Petrone, an accountant of 572 Varsity Road, South Orange, N, J., was held here today in $50,000 bail on warrants charging him with two forgeries totaling $6,994 against a Red Bank, N. J., building equipment concern.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Peoria (Ill.) Caterpillars, representing the United States, tonight won the second world basketball tournament, defeating Brazil, 62 -- 41. Each team entered the game unbeaten in six games.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received on Thursday 719 pints of blood. Included were 201 pints donated at Fort Monmouth, N. J., on the first of a two-day bloodmobile visit, and 150 taken at the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., Murray Hill, N. J.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Boston College Eagles used a strong running attack tonight to defeat Marquette, 13 -- 7, in an intersectional football game before 15,000 fans in near-freezing temperatures at Hilltop Stadium.

Establishment of a new series of radio installations across the Atlantic to meet the mounting volume of air passenger traffic between North America and Europe has been recommended by the International Civil Aviation Organization.
MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- A note of triumph was beginning to be heard today in the reports on the Soviet Union's accomplishments that are regularly issued on the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.
Inspector Francis W. Lent of the Division of Licenses headed the list of eighteen men promoted yesterday by Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The appeals board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has ruled against a decision of Director General Luther Evans to discontinue the employment of four United States citizens.
Clergymen and laymen of the Roman Catholic, Protestant an Jewish faiths will attend a national conference on "The Spiritual Foundations of Our Democracy" Monday through Wednesday in Washington.

ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- The twentieth annual State Conference on Parent Education ended here today with the 100 conferees affirming their faith in the ability of parents to raise their children well and urging closer cooperation among all those who have the best interests of children at heart.
The new management of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad believes that the company's board should not be limited to residents of New England to the degree it is today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders were invited by President Eisenhower today to join him and his Secretary of State Nov. 17 in a review of foreign policy.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- A clock winder died today in the gears of his favorite clock in the Gothic tower above Fleet Street.

Sterling Drug, Inc., and its subsidiaries yesterday reported a 14 per cent increase in nine-month earnings and declared an extra dividend of 25 cents and the regular quarterly of 50 cents on the common, to be paid on Dec. 1. No extra was paid last year.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Britain is preparing to associate formally with the European Coal and Steel Community. However, this association will fall far short of the hopes of the members of the pool.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 5 -- Defense counsel for Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard managed to score some points by attacking the autopsy report in day-long cross-examination in Common Pleas court here today. The young osteopath is accused of brutally slaying his wife so he could marry another woman.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 5 -- Oregon Democrats, in a jubilant post-election mood, were hopeful today that Richard L. Neuberger's successful. Senatorial campaign would lead to the restoration of committee assignments to Senator Wayne Morse.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Midwestern bankers were told today that present tax laws discourage the use of ordinary business judgment in the sale of business interests and spur mergers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that acreage allotments will be necessary for the 1955 corn crop in 805 commercial producing counties in twenty-one states.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Andrew W. Cordier, executive assistant to Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjold, left for San Francisco by plane tonight to study the possibility of holding a session of the General Assembly there next year.

Despite a court order, Frank Costello refused again yesterday to answer questions at a Government-held pre-trial denaturalization hearing. The 62-year-old gambler took refuge in the Fifth Amendment, contending that his answers might incriminate him in a criminal action.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Armour Co. lost more than $5,500,000 on operations in the first forty-four weeks of its fiscal year, the big packing company disclosed today. However, tax credits and adjustment of tax reserves resulted in net income for the forty-four weeks of $651,418.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Inventories in the hands of manufacturers and distributors at the end of September were $4,300,000,000 below those of a year before, the Government disclosed today. They had a book value of $77,400,000,000.

Herman H. Golub has purchased a one-family dwelling at 63-75 Dry Harbor Road in West Forest Hills, Queens, from Meyer Monchek. The sale was made through Morris Levin as broker and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain, whose own wardrobe is scrutinized by the public, went to the Smithsonian Institution today to look at inaugural gowns worn by all the First Ladies of the United States.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman paid warm tribute last night to Asser Levy, one of twenty-three Jewish settlers who came to this country 300 years ago.

On Nov. 28, 1953, Picasso began a series of sketches that had as the central idea the relationship between an artist and his model. By Feb. 5, 1954, he had completed 180 of them. The collection, with sixteen in full color, will be published Nov. 18 by Harcourt, Brace under the title "Picasso and the Human Comedy."

The Cruising Club of America held its annual meeting and dinner at the New York Yacht Club last night and elected Harvey Conover, widely known in yacht racing circles as the owner of the yawl Revonoc, as its commodore.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., NOV. 5 -- The Western powers were voted down today in the opening round of their campaign to keep Bulgaria out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Transport and General Workers Union and the employers in the Port of Liverpool announced today that they had reached an agreement on overtime employment of dock workers there.

I read Albion Ross' four articles on Africa. They are quite provocative, but to the average American who read them the issues raised might be confusing. Perhaps this is to be expected in such a report covering a continent as large and diverse as Africa.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 -- A special meeting of stockholders of Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc., has been called for Nov. 16 to vote on a proposal to increase the authorized cumulative preferred stock from 136,624 to 260,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- An American Airlines twin-engine Convair, carrying thirteen passengers and three crew members, made an emergency landing at Washington National Airport today after circling the field for more than two hours.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Maria Meneghini-Callas, American soprano, sang the leading role in "Norma" tonight for the Lyric Theatre in the Civic Opera House, although disturbed over a suit filed in Circuit Court charging her with breach of contract.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Nov. 5 -- Gov. Charles H. Russell pointedly disassociated himself today from any attempt by Senator Ernest S. Brown, Republican, to block the seating in January of Alan Bible, Democrat, as successor to the late Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat.
Notices posted in some city firehouses have exhorted firemen to go to Washington Thursday to attend a rally in support of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
Paced by John J. Rosenbaum, who repeated his 1953 victory, Cornell reained the team title in the sixteenth annual Heptagonal Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A British manufacturer today won a $1,066,662 contract from the United States Army in a major test of the Administration's new policy on the "Buy American" Act.

Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan warned the United States last night not to be deceived by the Communist "peace offensive" in Asia. He asserted that the whole of Southeast Asia was a major target of the Communists and that conquest of Japan was their ultimate aim in the Pacific.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Fairly active early buying lifted all wheat deliveries except the December to new crop highs, but the demand faded at that point and there was a sharp recession that canceled all gains.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The rise of a slave to a position of power is an age-old theme of Arab story-tellers. As if to prove that times have not changed completely, the saga was repeated when Saudi Arabia's King Saud appointed a new Minister of Finance to handle his country's oil revenues.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- More French reinforcements are being poured into Algeria to meet the threat of terrorist bands who became suddenly active at the beginning of the week and who continue to hold out in the high mountains in the eastern part of the country.
RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The state of war between Burma and Japan officially ended tonight with the signing of a peace treaty.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- To overcome the obstruction he encountered at the outset of debate on the budget, Premier Pierre Mendes-France asked today for a vote of confidence against the delaying tactics in the National Assembly.
The cotton futures market closed steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, 9 to 16 points higher than Thursday on active months.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Recent strength in hogs encouraged the country to loosen up supplies today and the upshot was an overrun of 3,000 head. All cleared well, although not until sellers were accepting 25 to 50 cents lower prices. Cattle moved at steady to 50 cents lower levels. Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Madeleine de Rauch introduces knee length skirts, kilts, felt shorts, bare knees and high wool socks for ski and after-skiware. Mme. de Rauch is a sports woman herself who never stumbles into the fancy dress field.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- Rock Hudson will start the new year by going from Universal to star in "Giant," the George Stevens-Henry Ginsberg production of the Edna Ferber novel.
Stocks fought off a wave of selling in the early hours of yesterday's market, held their own in the afternoon and closed moderately lower.

The Riverdale Towers apartment house at 3103 Fairfield Avenue in Riverdale, the Bronx, has been sold by Daniel Pepper to clients of Harry Koeppel, lawyer. The structure, erected by Campagna Brothers in 1948, contains 108 apartments and is assessed at $1,100,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Department of Justice announced today that the Board of Immigration Appeals had upheld a deportation order against Dick Haymes, Argentine-born singer. Federal Judge Alexander Holtzoff restrained the Government from deporting him immediately.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Lord Ismay, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, warned tonight it would be an "absolute mockery" of the Atlantic alliance's exertions if a slackening-off were to start in the belief that the Soviet threat had passed.
The 1955 Ford passenger cars to be introduced Friday will have a new body that required changing 570 major welding fixtures in Ford assembly plants, the company announced yesterday.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Social Outcast veered in the home stretch and nearly threw Eric Guerin today but the jockey, his right foot out of the stirrup, clung to the Vanderbilt horse and drove to a three-length victory in the $42,450 Narragansett Special at Narragansett Park.
Early action by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams to purge his department of corruptive influences was predicted yesterday at City Hall.

Today is the thirty-seventh anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution which brought Communist rule to Russia. As usual, the anniversary in Moscow will be made the occasion for speeches of self-congratulation, displays of Soviet armed might and parades to affirm "the toilers' spontaneous enthusiasm."
SOMERVILLE, N. J., Nov. 6 -- The wife of a prominent Princeton University geneticist and an amputee veteran of World War II were killed tonight in a head-on collision that injured four others.

ONE morning in early October, 1934, 11-year-old Peter Karageorgevich was gently roused from his bed in an English preparatory school to be told that his father had been murdered and he must immediately return to his native country to ascend the throne.

One small tablet of a new drug, Su-3088, taken before breakfast reduces blood pressure to normal throughout the day, Dr. Keith S. Grimson, Professor of Surgery at Duke Medical School and Duke Hospital, informs the American College of Physicians.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 6 (UP) -- The undefeated Arkansas Razorbacks, led by their sophomore tailback, George Walker, won their fifth straight Southwest Conference victory today with a 28-to-15 victory over Rice.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Tulane, aided by the booming punts of Quarterback John Caruso, held favored Alabama to a scoreless tie today before 22,000 homecoming fans, the largest crowd of Tulane's winless season.

THE leading female love interest of this novel is a personable Nova Scotian of 24 sea-breeze summers whose husband deserted her three years ago to fritter his time away dabbling in oils in Sunny California. As the story opens she is confronted with a major problem: What can she use as an excuse for a divorce?

FROM the time the white settlements of Virginia and New England began to crowd back the Indians in the early seventeenth century to the final subjugation of the Arizona Apaches in the late nineteenth, these two races fought each other along a moving frontier.

COLOR photography has been made so easy for the man in the street that many amateur photographers, and even some professionals who would feel handicapped in black-and-white photography without a fair mastery of the medium, blithely tackle color with no more than box-camera knowledge.

A majority of American college and university graduates are seriously deficient in business knowledge, a study of 150 leading institutions of higher learning shows. Large numbers of students, it was found, lack even an elementary understanding of practical, every-day business information.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Missouri's Bob Bauman smashed two feet with a minute and six seconds remaining for a touchdown that gave a 19-19 tie to Missouri against Colorado today in a Big Seven football game that probably eliminated both teams from Orange Bowl consideration.

ONE of my favorite art world stories concerns the sage advice offered me by one of its knowing inhabitants: "Never trust what a collector says he paid for a picture. The amount will be greater or less than the truth depending upon whether he wishes to appear rich or canny."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 6 -- William F. Van Tent of Manhattan, a polio victim, arrived at Mitchel Air Force Base tonight from Saudi Arabia after what Air Force officials described as the longest mercy flight on record with a patient in a "flying lung."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- Australian scientists, jolting in snub-nosed trucks and jeeps across hills and over seemingly endless plains, have mapped more than 300,000 square miles of Australia's Northland.

ROME, Nov. 6 -- The Right-Wing Socialist party abandoned today its intention of placing before Premier Mario Scelba the clear alternatives of submitting to a Cabinet shuffle or facing a Cabinet crisis.

RANDOLPH, Vt. -- Beyond the great bend of the Hudson at Glens Falls, and beyond the outflow of Lake George at Ticonderoga begins the almost 100-mile-long Champlain Valley, for the motorist a land of enchantment during Vermont's Indian Summer.
BLAWNOX, Pa., Nov. 3 -- Twenty-six inmates of the Allegheny County Workhouse here became students this week in a televised course of studies that may eventually bring high school diplomas.

ZAANDAM, The Netherlands, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- Preparations are being made here for another attempt to salvage smuggled gold valued at $20,000,000 believed to be aboard a German ship torpedoed by British warships off the Dutch coast in 1917.

RED BANK, N. J., Nov. 6 -- Harry Estelle, a former Red Bank school janitor, whose autopsy had been ordered by a court to determine the cause of a long illness, died today at Riverview Hospital

A., retired, from 1942 to 1945 chief of the basic economy department of the Inter-American Affairs Organization and director of its health and sanitation division, died Oct. 4 in the Letterman Army Hospital, San Francisco, the Army announced yesterday.
BOSTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Sammy Pino ran through and around Villanova's line for 150 yards and two touchdowns today as Boston University rallied for a 28-6 triumph over the unvictorious Wildcats.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Halfback Dan Cline's 21-yard touchdown pass to Quarterback Jim Maddock in the closing seconds of the first half carried Michigan to a 14-7 victory over Illinois today and kept alive the Wolverines' Big Ten title hopes before 58,812 fans at Michigan Stadium.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Vanderbilt's line checked Kenucky's first team for twelve minutes today, but couldn't stop Dan Netoskie, a second-string halfback, as the Wildcats rolled up three second-quarter touchdowns for a 19-7 victory before 28,000.

WACO, Tex., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Quarterback Billy Hooper scored two touchdowns and made a fourth-quarter gamble pay off today as he led Baylor to a 13-7 victory over Texas in a nationally televised football game.

BONN, Nov. 6 -- With the ratification of the Paris agreements seemingly assured, the question of Germany's reunification is gradually moving to the forefront as the major European problem for the great powers and a national issue for the German people.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The shots fired Monday night by the nationalist terrorists in Algeria came as a shock to Frenchmen. While the protectorates of Tunisia and Morocco had been the scenes of bloodshed and disorder in the last few years, Algeria, legally almost as integral a part of France as Normandy, had remained calm and seemingly impervious to the nationalist currents that had swept its two neighbors.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- Industrial activity in Pennsylvania during September gained 1 per cent over August, but was still 14 per cent below that of a year ago, according to the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University.

TORONTO, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, enjoying their most productive night of the season, scored four times in the second period tonight and went on to whip the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game.

After what former Ambassador George F. Kennan describes as a "long ordeal of unfortunate, repetitious investigations and uncertainties," John Paton Davies Jr., career diplomat of twenty-three years' experience, has been dismissed from the federal service.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Coast Guard Academy's powerful ground and air attacks defeated Rensselaer 35 -- 7, this afternoon before a Parents' Day crowd of 2,500.

IN 1953, one of the Horatio Alger Awards for business men who, from humble beginnings have gone to the top, went to Col. Henry Crown of Chicago. The Alger people chose better than they knew. In 1953 Colonel Crown was merely the multimillionaire head of a building materials firm.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 6 -- Another increase over a year ago for department store sales bore out earlier estimates that advance Christmas shopping this year got off to an early start. The four weeks' volume for the St. Louis area is now 4 per cent above a year ago.

UNTIL the ground freezes there will be need for careful attention to the water requirements of plants. Whenever this subject is discussed, gardeners hear the phrase, "water deeply." They may also hear such terms as water tables, water absorption and percolation, and soil composition.

DALLAS, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Southern Methodist's offense clicked all the way only once today, but it was enough to beat Texas A and M, 6 to 3, and keep the Mustangs in the Southwest Conference championship race.

LIKE a visiting relative who overstays his welcome, an unwanted tree stump in the back yard may require ingenuity and quite a lot of effort to dislodge. How to get rid of it is a real poser to the home owner, who would like an "easy way out."
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Jacob M. Arvey, Democratic National Committeeman for Illinois, was honored tonight for his services in speeding the recognition of Israel and aiding in her economic up-building.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's special representative, Gen. J. Lawton Collins, is arriving here at a critical moment in the struggle to prevent communism from grabbing another big chunk of Southeast Asia.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- The Judge Baker Guidance Center has received a $1,200,000 grant from the Hiram Edward Manville Foundation of New York to build and maintain a combined clinic and residence for the psychiatric treatment and education of disturbed children.
A rare species of woodpecker, unreported in the East for twenty years, has been sighted near Ossining.
The Jewish Book Council of America, of which the National Jewish Welfare Board is sponsor, will cite thirty-five Jewish authors for contributions to the literature of American Jewish history.

Further discussions of various aspects of a mutual defense pact between Nationalist China and the United States have again emphasized the position of the islands off the China coast that are still held by the Nationalists. One group, the Tachens, has again been under Communist attack during the past week.

RICHMOND, Nov. 6 -- Department store trade in the Fifth Re serve District in October was 2 per cent higher than in that month last year but volume for the year to date remains 1 per cent below the 1953 total. Sharp gains in the last two weeks of October were general throughout the district and with the advent of cold weather retailers are confident that the upswing will continue.

MONTREAL, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, continuing his near goal-a-game pace, scored twice as the Canadiens rallied to gain a 4-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight before 14,451 fans. Montreal took undisputed possession of the National Hockey League lead, breaking a tie with Detroit.

LATE fall is the recommended time (November is ideal) for planting lilacs. As lilacs are natives of rather cold climates, their rugged root systems recover quickly after transplanting and continue to make new growth until the ground becomes impenetrably frozen.

The Christmas fund of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club will be the beneficiary of a cocktail party and pageant of Christmas trees through the ages to be held on Nov. 18 in the St. Regis Roof. Mrs. Charles M. Amory, Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting and Mrs. Donald B. Tansill are co-chairmen of the executive committee for the benefit.

LONGPORT, N. J., Nov. 6 -- A St. Albans, N. Y., Air Force staff sergeant scheduled to be discharged from service tomorrow was believed to have been killed when his car crashed through a guard rail of the Longport - Somerspoint bridge early today and sank in forty feet of water in Risley Channel.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Gilbert Grandval, who, as military governor and then as French Ambassador, has ruled the territory of the Saar for the past nine years, announced today his voluntary resignation, to take effect as the French-German accords on the Saar become effective.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The former Chief of Staff of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization in Palestine was quoted today as having said that it "undoubtedly would have been more peaceful if another place on the globe than Palestine had been found for the Jews to build up their nation."
"Who is John Paton Davies? Part and parcel of the old Acheson * * * group which did so much toward delivering [China] into Communist hands." SENATOR MCCARTHY.
In his first sermon yesterday morning as assistant to Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, 117 East Eighty-fifth Street, Rabbi Sol Roth condemned "satisfied Americanism."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower and Senator Frederick G. Payne, Republican of Maine, both decided today that Mr. Payne should not leave the Senate to take the fifteen-year, $17,500 post of Controller General.

Mr. Lardner's invidious comparison of wrestling to chess -- "If honest, it [wrestling] is as wild as a chess game" -- betrays a woeful lack of understanding, even passing acquaintance, with chess. Baseball, football, boxing, wrestling, etc., have their fans; bullfighting its aficionados; golf its devotees.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today proclaimed Thursday, Nov. 25, as Thanksgiving Day and called on all citizens to observe the day with prayer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The approval by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles of the presentation of credentials by the American Ambassador to Israel at Jerusalem instead of at Tel Aviv was hailed here tonight.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 6 -- Louisiana's voters apparently approved a constitutional amendment that legislative leaders said would continue racial segregation in the public schools. There was, however, a difference of opinion as to what the proposal actually would accomplish.

THERE was quite a bit of sound, and some fury, in Chicago where the Theatre Owners of America gathered in annual convention last week. Hollywood producers were once again a prime target of criticism; first, for not making more pictures; secondly, for demanding rental payments, which, the theatre operators aver, leave them too slim a margin of profit.

VARIABLE winds blow, indeed, at the big red house in Canada where the busy Whiteoak clan is in session again. Renny's daughter Adeline is to marry Maitland Fitzturgis from Ireland, and Eden's capricious natural daughter Roma is to wed Norman Green.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France outlined today his plans for increased worker housing and for a stricter application of the minimum wage.

The last two great international expositions were both held in this country in the same year, 1939. The world had been at peace for more than twenty years when the Golden Gate Exposition in San Francisco opened its doors to the public on Feb. 18 that year, to be followed on April 30 by the New York World's Fair.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- So far as six-week-old Charles Harris is concerned, war is what Sherman said it is.
Whenever Sam Landorf feels discouraged about business prospects, he gets out the census forecast on the number of children in the United States -- and is cheered.
Following are the results of Congressional contests that were undecided and listed in Thursday's tabulation in The New York Times as in doubt:
THE influential role of television in politics no longer can be questioned after this fall's campaign and the extraordinarily close election of last Tuesday. The TV camera is the new machine boss.
Attila the Hun, quite ignored by moviemakers up to now, is about to step into the limelight in two new films. One, "Sign of the Pagan," made in Hollywood by Universal, stars Jack Palance as Attila.
After six successive losses, Wagner College celebrated homecoming day yesterday with a 13-0 victory over Susquehanna University before 4,400 spectators at Grymes Hill, Staten Island.
Stocks soared as the votes were tallied last week.
The heat's on in millions of American homes. And the battle to supply it grows hotter daily among the producers of oil, gas and coal as well as the manufacturers of equipment for the three fuels.

THE Shenandoah Central Railroad is going out of business because of Hurricane Hazel, and no more will "Tweetsie," the galloping little fifty-ton 4-6-0 steam locomotive whistle around the narrow gauge museum line at Penn Laird, near Harrisonburg, Va.

Shipping industry executives do not believe the inevitable reshuffling of Congressional committees as a result of last Tuesday's Democratic victories will affect materially the maritime legislative outlook.

Furniture and decorations covering the popular range of English and French periods and an unusual collection of books on cookery will be auctioned this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Defense Department is trying to pull together various proposals of the separate armed forces into a unified service pay-rise plan for presentation to the next Congress.
ALBANY, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Thruway Authority now has fourteen garages under contract to provide emergency services to disabled vehicles on the 366-mile stretch of the expressway open to toll traffic.
SOMERVILLE, N. J., Nov. 6 -- The ghost of an election in the last century has risen to haunt officials confounded by the question of who won the one held just last Tuesday.

With Fullback Jake Jacobowitz accounting for all his team's points, New Utrecht High won by 13-12 to stop New Dorp's winning streak at four in a Division 2 P. S. A. L. football game yesterday at Lincoln Field, Brooklyn.
ALFRED, N. Y., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Alfred University was knocked out of football's unbeaten ranks tonight by Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy, 18 -- 15.
Important aeronautical research, particularly the type related to guided missiles, is generally conducted far at sea or in desert wastes.
A Port Authority patrolman and a Narcotics Squad detective exchanged nine shots early yesterday morning at Seventh Avenue and 120th Street in a case of mistaken identity.
