TODAY'S agenda consists of four oratorios -- Handel's Messiah, Haydn's The Creation, Mendelssohn's St. Paul and Delius' A Mass of Life. The first two, of course, are fairly well known, for this is the seventh LP "Messiah" and the second LP "Creation," but the other two had to wait for the long-playing process to be recorded in their entirety.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Overtures toward cooperation with the Eisenhower Administration came from leading Democrats at the Capitol today. Conditions were set, however, and some campaign scars still were in evidence.
David H. Dawson has been appointed assistant general manager of the textile fibers department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., Wilmington, Del.

Some forms of heart disease and cancer, as well as diabetes and mental disease, have a tendency to run in families, according to the statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. New evidence of such tendency has recently become available from a study of the mortality experience of a large number of life insurance companies from 1935 to 1950.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Tony DeMarco, the seventh ranking welterweight contender from Boston, floored Pat Manzi of Syracuse three times in the first round to gain a technical knockout at 1:06 tonight at the Arena. DeMarco weighed 145 1/2 pounds, Manzi 146 1/2.
OTTAWA, Nov. 6 -- Canada will have a little election of her own on Monday. Twenty-one candidates are contesting six vacant seats in the Federal Parliament at Ottawa.

LIKE a fresh breeze from an old culture, the Ballets Espagnols of Teresa and Luisillo blew into the Mark Hellinger Theatre last week and restored the flush of youth to the face of the Spanish dance, which has been fairly haggard of late in these parts.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov, 6 -- Brazilian commentators, still puzzling over the significance of the Democratic election victories in the United States, agree that no major change affecting them is likely to develop.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 6 -- Mexico is slowly but steadily gaining ground in her drive to increase agricultural production.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 6 -- There is reason to believe that the extreme nationalist party, known as the Movement for the Triumph of Democratic Liberties, headed by Messali Hadj, had something to do with the outbreak of terrorism in Algeria Monday.

Japanese shipbuilders have landed contracts to build six large oil tankers and one large bulk ore carrier, it was learned yesterday. The vessels total 236,000 deadweight tons and will cost $25,000,000. Negotiations for additional bulk cargo tonnage are said to be in progress.

TO many Southerners, Hibiscus rosa sinensis is the "queen of shrubs." The graceful habit, the beautiful, glossy, evergreen leaves and the gorgeous, colorful blossoms all help make the Rose of China, or Chinese hibiscus, a top-flight landscape addition.
VIENNA, Nov. 6 -- Hungary has been told not only that she must reorganize her economy to restore the main accent to agriculture but that she must reorganize her agriculture itself.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 6 -- Production of steel in the Cleveland-Lorain district dipped slightly to 87.5 per cent from the previous week's revised rate of 88 per cent, but continued about 14 per cent above the national rate. Officials of steel plants in this area predict that production will remain high for the balance of this year and might carry over into the first quarter of next year.

BACH: Musical Offering: Scarlatti Orchestra of Naples, conducted by Giorgio Ghedini (Colosseum). Ghedini's own arrangement is used. It has more cleverness than depth, and some devices run counter to the Baroque spirit of the music. The Scherchen (Westminster) or Casals (Columbia) versions are preferable.

HAVANA, Cuba, Nov. 6 -- At Levisa Bay on the jungle-covered north coast of Cuba some 600 miles east of Havana, where the Nicaro nickel plant is located, the work of increasing production of the strategic metal has begun.

THIS is the first comprehensive anthropological account of human history which is both readable and authoritative. Sweeping through the corridors of a million years and ranging from fossil primates to the social structure of the U. S. S. R., Carleton Coon, author and educator, nevertheless manages to avoid superficiality and empty generalization.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Visiting officials from Coventry, England have joined with officials of Stalingrad in an appeal to the United Nations to ban hydrogen and atomic bombs.

GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- The United States has again been censured by its chief trading partners for maintaining quantitative restrictions on the import of dairy products. A Danish resolution affirming the right of other countries to take retaliatory measures against American trade as long as these import restrictions remain in force has been adopted by the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Alan Ameche collected 59 yards today to become the greatest ground-gainer in college football history as Wisconsin routed Northwestern, 34 -- 13, in a Big Ten game before a record-equaling crowd of 53,131 at Camp Randall Stadium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- In a fourteen-day drive that ended Wednesday, 250 members of the Secretariat were added to the roster of the United Nations Cooperative, Inc. The total enrollment for this enterprise, which has an annual turnover of $500,000, is 1,150.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 6 (AP) The University of Maine, powered by Ernie Smart, won the state college football series for 1954 with a 27-13 victory over Bowdoin today.
The incomparable combination of Hans Guenther Winkler, a 28-year-old German rider, and the aged brown mare Halla was supreme again at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.
In his story about popular sports, John Lardner omitted mentioning the fastest of all field games. I refer to lacrosse.

Nickel has been in short supply for so long that any warning of overproduction sounds grossly premature. Nevertheless, some industry authorities are expressing growing uneasiness as they try to appraise the nickel market picture of a few years hence.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 6 -- Department store trade in the Tenth District pushed vigorously forward under the impetus of widespread promotions and favorable shopping weather. The first cold spell of the season created a rush for heavy wearing apparel and winter types of merchandise.
STORRS, Conn., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Connecticut squeaked through to a 20-19 victory over favored Northeastern today to score its first gridiron victory of the season before a Dad's Day crowd of 7,700.

SAN FRANCISCO -- A prediction that Americans will double their foreign-travel expenditures to a probable $2 billion yearly level within a year or two, was made here last week before 1,500 travel agents. It came from Dr. Laurence C. Tombs, president of the American Society of Travel Agents, at A. S. T. A.'s twenty-fourth annual five-day Convention and World Travel Congress at the Municipal Opera House.

OWNERS of the Great Soviet Encyclopedia are getting a small printed slip these days from the Moscow State Publishing House which recommends that readers "remove pages 21 to 24 from Volume 5, and also the portrait between pages 22 and 23, in exchange for which pages with new text are sent to you.
The State Employment Service is ready to help women find thousands of temporary sales jobs in stores here during the Christmas rush.

ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida received an old friend's welcome today from Gov. Thomas E. Dewey as he arrived here to lunch with the Governor and fifteen other prominent Americans at the executive mansion.
WHODUNIT writer Erle Stanley Gardner is not a man to repine. When other Westerners lament the passing of the frontiers he takes off in a specially equipped camping car to look for those that haven't.

ATLANTA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Georgia Tech took three of Tennessee's favorite weapons -- a pass interception, a punt return and a clutch defense -- and used them today to trample the Vols, 28 -- 7, in a Southeastern Conference football game.

THE size of the quarry is just as important to some hunters as it is to most fishermen, which may account for the long trips some hunters make to get a chance at a moose. It also may be the reason for the annual pilgrimage of thousands of wildfowlers to the North Carolina banks, where the Canada goose makes its winter home.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Scotch Victor, a 12-1 shot, came down the stretch to capture the $32,875 Golden West Trot today at Hollywood Park and set a world record for a mile and three-sixteenths.

CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 1 -- As one of the events in the observance of its fiftieth anniversary in 1955, the province of Alberta will declare the Drum-heller Badlands area a provincial park. It will thus open one of the richest dinosaur beds in North America as a tourist area.

The Eisenhower Administration has been wrestling for several months with problems created by the railroads' loss of traffic. The industry, regulated and unsubsidized, has been falling steadily behind its comparatively unregulated and partially subsidized competitors.

YOUNG artists from France walked off with most of the prizes in the tenth international musical contests conducted by the Conservatory of Music in Geneva, Switzerland. French musicians won four of the six first prizes: Raymond Guiot won the flute contest, Annie Jodry the violin contest, Bernard Ringeissen the piano competition, and an ensemble consisting of Andre Boutard, Robert Casier and Gerard Faisandier won the contest for woodwind trio.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Senate reconvenes on Monday, in an atmosphere of election postmortem, to consider whether Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, should be censured for his conduct.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Eddie Vincent, an Iowa halfback, streaked 96 yards on a record run from scrimmage as the Hawkeyes downed Purdue, 25 -- 14, in a Big Ten game before a homecoming crowd of 53,000 today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 6 -- A newspaper backing the ruling Democratic party has demanded that "real measures" be taken to prevent Turkish university students taking part in politics or displaying their political sympathies.

MONTREAL, Nov. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Greenshields Co., Montreal investment house, says a great many so-called uranium companies have nothing more than moose pasture on which to base all kinds of claims to entice the public to buy stock.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- Outplayed in the first quarter, Notre Dame's heavily favored football forces stormed to two touchdowns in each of the ensuing periods and overwhelmed Pennsylvania, 42 -- 7, at Franklin Field today. The Fighting Irish enjoyed a 21-0 spread by the time the Quakers got around to scoring at 7:49 in the third.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Spinning Top, a non-winner in twelve previous starts this year, moved up in the stretch to win the $50,050 Vineland Handicap today before 32,456 as Garden State Park closed.

Richard Gregor played, in his piano recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, Bach's C minor Fantasy, Beethoven's Sonata in A, Op. 2, No. 2, a sonata by Rolf Liebermann, Schumann's Novelette in F sharp minor, and two Chopin pieces.

As part of a developing program designed to meet the acute need for school teachers, President A. Whitney Griswold of Yale University has appointed a special committee to make a two-year study of the needs and problems of secondary education in the United States.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 6 -- A problem in constitutional law will confront the Tennessee Legislature in January as a result of the election Tuesday of two state Senators who are below the 30 year age minimum required by the state charter.
The Westchester County Council of Social Agencies, Inc., will be the beneficiary of its second annual theatre party on Jan. 10 at the performance of "Fanny" at the Majestic Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The Navy's shipbuilding program will be increased next year to offset the threat of fleet "obsolescence,'' defense officials said today.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., .Nov. 6 -- Former President Truman said tonight he hoped the library being built to house his personal papers would some day become a cultural center of the nation.

Calling the Liberal party the "most totalitarian" in the country, Thomas J. Curran, the New York County Republican leader, urged yesterday that labor unions be barred from making political contributions.

On the basis of incomplete returns in many states, it now appears that the total vote in Tuesday's midterm elections was somewhat less than had been expected. Recent trends had made a turnout of 45,000,000 citizens seem probable. The actual number now appears to have been about 42,000,000.

LEWISTON, Me., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Don Lake of Colby, one of the nation's best small college passers, suffered a broken bone in his throwing hand today as Bates' football team defeated the Mules, 28 -- 13.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Theodore C. Streibert, the director of the United States Information Agency, likes to say that people and ideas are his agency's only raw materials. His difficulty is that he is short of raw materials, especially raw materials of the highest quality.

The Ford Foundation is offering grants for study and research dealing with Africa, Asia and the Near East, Soviet Russia and Eastern Europe. The awards are to be given through the Foreign Study and Research Fellowship project for the academic year 1955-56.

A cocktail party will be held on Dec. 5 for the benefit of the recently formed Girls Auxiliary of the Madison Square Boys Club. The event will take place at the home of Mrs. Seneca D. Eldredge of 131 East Sixty-sixth Street, who is chairman of the women's committee of the club.

JOHNNY BLOOD raced 100 yards for a touchdown on the first play of his first game as player-coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers. There was a huge grin on his face as he jogged past the bench, where Art Rooney, the owner of the team, was sitting.
A Barnard College Development Council has been established to coordinate long-range planning for the college's gradual development, culminating in Barnard's seventy-fifth anniversary in 1964.
MIAMI, Nov. 6 -- "Life Begins at Forty" will be the theme of the year-long celebration next year of the fortieth anniversary of Miami Beach as a township.
CAIRO, Ill., Nov. 6 (UP) -- A seaman's union organizer was shot in the arm today when he approached a Banta Towing Company towboat with a group of other organizers.

The National Bureau of Standards has used its high-speed computer in a pilot study of the Los Angeles smog, the purpose being to determine the effect on Pasadena, Calif., of a single source of air pollution in the Los Angeles area. The path of a pollutant released into the air is followed under given conditions of wind direction and wind velocity.

THE author of "South Mexico'' and "Island of Bali," Miguel Covarrubias, brings to his study of Amerindian art the lively intuitive understanding of the artist, steadied by the disciplines of the archaeologist and the art historian.
Anthony Alves, a 47-year-old Brooklyn fireman, was killed instantly yesterday morning in a head-on automobile collision on the Interboro Parkway in the Glendale section of Queens.

THERE is still time in the Northeast to plant roses before the ground freezes. November, in fact, is the month which brings delivery of fall-ordered bushes and late in the month the big rose-planting season begins in the milder areas of the Southeast and Southwest.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 6 -- The Ephs of Williams suffered defeat in their first Little Three encounter today with the Wesleyan Cardinals, 17 -- 0.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Elimination of the coca leaf is in prospect in Bolivia, Alberto Canedo, Bolivian Consul General, said this week. He confirmed that plans were under way to use lands formerly monopolized by this crop for expansion of coffee production.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The recent announced that the Government of Premier Pierre Mendes-France was studying means of reducing the production and consumption of hard liquor in this country has caused acute anxiety among Paris bar-owners.

On Nov. 6, 1874, three men pooled their talents in a new men's wear business. Today that company bears the names of the two who died shortly after, Marvin N. Rogers, a clothing manufacturer, and Charles B. Peet, a clothing jobber.

THE visitor returning to Israel after five years finds a nation on the move -- the physical achievements altering the face of the country, the inner, psychological achievements dramatically reshaping the lives of people drawn from seventy states.

THIRTY new galleries of post-Renaissance European decorative art will open to the public on Thursday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The emphasis in these galleries is on French and English designs of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The lavishness and richness of the furnishings are particularly striking to eyes accustomed to the uncarved and simple lines of contemporary design.

Mrs. Basil Goulandris, chairman of the dinner committee for the Fan Ball, which will be held next Friday in the grand ballroom of the Plaza, will give a tea on Tuesday at her home, 998 Fifth Avenue, in honor of Mrs. Russell A. Firestone, chairman of the patroness committee, and other committee members.

TO find Miguel Covarrubias in Mexico City, where he resides, is not an easy task, since you can find him everywhere, and from everywhere he has left just five minutes ago. But if you catch him at the right moment, he will patiently sit in a cafe and talk with you for hours, so that you feel sorry for all those who probably are still waiting for him.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 29 -- The old differences between Boer and Briton in their attitudes to the Negro multitudes of Africa are coming to a head in a church-state crisis in South Africa.
The Union Pacific Railroad has installed a new electronic freight-car switcher and coupler that is expected to save millions of dollars in rolling-equipment maintenance and freight-damage claims.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 6 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party lost control of its second state among India's twenty-seven today when the Congress party ministry was dismissed over the issue of prohibition in the Andhra State of southeast India.

CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 1 -- Government plans for the Trans-Canada Highway in the scenic and mountain section of Alberta have run into trouble in "Indian country," which is marked by an appeal to the white man's conscience.

PINOCCHIO has come to philately. The fictional longnosed wooden boy who wanted to become alive, and whose antics have intrigued so many motion-picture audiences, is pictured, with children of various nationalities as background, on a 25-lire carmine stamp received by Pierson Ostrow.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 6 -- Police departments in 145 communities on both sides of the Delaware River in the Camden-Philadelphia region are cooperating to make it tough for criminals to escape after committing major crimes in this area.

This week an estimated 20,000,000 parents and other citizens will spend an hour or more in the classrooms of every school system, large or small, in the country. It is all part of American Education Week, which began in 1921 and has been held each year since.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 6 -- When Robert A. Taft Jr. takes his seat in Ohio's 101st General Assembly at Columbus next January, the fourth consecutive generation of his family will have embarked on a career in public office in this country.

ELIZABETH FAIR belongs to the school of cheerfully ironic, pleasantly shrewd chroniclers of English village life, whose amusing books come as a relief, like diverting guests, welcome to the home at any time.

SAVE for summer recesses necessary to lower his blood pressure, Fred Allen was a Sunday night radio fixture for seventeen years. Over that span he contributed as much to the gaiety of the nation as any entertainer ever to face a microphone.

ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Cornell played it straight in beating Syracuse today. Adhering mainly to the fundamental running game, the Big Red humbled the favored Orange eleven by the count of 14 to 6 before a crowd of 25,000.

ONE of the bidding principles that bridge players should learn first, but often learn last if at all, is that certain bids should always show the same kind of hand. All no-trump bids and all raises of partner's bids fall into this class.

ATLANTA, Nov. 6 -- Demands for apparel, home furnishings and Christmas goods resulted in increased employment in some department stores in the district last week. Durable home furnishings sales for 1954, which lagged somewhat earlier in the year, now are estimated to equal those in the similar period of last year.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Southern California's Trojans overcame Stanford University, 21 -- 7, today and stormed right up to the gates of the Rose Bowl.

The annual Bagby Concert under the auspices of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., will be held on the afternoon of Nov. 29 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. As in previous seasons, the event will serve to augment the foundation's pension fund for needy musical artists.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Fort Wayne Pistons won their third game in a row in the National Basketball Association today, handing the New York Knickerbockers their first lost, 90 -- 83.

THE Vale of Kashmir is one of the rich prizes of the world, an enchanted valley, a Garden of Eden, a dream of a place in a world of harsh realities. But those realities have closed in. The Vale is a part of the much larger State of Jammu and Kashmir, which has been torn and fought over by India and Pakistan.

A new Soviet challenge to the West has emerged during the last few weeks and is now engaging the attention of Western policymakers. It is a Soviet Point Four program through which Moscow is seeking to make friends and influence people by offering to make major contributions to the industrialization of non-Communist underdeveloped nations, particularly in Asia.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The French police struck at the Algerian nationalist movement in France and Algeria today with raids in principal cities on headquarters of the movement.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A picture by an 8-year-old girl, submitted by her mother as a prank, was placed on exhibition today along with paintings by some of Britain's big-name artists.
HARTFORD, Nov. 6 -- The defeat of Gov. John Lodge Tuesday is expected to cause a major change in the control of the Republican party in Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today the election results showed that Americans wanted "the same sort of government America had during twenty years of New Deal and Fair Deal."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- The United States and six other nations made public today a draft resolution calling for the early establishment of an international atomic energy agency. They also proposed an international technical conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy.

Unfortunately, even the Weather Bureau sometimes errs when it encounters hurricanes, and the political predictors are far less reliable. ON Veterans Day (formerly Armistic Day) this week attention again will focus on the tomb of the Unknown Soldier in the National Cemetery at Arlington, Va. That memorial to an American "known but to God" is generally accepted as the national monument to all our unidentified war dead.

The recent letter, headed "The President's Political Role," of my fellow-Republican S. Martin Adelman is interesting. I don't think that any of our Presidents have gone very much into district politics. On the whole I think they have generally had an appreciation of the fact that the Presidency is a high office and each occupant represents, while in office, the people as a whole.

A three-year study of the Social Democratic movement in Japan will be launched this fall by Japanese and American scholars under the sponsorship of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Medford, Mass. To be undertaken by a special grant of $80,000 from the Ford Foundation, the project will study the development of the Japanese Socialist movement since World War I.

TWO hibiscus cuttings were brought to me four years ago by a friend who had just driven home to Connecticut from Florida. Little did I think then that they would grow into small shrubs, each filling a ten-inch tub.

The stories of men who make millions draw headlines but the tales of those who build their modest businesses slowly with patience and perspiration are just as much part of the Horatio Alger folklore of America.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 6 -- Penn State's halfback speed team of Lenny Moore and Ron Younker knifed through the Holy Cross defenses at will today as the Nittany Lions ground out a 39-7 decision over the Crusaders.
OSLO, Norway, Nov. 6 -- Norway is considering placing her trade with the Soviet Union on a long-term basis, according to circles close to the Government.

One of the Administration's major foreign policy projects is the so-called atoms for peace plan. The basic idea is to establish an international agency making available atomic materials for industrial and medical uses. The plan was proposed by President Eisenhower in a speech to the U. N. General Assembly last December.

NOW that the record companies have, almost unanimously, gotten together and established a uniform recording characteristic -- the RIAA curve -- the tape industry is beginning to think along similar lines.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 6 -- Jack Laverty, a fullback, recovered a Lafayette fumble in the end zone early in the second period to give Rutgers a 7-0 victory over the Leopards today before a Hall of Fame Day crowd of 11,000.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Set out deciduous shrubs and trees and rose bushes as soon as nurseries can deliver them. Dig a hole wide and deep enough to accommodate the roots and pack soil firmly about them. Water thoroughly and soak the ground weekly until it freezes. Mulch with peat moss immediately. AND IF THERE IS TIME:
BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Christiana Stable's Thinking Cap rushed up from last in the final half-mile today to capture the $65,240 Pimlico Futurity from ten other 2-year-olds.
Five days after Election Day 1954 the experts are still trying to fathom just what happened, what it meant, and what happens next.
Public opinion forecasters did fairly well in naming the winners in last Tuesday's election, especially in lesser contests, but there were five notable slip-ups in major ones.

JOURNALIST, poet, translator and authority on both China and India, Robert Payne is also a competent historical novelist. His "Blood Royal," dealing with that Shah Jehan who is known to us as the builder of the Taj Mahal, appeared two years ago.
BALBOA, C. Z., Nov. 6 (UP) -- A giant dipper dredge reopened today another twenty-five feet of the width of the channel at Gaillard Cut in the Panama Canal.

Now that the public bond market has absorbed successfully the best part of the fall's billion-dollar flood of new taxable corporate debt securities, the attention of financial specialists is shifting to that basic sector of the market occupied by the obligations of the United States Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Democrats won the election, not by a landslide but by erosion. They wore the Republicans down, particularly in the scattered valleys of industrial discontent, and leveled off the political struggle, not only in the Congress but also within each region of the nation.
St. Christopher's School in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. will be the beneficiary of a bridge party to be given Nov. 22 by the Triangle Circle in the ballroom of the Colony Club.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Billy Pappas passed for four touchdowns and set up another as New Hampshire defeated Massachusetts, 32 -- 12, today to win the Yankee Conference championship.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 6 -- Sixteen deck and engine officers of the Egyptian cargo-passenger steamer Mohammed Ali el Kebir ended their strike here early today after the Khedivial Mail Line of Alexandria, owners of the ship, agreed to accede to the men's demands.

ON Wednesday the Horticultural Society of New York, Inc., will have somewhat of a festive air when it stages its annual Thanksgiving Flower Show. The place is the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House, Fifty-ninth Street near Seventh Avenue and the time is 1 to 4:30 P. M.

I HEREBY nominate Selwyn Jepson's Eve Gill as the most wildly conceived heroine in detective fiction. Take Pearl White, Pamela North, Robin Hood, Arsene Lupin, Superwoman, Tommy Hambledon, and a bevy of the rashest idiot-heroines ever devised by the Had-I-But-Known school, melt them all down in a pipkin or crucible, and the residuum may be a shadow faintly resembling the egregious Eve.
DENVER, Nov. 6 -- Gordon Allott, Republican Senator-elect from Colorado, was an upset victor in balloting that otherwise followed predictions without exception.

FROM all parts of the country word has come of vacant tuberculosis hospital beds. The other day the City of New York closed its sanatorium at Otisville in the Catskills. The House of Rest at Sprain Brook, last private tuberculosis sanatorium in Westchester, has also just closed.

ESTHER BUBLEY, New York freelance photographer, won the $2,000 first black-and-white award in Photography Magazine's $25,000 savings bonds contest, the magazine announces in its December issue, out tomorrow.

BONN, Germany, Nov, 6 -- Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister under the Nazis, was released from Spandau prison in West Berlin shortly before noon today. The release of von Neurath, who is the first of the seven chief war criminals to leave the Allied prison, was arranged by the four High Commissioners in Germany.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 6 -- The Greeks on Cyprus have condemned .unseen the Constitution the British Government is preparing for this island colony.

PHOTOGRAPHIC exhibitions covering a broad range of interests and treatments are offered by local galleries. A show of nature photographs in black-and-white and Lumiere color plates taken during 1890-1900 by the late Grant La Farge, will open at 5 P. M. Tuesday at the Limelight Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South.

LYNBROOK, L. I., Nov. 6 -- Representative Frank J. Becker, Republican of New York, today urged that the Notre Dame-Army football game slated to be played in 1957 at West Point be moved to the Yankee Stadium in New York City.

NEVER an adherent to the cozier conventions of teenage fiction, Mary Stolz has given us another of her provocative novels -- this time about a girl who isn't sure what she wants but knows quite well what she doesn't want.

BOTH the New York City Ballet's production of "The Nutcracker" at the City Center and the Ballets Espagnols Teresa and Luisillo at the Mark Hellinger will finish their first weeks tonight and take up their runs again on Tuesday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 6 -- Both weekly wages and total employment increased again in Minnesota in September, the State Employment Service reported. Non - agricultural employment climbed 8,765 during the month to 860,171, the canning industry absorbing the bulk of the increase.

ALL throughout the Ozark region of this country, residents can "pick up papaws and put 'em in a basket" or in jest make people's mouths pucker by giving them an unripe persimmon. In other parts of the country many people have not so much as even seen these interesting trees although they are hardy to Connecticut, southern Michigan and parts of Ontario.

Five suspects were booked early today on charges of grand larceny involving thefts of $20,000 worth of high-priced radio and television equipment from the Harvey Radio Company, 103 West Forty-third Street.

HONG KONG, Nov. 6 -- After a twelve-day visit to Communist China, Prime Minister Nehru of India has gone home with the expressed conviction that the Peiping Government wants "peace." His observation coincided with the resumption of Chinese Communist attacks against the Nationalist-held islands off the Southeast China coast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The new Democratic Congress probably will shy away from a showdown with President Eisenhower on the party's demands for a general reduction in individual income taxes, at least until 1956.

AMONG distinguished living American writers, William Carlos Williams is perhaps the only one who qualifies as a complete man of letters, in the eighteenth century meaning of the phrase. His collected poems, his collected short stories -- and now the essays -- are equally original and rewarding.

PROBABLY there never has been so ambitious a project in juvenile literature as the Landmark Books. Now numbering fifty volumes, this, like all series, has its weak spots and imperfect members but in the main it has ably fulfilled its purpose: to present to young people the great figures, events and movements of American history.

Persons mailing to other countries letters or packages prepaid at the letter rate of postage, containing articles liable to customs duty, must affix to the cover a green label Form 2976, acting Postmaster Robert H. Schaffer said yesterday.

THE doctor next door charged Edward Everett Chase $5 for bringing his second daughter into the world, and $1.50 for each of two post-natal visits to mother and child. Whatever way you look at it, lawyer Chase got a bargain for his $8.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 6 -- Two-party politics in Florida appeared to be speeding toward reality this week.

BUDAPEST, which has lived through conquest, monarchy and dictatorship, is probably the most beautiful, well-cared-for city behind the Iron Curtain, including even Moscow. The people themselves seem well fed and are dressed better than citizens of the Soviet Union.
BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- The results of four years' study of the land and water resources of New York and the six New England states will begin to be unfolded next week.

RESIDENTS of Brooklyn who watch television this evening will have a chance to appraise the work of Jacques Tati, a solemn-looking French mime who thinks that the inhabitants of Dodgerland are highly discriminating people.
Herbert Tichman, clarinetist, and his wife, Ruth Budnevich, pianist, made their third New York appearance as a duo late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

THE automobile industry, which has been stirring the imagination of potential purchasers for weeks with intimations of great new 1955 models, has finally begun to show its wares. Three manufacturers already have unveiled new cars: Studebaker, Chevrolet and Pontiac.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sunday, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Last-ditch efforts of Federal mediators to settle a threatened strike by some 4,500 atomic production workers at Oak Ridge and Paducah, Ky., hit a snag early today.

NORTH CREEK, N. Y., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A slender young man determined to win a balloonist's license floated over the Adirondack Mountain wilderness for about six hours today and landed safely in treetops on the west bank of the Hudson.

A CONVERTED airliner equipped with turboprop power plants has made a series of demonstration flights over Long Island, and judging from the appraisal by its passengers and the sight-seers at La Guardia Airport who watched and listened to its operations, both the traveling public and the persons who live near the major airfields should welcome this type of aircraft.

EVERY so often a personality will rocket to the top of the motion picture world in a dazzling ascent to success. Some attain it by sheer physical allure and little else. In others, it can be traced to a remarkable affinity for publicity.

THE times do move, whether we point with pride or view with alarm the processes involved in the moving; and whether these processes portend good or ill to cherished ideals and standard procedures of other days.

SOUTH BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 6 -- Mrs. Consuelo Northrop Bailey, who has blazed fresh trails for modern American women on the political battlegrounds of Vermont, feels no different as Lieutenant Governor-elect of her state than she felt when she was "a good private citizen."

QUITE a few notables have sat down with King Arthur and his Round Table, including Malory and Twain. It's a sturdy medieval jumping-off place for practically anything from romantic appreciation to low comedy.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- On the eve of the thirty-seventh anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, the Soviet Union issued tonight a conspicuously warm invitation to Yugoslavia to resume "normal relations."

HAMILTON, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Colgate's unbeaten Red Raiders, with their sophomore quarterback, Guy Martin, showing the way and a junior, Frank Nardulli, accounting for the touchdown that kept Colgate's record clear, defeated an air-minded Bucknell football team today, 20 -- 14.

Maine Chance Farm's Jet Action, with an eleven-pound weight advantage and a liking for a wet track, beat William G. Hells Jr.'s Helioscope by half a length in the $58,200 Roamer Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- An eight-year Soviet boycott will end when Russian delegates take their places next week at the eighth general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

I LIKE opera. After watching it with an effort at professional detachment for more than to decades, I still like it. I look forward to the opening of the new Metropolitan Opera season tomorrow night, not because I care about the excitements of a first night but because I hope to hear some of my favorite operas again.

CAIRO, Nov. 6 -- The United States agreed today to grant Egypt $40,000,000 in development assistance in support of the Egyptian Government's current effort to modernize an economy that has changed little basically since the pyramids were built.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 6 -- Tons of Suffolk County potatoes are now being dug, bagged, graded and either sent off to market or to storage houses as South Fork farmers harvest the final 10 per cent of the 1954 potato crop.

May I be permitted to comment on Sidney H. Willner's letter published in your issue of Oct. 24. WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Major Alaskan air bases, keystones in the outer defenses for the United States, are believed to be within range of missiles Russia has and could fire from the Siberian mainland.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 6 (UP) -- North Carolina struck through the air in the last 90 seconds today to beat favored South Carolina, 21 to 19, before a homecoming crowd of 22,000.
BIRMINGHAM, England, Nov. -- This prosperous city and the glamorous industrial jungle ground it present a British paradox of widespread grumbling in the midst of an economic boom.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Unbeaten Ohio State, with Halfback Bobby Watkins leading the way, took time out from its Big Ten campaign today to defeat Pittsburgh's Panthers, 26 -- 0, before 80,886 fans.

HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 6 (AP) -- West Germany's economy, certain to set post-war records in both industrial production and foreign trade this year, has a valuable asset in merchant shipping as well.

"BARBARA WARD is probably the most brilliant writer on economics and political affairs in all of Europe," commented John Fischer in commending, six years ago, her first book to be published in America, "The West at Bay."

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 6 -- Backers of a statewide educational television network proposal in Wisconsin have announced they will continue to press for their project despite a 2-1 defeat in a statewide referendum on the question last Tuesday.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Hermann Field, the American architect recently released after five years' imprisonment in Poland, appealed today for "forbearance" in judging what he called the "injustice done to me" by the Polish Government. He issued the plea from a sanitarium near Warsaw.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- The American traveler often chooses the wrong time to the right places, which may explain why few Easterners are headed for the Rocky Mountains at this golden period of autumn sunshine, either as a destination in itself or on their way to the Southwest.

Fordham University took team honors and Joe Licari of St. John's captured the individual title yesterday in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate freshman cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. The meet was originally listed for last Tuesday but was rained out.
Columbia University expects to have received more than $1,000,000 in special "birthday gifts" by Dec. 31, the end of its bicentennial year.
Seven thousand longshoremen are due to be removed from the registration lists by the Waterfront Commission on Jan. 1 for failing to fulfill the commission's minimum "work appearance" requirements.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 6 -- Harvard ended seven years of frustration in its old football series with Princeton today by marching 86 yards in the third period to a touchdown that spelled a 14-9 victory for the Crimson.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Iowa has overtaken California to become the leading farm state in terms of farm income, preliminary figures showed today.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 2 -- An intensified drive to clean up questionable practices in Mexican exports and thus protect the name of the country's products in foreign trade marts is under way here.

TODAY will seem like Joe McCarthy Day on radio and television. With the Senate called for a special session tomorrow to take up censure recommendations against the Republican Senator from Wisconsin, the subject will undergo extensive debate today on various programs.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- English League division leaderships were unchanged today in an afternoon of rain, mud, and gloomy weather that saw 175 goals scored in forty-five soccer matches.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6 -- Army was on the stampede again today and ran up the second highest score recorded against a Yale football team.

NOT since 1916, when the Provincetown Players lured the theatregoers to Greenwich Village to applaud the works of a young playwright named O'Neill, has the off-Broadway movement shown as much vitality as it does today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 6 (UP) ---- Minnesota's Gophers bid for a higher national ranking and polished their offense for next week's important game with Iowa with a 44-6 triumph over Oregon State today.
ATLANTA, Nov. 6 -- Georgia will take no immediate action to carry out the provision of the Private School Amendment, ratified on Tuesday by the electorate, state officials declared today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A typical American drug store intrigued Queen Mother Elizabeth today that, although it was closed for the day, its doors were unlocked to permit her to wander, fascinated, among its offerings.

THE National Association of Travel Organizations will hold its fourteenth annual convention here this week, with sessions beginning on Wednesday and continuing through Friday at the Park Sheraton Hotel. About 500 members are expected to attend, representing all aspects of the domestic and international travel industry.

And in what combinations?

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 6 -- Vilhjalmur Stefansson, the grand old man of Arctic exploration, celebrated his 75th birthday Wednesday. Since 1947 he has been Arctic consultant at Dartmouth College, in whose library is housed the Stefansson collection, the world's greatest library on the polar regions.

EDGEWATER, N. J., Nov. 6 -- There's a strange silence aboard the scores of hulks berthed in the mud flats of the Hudson's west shore here. They have been "home" to hundreds of families for nearly half a century, but they are doomed.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 6 -- Miami's previously unbeaten and untied Hurricanes collided with a tornado from the plains of Auburn in the fourth period today and took a 14-to-13 lacing before 25,000 fans.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Detroit's Lions, aiming for a third straight National Football League title, routed the Baltimore Colts tonight, 27 -- 3, with Bobby Layne and Doak Walker leading the assault for the powerful champions.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Carmen La Rocca scored two first period touchdowns, one set up by an intercepted pass and the other on a 79-yard pass play to pace Temple, to an easy 27-0 victory over Brandeis today before 5,000 at Temple Stadium.

Nineteen Jewish organizations have praised the work of the Jewish Information Bureau of New York City as "a most useful service to the community." The bureau, at 103 Park Avenue, is a nonprofit agency that answers inquiries and supplies information on subjects relating to the Jewish community.

HONG KONG, Nov. 6 -- Communist China again hailed its "permanent and unbreakable ties" with the Soviet Union today in a governmental message of greeting to mark the thirty-seventh anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution.

The strange names -- half Japanese and half American -- exemplify the purpose of the class to teach young Japanese girls how to make happy homes for their American husbands upon the couples' return to the United States.

MADRID, Nov. 6 -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, an outspoken critic of the Franco regime, was reported today to have been placed by the Vatican in a position designed to lead to his retirement from active administration of the Diocese of Seville.

Iranian oil again is moving into the world markets. After almost three and one-half years, during which the vast oil installations of Iran were mostly idle, tankers are being loaded in the Persian Gulf port of Abadan for free world markets.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The State Department disclosed today that the United States and Nationalist China had been discussing the possibility of a military security treaty for almost a year.

FOR its opening exhibition in handsome new quarters at 40 East Sixty-eighth Street, the Rose Fried Gallery has hung a group of paintings by twentieth century European artists, the rebels of a generation ago and the old masters of today.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 (UP) -- U. C. L. A. maintained its pace as the nation's top-ranking and top-scoring football team today by overwhelming Oregon, 41 to 0, before 46,435 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A long-standing split in the Atomic Energy Commission was aired publicly today after the A. E. C. had been called on to submit a signed Dixon-Yates private power contract to Congress by Monday.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 6 -- Duke's Blue Devils, rated a 3-point edge over Navy before today's eighth annual Oyster Bowl game, proved to be the most futile favorites of the season as Navy registered a 40-7 victory at Foreman Field.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- The World Veterans Federation, which states it unites 18,000,000 war veterans in twenty-five countries, has requested top consultative status at the United Nations as a non-governmental organization, the group announced today.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 6 -- Centralization of schools on the eastern tip of Long Island under one board of education is now being considered by the Boards of Education of six villages that would make up the proposed East Hampton Central School District.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The famous old warship from whose bridge Admiral George Dewey uttered the immortal command, "You may fire when ready, Gridley," is headed for the junkyard unless some civic group rescues her.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 6 -- If political strategists had hoped to find in Tuesday's election a guide for the formulation of 1956 farm programs they were disappointed. Voters in the great corn and wheat areas of the Missouri Basin left them with little or nothing to go on.

AMES, Iowa, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Oklahoma downed Iowa State, 40 -- 0, today for its sixteenth consecutive victory, the seventh this season. The Big Seven champion preserved its record of never losing a Conference football game under Coach Bud Wilkinson in eight seasons.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- Improvement in New England business continues but changes have been minor and the upturn from August to November was hardly more than of usual seasonal proportions. Local merchants now believe 1954 will wind up with sales 1 to 2 per cent above those of 1953.
