Private travel and haulage -- not the airlines -- are the principal source of the railroads' woes, in the opinion of the Air Transport Association.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Michigan State, striking with its old-time fury, defeated Washington State, 54 -- 6, today for its second victory of the season.
The annual ball of the Junior League of Brooklyn, Inc., will be held on Jan. 28 at the St. George Hotel Roof. Proceeds will be donated to the league's welfare fund.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 6 -- Lehigh University produced an aerial circus in the second half to gain a 20-20 tie with Muhlenberg today before 8,000 fans.

MIAMI -- Economical vacations will continue in Florida during November and the first half of December. The airlines will continue low-priced package tours to Miami Beach and elsewhere until the latter part of December.

THIS column maintains that the reader of Western fiction will soon learn to grade the relative merits of rangeland stories if he asks himself "Could this have happened?" Not did it happen, but could the history of the Western frontier have developed such a situation?

The New York Times asked the winners in ten of last week's key Senate contests what issues and what other factors -- national and local -- they thought influenced the outcome. Democrats expressed the belief that they were aided by a general dissatisfaction with the Eisenhower Administration's policies, particularly its approach to unemployment and farm prices.

The free world is in danger of losing the important technological race for trained scientists, engineers and technicians. The Soviet Union is making an intensive effort to increase its supply of technically trained personnel.

THE spate of fantastically rare operas on records shows no signs of abating. At hand this week are a complete performance of Tchaikovsky's Mazeppa as performed at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow (Concert Hall Society, three disks), and excerpts from Haydn's Il mondo della luna (translated as The Man in the Moon) on a Period disk.

IN her review of "It Seems to Me" by Eleanor Roosevelt, Lucy Freeman quotes Mrs. Roosevelt as saying that President Roosevelt's famous remark "nothing to fear but fear itself" was "an original saying, if there is anything really original.
In the Sunday Magazine (Oct. 24) please note a misstatement made in picture-feature. "The Subway -- 50 Years Old."

The New York Football Giants, who lost their first big 1954 game at Cleveland last Sunday, will attempt to redeem themselves today in Pittsburgh. Their contest with the Steelers, which starts at 2:05 P. M., will be televised in New York, on Channel 5.

Boys and girls will be on extra special behavior in classrooms throughout the city this week. Eager hands will be raised when teacher asks a question, and there will be no quick whisperings or bright, furtive remarks when the instructor is not looking.

HURRY, hurry, hurry! Don't miss this one. It'll leave you breathless, delighted and cheering. Watch little Dan and his dog Kelly scramble through the tents, with the circus owner on their heels. Past the fat lady, past the sword swallower.
If the views of United Nations delegates and employes are a fair sample, most of the world outside the United States is well satisfied with the results of Tuesday's election.
BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- Now that the elections are out of the way, Boston politicians are expected to discuss Mayor John B. Hynes' new tax proposals without looking around to see who is listening.

VENICE -- The trans-Atlantic airlines and shipping companies are working on a plan for more uniform handling of ticket sales which could lead to the establishment of air-sea round-trip rates between America and Europe.

The qualities that Godfrey Nicholas Nelson, vice president and secretary of The New York Times, brought to his profession were praised yesterday at a funeral service held in the chapel of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Armed with the results of the Congressional elections, a hardy band of Democrats have moved anew to kill the Administration's private power proposal for the Atomic Energy Commission.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 30 -- Every Swede and every permanent resident of Sweden will be covered by health insurance from the first of next year, regardless of age, physical condition or income.

THE report the other day that Alec Guinness will next make a film in which he will play the serious role of a Cardinal imprisoned in an Iron Curtain country followed hard on the heels of the opening here of Mr. Guinness' "The Detective," in which he plays G. K. Chesterton's Father Brown.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Undefeated Miami of Ohio extended its winning streak to seven today with an upset, 6-0, triumph over Indiana's fumbling Hoosiers on Dick Hunter's third-period touchdown pass to Bob Wallace.

Your calendar for November -- "In November" (Oct. 31) -- describes the Mayflower Compact as "the first written constitution." Actually, that can be disputed, Charles and Mary Beard, in their "Rise of American Civilization," say of the Compact that the settlers of Plymouth "bound themselves into a body politic, agreeing to enact and abide by laws and ordinances for the general good."

D. W. BROGAN criticizes Arnold Toynbee in his review of "A Study of History" for not giving "due weight to the modern agnostic objection * * * that this universe is itself a speck of dust in the immensity of space," It would seem that Professor Brogan had somewhere got the idea that God was limited to our solar system.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Worcester Tech gained its sixth victory, to complete its first unbeaten football season since 1938, by overwhelming Norwich, 33 -- 0, today with Don Lussier scoring twice.

COLLECTED between these covers are articles that have appeared in ETC, the official organ of the International Society for General Semantics. They have been selected by S. I. Hayakawa, editor of the periodical and author of "Language and Thought in Action.

About three hundred research scientists from all parts of the country gathered last week at Bethesda, Md., for the First Interim Scientific Session of the American Rheumatism Association. It was a one-day meeting held in the Clinical Center of the National Institute of Arthritis and Metabolic Disease.

THE late George Eastman, founder of the Eastman Kodak Company, whose invention of flexible photographic film helped make possible the development of the motion picture industry, is, himself, the subject of a movie biography, it was learned last week.

Prime Minister Churchill raised one of the specters of the atomic age when he told the House of Commons last week that an "undue number" of atomic and hydrogen bomb explosions might have serious effects on the earth's atmosphere for 5,000 years.

Thanks for that splendid presentation by Barbara Ward ("One Answer to the Challenge of Africa," Oct. 31) which describes the struggles and hopes not only of the Gold Coast but of under-developed areas everywhere -- and the challenge to the prosperous free world to stop dealing in slogans and get down to facts.

FOR about two years a Navy lieutenant, with paper and pencil in hand, buttonholed just about every senior aviator who entered the Navy's section of the Pentagon. "Sir," the lieutenant asked, "did you ever serve with Marc Mitscher?"

THERE comes a time in the lives of most youngsters when they gravitate toward a strong leader. The twist in this story is that Lulu ruled in absentia. When 11-year-old Libby Barnes moved from Vermont to the new parsonage in Connecticut she found the shadow of Lulu, the former minister's daughter, preventing friendship with two neighborhood girls.

CONSUMERS, like voters, do not follow any set pattern of behavior. Retailers are well aware, however, that seasonable weather will encourage consumers to buy. This was illustrated last week in the pickup of cold weather apparel sales with the advent of cooler weather.
Business mergers and liberalization of the Social Security law, are forcing deep going revisions in pension plans.

American supremacy in science and technology is seriously threatened by a rapid increase in the supply of engineers in Russia, warns Dr. John T. Rettaliata, president of the Illinois Institute of Technology. This country has about 500,000 engineers and 200,000 scientists, but Russia has an estimated 400,000 and 150,000.

HOW many worlds away is is the Yangtze Valley in which an American child grew up in the Eighteen Nineties? Even within our country that decade belongs to a vanished time. In China the Dowager Empress still sat secure on the Peacock Throne in Peking's Forbidden City.

POSTMASTER GENERAL ARTHUR E. SUMMER-FIELD both surprised and delighted philately by his early announcement of at least part of the 1955 program for commemorative stamps. It has long been customary for the Post Office Department to wait until a year's end before disclosing the following year's schedule, and there have been instances of no information at all being made available in advance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Department stores in the Chicago area moved into the fall and winter selling season with lower stock than a year ago, Seventh District Federal Reserve reports showed. Combined main store and basement inventories were 3 per cent below a year ago.
HONG KONG, Nov 6 -- Communist China's policies in the Far East -- with numbers corresponding to those on the map above -- appear to be as follows:

MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 8 -Every diplomatic mission in Moscow had its ear cocked last night to two conversations at the reception given by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, at the Kremlin on the thirty-seventh anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 7 -- A national Jewish welfare leader said here today that the drastic shortage of personnel in the field of community service, particularly in educational and social work, had created "a serious problem."
Its first research grants, totalling $82,000 for six investigations, were announced yesterday by the Tobacco Industry Research Committee.
A delegation of buckwheat growers and processors visited here recently as part of an effort to focus greater attention on buckwheat groats.

As the Metropolitan Opera was making final preparations for the opening of its new season tonight with excerpts from "Pagliacci," "Boheme," "The Barber of Seville" and "Aida," the company announced the operas it would present during its second week.

On Oct. 24 you listed the names of ninety-six persons who had been appointed to the Mayor's Committee for Better Housing. It is unfortunate that not a single. Puerto Rican is among those appointed by the Mayor to this committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- Robert Howard Eisenbrey Jr., 47 years old, a member of a socially prominent Main Line family and his wife, Paula, 51, were found shot to death in their Chester County home today.

Simon E. Sobeloff, United States Solicitor General, said last night that Dr. Albert Einstein's formula that ushered in the atomic age brought with it not merely nuclear fission but spiritual confusion as well.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- When the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee resumes debate tomorrow on President Eisenhower's plan to pool atomic materials for peaceful research, delegates will have before them a seven-nation resolution.

The Soviet anniversary speech delivered Saturday night by Maxim Z. Saburov, a Deputy Premier, revealed that the Soviet's Government has largely failed in the first year of its effort substantially to increase farm production.

Cotton futures fluctuated narrowly last week and closed with small net gains in the face of developments that had a bearish tinge. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 5 to 17 points. In the preceding week they had been down from 3 to 14 points.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Nov. 7 (AP) -- A threatened strike against key atomic plants at Oak Ridge and Paducah, Ky., was averted today when company and union officials reached agreement on a "package" wage proposal.

I wish to express my appreciation for the attention and space you have given to explaining the importance of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and for the special reports on the conference in Geneva by Michael L. Hoffman.
A 27-year old laundryman was ordered held in $1,500 bail yesterday on a charge of ignoring twenty traffic tickets accumulated in the last eighteen months.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs beat the Chicago Blacks Hawks, 2-to-1, tonight.
The existence of a special police task force to investigate complaints of dishonesty within the uniformed ranks was disclosed yesterday.

THE Pinky Lee show for children is a conspiracy against parents. Presented at 5 P. M. Mondays through Fridays over N. B. C., the program is a tasteless, witless and crude half hour that calculatedly exploits behavior in children that sensible mothers and fathers do their best to curb.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The chairmen of the Democratic and Republican National Committees clashed today in a post-election dispute on the use of the "Reds-in-Government" issue in the Congressional campaign.
At the time of his arrival in this country Mohammed Ali, the Prime Minister of Pakistan, in one of his interviews leveled many aspersions at the so-called neutralist position of India.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- The peoples of the Soviet Union "do not want war," but they must stand vigilant against aggression, Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Defense Minister, declared today in Red Square.

The Navy Department has just announced that funds must be raised from private sources if the flagship of Admiral Dewey at the Battle of Manila Bay, the Olympia, is to be preserved as a national monument. Those funds should be forthcoming.
HONOLULU, Nov. 7 -- Hawaii's political leaders are divided in their view of the effect Tuesday's Democratic victory in the territory will have on its campaign for statehood.
Air raid warning sirens will be tested by the City Office of Civil Defense today at 11 A. M.

John Bates of the New York Athletic Club and the Fordham Varsity A. A. won the individual and team championships in the Metropolitan Junior A. A. U. cross-country meet yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.
Net income and billings of Foster Wheeler Corporation and its principal subsidiaries increased in the nine months ended Sept. 30, the company reported over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren of the United States asserted here tonight that political action in the fight against all forms of totalitarianism was not enough.

Throughout the nation this week, communities are observing "American Education Week." In New York City this observance is coupled with "Open School Week," and more than 800,000 parents and other interested persons are expected to visit their local schools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -Senator McCarthy, on the C. B. S. television program, said today he would make public his financial affairs only if somebody produced "any evidence of wrongdoing on my part," and if at the same time all other Senators bare their finances, too.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 7 (AP) -- West Germany's economic boom has hit a record high and shows sign of further expansion. Steel and automobile production and foreign trade are smashing all previous records. Employment has reached a post-war high and unemployment a post-war low.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 7 -- The stock market last week saw further sharp rises in practically all sections, driving the general stock average up to a new high level of 222.06 against the previous week's 215.55.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The State Department announced today that a protest had been sent to Moscow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Rams, who are virtually out of the National Football League race, wiped out a 10-point deficit today to defeat the San Francisco Forty-Niners, 42 -- 34. By losing, the Forty-Niners dropped a full game back of the Detroit Lions in the western division.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears lost a 14-point lead and then struck from behind with a pair of touchdowns in the final minutes of the fourth quarter to defeat the Green Bay Packers, 28 -- 23, today and snap a tie for third place in the western division of the National Football League.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 7 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's carefully laid plan to retire Nov. 30 without splitting the Nationalist party has misfired.

A United Reformation Service under auspices of the Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York was attended by 500 members of Brooklyn churches yesterday afternoon. Held at the Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, at St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, it brought to a close a celebration of the tercentenary of Protestantism, which started last January.

ROME, Nov. 7 -- The first of three beatifications with which the Marian Year will be brought to a close was celebrated today in St. Peter's Basilica. Added to the numbers of "the blessed" was Sister Maria Assunta Pallotta, who died half a century ago in China, where she was serving as a missionary.
Seven new films, including importations from France, Italy and Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The Rev. Thurston J. Davis, contributing editor to the Jesuit weekly magazine America, charged yesterday that a contemporary scholar had used the "Piltdown technique" in writing on the controversy over separation of church and state.
If anything seems at all certain in college football it is that Army and Navy are well out in front as the pride of the East. Also they are probably the two fastest teams.

As we learn more about the terrible possibilities of the atomic weapon -indeed, as Hanson Baldwin has pointed out in this newspaper, of the dangers of even a preparatory experimentation with it -- it is natural to turn prayerfully, if not always too confidently, toward the atom's humane and constructive qualities.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 7 -- A large United States corporation owning tin mines in Malaya is negotiating to establish an ilmenite refinery in Ceylon on a capital investment of about $2,000,000.

Goodson-Todman Productions, the television counterpart of Parker Brothers parlor games, have evolved a new program that will combine the elements of a guessing game, a travelogue and the electronic magic of Ed Murrow's "Person to Person."

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Harry Gallatin scored 10 points in overtime to lead New York to a 103-93 victory over Minneapolis' National Basketball Association champions before 1,618 fans today. Nat Clifton, with 29 points, and Carl Braun, with 26, also contributed heavily to the Knickerbockers' triumph, that marked the first opening-day defeat in history for the Lakers.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 7--Champion Timber of Ambleside, Irish wolfhound owned and handled by Mrs. Thomas B. Madigan of Huntington, L. I., registered his first best in show today, taking the top award at the Union County Kennel Club's sixteenth annual fixture at the Elizabeth Armory.
Although you may not have a chance to get home before the party, you will find time to "change" your dress if you have a jacket costume to put on in the morning.
The varying moods that can be achieved in metal furniture designs are illustrated in three new collections now available through decorators.

ARMY and Navy brought down the big ones on Saturday, blasting away at point blank range so destructively that no taxidermist could reassemble the pieces in order to mount trophies of the hunt. The Kaydets ripped away unbeaten Yale, 48 to 7, and the middies tore apart powerful Duke, 40 to 7. Now each service team engages in pigeon shooting this week, the West Pointers against forlorn Penn and the Annapolis contingent against hapless Columbia.

New tuberculosis cases reported here in the year ending Sept. 30 were 7.5 per cent fewer than in the previous twelve months. Deaths declined even more sharply, by 15 per cent. Just over half of the 6,641 new cases and nearly half of the 1,166 deaths were in Manhattan.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service has put in effect its experimental plan to process the documents of ocean passengers while ships are on the way to New York from Europe.

Harry Canelstein, operator, sold the taxpayer building containing several stores, including Kollner's Supermarket, in the block-front on Thirty - second Avenue, Bayside, Queens. The new owner is the L. S. Storch Realty Company, which acquired the property for investment in a deal negotiated by Ossip Associates, Inc., brokers.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation has acquired a "substantial interest" in the Marquardt Aircraft Company of Van Nuys, Calif., through an arrangement with Laurance S. Rockefeller and associates, it was announced over the week-end.
The Rev. Walter Donald Kring of Worcester, Mass., in a sermon here yesterday, described the laymen of the United States as "the real force in religion today."

Elena Nikolaidi, Greek contralto, gave a recital before more than 1,200 persons yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. She had the sensitive and musicianly assistance of Paul Ulanowsky, and by the end of the program cheers were being added to the applause.

The Composers Forum, which began as a Works Progress Administration project in the fall of 1935, was started on a new season Saturday night by Peggy Glanville-Hicks, who has been its executive secretary through the last three years.

David Dubinsky, union official and vice chairman of the Liberal party, replied yesterday to an attack on the party made Saturday by Thomas J. Curran, leader of the New York County Republican organization.
A roster of revised union demands will be presented to waterfront employers this afternoon by the port's longshoremen.
The tramp ship charter market sailed to higher rates last week, paying no heed to the end of the British dock strike, which some brokers had feared would prove an ill wind.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 7 -The slow process of tracking an elusive foe across rugged country has begun in the mountains of eastern Algeria, where French troops and security forces are operating against bands of armed rebels.

Averell Harriman, apparently the Governor-elect, expressed the hope yesterday that many state problems, including those involving New York City finances and taxes, would be handled on a nonpartisan basis.

Ordinarily, when an English exchange student arrives at an American prep school, it is assumed he will go out for soccer. At Peddie School at Hightstown, N. J., this year, the story is different. H. Alan Kitching of Great Ayton, Yorkshire, hasn't even considered Soccer. He's out for football.
Msgr. Edward R. Martin, former chief chaplain of First Army, charged yesterday that more than $5,000,000 had been collected to "kick" Senator Joseph R. McCarthy out of the Senate.

Mayor Wagner's fiscal advisers are troubled by the fact that the city's general fund receipts for the first three months of the fiscal year 1954-55 were only a trifle larger than those for the same period in 1953-54.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,335,956,605. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The drive for increased voter participation in the selection of Presidential candidates by substituting the primary for the convention method received impetus in Montana in last Tuesday's elections.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin's Revolution day address today Moscow's Red Square:...

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Refugee Poles in New York cautioned today against acceptance at face value of a message sent from Warsaw by Hermann Field, American architect recently released after five years in a Polish Communist prison.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 8 (AP) -The United States Air Force listed these survivors of the RB-29 that crashed on Hokkaido:
The first full-dress effort by a union group to tap the ideas of all sections of the community on means of safeguarding union welfare funds will be made at a public hearing here Nov. 22 and 23.
Relatives of Charles T. Dolan of Union City, N. J., who reported him missing more than two years ago, have been informed that he is buried in Potter's Field.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 (AP) -Lovely Lane Methodist Church, revered by American Methodists as the mother church on the Continent, is back in existence. It had become the First Methodist Church in Baltimore.
Enrollment in the city's four municipal colleges has doubled in the last ten years, according to the annual report of the Board of Higher Education.
BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 7 (AP) -- The directors of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association endorsed today a proposal to establish a fourth newsprint mill in the South.

Anti - Communist Russians marked the thirty-seventh anniversary of the Communist revolution yesterday by urging American aid for a counter-revolution as the only solution to the present world conflict.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- The motion-picture industry needs more "family entertainment," Elmer C. Rhoden declared in his first interview since being elected last Thursday to succeed the late Charles P. Skouras as president of National Theatres, Inc.
An advocacy program will be started at the New York University School of Law to supplement the regular curriculum and emphasize "the lawyer in action."
The new four-story school and community house of Congregation Shearith Israel, Central Park West and Seventieth Street, was dedicated at 6 West Seventieth Street yesterday afternoon.

Harrison Salisbury of The New York Times, until recently its correspondent in Moscow, and five out of six college students agreed yesterday that the lifting of trade restrictions with Soviet Russia would be a move toward peaceful coexistence with that nation.

John Paton Davies Jr., who was ousted from the Foreign Service last Friday, urged members of that service yesterday to "continue to report honestly and bravely their best opinions to their Government."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has forewarned his own party of the necessity of subordinating the future West German armed forces to the civil power of the Federal Republic. This fundamental objective was laid before the Christian Democrats yesterday in a statement analyzing the future relations between the armed forces and the state.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Buying of grains on the Board of Trade received considerable impetus following the election last week.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 (UP) -The Cleveland Browns, looking more each week like the powerhouse of old, massacred the Washington Redskins at Municipal Stadium today, 62 -- 3, with nine players sharing in the scoring.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 7 -- What promises to be a long and ruthless gasoline price war is raging in Switzerland.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Nov. 7 -Steel activity improved again last week. The gains were widespread and affected production, new orders and backlog. It is now a fair assumption that steel output in the fourth quarter will average above 75 per cent, or two to five points better than the average forecast a few months ago.

That white cross on a blue background displayed on flags fluttering from buildings, deco rating railroad and bus terminals, and on posters in store windows, buses and subway trains is the symbol of the United Hospital Fund of New York.
The New York City Transit Authority made public yesterday the factual survey upon which it bases its pending proposals to reduce bus and street car service in Brooklyn.
NOW that the campaign is over I will not be accused of partisanship, I hope, if I refer to an unfulfilled pledge made by the Republican party in 1952.
There are two phases in faith, "the hypothesis and the testing," the Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike said yesterday at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
The Greek liner Olympia is to be withdrawn from service on the North Atlantic and used exclusively on the New York-Meditterranean run commencing next spring.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The French Government has just announced the removal of quotas from 65 per cent of the goods traded with the countries that are members of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

The Omnibus Corporation and Hertz Stations, Inc., now entirely in the vehicle renting and leasing business, had consolidated net income of $1,108,603 for the first nine months of 1954, equal to $1.37 a share of common stock.
A series of table settings keyed to holiday entertaining will be on view at James McCutcheon Co. today through Friday.
PARIS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Max Conrad, father of ten children, landed a light two-engine plane near Paris today after a non-stop flight of 22 hours 23 minutes from New York.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 8 (AP) -Following is the text of the United States Air Force announcement today on the crash of the RB-29:
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 7 -Col. A. S. B. Shah, Pakistani Ambassador to Afghanistan, has been recalled for "possible early replacement," a high Government source reported today

The estate of Frank J. Russell of Marquette, Mich., has sold the two five-story apartment houses on plot 46 by 94 feet at 45 and 47 West Eighth Street to a client of Hillyer Bell, Inc., brokers, who resold the houses to Seymour Grudin for occupancy and investment.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The retreat from European union of a federal or supranational character has been conspicuous in the last three months.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 7 (AP) -Great Britain was the main customer of Argentina during the first five months of 1954 and West Germany its best supplier.
Ten persons -- a family of eight and a married couple -- were found dead in their beds early yesterday morning, the victims of carbon monoxide poisoning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Democratic Congressional victory last Tuesday brought bad news to more than 600 employes on Capitol Hill -- their job security vanished with the Republican majority.

Events tonight: Excerpts from "Pagliacci," "Boheme," "The Barber of Seville" and "Aida," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M.; Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman, conductor, Leonard Rose, 'cellist, Ben Storch, oboist, Bernard Garfield, bassoonist, Town Hall, 8:30; Mieczyslaw Horszowski, pianist, all - Beethoven program, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:30;

Representatives of the thirtyfour countries that adhere, in principle if not always in practice, to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, have been meeting in Geneva now for two weeks. Today, however, they will get down to work for the first time on the piece de resistance of this congress.

Directors of the Rubber Manufacturers Association have elected Ross R. Ormsby as president to succeed A. L. Viles, who retires on Jan. 1 after thirty-six years as its active head. He will continue, however, as general consultant.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 -- Title talk, silenced by the defeat at Cleveland a week ago, was resumed by the New York football Giants here today following a thoroughly convincing 30-6 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers.
BIRMINGHAM, England, Nov. 7 -- The reclamation of the Black Country, the first great battleground of the industrial revolution, is nearly half complete.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- With the four-day week, total purchases of grain and soybean futures on the Board of Trade were down last week.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Captain Ted Lindsay scored his 250th National Hockey League goal with the game less than three minutes old tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 1-0 victory over the New York Rangers.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 7 -- Scoring in each of the first three quarters, powerful Memorial High of West New York (N. J.) romped to a 27-0 victory over St. Peter's Prep before 8,500 fans at Roosevelt Stadium today. It was Memorial's fifth consecutive triumph this season and extended its over-all winning streak to seventeen.

A crude, home-made time bomb exploded last night in the orchestra level of the Radio City Music Hall. It injured two women and two boys and startled a large section of the capacity audience in the world's second largest theatre.

GENEVA, Nov. 7 -- Assured of strong British leadership, the principal non-Communist trading nation will start tomorrow the long task of revising the rules by which they govern themselves in international trade policy.

The Spanish equestrian team recorded its second victory in the sixty-sixth National Horse Show when Major Jaime Garcia Cruz captured the $1,000 international jumping stake last night. Major Garcia Cruz triumphed in a keen jump-off before a gathering of 8,000.

NARROWSBURG, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- In the dim light of early morning twenty archers stalked the woods, 1,000 feet up in the Catskills, for deer today. Hoof prints abounded and arrows went flying toward shadows believed almost certainly to be deer. But the rising sun found the hunters deployed upon a rocky ledge debating what revised techniques might be needed to bag any game.
BELGRADE, Nov. 7 -- The Soviet Union's overture for a resumption of normal relations with Yugoslavia was greeted with mixed feelings today by high officials of this country.

After nearly half a century of championing the cause of a progressive American art the Whitney Museum has moved deeper into the cultural heart of the city, fresh from its former brownstone outpost in Greenwich Village. There, in one form or another, it had offered a continuous opportunity for the young and unknown to exhibit their work, espe cially those who vigorously struck out to explore the frontiers of the challenging and the new.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., Nov. 7 -- Four teen-age boys spent this week-end atop the grandstand at the Belmont Park race track clocking and recording 400 airplanes that flew within their view during the forty-eight-hour vigil.

Among bridge players there is a suspicion that the great authorities change the rules and conventions of the game ever so often so that they can sell more books. The same charge cannot be made against the tax experts but the results are the same.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- The busy black carpenter of the Far West, apparently tired of flapping about before astounded bird lovers, has left its favorite elm beside Blueberry Pond and winged its way to parts unknown.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens rallied for three goals in the second period and one in the third to defeat the last-place Boston Bruins, 4 -- 3, tonight to maintain their National Hockey League lead.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Nov. 7 (AP) -- One state reformatory fugitive was killed and two others were injured when their stolen car -- pursued by prison guards and motor vehicle officers -- crashed into a concrete abutment on U. S. Route 1 here tonight.

TORONTO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A concern building cofferdams for the St. Lawrence seaway and power projects is buying the first 12,000 tons of steel from United States and Canadian producers instead of a German company.

A GOODLY number of the celebrities who came from far and from near lands for this year's National Horse Show made their annual shopping pilgrimage for things horsey down in East Twenty-fourth Street, the last vestige of what was once the city's thriving horse market.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan arrived tonight in search of United States economic assistance to forestall a threatening Japanese economic crisis.
The Juilliard String Quartet had the lion's share of the program that the Concert Society presented late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- In the comparative calm after Election Day, the Senate will convene in a special session tomorrow to sit in judgment on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (AP) -The Philadelphia Eagles mixed a consistent running attack with Bobby Thomason's timely aerials to whip the Chicago Cardinals and their "one-man gang," Ollie Matson, 30 -- 14, in a National Football League game at Connie Mack Stadium today.

Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth of 1 Sutton Place will give a tea Wednesday in her home for more than 200 women to formulate plans for the fiftieth anniversary celebration of Greer, a children's community in Dutchess County. A woman's committee is to be formed at the tea to advance plans.

" The Saint of Bleecker Street," the locale of which is the Italian-American section of downtown Manhattan, has been booked to open Dec. 27 in the 1,900-seat Broadway Theatre. The premiere had been listed previously for this month.

Trust Jean Dalrymple, dynamic head of the New York City Theatre Company, to wrap up a neat Christmas package for the customers. Just added to the trio of revivals previously announced for the winter series at the City Center is "The Fourposter."

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Top Thai Government officials and leading business men here are pooling their capital to form a large development corporation to help industrialize Thailand and conserve its foreign exchange, authoritative sources said here today.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France made vigorous efforts today to win a confidence vote from the National Assembly Tuesday and from the Socialist party later in the week.

Christ's "eternal priesthood" as the intercessor for mankind "before the throne of His Father" was stressed by the Rev. Charles J. McManus in his sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. Father McManus is a member of the cathedral clergy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (P) -- A Columbia University history professor declared today that "we must abandon the indignity of teachers' loyalty oaths and legislative investigations to discover subversives" among educators.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Increasing evidence that inventory liquidation has run its course in key industries was listed today by Northern Trust Company, Chicago, as one of the favorable indications for business in the months ahead.

The idea of carrying packed and sealed truck trailers by railroad is no longer an experiment, and now it is likely that the adaptation of this ready-to-roll package concept to sea commerce will mean the most radical development in ocean cargo handling in centuries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland, predicted today that more United States planes would be shot down by the Russians unless the United States took more drastic action than it had in the past.

This year's celebration in Moscow of the thirty-seventh anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution appears to have gone along a routine path reminiscent of past years, with only minor changes. Mr. Saburov's major policy speech contained few surprises, the most important being the fact that he was the one selected to deliver it.

Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill stated in the House of Commons last week that it was his "understanding" that the radio-activity released by the explosions of nuclear devices might be "cumulative" and that the detonation of an "undue number" might have serious effects upon the earth's atmosphere for 5,000 years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth attended services in Washington Cathedral this morning.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Queen Elizabeth II led the nation today in prayers of remembrance for the dead of the two World Wars in this century. The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh laid wreaths at the foot of the Cenotaph in Whitehall at 11 A. M., then stood with the dense throng in the traditional two minutes of silence.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 7 -Representative J. Percy Priest, Democrat of Tennessee, indicated today he would decline the post of majority whip in the next Congress. He seeks, instead, to be chairman of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 8 -Two Soviet jet fighters shot down a United States photo-reconnaissance plane in flames over Japan's northernmost island of Hokkaido yesterday, the Air Force announced today.

The Saidenberg Little Symphony, under Daniel Saidenberg, gave last night the first of the two all-Bach programs it is presenting at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. The series is to include all of the Brandenburg Concertos; the fourth, fifth and third were the ones played last night.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 -- The Most Rev. Patrick A. O'Boyle, Archbishop of Washington, warned tonight that a partnership of effort between public and voluntary welfare agencies was imperative.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Although the stock markets were not at any time much affected by the prolonged dock strike, the restoration of peace, or something very near peace, has been the signal for a further upward surge in prices. As a result, The Financial Times index of industrial shares has reached a record peak.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 7 -- A recount of the votes cast last Tuesday on the proposed City Charter amendment to abandon the proportional representation method of electing the City Council seemed certain here today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Newspaper executives from thirteen Latin American countries and the United States arrived today for a three-day seminar on problems facing journalism in the Western Hemisphere.

The erratic price movement of cocoa has thrown chocolate candymakers into a quandary. Prices started to rise in 1953 and continued to gain early this year. Manufacturers cut the size of their candy bars and searched for cocoa substitutes.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 7 -- Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, former President of Guatemala, charged today that his downfall in June had been caused by his independence of "North American imperialism,"
Three promotions in the marine department of the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company have been announced.
That peaceful night ride in the country may not be so peaceful hereafter.

The inexorable judgment of Joseph R. McCarthy by his peers draws nearer as the Senate convenes today to debate, and eventually to act upon, the report recommending censure of the junior Senator from Wisconsin.

" Primitive India," by V. de Golish, a record of four tribes, will be issued in December by Dutton. Translated from the French by Nadine Peppard, the book presents in photographs and introductory text and notes the life and strange customs of tribes that inhabit the mountains and jungles of southern India.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 7 (UP) -Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California, said today he would offer legislation "on the first day" of the new Congress in January to "nullify" the controversial Dixon-Yates private power contract.

Foreign exchanges did very little in the way of rate variations or volume business last week. British sterling came higher from London on Monday, on the settlement of the dock strike, but the advantage soon disappeared in the absence of a sustained demand.

A Methodist medical missionary who spent thirty-eight years working in China without pay said yesterday that 10,000,000 refugees from the mainland had made their way to Formosa in search of a free China and religious liberty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Fossil remains of an ancient mammal-like reptile have been found for the first time in the Western Hemisphere, the Geological Survey of the Department of Interior announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Eisenhower has been cautioned by at least one member of the White House staff to be careful about off-hand remarks indicating that he may retire at the end of his first term.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 7 -Horacio Lafer, former Finance Minister under the late President Getulio Vargas, today publicly supported Dr. Eugenio Gudin, Finance Minister, in his fight to stabilize Brazil's finances.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The persecution and purge of John Paton Davies Jr., a distinguished American diplomat, have had a profound and gloomy effect upon the morale of the United States Foreign Service. The Foreign Service comprises those careerdiplomats whose intelligence, vision and reliability in analyzing world affairs represent our first line of defense.
Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue, administered and staffed by the Jesuits, has undertaken a $1,500,000 building expansion program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A hardy band of volunteers returned to normal comforts tonight after three days and two nights out-of-doors testing ways of survival after an atomic attack. The thirty members began physical tests to help determine the effectiveness of special survival kits.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced over the weekend a reduction of $50 a pound to $380 in the price of purified silicon, a mineral used in solar batteries and electronic devices. The reduction was made effective on Nov. 1 and reflected the completion of new facilities for manufacture of the material.

No surprises were in store for those who attended the song recital that Victoria de los Angeles gave last night in Carnegie Hall. The soprano's voice was as lovely as ever. In texture, color and quality it is one of the most delicious sounds before the public today.

An investor has purchased the fifteen-story apartment house for sixty families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 220 West Ninety-third Street, corner of Broadway, from the Norwell Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Abbott Adams, Inc., and C. K. Abeles Co., brokers.

The era of live music, when musicians had to be seen to be heard, was revived briefly last night in nostalgic stories when a hundred veterans of Sousa bands met to celebrate the hundredth anniversary and fame of the "march king."
The ranks of the unbeaten and untied collegiate football teams was reduced to thirty-two yesterday, with six teams dropping out over the week-end

Our Government seems to be anxious to recommend democracy to the Asians but to care little about it in our own hemisphere. Recently President Eisenhower warned South Vietnam that unless it established a democratic form of government it could not expect further help from the United States.

Cat is being eulogized this week by Man. This will doubtless involve conversazioni, treatises and displays, not to mention slightly impudent appeals for Cat Welfare, as if Cat cannot take car of himself.

The need for helping young people to reaffirm their religious ideals was stressed last night by the Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe, minister of the Brick Presbyterian Church. He spoke at the annual dinner of the New York City Young Men's Christian Association at the Commodore Hotel.
Plans for one of the largest office structures to be built here since the end of World War II were announced yesterday.

The main contributing factor to delinquency in New York City is "the breakdown of the family as a stable unit," Dr. Adele E. Streeseman declared yesterday. Dr. Streeseman was the speaker at the first of a special series of discussions on youth and crime that will be heard weekly over Station WQXR on Alma Dettinger's program, "Other People's Business."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission said today two interstate natural gas pipeline companies had applied for wholesale natural gas rate increases totaling about $13,000,000 a year. Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, Houston, Tex., asked for a $9,754,000 or 7.7 per cent hike, which it proposes to make effective as of Nov. 3.
The first kosher rye bread to be made by a major baker under rabbinical supervision will be introduced in the metropolitan area next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain reviewed 3,600 parading midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy this afternoon. She received the traditional flourishes and twenty-one-gun salute accorded to royalty.

The physical and mental health of 800,000,000 Asians could be improved greatly for about 35 cents a year per capita by raising the nutritional quality of their staple rice diet, it was reported here yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Several Latin-American editors charged today that many big dailies in the United States ignored news from their countries and others presented "distorted" versions.
Rails and building materials issues headed a strong advance yesterday which carried the stock market through the 1954 highs.
Commercial refrigeration distributors who supply supermarkets are battling eight top dairy producers and some other manufacturers to hold substantial business gains made so far this year.

It is seldom that a person goes to see a collection of rugs and come away feeling that he has visited an art gallery. But visitors to Lord Taylor's this week might have that impression after viewing the new Edward Fields rugs and those of a young California weaver-designer named Miriam Leefe.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 8 -- Jawaharlal Nehru will relinquish the presidency of the ruling Congress party but will continue as Prime Minister of India by the unanimous demand of party leaders. This development was apparent tonight after Mr. Nehru had presided at a crucial meeting of the Congress working committee, the party's executive body.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 8 -- Former President Truman said today he believed the Democrats had won control of Congress last Tuesday because the people had expected returns from Republican political promises and did not get them.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 8 -- The Mizrachi Women's Organization of America voted tonight to expand facilities of the group in Israel to absorb 75,000 children who will be transferred during the next five years from North Africa.
TORONTO, Nov. 8--O. E. Lennox, chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission,-today deplored the charges of Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, that some
Domestic steel-making operations were at the rate of 76.4 per cent of the industry's theoretical capacity last week -- the highest level since mid-December last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The explosive Dixon - Yates private power contract remained unsigned today.
Disclosures on the giving of gratuities to city employes have led to the drafting of local legislation to ban the practice.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Vietminh is doubling the size of its field army and the British Government is watching closely developments in northern Laos, Sir Anthony Eden said today.

In your issue of Nov. 8 you printed a communication in your letters column from Harris L. Present, protesting that there was no representation of our rapidly growing Puerto Rican community on the Mayor's Committee for Better Housing.

"From now on, high productivity becomes the prime responsibility of marketing management and nobody else," it was declared yesterday by Roy W. Johnson, executive vice president of the General Electric Company.
Stockholders of the Foote Mineral Company in Philadelphia yesterday approved a three-for-one stock split. The additional shares will be issued Dec. 6 to holders of record Nov. 10.
The operation of the New Yorker Hotel was observed and assisted yesterday by students from the School of Hotel Administration of Cornell University.
CHICAGO, Nov 8 (AP) -- Hogs advanced 23 to 50 cents a hundredweight today, selling at their highest price since Sept. 23, in an active market. Closing prices showed the full advance.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Fred Saigh, former owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, said today he has entered the battle for control of Montgomery Ward Co. with twenty-one-point program for complete reorganization of the mail order chain.

Critics of some past Supreme Court appointments wanted a man aloof from the political arena to succeed the late Justice Robert H. Jackson, and President Eisenhower has obliged by giving them Judge John Marshall Harlan.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 8 -- Nassau County's 1955 tax rate is reduced nearly 7 cents on each $100 of assesed valuation -- from $1.395 to $1.326 -- in the proposed budget filed today by County Executive A. Holly Patterson.

The visit of Premier Yoshida points up a state of affairs about which much thinking is yet to be done. This is the fact that Japan is not yet a member of the United Nations, a condition which is generally attributed to the opposition to entry that the Soviet Union holds.

Following are the texts of a United States note to the Soviet Union on the shooting down of an American plane off Japan and a Soviet note to the United States as broadcast by the Moscow radio and monitored in London by the Associated Press:
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- Plans to bring next year's tenth session of the United Natioins General Assembly to San Francisco suffered a setback today.

On a height near the Potomac River commanding a sweeping view of the nation's capital five marines and a sailor who raised the Stars and Stripes on Mount Suribachi, Iwo Jima, one bloodstained day in February, 1945, are joined once more.
YONKERS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Hugh Bell drove Thomas Hat to victory in the $3,500 Central Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight with a clocking of 2:05 2/5 for the mile.

As the Senate debate on the McCarthy censure resolution gets under way many members of Congress must be giving some thought to devising ways to prevent such abuses as those which have shaped this issue.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 8 -- Ambassador Edward B. Lawson, the new envoy of the United States in Israel, called upon Premier Moshe Sharett today in his Jerusalem office. The visit was preliminary to Mr. Lawson's presentation of his credentials on Friday to President Itzak ben Zvi at his home here.

TOKYO, Nov. 8 -- The commander of the United States reconnaissance plane downed Sunday by Russian MIG jets said today the attack occurred over international waters and that at least one attacking fighter crossed over Japanese territory during the assault.
The first of a series of cast changes scheduled during the run of "The Nutcracker" by the New York City Ballet will take place in tonight's performance at the City Center.

In unusually strong language, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday denounced the "rat-hole salesmen" of "moose pasture" stocks who run "Operation Sucker" out of Montreal.

A new independent film making company, Palo Alto Productions, has been formed in California by Roger Corman. His first production will be "Five Guns West," a Western drama. John Lund will star. . . . The cast of "Not as a Stranger," currently in production on the West Coast, continues to grow.

Mohammed Naguib, President of Egypt and a guiding force in that country's development movement, has written his autobiography, which Doubleday will publish in March. Entitled "Egypt's Destiny: A Personal Statement," the volume "introduces the men who are to shape Egypt's new destiny and describes the secrecy and intrigue that was necessary to carry out their plans."

Thirty local housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration have invited bids Nov. 16 on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $103,288,000, it was announced yesterday. The notes will have various maturities, running from five to about seventeen months.

The State Banking Department has begun a sweeping inquiry into private pension funds to determine whether legislative safeguards are needed to prevent abuses. The inquiry is a companion to the investigation being conducted by the State Insurance Department into union welfare funds, but the pension study is not limited to plans established under union-management agreements.

Market analysts will often hazard an opinion that certain securities are underpriced or overpriced, that this or that stock is likely to do better than the market as a whole. Occasionally, as in offerings yesterday from a firm of put and call brokers, it is possible to get such opinions from Wall Street with money backing them.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- The subjection of the natural gas industry to regulation by the Federal Power Commission may be the first step in an attempt to bring oil and other industries under Federal regulation, A. M. Rippel, manager of Phillips Petroleum Company's natural gas department, declared here today.

The election of Harold H. Helm, president of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank, as president of the New York U. S. O. Defense Fund, Inc., was announced yesterday. The fund is the local representative of the United Defense Fund, the money-raising body for United Service Organizations and other defense-related projects.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 8 -- The real estate outlook for 1955 throughout the country is expected to be favorable, with sales of homes spurred by adequate financing continuing on liberal mortgage terms.
Outdoor advertising won approval from two somewhat unexpected sources at the national convention of the Outdoor Advertising Association of America at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell, a target of strong labor criticism during the recent election campaign, said today he would form a committee of union leaders to advise him on legislation and other matters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that political leaders had told him that the Republicans had lost election support from "pro-McCarthyites" in three Midwest states because of their "disappointment over handling of the McCarthy issue."
SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 8 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, special envoy of President Eisenhower, arrived today from Tokyo to "coordinate" United States aid to Indochina.
Clifford P. Case, Republican, appeared last night to have been elected United States Senator from New Jersey.
Now that the Navy has had its story told by N. B. C.-TV's "Victory at Sea," the Marines and Air Force are next on the television agenda.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP)--Royal Air Force boxers got off to a big lead today in preliminary bouts of the Britannia Shield competition.

Navy, one of the East's powerhouses, is overlooking no details in its preparation for the game with Columbia at Annapolis on Saturday. The midshipmen, who have scored 205 points while compiling a 5-2 record, yesterday requested assistance from the Lions, who have been shut out in their last two contests and have managed to tally 53 points in posting a 1-6 mark.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Seventeen hundred welders at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation stopped work today in protest over the dismissal last Friday of two union officials.

Gene (Cyclone) Fullmer, West Jordan, Utah, middleweight, extended his unbeaten string to twenty-five, with a unanimous decision over rugged Jackie La Bua, of East Meadow, L. I., in the main event of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

Bache Co., one of the country's largest stock exchange and commodity houses, announced yesterday that it has made arrangements for the sale of 2,500,000 shares of the Growth Stock Series of the National Securities Series of mutual funds.

Members of the Mount Holyoke Club of New York have arranged a concert of Christmas Carols to be given by the choir of Mount Holyoke College on the night of Dec. 16 at Town Hall for the benefit of the club's scholarship fund.

Friday's and Saturday's donations to the regional Red Cross blood program totaled 880 pints of blood. Included were 363 pints given at Fort Monmouth, N. J., on the second of a two-day donation that totaled 564, 180 pints at Remington Rand, Inc., 315 Fourth Avenue, and 126 pints at the Richmond Hill Masonic Temple, 114th Street and Jamaica Avenue, Queens.

A new one-year contract, calling for increased vacations and pension and welfare payments by the employers, but no rise in wages and overtime, has been signed by the Staff Officers Association of America and the American Merchant Marine Institute.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Oral references by the Duke of Windsor to Allied war plans to defend the French-Belgian frontier in 1940 were allegedly reported by intermediaries to Hitler, according to the latest volume of documents on German foreign policy.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 8 -- You pass many cars on these highways, decorated with two or three deer, but most of them are moving down from the northern counties or from across the border. Inquiries at several camps in the central and eastern areas indicate that the weather has been opposing the hunters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of the speech of Shigeru Yoshida, Japanese Premier, delivered before the National Press Club today:

The retail bill for food in the United States this year will run to the record total of $64,000,000,000, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America told the organization's annual convention at the Waldorf - Astoria Hotel yesterday.
The Shakespearewrights, a new off-Broadway group, will open its first production of the season, "Twelfth Night," at the Jan Hus Auditorium, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street, tonight at 8 o'clock.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- The Soviet Union charged today that in its present form the United States plan for the peaceful uses of atomic energy was more restricted than that proposed last December by President Eisenhower.

You are going to be approached -- perhaps today -- by a cheerful woman wearing a "United Hospital Fund" sash and bearing a blue collection box. She is one of 4,000 women who have volunteered to seek contributions indoors and out, for the benefit of the eighty-two voluntary hospitals in New York City.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 -- The gross value of the estate left by Bing Crosby's wife, Dixie, was set at $1,332,571 today in a Superior Court report. This also disclosed that debts, taxes, administrative expenses and fees would make the net only $550,616.

A Customs Advisory Council to encourage trade and improve cooperation between the Customs Service and importers, exporters, customs brokers and forwarders and other segments of the shipping industry has been established by Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs, and Aleer J. Couri, Appraiser of Merchandise.

The annual fair arranged by members of the Women's Auxiliary of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation will be held tomorrow morning and afternoon and on Thursday afternoon and evening in the Parish House of the church at 209 Madison Avenue.

Negotiations carried on over the past twelve years have resulted in acquisition first by the state and then by the city of a federal tract of land at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. This will enable the Park Department to begin construction of a much-needed waterfront playground by the end of the year.
TRENTON, Nov. 8 (AP -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that Joe Adonis, the gambler, had lied when he told a Bergen County grand jury that he had been born in Passaic.

Cocoa futures continued to climb on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Yesterday all positions closed the 1-cent-a-pound limit higher on 119 lots. There were ninety-four unsatisfied bids at the close. Shorts scrambled to cover and profit taking supplied the contracts.

Bright colors in dress and sports shirts, jackets, slacks and walking shorts are stressed at the spring show sponsored by the Boys Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association. Pink is by far the most popular color at the five-day event, which opened at the New Yorker Hotel on Sunday.

The contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) held the opening session yesterday at Geneva of a congress called to revise the policies and procedures of that organization.

Officers of the Freedom House criticized yesterday a statement by Msgr. Edward R. Martin that more than $5,000,000 had been collected to "kick" Senator Joseph R. McCarthy out of the Senate "solely beacuse of his Catholic ideals."

LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth achieved a pet ambition today -- she topped the list of British winning racehorse owners for the 1954 flat race season. No reigning monarch has turned the trick in a full season before.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, sponsor of the original censure resolution against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, said today he had long been "prepared" for a McCarthy blast against Mr. Flanders' family relationships.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- In one of his most earnest pleas for peace, President Eisenhower said today that it was essential that the people of all lands view with compassion and understanding the differing emotional drives of others.
The former "doctor to the world" diagnosed the world's problem last night as insecurity caused by clinging to grandpa's way of life.

The item in The Times of Oct. 30 reporting the adoption of a sanitary code by the Health Department which requires a warning label on paint containing more than 1 per cent lead stating that it is "harmful" and "should not be applied to toys, furniture or interior surfaces which might be chewed by children," is good news to those concerned with the prevention of lead poisoning in children.

Averell Harriman's unofficial plurality in the Governorship race bounced back to 11,803 yesterday, a net gain of 3,398 on the day. This was on the basis of official reports covering the voting in New York City and four upstate counties.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 8 -- Foreign aid programs for reclamation and electric power development drew censure here today in the light of drastic cuts for similar projects in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The United States demanded "moral and material reparations" today from the Soviet Union for the shooting down of a United States B-29 photo-reconnaissance plane over northern Japan yesterday.

Mrs. Benjamin F. Few will give a tea today at her home, 14 Sutton Place South, for members of the committee who are working toward the success of a tea dance and fashion show to be held on Thursday at the Plaza for the benefit of Judson Health Center.
Three official investigations were under way here yesterday into a gas-heater and appliance danger grimly highlighted on Sunday by twelve accidental deaths.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Supreme Court is now embarked on what is known as its "October term," and in the Virginia Law Review a professor of political science has written a study of its "bizarre behavior" in the last two decades which the black-robed brethren, lawyers, legislators and many others could read with profit.

GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- The British Government called on all Western nations today to join in the creation of a durable world trading system. The appeal came in a major policy statement to the Geneva trade conference.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 8 -- The Governor of Sind Province dismissed the provincial Cabinet tonight on charges of maladministration.

It was quite a shock to learn that if John Philip Sousa had lived until Nov. 6 he would have been a hundred years old. The sad fact is that the greatest of our bandmasters, who was also one of the most popular of our composers, died twenty-two years ago and ended his active career some time earlier.

Truck/drivers and helpers of the city's Sanitation Department voted unanimously last night to accept a contract offered by the city, with one remaining point of dispute to be submitted to a fact-finding committee.
Seventy thousand opera lovers in twenty-five cities across the country watched last night the closed-circuit telecast of the Metropolitan Opera Company's opening performance.
The Metropolitan Opera last night opened its new season not only in its own seventy-one-year-old theatre but in thirty-two other houses in more than twenty-five cities from coast to coast.

The opening of the Metropolitan Opera, accompanied by its lavish fashion show, endorsed light furs, short evening dresses and modest jewelry. Only a slight nod of approval was given to the new flatter, long torso look.

AMONG this week's exhibitions, one of the most immediately ingratiating is that of new drawings in color by Lily Cushing at the Maynard Walker Gallery. For the last year or so, this artist has been by the shores of the Mediterranean and has succumbed not only to its radiant land and sea vistas but also to a fragile and elusive manner of painting them that is delightfully reminiscent of Dufy.

NORTH HILLS, L. I., Nov. 8 -- Pat Cici, unattached, and Joe Phillips of the home club scored 33, 33 -- 66, six strokes under par, and then won a sudden-death play-off on the second hole to take the Long Island Professional Golf Association pro-pro title at the Links Club today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A sharp rise in automobile plant workers prevented the usual seasonal drop in factory employment between September and October, the Department of Labor reported today.

The French liner Flandre will enter drydock at her home port of Le Havre on Saturday for a five-month overhaul. As a result the French Line has been forced to cancel five West Indies cruises for the vessel. Passengers booked for four of these will be accommodated on two sailings of the Ile de France.
BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address today at a meeting of the National Council of Catholic Women:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Shigeru Yoshida, Premier of Japan, called today for an Asian Marshall Plan that would invest $4,000,000,000 yearly in the underdeveloped countries of Asia. "Action less noble, less decisive than that will not be enough to tip the scales against communism," he declared. "There is not much time. Let us act now."
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- American educators were advised today that they had better come from behind their ivied walls and observe what the world outside wanted in the way of education.
SHANGHAI, Nov. 7 -- In Shanghai there is an establishment called the Great World, which must be one of the strangest places of entertainment on earth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a life sentence imposed on William C. Chandler as an habitual criminal was invalid and ordered his release from the Tennessee State Penitentiary.

Service, both dismissed, and by John Carter Vincent, whom Secretary of State Dulles allowed to remain.
In the penultimate week of the season for most teams, college football offers rivalries of ancient vintage and games bearing heavily on conference races for championships and bowl bids.

The transfer of the Athletics from Philadelphia to Kansas City marks the third major league franchise shift within twenty months and the second recharting of the American League map in a little more than one year.

Terry Moore is joining the cast of "Daddy Longlegs." In the Twentieth Century-Fox musical she will portray Linda Pendleton, niece of Fred Astaire, who is co-starring with Leslie Caron, Miss Moore's last film was "King of the Khyber Rifles," made a year ago at Fox.
Oran (Hot Lips) Page, one of the nation's best jazz trumpeters, who died Sunday, was honored last night as he would have wished -- with the music of more than 100 of the most famous players of jazz.

Allen T. Klots, president of The Association of the Bar of the City of New York, and Chauncey Belknap, chairman of the Association's Committee on the Judiciary, issued the following statement last night on the nomination of Judge Harlan.
Other people's houses have a fascination. On Nov. 16 New Yorkers will have a chance to peer into some neighbors' kitchens.

Max Conrad's flight to Paris, which terminated Sunday afternoon, was interesting enough to be deemed worthy of about two-thirds of a column of type, a photograph and a map in this newspaper. Mr. Conrad, father of ten children, flew alone. He spent twenty-two hours and twenty-three minutes and $102 worth of gasoline.

The cotton futures market opened fairly steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, then slid sharply on news of the Government crop estimate. Futures closed near the lows of the day, 17 to 32 points net lower.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The first conference under the auspices of the new Foundation for Religious Action in the Social and Civil Order tonight took up the problem of how to make sure atomic energy would be used for "unprecedented progress" instead of "widespread devastation."

The one-story building at 1220 Broadway in Brooklyn has been leased by Jan Stores, Inc., from the Kalmon Dolgin Company. The remodeled structure formerly was occupied as a motion picture theatre. It will be used by the lessee for the sale of baby carriages, furniture and children's wear.

Mrs. Donald Aldrich of Whippoorwill became the new president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association yesterday at the group's annual meeting in the Hotel Biltmore, Mrs. Aldrich succeeds Mrs. F. Richard Smith of Woodway, who held office for the last two years.

A gasoline service station is to replace the old Dry Dock Savings Bank Building at 341-343 Bowery, southeast corner of East Third Street. The four-story structure, erected in 1875, has been sold by the bank to the L. B. Oil Company, Inc., through the Fred Berger Company, broker.
Kenny Lane, Muskegon, Mich., lightweight, gained a surprise victory over Orlando Zulueta of Havana in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The sixty-sixth annual National Horse Show continued to attract representative gatherings of persons prominent in social and civic life at yesterday's afternoon and evening sessions at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The theory that the Comet, Britain's pioneer jet airliner, crashed because of fatigue in the plastic adhesives that bound its metal parts together, rather than in the metals themselves, was expressed today in the official inquiry into two crashes last winter.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 8 -- The defense managed to get into the record today a neighbor's description of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard who is on trial for the murder of his wife, as a "good, decent fellow" who got along well with his wife, was kind to children and never lost his temper.

FOR the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Skowhegan (Me.) School of Painting and Sculpture, an exhibition of work by members of its faculty and by visiting artists has been arranged at the Downtown Gallery.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A Government report today raised this year's cotton production prospects by 5.6 per cent to 13,206,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight. It also reduced official hopes of making a sizable cut in the big cotton surplus.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- An influential member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee proposed today a series of economic conferences among the Western nations to serve as bases for the politico-military unity now being sought.
A 37-year-old cook and a 16-year-old girl were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn courts on charges of arson.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- A weak tone dominated the Board of Trade markets today, both grains and soybeans declining on scattered long liquidation.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Thirty girls who received child care certificates here today should have little trouble in "cornering" the baby-sitting market in this town in the future.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- After a period of mechanizing and streamlining her tax-collecting system, Mexico appears headed toward the best collection year in her history, according to figures made public by the Treasury today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Supreme Court supported today a lower court's ruling upholding the right of the State University of New York to bar national fraternities and sororities from its campuses.
SINGAPORE, Nov. 8 -- The Indochina peace settlement has been accompanied by intensified Communist efforts at political penetration in all parts of Southeast Asia, competent observers here say.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 8 -- A week ago today a bus going from Biskra to Arris in the mountainous Aures region or eastern Algeria fell into a rebel ambush as it entered the wild Thiganimine gorge.

Diamond Alkali Co and its export subsidiary, Diamond Inter-American Corp, through Cushman Wakefield, Inc, agent, offices in new Tishman Realty Construction Co building at 99 Park Ave -- Joseph F. Bernstein, broker.
Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., made public yesterday a program for Federal action to restore the economic health of the textile industry.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today agreed to review decisions upholding Oklahoma's authority to fix minimum prices for natural gas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Arthur S. Flemming, Director of Defense Mobilization, today announced the appointment of a three-man commission to "evaluate the adequacy of petroleum supply in the West Cost area during a period of defense emergency."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Treasury announced tonight that its short term borrowing costs had dropped to the lowest point in nearly three months.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association opened its seventieth season last night with a gala bill of excerpts from four operas, with many leading stars of the company in the important roles, and the whole show televised and shown in thirty-two theatres over the country.
One of the big upsets in the last election was in Oregon, where the Democratic candidate for the Senate, Richard Neuberger, nosed out the Republican incumbent, Senator Guy Cordon.
Major blocks of new and outstanding common stock valued at more than $25,000,000 will be offered to investors today.

One hundred persons attended yesterday the dedication ceremonies for the new Andre Meyer Department of Physics of Mount Sinai Hospital. The department is on the first floor of the hospital's Atran Laboratory. In the last eight months, according to Dr. Sergei Feitelberg, the department director, it has treated 900 patients.

IT isn't often that a fellow discovers poetic justice in baseball, the unbusinesslike sport in which squabbling over the Athletics has made everyone look ridiculous. Yet it is to be found in the return of Stanley Raymond Harris as the manager of the Detroit Tigers, just a little more than two decades since he blindly turned his back on them.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Illness of the star, Jean Arthur, tonight delayed the opening of George Bernard Shaw's "Saint Joan."

The thirty-eight-family apartment house at 3044 Kingsbridge Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the 2414 Creston Avenue Corporation to a client of S. and I. Paul, attorneys. The purchase price was about $130,000. Armstrong Brothers were the brokers.

MOSCOW, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- An Oklahoma Representative said today that both Georgi M. Malenkov, Soviet Premier and Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party, praised President Eisenhower in glowing terms during a surprise conversation at a Moscow diplomatic reception last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The leaders of both political parties have been spouting good fellowship and appealing for bipartisanship ever since the election, but nobody seems to be doing very much about getting the Atomic Energy Commission out of politics.

Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society offered a novelty at their second Town Hall concert of the season last evening, the first performance in this country of Paul Csonka's Concertina for Oboe, Bassoon and Orchestra.

C. V. Whitney's Fly Wheel won the Stoner Creek Handicap, the mile and a sixteenth classified race that featured the program at Jamaica yesterday. In addition to taking the first prize, the Whitney barn had a part of second place, too.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Bob Carpenter, president of the Philadelphia Phillies, said today his club has no alternative but to buy Connie Mack Stadium from Arnold Johnson, now that the Athletics are moving to Kansas City.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- There was a lot of "moving" at the Supreme Court today following announcement that Judge John Marshall Harlan would be nominated to the high court.
