The seven major New York newspapers are continuing to keep ahead of the 1953 volume in advertising linage. For ten months, according to an analysis of figures supplied by Media Records, Inc., they carried 125,537,620 lines, against 124,879,218 for the similar period of 1953.

Citations to six leading citizens for "pioneer work in their fields" were made last night at the Helmuth Fellowship Banquet of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, at the Roosevelt Hotel. Those honored were Federal Judge Irving Kaufman, David Sarnoff, Grover Whalen, Helen Hayes, Samuel Goldwyn and John R. Powers.
MADRID, Nov. 8 -- Spain's Roman Catholic Bishops have dismissed the Rev. Jesus Iribarren, editor in chief of Ecclesia, and author of articles considered critical of the Spanish dictatorship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Joseph Campbell, Columbia University treasurer, on leave serving as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, has been selected by President Eisenhower to be Controller General of the United States.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 8 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer canceled today the foreign policy statement he was to make in the Bundestag Thursday. He also requested postponement of the debate of the Paris agreements on armament, sovereignty and the Saar settlement.

BERGEN EVANS, who is a Professor of English at Northwestern University and a popular television master of ceremonies, looks upon the modern world with alarm and upon most of his fellow human creatures with scorn. These attitudes, which are bluntly and repeatedly expressed in his new book, "The Spoor of Spooks,"* are understandable enough.

Major league baseball's fantastic "Philadelphia Story" has finally come to an end. And for the American League, which yesterday placed its stamp of approval upon the shifting of the Athletics from Philadelphia to Kansas City, another new venture has begun.

Reflecting a 7 per cent decline in sales and operating revenue, net income of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) declined to $12,384,654 in the nine months ended Sept. 30 from $14,198,173 earned in the similar period last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named Theophil Carl Kammholz, 45-year- old Chicago attorney, today to be General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board when the term of George J. Bott expires in December.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Closing of the deal to move the Philadelphia Athletics to Kansas City was strictly anti-climactic to baseball fans here who twice previously had done their cheering prematurely.

The Soviets concluded their two-day celebration of the thirty-seventh anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution by staging two events which illustrate again the difference between their words and deeds. In Moscow they gave a banquet for foreign diplomats in the Great Kremlin Palace at which sweetness and light were present.

According to widely held opinion there is a large group of Government-insured unemployed in this country who don't try to get jobs: who "sit back," not exactly "waiting to be fed" like Mr. Wilson's kennel dogs, but at least waiting for the next compensation check to come in.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower would send to the Senate tomorrow the nomination of John Marshall Harlan, a Republican of New York, to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

The International Longshoremen's Association cut its welfare demands by 2 cents an hour yesterday, but the reduction did nothing to improve the chances of a contract agreement before the union's strike deadline of midnight Nov. 27.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden told Parliament today that the Saudi Arabian Government had rejected a British protest against the tanker monopoly she has granted to Aristotle Onassis, Argentine shipping magnate.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 -- Roman Catholic dioceses were urged tonight to meet the challenge of resettling 75,000 Catholic refugees in the United States. They were asked to form committees in every parish to obtain sponsorship assurances wherever and whenever possible.
The Department of Housing and Buildings has been informed by 3,906 landlords that compliance with city requirements for repairs and rehabilitation of their tenement buildings will cost $573,290.
Optimism has again become predominant among manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers, according to a survey of a cross-section of large and medium-size companies.

At 8 o'clock last night the subdued lights in the movie palace were lowered. For a moment the voice of Milton Cross suggested a Metropolitan Opera broadcast. Then the velvet curtains opened and what appeared like a newsreel came on the screen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The McCarthy censure proceeding opened before the Senate today and promptly developed into a wrangle.

Faced with a continuing decline in room sales, the nation's hotels are stepping up their efforts to attract business through extensive modernization programs. Simultaneously, they are attempting to cut costs by installing considerable new labor-saving equipment.
More than $1,000,000 in trans-Atlantic steamship fares will be added to tourist class passenger budgets during the 1955 summer season, it was learned here yesterday.

S. Klein's sales have increased since Ohrbach's moved from Union Square in late August, Spencer Allen, managing director, said yesterday. He added that the store expects to do 20 per cent more business than ever before in the fiscal year ending July 31, 1955.
Guy Richards of The New York Journal-American received the award of the Society of Silurians at its semi-annual dinner last night at the Statler Hotel.

Prime Minister Nehru's Congress party has sustained another defeat in a provincial election in India. It has lost the newly made linguistic state of Andhra to a Communist-dominated leftist coalition. Another state in the south of India, Travancore-Cochin, was lost by the Congress party last year, but there the Communists have been kept out of power by an alliance of the Congress party with the Socialists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Democrats outvoted Republicans by more than 1,750,000 in last Tuesday's election with the usual big assist from the South.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The Conservative party opened tonight a vigorous by-election campaign to hold the Parliamentary seat in the West Derby section of Liverpool that it won in 1951 general election by the slim margin of 1,707 votes.
A growing child population and the growing pressure of modern tensions make imperative increased public services for families, Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein declared yesterday.

Germany's successes in the National Horse Show continued in Madison Square Garden last night. This time the winning combination was Fritz Thiedemann and the aged brown gelding Meteor. They won the international individual championship challenge trophy before 9,000.
ALLEN, Okla., Nov. 8 (UP) -- A school official searching for a gas leak with a lighted match set off an explosion today that wrecked the Alien High School, injuring about fifty children.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Prices moved irregularly on the stock-markets here today. While the number of small rises about equaled that of declines and the firm undertone was maintained, the market seemed to have lost some of last week's buoyancy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Eight hundred pink candles were held high today at a celebration of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower's birthday.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 9 -- Budget expenditures in the fiscal year 1955-56 will total 28,000,000,000 Deutsche marks, the equivalent of $6,666,000,000, according to estimates completed by the Finance Ministry.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Forty-four ship repair contracts with a total value of $878,160 were awarded by the Maritime Administration in the two months ended Nov. 1, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- An attempt to save money on printing bills has set the Patent Office on its collective ear.

The National Orchestral Association, which trains musicians for orchestra work, opened its current season at Carnegie Hall last evening with a concert led by its musical director, Leon Barzin, Valarie Lamoree, soprano, was the soloist.

TRENTON, Nov. 9 -- New Jersey Democratic leaders, apparently determined to seek at least a partial recount of the ballots cast in last Tuesday's Senatorial contest, met tonight with Representative Charles R. Howell and two investigators recommended by the Democratic National Committee.
The New York Rangers will return to home ice tonight after an absence of ten days when they engage the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

At last, after a period of dashed hopes and false starts, the franchise of the Philadelphia Athletics is being transferred to Kansas City. This shift, approved by a vote of the American League club owners, means a third change in less than two years in the big league baseball map, which had defied change for the previous fifty years.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- The International Longshoremen's Association was accused today of seeking a return of the "pre-arbitration, law-of-the-jungle type of labor relations."

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 9 -- The Mizrachi Women's Organization of America adopted today a budget of $1,120,000 for the next year. The action was taken at the twenty-ninth annual convention of the major women's religious-Zionist group in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of a speech released today by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, which he plans to deliver tomorrow in the Senate in its debate of the censure action against him:

PARIS, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Ho Chi Minh, Vietminh President, replying to written questions submitted by the French news agency, said today that Frenchmen returning to Hanoi would be "well received." It was the first "interview" the Communist leader had given a Western reporter since he established his capital in Hanoi.
Dr. Albert Einstein has declared that, if he had his career to fashion all over again, "I would not try to become a scientist or scholar or teacher."
ALBANY, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Cargill, Inc., operator of grain elevators at the port of Albany, and its grain superintendent today were found innocent in Federal Court of misappropriating Government grain.

Terming present theatre ticket statutory regulations inadequate, Milton M. Bergerman, chairman of the Citizens Union, urged Mayor Wagner in a letter yesterday to appoint a small, representative committee "to make a study of the theatre."
TOKYO, Nov. 9 -- The United States High Command rejected here today Soviet charges that a B-29 reconnaissance plane invaded Soviet territory and opened fire before being shot down.

TOKYO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Red China's air line system, operated by the Chinese-Soviet Civil Airlines Company, now flies four major routes all radiating into Russian territory, the Peiping radio said today.

ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- A prolonged standing ovation greeted Ralph Vaughan Williams tonight at Cornell University at the close of his first concert appearance on a two-month visit to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- The Senate laid aside debate today on a motion to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to pay tribute to four members who died in the last five months.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- Two of Yale's best football players and possibly a third have been lost for the encounter with Princeton in the Bowl here Saturday, but Coach Jordan Olivar is far from discouraged for pessimistic over the situation.

A new cigar packed in trays of a dozen is being introduced by the Consolidated Cigar Sales Company as an addition to its Dutch Masters line. The cigar will retail at 25 cents each and at $2.89 for the box of a dozen. Distribution of the product, known as Crowns, will be limited for the first few months, with national distribution expected by late in the spring.

The National Horse Show ended in Madison Square Garden last night with Mexico taking the team event for the International Perpetual Challenge Trophy. A crowd of 10,000 watched the Republic's riders, Brig. Gen. Humberto Mariles, Capt. Joaquin Harcourt and Lieut. Roberto Vinals, guide their mounts to the only perfect performance among the teams of five countries.

The Board of Education approved plans yesterday for the new Aviation Trades High School, to be built in Long Island City, Queens. The school, which is designed to train young men in the repair, maintenance and construction of aircraft will be the largest of its kind in the United States.
GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- Italy and West Germany have agreed in principle on the movement of about 1,000 Italian workers each year into West Germany.

HONG KONG, Nov. 9 -- When the British Labor party mission visited Red China in August its members were told that mainland China's huge population -- already the world's largest at 582,603,000 for 1953 -- was increasing at the rate of 12,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A battle over the post of Republican House leader after the Democrats take control in January apparently was avoided today as Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. said he probably would take the job.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 9 -- Mohammad Ayub Khuhro was sworn in today as Chief Minister of Sind Province. He announced that he had set up a tribunal to inquire into charges of "maladministration and mischief" against his predecessor, Abdus Sattar Pirzada, and his twelve-man cabinet.
The McGraw Electric Company yesterday proposed a two-for-one stock split, declared an extra dividend and reported a sharp gain in earnings for the nine months this year.

George King of New York University captured the individual title and Manhattan College retained the team crown yesterday in the twenty-eighth annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate varsity cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park.

Mrs. J. Ogden Bulkley will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 139 East Seventy-ninth Street for the mothers of the debutantes to be presented at dinner parties in advance of the Grosvenor Debutante Ball to be held on Nov. 27 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Government goes before the Supreme Court tomorrow in a move aimed at breaking up what the Justice Department labels a monopoly in boxing.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 -- Arthur Larson, Under Secretary of Labor, predicted tonight that the "long-standing prejudice against older workers in American hiring practices" could be overcome by a full-scale study of their ability and work habits.
Banks and post offices will be closed tomorrow in observance of Veterans Day. But most stock exchanges throughout the country will be open. The Boston Stock Exchange will operate from 1 to 3:30 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The newly triumphant Senate Democrats took aggressive positions on domestic and foreign policies alike today in the first post-election conference of their chieftains.

In connection with the forthcoming debate in the United Nations on Indonesian problems may I call your attention to the resolution that was unanimously adopted at the thirteenth annual convention of the American Council of Christian Churches held in Boston Oct. 27-29?

VALPARAISO, Fla., Nov. 9 (UP) -- Air Commodore Geoffrey D. Stephenson, commandant of the Central Fighter Establishment of Britain's Royal Air Force, was killed in the crash of a United States F-100 Super Sabre at Eglin Air Force Base here, the Air Force announced today.

ON the return trip from Maine we checked some hunting areas in the southern part of that state and in New Hampshire. The reports in most sections were that the grouse and woodcock shooting was below par, but good deer hunting was indicated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Eisenhower Administration has authorized a significant expansion of the Export-Import Bank's lending operations to help United States industry meet growing competition for world markets.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 9 (UP) -- The pay-as-you-go television system has shut down its first operation in Palm Springs, Calif. However, its developers insisted today that the difficulty was "temporary" and "subscription TV is hotter than ever."
Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy has refused to dismiss a complaint in a $500,000 damage suit by Victor Lasky, author and lecturer, against The New York Post.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- United States and Japanese scientists will confer on the effects and uses of atomic radiation, the Atomic Energy Commission said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Government served notice today that it would not tolerate the use of its export permits to defraud other countries of customs revenue.
all their competitors did the same, both Democrats and Republicans.
PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The essential reason now given for rearming Germany is to restore political confidence in the West. This transcends in importance the strategical gain to NATO of a new German Army.

CHICAGO, Nov.9 -- The necessity for financial rewards commensurate with the risks of exploring and developing natural gas reserves will be recognized by the Federal Power Commission, industry members were assured today.
The sharp rise in cocoa futures continued yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market fluctuated in nervous trading, but the near-by months ended the cent-a-pound daily limit higher.

ATLANTA, Nov. 9 (UP) -- Mr. Yates, one of the sponsors of the Dixon-Yates contract, said today that the proposal was "fair and reasonable" and that the sponsors were ready to go ahead with the contract. He said the sponsors of the proposal had been negotiating a contract since February.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 (UP) -- William Hartack scored a riding triple, Frank Smith accounted for both ends of the daily double and Mrs. S. Smith's favored French Bleu scamped to a two-length triumph in the feature to highlight the program at Pimlico today.

With teen-age girls "appearing determined to avoid household drudgery" the future market for labor-saving devices around the home could increase considerably, Lester Rand decleared yesterday. Mr. Rand, president of Youth Research Institute, based his observation on conclusions he reached after a recent survey he conducted among 250 teen-age girls in the Midwest.
Zinc shipments rose sharply last month to 90,415 tons from 77,885 in September, the American Zinc Institute reported yesterday. The October volume was the largest since November, 1952.

Averell Harriman, speaking as Governor-elect, said yesterday that he intended to keep partisan politics out of the new State Administration "insofar as possible." Meeting with re porters in his headquarters at 270 Park Avenue after an hour-and - a- half conference with Democratic leaders, the Democratic-Liberal candidate in the recent election explained:
The four-year rejuvenation of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will come to an end tomorrow with the opening of thirty galleries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Brotherhood was presented as a "moral imperative" by Dr. Benjamin Mays, president of Morehouse College, Atlanta, Ga., at tonight's opening session of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.
Recently the reader mail bag has brought forth letters on the white fruit cake that this department detailed ten days ago in The Sunday Magazine of this paper.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 9 -- The Federal Commissioner of Reclamation told the West today that the future of reclamation depended upon the West itself, not upon the Eisenhower Administration.
Two men died and four women and a child were injured in fires in a Manhattan rooming house and a Brooklyn industrial building yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- The back-to-school movement for adults, which has gained considerable momentum during the year, has attracted more than 3,000,000 persons into today's public school classrooms they thought were left behind in their youth.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today signed Lauren Bacall and Charles Boyer to co-star in "The Cob-Web," the film adaptation of the William Gibson novel.

The Department of Health reports that almost 400 persons died of accidental gas poisoning in this city during the last four years -- eighty-eight of them so far this year. On the face of it these figures indicate neither an improvement nor an amelioration, but a frightening maintenance of the status quo.
Grants for scientific studies and support of educational endeavors, amounting to $4,266,926, were announced yesterday by the Rockefeller Foundation and the General Education Board.

Fire Commissioner Cavanagh and Police Commissioner Adams deserve the appreciation and wholehearted support of every citizen of New York City for their forthright, courageous attack on graft in their departments.

Columbus, Ohio, borrowed $4,101,713 in the public market yesterday to finance various public improvements. An issue of $4,000,000 of waterworks bonds due from 1956 to 1990 was sold to Bankers Trust Company and associates at a bid of 100,579 for obligations bearing 2 1/4 per cent interest, an interest cost of 2.23 per cent.

DECATUR, Ill., Nov. 9 -- Directors of the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company, corn and soybean processor, declared a stock dividend today of one share of common stock for each fifty shares of common stock outstanding of record on Nov. 19.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower plans to go duck hunting Friday and Saturday on Lake Erie near Toledo.

A youth said by the police to have been seen knocking down a parking meter with his automobile in Harlem early today was arrested on a grand larceny charge after a chase in which three shots were fired. The police said that three other parking meters from the same neighborhood, all containing money, were found in the car.
The Abraham Straus branch in Hempstead, L. I., yesterday placed its new third story in full operation. Departments had been moving upstairs during the last few weeks on a piecemeal basis.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Bobby Woods, 135 pounds, Spokane, Wash., stopped Armando Lopez, 138, Havana, at the end of the seventh of a scheduled 10 round bout tonight. The fight was stopped by the ring physician, Dr. Alexander Robbins, after an examination of Lopez' right eye.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Support in wheat broadened on early dips and the market developed considerable strength. Some buying was credited to export interests.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 -- The Harvard football team held only a half-hour scrimmage today in preparation for Brown's visit to the Stadium Saturday. The first string was used mostly on defense during the drill.

Judy, a 36-year-old Indian elephant weighing 8,000 pounds, lumbered diffidently about the Prospect Park Zoo enclosure at 8:20 A. M., yesterday. Calmly swinging her trunk, she watched a keeper and an attendant prepare to descend into the moat separating the elephant house from the outer fence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President Eisenhower defined democracy today as "nothing in the world but a spiritual conviction that each of us is enormously valuable because of a certain standing before our God."
The International Paper Company and its subsidiaries, the world's largest papermaking organization, increased earnings 4.2 per cent for the first nine months of the year despite a dip in sales.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 9 -- The Government-supported "new deal" for American copper producing companies here, which suffered serious defeat in the Chamber of Deputies on Friday night, has been moved up to the Senate, marked "urgent."
THE way things are going Pat Weaver, the National Broadcasting Company's indefatigible president, may decide to take an option on the Republic of France.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 (UP) -- The United States Court of Appeals of the Ninth Circuit reversed today a Los Angeles Federal Court award of $25,789 to Ring Lardner Jr., a screen writer, as back pay from a movie studio that had discharged him for refusing to answer questions regarding Communist affiliation.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Japan today Called the shooting down of a United States! B-29 photo reconnaissance plane Sunday by Soviet MIG's a "provocative act" that was a "viola. tion of Japanese air."

GUATEMALA, Nov. 9 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas revealed today that the essence of the United Fruit Company's proposals for a new operating contract was that it would keep 50 per cent of its holdings. This would include land expropriated in the southern province of Tiquisate during the regime of Jacobo Arbenz Guzman.

Business men, according to the monthly figures of the Department of Commerce, built up their inventories in September for the first time in five months. However, while a hopeful sign, it is possible to read too much significance into this. Based on the experience of past years, department officials say the rise should have been around $500 millions; actually, it was less than $100 millions.

Bell Gossett Company yesterday split its common stock three for one and increased its dividend. Shareholders at a special meeting at Morton Grove, Ill., approved the proposal to increase the authorized 600,000 shares $5 par to 2,500,000 shares $2 par, thereby providing for the three-for-one split.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, on trial on a charge of murdering his wife, was considering divorcing her only four months before her death, a close friend of Mrs. Sheppard testified today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The British Embassy held a reception today for Queen Mother Elizabeth. Two thousand guests were invited and probably all showed up.

Sotto Voce, owned by Mrs. Louis Lazare, and Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Outsmart engaged in a tense stretch duel in the feature at Jamaica yesterday, with the former winning. The event was a six-furlong purse for fillies and mares and attracted six starters, but the crowd of 17,511 liked Sotto Voce first and Outsmart second.

For two hours yesterday in Supreme Court legal lights of the Republican and Democratic parties in the city and state fought to no decision over who was entitled to possession of original registration and voting records.
A grant of $500,000 to search for a vaccine to prevent the blinding disease trachoma, has been made by the Arabian American Oil Company to the Harvard School of Public Health.

High-ranking officers of the United States armed forces, as well as persons prominent in the social, civic and diplomatic fields, attended the closing session of the sixty-sixth National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (UP) -- JosephI T. Meek, unsuccessful RepublicanI candidate for United States Sen-i ator, today got his old job backI as president of the Illinois Federation of Retail Associatibns. The federation's thirty-eight-man board of directors voted unanimously to give Mr. Meek his job back effective Dec. 1. He had quit the job to run for the Senate! against Democratic Incumbent Senator Paul H. Douglas.

Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., yesterday reported a 7 per cent sales increase in the first quarter of its new fiscal year and an improvement in earnings over the corresponding three months of last year.

" Hugh Roy Cullen: A Story of American Opportunity," by Ed Kilman and Theon Wright, will be published Nov. 29 by Prentice-Hall. It traces the career of the Texas oil man and philanthropist, who is known as the "King of the Wildcatters."
A high record of professional employment and a long term of service are some of the "striking" findings in a survey made of a group of women who received their Ph.D. degrees from Bryn Mawr College.
" Honestly Celeste!" the television show starring Celeste Holm, which won unfavorable reviews after its debut on Oct. 10, is making changes in its production and writing staff.

The writer has been distressed to note that increasingly, during the past year or so, in the press, in public discussions and in the public mind generally the Atomic Energy Commission has come to be thought of, for the first time in its history, in terms of the political affiliations or obligations of its members.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- Seven major oil companies today submitted high bids totalling $23,357,029 for nineteen oil and gas leases in submerged lands of the Outer Continental Shelf which lies 10.35 miles or more off the Texas coastline.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Shigeru Yoshida, Premier of Japan, conferred with President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles today on steps to help Japan out of her current economic difficulties.

The Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will be the beneficiary of tours to be conducted every Wednesday through Dec. 22 from 1 to 4 P. M., through the Florian Papp Workshop at 351 East Fifty-fourth Street. Admission will be $1.
The first six teams were identical yesterday in The Associated Press and The United Press college football polls.

Progress in the care of children who are public charges has been steady in recent years, Winford Oliphant, director of the State Bureau of Child Welfare, told the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs yesterday. He was one of several speakers at the sixtieth annual convention of the group at the Roosevelt Hotel.

John Francis Roche, confessed slayer of five persons, was found guilty of first degree murder yesterday. There was no mercy recommendation by the General Sessions jury of twelve men, who brought in their verdict after ninety minutes deliberation.

Dr. Harry Linn Fisher, noted expert on rubber and president of the American Chemical Society, will receive the Chandler Medal from Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, at ceremonies at Havemeyer Hall on the campus tonight.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Mild optimism regarding the immediate future of the United States economy, coupled with misgivings about United States tariff policy, were expressed in the annual survey of the United States outlook by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

Back in the Eighteen Eighties in New York, 25 per cent of all babies died in their first year. oday, less than 3 per cent die in their first year. Our average life span has increased almost thirty years since the United Hospital Fund was started in 1879.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 9 -- Junior Dick Martin will start at fullback for Princeton University's football team when the Tigers meet their traditional rival, Yale, at New Haven on Saturday, Coach Charlie Caldwell said today.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Willie Troy, the sixth-ranking middleweight, pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision tonight over Jesse Turner of St. Louis in Municipal Auditorium.

The Society for Strings, Inc., a nonprofit organization for the development of string players, announces a series of chamber music workshops to be held Sundays at 6 P. M. at the studios of the National Orchestral Association, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street.
Maryland obtained permanent financing for the construction of a vehicular tunnel under the Patapsco River at Baltimore Harbor by the sale of $180,000,000 of toll revenue bonds yesterday.
Football's unsung heroes, the linemen, without whose help the backs would have rough going, are credited with the success of the Philadelphia Eagles in the National Football League this season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said firmly today that United States foreign policy would have no part of "preventive war."
SELDOM do audiences get the kind of opportunity to hobnob with Shakespeare that was offered them last evening in Yorkville.
TORONTO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Ray Powers, 28-year-old Hamilton jockey, today was ruled off Ontario tracks for life by the Ontario racing commission for offering bribes in an effort to "fix" horse races.

The members of the average American family of three and one-quarter persons, their appetites satisfied with a portion of the four pounds of food each consumes daily, will climb into their three-year-old car this Sunday, back it out of the driveway of the home they own and have lived in five years or longer and go for a drive.

In the broadest market in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, stocks pushed forward to new highs in the first hour yesterday and spent the rest of the session fighting off the pressures of profit taking and other selling.

ASSOCIATED ARTISTS of New Jersey, numbering about fifty painters and sculptors, is holding its seventh New York exhibition at the Artists Equity Gallery. This body is regional in name only, there being nothing about the predominantly conservative works of art that could not as well have originated on this side of the Hudson River as on the other.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:
Two 1955 car lines with many new features were an- Chrysler division, Chrysler Corporation. They are composed of ten models in the medium price bracket Chrysler group and four in the Imperial line.

The Young Women's Christian Association was praised yesterday by Commissioner of Correction Anna M. Kross for showing the way to keep youth from crime by providing social, cultural and recreational facilities.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Sir Winston Churchill urged East and West tonight to live in friendship and peace. He hailed the day when the Western powers, on the basis of united strength, would negotiate an understanding with the Communist bloc.
Endorsement by President Eisenhower of the American Bible Society's Worldwide Bible Reading program, from Thanksgiving to Christmas was made public yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Nov. 9 -- A trip to Jamaica, Queens, in a special car of the Long Island Rail Road, a meeting and a trip back here in a station wagon and -- presto! -- one-half of the building fund goal of the North Country Community Hospital had been raised, H. Irving Pratt, president of the hospital, announced this afternoon.
The trend toward mergers in the textile industry has about run its course, according to J. Spencer Love, chairman of the Burlington Mills Corporation.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- If toys are a mirror of the adult world, the Frenchwoman is enjoying more household appliances than ever before, judging by the toy exhibits at the seventh annual Salon of Childhood, which opened today at the Grand Palais.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Nov. 9 -- A massive welded steel shield weighing 240 tons started its inch-by-inch journey under the Hudson River at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon. This began the major underwater operation in the construction of the $100,000,000 third tube of the Port of New York Authority's Lincoln Tunnel.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger received the Gold Medal Award of the Hundred Year Association last night for "outstanding achievement in the advancement of New York."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- There are two ways in which a Government official can avoid an embarrassing subject at a press conference. The first is to talk it to death without saying anything, and the second is to refuse to answer questions on the ground of national security.

Devereux Milburn Jr., president of the Sportsmanship Brotherhood, disclosed the terms of the Grantland Rice Award at a joint memorial luncheon of the Touchdown Club of New York and the Sportsmanship Brotherhood at the Hotel Astor yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The stock markets here were quieter today and prices irregular. The dullness was partly ascribed to diversion of interest to new issues.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 -- More shopping centers will be erected in this country in the future to meet the retail buying needs of an "America on Wheels." Opening later in the morning and staying open later in the evening is the trend in these developments, a former president of the Chicago Real Estate Board declared here today in an address at the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 9 -- New York Shipbuilding Corporation officials said today they were compelled to send 500 workers home because of a work stoppage, now in its second day, by 1,400 welders at the huge yard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Lawyers argued in the Supreme Court this afternoon whether "the play's the thing" or the playwrights, actors, salaries, contracts, scenery and all the personnel and paraphernalia of a theatrical production.
PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Three leaders of the Jewish community in the United States appealed today for an end to discrimination against the 340,000 Jews of Tunisia and Morocco.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland banker, said today he and his associates had bought 213,467 shares of common stock in the Portsmouth Steel Corporation for about $2,500,000 from the Alleghany Corporation.

President Eisenhower's selection of John Marshall Harlan of New York as associate justice of the Supreme Court deserves the enthusiastic approval it has so widely received. Named to fill the vacancy left by the untimely death of Robert H. Jackson, Judge Harlan is being elevated to the highest tribunal from his present position on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, to which he was appointed last March.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of "Quadrille" on the night of Dec. 15 at the Coronet Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Society of St. Johnland. Mrs. John Gerdes is chairman of the executive committee for the event, and among her aides is Mrs. Lyman C. Bleecker.

The premiere of "Wedding Breakfast" at the Forty-eighth Street has been deferred from Nov. 16 to Nov. 20 because extra rehearsal time is needed. Cuts are being made in Theodore Reeves' four-character comedy, now in Washington, and the motivation is undergoing clarification.

While Premier Yoshida, the statesman who led Japan from the chaos of national collapse to liberty and independence, is attempting to gain additional American aid in a gathering economic crisis, some political groups in Tokyo have launched an effort to overthrow him.

JERSEY CITY, NOV. 9 -- A motion by attorneys for four Hoboken police captains and two former public safety officials for the dismissal of eight-year-old conspiracy indictments was granted here this afternoon by Superior Court Judge Gene R. Mariano.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today the United States was considering providing fighter escorts for United States planes flying close to Communist territory.

Stone Webster Securities Corporation and Dean Witter Co. are offering a new issue of $4,000,000 of first mortgage 3 3/8 per cent bonds of the Sierra Pacific Power Company at 101.997 to yield 3.27 per cent to investors. The bonds, which will come due in 1984, were bought by the investment houses at competitive bidding yesterday with a bid of 101.32.

Seven members of the Colgate University faculty have sent telegrams to Cardinal Spellman and to Msgr. Edward R. Martin, protesting the latter's charge that an effort was being made to oust Senator Joseph R. McCarthy from the Senate because of his "Catholic ideals."
The apartment of A. George Lichtenstein at 441 West End Avenue was robbed of jewelry and furs valued at $25,000 yesterday while he and his wife were out, the police were told.
PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The elongated bodice so tightly molded that it reveals all feminine curves is beautifully handled by Jacques Fath in his midseason collection of late-day frocks.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 9 -- Iran's leaders have voiced determination to continue with the punishment of "traitors" and to correct the economic and moral conditions that breed revolutionary conspiracies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Senate Democratic leadership served notice on the Atomic Energy Commission today to get out of politics. Further, the Democrats pledged themselves to kill the controversial Dixon-Yates private power contract.

The monthly report of the Shipbuilders Council of America yesterday listed only twelve vessels, aggregating 156,760 gross tons, as under construction or on order from American shipyards -- the lowest point reached by the industry in almost six years.

With three more gas poisoning accidents bringing the number of such deaths this week to fifteen, the Department of Health yesterday ordered the transfer of inspectors from other duties to intensify the drive against defective gas appliances.

Wine-bibbing crewmen aboard the French liner Ile de France admitted yesterday that milk was a legitimate source of nutrition. However, they feel that it should be used only in emergencies, such as when the wine casks are bone dry.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France won another victory today in a dispute with the National Assembly. It was on the question of procedure in the discussion of the budget, which the Premier wishes to expedite.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 10 -- The two leading contenders for Premier Shigeru Yoshida's position as Japan's most important conservative political leader will meet today to discuss the formation of a new political party.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 9 (UP) -- Tom Gray, chairman of the Willys unit, Local 12, United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., said today workers who voted in April to take a pay cut to help the company had profited some $323,000 by their move.

His four-month struggle to land the Philadelphia Athletics' franchise and move it to Kansas City having been brought to a successful conclusion, Arnold Johnson, major league baseball's newest club owner, yesterday set himself to some more formidable tasks.
GRAPHIC art is well represented in the crowded art calendar this week with four outstanding exhibitions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Backers of the United States program for the peaceful uses of atomic energy suggested today the inclusion of the Soviet Union, India and Brazil in the preliminary stages.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Classified documents alleged to have been copied illegally by Joseph Sidney Petersen Jr., former Government employe under indictment for espionage, related to military movements in Korea in 1952 and the breaking of Netherlands Government codes, the Department of Justice disclosed today.
The cotton futures market slumped 20 to 51 points ($1.00 to $2.55 a bale) here yesterday. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was active.

NOT since Alice followed the White Rabbit into Wonderland, where things got "curiouser and curiouser," has there been anything like the Philadelphia Story. The American League owners in their valiant efforts to mess up the plot even bore a vague resemblance to the Red Queen, who screamed, "Off with their heads!"

BERLIN, Nov. 9 (Reuters) -- Two East German Government officials were sentenced to death in East Berlin today on charges of working for a United States-financed espionage organization. Five others were sentenced to long prison terms.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The Duke of Windsor denounced today as "completely untrue" allegations that in 1940 he had discussed Allied war plans with persons who later passed them through German channels to Hitler.

Four four-footed newly invited browsers at the New York Public Library were taken yesterday to the St. Agnes branch to receive an official welcome and recognition for their canine kind. Until now, dogs and cats and other pets of library users in the system's branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island have been permitted inside some branch libraries in a spirit of kindly sufferance.

Dr. Gabriel Hauge, economic adviser on President Eisenhower's personal staff and a former senior statistician for the Federal Reserve Board, told the Grocery Manufacturers of America yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that they have already contributed heavily to the attainment of the President's goal of a $550,000,000,000 annual gross product within the next ten years.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, Nov. 10 -- The Peiping radio said this morning that six waves of United States military aircraft "intruded" over the Chekiang coastal areas of southeast China in fifty sorties last Sunday and Monday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 9 -- The Australian Council of Trade Unions affirmed today its support of a nation-wide strike by members of the Waterside Workers Federation and directed members of other unions to carry on their duties until otherwise instructed.
YONKERS, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Prince Eton, owned by Mrs. Katherine Peters of Schuylkill Haven, Pa., and driven by John Bedell, scored a driving triumph at Yonkers Raceway tonight in the Forget Me Not Pace.

Veterans Day tomorrow will be celebrated with parades, patriotic ceremonies and mass administrations of the citizenship oath to 50,000 new citizens throughout the nation. Formerly observed as Armistice Day, the holiday was changed to Veterans Day by Federal law on June 1.
ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- The United States Supreme Court's decision upholding the State University ban on national social organizations on its campuses will have no immediate effect on those institutions.

The election of Dr. Walter O. Lundberg as chairman for 1955 of the division of agricultural and food chemistry of the American Chemical Society was announced yesterday. Dr. Lundberg, who is executive director of the Hormel Institute and Professor of Agricultural Biochemistry at the University of Minnesota, succeeds Dr. C. S. Boruff, technical director of Hiram Walker Sons, Inc., Peoria, Ill.

FLINT, Mich., Nov. 9 -- An alliance is only as strong as its parts, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway said tonight in warming against any retreat toward a posture of isolationism by the United States because of disagreements with its Allies.
GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- John McEwen, Australian Minister for Agriculture, made the boldest of several attacks loosed today on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Senate Investigators of housing scandals found today that after contractors had reaped an estimated $1,000,000,000 "windfall" profit through Government-guaranteed home construction loans, they were allowed to raise rents by at least $2,000,000 a year.

Two new films open today at first run theatres. At Loew's State is "Phffft," a marital comedy starring Judy Holliday, Jack Carson, Jack Lemmon and Kim Novak with Luella Gear and Donald Randolph heading the supporting cast.
RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 9 -- Lieut. Gov. Luther Hartwell Hodges was sworn in this afternoon as Governor of North Carolina a few hours after funeral services for Gov. William B. Umstead, who died Sunday.

Little orchestras have proliferated in this city since World War II. One of the best of them that has emerged is Robert Scholz' American Chamber Orchestra and last night this ensemble gave the first of the three Tuesday evenings of music it is presenting this season at Town Hall.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 9 -- The National Council of Catholic Women today asked the United States to continue to seek "enforcible disarmament on a worldwide scale."

Unionized employes of the John Wanamaker department store hope for a formal answer this afternoon on their offer to invest 10 per cent of their weekly earnings in the store to prevent its scheduled closing Jan. 31.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- After circling Chicago for more than an hour while the crew made desperate efforts to free its jammed landing gear, an American Airlines Convair twin-engined plane landed safely on the nose and left wheels at the Glenview Naval Air Station airport at 5:05 P. M. today.

Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, former president of Smith College and widow of the banker who served as Ambassador to Mexico, received the annual public service citation of the Community Service Society yesterday.

Investigation Commissioner Peter Campbell Brown directed commissioners of three city departments yesterday to turn over to District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Kings County any information they have about gratuities allegedly paid to city workers by a concern of building wreckers.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 9 -- Well-qualified legislators are the answer to unscrupulous lobbyists, a discussion group at the National Municipal League's annual conference heard today.

Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's concern about the political and psychological loyalties of the projected West German army emphasizes the intangible problems and hidden dangers that will confront Bonn and the West as the Federal Republic takes up arms.

THE maintenance force at Rockefeller Center has picked the Center's 1954 Christmas tree. It's a sixty-five footer, about sixty-five years old, out of woods owned by Elmer Rowe in Belvidere, N. J. It weighs about four tons and will be trailer-trucked into Rockefeller Plaza around 8 o'clock the morning of Nov. 29.

A new geologic calendar offering a more precise time scale for the age of the earth and its rocks was described yesterday at Columbia University at the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences. The academy also was told of a "newborn" superstar a million times as bright as the sun.

A ceremonial traffic tie-up was held yesterday noon at Park Avenue and Thirty-third Street, for what 1,500 smiling pedestrians decided was a good reason. It was a tribute to Patrolman James Dunn, retiring after thirty-four years' directing traffic at that hot corner.

Control of the two apartment houses at 2559 and 2575 Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx has been acquired by a syndicate represented by Mitchell Siegel, attorney, through the purchase of stock of Sedgwick Towers, Inc., and Sedgwick Properties, Inc. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers.
The Republic of the Philippines was honored here yesterday by the American Arbitration Association.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A resolution proposing censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was formally introduced this afternoon for action in the Senate.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 9 (AP) Mrs. J. M. Branham's Shadows Start, slated for retirement to a breeding farm, closed his thoroughbred racing career today by scoring his first victory of the season in the Narragansett Park feature.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Bangs almost down to the eyebrows and casual tapered strands on the brow strongly reminiscent of the haircut of young men of fashion during the Directoire period, have led Paris to dub the new hairdos the "Dandy Coiffures."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 10 (AP) -- "Were not trying to kid ourselves," Coach Lou Little of Columbia said today of his team's football contest against Navy here Saturday.
BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- Berlin housewives began rummaging in their closets today looking for treasure.

The New York Stock Exchange had its third successive 3,000,000-share day yesterday as new highs were established for the current upward movement. The market fought off a wave of realizing in the afternoon and managed to close with moderate net gains.

Taking advantage of the present special session, President Eisenhower yesterday submitted to the Senate the Southeast Asian Collective Defense Pact with the request for immediate committee study and early approval. As stated in his special message and in an accompanying letter from Secretary Dulles, this pact, which has already passed the British House of Commons, complements our other Pacific security treaties and represents another bulwark for security in that area.
That children with serious emotional disturbances are not, because of general public apathy and misunderstanding, receiving the kind of help they need, was indicated last night.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 10 -- Directors of the National Reclamation Association moved today to provide a convincing answer to this question being asked with growing frequency by Eastern members of Congress:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- The Most Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart of Washington decried tonight the manner in which the free countries had kept their doors "selfishly closed or only grudgingly ajar" to migration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the first day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. Debate was opened by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, chairman of the select committee that studied the charges against the Wisconsin Republican.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Sewell L. Avery, chairman of the board of Montgomery Ward Co., today declared "the management of Montgomery Ward will use every legitimate means to resist and defeat the raiding parties being organized to grab the large liquid assets of this company."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 5 points lower to 9 points higher than on Tuesday, with far months relatively strong.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower stood his ground today for the Dixon-Yates private power contract.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Eight American cities are expected to extend bids for the 1960 Olympic Games before a selection group of the United States Olympic Committee meeting here next Tuesday and Wednesday. The 1956 Games will be held in Melbourne, Australia.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 10 (AP) -- The three-day total of prices bid for horses at the annual standardbred sales today soared to $944,705 for 578 head.

The Catholic War Veterans do not support the personal ambition of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy or any other elected official engaged in partisan political controversy. As a member of that organization I deeply regret any inference that the Catholic War Veterans or even a substantial number of its members subscribe to the political opinions expressed by Msgr. Edward R. Martin in his address before a local meeting of our organization at the Roosevelt Hotel.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 10 -- The bill to amend the Stevedoring Industry Act passed all stages in the House of Representatives today and tonight was sent to the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Any refusal to look at new ideas, foreign or domestic, is a confession of fear, President Eisenhower asserted today. He for one doesn't feel that fear.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower told a delegation from the National Conference of Christians and Jews today that "without a concept of the dignity of man founded on religious faith, we are sunk."

Two new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Little Carnegie is "Aida," an Italian-made version of the Giuseppe Verdi opera in Ferrania-color. Sophie Loren, Lois Maxwell, Luciano della Marra and Afro Poli head the cast of the I. F. E. release.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows;
HONG KONG, Nov. 10 -- Gen. Su Yu has been named chief of staff of the Chinese Red Army's General Staff. He succeeds Gen. Nieh Jung-chen, who had been chief of staff on an "acting" basis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Wheat and corn futures displayed considerable strength today, especially wheat, which was bought heavily at times although meeting waves of profit-taking by longs on the hard spots.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- The oil industry is on the threshold of what might become its greatest era, M. J. Rathbone president of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:

The eleventh annual Christmas fair arranged by members of the Womens Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church will be held on next Thursday night and next Friday morning and afternoon in the recreation hall of the church, Park Avenue at Ninety-first Street.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 10 -- An America supreme in the air is the best guarantee of world peace, realtors were told today.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Two Japanese leaders purged by the Allied occupation formally decided yesterday to form a new conservative party to oust the pro-United States Yoshida Government.

It is now possible, if you have had a difficult day at the office, to stop at Grand Central Terminal on the way home and tell your troubles to the United States Department of Labor. All you have to do is sit down in an oversize telephone booth on the north balcony of the terminal and pick up a free phone connected directly to the New York regional office of the department.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Retail stores across the nation sold $14,623,000,000 worth of goods in October, the Bureau of the Census estimated today.

Dr. Clarence C. (Buddy) Combs, Eatontown, N. J., veterinarian who captains the Red Bank Polo Club, again has been placed at the top with a ten-goal rating according to the 1954-55 handicaps released yesterday by the Indoor Polo Association of America.

WITH slender resources of production, but commendable zeal and unflagging enthusiasm in the cause of modern music-drama, The Opera Players, under the direction of Paul Aron, gave two chamber operas, one of them a world premiere, last night in the Provincetown Playhouse.

An American President, by the nature of his position, makes history and is a historical figure. Too often our Presidents have left the necessary process of gathering biographical material to posterity. The birthplaces of most of our Presidents are gone and in a number of cases there are not even markers on the sites.

The Proctor Gamble Company made an interesting deal yesterday. It purchased alternate-week sponsorship of three current television shows -- "I Love Lucy," "Topper" and "My Favorite Husband," all on the C. B. S. network.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 10 -- The big question agitating Princetonians as Nassau's seventy-seventh football game with Yale approaches is whether or not Royce Flippin will be in the Tiger backfield Saturday in the Bowl.

HOBOKEN, Nov. 10 -- The hundredth anniversary of Castle Stevens, ancestral home of the Stevens family on the campus of Stevens Institute of Technology here, was observed this afternoon with the unveiling of a plaque at the historic structure on the grounds of the engineering college.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Adult education leaders meeting here indicated today that they were being snubbed or at least not receiving due recognition at high Government levels.

Quick action developed yesterday as a result of the charges made by Milton M. Bergerman, chirman of the Citizens Union, in a letter to Mayor Wagner, declaring that the regulation of theatre ticket sales was "the most successful farce in the history of the New York theatre."

MONTREAL, Nov. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Details of a service installed by the Bell Telephone Company of Canada were given today in Superior Court during extradition proceedings against two Montreal stock salesmen. The two are wanted in Detroit in connection with an alleged $300,000 oil stock swindle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The interfaith leaders seeking a statement of common faith on which to fight communism concluded a three-day conference here today.
A touch of warfare exploded yesterday on Governors Island, while bright afternoon sunlight glinted on Manhattan's sky-scrapers across the bay.
Parades, speeches and the traditional period of silence will mark today's observance here of Veterans Day, previously called Armistice Day.
LANSING, Mich., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Purchase of the assets of Reo Motors, Inc., of Lansing by the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation of Detroit was announced today by the Reo directors.

Despite a weak opening, cocoa prices closed strong yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The near-by December option ended at the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit higher. Final quotations were 77 to 100 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on 347 contracts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Zenith Radio Corporation reported today that its net profit in the nine months ended Sept. 30 declined to $2,573,954, or $5.23 a share, from $4,098,074, or $8.32 a share, in the corresponding period of 1953.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today reaffirmed its approval of the "agreed system plan" for reorganizing the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

Advertising has helped this country to come through "a most difficult time" and it is helping now in the economy's drive "toward the greatest days our nation has even known," Henry J. Taylor, economist and news analyst, told the national convention of the Outdoor Advertising Association at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

Events tonight: "Die Meistersinger," Metropolitan Opera, 7:30 o'clock, New York Philharmonic- Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Zino Francescatti, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; De la Maza, guitarist, Town Hall, 8:30; Composers Group of New York, Mason Hamlin Salon, 8 East Forty-third Street, 7.
LINDENHURST, L. I., Nov. 10 -- Frank Frevele, clerk of the school district here, said tonight that he had scheduled a special district election on Dec. 4 to choose five new trustees.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- A distinguished Icelandic anthropologist, Prof. Jon Steffensen, has come to the conclusion that a considerable proportion of the blood-thirsty Viking pirates of the ninth century and onward probably were restless Irishmen "out on the loose."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Georgi M. Malenkov, the Soviet Premier, has proposed the application of practical, old-fashioned diplomacy as a way to ease tensions between East and West.

Delegates of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs recommended yesterday that welfare rolls be opened to public inspection in all counties "where secrecy in welfare spending is still in effect."

Grocery manufacturers were urged yesterday by a leader in the industry to step up their efforts to improve the nutritive value of their products. They were also urged to intensify campaigns to educate the public in desirable food habits.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The Viscount, Britain's four-engined turbo-prop airliner, has been virtually approved for operation on United States routes, its manufacturer, Vickers Armstrong, announced today.

Home from a road trip on which they won two of three games, the New York Knickerbockers will face the Rochester Royals at Madison Square Garden tonight in the second half of the local season's first National Basketball Association double-header.

The election of Conrad Hilton and Richard C. Patterson as directors of the Empire State Building Corporation was announced yesterday by Col. Henry Crown, president of the company that owns the world's tallest office building.

Manufacturers of men's wear were lauded yesterday for producing well-styled lines representing good values for spring. Ele Schneider, merchandise manager for Kirby, Block Co., Inc., speaking at a clinic at his company's offices, added that no price declines in men's wear could be expected.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The Air Force today grounded its F-100 Super-Sabrejet fighters the world's fastest operational plane, because of three recent crashes.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 10 -- President Juan D. Peron accused Roman Catholic Bishops tonight of waging a campaign against his regime. Declaring he did not blame the church, the President said the three bishops were "enemies of the Government."
The Traffic Department, which is studying how to simplify the Columbus Circle traffic pattern, was forced last night into some temporary changes.

A contract has been signed by Webb Knapp, Inc., for the purchase of the two six-story store and office buildings at 693 and 695 Fifth Avenue from Warner-Hudnut, Inc. The transaction also includes the purchase by Webb Knapp and the leasing back to Warner-Hudnut of the five loft buildings on the west side of the Avenue of the Americas between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- General Manager Frank Lane of the Chicago White Sox predicted today that San Francisco and Los Angeles would get major league baseball as part of a ten-club league set-up within three years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers were completing a 1954 harvest that would be within 3 per cent of last year's large volume despite losses from a severe drought.
Slices of frog's eggs one-millionth of an inch thick have revealed the existence of tiny "threads of life" linking the nucleus of the living cell with its outer envelope of protoplasm.
The New Breed stood in serried ranks yesterday in homage to the Old.

Borough President John Cashmore promised a group of property owners in the Marine Manor section of Brooklyn yesterday that they would not have to abandon their small homes to make way for the construction of a new junior high school.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10 -- The Mizrachi Women's Organization of America elected Mrs. S. Deborah Ebin of Brooklyn today as its national president at the closing session here of its twenty-ninth annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The $1,000,000 Philip Murray Foundation, established after the death of the former Congress of Industrial Organizations president in 1952, is "virtually out of business," its director reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Ambassador Bohlen sent a full report on his conversation with Premier Malenkov to the State Department for the consideration of Secretary Dulles and President Eisenhower.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 10 -- Three supervisory employes at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation were manhandled today as a work stoppage by 1,400 welders at the huge yard went into its third day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The Government is planning to give foreign housewives, including some with "Communistic leanings," a look at kitchens in the United States.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 -- Jordan Olivar, Yale's head football coach, today named Al Ward, a sophomore from Glencoe, Ill., as a starter for the Elis' meeting with Princeton in the Bowl on Saturday. Ward will open at left halfback.

A charge that there may exist in this country "a planned campaign to destroy men who show leadership and praiseworthy American principles" was made yesterday by Roger M. Kyes, vice president of the General Motors Corporation.

Isaac Harris, a venerable Staten Islander, celebrated his 104th birthday yesterday calmly without party or other celebration. Mr. Harris, who lives at 444 Bloomingdale Road, Pleasant Plains, said he was born in New Brighton, S. I., on Nov. 10 1850.
A man who lives in a glass house and throws stones should not be surprised when he discovers that he is undergoing a shattering experience.

Steel production in the United States increased last month to 7,702,000 net tons, the highest level for any month since January, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 6,807,483 tons of ingots and steel for castings produced in September and with the year's low to date of 6,627,597 tons in July. Output in October last year was 9,462,722 tons.
A large crowd of Queens property owners cheered, stamped and at times jeered during a hearing in City Hall yesterday to punctuate their insistence that their home areas were not slums.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The man who predicted the H-line years ago and was called a fool by fashion experts has the last laugh on everybody now, thanks to Christian Dior.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Losses predominated in the stock markets today and business slackened slightly, though still running at a high level. British Government funds were a firm exception, but the demand was confined mainly to securities with a life or fifteen years or less; gains were in the neighborhood of five shillings (seventy cents).
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 10 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain, arrived tonight to spend the remainder of her United States visit here.
It seems unlikely that first prize in a horse-naming contest ever would go to the person who named the winner of yesterday's feature race at Jamaica, The winner was Dead Duck.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The editorial board of Tribune, weekly publication of the left-wing faction of the Labor party headed by Aneurin Bevan, defied tonight a virtual ultimatum laid down by the party's National Executive Committee.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 10 -- Argentina's General Confederation of Labor declared war today against Roman Catholic infiltration into key positions in unions. It told church authorities that the confederation's executive board considered the actions of certain priests "the greatest danger" to President Peron's syndicalist organizations.

MONTREAL, Nov. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Leopold A. Renaud, president of the Montreal brokerage firm bearing his name, said today he was soliciting proxy votes from common stockholders of the Brown Company of Berlin, N. H.
Fifteen persons were injured late yesterday afternoon in a collision between a bus and a privately owned taxicab in Long Island City, Queens.

The United States Gypsum Company raised annual dividends on its common stock to $10 a share with the declaration yesterday of an extra of $4 along with the regular quarterly dividend of $1. They are payable on Dec. 24.

Macy's New York and Gimbles New York have quietly cut prices on branded lines of electric house-wares to bring them in line with those quoted by discount houses. Cuts ranged from 20 to 30 per cent. So far as could be learned yesterday no fair-traded merchandise was involved.
Nuts of many varieties are in good supply at reasonable cost for the home cook to use now and throughout the holiday season.

Jesuit missionaries in North America in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries sent to their superiors in France reports of exploration, travel and adventure that have since become a source for the understanding of early American history.

A drastic modification of the city's master plan of one-way avenues is under study by the Traffic Department. The proposal would reverse the traffic pattern on one-way avenues on the West Side as well as add Broadway to the network.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Edmund R. Whittaker, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said today he "deplored' what he called the tendency of many companies to sell major medical insurance at low rates but with limited coverage.

The second annual Xavier Award of the New York Province of the Society of Jesus was made last night to Auxiliary Bishop Fulton J. Sheen of the New York Roman Catholic Arch- diocese, who is national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower submitted the Southeast Asian defense treaty to the Senate today and pressed for its "early and favorable consideration" and ratification.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- France and the Soviet Union signed a trade agreement today calling for a 60 per cent increase in the exchange of goods between the two countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Joe McCarthy has decided on his strategy. He is going to fight against censure by the Senate with every weapon at his command and he's going to keep it up as long as he can.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- The United States warned its chief partners in world trade today that it would not wait forever for them to give exports from the United States the equal treatment to which they are, by agreement, entitled.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- A United States consultant to the French shoe and clothing industries has demonstrated what can be done by the Government of Premier Pierre Mendes-France in its announced program of expanding French productivity.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Brookfield Farms' I Salute, a 7-10 favorite, broke Pimlico's six-furlong track record in the feature today, but the chief excitement was caused by a 209-to-1-shot's victory in the eighth and final race.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh was reported to have agreed yesterday to abandon mass hearings on housing violations such as the session in the Bay Ridge Magistrate's Court on Oct. 8 to which 11,356 landlords were summoned.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Senate plunged into the McCarthy censure debate today in intense bitterness.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Government asked the Supreme Court today to permit its antitrust suit against professional boxing to go to trial in the lower courts on its merits.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Col. Earl (Red) Blaik, Army football coach, will be absent from the bench for the first time in his twenty-one-year career as a head coach on Saturday when Army meets Penn at Franklin Field.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 10 -- Dr. Hossein Fatemi, Foreign Minister under former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, was shot at 6 A. M. today by an army firing squad. He had been convicted by a court-martial of rebellion against the monarchy in the days immediately before Dr. Mossadegh was overthrown by the Royalists.

The holding company of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company has sold its porperty at 605-635 West 132d Street and 604-634 West 133d Street to a wholly-owned subsidiary of the General Realty and Utilities Corporation and has leased it back for twenty-five years.

THERE is likely to be some improvement in the duck shooting in Connecticut, Long Island and New Jersey next week, for a sharp drop in temperature in the north sent the loitering waterfowl southward. Reports from both Connecticut and Long Island yesterday indicate that good flights of diving ducks are arriving.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, announced today approval of a Bureau of Land Management order returning 90,240 acres in Colorado to the public domain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower expressed confidence today that his Republican Administration and the new Democratic Congress arriving in January would be able to carry on a truly bipartisan foreign policy.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The resignation of Robert Marjolin, Secretary General of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, was announced here today. M. Marjolin is now in the United States fulfilling speaking engagements.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- France today won the four-sport Britannia Shield competition for servicemen, with the Netherlands second, the British Royal Air Force third and the United States Air Force sixth.
ABILENE, Kan., Nov. 10 -- Granted the minimum of fanfare a President can expect, General Eisenhower returned for a visit to his hometown here tonight.

New designs and better fabrics have raised sales of living-room furniture "to a very satisfactory rate" in the last few months, D. H. Kroehler reported yesterday. He is president of the Kroehler Manufacturing Company, said to be the largest producer of living-room furniture in the world.
The Victory ship Allendale was towed out of New York yesterday, bound for lay-up in Virginia after getting $36,754 worth of repairs in two shipyards here.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The French Socialist party congress brightened today the prospect for French ratification of the Paris agreements.
Giant balloons are dropping 14,500,000 propaganda leaflets monthly over Hungary.

Thirty-six years ago today, when the armistice ending World War I was signed, great celebrations took place throughout the world -- and for good cause. Hostilities had ceased and mankind had effected what was thought to be a lasting peace. Nov. 11 became a national holiday in the British Isles, France and the United States.
Governor Dewey has purchased a cooperative apartment at 141 East Seventy-second Street and will live there with his family after his term expires, it was learned yesterday.

Although they did only a little of the attacking and play-making, the Toronto Maple Leafs gained the victory in their National Hockey League game against the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.
Directors of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, Inc., proposed yesterday a 3-for-1 split of the capital stock.
Averell Harriman, the apparent winner of last week's Governorship election, said yesterday that he was seeking a man of "creative capacity" to head the State Commerce Department.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines appealed today to the United States and the Soviet Union to donate to the United Nations the amount of nuclear materials required for an atomic bomb.
A new safety campaign by the city threatened yesterday to drive thousands of families from single furnished rooms in slums and other substandard areas.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., permanent United States Representative to the United Nations, said today there was "nothing to" reports that he planned to resign and accept a high position in the Eisenhower Administration in Washington.

W. R. Grace Co., foreign trading and shipping concern with large interests in the chemicals field, announced yesterday the election of James J. Minot and Philip L. Reed as directors and Hugh S. Ferguson as a vice president.
Brooklyn College opened its twenty-fifth anniversary celebration yesterday in its new arts and music building, Walt Whitman Hall. Twenty-five hundred persons were on hand.

Plans to spend $500,000 in the next five years in an attempt to learn how to prevent or cure the common cold were approved by fifty industrial leaders meeting here yesterday at the Union League Club, 38 East Thirty-seventh Street.

Fifty-seven prize-winning objects in the fourth annual Versatility in Design Contest held by the Hess Brothers department store of Allentown, Pa., were shown yesterday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The demagoguery of Senator McCarthy has rarely been revealed in clearer terms than in the address which he released in opening his defense against the pending resolution of censure. And seldom has he shown so unmistakably his contempt for the intelligence of the American people as he has in this speech consisting of a mixture of effrontery and self-serving martyrdom.

What is said to be the first time a union has undertaken the presentation of a play dealing with geriatrics will take place next Tuesday night at the Roosevelt Auditorium, 100 East Seventeenth Street.
The New York Athletic Club paid tribute last night to nine member athletes and two teams that won or shared national titles in six sports during 1954.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The page-leaves in the calendar will be turned fifty-four times before the Democrats can take control of the machinery of Congress -- provided the party balances are not altered meanwhile. But already they are supporting the President's campaign argument against the transfer of Congressional responsibility from the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Southern coal producers hope to negotiate labor cost reductions with John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers without disturbing their wage contracts, a top industry spokesman said today.
A modernistic new subway station at Howard Beach, Queens, has been planned by the Transit Authority.

MONTREAL, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The chairman of the Montreal Stock Exchange said last night that bogus stock operations were being conducted here and that the city's two stock exchanges were "gravely concerned."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The question of defining aggression was postponed at the United Nations today for two more years.

TRENTON, Nov. 10 -- New Jersey Democratic leaders decided today to seek a state-wide recount of the ballots cast in last week's Senatorial election. The decision was reached after a long conference with Representative Charles R. Howell, the Democratic candidate.
Many parties will be given at the annual dinner of the Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York to be given next Monday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 10 -- Joseph P. Kennedy, father of Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, issued a statement tonight saying his son was "making good progress after his recent operation and is in no danger."
