WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

Now that the practice of New York City's firemen to hold down part-time outside jobs, long winked at, has official sanction and is out in the open, the interest among the fire-eaters in making spare-time, change has mounted.
Marking Veterans Day, 100 veterans of three wars are to donate blood today at the Red Cross donor center, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.

We heard a lot of nonsense shouted by the leaders and candidates of both parties during the election and now, after the dust is settled and barrels of aspirin are consumed to relieve headaches, we hear a lot of talk of losers and winners shaking hands like good sports.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Latin American newspaper executives attending the Caribbean area press seminar left today for Washington and the final three days of the conference.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- Allied Artists Pictures Corporation for the first time has declared a cash dividend of 10 cents a share on the common stock of the company, Steve Broidy, president, announced here today at the annual stockholders' meeting held at the studio.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Utah Republican, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy on these counts against him:

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development made a profit of $5,400,000 for the three months ended Sept. 30 and increased reserve funds against possible losses to $154,000,000. For the same period last year the bank's profit was $5,300,000.
A legal fight to determine whether Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein or the Board of Elections had prior right to registration signature books was settled out of court last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from President Eisenhower to Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of Upstate New York nd chairman of the Senate-House Atomic Energy Committee, on the controversial Dixon-Yates contract:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 3, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

A masked gunmen held up and shot a payroll messenger yesterday afternoon on the fourteenth floor of 65 West Thirty-ninth Street and escaped with $6,910. The gunman overlooked an additional $1,000, which the messenger, a foreman for Brookfield Hats, manufacturer of women's hats, was carrying in another envelope in a jacket pocket.

Automobile tires that will last for 100,000 miles are in the early development stage and probably will be available in three or four years, Dr. Harry L. Fisher, president of the American Chemical Society, said last night. Such tires will be virtually puncture-proof and can be made in colors to match the car.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined by 651,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 149,138,000 barrels, compared with 149,789,000 a week earlier and 141,635,000 a year ago.
The Dixon-Yates contract is complicated enough to excuse errors of fact in argument.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Cardinal Spellman said today that the anti-Communist nations had "waited and wavered in apathy and apeasement" while the Communists had girded themselves for another war -- "A war for America's annihilation."
BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- Parents have it in their power to protect their children from harmful television shows and bad literature, the National Council of Catholic Women was told today.

The musical stage rights to "Serenade," James M. Cain's earthy and highly successful novel of 1937, have been purchased by the newly formed producing team of Martin Gabel, Robert L. Joseph and Henry M. Margolis.

The State of Maryland announced yesterday plans for the sale of general obligation bonds totaling $16,025,000 to finance various construction projects. The state will receive bids for the bonds on Nov. 24. The issue will be dated Dec. 15, 1954 and will come due serially from 1957 to 1969.

Our squadron is adopting a Japanese orphanage this Christmas. We need some clothes to give the children, as the orphanages here are not adequately heated. The children range in age from 1 to 12 and are poorly clothed. Clothes that are worn out by our standards are good for many years here and anything that these children could get to keep them warm would be greatly appreciated by both us and them.

TORONTO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A second jockey was suspended day as the Ontario Racing Commission continued its investigation of reports that gamblers tried to fix a horse race at Dufferin Park here last Saturday.

AUCKLAND, N. Z., Nov. 10 -- A report of a United States plan to test hydrogen bombs in the Antarctic has become a campaign issue in the New Zealand election. The topic was raised by the leader of the Opposition in Parliament, Walter Nash, who is leading the Labor party campaign for the election Saturday.

A racket in staving off traffic tickets through sale of police "courtesy cards" at $10 and up was disclosed yesterday. In Kings County Court last night it was said to involve "at least" 100 motorcycle and patrol car police in the city and on the Long Island and Westchester parkways.

Dr. You Chan Yang, South Korean Ambassador to the United States, reaffirmed last night that his nation wanted "a limited and carefully restricted war" waged to free North Korea from Communist control.

TELEVISION, the electronic monster that strangles most sports, has been the biggest boon to professional football since the invention of the turnstile. Only the pro football men have licked video and made it a slave instead of a master. By televising the "away" games and blacking out the "at home" games, they have adroitly steered clear of the giveaway factor that is choking the life out of baseball, boxing and other sports.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Rugged Al Andrews, his nose bleeding freely from the fifth round on, tonight pounded out a decision over fast-punching Chico Varona of Havana, Cuba, in a non-televised ten-round bout at the Chicago Stadium.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Boston and Chicago swapped places at the bottom of the National Hockey League tonight when the Bruins defeated the Black Hawks, 4 -- 3, on Fleming Mackell's unassisted third-period goal.

ROME, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The publisher of the Rome Daily American, Ray Vir Den, today accused "a few colonels" of "action that strikes at freedom of the press," and branded an Army denial a "masterpiece of evasion."

Dr. Selman A. Waksman, 1952 Nobel Prize winner in physiology and medicine, warned last night that the world could not be made safe from new diseases and new epidemics unless nations "find ways and means of living together in peace."
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Arnold Johnson said today he would enlarge the stadium of the Kansas City Athletics to accommodate 45,000 baseball fans, if necessary.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The French Cabinet adopted tonight a series of measures designed to limit the manufacture, sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages. Such measures have been unknown in peacetime in France.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Arguments were ended today in the Supreme Court on the Government's appeal from a lower court dismissal of its anti-trust suit against the Shubert theatrical interests. The court took the case under advisement.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 10 -- Nasrollah S. Fatemi, former member of the Iranian Parliament and delegate to the United Nations, suffered a heart attack today when told of the execution of his brother, Hossein, as a traitor in Iran.

Ten thousand American and European menus, dating from 1790 to 1952, were sold for $900 at the auction of cookbooks and related materials that ended yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 10 -- The Communist Vietminh Government of Northern Vietnam was reported here today to have sent two regiments to the Tonkin coastal region south of the Red River delta to prevent thousands of Vietnamese Catholics gathered along the coast from fleeing south.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower and Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan agreed in a joint statement today that the United States and Japan would cooperate with the free nations of Asia "to maintain and promote the peace and prosperity of Asia."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A giant statue honoring the Marine Corps was dedicated today with Vice President Richard M. Nixon saluting it as "a symbol of the hopes and dreams of all Americans." The seventy-five-foot bronze memorial, in Arlington, Va., close by the Arlington National Cemetery, depicts the historic flag raising on Iwo Island during World War II.
HAIFA, Israel, Nov. 9 -- American benefactors of Jewish refugee immigration to Israel watched the new "ship-to-settlement" policy in action today.

The fourteenth annual convention of the National Association of Travel Organizations opened yesterday at the Park Sheraton Hotel. Four hundred delegates from all sections of the country are registered for three days of travel-promotion discussions.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10 -- Lieut. Comdr. Edwin D. Scorza, 32 years old, of Somers Point, N. J., was killed today when a Navy Corsair fighter crashed into a marsh while he was simulating a strafing mission.

Walter Gordon Merritt, for more than half a century in the forefront of industry's legal spokesmen in labor cases, has been dropped as counsel for the Hat Corporation of America. A forty-five-week strike of 1,500 workers in the company's plant at Norwalk, Conn., was settled last May.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of a joint statement issued today by the White House covering talks between President Eisenhower and Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida:

Percival Robert Moses, consulting engineer and an active supporter of civic enterprises here, was honored on his eightieth birthday yesterday by members of the Downtown Manhattan Association, of which he is honorary president and former chief executive.

The annual card party for the benefit of the Helping Hand Association will be held on Monday in the ballroom of the Colony Club. The event will mark the eighty-ninth anniversary of the founding of the beneficiary, one of the oldest private charitable organizations in New York. It was organized in 1865.

A sufficient number of the ballots cast in last week's election have now been totaled on a national scale to provide startling statistical confirmation of the closeness of the contest. According to unofficial figures, compiled by The Associated Press, the Democrats had a plurality of some 1,750,000 out of approximately 42,000,000 votes.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 10 (Reuters) -- John Nicholls, new British Ambassador to Israel, presented his credentials today to President Izhak Ben-Zvi at a ceremony in the Israeli sector of Jerusalem.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan yesterday ruled that Jules Fink, owner of the Marlot Stable, whose application to race his horses here was first denied five years ago, is entitled to a new hearing by the New York State Racing Commission.

Hanging in the window of Hansen Lamps, 978 First Avenue, is a lighting fixture that looks like a translucent hornet's nest. It is one of a group of hand-blown crystal lamps, chandeliers and wall fixtures created by Carl Fagerlund for a Copenhagen hotel and the Frederiksberg (Denmark) Town Hall.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10 -- The Harvard varsity football team scrimmaged with the junior varsity for an hour today, with emphasis on its defenses and its passing attack.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 10 -- John M. Gleason, Greenwich Police Chief since 1941, past president of the International Association of Chiefs of Police and one of the nation's foremost law enforcement officials, was appointed today by the Greenwich Board of Selectmen as the town's first Chief Administrative Officer.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 10 (UP) -- Forty-one German scientists, creators of Hitler's V-2 rockets, will become American citizens tomorrow.

Ernest M. Frost, director of the Greater New York March of Dimes, appealed yesterday for the enlistment now of 150,000 New York City women as volunteers for the 1955 Mothers March on Polio. Mr. Frost spoke at a luncheon, attended by forty leaders in the five boroughs who are organizing the local mothers' march, at Cavanagh's Restaurant 260 West Twenty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower took a calm and moderating view today of the attack by Soviet aircraft last Sunday on a United States plane.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- There is a strong trend in West Europe and Britain toward the negotiation of a general settlement of Continental problems with the Soviet Union.
YONKERS, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Ogden Hanover, driven by Charles Fitzpatrick Jr., won the featured Hartsdale Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight by a head from the 3-2 favorite, Buffalo Street.
A warning that tuberculosis may be contracted from domestic servants, barbers and beauty parlor employes was sounded yesterday by a city Health Department expert.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Clarence W. Miles, president of the Baltimore Orioles, assured the Washington Senators today he would sit down with them and "iron out TV differences."

News of Jacques Fath's improving health was brought to New York by Harry Lupia, who left Paris by plane Monday night. The Paris designer, who has been suffering from a blood disease, is confined to his home. He is able to see his friends and to follow through on the work of his collection.

Leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association in this city demanded yesterday the right to make a face-to-face reply to charges by Philadelphia pier operators that the New York group was encouraging the thirteen-day-old shutdown of dry cargo handling in Philadelphia.

Two rare copies of the War Message that the late President Woodrow Wilson delivered to a joint session of Congress on April 2, 1917, will go on display today at the Wilson Collection of the Columbia University Libraries. The collection is in the Butler Library Building, West 114th Street near Broadway.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Charging irregularities, Senator Thomas A. Burke, Democrat, demanded today a recount of the Hamilton County vote that was the difference between victory and the defeat he suffered in the Nov. 2 election.

Slim silhouettes in casual but sophisticated fur fashions were shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria by Aronowicz, 19 West Fifty-seventh Street. The trench coat, the shirt-jacket and the short, easy-to-wear bolero were interpreted in luxurious furs.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10 -- Dmitri Shostakovich, who is perhaps the greatest living Russian composer, has recently completed three new works, is reviving one of his old unpublished compositions and is planning a new opera.

Despite the rapid growth in the use of machines, only 5 per cent of the cost of bookkeeping in American offices has been found to be accounted for by such devices, the balance going to payrolls. Thomas J. Watson Jr., president of the International Business Machines Corporation, made this observation yesterday when he spoke at a special meeting of banking executives sponsored by the I. B. M. in the Biltmore Hotel.

Three members of The New York Times Company have been elevated to executive posts left vacant by the recent death of Godfrey N. Nelson. The appointments, made by the board of directors in realigning the duties and responsibilities formerly exercised by Mr. Nelson, were announced yesterday by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president.

Leg of lamb, which is being offered in many stores at moderate cost (about 65 cents a pound), is a great favorite with those who cook with an Italian or Middle Eastern touch. Such cooks like to prepare this cut with sage, rosemary, oregano, garlic, olive oil and wine (not all in a single recipe, of course).
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The State Education Commissioner has removed five of the nine members of the Lindenhurst (L. I.) Board of Education for "willfully disobeying" his orders.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 10 -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, osteopath on trial here for the murder of his wife, mentioned a few months before the crime that injuries to the head were easy to feign, according to testimony today by a close friend.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. achieved record sales and earning's in the first nine months this year, William S. Paley, chairman, reported yesterday. As a result, directors voted a special cash dividend of 30 cents and a 2 per cent stock dividend along with the regular quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 10 -- The bodies of two men who disappeared last night after embarking on a fishing trip were washed up on the beach of West Island, the Junius S. Morgan estate here, shortly before noon today.

Edward Dougherty, president of the Standardbred Owners Association, was suspended from New York harness tracks for one year, effective yesterday, by George P. Monaghan, State Harness Racing Commissioner, following a meeting at the commission offices here yesterday. Monaghan also suspended eight drivers for a period of six months.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 11 -- The lower house of the Jordanian Parliament gave a vote of confidence, 35 to 3, today, to the new Government headed by Tewfik Abdul Huda. The vote followed a sharp debate over revision of the British-Jordanian treaty.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov 11 (UP) -- Brazil's currency weakened on all fronts today. In the free exchange market, the cruzeiro was quoted at 73 to the dollar, a record low in value.
I am a devout believer in free enterprise and big business. However, I think there is something radically wrong.
DENVER, Nov. 11 -- The United States Air Force Academy, which is to admit its first class of 300 cadets here next July, will be neither a trade school nor a "football factory."

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Air Experts of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have recommended a French design for a new lightweight jet fighter for use throughout the fourteen-country alliance. The search has been going on for more than a year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Senate did not solve the McCarthy question today but it sure dealt with a lot of other questions. For example and to wit:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- High-level economic conversations between the United States and Yugoslavia will begin here tomorrow. They will deal with Yugoslavia's acute balance of payments difficulties and shortage of wheat, but their expansion into political and military spheres is believed possible.
Progress made in washability should prove a boon to the knitted fabric industry, according to two of the leading producers in the field.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Sewell Avery, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., refused today to comment on the charge of Louis E. Wolfson that he is gambling the future of the company on a depression. Mr. Avery also was silent on Mr. Wolfson's invitation to join him in a cross-country series of debates before stockholder groups.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The National Broadcasting Company today offered to give the movie industry a ninety-minute TV spectacular to plug 1955 movies -- thanks largely to Ed Sullivan of rival C. B. S.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony concert at Carnegie Hall last night was as comfortable as a visit with good, old friends. With the music of Brahms and Mendelssohn on the program, there were no surprises except the ever-recurring wonder of how rewarding these familiar scores can be.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 11 -- Austria has agreed, subject to certain conditions, to grant up to $20,000,000 credit for exports of machinery, equipment and investment goods to Turkey.
Dr. Einstein's repudiation of the role of science in the United States, though doubtless sincere, does an undeserved and unnecessary injury to the cause of America's intelligentsia.

FORT WORTH, TEX., Nov 11 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Army, Robert T. Stevens, said today an American soldier captured in fighting the Reds must be as ready to repel Communist assaults on his mind and soul as he was to stand up to attacks on his body on the battlefield.
The introduction of three new dual - purpose sewing machine cabinets marked the reopening yesterday of the Necchi-Elna Sewing Center, 379 Fifth Avenue.

Hamilton Fish Armstrong in a letter published on Nov. 8 refers to "an unfilled pledge made by the Republican party in 1952" and adds that the Republican platform contained the plank: "We pledge a more efficient and frequent mail delivery service."

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Engineers moved into action at Blues Stadium today to start getting the park ready for the Kansas City Athletics and major league baseball by next spring. They asked for work space in the front office.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- Charles E. Bohlen, United States Ambassador, left Moscow by air today for a short vacation in Sweden and Denmark.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Nov. 11 -- One bridge of a $5,000,000 twin-bridge project designed to eliminate Nassau County's worst summer traffic bottleneck is scheduled for completition by the first of the year.

Ralph (Tiger) Jones, the 26-year-old middleweight contender who has not fared well in recent appearances, meets Hector Constance, a newcomer from Trinidad, B. W. I., in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- British funds joined the downward movement of prices on the stock market here today. South African gold-mining shares were the only firm section.

Carbon monoxide will snuff out fifty or more lives in New York homes this winter unless householders are "extraordinarily careful" with gas appliances, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health, warned yesterday.

THE performance of "Die Meistersinger," the first performance of the 1954-55 subscription season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, must long stand out for its eloquence, its noble spirit and the achievements of the singers, several of them making their debuts, as one of the historic triumphs of this famous lyric theatre.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 11 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said here tonight that the nation's teachers had been "the victims of demagogues" and as a result many of them were afraid to deal with controversial issues.
BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- The juice from like cherry-like fruit of an obscure Puerto Rican tree is being added to apple juice bottled here as canning of the 1954 New England apple crop starts this week.

At the conclusion of the Japanese Premier's official visit in Washington a joint statement indicated a broad area of agreement in principle. There is an urgent need to build up the Japanese economy if the nation is to survive among the community of the free.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Turner Catledge, managing editor of The New York Times, told a Veterans Day luncheon today that the country's strength depended on "the strength of the American dream of freedom, tolerance and respect."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Col. Ben Limb, South Korean observer at the United Nations, said today that his Government could not accept one of the phrases in a report to the General Assembly on the Korean negotiations at the Geneva conference last summer.

The two-story buisiness building at 198-200 Main Street in Hackensack, N. J., has been sold by A. B. B. B. Block to George Sherman. The building is on a plot 50 by 100 feet and there is a parking lot 25 by 150 feet. There are three stores on the ground floor of the structure and offices on the second floor.
Since Betty and Jane Kean last cavorted on the Broadway stage, in "Along Fifth Avenue" (1949), their stature as a comic sister team has jumped by leaps and bounds in the night club and video sectors.

Carl Braun's twenty-five-foot set shot twelve seconds before the final buzzer gave the New York Knickerbockers a 79-78 decision over the Rochester Royals last night in the second half of Madison Square Garden's first National Basketball Association doubleheader of the season.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 11 -- The Citizens for Eisenhower organization acted like "a party within a party" in the recent election, in which the Democrats captured a United States Senate seat in Oregon and one of the state's four Congressional seats, a Portland Republic leader asserted today.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 -- At least thirty vessels are scheduled to load grain cargoes here for the Continent. Shipping officials say the grain export picture looks brighter than at any time since last year.
WASHINGTON Nov. 11 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy got a roaring, whistling ovation tonight from a mass meeting held to back him in his fight against Senate censure charges.

MILFORD, N. H., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Milford's admitted ex-Communist police chief won the support of the town fathers today after the chief and a former undercover agent gave "conflicting" testimony about the chief's former Communist activities.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- In the view of the French officials most directly concerned the terrorism in North Africa is no longer merely a local problem but one affecting the security of the entire free world.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Forty-one German rocket scientists became American citizens here today, and received congratulations from a British flier who once bombed them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The State Department is drafting a new note to the Soviet Union on the shooting down last Sunday of a United States Air Force RB-29 plane, hoping to find out whether the Soviet would seriously like to avoid such incidents in the future.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, Senate Republican leader, said today he had seen nothing to indicate the Soviet "leopard has changed his spots."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 11 -- Coach Lloyd Jordan said today he believed all of his injured Harvard players would be able to play against Brown at the Stadium Saturday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 11 -- The nation-wide program of consumer price decontrol began today in this city, an expensive one to live in. This coincided with an official report that $105,000,000 of United States economic aid would begin to arrive "in the near future."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The United States denied today it planned a search expedition for hydrogen or atomic bomb testing grounds in the Antarctic.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The United States Army in Europe quietly observed Veterans Day today, the thirty-sixth anniversary of the end of World War I.
The dismissal of John Paton Davies Jr. from the Foreign Service after a diplomatic career of twenty-three years has raised more questions than it has answered.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Gen. Charles L. Bolte declared today here that the Army's new unit rotation plan would require that at least as many of its proposed twenty-four combat divisions be kept home as were sent overseas.

In your edition of Nov. 9 you printed a letter from Warren Moscow, assistant to the Mayor, purporting to correct an alleged misconception on my part with regard to the composition of the Mayor's Committee for Better Housing.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Chancellor Adenauer predicted confidently today he could get ratification of the Paris agreements despite troubles within his coalition over the Saar.
Two more employes have been reinstated after hearings in the drawn-out security risk investigations at the Army Signal Corps Center in Fort Monmouth, N. J., and another has been suspended.
President William V. S. Tubman of Liberia cut short his tour of the Southern states and returned quietly to New York City early this week to get down to business.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 11 (UP) -- The eligibility of Halfback Tommy Bell of the Army football team is being "studied" by the Eastern College Athletic Conference, Lieut. Col. James Schwenk, Army's graduate manager of athletics, said tonight.

BROWNS MILLS, N. J., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The state police chased an auto for fourteen miles early today at speeds up to ninety miles an hour until the car slammed broadside into a tree, killing a woman and injuring two soldiers from Fort Dix.
The text of the address by Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General of the United States, at the naturalization ceremonies at Ebbets Field and the Polo Grounds yesterday follows:

Prospects for early ratification of the Paris agreement for a Western European Union brightened considerably yesterday when a national congress of the French Socialist party and a parliamentary caucus of the British Labor party both decided to support this promising substitute for the ill-fated European Defense Community.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 11 -- Sir William Slim, Governor General, opened the South Australian Government's uranium mine and treatment plant yesterday at Radium Hill, north of Adelaide. Sir Lyell McEwan, South Australian Minister for Mines, said there were possibilities of another uranium mine being established at Crockers Well, fifty miles away.
BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 11 -- The Southern Governors Conference gave a cold reception today to a proposal on racial segregation in the public schools.
Bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange had an average price of $100.39 on Oct. 31, against $100.53 on Sept. 30. The figure was the smallest for a month-end since May 31, when it was $100.

i' Everts to,lay: Philharmonic. Symphony, Dimitri Mitropbulos iconducting, Zino -Franeescatti violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.-IV[.:; ."The-Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Robert Schrade, pianist), carnegie Hall, 8:30; Angela Pistilli, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30 and Mercedes Walker, pianist, Carl Fischer Hall, 8:30.

Today's new film is "Bengal Brigade," an adventure film from Universal-International, at the Palace. The cast is headed by Rock Hudson, Arlene Dahl, Ursula Thiess and Torin Thatcher. Richard Alan Simmons wrote the screen play from a novel by Hall Hunter. Laslo Benedek directed, and Ted Richmond produced.
ABILENE, Kan., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's speech today at the dedication of the Eisenhower Memorial, Museum:

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Every one in town is pleased that the man entrusted to handle the Greenwich experiment in town management is John M. Gleason, a policeman here for twenty-five years and chief of police since 1941.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Assembling from widely scattered areas of Britain, 5,000 old-age pensioners unanimously approved today a resolution demanding that the Government increase their weekly pension from the equivalent of $4.55 to $7.

The nation's pulp industry seems bound for new highs this year -- as in six out of the last eight years -- in both production and consumption. A third-quarter check by Lawson Turcott, president of the Puget Sound Pulp and Timber Company, indicates heavier exports and a domestic consumption riding on an even keel, perhaps a little above last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee approved today in what amounted to a party line vote, President Eisenhower's nomination of George C. McConnaughey to be a member and chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- French Socialists authorized their party today to vote for ratification of the Paris accords on West German sovereignty and armament. They did not fully agree to enter the Cabinet but suggested conditions for participation that promised trouble.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 11 -- Alexander F. Jones, executive editor of The Syracuse Herald-Journal, said today the Bar Association of the City of New York was the chief force behind a move to amend New York State laws to prevent any officer of the law from giving pre-trail information in criminal cases to the press.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles would be willing, in support of bipartisanship, to name as a State Department consultant a qualified Democrat.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- National Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to allow the airlines to confer on the possibility of charging passengers for reserved seats.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 11 -- The "uncharted hesitancies of present-day society" have affected Jewish families particularly, according to Max J. Etra, president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America.

Lower, longer and wider 1955 Plymouth cars were announced yesterday by the Plymouth division, Chrysler Corporation. The cars will go on display in dealer showrooms throughout the New York metropolitan area next Wednesday.

Stockholders of the Tennessee Corporation, producer of fertilizers and metals, approved a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. This action increases the outstanding shares to 1,770,128 from 885,064.
ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- An additional thirty miles on the southern section of the Thruway will be opened to traffic about Dec. 15, the State Thruway Authority announced today.
The most heartwarming news story of many a long generation came out of the West the other day. It concerned Lawrence Wahlstrom, a landscape architect -- naturally of Hollywood -- and a machine.

The New York State Federation of Women's Clubs adopted resolutions yesterday opposing the closed shop, calling for a crusade against crime comics and urging an end of Government competition with private enterprise, except for defense purposes.

A biography of David Ben-Gurion, Israel's first Prime Minister, will be published Nov. 20 by Praeger. The author is Barnet Litvinoff. Ben-Gurion in his early days lived in a ghetto in Poland. His later experiences ranged from farm worker to head of a nation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The National Conference of Christians and Jews closed its annual meeting here today with an announcement of an "aggressive" campaign for 100,000 new members in 1955. The organization now has 200,000 members.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 11 -- Princeton's sagging football fortunes received a big lift today with the announcement that the Tigers' tailback, Royce Flippin, will be ready for "spot duty" if needed against Yale Saturday.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- Archaeological discoveries of unusual importance have been made in a villa that the Roman Emperor Hadrian built at the foot of the hills on which rises the town of Tivoli (the ancient Tibur) seventeen miles east northeast of Rome.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Twenty-six billion dollars more than planned must be spent in the next ten years to step up the nation's highway development program, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman of President Eisenhower's Advisory Committee on the Highway Program, said today.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., which only a few months ago was battling the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., for control of air-line mechanics, pledged "all-out cooperation" to its erstwhile rival yesterday in a threatened strike against six big air lines.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 11 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's eighth general conference, which opens tomorrow, promises to have a marked political flavor.
With the game against Columbia forty-eight hours away, Eddie Erdelatz, coach of Navy's formidable football squad, was "at sea" yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The Security Council agreed today that a United Nations inquiry into Egypt's seizure of an Israeli freighter at the entrance to the Suez Canal should get priority consideration over other Egyptian-Israeli disputes.

The Rev. Dr. George F. Mac-Leod, founder of the Iona Community in the Scottish Hebrides, declared last night that "the time is past when men can speak of war as an instrument of policy." The island community is based on the principle of self-help.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 11 -- Negotiators representing the seven states in the Columbia River Basin, the country's greatest hydro-electric power region, approved an interstate compact today for the coordination of the basin's power, water and allied resources.

New York residents have donated $15,614,194 of the $165,000,000 worth of American aid contained in the 15,000,000 CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Everywhere, Inc.) packages that have been delivered to date in sixty foreign countries. Chicago is second with $3,264,113.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Scott McLeod, State Department Security and Consular Affairs Director, will be United States representative at the meeting of the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration opening in Geneva on Nov. 20.

GLENWOOD LANDING, L. I., Nov. 11 -- The Glen Players decided today to try to stage "Death of a Salesman" even though the leading man, a former American Legion official, had quit in protest against the author.

St. John's University in Brooklyn announced yesterday it had chosen Harry J. Kirk, civil engineer of Washington, as the "outstanding Catholic layman" of the year in this country. Mr. Kirk will receive the university's St. Vincent de Paul Medal in recognition of his efforts for the needy.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Standardbred Owners Association tonight voted unanimously to back its president, Edward T. Dougherty, in his disagreement with the New York Harness Racing Commission.

LINDENHURST, L. I., Nov. 11 -- The possibility that teachers here might not be paid on schedule was averted today. The action came an hour before Edward J. McGraw, president of the Board of Education, was served with notice of his ouster by Lewis A. Wilson, State Commissioner of Education.

Trading in cottonseed and soybean oils was featureless yesterday in a quiet holiday market. The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, the New York Cocoa Exchange, the Commodity Exchange, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange were closed in observance of Veterans Day (formerly Armistice Day).

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 11 -- Rutgers University, anticipating a 1964 enrollment at least double its present 18,000, today asked the State for a $7,163,488 appropriation increase to meet expanding operations and capital construction.

LAST month more than 1,400 books were published. Many of these, of course, were school and college texts, medical books, law books and children's books which did not reach the "Books of The Times" office. But the rest, the "trade books" which did, were so numerous that many that were eminently reviewable and an uncounted number of superior books were lost in the shuffle.
A 28-year-old traffic policeman was dismissed yesterday after a departmental trial for trying to get a "gratuity" instead of writing out a summons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 695,097 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 41,136 cars or 5.6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 52,771 cars or 7.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 134,198 cars or 16.2 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- The state's weight-distance tax on trucks is rapidly becoming an unwanted problem child, only a little more than three years after the Legislature produced it with a flourish of publicity.
Directors of the Reynolds Metals Company yesterday declared a special year-end dividend of 50 cents, a 5 per cent stock dividend and the regular quarterly of 25 cents.
A Long Island Rail Road train arrived at Pennsylvania Station forty-two minutes late yesterday after stalling a bare two minutes from its destination.

Officials of the International Boxing Guild will receive an opportunity to defend themselves against charges of black-listing, discrimination and monopolistic practices today when they appear at a hearing held by the New York State Athletic Commission.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries, world's largest producer of nickel, achieved record sales in the first nine months this year and increased earnings to $47,430,561 from $41,252,680 in the similar period of 1953.
Frank Lloyd Wright, the lively dean of radical architecture and caustic critic of American culture, is quitting Wisconsin because, he says, he is not appreciated in his home state.

Former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer received the 1954 Hall of Fame Award of the Alumni Association of the Educational Alliance last night. At a dinner the group praised his activities in the community center, including his work as a volunteer leader of a boys' club.

Stuyvesant High's undefeated football team scored its fifth straight victory, defeating Monroe, 32 -- 6, and Clinton turned back its Bronx rival, Evander, 14 -- 6, in a Public Schools Athletic League doubleheader before 2,000 at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

The always fanciful and occasionally fancy creations of Italian designers of today were discussed and displayed at a luncheon meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. Architectural designs, home furnishings and fashions were part of the program arranged under joint sponsorship of the National Home Fashions League and the Fashion Group.
I refer to the letter addressed to you by Robert J. Alexander, published on Nov. 8.
Fair trade was described yesterday as a bulwark against monopoly in distribution.

Not only did Regino De La Maza present a program of music originally composed for the guitar last night in Town Hall, but also he included many pieces announced as first New York performances. These were a fantasy by Luis de Narvaez, three pieces by Francois Campion, a passacaglia by Ludovico Roncalli, Bach's Third Suite for Lute, and shorter pieces by Pittaluga and the guitarist himself.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The wheat market showed strength again today, with all months except December making new highs for the season. The December contract was strong, too, both here and at Minneapolis, on the small primary arrivals and a better export demand.

Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn took the individual and team laurels in the freshman, junior varsity and varsity divisions to sweep honors yesterday in the thirty-second Athletic Association of Private Schools cross-country championships at Van Courtlandt Park, the Bronx.

THE results of the first week's hunting on the wilderness tracts in the Adirondack Forest, where 3,670 hunters scoured the woods with high hopes and special antlerless deer tags, were not especially successful. Only 804 deer were checked out.
MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (UP) -- The league-leading Montreal Canadiens, scoring almost at will, gained a costly 7-4 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 14,033 Forum fans tonight.

When George Kennan was sworn in as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union two and a half years ago, reliable reports attributed to him the hope that he might be able to introduce some of the virtues of old-fashioned diplomacy into Soviet-American relations.
The weather man relented yesterday and New York store executives described business as "highly satisfactory."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, told a Veterans Day assembly at Arlington National Cemetery today of the awesome power of nuclear weapons that now could destroy a whole civilization in a single night.

The Outdoor Advertising Association of America announced yesterday the election of Harley B. Markham as its president. Mr. Markham, who had been vice president since, December, 1952, is an executive. of Big Four Advertising, Inc., Pocatello, Idaho.

An educational campaign on "the role of the advertising agency in an economy that positively demands efficient advertising if consumption, and thus our full American capacity, is to be maintained," is to be started next week by Foote, Cone Belding.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Dean Loucks, the sophomore quarterback from White Plains, N. Y., is expected to get his first starting assignment for Yale Saturday when the Elis square off against Princeton in the Yale Bowl.

A stabbing marked a labor dispute in Brooklyn yesterday when two members of rival unions grappled with each other on a picket line in front of the Century Interior, Inc., decorating plant at 1535 Sixty-third Street.
Plaid and paisley printed calf, flat fur and bold colored lizard were some materials used in the lively group of resort shoes introduced yesterday by I. Miller 689 Fifth Avenue.
YONKERS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Queen's Joy, owned by Mrs. Catherine Peters of Schuylkill Haven, Pa., won the Thornwood Trot by a head from Irene Gallon at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- On what used to be called Armistice Day, which was celebrated generally except on the domestic political from the contract of the Atomic Energy Commission with the Dixon-Yates private power group was amended in deference to the voting decisions on Nov. 2.

The big shots who kept tens and fivers clipped to the underside of their driver's permit have apparently been organized into a going business. They have been sold "courtesy cards" by policemen or civilian contacts, to be flashed when stopped for traffic violations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The politically explosive Dixon-Yates private power contract was signed today by the Atomic Energy Commission. It contained significant changes, including a limit on profits and the granting to the Government of the right to take over the private steam plant to be constructed.
Richard Rodgers, composer of more than 1,000 melodies, presented a seventeen-volume collection of his original manuscripts to the Library of Congress yesterday.

An increase of 6 cents a pound on loin of pork for roasting or chops was reported yesterday by the City Department of Markets. This is the first time pork prices have advanced since the middle of September.
NO New York tower clock could seize a clock winder in its gears and do him to death as the old Royal Courts of Justice clock did with poor Tommy Manners in Fleet Street, London, a few days ago.
ROME, Nov. 11 -- Freedom of religion won a decisive victory in Italy today.
WASHINGTON Nov. 11 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's defense against censure charges was interrupted briefly today when 15-month-old Deirdre Walsh set up a howl in the Senate gallery.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UP) -- A joint Congressional economic subcommittee asked Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey and Federal Reserve Board Chairman William M. Martin Jr. today for their "judgments" on eight questions of Government finance and economic policy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Eisenhower Administration gave its blessing today to a proposed $100,000,000 international corporation that would help finance private industrial enterprises in underdeveloped countries.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Physicians voted voluntarily at Michael Reese Hospital to disclose their financial records in a drive against fee-splitting with surgeons, it was announced today.
A Municipal Court jury has awarded $1,333.50 in damages to two girls who charged that their landlord had evicted them after they complained they had been overcharged in rent.
The first Israeli ship to be built by West Germany under the restitution agreement will be delivered to her owners today, providing she passes her sea trials.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 11 -- Pressure on West Germany to create its armed forces within three years of ratification of the Paris agreements is regarded with serious misgivings by responsible officials here.

TRENTON, Nov. 11 -- Democratic leaders formally announced tonight their intention of seeking a state-wide recount of the ballots cast in last Tuesday's Senatorial contest. Tomorrow they will file the required applications in Superior Court.

Final plans for the Annual Gotham Ball, at which forty-one young women will make their debuts, are being completed by the ball committee headed by Mrs. William F. Berghold. The fete, which will aid the New York Foundling Hospital, will be held in the grand ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 25, Thanksgiving night.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has upheld a lower court's refusal to approve a plan for reorganization of the Florida East Coast Railway Company by merging it with the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company.

The Marshall Management Corporation, Louis Sachar, president, and Joseph Rosen have sold the twelve-story loft building at 138-144 West Twenty-fifth Street to an investing client of Hyman Wiener, attorney. Williams Co. were the brokers and Leo Kotler was attorney for the sellers.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Sir Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today he had asked for some children's horror comics to read to weigh the need for banning them, but had been too busy so far to read them.

BECAUSE football is an emotional game, coaches have never hesitated in the past to use strange devices in order to inspire their impressionable heroes to superhuman effort for the Big Game. One favorite, now worn out from use, was that the coach was about to shuffle off this mortal coil and that victory was his dying wish.

At 9:25 or thereabouts four mornings a week, a rather unusual procession begins its straggling course down Bank Street, in Greenwich Village. Snowsuited toddlers, their mothers in tow, trot briskly along the sidewalk, speeding their pace as they approach No. 69.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 11 -- Veterans Day was marked today by Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain by two minutes of prayer in George Washington's pew in Bruton Parish Church.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The United States and its associates in the Manila defense treaty will meet shortly to prepare action against a serious threat of internal subversion in Asia. They expect to gather for this purpose long before the treaty has gone into effect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Chairman William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, announced today the Senate Antimonopoly Subcommittee would investigate the pending sale of the Follansbee Steel Company in West Virginia.

MIAMI, Nov. 11 -- The house of delegates of the American Dental Association voted 235 to 152 today against a proposal to ask Congress to include dentists in the old age and survivors program of the Social Security Act. By 180 to 153 it voted against inclusion of dentists on a voluntary basis.

The establishment of a permanent peace between Israel and the Arab states can result in a highly "creative system of life and living" among all peoples in the Middle East, Deputy City Administrator Gordon R. Clapp asserted last night.

ATHENS, Nov. 11 -- Spyros Markezinis, who resigned last April from the post of Minister of Coordination after a dispute with Premier Alexander Papagos, announced today that from now on he would be an independent in the Chamber.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, who has had financial interest in motion pictures for a number of years, is entering the field of independent production with his own company, C. V. Whitney Pictures, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the second day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy:
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 11 -- Twenty-five hundred union workers invaded the closed yard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation this morning and were still inside the plant late today.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 -- President Juan D. Peron has threatened "energetic action" to resolve difficulties with certain elements of the Roman Catholic Church if such troubles are not ended within a week.

Two conflicting versions of a recent decision by the Greek high courts further confused yesterday the competition between two steamship lines for Greek registry and the New York-Greece passenger trade.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Nov. 11 -- Charles Christie, a Republic Aviation Corporation engineer, who was dismissed five months ago as a "security risk," will go back to work Monday -- apparently as a result of the untangling of the words "neurodermatitis" and "psychoneurosis."

Horace Heidt and his orchestra will be starred in a new television series to be presented over the N. B. C. network on Saturdays from 7:30 to 8 P. M. The program, which will replace the "Ethel and Albert" series, will begin sometime in January under the sponsorship of Swift Co.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Members of the International Typographical Union have refused to add an industrial pension for the union's officers and employes but accepted four other proposals.

Pin Oak Farm, which hadn't won a stakes race all year, took the money in a big one at Jamaica yesterday. Pin Oak's 2-year-old colt Roman Patrol won the $55,375 Remsen, and to the four owners of the stable went $37,250.

Plans are being made at meetings at the Sherry-Netherland for the performance of the new musical show, "House of Flowers" on the night of Jan. 6 at the Alvin Theatre for the benefit of the West Side Day Nursery.

The Chamber Opera Players presented Alessandro Scarlatti's comic opera, "The Triumph of Honor;" in an English translation, with recitatives replaced by spoken dialogue, at the Alma Gluck Theatre last evening.

President Juan D. Peron has long established himself as an eccentric and incalculable dictator. Now he and his henchmen who control the General Confederation of Labor (the C. G. T.) have tangled with the Roman Catholic hierarchy in their country.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The $20 hog reappeared on the livestock market today when that price was paid for the first time since Sept. 28.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Arnold Johnson of Chicago, who heads the syndicate which purchased the Philadelphia Athletics to move the team to Kansas City, said tonight he expected to name his field manager and a general manager within a few days.
A 20 per cent increase in pension payments to retired bricklayers was authorized yesterday by trustees of the industry's union-management pension fund.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Senator Francis Case of North Dakota emerged today as the spearhead of a move by some Republicans to permit Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to escape censure on two of three counts by apologizing for his conduct.

CAIRO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A Moslem Brotherhood witness testified today that President Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib had agreed with the Brotherhood to make a broadcast to "calm the population" if the October plot to assassinate Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser had succeeded.

Jose Limon and his dance company will be the first attraction to tour abroad under the sponsorship of the International Exchange Program administered by the American National Theatre and Academy for the United States Department of State.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Sir Norman Brookes, president of the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia, told a crowd of 7,000 at a professional tournament tonight that his organization would welcome open championships between amateurs and professionals.
Net income and sales of the Stauffer Chemical Company increased in the quarter and nine months ended Sept2 30, the company reported yesterday.
New evidences of underworld penetration into union-management relations in the New York trucking industry came to light yesterday.

For the fourth successive day stocks set new highs for the year yesterday. Rails, steels and building materials took over the leadership of a market in which gains of more than 2 points were commonplace and losses were sparce and slender.

The question that seems to plague the Yankees each winter, namely, whether Allie Reynolds will pitch one season more for them, apparently is back where it has been in recent years. It all depends upon the ace right-hander's outside interests.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz of Chile warned today that grave economic troubles in Latin America could lead to revolution in many countries. He appealed for more financial help and technical aid to this region.

The Tennessee Valley Authority expects to have a total generating capacity of nearly 10,000,000 kilowatts by the end of 1956. The proposed Dixon-Yates contract for a steam plant at West Memphis, Ark., would supply about 600,000 kilowatts -- not an inconsiderable amount but small in proportion to the total capacity.
Ebbets Field and the Polo Grounds served yesterday as vast open courtrooms in which 16,000 men and women became citizens of the United States.

Marking Veterans Day, twenty-five members of the American Veterans Committee gave blood to the regional Red Cross blood program at Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue yesterday morning. Officials of the committee said they expected at least 300 committee members to give blood before the end of the week.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 (UP) -- The Charfran Stable's Argentinebred Cascanuez, with Bobby Ussery up, gained a four-and-a-half-length triumph today in the $10,090 Exterminator Handicap at Pimlico.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The British Parliament's approval of the Paris agreements on West German armament and sovereignty was assured today.

THE color television presentation of "Panama Hattie," with Ethel Merman playing the part she originated in the Broadway musical, was a spiritless affair on Wednesday evening over C. B. S. The fault was not that of Miss Merman, who brought what zest she could to the occasion.

Spokesmen for labor and management paid tribute yesterday to Philip Murray, the late president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, at ceremonies dedicating the Philip Murray Hearing Room at the New York headquarters of the American Arbitration Association, 9 Rockefeller Plaza.

MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 12 -- A nation-wide review of recent articles in the Soviet press discloses many examples of the overzealous and offensive antireligious propaganda that was condemned yesterday by the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 11 (UP) -- The three Swedish tennis players who will meet the United States in the interzone Davis Cup final on Dec. 16-18 at Brisbane won their first-round matches as the New South Wales championships began today at White City Stadium.

The Bronx real estate firm of Langsam Schiffman has been dissolved and the principals have formed new companies. Ralph Langsam, with Murray Siegel, has opened an office at 2025 Davidson Avenue, and Benjamin Schiffman, with Leonard Goldkopf, has an office at 210 East 181st Street.
A plan has been developed to merge the Ketay Corporation and the Norden Laboratories Corporation, Producers of electronic instruments.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway managed last month to better earnings of the road in October, 1953, by one cent a share. It was the first time this year in which net surpassed that of the current month of 1953.

ABILENE, Kan., Nov. 11 -- Before a crowd of fellow townsmen jamming the grounds about his old homestead, President Eisenhower today dedicated the Eisenhower Memorial Museum as an institution devoted to good citizenship in the United States.

Our voluntary hospitals have helped to give us easier, safer childbirth, healthier childhood and a much longer span of life. This has been an expensive bill for the nonprofit voluntary hospitals as they have de veloped, and this is a continuing and unending bill, which confronts these institutions annually.
HONOLULU, Nov. 11 -- Hawaiian Airlines, Ltd., which never has had a passenger or crew fatality or injury, celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary today.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Goalie Harry Lumley celebrated his twenty-eighth birthday tonight with his first shutout of the season as the Toronto Maple Leafs beat the Detroit Red Wings, 1 -- 0, before 10,933 fans at Olympia.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 11 -- Dr. Lincoln B. Hale, director of the United States aid program in Israel, said tonight the nation's progress in six and one-half years was "a modern miracle."
A busy United States paused for a moment yesterday to pay homage to all who have fought for its liberty, and to reflect on a civilization that has produced the tools of possible self-destruction.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Jean Monnet, principal author of recent projects to unite Western Europe on a supranational or federal basis, will leave his official post to rally French public opinion to the support of this type of European union.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 11 -- With most of its difficulties ironed out, the Federal Housing Administration is set to speed up its program.
The 1955 Lincoln line, with 225-horsepower V-8 engines and new-type automatic transmissions, was announced yesterday by Lincoln-Mercury division, Ford Motor Company.

The Railroad Retirement Board deserves commendation for withdrawing the request it had made to the Federal Civil Service Commission to remove from civil service status ten top career men, none of whom had had less than fifteen years of service with the board.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 -- Milton Caniff, creator of the comic strip, "Steve Canyon," said here tonight that the comic strip might be "the Achilles heel of American newspaper freedom."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- The Commerce Department announced today that it had again denied export privileges to two New York concerns and two of their officials.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- France cut its trade deficit almost in half during the first ten months of 1954.
Yale, Ohio State, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Southern California are poised today for victories that would assure at least their staring in conference titles or playing in one of football's bowl games.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) -- While equaling Pimlico's mile and an eighth track record, Thorncliff Farm's Rock Cottage carried Bill Hartack to his fourth winner on today's card at the Maryland Jockey Club track.
Without ceremony, the career of Ellis Island as an immigration station came to a virtual close yesterday.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 3 to 15 points higher than on Wednesday. Business was moderate.

A score of traditional Eastern prep school football contests add spice today to an attractive scholastic schedule. Heading the list of old rivalries are the seventy-fifth meeting between Andover and Exeter at Andover, Mass., and the forty-ninth encounter between Lawrenceville and The Hill School, at Pottstown, Pa.

Many employes of the New York Stock Exchange are watching the Big Board volume as closely as the most commission-minded exchange member. To them, volume spells bonus. The exchange, under its present formula, has been paying a quarterly bonus based on volume in relation to a working force of 1,100 to 1,149 employes.
William Shakespeare was declared here yesterday to be a poor judge of the relation between physiognomy and character.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Schirick reserved decision today on a suit by New York City to throw out the $65,000,000 reorganization plan of the Long Island Rail Road.
SODOM, Israel, Oct. 29 -- Sodom has had its first show since the spectacle of 4,000 years ago that froze Lot's wife into a pillar of salt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay said today that Kerr-McGee Oil Industries, Inc., of Oklahoma City could withdraw erroneous bids totaling about $15,000,000 for oil and gas leases on the Continental Shelf off Louisiana.

Many of us are alive today only because of the high quality of the nonprofit voluntary hospitals of this city. It has been only recently, within our own memories, that the miraculous drugs and medical skills of our modern hospitals have become a reality.

Inexpensive, unusual gifts and toys for older youngsters to give as well as receive may be made at home with such low-cost materials as terry cloth towels, plywood or a few yards of cotton cloth. And even adults might be interested in making these "do-it-yourself" gifts.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 533 pints of blood on Thursday. Included were 230 pints taken at the J. Walter Thompson Company, 420 Lexington Avenue, and 140 donated at the Shell Oil Company, 50 West Fiftieth Street, by employes of that concern and other oil companies.
The Fordham Rams will meet the Crusaders of Holy Cross today for the twenty-fifth time since the football series opened in 1902. The game will be played at the Polo Grounds, starting at 1:30.
The small, red brick Staten Island Museum, a community gathering point for decades for thousands of residents with a wide variety of interests, is reopening its doors tomorrow.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Tony Trabert and Ham Richardson started preparing for America's bid to regain the Davis Cup by winning second-round matches in straight sets today at the New South Wales tennis championships in White City Stadium.

Any remaining complacency about a supposed United States technological superiority over the Soviet Union should have been rudely shattered by the facts given in this newspaper's recent review of the technological race between the free world and the Soviet bloc.
Three industrialists -- from the eastern, middle and western parts of the country -- have been reelected co-chairmen of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 12 -- A German expedition of fourteen men accompanied by two Pakistanis has abandoned its attempt to climb Hidden Peak, a 26,740- foot unconquered mountain in the Karakorum Range of Pakistan.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Navy today announced successful air defense tests with its new supersonic guided missile "Terrier."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the third day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

THOSE who enjoy fast action with striped bass but hate to pass up the opportunities for duck hunting now face a difficult decision. The bass are practically jumping into the boats out at Montauk, and some of them are king size fish.

TORONTO, Nov. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Three top Mexican military riders, led by the 1952 Olympic champion, Gen. Humberto Mariles, tonight won the international low-score competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 (UP) -- This city's downtown "attack area" was cleared within 10 minutes today after sirens shrilled out the nation's first "go home" civil defense test.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The price decline gathered momentum on the stock market here today for most issues except British funds and South African gold-mining shares.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 4.1 per cent above that of the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 3.5 per cent and orders 1.8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Indications are reaching Washington that the "new course" in economic, policy adopted by the Soviet Union's European satellites will become a permanent feature of their economic lives.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Wendell P. Brown, Solicitor General who joined the State Law Department in 1925 as an Assistant Attorney General, will retire at the end of this year to enter private law practice here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Brazil has modified its foreign exchange regulations affecting coffee exports, apparently with a view to stabilizing coffee prices abroad. [News of the action caused a rise in prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.]

The Rutgers University Forum will present a round-table discussion on the subject "Retarded Children Can Be Helped" over a group of New Jersey radio stations, starting next week. The first broadcast will be offered on Tuesday at 8:05 P. M. over stations WAAT and WAAT-FM.

Former President Truman's so-called Point Four, announced five years ago, has had excellent results even though it has not improved the lot of man on a really massive scale. It has given hope of what might be done to produce more food and more happiness for hundreds of millions of people.
Your editorial of Nov. 9 entitled "An Election in India" begins with the following sentence: "Prime Minister Nehru's Congress party has sustained another defeat in a provincial election in India."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan told members of the Senate today that he hoped the United States and Japan would continue to work together "on the course of peace and security for the free world."

HOMER, Philip Wylie, Hakluyt, T. S. Eliot and several other eminent fishermen and lit'ry tars have affably conspired with A. C. Spectorsky to build a fine volume, beautifully illustrated, called "The Book of the Sea."* This is one of the handsomest books of the year and an ideal present for all seafarers, all who love the ocean's cantankerousness, mystery and splendor.
The backlog of corporate financing through issues of bonds and preferred stock has risen in the past week from $320,396,000 to $542,638,500, according to the Investment Dealers Digest.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- After edging up to new highs on the movement, wheat reacted as much as 1 cent today on week-end profit taking. The trade was not large and buyers were cautious.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Saturday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- New Zealanders voted in a general election today for a new national Parliament. In the present single-house Parliament the National party holds fifty seats and the Laborites thirty. About 1,200,000 persons are eligible to vote. The issue, stated at its simplest, is socialism versus private enterprise.
President William V. S. Tubman of Liberia sailed for Haiti yesterday with words of admiration for the United States and an optimistic report of Negro life in the South.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- The fifteen-day shutdown of dry cargo handling in the Port of Philadelphia has been ended under a compromise agreement worked out this afternoon by union-management negotiators.
Nine city motorcycle policemen appeared yesterday before a Brooklyn grand jury as it began considering evidence of a bribery racket in traffic law violations.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Back in its own class after a rough week-end, Yale's solid line was favored to stop Princeton in a Big Three traditional football game tomorrow and lead the Elis to their first Ivy League championship since 1946.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Senator William Langer, Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, announced plans today for hearings Nov. 19 on the nomination of Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- The Supreme Court upheld today the dismissal of Dr. Dick Helander, Bishop of the Protestant State Church, from his office.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A New Yorker has come to the aid of the window trimmer who must wrestle with department store dummies.

Robert Schrade gave his fourth New York piano recital, his first in Carnegie Hall, last night. On his program were short and attractive pieces by Clementi, Dussek and Hummel, a Handel suite, Brahms' Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Handel, Ernest Bloch's Sonata and pieces by Faure, Ravel and Chopin.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Coach Lou Little and his Columbia squad arrived today to play a Navy football team that promises to do nothing toward satisfying the Lions' hunger for victory.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Some associates of Robert Marjolin, retiring secretary general of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, took exception to a dispatch published today in The New York Times. The dispatch mentioned M. Marjolin's resignation in connection with that of Jean Monnet, chairman of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community.

Additional land in Burlington, N. J., has been purchased by J. Chein Co. for the expansion of their plant. It was bought from the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey through the Leo Flaster Agency, broker. The Chein concern, manufacturer of toys and metal specialties, occupies a one-story building of more than 92,000 square feet on a tract of eight acres.

NASHUA, N. H., Nov. 12 -- A woman was killed and twenty persons were injured, three of them critically, at dawn today when the Red Wing of the Boston and Maine Railroad, from Montreal to Boston, left the rails and eight cars overturned. About twenty-five other passengers and railroad employes were bruised and cut but did not require hospitalization.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 -- The first policeman on the scene of the slaying of Mrs. Marilyn Sheppard last July 4 testified today that he had found all window screens in her room secure and no sign of a struggle. He denied finding even a footprint on the beach below, where the accused husband asserts he fought with the killer.
Applicants for school crossing guard posts in Brooklyn may obtain blanks at resident precincts for filing not later than midnight, Dec. 8, it was announced yesterday at Police Headquarters.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- The State Board of Equalization and Assessment had some good news today for school districts in the state that have been looking for greater borrowing power.

FOR those opera first nighters who did'nt know how "The Barber of Seville" started and how it all came out, there was a chance last night to become oriented. Having performed only the second act at Monday's opening, the Metropolitan presented all of Rossini's opera last night, and it made a full, pleasant evening on its very own.

THE new Barone Gallery, 202 East Fifty - first Street, starts with a double program -- to give a series of one-man shows and to devote part of the gallery to group exhibitions in which it is hoped to bring forward artists with talent who are perhaps not yet ready for one-man shows.
A general increase of $40 to $168 in the New York City delivered prices of the 1955 Ford car line was announced yesterday by local dealers.
In an elaborate gold and red decor, the fifth annual Fan Ball was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

David J. Schneider, who has achieved some notable success at the race tracks, was the victim yesterday of a hold-up in Queens. The loss, which was reported to detectives of the Elmhurst station, included furs valued at $5,000 and jewelry worth $2,000.
Harold N. Leitman announced yesterday that he and his associates had bought a majority interest in Adam Hat Stores, Inc., from Elias Lustig, the founder, who is president and board chairman.
The sale of the Dr. H. H. Phillips citrus groves in central Florida to the Granada Groves Corporation and their leasing to the Minute Maid Corporation were announced yesterday.

What had been more or less expected became a fact yesterday when the New York City Center Theatre Company announced the engagement of John Stix as director of Joshua Logan's "The Wisteria Trees," starring Helen Hayes.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday opened an inquiry into charges of discrimination and monopoly against the fight managers' organization known as the New York Boxing Guild and its parent International Boxing Guild.

FORT SILL, Okla., Nov. 12 (UP) -- The Army accused Maj. Ambrose H. Nugent today of betraying his country and his men in a Korean prisoner-of-war camp and of becoming a willing tool of his Communist captors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- During the week ended Nov. 10, member bank reserves increased $412,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Representative George H. Bender, Republican Senator-elect from Ohio, said today that the Navy's Admirals "apparently" were trying to take control of the Marine Corps.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The eight Roman Catholic pastors of this area issued a statement today declaring that Emil Mazey, secretary-treasurer of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., "deserves to be called decisively to task for insolence" in criticizing Circuit Judge F. H. Schlichting.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 145-149 East Forty-ninth Street has been sold by Frank Samuels and William Walter to Waldorf Building, Inc., an investment group represented by Tart Brothers Wald, attorneys.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 12 -- The Mineola Board of Education today ordered that "slanted and controversial" school library books be set apart on a reserve shelf. Pupils will be permitted to read them only under supervision of a teacher.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Nov. 12 -- Edward B. Lawson, new United States Ambassador, gave President Izhak Ben-Zvi today a message from President Eisenhower expressing hope that the ties of friendship between the two countries would be strengthened.

Limes, an outstanding offering in the fruit stalls, according to the Department of Agriculture, should be heavy for their size, with smooth, glossy, thin skins and fine-grained, juicy pulp. Those with green skins have a more acid flavor than the yellow, but both have the same amount of juice. Limes will keep for weeks if stored covered in the refrigerator.

The old Huntington Methodist Church at 309-311 Main Street in Huntington, L. I., is to be replaced by a store and office building. The property has been sold by the church to Malcolm L. Bennet of New York in a transaction negotiated by William A. White Sons as brokers.

Social security has its roots deep in Swedish tradition. So has low-cost medical care. This year 70 per cent of Sweden's population has assured itself of medical care on the basis of payments voluntarily made to independent "sickness societies" or "funds" heavily subsidized by the state.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Carol, Dolly, Edna and Hazel sent to Lloyd's today the bill for their tragic sprees and it came to $112,000,000.
The unseasonal decline in business loans by banks in the York area was intensified this week.

CAIRO, Nov. 12 -- The Arab League member states are reported to be planning to give greater official status to Jerusalem to counteract Israel's establishment of her capital in the western suburbs, which remained in Israeli hands after the Palestine war six years ago.

OSHKOSH, Wis., Nov. 12 (UP) -- An Oshkosh dressmaker who thought her relatives neglected her has left her estate to a man she knew for only four hours. A settlement reached yesterday gave Joseph Kogut of Cuyler, N. Y., the bulk of Miss Margaret Jorgenson's $97,864 estate.

Angela Pistilli, pianist, made her debut in a recital at Town Hall last evening. A native of Brooklyn, Miss PistiIli has studied with Billie Cane of the New York School of Music, Hedy Spielter and, most recently, Paolo Gallico.
Basic national security requirements call for an immediate orderly replacement of the country's merchant fleet, Senator John M. Butler declared last night.

TRENTON, Nov. 12 -- New Jersey Republicans, in an eleventh-hour surprise move, today followed their Democratic opposition in seeking the legal right to recount all ballots cast in last week's Senatorial election.
Permit me to call your attention to fan especially unfortunate misstatement which found its way into your obituary notice on the late Edward C. Carter. I refer to the following passage:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- The Soviet Union asked today that the proposed international agency for developing the peaceful uses of atomic energy be placed under the United Nations Security Council, where the veto would be operative.
